{"sars": [{"archive_id": "3798112", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> SARS-like coronavirus - China: bats, pandemic potential", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3798112", "date": "2015-11-17 14:47:23", "main_text": "SARS-LIKE CORONAVIRUS - CHINA: BATS, PANDEMIC POTENTIAL\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 11 Nov 2015\nSource: Mail Online [edited]\nhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-3314247/New-SARS-like-virus-jump-directly-bats-humans-without-mutating-sparking-fears-future-epidemic.html\n\n\nNew SARS-like virus can 'jump directly from bats to humans without mutating, sparking fears of a future epidemic'.\n\nScientists have discovered a new virus, similar to SARS, that can jump from bats to humans, prompting fears of a future epidemic.\n\nThey warn there is no treatment for the virus, referred to as SHC014-CoV, which can cross the species divide without the need to mutate.\n\nBut, they caution, it is still not clear whether or not the disease has the ability to spread from human to human.\n\nSenior study author, Dr Ralph Baric, at the University of North Carolina, said: 'Studies have predicted the existence of nearly 5000 coronaviruses in bat populations and some of these have the potential to emerge as human pathogens. So this is not a situation of 'if' there will be an outbreak of one of these coronaviruses, but rather when and how prepared we'll be to address it.'\n\nResearchers said their discovery is notable, as it highlights an ongoing debate over the US government's decision to suspend all gain of function experiments on a variety of select agents, earlier this year [2015].\n\nThe move has put a substantial standstill on the development of vaccines or treatments for these pathogens should there be an outbreak.\n\nSARS, severe acute respiratory syndrome, first jumped from animals to humans in 2002 to 2003, triggering a worldwide outbreak with around 8000 cases being diagnosed, including one at the university's Chapel Hill location. Almost 800 people lost their lives during the outbreak.\n\nSARS-CoV presents much like flu symptoms, but can accelerate, compromising a person's breathing and lead to a deadly form of pneumonia.\n\nThe outbreak was controlled through public health interventions, and the original virus was thought to have been extinct since 2004.\n\nDr Baric and his team demonstrated that the newly-identified SARS-like virus, labelled SHC014-CoV, can jump from its host, Chinese horseshoe bats.\n\nThe virus latches on to the same receptor in the body as the SARS virus, allowing it to be transmitted across to humans.\n\nIn addition, the team discovered the new virus also replicates as well as SARS-CoV in primary human lung cells, the preferred target for infection.\n\nDr Baric, who works at the university's Gillings School of Global Public Health and is an expert in coronaviruses, added: 'This virus is highly pathogenic and treatments developed against the original SARS virus in 2002 and the ZMapp drugs used to fight Ebola fail to neutralise and control this particular virus.\n\n'So building resources, rather than limiting them, to both examine animal populations for new threats and develop therapeutics, is key for limiting future outbreaks.'\n\nThe findings are published in the journal Nature Medicine.\n\n[Byline: Lizzie Parry]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The finding is presented in the last issue of Nature Medicine http://www.nature.com/nm/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nm.3985.html.\n\nUsing metagenomic data showed that chimeric SHC014 viruses replicate in human airway cultures, cause pathogenesis in vivo, and escape current therapeutics. This work suggests a potential risk of a SARS-like pandemic that warrants preparedness efforts.\n\nHorseshoe bats (_Rhinolophus_ spp) were the source of SARS-CoV's, as is also the case for SHC014-CoV. All species are insectivorous, capturing insects in flight. - Mod.PMB\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155.]", "summary": "\n\nDr Baric, who works at the university's Gillings School of Global Public Health and is an expert in coronaviruses, added: 'This virus is highly pathogenic and treatments developed against the original SARS virus in 2002 and the ZMapp drugs used to fight Ebola fail to neutralise and control this particular virus. China: (HK SAR) Indonesian women, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=911202", "date": "2011-10-16 19:32:07", "main_text": "RUBELLA - CHINA: (HONG KONG SAR), INDONESIAN WOMEN, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Oct 2011\nSource: 7th Space InteractiveWeb [abbreviated & edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/397065/suspected_rubella_outbreak_involving_three_indonesians_investigated.html\n\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is\ninvestigating a suspected outbreak of rubella involving 3 Indonesian\ndomestic helpers who attended a church in Causeway Bay. The CHP\nreceived notification from Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital\nand private doctors about 3 rubella cases involving Indonesian\ndomestic helpers, aged 27, 32 and 34, respectively. Laboratory tests\non the 34-year-old patient's blood samples yielded a positive result\nfor rubella virus [infection]. All of them are in stable condition. No\nhospitalisation is needed.\n\nUpon epidemiological investigation, CHP found that the trio attended\nthe same church before and during the onset of symptoms. An operation\nwas mounted today (Sun 16 Oct 2011) in which a health talk was\ndelivered. Questionnaires were distributed to attendees to assess\nwhether there were other persons with infection. A spokesman for the\nCHP said: 'Immunisation was offered to those in need. The CHP has\nidentified 11 people with symptoms and conducted blood tests on\nthem.'\n\nThe spokesman explained that rubella infection, also known as 'German\nMeasles,' is a highly infectious disease caused by rubella virus. It\ncan be transmitted by contact with secretions from nose and pharynx of\ninfected persons through droplet spread or direct contact with\npatients from one week before to at least 4 days after the onset of\nsymptoms. Incubation ranges from 14 to 23 days. As for symptoms,\nchildren usually present with a diffuse rash and enlargement of lymph\nnodes, but adults may experience a 1-5 day history of low-grade fever,\nheadache, malaise, mild cough and conjunctivitis followed by a skin\nrash as in children.\n\nRubella infection also produces anomalies in the developing fetus,\nleading to congenital rubella syndrome, which is characterised by\ndeafness, eye lesions, heart malformations and mental retardation in\ninfants born to women who were infected during the 1st 3 months of\npregnancy. The spokesman said that immunisation with rubella vaccine\nis effective in preventing the disease. He urged those who are not\nimmunised, especially child-bearing-aged women, to check their\nimmunity status before pregnancy and receive rubella vaccine\naccordingly.\n\n--\nCommunicated by;\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[By August 2006, 117 countries had implemented rubella vaccines as\npart of their routine national vaccination programmes. However, many\ncountries in Asia, such as the Philippines, Cambodia, Indonesia, and\nViet Nam, have not introduced rubella vaccination into their national\nimmunization program. Therefore, rubella infection remains endemic in\nmany countries in Asia, and immigrants from these countries pose a new\nchallenge in the global effort to decrease rubella infections.\n(Ching-Chiang Lin, et al., Am J Trop Med Hyg January 2010 vol. 82 no.\n1 40-44 http://www.ajtmh.org/content/82/1/40.full). It is not stated\nwhen the 3 Indonesian domestic workers arrived in Hong Kong, but it\nseems likely that they had not been immunised previously and\ncontracted infection in Hong Kong. If any of the women are pregnant,\nthe outcome could be serious. Further information is requested. -\nMod.CP]\n\n[For the interactive HealthMap/ProMED map of Hong Kong, see\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1l5N. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "\n\nRubella infection also produces anomalies in the developing fetus,\nleading to congenital rubella syndrome, which is characterised by\ndeafness, eye lesions, heart malformations and mental retardation in\ninfants born to women who were infected during the 1st 3 months of\npregnancy. Evidence for SARS-CoV-2 related coronaviruses circulating in bats and pangolins in Southeast Asia. Nat Commun. 2021 Feb 9; 12(1): 972. doi: 10.1038/s41467-021-21240-1. PMID: 33563978\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nAmong the many questions unanswered for the COVID-19 pandemic are the origin of SARS-CoV-2 and the potential role of intermediate animal host(s) in the early animal-to-human transmission. The discovery of RaTG13 bat coronavirus in China suggested a high probability of a bat origin. Here we report molecular and serological evidence of SARS-CoV-2 related coronaviruses (SC2r-CoVs) actively circulating in bats in Southeast Asia. Whole genome sequences were obtained from 5 independent bats (_Rhinolophus acuminatus_) in a Thai cave yielding a single isolate (named RacCS203) which is most related to the RmYN02 isolate found in _R. malayanus_ in Yunnan, China. SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibodies were also detected in bats of the same colony and in a pangolin at a wildlife checkpoint in Southern Thailand. Antisera raised against the receptor binding domain (RBD) of RmYN02 was able to cross-neutralize SARS-CoV-2 despite the fact that the RBD of RacCS203 or RmYN02 failed to bind ACE2. Although the origin of the virus remains unresolved, our study extended the geographic distribution of genetically diverse SC2r-CoVs from Japan and China to Thailand over a 4800-km [about 2983 mi] range. Cross-border surveillance is urgently needed to find the immediate progenitor virus of SARS-CoV-2.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nMary Marshall\n<mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[_Rhinolophus_ species (horseshoe bats) were found to carry a diverse group of SARS-like coronaviruses and, thus, are thought to be the natural reservoirs of this group of viruses. The genome of SARS-CoV-2 shares approximately 80% and 96.2% nucleotide sequence identity with SARS-CoV and bat SL-CoV RaTG13, respectively. This high homology suggests that SARS-CoV-2 might have originated from bats. However, whether transmission from bats to humans was direct or through an intermediate animal host remains to be determined.\n\nPangolins are peculiar mammals of the order Pholidota, with only one extant taxonomic family, Manidae. There are 8 living species grouped in 3 genera. _Manis_ comprises the 4 species found in Asia, while _Phataginus_ and _Smutsia_ each include 2 species living in Sub-Saharan Africa.\n\nPangolins entered in the COVID-19 discussion when they were suggested as the possible source of infection for humans, acting as a bridge species which hypothetically exposed humans to a coronavirus that naturally circulates in bats of the genus _Rhinolophus_. This contention was based on genetic comparison of coronaviruses taken from pangolins and SARS-CoV-2 from humans (99% similar), and also on the affinity of SARS-like CoV for pangolin's receptors.\n\nMalayan pangolins (_Manis javanica_) confiscated from smugglers in China (collected in August 2017-January 2018) tested positive to coronaviruses closely related to SARS-CoV-2.\n\nAfrican pangolins were reported sharing burrows with bats, proving that at least those African species of pangolins and bats interact and therefore there is opportunity for pathogen exchange. Some _Rhinolophus_ species are known to use underground burrows, just like pangolins. During winter, _R. hipposideros_ can be found hibernating mainly in underground sites including cellars, small caves, and burrows. - Mod.PMB]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nMary Marshall\n<mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[_Rhinolophus_ species (horseshoe bats) were found to carry a diverse group of SARS-like coronaviruses and, thus, are thought to be the natural reservoirs of this group of viruses. However, whether transmission from bats to humans was direct or through an intermediate animal host remains to be determined.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-02-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Pholidota", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Yunnan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Smutsia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2580209", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> SARS-like coronavirus - China: (YN) antigenically related to SARS-CoV", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2580209", "date": "2014-07-01 17:45:38", "main_text": "SARS-LIKE CORONAVIRUS - CHINA: (YUNNAN), ANTIGENICALLY RELATED TO SARS-COV\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 30 Jun 2014\nSource: People's Daily online [edited]\nhttp://english.peopledaily.com.cn/n/2014/0630/c98649-8748648.html\n\n\nChina's Military Veterinary Institute of Military Medical Sciences has detected a new type of SARS-like coronavirus in the bats of Yunan Province [SARS is an acronym for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome].\n\nAnalysis shows that the virus can infect humans, and it may be the precursor of the SARS virus or a 'relative.' The discovery represents an important discovery in the hunt for the source of SARS. According to researcher Tu Changchun, bats carry more viruses than any other creature. 130 different strains [virus species] have been found. Although in recent years, many types of coronavirus have been found in bats, and it has gradually been established that bats are the natural host of SARS-like coronaviruses, there has been no evidence of transmission to human beings, and no evidence showing there are significant differences in the genetic structure of the virus. A new virus has now been found in Yunnan bats, and the genetic diversity of this new virus has been clarified. The research group also found that a rotavirus infecting bats in the region may be the cause of diarrhea among children in Southeast Asian countries.\n\nIn 2012, the Middle East reported an infectious disease caused by a new coronavirus: Middle East respiratory syndrome [virus]. The clinical manifestations are similar to SARS, causing a general panic similar to that accompanying the original SARS outbreak.\n\n[Byline: Shen Jifei]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The preceding news item was translated from a Chinese-language article and refers to a recent paper published in the Journal of Virology entitled 'Identification of diverse alphacoronaviruses and genomic characterization of a novel SARS-like coronavirus from bats in China.' By Biao He and 12 others at the China's Military Veterinary Institute of Military Medical Sciences.\n\nAbstract:\n'Although many severe acute respiratory syndrome-like coronaviruses (SARS-like CoVs) have been identified in bats in China, Europe and Africa, most have a genetic organization significantly distinct from human/civet cat SARS CoVs in the receptor-binding domain (RBD), which mediates receptor binding and determines the host spectrum, resulting in their failure to cause human infections and making them unlikely progenitors of human/civet SARS CoV.\n\nHere, a viral metagenomic analysis of 268 bat rectal swabs collected from 4 counties in Yunnan province has identified hundreds of sequences relating to alpha- and betacoronaviruses. Phylogenetic analysis based on a conserved region of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase gene revealed that alphacoronaviruses had diversities with some obvious differences from those reported previously. Full genomic analysis of a new SARS-like CoV from Baoshan (LYRa11) showed that it was 29 805 nt in length with 13 open reading frames (ORFs), sharing 91 percent nt identity with human/civet cat SARS CoVs and the most recently reported SARS-like CoV Rs3367, while 89 percent with other bat SARS-like CoVs. Notably, it showed highest sequence identity with the S gene of SARS CoVs and Rs3367, especially in the RBD region. Antigenic analysis showed that the S1 domain of LYRa11 could be efficiently recognized by SARS-convalescent human serum indicating that LYRa11 is a novel virus antigenically close to SARS CoV. Recombination analyses indicate that LYRa11 is likely a recombinant descended from parental lineages that had evolved into a number of bat SARS-like CoVs.'\n\nConclusion: The authors conclude that although many SARS-like coronaviruses (CoVs) have been discovered in bats worldwide, there are significantly different genomic structures, particularly in the S1 domain, which is responsible for host tropism determination, between bat SARS-like CoVs and human SARS CoVs, indicating that most reported bat SARS-like CoVs are not the progenitors of human SARS CoV. We have identified diverse alphacoronaviruses and a close relative (LYRa11) to SARS CoV in bats collected in Yunnan, China. Further analysis showed that alpha- and betacoronaviruses have different circulation and transmission dynamics in bat populations. Notably, full genomic sequence and antigenic study demonstrated that LYRa11 is phylogenetically and antigenically closely related to SARS CoV. Recombination analyses indicate that LYRa11 is a recombinant from certain bat SARS-like CoVs circulating in Yunnan province.\n\nClearly, the coronavirus described above is closely related to the bat coronaviruses associated with SARS and MERS but is not directly responsible for these diseases. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/351.]", "summary": "\n\nConclusion: The authors conclude that although many SARS-like coronaviruses (CoVs) have been discovered in bats worldwide, there are significantly different genomic structures, particularly in the S1 domain, which is responsible for host tropism determination, between bat SARS-like CoVs and human SARS CoVs, indicating that most reported bat SARS-like CoVs are not the progenitors of human SARS Although many severe acute respiratory syndrome-like coronaviruses (SARS-like CoVs) have been identified in bats in China, Europe and Africa, most have a genetic organization significantly distinct from human/civet cat SARS CoVs in the receptor-binding domain (RBD), which mediates receptor binding and determines the host spectrum, resulting in their failure to cause human infections and making them unlikely progenitors of human/civet SARS CoV.\n\n Full genomic analysis of a new SARS-like CoV from Baoshan (LYRa11) showed that it was 29 805 nt in length with 13 open reading frames (ORFs), sharing 91 percent nt identity with human/civet cat SARS CoVs and the most recently reported SARS-like CoV Rs3367, while 89 percent with other bat SARS-like CoVs. A new virus has now been found in Yunnan bats, and the genetic diversity of this new virus has been clarified.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yunnan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Yunnan province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Baoshan", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Yunan Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "YUNNAN", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1038268", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Spotted fever rickettsiosis - China: HK SAR ex S. Africa", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1038268", "date": "2012-02-10 11:31:06", "main_text": "SPOTTED FEVER RICKETTSIOSIS - CHINA: HONG KONG SAR ex SOUTH AFRICA\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Feb 2012\nSource: Hong Kong New Yahoo [Trans. by submitter][edited]\nhttp://hk.news.yahoo.com/%E7%88%B6%E5%A5%B3%E5%9C%A8%E5%8D%97%E9%9D%9E%E8%A2%AB%E8%9D%A8%E5%92%AC%E6%84%9F%E6%9F%93%E6%96%91%E7%96%B9%E7%86%B1-054800787.html\n\n\nA father and his daughter have been confirmed to have spotted fever after traveling to South Africa.\n\nThe Centre for Health Protection indicated that the patients' family of 5 traveled to South Africa in December 2011. While there, the father and a daughter were bitten by ticks. On the 4th day upon returning to Hong Kong, the father complained of headache and had an eschar. The daughter was also found to have eschar[s?] and lymphadenopathy. They were seen by a private physician. Both are in stable condition after receiving treatment; no hospitalization is needed. Laboratory tests confirmed both to have been infected by spotted fever. The mother and another daughter also had similar but less severe symptoms. They have recovered after receiving treatment.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Angela Huang\n\n[Rickettsioses are causes of arthropod-borne human diseases, which can be roughly divided into typhus, scrub typhus and the spotted fever groups. In retrospect, it is surprising that, given the years that ProMED has been functioning, this is the 1st posting of a spotted fever group infection originating in Africa. This is the case despite Freedman, et al (1) reporting the spotted fever rickettsial diseases were the 2nd most common cause of fever in travelers returning from the developing world, after malaria but before dengue and typhoid fever.\n\nIn Africa, Mediterranean spotted fever had long been thought to be the predominant rickettsial disease caused by _R. conorii_. With the identification of _R. africae_ from patients with African tick bite fever in 1992 (2), it has been recognized that this disease is clearly the most prevalent cause of rickettsial infection in sub-Saharan Africa, and this disease is actually commonly reported in travelers returning from South Africa (3), particularly in those traveling to Kruger National Park. The literature contains a significant number of case reports documenting the acquisition of this infection in travelers and is represented by references 4-6. Reference 6 underscores one of the relevant physical findings of _R. africae_ infection, the presence of multiple, rather than one, eschars (lesions referred to a tache noir).\n\nThe CDC publication found at http://www.cdc.gov/otherspottedfever/ is a valuable reference listing the large number of spotted fever rickettsiae described throughout the world. The tables also include _R. aeschlimannii_ as a cause of spotted fever in southern Africa.\n\nIt is most likely that these cases described are due to _R. africae_ and are cases of African tick bite fever.\n\nReferences\n---------\n1. LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1EPe.] On the 4th day upon returning to Hong Kong, the father complained of headache and had an eschar. \n\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "dengue", "malaria"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-12-25 00:00:00", "1992-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "HONG KONG", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "LH", "country": "Guadeloupe"}, {"location": "South Africa", "country": "South Africa"}, {"location": "Hong", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Switzerland", "country": "Switzerland"}, {"location": "Equatorial Africa", "country": "Equatorial Guinea"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2032131", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> SARS-like coronavirus - China: (YN) horseshoe bats", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2032131", "date": "2013-10-31 14:12:24", "main_text": "SARS-LIKE CORONAVIRUS - CHINA: (YUNNAN) HORSESHOE BATS\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\nDate: Wed 30 Oct 2013\nSource: The Canadian Press [edited]\nhttp://www.canada.com/health/SARSlike+viruses+found+Chinese+bats+closest+hits+2003+outbreak+virus/9102750/story.html\n\n\nA consortium of international scientists has discovered a SARS-like virus recovered from a Chinese horseshoe bat, further solidifying the theory that these bats are the ultimate source of the virus that killed more than 900 people around the globe in 2003. The new virus, which they called WIV1, is the closest match yet between SARS [virus] and coronaviruses from bats. In fact, the viruses are close enough genetically that antibodies in stored blood samples from SARS patients neutralized the virus in 7 of 9 samples tested. The scientists also reported that the virus uses the same receptor -- called ACE2 -- to latch onto and infect cells that SARS [virus] does. In laboratory work, WIV1 was able to directly infect human cells. That, they suggested, means that viruses like this may not need an animal go-between to cause human outbreaks -- they may be able to jump directly from bats to people. 'Intermediate hosts many not be necessary for direct human infection by some bat SL-CoV [ SARS-like coronavirus],' they wrote in the paper, which is published in the journal Nature (see abstract reproduced in part [2] below).\n\nOther scientists, though, cautioned that just because something occurs in the artificial confines of a laboratory doesn't mean it would also happen readily in nature. 'We've known for a long time that bats carry all sorts of dangerous viruses. Yet we don't all die,' said Marion Koopmans, chief of virology in the Dutch National Institute of Public Health's Center for Infectious Disease Control. 'Cells in a test tube in the lab are very different from cells in a human host.' Koopmans said even if it isn't essential to have another animal serve as a bridge -- the way infected civet cats did in Chinese animal markets during SARS -- it may remain more likely that bat viruses might take an indirect route into the human population. 'It may not be essential to have an in-between host, but it may be that if bats carry viruses that easily infect intermediate hosts, that their ability to get to humans is much greater,' she said.\n\nMichael Osterholm, Director of the Center for Infectious Diseases Research and Policy at the University of Minnesota, said a factor that needs to be considered is how bat viruses could come in contact with human cells. In other words, what body fluid from the bat -- saliva, urine, feces, blood -- carries and therefore can transmit the virus? 'If the primary body fluid involved with transmitting (bat) coronaviruses to other animal species or humans in feces, the question becomes: How often is that likely to occur?' Osterholm asked.\n\nPeter Daszak, co-senior author of the paper, said it is true that this type of viral species jump is uncommon. But he said as humans encroach on the habitat of bats and other wild species, the risk rises. 'There are many, many thousands of people -- millions -- in China who live close to bats. The problem is that we're doing things that put us at risk. We're increasingly catching bats, bringing them into the wildlife (meat) trade, and eating them globally,'' said Daszak, a disease ecologist who is president of the conservation group Ecohealth Alliance. 'So yes, the risk is low. But actually, multiply that by billions of people and multiply it by an increasing annual encroachment into forest and an increasing connectivity with wildlife, and the risk grows.'\n\nThe finding resulted from work done in China's Yunnan Province. The scientists gathered feces and collected fecal swabs from horseshoe bats over the course of 12 months from April 2011 and September 2012. Of 117 samples, 23 per cent were positive for coronaviruses. Genetic sequencing of RNA from the samples showed evidence of 7 different strains of coronaviruses. The scientists were able to generate genetic sequences for 2, which were a 95 per cent match for a SARS virus known as Tor2. (Its name indicates it was isolated from a Toronto SARS patient.) But WIV1 was the only live virus they were able to extract from the material. Daszak said this is the 1st time, to his knowledge, that has occurred. They tested the virus to see if it could grow in a wide variety of different types of cells from different species -- human respiratory tract and pig kidney cells among them. The virus grew in a surprising number, though not all.\n\nGerman coronavirus expert Christian Drosten was involved in a study published last year [2013] that showed the MERS coronavirus -- a SARS cousin -- had a similar ability to infect cells from a diverse number of animal species. At the time, Drosten and his co-authors reported this was a rare feature of MERS, which is the virus behind the ongoing outbreak in the Middle East. Drosten said seeing similar behaviour in this new virus suggests some coronaviruses probably pose more of a risk to humans than others because they have more potential to jump species. 'Here we have a big challenge for future research: to discriminate those potentially dangerous viruses from those that are ... most likely harmless because they are restricted to their hosts,' Drosten said in an email.\n\nThe [research] was carried out by scientists from the Wuhan Institute of Virology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Ecohealth Alliance, the University of California, Davis, the CSIRO [Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation] Australian Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong, East China Normal University at Shanghai, and Duke-NUS Graduate Medical School in Singapore.]\n\n[Byline: Helen Branswell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 30 Oct 2013\nSource: Nature journal [edited]\nhttp://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature12711.html\n\n[Ref: Ge XY, Li JL, Yang XL, et al: Isolation and characterization of a bat SARS-like coronavirus that uses the ACE2 receptor. Nature (2013) doi:10.1038/nature12711]\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nAbstract\n--------\nThe 2002-3 pandemic caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) was one of the most significant public health events in recent history. An ongoing outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus suggests that this group of viruses remains a key threat and that their distribution is wider than previously recognized. Although bats have been suggested to be the natural reservoirs of both viruses, attempts to isolate the progenitor virus of SARS-CoV from bats have been unsuccessful. Diverse SARS-like coronaviruses (SL-CoVs) have now been reported from bats in China, Europe, and Africa, but none is considered a direct progenitor of SARS-CoV because of their phylogenetic disparity from this virus and the inability of their spike proteins to use the SARS-CoV cellular receptor molecule, the human angiotensin converting enzyme II (ACE2).\n\nHere we report whole-genome sequences of 2 novel bat coronaviruses from Chinese horseshoe bats (family: _Rhinolophidae_) in Yunnan, China: RsSHC014 and Rs3367. These viruses are far more closely related to SARS-CoV than any previously identified bat coronaviruses, particularly in the receptor binding domain of the spike protein. Most importantly, we report the 1st recorded isolation of a live SL-CoV (bat SL-CoV-WIV1) from bat faecal samples in Vero E6 cells, which has typical coronavirus morphology, 99.9 per cent sequence identity to Rs3367 and uses ACE2 from humans, civets, and Chinese horseshoe bats for cell entry. Preliminary in vitro testing indicates that WIV1 also has a broad species tropism.\n\nOur results provide the strongest evidence to date that Chinese horseshoe bats are natural reservoirs of SARS-CoV, and that intermediate hosts may not be necessary for direct human infection by some bat SL-CoVs. They also highlight the importance of pathogen-discovery programs targeting high-risk wildlife groups in emerging disease hotspots as a strategy for pandemic preparedness.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A photograph of a Chinese horseshoe bat can be seen at http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/sites/default/files/public/styles/ss_media_popup/public/media/article/horseshoe_bat-flickr.jpg?itok=QVyS7C4_.\n\nGenome sequencing revealed that 2 of these novel viruses are more closely related to the SARS-CoV than any virus seen before. One infectious isolate was obtained which could be propagated in cell culture, and its receptor binding properties established and the receptor identified as the angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptor, which is mainly found in pneumocytes, deep in human lungs.\n\nThe authors conclude that Chinese horseshoe bats are natural reservoirs of SARS-CoV and that intermediate hosts may not be necessary for direct human infection by some bat SARS-like coronaviruses. This virus, however, is not the SARS-CoV.\n\nThe ongoing outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus suggests that other bat-derived coronaviruses remain a threat and that their distribution may be wider than previously recognised. Furthermore, that they may not require adaptation in an intermediate host prior to human infection. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/7dum.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n[1]\n \n\nGerman coronavirus expert Christian Drosten was involved in a study published last year [2013] that showed the MERS coronavirus -- a SARS cousin -- had a similar ability to infect cells from a diverse number of animal species. media report\n\n******\n[1] Pneumonia of unknown cause - WHO 5 Jan 2020\nDate: 5 Jan 2020\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News, 5 Jan 2019 [edited]\nhttps://www.who.int/csr/don/05-january-2020-pneumonia-of-unkown-cause-china/en/\n\n\nOn [31 Dec 2019], the WHO China Country Office was informed of cases of pneumonia of unknown etiology (unknown cause) detected in Wuhan City, Hubei Province of China. As of [3 Jan 2020], a total of 44 patients with pneumonia of unknown etiology have been reported to WHO by the national authorities in China. Of the 44 cases reported, 11 are severely ill, while the remaining 33 patients are in stable condition. According to media reports, the concerned market in Wuhan was closed on [1 Jan 2020] for environmental sanitation and disinfection.\n\nThe causal agent has not yet been identified or confirmed. On [1 Jan 2020], WHO requested further information from national authorities to assess the risk.\n\nNational authorities report that all patients are isolated and receiving treatment in Wuhan medical institutions. The clinical signs and symptoms are mainly fever, with a few patients having difficulty in breathing, and chest radiographs showing invasive lesions of both lungs.\n\nAccording to the authorities, some patients were operating dealers or vendors in the Huanan Seafood market. Based on the preliminary information from the Chinese investigation team, no evidence of significant human-to-human transmission and no health care worker infections have been reported.\n\nPublic Health Response\nNational authorities have reported the following response measures:\n- 121 close contacts have been identified and are under medical observation;\n- The follow-up of close contacts is ongoing;\n- Pathogen identification and the tracing of the cause are underway;\n- Wuhan Municipal Health Commission carried out active case finding, and retrospective investigations have been completed;\n- Environmental sanitation and further hygiene investigations are underway.\n\nWHO is closely monitoring the situation and is in close contact with national authorities in China.\n\nWHO risk assessment\nThere is limited information to determine the overall risk of this reported cluster of pneumonia of unknown etiology. The reported link to a wholesale fish and live animal market could indicate an exposure link to animals. The symptoms reported among the patients are common to several respiratory diseases, and pneumonia is common in the winter season; however, the occurrence of 44 cases of pneumonia requiring hospitalization clustered in space and time should be handled prudently.\n\nWuhan city, with a population of 19 million, is the capital city of Hubei province, with a population of 58 million people. WHO has requested further information on the laboratory tests performed and the differential diagnoses considered.\n\nWHO advice\nBased on information provided by national authorities, WHO's recommendations on public health measures and surveillance of influenza and severe acute respiratory infections still apply.\n\nWHO does not recommend any specific measures for travellers. In case of symptoms suggestive of respiratory illness either during or after travel, travellers are encouraged to seek medical attention and share travel history with their healthcare provider.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions on China based on the current information available on this event.\n\nFor more information:\n\nInfection prevention and control of epidemic-and pandemic prone acute respiratory infections in health care, WHO guidelines: (https://www.who.int/csr/bioriskreduction/infection_control/publication/en/)\nWuhan Municipal Health Commission briefing on the pneumonia epidemic situation, 31 Dec 2019 (in Mandarin): http://wjw.wuhan.gov.cn/front/web/showDetail/2019123108989\nWuhan Municipal Health Commission briefing on the pneumonia epidemic situation 3 Jan 2020 (in Mandarin): http://wjw.wuhan.gov.cn/front/web/showDetail/2020010309017.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Wuhan Municipal Health and Health Committee's Report on Unexplained Viral Pneumonia\nDate: 5 Jan 2020\nSource: Wuhan Public Health Commission Press Release [machine trans. edited]\nhttp://wjw.wuhan.gov.cn/front/web/showDetail/2020010509020\n\n\nWuhan Municipal Health and Health Committee's Report on Unexplained Viral Pneumonia\nIssuing authority: Wuhan City health committee | Published: 2020-01-05 20:33:24\n\nSince [31 Dec 2019], our committee has carried out search and retrospective investigation of viral pneumonia cases of unknown cause in the city. As of 8:00 on [5 Jan 2020], a total of 59 patients with unexplained diagnosis of viral pneumonia were reported in our city, including 7 critically ill patients, and the remaining patients' overall vital signs were stable. At present, all patients are being isolated in medical institutions in Wuhan Treatment with no deaths. Among the 59 patients, the earliest onset of the case was [12 Dec 2019], and the latest onset was [29 Dec 2019]; 163 close contacts have been followed up for medical observation, and the follow-up of close contacts is still in progress.\n\nAn epidemiological survey showed that some patients were operating households in Wuhan South China Seafood City (South China Seafood Wholesale Market). As of now, preliminary investigations have shown no clear evidence of human-to-human transmission and no medical staff infections. Respiratory pathogens such as influenza, avian influenza, adenovirus, infectious atypical pneumonia (SARS) and the Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) have been excluded. Pathogen identification and cause tracing are still underway.\n\nAt present, with the support of the state and Hubei Province, Wuhan has adopted the following main prevention and control measures:\n- 1st, to treat patients with all its strength.\n- The 2nd is to carry out isolation treatment for all cases.\n- The 3rd is to continue to conduct relevant case searches and retrospective investigations in medical institutions throughout the city.\n- The 4th is to carry out close contact tracking seriously, implement medical observation on the close contacts that have been tracked according to regulations, and have not found any abnormal symptoms such as fever.\n- 5th, we will take measures to suspend the market for South China Seafood City and carry out environmental sanitation and further hygiene investigations.\n- 6th, actively carry out epidemiological investigations.\n- 7th, cooperate with the state and province to carry out pathogen identification (including nucleic acid detection and virus isolation and cultivation) and trace the cause, and prevention and control work is proceeding in an orderly manner.\n\nExperts suggest that the city is currently in the season of high incidence of infectious diseases in winter and spring. Citizens should pay attention to maintaining indoor air circulation to avoid closed and airless public places and crowded places. Wear masks when necessary. If you have fever, respiratory infection symptoms, especially persistent fever, go to a medical institution in time.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n******\n[3] Singapore suspected case, RSV [Respiratory Syncytial Virus) identified - media report\nDate: 4 Jan 2020\nSource: Straits Times [edited]\nhttps://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/wuhan-pneumonia-first-suspect-case-identified-here\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health said on Saturday [4 Jan 2020] that it had been notified of the 1st suspected case of the mystery Wuhan virus here, involving a 3-year-old girl from China who had pneumonia and a travel history to the Chinese city of Wuhan. She had been warded for further assessment and treatment, and isolated as a precautionary measure, said the ministry.\n\nCountries have grown concerned over a viral outbreak in Wuhan marked by unusual cases of pneumonia. These appear to be linked to a wholesale seafood market there, where not just seafood is sold, but also live animals, including, reportedly, birds and snakes, and the organs of rabbits and other wildlife.\n\nAt least 44 people had been affected there; and 11 were seriously ill, raising the spectre of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), which hit Singapore hard in 2003.\n\nSingapore has started temperature screening for passengers arriving from the city at Changi Airport, and doctors are on the lookout for possible cases. Experts, however, say that there have been no reports of human-to-human transmission, which means much less risk to the public.\n\nThe girl in Singapore was in stable condition, MOH said, without giving details on how the case had been uncovered.\n\nIt noted that she had not visited the Huanan seafood wholesale market in Wuhan associated with the cluster of pneumonia cases.\n\nPreliminary tests also showed that she was positive for respiratory syncytial virus, MOH added, which is a common cause of childhood pneumonia.\n\nInvestigations are ongoing to confirm this as the cause.\n\nCoordinating Minister for Infrastructure and the Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan said on Saturday [4 Jan 2020] that Singapore is monitoring the pneumonia situation in Wuhan closely.\n\n'There is no evidence of person-to-person transmission so will likely be just a normal fever outbreak,' he wrote in a Facebook post. 'But after SARS in 2003, we cannot be complacent.'\n\nThere are 2 airlines connecting directly to Wuhan, he said: Scoot and Urumqi Airlines, and the 1st temperature screening at T1 for a Scoot flight, an uneventful one, was done on Saturday morning [4 Jan 2020].\n\n-\nCommunicated by:\nJohn Cathey <jt.cathey@gmail.com>\n\n******\n[4] Hong Kong 8 more suspected cases, none with 'unidentified strain' - media report\nDate: 5 Jan 2020\nSource: South China Morning Post [edited]\nhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3044723/six-more-hong-kong-patients-hospitalised-over\n\n\nAuthorities in Wuhan announced on Sunday [5 Jan 2020] that 59 people had been admitted to hospital with an unidentified form of pneumonia, up from 44 on Friday [3 Jan 2020], while 9 more patients were found with fever or respiratory symptoms after returning to Hong Kong from the city in central China.\n\nIn Singapore, the Ministry of Health earlier said it had been informed of a suspected case, involving a 3-year-old girl from China who had pneumonia and a history of travel to Wuhan.\n\nHealth authorities in the mainland city said on Sunday [5 Jan 2020] night that the virus was not severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) or MERS (Middle East respiratory syndrome) but that a final identification of the strain was still in progress.\n\nAlthough the total number of infections had increased, there were fewer people in serious condition, falling to 7 from 11, according to a statement on the website of the Wuhan Municipal Commission. At least 163 people who had been in close contact with those infected were placed under medical observation. A seafood market in the Hubei province city was the site of the outbreak.\n\nThe authorities had previously ruled out common flu, avian flu, adenovirus infection and other common respiratory diseases. Further laboratory tests and investigations were underway.\n\nThe commission added that a preliminary investigation found no evidence of human-to-human transmission, and none of the medical staff had been infected. Some of the patients are vendors at the same seafood market, which has already been shut down and sanitised, it said.\n\nHong Kong's Centre for Health Protection (CHP) said public hospitals had admitted 8 more patients, including a boy, 9, and a 2-year-old girl, in the 24 hours to noon on Sunday [5 Jan 2020] with fever, respiratory infection or pneumonia symptoms who had also been to Wuhan in the past 14 days. At least 7 of them confirmed that they had not been to any wet market there.\n\nThe patients were all in stable condition. Apart from the 2 children, the other new cases reported involved 4 men and 2 women, aged between 22 and 55. The 9-year-old boy, who was seen by a private doctor, was the latest suspected case revealed.\n\nAll patients were quarantined and being treated in Queen Elizabeth, Princess Margaret, Ruttonjee, Tseung Kwan O and United Christian hospitals. Four were confirmed to have flu or other related illnesses, while the others were waiting for test results.\n\nMeanwhile, Chinese University's student union said a 20-year-old female student residing in a United College dormitory was hospitalised for suspected pneumonia symptoms. It was understood she had travelled to Wuhan \u00adrecently. A university spokeswoman said the student returned to Hong Kong on [29 Dec 2019] and developed symptoms on Saturday [4 Jan 2020]. She and her roommate were sent to hospital for further checks.\n\nThat takes the total number of suspected cases reported in the city to 17. But, of 8 other cases reported by Saturday [4 Jan 2020] evening, none of the patients were found to have the unidentified strain. The Hospital Authority said at least 5 people among all those identified as suspected cases had been discharged from hospital.\n\n'The [Hong Kong] government has been continuously in close contact with the relevant mainland authorities for the latest updates ... people are also reminded not to visit the wet market or eat wild animals when travelling,' Secretary for Food and Health Sophia Chan Siu-chee said.\n\nChan also said local authorities had adopted an active response to the incident. The health minister visited the infectious disease centre at Princess Margaret Hospital on Saturday [4 Jan 2020] and discussed response policies with medical staff.\n\nA new response mechanism for infectious diseases was launched by the Hong Kong government on Saturday [4 Jan 2020], and it was set to a 'serious' level, the 2nd on a 3-tier scale beginning with an alert and ending with an emergency declared at its peak. Doctors are required to report patient cases with fever and acute respiratory symptoms or pneumonia symptoms who had visited Wuhan within 14 days before the onset of the illness, whether or not they had visited any wet markets or seafood markets there.\n\nWuhan authorities announced on Friday [3 Jan 2020] that 44 people had been admitted to hospital with the unidentified virus, up from 27 on Tuesday [31 Jan 2020]. Professor David Hui Shu-cheong, a Chinese University respiratory medicine expert, believed the new cases might not have a direct connection with the wet market in Wuhan, but it was necessary to isolate the patients as a precaution. Hui also said the government should consider further strengthening screening measures on travellers from Wuhan, especially if there were possible risks of a community outbreak there. 'For instance, [the government] can install extra screening facilities on the platforms at the West Kowloon high-speed rail terminus. If there are any passengers who have been to Wuhan, they should be screened,' he said.\n\nOn Saturday [4 Jan 2020], a voluntary lane at the West Kowloon terminus dedicated for travellers from Wuhan was unused, even as passengers got off a train that had stopped in the city. Chan said while not all passengers on trains that stopped in Wuhan had necessarily visited the city, the government would continue to liaise with personnel at each boundary control point to step up quarantine measures.\nIn a statement issued late on Sunday [5 Jan 2020], the Centre for Health Protection said it had received notification from the mainland's National Health Commission on the latest information about the Wuhan cases.\n\n'While the causative pathogen and cause of infection are still under investigation, respiratory pathogens including influenza viruses, avian influenza viruses, adenovirus, Severe acute respiratory syndrome [SARS] and Middle East respiratory syndrome have been ruled out,' it said.\n\n'According to the risk assessment of the World Health Organisation, the reported link of this cluster of pneumonia of unknown aetiology to a wholesale fish and live animal market could indicate an exposure link to animals.' Macau has reported 4 cases of patients who had recently been to Wuhan and developed suspected pneumonia symptoms, but all have been confirmed to be flu or other common viruses.\n\nMeanwhile, as flu season approaches its peak between January and March 2020, Chan said about 1.15 million doses of flu vaccination had been administered since last October [2019], according to figures by the Department of Health, nearly an 18 per cent increase year on year and a rise especially among children. The health minister said flu activity was still below baseline level, but also noted that flu vaccination rates among people aged 50 to 64 was not as satisfactory despite the government previously rolling out a subsidy scheme targeting the group.\n\n[Byline: Chan Ho-him and Jun Mai]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[First, our thanks go to subscribers for submitting multiple sources of information providing the current updates. SAR, Norway, D222G mutation", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=407619", "date": "2010-04-09 13:00:03", "main_text": "INFLUENZA PANDEMIC (H1N1) (29): HONG KONG SPECIAL ADMINISTRATIVE\nREGION, NORWAY, D222G MUTATION\n***********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Hong Kong SAR\n[2] Norway\n\n******\n[1] Hong Kong SAR\nDate: Thu 8 Apr 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 15, Issue 14 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19534>\n\n\nLetter: Association of D222G substitution in haemagglutinin of 2009\npandemic influenza A (H1N1) with severe disease\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe preferential binding of influenza virus to sialic acid-alpha2,3-\ngalactose (alpha2,3 receptor) or sialic acid-alpha2,6-galactose\n(alpha2,6 receptors) may determine its tropism as alpha2,3 and\nalpha2,6 receptors are dominant on lower and upper respiratory cells\nrespectively [1]. The recent glycan microarray analysis suggested\nthat the haemagglutinin (HA) D222G substitution could cause a shift\nfrom alpha2,6 receptors to the mixed alpha2,3/alpha2,6 receptors\nspecificity which might increase binding to alpha2,3 receptors [2]\nand contribute to severity of disease. This substitution in the HA\ngene has been reported in samples of viruses obtained from cases with\nmild to severe illness from around 20 countries, areas and\nterritories [3]. A recent study from Norway has evaluated the\nclinical relevance of this substitution with severe and mild cases [4].\n\nIn an attempt to understand the relevance of HA D222G substitution\namong pandemic influenza A (H1N1) causing infections in Hong Kong, HA\ngene sequences from respiratory specimens and virus isolates of\nsevere and non-severe cases were examined. Cases were individuals who\nhad laboratory confirmed pandemic H1N1 influenza virus by either\nviral culture or reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) of respiratory\nspecimens [5]. The severe cases were individuals classified by the\nattending physician as being in a serious or critical condition.\n\nFrom 1 May 2009 to 31 Jan 2010, 458 respiratory samples were\nexamined. Of 219 severe cases, nine (4.1 percent) showed D222G\nsubstitution while none of the 239 non-severe cases showed D222G\nsubstitution. Four of the nine cases died. The association of D222G\nwith severe disease was statistically significant (p=0.002, Fisher's\nexact test, doubled one-sided). Other substitutions, of D222N (severe\ncases, n=3; non-severe cases, n=1) and D222E (only in non-severe\ncases, n=4) were also found. The 1st severe case appeared on 6 July\n2009 and D222G substitution was detected in July, September, November\nand December of the same year (These data are tabulated in the\noriginal publication, to which interest readers are referred).\n\nNo distinct phylogenetic clusterings of the severe cases with D222G\nsubstitution have been observed (data not shown). To put this in\nperspective, from July 2009 to January 2010, the accumulated severe\ncases were 244 while the number of isolates in our laboratory was 25\n625. Priority of analysis has been given to severe cases over\nnon-severe cases, with 90 percent and 1 percent of cases analysed respectively.\n\nInfluenza is an RNA virus which evolves rapidly, frequently changing\nsurface structures. A recent study at the United States (US) Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported 14 cases with D222G\nsubstitution found only in virus isolates but not in the original\nclinical specimens [3]. We observed similar finding with one\nnon-severe case showing D222G substitution in a virus isolate but not\nin the original clinical specimen, however, for the other 9 severe\ncases, we detected D222G substitution in both the virus isolate and\noriginal specimen. Similar to the Norwegian study, we also found\nmixed 222G and 222D in some severe cases [4]. Although experiments\nwith ferrets did not support a causal link of D222G substitution with\nvirulence [3], further study is warranted to elucidate the intriguing\nrelationship between D222G substitution and severe disease.\n\nReferences\n----------\n(1) Shinya K, Ebina M, Yamada S, Ono M, Kasai N, Kawaoka Y. Avian\nflu: influenza virus receptors in the human airway. Nature.\n2006;440(7083): 435-6.\n(2) Stevens J, Blixt O, Glaser L, Taubenberger JK, Palese P, Paulson\nJC, et al. Glycan microarray analysis of the hemagglutinins from\nmodern and pandemic influenza viruses reveals different receptor\nspecificities. J Mol Biol. 2006;355(5):1143-55.\n(3) World Health Organization. Preliminary review of D222G amino acid\nsubstitution in the haemagglutinin of pandemic influenza A(H1N1) 2009\nviruses. Wkly Epidemiol Rec. 2010;85(4):21-2 [English, French].\n(4) Kilander A, Rykkvin R, Dudman S, Hungnes O. Observed association\nbetween the HA1 mutation D222G in the 2009 pandemic influenza A(H1N1)\nvirus and severe clinical outcome, Norway 2009-2010. Euro Surveill.\n2010;15(9) pii=19498. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19498>\n(5) Cheng PK, Wong KK, Mak GC, Wong AH, Ng AY, Chow SY, et al.\nPerformance of laboratory diagnostics for the detection of influenza\nA(H1N1)v virus as correlated with the time after symptom onset and\nviral load. J Clin Virol. 2010;47(2):180-5.\n\n[Reported by: G C Mak1, K W Au1, L S Tai1, K C Chuang1, K C Cheng1, T\nC Shiu1, W Lim 1\nAt: 1 Centre for Health Protection, Department of Health, Hong Kong SAR]\n\n******\n[2] Norway\nDate: Thu 8 Apr 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 15, Issue 14 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19535>\n\n\nReply: Association of D222G substitution in haemagglutinin of 2009\npandemic influenza A (H1N1) with severe disease\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nWe appreciate the response to our paper [see ProMED-mail references\nbelow] made by Dr. Mak and colleagues, whose data from Hong Kong SAR\nappear to be in good agreement with what we have seen in Norway.\n\nIn our original study, we observed a significantly higher frequency\nof D222G in patients with severe outcomes (including fatal) compared\nto patients with mild disease. In fact, in both our data set and the\nHong Kong data, mutant viruses were not found among several hundred\nmild cases. Furthermore, as can be seen from our published data, the\nfrequency may be higher also in fatal outcomes (8 of 27 cases) versus\nsevere non-fatal outcomes (3 of 34 cases). Comparing these\nfrequencies results in p=0.078 with Fisher's exact test (2-sided) and\np=0.046 with the Mid-P Exact test (2-sided). It would be interesting\nto know if the new data from Hong Kong SAR can corroborate this\nobservation. Mak et al. report 4 fatal D222G cases and 5 non-fatal\nsevere D222G cases, but one would also need to know the total number\nof fatal cases versus non-fatal severe cases analysed to make the\ncomparison. Hopefully, this information can be obtained.\n\nD222G substitution in virus isolates only and not in the original\nclinical specimens was found in one case in Hong Kong and 14 cases\nreported by the United States (US) Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention [1]. We have also seen this virus culture artifact in one\ncase with mild disease. This case was counted as wild type in our\ndata set. This further underscores the importance to perform the\nsequence analysis of the primary specimen.\n\nThe frequency of D222G mutant viruses in the severe cases is somewhat\nlower in the Hong Kong data, compared to ours (4.1 percent in Hong\nKong data versus 18 percent in our data set). Whilst this difference\nmay represent a real variation in frequency, it may also arise from a\ndifferent composition of cases; e.g., if the proportion of fatal\ncases were higher in the Norwegian sample of severe plus fatal cases.\nMak and colleagues also observed, as we did, that the 222G mutant\nsometimes occurs in a mixture with non-mutated 222D genomes.\n\nSensitivity of detection of mutant viral genomes when occurring as\nthe minority variant in such mixtures may thus also influence the\nobserved frequency. We have been using a pyrosequencing assay to\nidentify the 222 genotype. Under ideal conditions this methodology\ncan reliably detect and quantitate a mutant when present in the total\nvirus population at levels as low as 10 percent [2]. However, in our\ndata set the initial finding of D222G mutants by pyrosequencing could\nuniformly be verified by conventional sequencing. Therefore, since\nthe Hong Kong data come from a study focusing on this particular\nposition we assume that the methodology difference is not likely to\nhave caused the different frequencies in the 2 data sets. In the\noverall global data, however, it is possible that some cases with\nmutant/wild type mixtures have been overlooked and only the majority\nsequence recorded.\n\nReferences\n----------\n[1] World Health Organization. Preliminary review of D222G amino acid\nsubstitution in the haemagglutinin of pandemic influenza A(H1N1) 2009\nviruses. Wkly Epidemiol Rec. 2010;85(4):21-2. [English, French].\n[2] Lackenby A, Democratis J, Siqueira MM, Zambon MC. Rapid\nquantitation of neuraminidase inhibitor drug resistance in influenza\nvirus quasispecies. Antivir Ther. 2008;13(6):809-20.\n\n[Reported by: A Kilander1, R Rykkvin1, S G Dudman1, O Hungnes 1\nAt: Department of Virology\nNorwegian Institute of Public Health\nOslo, Norway]\n\n--\nCommunicated by;\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These data from the investigations in Hong Kong SAR and Norway are\nin agreement in that there is a good (but not absolute) correlation\nbetween the presence of the D222G substitution in the HA protein and\ndisease severity. It is suggested that this mutation may affect\ndisease severity by causing a shift in virus binding from alpha2,6\nreceptors to mixed alpha2,3/alpha2,6 receptors in the respiratory\ntract. These are interesting observations. However, it has been\nobserved also in these studies, and independently, that the D222G\nsubstitution may be present also in virus isolates (i.e., virus\npropagated in culture) only and not detectable in the original\nclinical specimens. Perhaps the H222G mutation occurs at high\nfrequency and is favored in rapidly replicating virus either in\nculture or in severely affected patients? - Mod.CP]", "summary": "We observed similar finding with one\nnon-severe case showing D222G substitution in a virus isolate but not\nin the original clinical specimen, however, for the other 9 severe\ncases, we detected D222G substitution in both the virus isolate and\noriginal specimen. Other substitutions, of D222N (severe\ncases, n=3; non-severe cases, n=1) and D222E (only in non-severe\ncases, n=4) were also found. Of 219 severe cases, nine (4.1 percent) showed D222G\nsubstitution while none of the 239 non-severe cases showed D222G\nsubstitution. INFLUENZA PANDEMIC (H1N1) (29): HONG KONG SPECIAL ADMINISTRATIVE\nREGION, NORWAY, D222G MUTATION\n***********************************************************************************************\n Furthermore, as can be seen from our published data, the\nfrequency may be higher also in fatal outcomes (8 of 27 cases) versus\nsevere non-fatal outcomes (3 of 34 cases). The frequency of D222G mutant viruses in the severe cases is somewhat\nlower in the Hong Kong data, compared to ours (4.1 percent in Hong\nKong data versus 18 percent in our data set). Observed association\nbetween the HA1 mutation D222G in the 2009 pandemic influenza A(H1N1)\nvirus and severe clinical outcome, Norway 2009-2010. \n\nIn our original study, we observed a significantly higher frequency\nof D222G in patients with severe outcomes (including fatal) compared\nto patients with mild disease. In fact, in both our data set and the\nHong Kong data, mutant viruses were not found among several hundred\nmild cases. "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-07-06 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2010-01-31 00:00:00", "2009-07-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "HONG KONG SPECIAL ADMINISTRATIVE \n REGION",
