"country": "unknown"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7565035", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> COVID-19 update (312): China, SARS-CoV2 origin, animal reservoir, WHO mission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7565035", "date": "2020-07-11 21:34:36", "main_text": "CORONAVIRUS DISEASE 2019 UPDATE (312): CHINA, SARS-COV-2 ORIGIN, ANIMAL RESERVOIR, WHO MISSION\n**********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Jul 2020\nSource: Science Magazine - News [edited]\nhttps://www.sciencemag.org/news/2020/07/who-led-mission-may-investigate-pandemic-s-origin-here-are-key-questions-ask\n\n\nThe 2-person team from the World Health Organization (WHO) traveling to China today [10 Jul 2020] to address the origin of the COVID-19 pandemic is unlikely to come home with answers. Rather, the duo -- an epidemiologist and an animal health expert whose names have not been released -- will discuss with Chinese officials the scope of a larger international mission later, according to a WHO statement.\n\nBut this initial trip offers real hope that the mystery of the virus' origins, which has become a political powder keg and the subject of countless conspiracy theories, will finally be investigated more thoroughly and transparently. (A similar WHO-led mission to examine how China was handling its fight against the virus, launched after weeks of diplomatic wrangling, returned in February [2020] with a surprising wealth of information) [comment 1].\n\n'Science must stay open to all possibilities' about the pandemic's origins, Mike Ryan, executive director of WHO's Health Emergencies Programme, said at a press conference on 7 Jul [2020]. 'We need to lay out a series of investigations that will get the answers that I'm sure the Chinese government, governments around the world, and ourselves really need in order to manage the risk going forward into the future.'\n\nQuestions range from hunting for animals that might harbor the virus to examining the possibility that it came from a laboratory. There are plenty of details to investigate, and it could be a long road. Origin riddles for other new infectious diseases often took years to solve, and the route to answers has involved wrong turns, surprising twists, technological advances, lawsuits, allegations of cover-ups, and high-level politics. Determining how a pathogen suddenly emerges in people requires a lot of sleuthing, but past successes offer clues of where to look for new insights, as do the few data points that now exist for SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19.\n\nThe initial, tidy origin story told by health officials in Wuhan during the 1st few weeks of January [2020] was that a cluster of people connected to a seafood market developed an unusual pneumonia, and that the outbreak stopped after the market was closed and disinfected. But confusion about the origin of the novel coronavirus identified in Wuhan patients arose when researchers published the 1st epidemiologic studies of the city's outbreak: 4 of the 1st 5 cases confirmed to have SARS-CoV-2 infections had no link to the market.\n\nSoon, other theories emerged. Some believe it's no coincidence that the city is host to the Wuhan Institute of Virology (WIV), home to leading bat coronavirus researcher Shi Zheng-Li. Her group, one of the 1st to isolate and sequence SARS-CoV-2, has trapped bats in the wild for 15 years, hunting for coronaviruses to help identify pandemic threats. In their 1st report about the new virus, the scientists described a bat coronavirus in their collection that was 96.2% similar to SARS-CoV-2 [comment 2].\n\nU.S. President Donald Trump early on endorsed speculation that the virus entered humans because of an accident at WIV. A more contentious theory is that the lab created the virus. (Researchers at the lab insist neither scenario has any merit, and evolutionary biologists elsewhere have argued the virus shows no evidence of having been engineered.)\n\nThe most popular hypothesis is that SARS-CoV-2 spread into humans from an intermediate host, an animal species susceptible to the virus that acted as a bridge between bats and humans. In the case of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), civets turned out to play that role for the responsible coronavirus. For Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), also a coronavirus disease, it quickly became clear camels were the culprit because highly similar viruses were found in the animals and people caring for them.\n\nChinese officials have reported conducting tests for SARS-CoV-2 at the Wuhan seafood market, but what they found remains sketchy. China's state-run news agency, Xinhua, said 'environmental samples' tested positive for the virus in a zone of the market that sold wildlife, but the report had no details about the results or even a list of the species for sale. Other studies have discovered similarities between SARS-CoV-2 and a coronavirus found in pangolins, an endangered species that eats ants, but the pangolin virus is more divergent genetically from SARS-CoV-2 than the closest bat virus, and there's no evidence pangolins or their scales -- used in traditional Chinese medicine -- were sold at the market.\n\nSo, assuming WHO's team and the Chinese government work out a deal for an international mission to study the pandemic's origins, where would it start? Here are some key questions that need answers.\n\n- What, exactly, did the studies of the Wuhan seafood market sample, and what did the researchers find? With SARS, which emerged in a person in China's Guangdong province in November 2002 -- but was not reported to WHO for 3 months -- extensive sampling of animals at marketplaces in the province found its virus in palm civets by October 2003.\n\n- Does more epidemiological data exist about the earliest cases than have been made public so far (such as in https://tinyurl.com/vssjprg and https://tinyurl.com/w5qfs4w)? Where had they traveled? Were they in contact with any animals? What interactions did they have with each other? Have antibody tests been done on any of their contacts? Do stored blood or tissue samples for any of their contacts exist that could show earlier infections?\n\nFor SARS, by June 2004, 14 months after the discovery of that virus, researchers had reported detailed epidemiological analyses of humans and animals: 39% of the earliest cases were food handlers, traders of live animals were 13 times more likely to have antibodies to the virus, and in that group, 72% handled civets. New interviews with the earliest COVID-19 cases could reveal surprising links between them. COVID-19 clusters, for example, have occurred among people who were dining and drinking together, gathering at religious services, and even playing mahjong.\n\n- How aggressively have Chinese researchers looked for SARS-CoV-2 in samples collected before the 1st known cases in Wuhan? Have they looked outside of Wuhan? How far back in time have they probed?\n\nHospitals and diagnostic labs sometimes store blood, nasal swabs, and tissue samples from patients, especially if they die from unexplained illnesses. Just such samples led to the realization that MERS, 1st recognized in Saudi Arabia in June 2012, had killed 2 people in Jordan in April of that year [2012]. Analyses of stored samples from those 2 people and blood sampling of others who became ill but survived that outbreak confirmed that they all had MERS. Scientists realized camels were the source of Middle East respiratory syndrome when highly similar viruses were found in the animals and people caring for them.\n\n- Can widespread screens be done of bats and other wild animal species thought to be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 and common in China, including primates, deer, and rodents? Animal feces or urine often contain genetic evidence of viruses. Shi's group at WIV has routinely found coronaviruses in fecal samples and nasal swabs of bats. The sampling of feces from chimpanzees in sub-Saharan Africa has greatly contributed to understandings of the origins of the HIV-1 epidemic, and the Nipah virus, which surfaced in Malaysian pig farmers in 1998, was found in flying bats 2 years later by sampling their urine and fruit that they had partially eaten.\n\n- Can widespread screening of susceptible domesticated animals provide clues to COVID-19's origin? AIDS researchers discovered that pet monkeys harbored a simian immunodeficiency virus that is closely linked to HIV-2, a less common variant that also infects people. Shi's group did a study of domesticated and feral cats in Wuhan and found SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in 15% of the 141 samples tested. No antibodies were found in samples taken before the Wuhan outbreak surfaced, but do veterinarians possibly have additional stored samples? Can more feral cats be tested? Cats, notably, have a thing for seafood, and the Wuhan market at least played a role in amplifying early spread.\n\n- Do stored samples from farmed animals exist? The genetic signature of the influenza virus that caused a pandemic in 2009 showed it clearly had a pig origin, but it wasn't until 2016 that researchers reported the likely location of farms in Mexico that raised the infected pigs. Their study found 58 influenza viruses in respiratory samples stored by a central lab that diagnosed sick pigs. In all, the samples came from 22 farms in 6 Mexican states taken between 2010 and 2014. Phylogenetic analyses allowed the researchers to work backward from the genetic sequences of the viruses they found and pinpoint 2 states that likely were the origin of the pandemic. The data further suggest the virus initially came to Mexico from pigs imported from Europe.\n\n- Can widespread screening take place of people in China who might come in contact with bats or other wildlife that harbor SARS-CoV-2? Peter Daszak of EcoHealth Alliance and Shi -- who had their funding from the National Institutes of Health cut in April [2020] after pressure from the White House -- published a study last year [2019] of blood taken from nearly 1500 people in Chinese provinces where bats carry SARS-related coronaviruses. They also interviewed people about their histories of illnesses and contact with animals. Only 9 people had evidence of being infected with a bat coronavirus, but as they noted, antibodies quickly wane. The team showed that spillovers from bats to humans occur routinely.\n\n- Do government health reports contain any information about possible COVID-19 cases that predate 1 Dec 2019, the 1st confirmed case of SARS-CoV-2 in the scientific literature? The South China Morning Post reported having seen 'government data' that a 55-year-old person from Hubei province had COVID-19 on 17 Nov [2019]. The article says 8 other cases of the disease occurred that month [November 2019]. Wuhan is Hubei's capital, but the government records did not specify where these people lived, the newspaper noted. It's possible the virus was first isolated from patients in Wuhan but emerged outside the city. The influenza virus that caused the pandemic in 2009 first was isolated in San Diego, California, not in Mexico, where it originated.\n\n- Are there stored samples from sewage plants in China that can be probed? Studies of stored sewage samples in Italy described in a press release from that country's National Institute of Health suggest SARS-CoV-2 was circulating there in December 2019, even before doctors noticed the 1st case in Wuhan. A study from Barcelona, Spain, posted on medRxiv and not peer reviewed, claims to have found SARS-CoV-2 in sewage samples from March 2019. These reports have not been independently confirmed and have been subject to much criticism, but that does not undermine the potential value of studying archival sewage samples for SARS-CoV-2.\n\n- What experiments with bat coronaviruses took place at WIV? This is the mother of all questions for those who suspect SARS-CoV-2 came out of the facility. Accidental lab releases do happen, and one even triggered a pandemic: An influenza strain that surfaced in 1977 was linked to strains in Russian labs collected 2 decades earlier.\n\n- Is it possible that somebody at WIV became infected with the virus and then passed it on to others outside the lab? It's unknown which bat viruses WIV has in its collection of samples and whether any of them infect humans. And a controversy surrounds the closest bat virus to SARS-CoV-2, which is called RaTG13. As Shi and co-workers reported, they only fully sequenced this virus after SARS-CoV-2 surfaced, and they looked through their database for potential relatives. (The group often sequences only one small region of bat coronaviruses genomes that mutates infrequently, so changes indicate distinct viruses.) A great deal of speculation has circled around the naming of the partial sequence: Shi's group earlier had reported a virus named BtCoV/4991 that exactly matches RaTG13 in that small region, but are they one and the same? Or could it be, as some assert, that BtCoV/4991 is SARS-CoV-2 itself? What other bat coronaviruses has the lab yet to fully sequence? Could any of them offer clues?\n\nAnother outstanding question is whether Shi's team or other researchers in Wuhan manipulated bat viruses in 'gain-of-function' experiments that can make a virus more transmissible between humans. In 2015, Shi co-authored a paper that made a chimeric SARS virus by combining one from bats with a strain that had been adapted to mice. But that work was done at the University of North Carolina, not in Wuhan, and in collaboration with Ralph Baric. Did Shi's group later carry out other gain-of-function studies in Wuhan, and if so, what did they find?\n\nFinally, diplomatic cables from the U.S. Embassy in Beijing in 2018 warned that a new, ultra-high-security lab at WIV had 'a serious shortage of appropriately trained technicians and investigators.' Did Shi's team ever work with coronaviruses in that lab, and, if so, why?\n\nIf history repeats itself, it might take years -- or even decades -- to crack this case. Scientists haven't unequivocally identified Ebola's source 45 years after its discovery. But the key, time and again, to clarifying the origins of emerging infectious diseases is unearthing new data. WHO's push to organize the probe promises to, at the very least, accelerate what has been a plodding pursuit for answers.\n\n[Byline: Jon Cohen]\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nMary Marshall\n<mjm2020@googlemail.com>\n\n[1. The report of the 1st WHO-China Joint Experts Mission on Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19), 16-24 Feb 2020, was published on 28 Feb 2020. It included (p 8) the following segment, titled 'Zoonotic origins': 'COVID-19 is a zoonotic virus. From phylogenetics analyses undertaken with available full genome sequences, bats appear to be the reservoir of COVID-19 virus, but the intermediate host(s) has not yet been identified. However, 3 important areas of work are already underway in China to inform our understanding of the zoonotic origin of this outbreak. These include early investigations of cases with symptom onset in Wuhan throughout December 2019, environmental sampling from the Huanan Wholesale Seafood Market and other area markets, and the collection of detailed records on the source and type of wildlife species sold at the Huanan market and the destination of those animals after the market was closed.' A link to the report and the said text were reproduced in posting 20200312.7081842, with the following commentary: 'Wishfully, animal-health specialists were included among the members of the WHO Joint Mission.' It is relieving to note this comment may have been acknowledged.\n\n2. Zheng-Li Shi team's pre-print paper, 'Discovery of a novel coronavirus associated with the recent pneumonia outbreak in humans and its potential bat origin,' in which the virus strain RaTG13 was addressed publicly for the 1st time, was published on 23 Jan 2020 at https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.01.22.914952 and reviewed in the commentary of 20200201.6943858. The paper's final version was published later in Nature (doi: 10.1038/s41586-020-2012-7).\n\nHopefully, the current visit of the 2 experts will pave the road to a thorough, science-based, fully transparent investigation into the origin of the pandemic, in the spirit of One Health and One World. In view of the Dutch experience, China's mink farms should be included in the investigation. Industries of other farmed animal species deserve consideration as well (e.g., rabbits, boars). - Mod.AS\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nChina: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155]", "summary": "Other studies have discovered similarities between SARS-CoV-2 and a coronavirus found in pangolins, an endangered species that eats ants, but the pangolin virus is more divergent genetically from SARS-CoV-2 than the closest bat virus, and there's no evidence pangolins or their scales -- used in traditional Chinese medicine -- were sold at the market.\n\n For SARS, by June 2004, 14 months after the discovery of that virus, researchers had reported detailed epidemiological analyses of humans and animals: 39% of the earliest cases were food handlers, traders of live animals were 13 times more likely to have antibodies to the virus, and in that group, 72% handled civets. China: hormone therapy, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=356281", "date": "2009-12-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SEVERE ACUTE RESPIRATORY SYNDROME - CHINA: HORMONE THERAPY, REQUEST\nFOR INFORMATION\n***************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 25 Dec 2009\nSource: Thomson Reuters Foundation AlertNet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/TOE5BO044.htm>\n\n\nChina - SARS victims suffer hormone treatment effects\n-----------------------------------------------------\nAbout 300 survivors of a deadly outbreak of SARS [severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome] in China in 2003 are now suffering from serious\nafter-effects, possibly due to aggressive hormone treatment to save\ntheir lives, the Beijing News said on Friday [25 Dec 2009]. China's\nMinistry of Health did not immediately respond to a request for\ncomment, asking that a fax be sent.\n\nSARS, was an unknown disease when it first struck in late 2002.\nInitially covered up by the Chinese government, it spread rapidly\nfrom south China to other cities and countries in 2003, causing\npublic panic. The most common complaints of the survivors are hip\nproblems due to bone thinning, depression, and fibrosis of the lungs\nthat makes breathing difficult.\n\nThe last human case of SARS was reported in June 2003. Over 8000\npeople came down with the disease, and 775 died. The SARS experience\nhas been credited with inspiring a more transparent health reporting\nsystem in China and prompting better emergency preparedness.\n\n[Byline: Lucy Hornby]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) is a viral respiratory\nillness caused by a coronavirus, called SARS-associated coronavirus\n(SARS-CoV). SARS was first reported in Asia in February 2003. Over\nthe next few months, the illness spread to more than 2-dozen\ncountries in North America, South America, Europe, and Asia before\nthe SARS global outbreak of 2003 was contained. Currently, there is\nno known case of SARS transmission anywhere in the world. The most\nrecent human cases of SARS-CoV infection were reported in China in\nApril 2004 in an outbreak resulting from laboratory-acquired infections.\n\nIn general, SARS begins with a high fever. Other symptoms may include\nheadache, a feeling of discomfort, and body aches. Some people also\nhave mild respiratory symptoms at the outset. About 10 percent to 20\npercent of patients have diarrhea. After 2 to 7 days, SARS patients\nmay develop a dry cough. Many patients develop pneumonia. SARS is\nspread by close person-to-person contact. The nature of the sequelae\nexhibited by the 300 Chinese survivors of SARS infection referred to\nabove are not defined. It is unclear to what extent their condition\nis a consequence of the original SARS virus infection or their\nsubsequent aggressive hormone therapy. Further information is\nrequested. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 25 Dec 2009\n -----------------------------------------------------\nAbout 300 survivors of a deadly outbreak of SARS [severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome] in China in 2003 are now suffering from serious\nafter-effects, possibly due to aggressive hormone treatment to save\ntheir lives, the Beijing News said on Friday [25 Dec 2009]. Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) is a viral respiratory\nillness caused by a coronavirus, called SARS-associated coronavirus\n the next few months, the illness spread to more than 2-dozen\ncountries in North America, South America, Europe, and Asia before\nthe SARS global outbreak of 2003 was contained. The most\nrecent human cases of SARS-CoV infection were reported in China in\nApril 2004 in an outbreak resulting from laboratory-acquired infections. Initially covered up by the Chinese government, it spread rapidly\nfrom south China to other cities and countries in 2003, causing\npublic panic. It is unclear to what extent their condition\nis a consequence of the original SARS virus infection or their\nsubsequent aggressive hormone therapy. The most common complaints of the survivors are hip\nproblems due to bone thinning, depression, and fibrosis of the lungs\nthat makes breathing difficult. The nature of the sequelae\nexhibited by the 300 Chinese survivors of SARS infection referred to\nabove are not defined. The SARS experience\nhas been credited with inspiring a more transparent health reporting\nsystem in China and prompting better emergency preparedness. His condition worsened\nafter convulsions, and he fell into a coma, the Centre for Health\nProtection said. His condition was said to be critical on Thursday\n[21 Aug 2008], with signs of blood poisoning and brain abnormalities.\nHealth officials are already conducting an investigation into the\nillnesses after the deaths last week of 2 girls, 9 and 3, who\nsuffered from inflammation of the heart and blood poisoning.\n\nA 3rd girl, 7, is in critical condition, suffering from brain\ninflammation. Thomas Tsang Ho-fai, controller of the Centre for\nHealth Protection, said it was not known whether one single virus or\ndifferent viruses were responsible and an investigation was ongoing.\nIn the meantime, he reminded parents to pay close attention to their\nchildren's health and seek medical help if they developed persistent\nhigh fever, vomiting or convulsions.\n\nIn March 2008, the government closed all Hong Kong primary schools\nand kindergartens after the deaths of 2 children caused panic among\nparents who remembered the grim days of the 2003 outbreak of SARS, or\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome, which killed 299 and infected 1755\nin Hong Kong. It brought the return of surgical-style face masks,\nwhich were sold by the millions and worn on the streets, in schools\nand in workplaces during the SARS outbreak.\n\nAn investigation into the March 2008 illnesses revealed the deaths\nwere not the result of a virulent virus but strains of the H1N1 and\nH3N2 [seasonal influenza] Brisbane viruses, which had been\ncirculating in different parts of the world earlier this year [2008].\nAs well as SARS, Hong Kong saw the world's 1st modern-day outbreak of\nbird flu in 1997, when the virus infected 18 people, killing 6 of them.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nClaudio Po\nDirezione Generale Sanite Politiche Sociali\nRegione Emilia-Romagna\nViale A. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. 'The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,' Tsang said.\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The patients were\nchildren who all recovered, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). In 1999 an influenza A (H9N2)\nvirus was isolated from 2 patients (aged one and\n4 years old) by the Virus Unit of the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health. Both girls recovered fully.\nThis was the 1st occasion that an H9N2 virus had\nbeen isolated from humans in Hong Kong, although\ninfluenza A (H9N2) viruses had been isolated from\nducks and chickens for several years previously.\nIn both instances the H9N2 virus was isolated\nfrom mildly ill young children and there was no\nfurther spread of infection. The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. On these occasions only the H5N1\nviruses caused severe disease in humans. Dr York Chow, secretary for Food and Health of Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region (HKSAR) government made the announcement after the\nDepartment of Health and the Bureau of Education met last night to review\nthe data of the flu and the response of parents.\n\n'We made the decision given the rising trend of flu infections within the\ncommunity as the flu peak is expected to continue for weeks,' Chow told\nreporters. 'We hope such precautionary measures will help reduce the cross\ninfection of the flu virus in schools and the community.' On yesterday\nmorning, Chow said that an expert group will do its best to investigate the\nrecent deaths of 3 children with flu-like symptoms, adding that at this\nstage, no common factors have been identified. He said the most important\nthing at the moment is to grasp a clear picture of the outbreaks and\nwhether they are spreading.\n\nYesterday, the Center for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of\nHealth (DH) received reports of influenza-like illness (ILI) outbreaks\naffecting 23 schools involving a total of 184 people. A CHP spokesman said\nILI may be caused by influenza or other respiratory viruses. CHP's\nofficials have visited all these institutions and provided health advice to\nthe staff accordingly. CHP will provide the public with information on\nseasonal influenza starting today. A hotline will operate from 9am to 6pm.\nfrom Monday to Friday.\n\nCHP received a report from Hospital Authority yesterday concerning a 3 year\nold boy who was admitted to Princess Margaret Hospital Tuesday because of\npersistent fever, cough and shortness of breath. The boy was transferred to\nIntensive Care Unit and is now in stable condition, said the spokesman,\nadding that initial investigation showed his respiratory sample yielded\npositive results for influenza A (H1N1). Further tests are under progress.\n\nRegarding the death of a 7 year old boy with respiratory and neurological\nsymptoms in Tuen Mun Hospital, the spokesman said further laboratory tests\nshowed that the boy's respiratory sample yielded positive results for\ninfluenza A (H1N1) [see the following report for modification of this\ndiagnosis. - Mod.CP].\n\nOn the death of a 21 month old boy who passed away on 24 Feb 2008, the\nspokesman said that examination of the boy's respiratory sample yielded\nnegative results for Influenza A and B. 'There is no evidence at the\npresent stage suggesting the boy has contracted influenza. Further\ninvestigation is ongoing,' he said.\n\nThe Hospital Authority (HA) on Wednesday [12 Mar 2008] announced that a\nspecial fund of 20 million HK dollars (2.6 million USD) had been set aside\nto implement a series of measures run up to the end of April 2008 to cope\nwith recent surge in demand for public hospital services due to seasonal\ninfluenza.\n\nPublic hospitals have been experiencing a prolonged increase in emergency\ndemand lately, in particular the emergency medical admissions, HA chief\nexecutive Shane Solomon told the media during a visit to the North District\nHospital yesterday afternoon.\n\n'Compared with February last year, the daily number of emergency medical\nadmissions is 16 percent higher. At the same time, recent admission to\npediatric wards in public hospitals has also surged,' he said. The sudden\nand unprecedented surge in demand in medical and pediatric wards has\ncreated great pressure on the front line staff, who have worked extra\nhours, with many of them canceling leave, working longer hours and on their\ndays off, he said. 'Over the last 2 weeks, an additional 15 000 hours of\nextra nursing and supporting staff have worked, adding the equivalent of\n192 full-time staff to the ward,' he said.\n\nTo cope with the recent surge, various hospital clusters have opened extra\nbeds and implemented other initiatives to cope with patient needs. Solomon\nalso reassured the public that the HA will closely monitor the situation on\na daily basis to plan for further measures.\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 14 Mar 2008\nSource: Shanghai Daily online [edited]\n<http://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/?id=352174&type=National>\n\n\nFlu viruses found in Hong Kong victim\n-------------------------------------\nExperts in Hong Kong found 2 flu viruses and a steroid inside the body of a\nboy who died of influenza in an outbreak that has forced the closure of all\nkindergartens and primary schools in the special administrative region\n(SAR). The city's Department of Health found the H1 and H3 viruses and\ncomponents of a steroid after examining the body of the 7 year old boy,\nGuangzhouDaily reported today [Fri 14 Mar 2008].\n\nA 3 year old girl also died of the flu early this month, following the\ndeath of a 2 year old child at the end of February 2008. Hong Kong health\nofficials have reported 9 confirmed flu cases and 65 suspected ones since 6\nMar 2008, mostly at schools, in the territory of nearly 7 million.\nScientists suspected that the 7 year old had taken a steroid to treat his\nasthma, which weakened his immune system, the report said. The boy's death\nreport is not likely to come out soon, the report said. But scientists have\nalready ruled out the possibility of bird flu or severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome, an epidemic that killed hundreds of people in Hong Kong in 2003.\n\nYuen Kwok-yung, a leading Hong Kong scientist, and a panel of experts\nstudied the 2 deceased flu patients and found that the flu virus had not\nspread beyond their lungs, which suggested the virus was not too virulent.\nThe World Health Organization also said yesterday that there was no reason\nfor concern. WHO spokesman Peter Cordingley called the Hong Kong outbreak\n'just regular seasonal flu.'\n\nLate on Wednesday [12 Mar 2008] the Hong Kong government ordered all\nkindergartens, primary and special education schools to close for 2 weeks\neffective yesterday. This move was reminiscent of measures taken during\nHong Kong's outbreak ofSARS. The closure in effect starts the Easter\nholiday for schools about a week in advance. It will affect nearly 560 000\nstudents at 1745 schools. Many schools have required students to wear masks\nsince the outbreak occurred nearly 2 weeks ago [see a photograph\naccompanying the original text of part [1]. - Mod.CP].\n\n[byline: Lydia Chen]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[These reports indicate that the Hong Kong SAR is experiencing a serious\noutbreak of seasonal influenza. The deaths of 2 of 3 affected children has\ncaused the health care authorities to close Hong Kong's kindergarten and\nprimary schools for a period of 2 weeks. Two of the children were\nseropositive for H1N1 influenza virus. The unusual feature of this report\nis that one of the 2 H1N1 seropositive children was also seropositive for\nH3N2 influenza virus. This latter child was receiving steroid treatment and\nit is suggested that his immune system had been weakened and he was more\nsusceptible to infection. If so it indicates that both H1N1 and H3N2\nviruses are circulating in the outbreak of seasonal influenza in Hong Kong.\nDetails of the diagnostic testing are not provided, however, and it may be\nthat a response to vaccine virus is being measured if the child had been\nvaccinated recently. Dr York Chow, secretary for Food and Health of Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region (HKSAR) government made the announcement after the\nDepartment of Health and the Bureau of Education met last night to review\nthe data of the flu and the response of parents. \n\nYuen Kwok-yung, a leading Hong Kong scientist, and a panel of experts\nstudied the 2 deceased flu patients and found that the flu virus had not\nspread beyond their lungs, which suggested the virus was not too virulent. \n\nYesterday, the Center for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of\nHealth (DH) received reports of influenza-like illness (ILI) outbreaks\naffecting 23 schools involving a total of 184 people. \n\nCHP received a report from Hospital Authority yesterday concerning a 3 year\nold boy who was admitted to Princess Margaret Hospital Tuesday because of\npersistent fever, cough and shortness of breath. The deaths of 2 of 3 affected children has\ncaused the health care authorities to close Hong Kong's kindergarten and\nprimary schools for a period of 2 weeks. Late on Wednesday [12 Mar 2008] the Hong Kong government ordered all\nkindergartens, primary and special education schools to close for 2 weeks\neffective yesterday. Hong Kong health\nofficials have reported 9 confirmed flu cases and 65 suspected ones since 6\nMar 2008, mostly at schools, in the territory of nearly 7 million. \n\n'We made the decision given the rising trend of flu infections within the\ncommunity as the flu peak is expected to continue for weeks,' Chow told\nreporters. Officials suspected she\nwas infected by birds at the market, he said.\n\nH9N2 is a mild strain [of avian influenza A\nvirus], [the H5N1 strain of avian influenza A\nvirus] has caused the deaths of at least 169\npeople worldwide. [The H9N2 virus belongs to a\ndifferent serotype of avian influenza A virus and\nshould not be described as a strain of H5N1\nvirus. These 2 avian influenza A viruses should\nbe regarded as distinct viruses differing in\nvirulence, host range and transmissibility. -\nMod.CP]. 'The baby's case is not that serious,\nand there's no serious indication that there was\nhuman-to-human infection,' Tsang said.\n\nHong Kong reported 2 cases of the mild strain in\n1999 and one in 2003, he said. The patients were\nchildren who all recovered, he said. The recent\ncase returned home after spending 5 days in the\nhospital, but the child was put into isolation\nafter her samples tested positive for H9N2, said\nTsang, adding that the case was confirmed Tuesday [20 Mar 2007].\n\nOfficials were taking more samples from the\nmarket and family members, he said. Hong Kong\naggressively monitors bird flu because an\noutbreak [caaused by a highly pathogenic strain\nof different serotype - Mod CP.] in 1997 jumped\nto humans and killed 6 people. That prompted the\ngovernment to slaughter the entire poultry\npopulation of about 1.5 million birds.\n\n--\nJoseph P. Dudley, Ph.D\nChief Scientist,\nEAI Corporation\nResearch Associate,\nInstitute of Arctic Biology - University of Alaska Fairbanks\nDepartment of Earth Science - University of Alaska Museum\n<fnjpd@uaf.edu>\n\n[This case has precedents (e.g. see ProMED-mail\nposting : Influenza A (H9N2), bird-to-human -\nChina (Hong Kong) 19990407.0566 and Influenza A\n(H9N2), bird-to-human - China (Hong Kong)\n19990805.1347). The circumstances\nsurrounding the exposure of these children to infection have not been reported.\n\nOther avian influenza viruses have been isolated\nfrom human patients, notably the H5N1 virus in\nHong Kong in 1997 and subsequently, and H9N2 (and\nH5N1) in 2003, and the H7N7 virus in the more\nextensive poultry outbreak in the Netherlands\nearlier in 2003. On these occasions only the H5N1\nviruses caused severe disease in humans. Pepito S. Leysa, chief of the Agriculture\ndepartment's Regional Crop Protection Center (RCPC), said that\nvisible manifestations of panama disease, or fusarium wilt, were\ndiscovered in a 3-hectare lakatan banana plantation in Alabel,\nSarangani. Lakatan is a banana variety.\n\nThe banana varieties susceptible to panama disease are latundan,\nsenorita and lakatan. Cavendish banana has succumbed to the new\nstrain (race 4) of the disease. Saba or cardaba, on the other hand,\nis a resistant cultivar, the statement added.\n\nPanama disease was 1st reported in the Philippines in 1920 on\nlatundan variety in Los Banos and Calamba, Laguna, and in\nmunicipalities of Batangas. It was confirmed in commercial Cavendish\nfarms in 1974 and 1979. The pathogen ended up totally destroying 13\nhectares of latundan farms in Eden, Toril in Davao City.\n\nAside from panama disease, the affected banana farm was also infested\nby the banana bunchy top virus, moko and sigatoka diseases, Mr. Leysa\nsaid. It was the 1st time that crop protection experts confirmed the\npresence of the devastating panama disease in Central Mindanao\nregion. The region hosts at least 3 large banana producers.\n\n[Byline: Romer S. Sarmiento]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Control measures\nDate: 17 Dec 2008\nFrom: Mark Laing [edited]\n<Laing@ukzn.ac.za>\n\n\nRe: control of panama disease\n-----------------------------\nThe problem with rotation as a disease control measure is that it\ndoes not work with some soilborne pathogens such as panama wilt\nbecause the pathogen will persist in the soil for at least 20 years.\nNot many farmers can wait that long between cycles.\n\nSo a more proactive approach is needed. We are combining 4 discrete\ntreatments into an integrated control programme:\n\n1. a beneficial endophyte applied to fresh tissue cultured plants;\n\n2. a _Trichoderma harzianum_ biocontrol agent applied as a drench every month;\n\n3. potassium silicate drenches applied every 2 months (5L x at 1000 ppm);\n\n4. 75 mm of lignitic mulch (macademia nut husks) covering the drip zone.\n\nSo far this integrated package is working well, far better than\ncontrol measures we have tried previously (including fungicides) to\ncontrol _Fusarium_ which is a major problem in South Africa. We are\nalso using the same approach on other tree crops (citrus, avocado,\ncoffee, macademia, papaya) and it is working well there also.\n\n[We are most grateful to Prof. Laing for this valuable contribution. - Mod.DHA]\n\n--\nProfessor Mark Laing\nSchool of Biochemistry, Genetics, Microbiology and Plant Pathology\nUniversity of KwaZulu-Natal\nPietermaritzburg\nSouth Africa\n<laing@ukzn.ac.za>\n<http://www.ukzn.ac.za>\n\n[Panama disease of banana (PD, also called fungal or fusarium wilt)\nis caused by the soilborne fungus _Fusarium oxysporum_ f.sp.\n_cubense_. Symptoms include yellowing, wilting, and streaking of\npseudostem, and affected plants die rapidly. The pathogen is spread\nby infected planting material, mechanical means, soil, and water, and\ncan survive in the soil for decades.\n\nSeveral races of the pathogen exist. Races 1 and 2 attack several\ndifferent cultivars of eating and cooking bananas, but not Cavendish\nvarieties (for information on banana genotypes please see link\nbelow); race 3 attacks ornamental _Heliconia_ species only; temperate\nrace 4 and the recently emerged tropical race 4 (TR4) attack\ncultivars in the Cavendish subgroup as well as hosts of races 1 and 2.\n\nDisease management is difficult for PD and mostly relies on\nphytosanitation for pathogen exclusion. Constant vigilance is\nrequired in areas where the fungus is present to prevent flare-ups.\nSince no effective chemical or cultural control measures are\navailable, the integrated approach described in item 2 represents a\nvery important development.\n\n_Trichoderma harzianum_ is a fungus that is also used as a fungicidal\nbiocontrol agent for foliar applications as well as seed and soil\ntreatments. It has been reported to be successful for suppression of\nvarious fungal pathogens including soil-inhabiting species of\n_Fusarium_, _Rhizoctonia_, _Sclerotium_, _Sclerotinia_ and _Botrytis_.\n\nCardaba and saba are cooking bananas, all the other cultivars\nmentioned in item 1 are dessert varieties. The other diseases\nmentioned are _Banana bunchy top virus_ (more information via\nProMED-mail post 20090204.0486), moko disease (caused by the\nbacterium _Ralstonia solanacearum_; more information via ProMED-mail\npost 20071112.3676), and the fungal sigatoka diseases (black and\nyellow sigatoka caused by _Mycosphaerella fijiensis_ and _M.\nmusicola_, respectively; more information via ProMED-mail post\n20071012.3351).\n\nMaps\nPhilippines:\n<http://www.ac.wwu.edu/~fasawwu/resources/img/map-philippines.png> and\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=11.7,122.9,5>\nPhilippine worldwide - China (32): civet cat ban", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=762", "date": "2004-10-20 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE - CHINA (32): CIVET CAT BAN\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 20 Oct 2004\nFrom: Chris Griot <Christian.Griot@ivi.admin.ch>\nSource: China Daily, News, Wed 20 Oct 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2004-10/18/content_383421.htm>\n\nChina: proposed ban on sale of civet cat meat in Guangdong\n-----------------------------------------------\nTo prevent a winter return of the deadly SARS virus, a senior Chinese\nhealth official will visit southern Guangdong province this month [October\n2004] to map out measures such as banning civet cat from menus, a newspaper\nsaid on Mon 18 Oct 2004. Initiatives to be hammered out by Vice Minister of\nHealth Wang Longde and provincial officials would include banning\nrestaurants from cooking and serving high-risk animals, such as civet cats,\nHong Kong's Wen Wei Po said.\nChinese health experts have concluded that the civet cat, considered a\ndelicacy in the south, was a primary source of last year's [2003] SARS\nepidemic. Thousands of civets were killed in Guangdong province in January\n[2004] because of fears they may carry a form of the virus that can jump to\nhumans. Guangdong would be the focus of Wang's move, and the measures for\ncivet cats there would not be extended to the whole country, the newspaper\nsaid.\nThe civet is a small carnivorous mammal found in Asia and Africa. The brown\nfurry creature with a cat-like body, long tail, and weasel-like face has\nlong been coveted by those who believe its tender flesh will improve their\nhealth and complexion. Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) emerged in\nGuangdong in November 2002 and was soon spread by travelers. The disease\neventually killed some 800 people around the world and infected about 8000.\nA top Chinese health official warned, on Sat 16 Oct 2004, of the increased\nrisk of infectious diseases, such as SARS and avian influenza, jumping\nacross the border to Hong Kong in 2005, as more Chinese travel to the\nsouthern city for work and play. Speaking after a 2-day meeting with health\nofficials from Hong Kong and Macau, Chinese Vice Minister for Health Huang\nJiefu stressed the need for surveillance and information sharing to control\nthe spread of infectious diseases.\n--\nChris Griot\n<Christian.Griot@ivi.admin.ch>\n[Civet cats and some other animals are undoubtedly susceptible to SARS\ncoronavirus infection, but the role of civet cats in the epidemiology of\nthe human disease of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) remains\nunclear. Even assuming that civet cats were the source of the outbreak of\nSARS beginning in South China in 2002/2003, banning the consumption of\ncivet cat meat in Guangdong province only can have limited success. These\nanimals are widespread in the wild and in captivity, hence contact between\nhumans and civet cats could occur anywhere in China and beyond.\nCoronaviruses are spread mainly by respiratory routes, and cooked meat\nwould not be infectious. Banning of civet cat farming might be a more\neffective measure. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n To prevent a winter return of the deadly SARS virus, a senior Chinese\nhealth official will visit southern Guangdong province this month [October\n2004] to map out measures such as banning civet cat from menus, a newspaper\nsaid on Mon 18 Oct 2004. [Civet cats and some other animals are undoubtedly susceptible to SARS\ncoronavirus infection, but the role of civet cats in the epidemiology of\nthe human disease of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) remains\nunclear. Initiatives to be hammered out by Vice Minister of\nHealth Wang Longde and provincial officials would include banning\nrestaurants from cooking and serving high-risk animals, such as civet cats,\nHong Kong's Wen Wei Po said. A top Chinese health official warned, on Sat 16 Oct 2004, of the increased\nrisk of infectious diseases, such as SARS and avian influenza, jumping\nacross the border to Hong Kong in 2005, as more Chinese travel to the\nsouthern city for work and play. \nChinese health experts have concluded that the civet cat, considered a\ndelicacy in the south, was a primary source of last year's [2003] SARS\nepidemic. The brown\nfurry creature with a cat-like body, long tail, and weasel-like face has\nlong been coveted by those who believe its tender flesh will improve their\nhealth and complexion. Even assuming that civet cats were the source of the outbreak of\nSARS beginning in South China in 2002/2003, banning the consumption of\ncivet cat meat in Guangdong province only can have limited success. \nChris Griot\n<Christian.Griot@ivi.admin.ch>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2005-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-25 00:00:00", "2002-11-25 00:00:00", "2032-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-10-25 00:00:00", "2004-10-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Hong Kong 's", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Macau", "country": "Macao"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206041", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (31): China, cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206041", "date": "2004-07-04 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (31): CHINA, CASES\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 3 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO Western Pacific Regional Office Press Release 2 Jul 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.wpro.who.int/sars/docs/update/update_07022004.asp>\n\nChina's recent SARS outbreak: important lessons for global public health -\n2 Jul 2004\n-----------------------------\nIt has been more than 2 months since the Ministry of Health of China\nnotified WHO and the world about an outbreak of SARS in Beijing and Anhui\nProvince. Since then, WHO experts have been supporting the Chinese\nauthorities in their investigation into the cause of the\nlaboratory-acquired cases, and in assessing the effectiveness of measures\ntaken to control the outbreak.\nOn 1 Jul 2004, the Ministry of Health of China released its status report\non the investigation. The outbreak has now been successfully contained, but\ninitial findings from the investigation and the assessment of control\nmeasures have raised several important lessons for global public health.\nInvestigation into the source of the outbreak\n---------------------------------------------\nDuring the investigation, a substantial amount of information was gathered,\nalthough all the practices within the National Institute of Virology in\nBeijing have yet to be thoroughly assessed. Although not all detailed\ninformation has been made available to WHO, the following conclusions have\nbeen made about the source of the outbreak:\n- the National Institute of Virology in Beijing was the most likely source\nof the outbreak.\n- at least 4 individuals may have been infected with SARS at the Institute.\nThese include the 2 laboratory workers reported in April, and 2 additional\nlaboratory workers. These 2 additional laboratory workers appear to have\nsuffered from SARS-like illnesses in early February 2004. Recent laboratory\ntests performed at a national reference laboratory were positive for SARS\nantibodies.\n- the use of inactivated SARS coronavirus, which was not tested to\ndetermine the effectiveness of the inactivation, in a general laboratory at\nthe Institute appears the most likely cause of the outbreak.\nDuring the investigation, it became apparent that all the positive\nlaboratory workers worked in the same general laboratory at the Institute.\nAlthough no research involving live SARS viruses was known to have taken\nplace in this laboratory, SARS coronavirus that had been inactivated in a\nBiosafety Level 3 laboratory in the Institute was used on several occasions\nduring the early months of 2004 in experiments carried out in this area.\nThe timing of the use of inactivated SARS coronavirus in the general\nlaboratory coincides with the presence there of all the positive workers\nand with their likely incubation periods.\nWHO recommends that further work is needed to verify the effectiveness of\nthe method used to inactivate the live SARS virus. At the same time, other\npossible explanations of the cause of the outbreak cannot be fully excluded.\nBiosafety concerns raised by the outbreak\n-----------------------------------------\nThe incident at the National Institute of Virology in Beijing has raised\nconcerns about biosafety in general, and the way in which inactivated viral\nmaterial is handled in particular. 'In light of the investigation, WHO\nbelieves that Member States should carefully review biosafety standards and\nstrengthen them to avoid further incidents,' said Dr Shigeru Omi, regional\ndirector of WHO's Western Pacific Region.\nWHO will be working with Member States and expert groups to develop country\nand regional strategies to strengthen biosafety. Core components of such\nbiosafety programmes at country level are likely to include:\n- a containment policy to reduce the number of laboratories storing and\nworking on SARS coronavirus.\n- a legislative framework and independent advisory body to assist in the\ndevelopment, implementation and evaluation of a national biosafety\nprogramme and in the investigation of biohazard incidents and the\ndissemination of lessons learned to the global scientific community.\n- a laboratory accreditation system based on standardized biosafety criteria.\n- an occupational health service to monitor the well being of laboratory\nworkers.\n- comprehensive biosafety and training programmes in all diagnostic and\nresearch institutes supported by a management framework that facilitates\ncompliance with evidence-based guidelines and the adoption of a positive\nbiosafety culture.\nWHO also emphasizes that scientists working with highly pathogenic viruses\nsuch as SARS need to handle inactivated material with the utmost caution.\nIn particular, WHO recommends that:\n- researchers use appropriate and internationally accepted methods for\nvalidating the inactivation of live viruses.\n- inactivated material should be handled only in laboratories at biosafety\nlevel (BSL) 2 or above.\n- researchers handling inactivated material should wear appropriate\npersonal protective equipment.\n- new methods for inactivation should be adopted only after rigorous testing.\n- clear and comprehensive protocols should be available for all\ninactivation techniques.\nAssessment of effectiveness of outbreak control measures\n--------------------------------------------------------\nIn addition to supporting the investigation into the possible source of the\noutbreak, WHO has worked with Chinese authorities to evaluate the\neffectiveness of the outbreak control measures. Joint WHO-Ministry of\nHealth teams have visited all the hospitals where the recent cases were\ntreated before they were admitted to designated SARS facilities. In\naddition, WHO experts have reviewed data on contact tracing and other\ncontrol measures.\n'Overall,' said Dr Omi, 'WHO believes that the Chinese authorities acted\nswiftly and effectively to control the outbreak once the alarm had been\nraised. Extensive contact tracing was undertaken in a matter of hours, and\nthe effective isolation of cases and identification of contacts appears to\nhave ensured that the outbreak was contained with remarkable speed.'\nBut there was a delay in detecting the initial cases. As a consequence, 2\ngenerations of transmission occurred and the application of effective\nhospital and community control measures took place late in the outbreak.\nThe Ministry of Health of China has acknowledged this and is looking to\nstrengthen further the current detection and response system.\nThere are a number of lessons from this outbreak that are important\nglobally, for member states and for WHO itself:\n- health care workers, laboratory workers and people in close contact with\ncertain animals are at risk of contracting a range of infectious diseases\nwith outbreak potential. Disease detection systems need to be designed to\ntake these risk factors, as well as clinical information, into account --\nand to be robust enough to ensure that nobody slips through the net and\nevades detection.\n- health care workers need to be aware of the risks associated with certain\noccupations (including their own) and to be able to take a detailed\noccupational history from a patient.\n- health care workers also need to be aware of the importance of asking\nabout the health of close contacts of anyone with a potentially contagious\nrespiratory illness. Quickly identifying possible clusters of respiratory\nillness is important in the control of such diseases and the detection of\nnew or rare infectious diseases.\n- all health care workers should be empowered to initiate effective\nmeasures to protect themselves and others from potentially contagious\ndiseases, in a 'safety first' approach. This means that health care workers\nshould be aware of potential clinical and epidemiological risk factors;\nhave ready access to the equipment and knowledge needed to protect\nthemselves and others; and be allowed to initiate the most appropriate\ninfection-control measures immediately -- with validation and approval from\nsenior members of staff later.\nThis recent outbreak has demonstrated once again that SARS is a containable\ndisease. WHO commends the Chinese authorities for taking swift action to\ncontrol the latest outbreak. WHO will be working closely with the Chinese\nauthorities to assist in the strengthening of biosafety, and to build a\nlong-term strategy for strengthening laboratory research and diagnosis in\nChina.\nWHO looks forward to working with China in its efforts to tackle SARS and\nother public health issues in the future. For more information, please\ncontact: Mr Roy Wadia <wadiar@chn.wpro.who.int> or Mr Peter Cordingley\n<cordingleyp@wpro.who.int> or Mr Dick Thompson <thompsond@who.int> or Ms\nMaria Cheng <chengm@who.int>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This WHO/WPRO Press release is much clearer than that in the last\nProMED-mail posting of 2 Jul 2004, which relied upon newswires and machine\ntranslations of the abstract available on the Chinese Ministry of Health\nwebsite. The breach in laboratory safety protocols (working with a\nsupposedly inactivated virus in an open laboratory without testing the\nefficacy of the inactivation process) seems likely to have led to a\ncontamination of the environment with a live SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV).\nIt remains curious that the initial infections were in February and the 2nd\nwave of infections occurred in late March and mid-April (see SARS -\nworldwide (18): China, cases 20040423.1125). As correctly noted, in\naddition to the breaches in laboratory protocols, of the 4 cases linked to\nlaboratory exposure, 2 went completely undetected until a serosurvey, and\nboth of the 2nd-round cases had significant delays in diagnosis, despite\nworking in a virology laboratory where the SARS-CoV had been handled and\nhaving clinical illnesses compatible with SARS-CoV infection. Once\nidentification of SARS-CoV as the etiology of the illnesses in April 2004\nwas made, then appropriate and rapid case containment measures were\nimplemented and further transmission was interrupted.\nThis incident highlights the ever-present concerns about early detection of\nemerging and reemerging infectious diseases with a key focal point for this\nactivity being the 'point of service' when cases first come to the\nattention of the health sector. Lessons learned in reviewing the\nidentification of newly emerging infectious diseases such as HIV-related\nillness, nipah virus infection, and SARS-CoV infection include the\nimportance of the 'astute' clinician to alert the public health sector that\n'something different' was going on. A challenge to the public health arena\nis how to shorten the time between the onset of illness, the identification\nof the problem, and the implementation of investigation and control\nmeasures. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "As correctly noted, in\naddition to the breaches in laboratory protocols, of the 4 cases linked to\nlaboratory exposure, 2 went completely undetected until a serosurvey, and\nboth of the 2nd-round cases had significant delays in diagnosis, despite\nworking in a virology laboratory where the SARS-CoV had been handled and\nhaving clinical illnesses compatible with SARS-CoV infection. To be more precise, the authors implicate 3\nspecies of horseshoe bat of the genus _Rhinolophus_.\nI have done some initial research and can only find reference to horseshoe\nbats in PNG [Papua New Guinea] but other reports state that they are\npresent in a number of Pacific Islands without specifying which\nones. Would subscribers to Pacvet [or others] please let us know whether\nhorseshoe bats occur in their countries and territories and if possible\nwhich species?\n[Reference: Bats Are Natural Reservoirs of SARS-Like Coronaviruses. Wendong\nLi, Zhengli Shi, Meng Yu, Wuze Ren, Craig Smith, Jonathan H.Epstein,\nHanzhong Wang, Gary Crameri, Zhihong Hu, Huajun Zhang, Jianhong Zhang,\nJennifer McEachern, Hume Field, Peter Daszak, Bryan T. Eaton, Shuyi Zhang,\nand Lin-Fa Wang. Science, page 11183911\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1118391v1?etoc>]\n--\nDr. Stephen D. Angus\nVeterinary Epidemiologist\nAnimal Health & Production Service\nSecretariat of the Pacific Community\nPrivate Mail Bag\nSuva\nFiji Islands\n<SteveA@spc.int>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 30 Sep 2005\nFrom: Steve Angus <stevea@spc.int>\nSource: BBC News, Thu 29 Sep 2005 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/2/hi/science/nature/4291386.stm>\n\nThe likely source of the respiratory disease SARS is the horseshoe bat, a\nnew study suggests. Researchers found a virus closely related to the SARS\ncoronavirus in bats from 3 regions of China. Writing in the journal\nScience, they say the virus may have needed to infect another animal such\nas the civet before it could transmit to humans. They suggest that live\nhorseshoe bats [should be] kept out of markets until the transmission path\nis fully understood.\nThe SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome) outbreak in 2002/3 caused\nabout 770 deaths, and economic damage estimated in billions of dollars;\ncentred on east Asia with origins in southern China, fatalities occurred as\nfar afield as Canada. The virus we found is 92 percent similar to the human\nSARS virus. Schools and businesses closed, international trade and travel\nwere restricted; and for a time, until basic public health measures\ncurtailed the outbreak, it seemed as though the next major global disease\nof humanity had emerged.\nBut it emerged from where? In May 2003, the suggestion emerged that the\nvirus responsible had entered the human population from civets, animals\neaten in wildlife restaurants and butchered in live animal markets in\nsouthern China. The World Health Organisation (WHO) endorsed this link\nearly in 2004, an announcement which led authorities in China to embark on\na culling programme which saw an estimated 10 000 civets killed, as well as\nother animals suspected of harbouring SARS virus, such as badgers and raccoons.\nBut for some time, the prevailing theory among scientists has been that\ncivets were not the original source, or reservoir, of infection. One clue\nis that they appear to have little immunity, and become seriously ill;\nwhereas species which harbour pathogens for a long period of history\nusually adapt to them. So where did the SARS virus come from? One theory\nnamed birds; but earlier this month, researchers at Hong Kong University\nfound cause to suspect bats. In a Hong Kong bat species they found a virus\nclosely related to that found in SARS patients.\nNow an international collaboration between scientists in China, Australia\nand the US has gone further, and identified a SARS-like [coronavirus] in 3\nspecies of bats from mainland China. 'The virus we found is 92 percent\nsimilar to the human SARS virus,' said Zhengli Shi from the Institute of\nZoology at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing. 'Why it is there in\nthese bats, why it can infect just these species, we are not sure -- it is\na story we want to discuss,' she told BBC News.\nAll 3 species of bat in which Dr Shi's group found the SARS-like\ncoronavirus, are horseshoe bats of the genus _Rhinolophus_, as does the\nspecies identified in the Hong Kong study. Genomic analysis suggests that\nthe bat coronaviruses found by this group and by the Hong Kong team are\nvery alike, and that both are closely related to the human and civet forms.\nThe major differences lie in genes which relate to the binding of virus\nparticle and the host cell. 'This virus, we are sure, cannot infect\nhumans,' said Zhengli Shi. One of the big questions is, then, how the virus\njumped from bats to humans -- and whether in the body of an intermediary,\nsuch as the civet, it can adapt in such a way that it can then infect a\nhuman. 'At the moment we don't know,' said Peter Daszak, Director of the\nConsortium for Conservation Medicine in New York, who was also involved in\nthe study.\nSo civets could be an 'amplifier host' for SARS. If they are, one\nsuggestion, according to Peter Daszak, is to keep them away from horseshoe\nbats. 'In the east Asian region, we need to face up to high-risk\nbehaviours,' he said, 'and in this situation, bringing these species into\nlive markets, butchering and eating them and using them in medicines, is a\nhigh-risk behaviour.'\nWHO spokesperson Dick Thompson told BBC News: 'We see this as another piece\nof the SARS jigsaw. 'There's an unfinished agenda for SARS, and clearly we\nneed to understand the disease ecology better.' Confirming horseshoe bats\nas the source of SARS would carry implications for future public health\nresearch and policy. 'These bats have a wide distribution in Europe and\nAsia,' said Peter Daszak, 'and what we don't know, and need to know\nurgently, is the distribution of the SARS-like coronavirus in these bats.\nThe last thing we should do is to take it out on the bats, because the\nevidence suggests that they have carried this coronavirus for thousands,\nperhaps millions of years; only recently has it emerged in a big way, and\nit was human behaviours that made the difference.'\n[Byline: Richard Black]\n--\nDr. Stephen D. Angus\nVeterinary Epidemiologist\nAnimal Health & Production Service\nSecretariat of the Pacific Community\nPrivate Mail Bag\nSuva\nFiji Islands\n<SteveA@spc.int>\n[Correspondents should direct their responses to Dr. Angus in the first\ninstance. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Schools and businesses closed, international trade and travel\nwere restricted; and for a time, until basic public health measures\ncurtailed the outbreak, it seemed as though the next major global disease\nof humanity had emerged.\n Science, page 11183911\n<http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1118391v1?etoc>]\n--\nDr. Stephen D. '", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2004-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Papua New Guinea", "country": "Papua New Guinea"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Wendong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206033", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (30): China, cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206033", "date": "2004-07-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (30): CHINA, CASES\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 2 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Herald Sun [edited]\n<http://www.heraldsun.news.com.au/common/story_page/0,5478,10022647%255E1702,00.html>\n\nSARS cases linked to Beijing death\n----------------------------------\nTwo laboratory workers in Beijing suffered SARS-like illnesses in Feb 2004\nthat were not detected until an outbreak traced to the same facility 2\nmonths later killed one person, the World Health Organization said today.\nWHO called on China and other governments to tighten rules on handling the\nSARS virus after Chinese investigators on Thursday said sloppy work at the\nBeijing laboratory was to blame for the April outbreak that sickened 9\npeople. The 2 workers who fell ill in February recovered and went back to\nwork, said Roy Wadia, a WHO spokesman in Beijing. He said they weren't\ndetected until they tested positive for SARS antibodies when hundreds of\nlab workers were screened following the April outbreak.\nDoctors couldn't confirm whether the two had SARS because too much time had\npassed since their illness, Wadia said. 'The fact that these cases weren't\nfound sooner suggests that the detection system isn't fully in place\nthroughout the Chinese health system,' said Wadia. He said one of the ill\nworkers oversaw the inactivation of the virus, which should have made her\n'a prime suspect' for SARS. 'It seems that the right questions weren't\nasked,' he said. On Thursday, China said the chief of its disease-control\nagency had resigned to take responsibility for the outbreak traced to the\nNational Institute of Virology, which is run by his agency.\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome emerged in the southern Chinese province\nof Guangdong in late 2002 and killed 349 people on China's mainland and 774\nworldwide before subsiding last June. During that outbreak, Chinese leaders\nwere widely criticized for failing to release information promptly and\nrespond to foreign pleas for cooperation.\nIn the April outbreak, 2 people working at a Beijing virus institute are\nbelieved to have contracted SARS and spread it to 7 people outside the lab.\nThe mother of one lab worker died. China quarantined more than 500 people\nfollowing the outbreak and ordered hospitals and universities to hand over\nvirus samples to secure government laboratories for storage. The Chinese\ngovernment informed WHO of the February cases in May, Wadia said.\nA statement Friday by WHO called on other governments to reduce the number\nof laboratories handling the virus and to watch the health of lab workers\nclosely. 'WHO believes that member states should carefully review biosafety\nstandards and strengthen them to avoid further incidents,' Dr Shigeru Omi,\nWHO's regional director, said in the statement.\n[byline: Joe McDonald]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 2 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters UK [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/MAN162407.htm>\n\nWHO urges laboratory safety reviews for SARS\n--------------------------------------------\nThe World Health Organization urged countries on Friday to review safety in\nlaboratories after finding that this year's outbreak of SARS probably\noriginated in China's National Institute of Virology in Beijing. WHO said\nat least 4 laboratory workers may have been infected with severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome [virus] at the institute at the start of an outbreak\nin March that killed one person and infected 9 others.\n'In light of the investigation, WHO believes that member states should\ncarefully review biosafety standards and strengthen them to avoid further\nincidents,' Shigeru Omi, regional director of WHO's western Pacific region,\nsaid in a statement. WHO said an inactive SARS virus was used several times\nin early 2004 in experiments at the Beijing laboratory when the 4 workers\nwere present. China's Health Ministry said on Thursday that the outbreak\noriginated in the laboratory.\nWHO said it would work with countries to develop strategies to strengthen\nsafety, including the reduction of laboratories storing and working on\nSARS. It also said scientists working with highly pathogenic viruses such\nas SARS needed to handle inactive material with the utmost caution.\n'Disease detection systems need to be designed to take these risk factors,\nas well as clinical information, into account, and to be robust enough to\nensure that nobody slips through the net and evades detection,' it said.\nSARS first emerged in southern China in late 2002 and spread around the\nworld to infect 8000 people in nearly 30 countries, devastating the airline\nand tourism industries. Nearly 800 people died. China, hardest-hit after\nhiding the extent of the disease in the early stages, declared victory over\nthat outbreak in July 2003. WHO declared 2004's outbreak contained in May.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 2 Jul 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Chinese Ministry of Health Website [machine trans.; edited]\n<http://www.moh.gov.cn/dsyyw/xwfb/1200407010015.htm>\n\nResults of investigation into lab-linked SARS outbreak\n------------------------------------------------------\nAs part of the investigation into the background of the SARS outbreak in\nBeijing and Anhui, the Medical Department established an investigation\ngroup made up of 7 representatives from the Military Medical Science\nAcademy, The Beijing Centers for Disease Control, and the China (national)\nCenter for Disease Control. A WHO expert also took part in the\ninvestigation. Results of the investigation are as follows:\n1. The epidemic was associated with transmission in the laboratory. (1)\nThere were 2 identified index cases who worked in the same laboratory. (2)\nThe laboratory where they worked has been continuously involved in\nscientific research related to the SARS-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV).\nAfter access to the viral institute was blocked, there were no additional\ncases of SARS. Analysis of a chest fluid sample from the mother of the\nindex case residing in Anhui, a 2nd-generation case, identified a SARS-CoV\n(HT-SCoV-2) with a gene sequence consistent with that studied in the\nlaboratory [? machine translation awkward here - Mod.MPP] (4) the 2 index\ncases working in the laboratory did not report wild animal contact and (5)\ndid not have known contact with other SARS cases during the incubation\nperiod prior to illness and (6) there was a 15-day period between their\ncontact in the laboratory and onset of illness [suggesting their infections\nwere independent of contact with each other - Mod.MPP].\n2. The virus that had been studied in the room in which the index cases\nworked was a virus from the diarrhea virus laboratory. (1) Both index cases\nassociated with the laboratory came from the diarrhea virus room. In\naddition 2 other people in this room were positive for SARS-CoV IgG and IgM\nantibodies [laboratory workers at the China CDC were tested serologically.\n- Mod.MPP], (2) specimens from the 2nd-generation case [mother of the index\ncase from Anhui] had gene group sequencing consistent with HT-SCoV under\nstudy in the diarrhea virus room, and (3) a serosurvey conducted on the\nentire staff of the Viral Institute found no individuals in other units\nwithin the Institute with evidence of SARS-CoV infection.\n3. Absence of observance of level 3 safety requirements were associated\nwith the SARS epidemic. (1) the 2 index cases associated with the\nlaboratory did not observe level 3 laboratory safety (2). Even though the\ndiarrhea laboratory requires level 3 safety procedures, work on blood\nimmune serum was conducted by the 2 cases was conducted [? without\nobserving level 3 standards -- difficult machine translation here] (3). The\ndiarrhea virus laboratory is a designated level 3 laboratory and is\nequipped with appropriate laboratory hardware, and the basic structure of\nthe laboratory conforms to regulations.\n4. Etiology of the laboratory infection link: The [? decontamination after\nresearch on the virus was not thoroughly conducted -- difficult machine\ntranslation here - Mod.MPP]. At the end of the 2004 Spring holidays, no\nadditional experiments were done on the SARS-CoV in the laboratory during\nthe period when the 2 index cases in this current outbreak were working in\nthe laboratory. The method used for decontamination of the laboratory (1\nper cent NP40 + PBS + 1 per cent SDS for 60 mins) had not been monitored\n[suggesting poor quality control of laboratory procedures -- machine\ntranslation difficult here. - Mod.MPP]\nThe findings of the investigation recognized that the source of the SARS\noutbreak was the laboratory, where safety controls were bad, enforcement of\nrules and regulations was lax, and technical personnel did not follow\ncorrect procedures, resulting in a laboratory accident which led to\ninfection of laboratory staff members.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The finding of serologic evidence of SARS CoV infection in 2 additional\nlaboratory personnel working on SARS CoV research in the same laboratory\nwhere the 2 index cases from the April/May 2004 outbreak worked is further\nevidence of laboratory exposure as the origin of the outbreak. What is\nunclear from the press releases (probably related to difficult\ntranslations) is whether there was direct contact between these 2\nadditional individuals and the index cases, or whether the exposure was\npurely laboratory contamination. The fact that both of the other\nindividuals with serologic evidence of recent SARS CoV infection had\nillnesses compatible with SARS back in February makes the latter hypothesis\n-- laboratory exposure -- more likely. We hope an official translation of\nthe findings of the investigation will be available soon. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "MPP] (4) the 2 index\ncases working in the laboratory did not report wild animal contact and (5)\ndid not have known contact with other SARS cases during the incubation\nperiod prior to illness and (6) there was a 15-day period between their\ncontact in the laboratory and onset of illness [suggesting their infections\nwere independent of contact with each other - Mod.MPP].
