The institute is known to have conducted\nexperiments using the live SARS coronavirus during Feb and Mar 2004.\n2 researchers at the institute developed SARS in late Mar and mid-Apr\n2004. However, neither is known to have conducted research using the\nlive virus, suggesting some other source of infection within the\nlaboratory or, possibly, elsewhere.\nMembers of a joint WHO-Chinese investigative team, wearing full\npersonal protective equipment, entered the institute last Fri 30 Apr\nand again yesterday [4 May 2004]. Initial findings indicate that the\ninvestigation will be complex, as no single infectious source, or\nsingle procedural error, appears likely to explain the infection in\nthe 2 researchers.\nContinuing investigation is needed to determine the source of\ninfection and to ensure that conditions, equipment, and biosafety\nprocedures within the institute do not pose an ongoing risk of SARS\ninfection to lab personnel. A large number of samples from various\nlocations within the institute were taken by Chinese investigators.\nThese samples are also undergoing analysis at the WHO SARS laboratory\nin Hong Kong.\nWHO has strongly recommended that work using the live SARS virus be\nconducted in biosafety level 3 facilities in order to minimize the\nrisk of laboratory-acquired infections. Further investigation of the\ninstitute is needed to ensure that any work using the live virus\nfully complies with the strict requirements for physical containment\nof the virus: storage, administrative control, work procedures,\npersonal protection of laboratory workers, and, authorization and\nmonitoring of all staff admitted to the laboratory.\nThe National Institute of Virology was closed on 23 Apr 2004, and\nmost of its staff were quarantined for medical observation. However,\na small number of staff have remained within the facility to continue\nessential experiments and to care for laboratory animals.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We await further information on the results of the studies mentioned\nabove. In both of the prior 2 episodes of clinically apparent SARS\ntransmission (as a result of laboratory accidents), breaches in\nstandard laboratory procedures were identified as the probable\netiology of the infections. Perhaps the bigger issue arising from\nthese incidents is the quality control of laboratory safety\nprocedures at the international level. Human error is often the\nultimate culprit in these situations. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Further investigation of the\ninstitute is needed to ensure that any work using the live virus\nfully complies with the strict requirements for physical containment\nof the virus: storage, administrative control, work procedures,\npersonal protection of laboratory workers, and, authorization and\nmonitoring of all staff admitted to the laboratory. During this period there have been no reports of\nother cases from other provinces.\nThe 3 cases are the father of the nurse who cared for the index case\nfrom Anhui, a patient on the same ward as the nurse, and a visitor of\nthis latter patient. Confirmation was made through IgM and IgG\nantibody testing and the combined clinical and epidemiologic\nhistories of these cases.\nThe 1st case in Beijing [the nurse who cared for the index case from\nAnhui] is in good condition, with 18 consecutive days without fever\nand will be discharged from the hospital shortly. The other 6 cases\nin Beijing will remain in isolation at the Ditan Hospital. 99 close\ncontacts have been released from observation.\nThe index case in Anhui has now had 11 consecutive days without fever\nand will shortly be discharged from the hospital. 89 close contacts\nhave been released from observation.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, Anhui province has reported 2 cases of SARS,\nBeijing has reported 7 cases of SARS, and other provinces have not\nreported any suspected or confirmed cases of SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last update there have been no new cases of SARS reported\nin China. With today's information, all previously suspected cases\nof SARS have been confirmed as due to SARS coronavirus infection by\nthe laboratories in China. For the investigation of such laboratory infection cases, the\ninvestigation team must base their investigation on BMBL [see below]\nor WHO guidelines, and not based on some never-before-recorded\ncomments of the individual team members.\n2. My concern is that when investigations are focused on lab\ninfection, other possible routes of infection will be neglected.\n3. I understand that one of the patients had not been working with\nlive SARS virus, suggesting that there may be an unknown source of\ninfection within the lab. Despite the closing of the institute, some\nstaff members are left behind to carry on routine work. This further\nincreases the risk of more infections.\n4. It is essential to perform a sero-survey of the members of the\ninstitute staff to see whether there any are asymptomatic infections.\n--\nTang Kin Fai, PhD\nResearch Scientist\nEnvironmental Health Institute\nNational Environment Agency, Singapore\n<TANG_Kin_Fai@nea.gov.sg>\n[Dr. Tang raises some interesting points. But WHO experts and the Chinese authorities are still\ntrying to determine the exact cause of the outbreak. The investigation has\ncentred primarily on the National Institute of Virology in Beijing, where\nexperiments using live and inactivated SARS coronavirus have been carried\nout. Two researchers at the institute developed SARS in late March and\nmid-April 2004. The outbreak was reported on April 22 and the institute was\nclosed a day later.\nPreliminary findings in the investigation have yet to identify a single\ninfectious source or single procedural error at the institute -\u00ad and it is\nconceivable that an exact answer may never be determined. Neither of the\nresearchers is known to have directly conducted experiments using live SARS\ncoronavirus. But investigators have serious concerns about biosafety\nprocedures at the institute \u00ad- including how and where procedures using\nSARS coronavirus were carried out, and how and where SARS coronavirus\nsamples were stored.\nWHO and Chinese authorities view with concern the occurrence of\nlaboratory-associated SARS cases. WHO urges all member states to view this\nlatest outbreak as an opportunity to review the biosafety practices of\ninstitutions and laboratories working with SARS coronavirus.\nDuring and after the SARS outbreak of 2003, a large number of specimens\nwere collected from possible human cases, animals and the environment.\nThese specimens, which may contain live SARS coronavirus, are still kept in\nvarious laboratories around the world. Some of them are stored in\nlaboratories at an inappropriate containment level. SARS coronavirus has\nalso been propagated in reference and research laboratories, and\ndistributed to other laboratories for research purposes. Research using\nlive and inactivated SARS coronavirus -\u00ad and other pathogens capable of\ncausing serious illness -- is being conducted in many laboratories.\nWHO has issued the following laboratory safety guidelines and recommendations:\nWHO biosafety guidelines for handling of SARS specimens (25 Apr 2003)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/biosafety2003_04_25/en/>\nSummary of the discussion and recommendations of the SARS laboratory\nworkshop of 22 Oct 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/guidelines/en/SARSLabmeeting.pdf>\nWHO post-outbreak biosafety guidelines for handling of SARS coronavirus\nspecimens and cultures (18 Dec 2003)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/biosafety2003_12_18/en/>\nIn these guidelines, WHO strongly recommends Biosafety Level 3 (BSL 3) as\nthe minimum containment level to work with live SARS coronavirus. WHO also\nurges member states to maintain a thorough inventory of laboratories\nworking with and/or storing live SARS coronavirus and to ensure that\nnecessary biosafety standards are in place.\nWHO commends the Chinese authorities for taking swift action to contain the\nlatest outbreak once it was recognized and reported, by way of extensive\ncontact tracing and the quarantine and medical observation of such\nindividuals. Once again, it has been demonstrated that SARS is a\ncontainable disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the above information, transmission of the SARS coronavirus\n(CoV) in China has been interrupted after 3 generations of cases. Due to delayed identification of the etiology of this patient's\nillness, transmission to 2nd- and 3rd-generation cases had occurred before\ncontrol measures were implemented. post, the numbers will not match the linked numbers because they will have been updated since the post was prepared.\n\nThere are now a total of 476 confirmed cases of COVID-19 (Coronavirus disease Overall, 1068 (95.9%) of all fatalities reported by mainland China were reported from Hubei province. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[3] Viral taxonomy: SARS-CoV-2\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: bioRxiv [edited]\nhttps://doi.org/10.1101/2020.02.07.937862\n\n\nRef: Gorbalenya AE: _Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus_ -- The species and its viruses, a statement of the Coronavirus Study Group. bioRxiv 2020.02.07.937862; doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.02.07.937862\n\nAbstract\n--------\nThe present outbreak of lower respiratory tract infections, including respiratory distress syndrome, is the 3rd spillover, in only 2 decades, of an animal coronavirus to humans resulting in a major epidemic. Here, the Coronavirus Study Group (CSG) of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses, which is responsible for developing the official classification of viruses and taxa naming (taxonomy) of the _Coronaviridae_ family, assessed the novelty of the human pathogen tentatively named 2019-nCoV. Based on phylogeny, taxonomy and established practice, the CSG formally recognizes this virus as a sister to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronaviruses (SARS-CoVs) of the species _Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus_ and designates it as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). To facilitate communication, the CSG further proposes to use the following naming convention for individual isolates: SARS-CoV-2/Isolate/Host/Date/Location. The spectrum of clinical manifestations associated with SARS-CoV-2 infections in humans remains to be determined. The independent zoonotic transmission of SARS-CoV and SARS-CoV-2 highlights the need for studying the entire (virus) species to complement research focused on individual pathogenic viruses of immediate significance. This research will improve our understanding of virus-host interactions in an ever-changing environment and enhance our preparedness for future outbreaks.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] COVID-19 the disease, SARS-CoV-2 the virus\nA. Date: Tue 11 Feb 2020 12:10 p.m. EST\nSource: Washington Post [edited]\nhttps://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/coronavirus-china-live-updates/2020/02/11/2b8de3ba-4c5c-11ea-b721-9f4cdc90bc1c_story.html\n\n\nWhy there are 2 new names for the coronavirus epidemic?\n-------------------------------------------------------\nThere are 2 new names associated with the epidemic unfolding in China and in 2 dozen countries around the world.\n\nThe 'novel coronavirus' will be designated 'severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2,' or more simply 'SARS-CoV-2.'\n\nThe disease it causes is 'COVID-19.'\n\nThe name of the disease was announced by the director general of the World Health Organization on Tuesday [11 Feb 2020] at a news conference. The naming of the virus came from a committee of experts who published a paper on a biology preprint site that described their research and rationale for giving the new virus a derivative name.\n\n'It will be like HIV and AIDS -- different names for virus and disease,' said Benjamin Neuman, a virologist at Texas A&M University at Texarkana and a co-author of the paper.\n\nThe naming of the virus came after close study of its genetic makeup by a dozen scientists, including Neuman, who form the Coronavirus Study Group, part of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses.\n\nNeuman said the new virus is the same species as the virus that caused the outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in China in 2002-2003.\n\n'Same species, but different member of the species,' Neuman said.\n\n[Byline: Joel Achenbach]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n---\nB. Date: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: NPR [edited]\nhttps://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2020/02/11/802352351/new-coronavirus-gets-an-official-name-from-the-world-health-organization\n\n\nThe new coronavirus disease that was first identified in Wuhan has received an official name from the World Health Organization (WHO): 'COVID-19.' 'COVI' comes from coronavirus. The 'D' stands for disease. The 19 represents 2019, the year the virus was first identified, in December [2019]. The name will apply for the 'entire spectrum' of cases, from mild to severe, according to a WHO spokesperson.\n\nThe disease had been given the temporary name '2019-nCoV' by WHO in January [2020], identifying the pathogen as a novel (previously unidentified, that is) coronavirus that first emerged in humans in 2019.\n\nAs weeks went by, people began calling it 'Wuhan virus.' But that's a problematic label. WHO guidelines for naming infectious diseases, issued in 2015, discourage names that refer to specific places, people and professions, aiming to avoid negative repercussions from stigmatizing a geographic area or a population group. In addition, no food or animal names should be used, the guidelines say -- 'swine flu' is listed as an example to be avoided after fear of that pathogen led the Egyptian government to order the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of pigs.\n\nThere are other considerations besides stigma. 'The attempt is to describe a disease using terms that people can understand as well as possible,' says Keiji Fukuda, a professor at the University of Hong Kong who helped draft the WHO guidelines. 'So not to be too jargon-y.' And speed is of the essence. Fukuda says in the absence of an easy-to-use, descriptive virus name, it's easy for other monikers to take hold. 'You really are racing pretty quickly to get a name out there. If someone coins a phrase which is catchy and which other people quickly begin repeating, it can be very hard or impossible to pull back,' Fukuda says.\n\nWhen SARS -- a member of the coronavirus family, like COVID-19 -- began spreading internationally in 2003, there was no formal process for naming it. Dr. David Heymann, who was leading the WHO's infectious diseases unit in Geneva at the time, had just left for a camping trip with his son's Boy Scout troop when he got a call about the disease's growing reach. He left his son with the other Scouts and headed back to the office. It was a quick meeting -- half an hour, maybe less. 'There were no rules at that time about how to name it, so we just went ahead and did it,' says Heymann, who is now an epidemiologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. 'The 1st thing we decided was it would be good to have a name that had the same type of a ring as AIDS -- easy to say and short.'\n\nFukuda says despite the ad hoc nature of Heymann's meeting, the group came up with a solid name.\n\nIn other recent outbreaks, naming the virus didn't go so well. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, named in 2013, now appears in the 'examples to be avoided' column of the WHO's guidance. 'That's currently held up as an example of sort of what not to do,' says Neuman. 'It name-checks a particular region of the Earth, when really a virus is happy infecting anybody that it can get to. It just happens to originate in a particular area.'\n\nIn addition, an 11-member committee from the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses has proposed a name for the virus that causes the disease now known as COVID-19. The name they are proposing is SARS-CoV-2, which, according to the naming committee 'formally recognizes this virus as a sister to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronaviruses.'\n\n[Byline: Brett Dahlberg and Elena Renken]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[We will be changing the name of this thread (the subject line) from Novel coronavirus to COVID-19 in keeping with the official naming released today. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5] Selected media reports of transmission outside mainland China\nA. USA ex China (Wuhan)\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: The Hill [edited]\nhttps://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/482490-cdc-identifies-13th-patient-with-coronavirus-in-us\n\n\nFederal health officials on Tuesday [11 Feb 2020] confirmed another case of the novel coronavirus in the USA, bringing the total number of confirmed infections to 13. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the individual was an evacuee from Wuhan, China, who was under federal quarantine in San Diego, CA. But the patient had been allowed to leave UC San Diego hospital and return to the quarantine site after a 'mix-up' with the testing results, a CDC official told reporters Tuesday [11 Feb 2020].\n\n'It turns out there was probably a mix-up, and the original test wasn't negative,' said Dr. Anne Schuchat, principal deputy director of the CDC. 'There has been a new test collected in order to understand whether the person is still symptomatic, so there was just a little bit of a mix-up there.' Schuchat did not provide any information about how the mix-up happened.\n\nAccording to a brief statement released by UC San Diego Health late Monday [10 Feb 2020], 4 patients admitted to its isolation units last week were discharged back to their quarantine quarters at Marine Corps Air Station Miramar after the CDC said coronavirus tests came back negative. Further testing revealed that 1 of the 4 patients tested positive for coronavirus, the statement said. The patient was returned to the hospital for observation and isolation until cleared by CDC for release.\n\nSchuchat said the patient's contacts with others are believed to be limited but is being reassessed. The CDC is quarantining an undisclosed number of Americans who have been evacuated from China. Individuals should be removed from quarantine sites and isolated if they begin showing symptoms or test positive for the coronavirus, Schuchat said.\n\nAccording to the university, another patient from the quarantine site was also transported to UC San Diego Health. The patient is being evaluated and will remain admitted until the test results are confirmed by the CDC.\n\n[Byline: Nathaniel Weixel and Jessie Hellmann]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It is unclear from the above media report as to whether the individual is asymptomatic or symptomatic and what impact the individual's return to the quarantine location will have for others in quarantine and the duration of the quarantine. - Mod.MPP]\n\n---\nC. Germany (Bavaria)\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: Reuters [edited]\nhttps://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-germany-cases/germany-confirms-two-more-cases-of-coronavirus-raising-overall-number-to-16-idUSKBN2052GT\n\n\nGermany on Tuesday [11 Feb 2020] confirmed 2 more cases of coronavirus in the southern state of Bavaria, raising the overall number of known cases in Europe's most populous country to 16.\n\nThe 2 new cases of coronavirus are related to infections among staff at a company in the Starnberg district west of Munich, the Bavarian health ministry said. Hong Kong\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: Hong Kong Center for Health Protection Press Release [edited]\nhttps://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202002/11/P2020021100768.htm\n\n\nLatest progress in follow up on novel coronavirus infection in Hong Mei House, Cheung Hong Estate\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today ([11 Feb 2020]) continuing to proactively follow up on the cases of novel coronavirus infection in Hong Mei House, Cheung Hong Estate in Tsing Yi. Questionnaires with the households at the A07 units of Hong Mei House have been completed. Apart from the close contacts of the resident involved in the case confirmed yesterday ([10 Feb 2020]), so far no additional case has been recorded from other households.\n\nPersonnel from the CHP have successfully traced all 34 households of all the A07 units of Hong Mei House. Active case finding was conducted to identify if there are undiagnosed cases. Five residents who were symptomatic were sent to hospitals for isolation and treatment. All of the respiratory samples tested negative for novel coronavirus.\n\nAmong the 34 households, 2 are from the confirmed cases, about 100 residents from 30 households are being arranged to be transferred to quarantine centres while the remaining 2 households currently do not reside in their units due to individual reasons.\n\nThe CHP is continuing epidemiological investigations into the cases of novel coronavirus infection in Hong Mei House. Together with the Environment Bureau, and departments including Housing Department (HD), the Electrical and Mechanical Services Department and the Architectural Services Department, the CHP is investigating and examining if environmental factors were involved in the infection of the cases.\n\nAccording to the HD's information, the HD's Maintenance Surveyor and technical inspection team has conducted a detailed inspection at the unit A07 of Hong Mei House where the 62-year-old female patient resides. The vent pipe at the toilet which was altered without permission has been sealed up. The inspection team will inspect other 07 units in the building. If unauthorised alteration of vent pipes in the toilets are detected, immediate and proper follow-up actions will be taken.\n\nAs the investigations by relevant departments are ongoing, the CHP advised that, as a precautionary measure, the residents of Cheung Hong Estate at this stage should not open the window or turn on the ventilator when using the toilet.\n\nThe Food and Environmental Hygiene Department and the HD will conduct thorough cleaning and disinfection for the building. The DH today organised a health talk for residents of Cheung Hong Estate to give health advice on the prevention of pneumonia and respiratory tract infection to residents.\n\nA spokesman for the CHP said, 'The public is strongly urged to maintain at all times strict personal and environmental hygiene, which is key to personal protection against infection and prevention of the spread of the disease in the community.'\n\nThe spokesman said, 'On the personal level, members of the public should wear a surgical mask when having respiratory symptoms, taking public transport or staying in crowded places. They should also perform hand hygiene frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes. The public should go out less and reduce social activities, and maintain appropriate social distance with other people as far as possible.\n\n'As for household environmental hygiene, members of the public are advised to maintain drainage pipes properly and regularly pour water into drain outlets (U-traps); after using the toilet, they should put the toilet lid down before flushing to avoid spreading germs.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is impressive to say the least. Lessons were definitely learned and not forgotten from the Amoy Gardens outbreak in 2003. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[6] WHO situation report 22 (as of 11 Feb 2020*)\nDate: Tue 11 Feb 2020\nSource: World Health Organization [edited]\nhttps://www.who.int/docs/default-source/coronaviruse/situation-reports/20200211-sitrep-22-ncov.pdf?sfvrsn=fb6d49b1_2\n\n\n*The situation report includes information provided by national authorities as of 10 a.m. CET.\n\nHighlights\n----------\n- No new countries reported cases of 2019-nCoV in the past 24 hours.\n\n- An advanced team is currently in Beijing to prepare an international mission and to determine the questions the international team will want to learn more about: from characteristics of the virus to public health response China put in place to try to contain the virus. The group of international experts, with a range of specializations, will work with Chinese counterparts on increasing understanding of the outbreak to guide global response efforts. Since being notified of the outbreak on [31 Dec 2020], the WHO Country Office in China, supported by the regional and international offices, has worked to support China, and indeed the world, to scale up the response. A small mission was sent to Wuhan mid-January, and the Director-General visited in January [2020].\n\n- Following WHO best practices for naming of new human infectious diseases, which were developed in consultation and collaboration with the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), WHO has named the disease COVID-19, short for 'coronavirus disease 2019.'\n\nTechnical focus: Zoonotic component of 2019-nCoV and human-animal interface\n---------------------------------------------------------------------------\nIncreasing evidence demonstrates the link between the 2019-nCoV and other similar known coronaviruses (CoV) circulating in bats, and more specifically those of the _Rhinolophus_ bat sub-species. These sub-species are abundant and widely present in Southern China, and across Asia, the Middle East, Africa and Europe. Recent studies indicate that more than 500 CoVs have been identified in bats in China. To be noted that serological studies conducted in rural population living close to bats' natural habitat in caves revealed a 2.9% bat-CoV seroprevalence, demonstrating that humans' exposure to bat-CoVs might be common (1).\n\nHowever, the route of transmission to humans at the start of this event remains unclear. Bats are rare in markets in China but hunted and sold directly to restaurants for food (2). The current most likely hypothesis is that an intermediary host animal has played a role in the transmission.\n\nBoth Chinese and external expert groups are working in trying to identify the animal source of this new virus. Identifying the animal source of the 2019-nCoV would help to ensure that there will be no further future similar outbreaks with the same virus and will also help understanding the initial spread of the disease in the Wuhan area. It would also increase our understanding of the virus and help us understand how these viruses jump from animals to humans -- thus, providing critical knowledge on how to protect us from future similar events. In this regard, strengthening food control and market hygiene activities in live food market will be essential to protect people from similar and other zoonotic diseases.\n\nReferences\n1. Wang N, Li SY, Yang XL, et al. Serological evidence of bat SARS-related coronavirus infection in humans, China. Virol Sin. 2018;33(1):104-107.\n2. Li H, Mendelsohn E, Zong C, et al. Human-animal interactions and bat coronavirus spillover potential among rural residents in Southern China. Biosaf Health. 2019;1(2):84-90.\n\n[The figures provided in the report are the figures from the National Health Commission of China from 12 Feb 2020. The\nnurse subsequently developed respiratory symptoms and was admitted to\nhospital on 7 Apr 2004. She was visited the next day by family members,\nincluding the mother and aunt. The 44 year old mother is now in a critical\ncondition. The 36 year old aunt, who was diagnosed with bilateral pneumonia\nearlier this week, is in a stable condition. Both patients are part of a\n3rd generation of cases that includes the nurse's father and 2 other\npatients hospitalized on the same ward, including one patient who shared a\nroom with the nurse.\nThe number of SARS cases either clinically confirmed or under investigation\nremains 9: 7 in Beijing and 2 (including the single fatality) in Anhui\nProvince. In Beijing, all 7 SARS cases are now being treated in isolation\nat Ditan Hospital. This is a risk reduction strategy aimed at preventing\nfurther spread through the hospital system.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case at the start of an outbreak requires\nindependent verification of results by an external international reference\nlaboratory. Such procedures are considered necessary in view of the\nimplications that confirmed SARS cases can have for international public\nhealth.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 29 Apr 2004\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhj12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO update 28 Apr 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_04_28/en/>\n\nChina reports additional SARS case -- update 3 28 April 2004\n----------------------------------\nChinese health authorities have today announced that an additional case of\nSARS is under investigation. This brings the total number of cases in\nChina, reported since 22 Apr 2004, to 9. Of these, one has died.\nThe new case in Beijing is a 49 year old woman retired doctor. On 12 Apr\n2004, she was admitted to the same hospital ward where a 20 year old nurse\nwas being treated for pneumonia. The former doctor began developing\nSARS-like symptoms on 19 Apr 2004 and on 22 Apr 2004 was transferred to\nDitan Hospital and placed in isolation. Her condition is listed as\ncritical. The 20 year old nurse, previously reported to WHO as a confirmed\ncase, has been linked to an additional 5 cases. These include the one\nreported today and 4 reported on Sunday. To date, all cases have been\nlinked to chains of transmission involving close contact with an identified\ncase. The 2nd confirmed case, who remains hospitalized in Anhui Province,\nis a 26 year old postgraduate student who had been conducting research at\nthe National Institute of Virology in Beijing. She is thought to be the\nindex case in the present outbreak.\nDuring the 2003 outbreak, the transmission of SARS was greatly amplified in\nhospital settings. As a risk reduction strategy in Beijing, all 7 SARS\ncases are now being treated in Ditan Hospital. But patients were treated or\nassessed in open wards at 7 hospitals (5 in Beijing and 2 in Anhui) before\nsuspicions of SARS were raised and procedures of isolation and infection\ncontrol were introduced. In addition, the 2 patients in Anhui travelled\nlong distances within China by train. As these events created opportunities\nfor multiple exposures, Chinese authorities have undertaken extensive\ntracing and follow-up of contacts. In Beijing, nearly 700 persons have been\nisolated or placed in quarantine.\nSARS has a relatively long incubation period, generally accepted to be 10\ndays. Based on present knowledge about the disease, people exposed to the\nvirus are not infectious before the onset of symptoms. For these reasons,\nrapid detection and isolation of cases, and rapid tracing and follow-up of\ncontacts have been used successfully to bring a SARS outbreak under control.\nInvestigation of the outbreak\nFollowing a request by the Chinese Ministry of Health, the initial members\nof a WHO team are now in Beijing to assist in the investigation and control\nof the outbreaks there and in Anhui. Investigation of the source of\ninfection will focus initially on biosafety procedures at the National\nInstitute of Virology in Beijing. 2 of the 9 cases reported by China,\nincluding the earliest case, were researchers at the institute, which has\nbeen conducting work using the live SARS coronavirus.\nChinese authorities are providing WHO with detailed clinical and\nepidemiological information on all cases. This information is important in\nassessing the severity of illness caused by the virus and the extent of its\ntransmission. Of the 8 patients currently hospitalized for treatment, the\npatient in Anhui Province continues to improve. In Beijing, 2 patients are\nin critical condition, and the others remain under treatment for pneumonia.\nIf the source of infection is determined to come from the National\nInstitute of Virology in Beijing, this will be the first SARS outbreak\ncaused by a laboratory-acquired virus, which could possibly cause different\npatterns of illness and transmission. Previous laboratory-associated cases\n-- a single case each in Singapore in September 2003 and in Taiwan, China\nin December 2003 -- did not result in any further transmission. Both cases\nfully recovered.\nIn addition, 4 cases (3 confirmed and 1 probable) were reported in\nGuangdong Province in December 2003 and January 2004, presumably acquired\nfrom an environmental source. Unlike the present outbreak, these cases were\nassociated with mild illness only and did not result in secondary\ntransmission to others.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Since the last update additional laboratory results have come in on 2\npreviously reported suspected cases. No reports of new cases associated\nwith this current outbreak have been reported in the past 24 hours.\nAccording to the China MOH daily update, confirmation of SARS Co-V\ninfection in the 2 newly confirmed cases mentioned above was based on IgM\nand IgG serologic findings. As mentioned in the discussion, official\nconfirmation will depend upon independent testing from an international\nreference laboratory. Based on the clinical and epidemiologic pictures of\nthis current outbreak, it is highly likely that these probable cases will\nbe confirmed by independent laboratory testing\n<http://www.moh.gov.cn/zhgl/zt/yqfb/1200404290003.htm>. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Both patients are part of a\n3rd generation of cases that includes the nurse's father and 2 other\npatients hospitalized on the same ward, including one patient who shared a\nroom with the nurse. There are no\nadditional case reports from other provinces.\nThe new case reported by Beijing is a 49 year old woman, a retired doctor\nfrom Beijing Xuanwu district. Three days later she was\ntransferred to another hospital in Beijing when information became\navailable that she had shared a hospital ward with the nurse who had cared\nfor the index case [hence this patient would be a 3rd-generation case -\nMod.MPP]. worldwide (22): China (HK SAR), transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=609", "date": "2004-04-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (22): CHINA (HK SAR), TRANSMISSION\n***************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 23 Apr 2004\nFrom: Joseph Dudley <jdudley@intellibridge.com>\n\nA comment on SARS transmission\n------------------------------\n[The following comment from Dr Joseph Dudley relates to the New England\nJournal of Medicine (NEJM) paper on SARS transmission at Amoy Gardens in\nHong Kong, reported in ProMED-mail post: 'SARS - worldwide (17): China (HK\nSAR), transmission.' - Mod.CP]\nI find it exceedingly interesting that so much effort and energy seems to\nbe focused on identifying exotic, rather than prosaic, mechanisms for the\ntransmission of SARS in Hong Kong and mainland China (the focus being on\nraccoons, dogs, and palm civets rather than on commensal rats and domestic\ncats in Guangzhou, or upon airflow engineering, and aerosolization\nquotients instead of rat contamination and transmission)\n<http://www1.chinadaily.com.cn/en/doc/2004-01/05/content_295598.htm>.\nAs hypothesized by Stephen Ng,\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/hot/sars/news/aug1503rats.html>,\nthe contamination of the ventilation system by feces and urine from a\nsingle infected rat -- whose territory was located in the ventilation\nshafts and in other areas of the upper floors of the building in question\n-- would appear to be an equally effective and efficient -- if not nearly\nas elegant or complex -- mechanism for the spread of the 2003 SARS outbreak\nat the Amoy Gardens complex in Hong Kong as that proposed by Yu and\ncolleagues in their NEJM paper\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/350/17/1731>.\nThe Hong Kong government appears to have invested a considerable amount of\neffort and resources into refuting Ng's idea that rats might have been\ninvolved in the etiology of the 2003 SARS outbreak in the Amoy Gardens\ncomplex. See press release at\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200402/28/0228205.htm>.\nNonetheless, I submit that Occam's Razor might well be an appropriate tool\nfor cutting through much of the current confusion and obfuscation on this\nissue, although the implications which follow therefrom -- that urban rats\nand cats may be serving as reservoirs and vectors for the SARS virus in\nHong Kong -- and/or mainland China -- are extremely unsettling and,\nperhaps, even frightening in terms of their long-term epidemiological and\npublic health significance <http://www.britannica.com/eb/article?eu=58133>\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occam's_Razor>.\n--\nJoseph P Dudley, PhD\nSenior Analyst, Biosecurity & Agriculture\nINTELLIBRIDGE\n1101 30th Street, NW Suite 100B\nWashington DC 20007\n<jdudley@intellibridge.com>\n[Dr Dudley has added the following further comment in response to an\nobservation by a ProMED-mail moderator (MPP) that a more generalized\nspread, nearly impossible to interrupt, might be seen if a large number of\nfreely roaming animals were involved in transmission. - Mod.CP]\nAlthough SARS obviously didn't originate in rats, the current evidence\nseems to indicate that what we are witnessing and tracking at this time is\na significant evolutionary event involving the process of the tentative\nearly stages of the establishment ['adaptation'] of a newly-mutated viral\npathogen (the SARS coronavirus) in a new stable reservoir host (rats, cats,\nhumans, etc.).\nIf we are fortunate, the SARS virus, in its current form, may not be able\nto establish itself as a self-sustaining zoonotic pathogen within rat\npopulations, and the disease may only occur in rats as a transient and\ndead-end secondary host (in which case, the closing of wildlife street\nmarkets -- for raccoons, dogs, palm civets, etc. -- could successfully\nprevent subsequent outbreaks). The current data do suggest that this may in\nfact be the case at present.\nIt cannot be ruled out that the hypothesized role of rats in the Amoy\nGardens outbreak could have involved mechanical transmission rather than\nurine/fecal contamination (as might have occurred had a rat crawled/swam\nout of a SARS-contaminated toilet and then tried -- successfully or\nunsuccessfully -- to exit the toilet room by means of the ventilation fan\nopening or by means of a ventilation shaft).\nIt seems possible, however, that if the intensive rat-eradication efforts\nundertaken at the sites in Guangzhou or Hong Kong, where SARS outbreaks\noccurred, were, in fact, successful, or nearly so, we could still have a\npossibility of latent SARS infections circulating in such a very small\nnumber of individual rats that we would not expect the disease to have\nrevealed its presence in urban rat populations at this early date; at least\nuntil the next time there is a recurrence of the reported scenario in\nGuangzhou this year, in which several rats infected with SARS were trapped\nin an apartment of an isolated SARS victim who has no known contacts with\nany of the suspected wildlife hosts for the SARS virus\n<http://www1.chinadaily.com.cn/en/doc/2004-01/05/content_295598.htm>.\nFor all of these reasons, it is extremely important for any and all\npotential SARS reservoirs and transmission mechanisms to be thoroughly, and\nexhaustively, investigated. We must also recognize that what is true for\nthe SARS virus today may not necessarily be true tomorrow, as demonstrated\nover the past year with the avian influenza A (H5N1) virus. Demonstration\nof past recombination events in the SARS-CoV lineage indicates this virus\nhas a clear potential for rapid unpredictable change that makes this\npathogen an extremely challenging adversary for drug and vaccine\ndevelopment well as for public health management (Rest & Mindell 2003).\nReference:\nRest JS, Mindell DP. SARS-CoV has a recombinant polymerase and\ncoronaviruses have a history of host-shifting. Infection, Genetics and\nEvolution 2003; 3: 219-25. <http://www.ummz.lsa.umich.edu/molsys/RM03IGE.pdf>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This thread is now closed - Mod.CP]", "summary": "It seems possible, however, that if the intensive rat-eradication efforts\nundertaken at the sites in Guangzhou or Hong Kong, where SARS outbreaks\noccurred, were, in fact, successful, or nearly so, we could still have a\npossibility of latent SARS infections circulating in such a very small\nnumber of individual rats that we would not expect the disease to have\nrevealed its presence in urban rat populations at this early date; at least\nuntil the next time there is a recurrence of the reported scenario in\nGuangzhou this year, in which several rats infected with SARS were trapped\nin an apartment of an isolated SARS victim who has no known contacts with\nany of the suspected wildlife hosts for the SARS virus\n<http://www1.chinadaily.com.cn/en/doc/2004-01/05/content_295598.htm>. Nonetheless, I submit that Occam's Razor might well be an appropriate tool\nfor cutting through much of the current confusion and obfuscation on this\nissue, although the implications which follow therefrom -- that urban rats\nand cats may be serving as reservoirs and vectors for the SARS virus in\nHong Kong -- and/or mainland China -- are extremely unsettling and,\nperhaps, even frightening in terms of their long-term epidemiological and\npublic health significance <http://www.britannica.com/eb/article?eu=58133>\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occam's_Razor>.\n I find it exceedingly interesting that so much effort and energy seems to\nbe focused on identifying exotic, rather than prosaic, mechanisms for the\ntransmission of SARS in Hong Kong and mainland China (the focus being on\nraccoons, dogs, and palm civets rather than on commensal rats and domestic\ncats in Guangzhou, or upon airflow engineering, and aerosolization\nquotients instead of rat contamination and transmission)\n<http://www1.chinadaily.com.cn/en/doc/2004-01/05/content_295598.htm>. It cannot be ruled out that the hypothesized role of rats in the Amoy\nGardens outbreak could have involved mechanical transmission rather than\nurine/fecal contamination (as might have occurred had a rat crawled/swam\nout of a SARS-contaminated toilet and then tried -- successfully or\nunsuccessfully -- to exit the toilet room by means of the ventilation fan\nopening or by means of a ventilation shaft). The case details are as follows: a 2 year old boy, who became ill\non 10 Apr 2004 with fever and rash over hands and mouth. He was admitted to\nQueen Elizabeth Hospital on 14 Apr, discharged on 15 Apr, and recovered. He\nhad not travelled recently.\nCumulative Total in 2004: 3 imported and 0 local cases. The total number of\ncases in previous years: 60 in 1998, 22 in 1999, 6 in 2000, 30 in 2001, 5\nin 2002, 1 in 2003.\nIt is essential that the public stays alert to the threat of EV-71\ninfection and take the following preventive measures in prevention of the\ndisease: wash hands before eating and after going to toilet and changing\ndiapers; cover mouth and nose when coughing and sneezing; maintain good\nventilation; clean thoroughly toys or appliances which are contaminated by\nnasal or oral secretions.\nParents are advised to seek medical advice if their children develop\nsymptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease. Children suffering from the\ninfection should stay at home and avoid contacting other children until the\nillness is over. For more information on EV-71, members of the public can\nbrowse the Central Health Education Unit website <http://www.cheu.gov.hk>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a generally benign form of\nenterovirus 71 (EV-71) infection which produces superficial rashes on the\nmouth and extremities of the limbs of children. In a small proportion of\ncases there may be severe neurological sequelae (For a description of a\nrecent fatal case in Macao, see 'Enterovirus 71 encephalitis, fatal - China\n(Macao) 20040415.1027'). HFMD is relatively rare in Europe, North America,\nand Australasia, but since 1997 there has been a significant increase in\nEV71 epidemic activity throughout the Asia-Pacific region, often associated\nwith severe encephalitis and high case fatality rates. The emergence of\nlarge-scale epidemic activity in the Asia-Pacific region has been\nassociated with the circulation of 3 genetic lineages that appear to be\nundergoing rapid evolutionary change. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "It is essential that the public stays alert to the threat of EV-71\ninfection and take the following preventive measures in prevention of the\ndisease: wash hands before eating and after going to toilet and changing\ndiapers; cover mouth and nose when coughing and sneezing; maintain good\nventilation; clean thoroughly toys or appliances which are contaminated by\nnasal or oral secretions. The\nteam, which is expected to begin work on Wednesday, will include experts in\nepidemiology, virology, infection control, and laboratory biosafety.\nResults of investigations to date point to laboratory research at the\nNational Institute of Virology in Beijing as the likely source of the\noutbreak. The institute has been engaged in research with the SARS\ncoronavirus, including the development of a vaccine.\nTwo of the recently reported cases were conducting research at the\nlaboratory: a 26 year old female postgraduate student from Anhui Province,\nand a 31 year old man. The dates of symptom onset in the 2 cases were\nseparated by 23 days, suggesting that more than one opportunity for\nexposure may have occurred in the laboratory from mid-March through early\nApril 2004. Authorities have closed the virology institute and placed its\nmore than 200 employees under medical observation. Numerous environmental\nsamples from the laboratory have been taken to help assess possible sources\nof contamination, and these samples will be shared with WHO.\nUnderstanding and eliminating the source of infection are critical steps in\nbringing the outbreak under control. An equally important activity is to\nquickly detect all chains of transmission and interrupt them through rapid\ncase detection, tracing and follow-up of contacts, and infection control in\nhospitals.\nWHO is concerned about additional opportunities for exposure that may have\nalready occurred. Some patients were treated or assessed in several\ndifferent hospitals before a suspicion of SARS led to the introduction of\nadequate precautionary measures, including isolation of patients and strict\nprocedures for infection control. One patient travelled a long distance\ntwice by train within China while symptomatic.\nChinese authorities have heightened surveillance and reporting for\nSARS-like illness in health care facilities and have sent investigative\nteams to Anhui Province.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, China has reported that 8 people have been clinically\ndiagnosed as SARS cases or are under investigation for possible SARS\ninfection -- 6 in Beijing and 2, including the single fatality, in Anhui\nProvince. As of today, close to 1000 contacts of these cases are under\nmedical observation, including 640 in Beijing and 353 in Anhui.\nThe most recent cases, announced on Sunday, are 4 close contacts of a 20\nyear old nurse who treated the Anhui student at a Beijing hospital. The\ncases -\u00ad all in Beijing -\u00ad are currently under investigation. They include\nthe nurse\u0092s mother, father, aunt, and a woman who shared a hospital ward\nwith the nurse when she was undergoing treatment. Onset of symptoms for all\n4 occurred between 16 and 19 Apr 2004. The nurse\u0092s mother is in serious\ncondition following the development of pneumonia. The other 3 people are in\na stable condition.\nIn addition, health authorities have reported that 2 doctors who treated\nthe postgraduate student during her hospitalization in Hefai, Anhui, have\ndeveloped fever. A person in close contact with one of the doctors has also\ndeveloped fever.\nTo date, all diagnosed cases and cases under investigation have been linked\nto chains of transmission involving close personal contact with an\nidentified case. There is no evidence of wider transmission in the community.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours since the last update (20040425.1150), there are the\nadditional reports of fever in 2 physicians treating the index case in\nAnhui and in a close contact of one of these 2 physicians. According the\nChina Minstry of Health (MOH) website (<http://www.moh.gov.cn>), there has\nbeen the implementation of increased surveillance for 'atypical pneumonia'\ncountry-wide, but no additional suspected cases have been identified.\nAs with 2003, there is an 'outbreak' of newswire reports and speculations\non this current situation, and for this reason we have chosen to be highly\nselective of newswire information we post, preferring to rely upon the\nofficial reports available from WHO and the Chinese MOH. Lessons were\nclearly learned after the 2003 outbreak, and there is now apparent\ntransparency in reporting. We will continue to screen newswire reports for\npossible early introduction of probable SARS activity in new geographic\nregions (outside of the currently identified Beijing and Anhui provinces),\nincluding any possible international spread.\nWe are still awaiting information on the independent laboratory testing of\nspecimens from the currently identified cases in China. Until these results\nare available, the cases are being classified as probable and suspected.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case at the start of an outbreak requires\nindependent verification of results by an external international reference\nlaboratory. Such procedures are considered necessary in view of the\nimplications that confirmed SARS cases can have for international public\nhealth. Irrespective of the 'tentative' classifications, appropriate\ninvestigations and disease control measures have been implemented, under\nthe assumption that infection with SARS coronavirus has truly occurred.\nHence, it is a semantic discussion that will not delay appropriate control\nmeasures to interrupt transmission.\nFrom the information currently available, there is now evidence of 3\ngenerations of transmission. The 1st generation involved the index case\nfrom Anhui, and possibly a 2nd '1st-generation' case, the postdoctoral\nstudent from Beijing whose onset of illness was 23 days after the onset of\nillness of the index case from Anhui. The 2nd generation included the\nmother of the index case from Anhui and the nurse who cared for the index\ncase from Anhui while she was hospitalized in Beijing, and possibly the\nphysicians who cared for her while hospitalized in Anhui. The 3rd\ngeneration of cases are the family members of the nurse (from the 2nd\ngeneration), a patient hospitalized in the same ward as the nurse before\nSARS was identified as a possible diagnosis for the nurse's illness, and a\nclose contact of one of the physicians who treated the index patient in\nAnhui. This pattern of nosocomial spread due to lack of early\nidentification of SARS as a possible diagnosis is very reminiscent of the\noutbreak in 2003.\nConcern about possible spread outside of the current identified 'close\ncontact' circle around these cases is warranted. It is to be hoped that the\nthreshold for suspicion of possible SARS will be lowered country-wide, so\ncases that may occur related to transmission while travelling on the trains\nbetween Anhui Province and Beijing will be identified and isolated early,\npreventing further generations of transmission.\nIn addition, there are appropriate concerns about laboratory safety\nprocedures. This is now the 3rd incident of SARS transmission within a\nlaboratory working on SARS research. The first 2 occurred in Singapore and\nTaiwan (see ProMED-mail postings SARS - worldwide (185): Taiwan, probable\nlab exposure 20031217.3081 and SARS - worldwide (174): Singapore laboratory\nexposure 20030923.2397). Since the 2003 outbreak, it seems as though\nlaboratory exposure is a higher risk factor than the possible zoonotic\nexposure. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "The 3rd\ngeneration of cases are the family members of the nurse (from the 2nd\ngeneration), a patient hospitalized in the same ward as the nurse before\nSARS was identified as a possible diagnosis for the nurse's illness, and a\nclose contact of one of the physicians who treated the index patient in\nAnhui. Since the 2003 outbreak, it seems as though\nlaboratory exposure is a higher risk factor than the possible zoonotic\nexposure.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2004-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Anhui", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Anhui Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hefai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205627", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (17): China (HK SAR), transmission", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205627", "date": "2004-04-23 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (17): CHINA (HONG kONG SAR), TRANSMISSION\n**********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 22 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promendmail.org>\nSource: Reuters Health, Wed 21 Apr 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.reutershealth.com/en/index.html>\n\nSARS spread in buildings by airborne droplets\n---------------------------------------------\nVirus-laden aerosols appear to be responsible for the large community\noutbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) that occurred in Hong\nKong in 2003, according to results of study of detailed airflow-dynamics.\nAlthough this type of transmission is probably not common, 'airborne spread\nof a concentrated source of virus can infect many persons within a short\nperiod of time,' lead investigator Dr Ignatius T S Yu told Reuters Health.\nIn such circumstances: 'Avoidance of close contacts alone may not be\nadequate,' he added. 'The prevention of aerosolization of the virus source\nshould take priority,' especially in hospitals. 'One should think about\ncontaining and/or removing the aerosols through engineering means, and\npersonal protective gear will have to be stepped up.'\nThe SARS outbreak that Dr Yu and his team investigated affected more than\n300 residents of Amoy Gardens, a private housing complex, they explain in\nthe 22 Apr 2004 issue of the New England Journal of Medicine [N Engl J Med\n2004; 1710-2\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/350/17/1731>,1731-9\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/short/350/17/1710>]. Hypotheses to\nexplain the spread include direct person-to-person contact, transmission\nthrough the sewage disposal system, use of communal facilities, and even\nroof rats running through sewage and water pipes. The epidemic curve and\nspatial distribution of the cases, however, are consistent with virus-laden\naerosols spread from a single source, the report indicates.\nDr Yu, at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, and colleagues obtained\ndetailed site plans of the drainage system of the housing complex, along\nwith meteorological data. They modeled the effects of turbulence on airflow\nand the dispersal of pollutants. Among the initial 187 cases in the housing\ncomplex, the index patient and 99 others lived in one building. The\nepidemic started on 21 Mar 2003 and peaked on 24 Mar 2003, with onset of\nsymptoms occurring between 24 and 26 Mar 2003 in most patients. The risk of\ncontracting the infection was 5 times higher in units on middle and upper\nfloors than on lower floors.\nAn environmental health team found that a bathroom exhaust fan could have\ndistributed contaminated aerosols into an airshaft connected to other units\nin the building. It appears that wind then distributed the aerosols from\nopen doors and windows to other buildings.\nThe index patient had extremely high concentrations of SARS coronavirus in\nfeces and urine compared with respiratory secretions, the authors note.\nBecause this patient had used a toilet in the building during a bout of\ndiarrhea, the authors suggest that 'huge numbers of aerosols [were\ngenerated] when toilets were flushed.'\nSimilar events would require 'a large concentrated dose of the virus\nsource, a mechanism of dispersing the source into fine aerosols that can be\nsuspended in air for a long period of time, and the appropriate weather and\nwind conditions and topography so that the virus could be spread to a large\nnumber of people in a short period of time,' Dr Yu said. In such an event,\n'many persons could be affected within a very short period of time [and]\ntransmission [could be] much more efficient than close contact\ntransmission,' he added. The clinical implications of airborne transmission\nare particularly important for infection control in hospitals and in public\nindoor settings such as airplanes and schools,' Dr Chad J Roy and Donald K\nMilton write in a related editorial. Dr Roy at the US Army Medical Research\nInstitute of Infectious Diseases in Fort Detrick, Maryland, and Dr Milton\nat Harvard School of Public Health in Boston recommend aggressive\nair-sanitation measures, such as upper-room germicidal ultraviolet irradiation.\nDr Yu and his colleagues are now planning field experiments using tracer\nparticles or gas under similar weather conditions. 'Our team of medical\nepidemiologists and ventilation engineers will continue to collaborate to\nstudy other diseases and health conditions, infectious or non-infectious,\nrelated to airflows and ventilations.'\n[byline: Karla Gale]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A significant feature of the Amoy Gardens incident would appear to have\nbeen the high concentration of SARS coronavirus present in the feces and\nurine of the index case, relative to the amount present in respiratory\nsecretions. If this is a general phenomenon, it would support other\nobservations that handwashing was among the most important factors in\ncontaining the spread of infection within hospitals. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The SARS outbreak that Dr Yu and his team investigated affected more than\n300 residents of Amoy Gardens, a private housing complex, they explain in\nthe 22 Apr 2004 issue of the New England Journal of Medicine [N Engl J Med\n2004; 1710-2\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/350/17/1731>,1731-9\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/short/350/17/1710>]. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Similar events would require 'a large concentrated dose of the virus\nsource, a mechanism of dispersing the source into fine aerosols that can be\nsuspended in air for a long period of time, and the appropriate weather and\nwind conditions and topography so that the virus could be spread to a large\nnumber of people in a short period of time,' Dr Yu said. Dr Roy at the US Army Medical Research\nInstitute of Infectious Diseases in Fort Detrick, Maryland, and Dr Milton\nat Harvard School of Public Health in Boston recommend aggressive\nair-sanitation measures, such as upper-room germicidal ultraviolet irradiation.\n Virus-laden aerosols appear to be responsible for the large community\noutbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) that occurred in Hong\nKong in 2003, according to results of study of detailed airflow-dynamics.\n Hypotheses to\nexplain the spread include direct person-to-person contact, transmission\nthrough the sewage disposal system, use of communal facilities, and even\nroof rats running through sewage and water pipes. In such an event,\n'many persons could be affected within a very short period of time [and]\ntransmission [could be] much more efficient than close contact\ntransmission,' he added. The clinical implications of airborne transmission\nare particularly important for infection control in hospitals and in public\nindoor settings such as airplanes and schools,' Dr Chad J Roy and Donald K\nMilton write in a related editorial. [A significant feature of the Amoy Gardens incident would appear to have\nbeen the high concentration of SARS coronavirus present in the feces and\nurine of the index case, relative to the amount present in respiratory\nsecretions. Our team of medical\nepidemiologists and ventilation engineers will continue to collaborate to\nstudy other diseases and health conditions, infectious or non-infectious,\nrelated to airflows and ventilations.' It was the\nfirst reported death from SARS since a deadly outbreak last year claimed\nhundreds of lives worldwide. China, the country worst hit by severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, set up emergency controls as it confirmed 2 other\npeople were confirmed to have contracted the disease.\nHong Kong, which was also badly hit last year, raised its alert level. The\nlocal government said in a statement it had sent extra staff to the airport\nand the city's railway station that receives through-trains from China to\nspot ill people.\nChina's health ministry said a woman died, apparently of SARS, on 19 Apr\n2004 after taking care of her daughter, a 26 year old medical student who\nstudied for 2 weeks in a disease control laboratory in Beijing before\nreturning home ill to the eastern province of Anhui. The daughter is one of\nthe 2 patients confirmed to have contracted by the disease. The other\nconfirmed patient, a 20 year old nurse at a Beijing hospital, had treated\nthe medical student, it said in a statement on its website.\nThe ministry quoted experts as saying the source of infection might have\nbeen the lab, adding it had been sealed. 'The investigation shows...the\npatient in Beijing has epidemiological links with the confirmed SARS case\npatient in Anhui,' it added. A 31 year old male post-doctoral student [in\nBeijing] who worked alongside [the 26 year old patient from Anhui] in the\nlab was also suspected of having the disease. The cases in Beijing were the\nfirst recorded in China's capital since it was ravaged by the outbreak last\nyear.\nChina's State Administration of Quality Supervision, Inspection and\nQuarantine issued a circular ordering the quarantine of anyone found with a\nfever at its borders. China had learned from last year's epidemic and would\nkeep the public alerted, vice minister of health Zhu Qinsheng said, after\nattending a meeting of health ministers from South East Asia, Japan, South\nKorea, and China in the northern Malaysian state of Penang. 'We learned\nfrom the experience of last year's SARS outbreak and this time we will do\nour best and immediately alert the public. We are confident that the\nsituation will be under control,' he was quoted as saying. 'We are\nprepared. We are confident that SARS will not spread like it did in the\npast,' he told reporters.\n[The patient from Beijing], a nurse from Beijing's Jiangong Hospital, was\nin an isolation ward in Beijing's Ditan Hospital, the health ministry said.\nAuthorities have placed 188 people who had close contact with [her] under\nmedical observation, 5 of who have shown symptoms of SARS and been isolated\nat Ditan, it said. The Beijing government said the hospital was well\nprepared to deal with the case and 3 wards had been cleared and disinfected\nfor other possible SARS patients.\n[The patient from Anhui] was in stable condition at a university hospital\nin the Anhui provincial capital of Hefei and another 117 people in Anhui\nwere under medical observation, it said. Three of them had been isolated\nwith fever symptoms, the official Xinhua news agency said. SARS is a type\nof atypical pneumonia that first emerged in the southern Chinese province\nof Guangdong late in 2002, spread to Hong Kong, Beijing and on to more than\n30 countries, infecting about 8000 people and killing nearly 800. China\nconfirmed 4 more cases of SARS in Guangdong early this year, the first\nsince the global outbreak was declared over in July. All 4 have since\nrecovered.\n[byline: Jonathan Ansfield]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 23 Apr 2004 19:49:05 +0800\nFrom: Jack Soo <kyip@gmx.net>\nSource: China MOH website press release [Trans. by Jack Soo]\n<http://www.moh.gov.cn/zhgl/zt/yqfb/1200404230004.htm>\n\nCases of [atypical pneumonia] in Anhui and Beijing; experts [suspect]\nsource may be lab infection\n--------------------------------------------------\nA medical department news spokesperson confirmed that the medical expert\ngroup has identified] a [case of atypical pneumonia infection] in Anhui\nProvince and that [Beijing province also has a case of atypical pneumonia].\n[The patient in] Anhui, is a 26 year old [woman], Anhui medical college\nmaster graduate student. During the period 7--22 March she was studying in\nthe Chinese Viral disease control laboratory and on 23 Mar 2004 she took\nthe train to return to Hefei, Anhui. On 25 Mar 2004 she developed fever and\ntook the train back from Anhui to Beijing. On 29 Mar 2004 she underwent a\nmedical examination, was found to have pneumonia and was admitted to\nhospital at the [?Beijing Healthy Palace] hospital. On 2 Apr 2004 she took\nthe train to return to Anhui Huai Nan for treatment. On 4 Apr 2004 she was\ntransferred to the Anhui Medical College for continued treatment of viral\npneumonia. Beginning 31 Mar 2004, her mother continuously cared for and\naccompanied her and provided nursing care.\nOn 8 Apr 2004 [her mother] developed a fever and was admitted to hospital\nin the Anjui Medical College Hospital with viral pneumonia. On 19 Apr, her\nmother worsened and died. Upon receipt of notification of this death by the\nlocal medical department, the early warning mechanism was activated. On 21\nApr 2004, the Anhui Province Disease Control center had IgG positive blood\ntests [for SARS Co-V], this was reexamined by the Jiangsu Province Disease\nControl Center which also had IgM and IgG seropositivity.\nOn the evening of 21 Apr 2004, the Anhui Province Health Department\nreported the findings to the Medical Department. On the morning of 22 Apr\n2004, the Medical Department expert group rushed to Anhui. On 23 Apr 2004\nthe China Center for Disease Control senate compared the laboratory tests\n(IgG and IgM findings). The medical department expert group reviewed the 2\npatients clinical courses/presentations, the laboratory examinations and\nthe epidemiologic investigation and [confirmed] the diagnosis of atypical\npneumonia in the index case from Anhui [the graduate student] and referred\nautopsy specimens for confirmation on the index case's mother.\nAnhui Province has conducted strict disinfection of the areas of the 2\npatients and has identified 117 close contacts of these 2 patients. At\npresent, the index case is stable, and one of her close contacts has\ndeveloped fever.\nFurther investigation revealed that in Beijing on 22 Apr 2004 there was a\nreport of a case of atypical pneumonia that is epidemiologically linked to\nthe index case in Anhui. The case in Beijing, a nurse, cared for the index\ncase from Anhui during the period 29 Mar to ? Apr when the patient was in\nthe Healthy Palace Hospital in Beijing. Given the epidemiologic linking of\nthe 2 patients, Beijing has classified the case in Beijing as a case of\natypical pneumonia [SARS] infection. Currently the case in Beijing is\nafebrile. Of 188 close contacts of this case in Beijing, 5 have fever. 3 of\nthese 5 are close relatives of the Beijing case and 2 are from the hospital\ncontacts at the Earth Temple Hospital (one a patient and one a visitor\ncaring for a patient).\nOn 23 Apr 2004, Beijing reported another case of atypical pneumonia (SARS).\nThis patient is a 31 year old man, doing postdoctoral work at the China\nCenter for Disease Control Viral Disease laboratory. On 17 Apr [???], on 22\nApr 2004 he was admitted to the Earth Temple Hospital. On review of his\nclinical and epidemiologic history, Beijing immediately classified him as a\ncase of atypical pneumonia [SARS].\nIn view of the fact that the index patient in Anhui and the patient from\nBeijing both worked in the China Center for Disease Control viral\nlaboratory the epidemiological investigation is pointing towards the\nlaboratory as the source of infection and further investigations among the\nlaboratory staff are in process. The Medical Department has sealed the\nChina Center for Disease Control Viral laboratory and is investigating the\npersonnel, obtaining laboratory specimens from sampling within the\nlaboratory. Safety control measures are being investigated and implemented.\nThe medical department has requested the fever monitoring be conducted\nunder supervision [of laboratory staff?]. The medical department has\nreported to the World Health Organization and to Hong Kong. The Red Cross\nSociety of China has reported this to the Taiwan Red Cross.\n--\nJack Soo\n<kyip@gmx.net>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[From the descriptions provided in the 2 statements above, it appears as\nthough the original infection may have been a laboratory accident, although\nmore detailed information on the index case contacts/exposures prior to\nonset of illness are not provided. What is not clear is whether the\nlaboratory contamination was from a specimen from another as yet\nunidentified patient with SARS coronavirus (Co-V) infection, or from\nresearch being conducted on the SARS Co-V. While confirmation of SARS Co-V\ninfection from an independent international reference laboratory is still\npending, the epidemiology described above with probable secondary cases\n[including a health care worker caring for the index case and a second\nlaboratory researcher in the same laboratory as the index case] and a death\n[in a close family member contact caring for the index case] is reminiscent\nof the SARS outbreak in 2003. Appropriate isolation measures appear to be\nunder way now. Remembering the 2003 outbreak, a cause for concern here is\nthat the case currently in hospital in Anhui traveled between Beijing and\nAnhui twice while apparently clinically ill. Her mode of transportation was\non a public train, and may have been associated with exposure to a wider\nnet of individuals during transportation. Information on the identification\nof all potential contacts while in route isn't clear at this point. In\naddition, we do not know whether respiratory precautions were in place for\nthe early part of her hospital admission. The occurrence of a case in a\nhospital nurse who cared for her suggests that respiratory precautions were\nnot in place for the initial period of her hospitalization in Beijing. We\nawait further news on the epidemiology investigations and observations of\nknown contacts of these cases. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "--\nJack Soo\n<kyip@gmx.net>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n What is not clear is whether the\nlaboratory contamination was from a specimen from another as yet\nunidentified patient with SARS coronavirus (Co-V) infection, or from\nresearch being conducted on the SARS Co-V. MOH [machine trans. edited]\n<http://www.moh.gov.cn/zhgl/zt/yqfb/1200404250003.htm>\n\nFrom the Medical Department Public News Office: 25 Apr 2004 SARS update\n----------------------\nDuring the period 10 AM 24 Apr 2004 through 10 AM 25 Apr 2004, Beijing\nreported 4 suspected cases of SARS. There were no reports of additional\ncases from other provinces.\nThe 4 suspected cases reported by Beijing include contacts of [the nurse\nwho had cared for the index patient from Anhui]. Her father has a fever\nwithout signs of pneumonia, her mother has fever with signs of worsening\npneumonia, her aunt with a fever and no signs of pneumonia, and a patient\nfrom the ward [?from same room as either the nurse or the index patient]\nwith a fever and no signs of pneumonia.\nAt present there are 337 close contacts of the patients in Beijing that are\nunder observation, and 133 close contacts of the patient in Anhui [the\nindex case] who are under observation.\nSince 22 Apr 2004, there has been one case of SARS confirmed in Anhui and\none suspected case of SARS from Anhui. There has been one case of SARS\nconfirmed in Beijing and 4 suspected cases of SARS reported from\nBeijing. There have been no additional confirmed or suspected cases from\nother provinces.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2] China - MOH / Anhui Province announcement\nDate: 25 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: China MOH / Anhui Province Health Dept. announcement [machine\ntransl.; edited]\n<http://www.moh.gov.cn/zhgl/zt/fdgzdt/1200404250002.htm>\n\nOn 23 Apr 2004, our Province [Anhui] has diagnosed 2 patients with SARS\nwith a history of train travel to the province.\nOn 6 Mar 2004, there was travel on the Hefei - Beijing line 1410 train\nOn 23 Mar 2004, there was travel on the Beijing - Hefei T63 'inferior'\ntrain [?second class]\nOn 27 Mar 2004, there was travel on the Hefei - Beijing T64 'inferior'\ntrain of 17 compartments [?second class]\nOn 2 Apr 2004 there was travel on the Beijing - Huai Nan 1409 train of 13\ncompartments\nAll passengers who were riding on the above-mentioned coaches and\ncompartments: please report to your local disease control office for\nmedical evaluation/consultation.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] Taiwan response - CDC Taiwan\nDate: 25 Apr 2004\nFrom: Peter Chang MD <wpc94@yahoo.com>\nSource: CDC Taiwan 23 Apr 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n<http://203.65.72.83/En/ITC/ShowPublication.ASP?RecNo=959>\n\nTaiwan SARS Responsive Level Escalated to Level A\n------------------------------------------------\nIn response to 2 suspected SARS cases reported in China, Taiwan Department\nof Health has announced today that starting 24 Apr 2004, the SARS\nresponsive level will be escalated from 'SARS and other emerging infectious\ndiseases preparedness phase' to level A, which is defined as when the 1st\nconfirmed case of SARS is reported globally.\nAccording to the press releases from WHO and Department of Health, Hong\nKong, 2 suspected SARS cases in Beijing and Anhui respectively have been\nreported. Please refer to <http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_04_22/en/> and\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm> for further information.\nTherefore, the Department of Health has resumed 'SARS control and\nprevention committee' meetings to improve our level of response to SARS.\nThe following precautionary measures have been adopted:\n1. All incoming passengers are required to fill in the 'SARS and other\ncommunicable diseases survey form' and to have their body temperature taken\nby an infrared thermal camera.\n2. Since\n16 Dec 2003, the Chinese Ministry of Health has reported 4 cases of SARS (3\nconfirmed and 1 probable). All 4 cases are from Guangdong, the same\nprovince where the first case of SARS in 2003 was confirmed in a 32 year\nold man and where the first cases of SARS were identified in November 2002.\nAll 4 patients have recovered from their illness and have been discharged\nfrom the hospital. None of their contacts have developed SARS-like illness.\nThe source of infection of the 4 patients is not known; however, SARS\ncoronavirus (SARS-CoV), the virus that causes SARS, has been collected from\ncages that housed civet cats in the restaurant where one of the patients\nworked. The Chinese Ministry of Health continues to work in close\ncollaboration with WHO to broaden the investigation and enhance\nsurveillance throughout China. For additional information about these\ncases, see: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/archive/en/>.\nCurrently CDC and WHO do not recommend that the general public avoid travel\nto any of the countries affected by SARS. Previous SARS research has shown\nthat SARS can be controlled and contained through early detection,\nisolation of suspect cases, and tracing of their contacts. In addition,\nbased on limited available data, it would be prudent for travelers to China\nto avoid going to live food markets and having direct contact with civets\nand other wildlife from these markets. Although there is no evidence that\ndirect contact with civets or other wild animals from live food markets has\nled to cases of SARS, viruses similar to the SARS-CoV have been found in\nthese animals, and some humans working with these animals have evidence of\ninfection with SARS-CoV, or a very similar virus.\nCDC will provide updates on SARS\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/index.htm>) and Travelers' Health\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/travel>) websites as further information becomes\navailable.\nAdditional information about SARS for clinicians and the public can also be\nfound at the CDC SARS website (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars)> and the\nWHO SARS website (<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/index.html>).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although there is no evidence that\ndirect contact with civets or other wild animals from live food markets has\nled to cases of SARS, viruses similar to the SARS-CoV have been found in\nthese animals, and some humans working with these animals have evidence of\ninfection with SARS-CoV, or a very similar virus.
