Investigation of the case, including extensive\nlaboratory testing and tracing and observation of contacts, is under way.\nThe case is a 20 year old nurse who developed SARS-like symptoms in Beijing\non 5 Apr 2004 and was admitted to hospital on 7 Apr 2004. As her condition\ndid not improve, she was transferred on 14 Apr 2004 to a second Beijing\nhospital, where she was placed in intensive care. Results of initial blood\ntests, received today, indicate a likely infection with the SARS\ncoronavirus, but further testing is needed before a diagnosis of SARS can\nbe confirmed.\nContact tracing has identified 171 contacts, who have been placed under\nobservation. Of these, 5 have developed fever. If confirmed, this will be\nthe first case of SARS since January this year, when authorities in\nGuangdong Province confirmed infection in a 35 year old businessman and a\n20 year old waitress. Following the end of the SARS outbreak, announced by\nWHO on 5 Ju 2003, 5 SARS cases have been confirmed. Two occurred in\nlaboratory workers, in Singapore and Taiwan, China, and 3 in Guangdong\nProvince. The third Guangdong case, in a 32 year old television journalist,\nwas announced in December 2003. None of these 5 cases resulted in further\ntransmission of the virus.\nChina, which experienced the largest number of SARS cases during the 2003\noutbreak, has a well-developed system for the detection and investigation\nof possible cases of SARS. The patient, now hospitalized in isolation in\nBeijing's Ditan Hospital, has received 2 examinations by a medical expert\nteam of the Ministry of Health (MOH). The patient, a 20 year old female,\nwas a nurse in Beijing's Jiangong Hospital, the spokesman said.\nBeijing has geared up the early warning system for SARS, organized an\nepidemiological investigation and disinfected the living and working places\nof the patient. Some 171 people who had close contact with the patient have\nreceived medical observation and 5 who developed fever have been isolated\nfor further observation.\nThe MOH has reported the case to the World Health Organisation,and informed\nHong Kong and Macao health authorities about the matter. The patient\nreported symptoms of fever, cough and shivering on 5 Apr 2004 and was\nhospitalized in Jiangong Hospital on 7 Apr 2004. She was transferred to the\nIntensive Care Unit of the Renmin Hospital attached to the Beijing\nUniversity on 14 Apr 2004. On 19 Apr 2004, 2 relatives who accompanied the\npatient in hospital reported fever so the hospital immediately geared up\nthe early warning system for SARS. A medical examination at the hospital\nshowed that the patient was IgG positive on Wed 21 Apr 2004. In the morning\nof Thu 22 Apr 2004, an examination by the Beijing Center for Disease\nPrevention and Control (CDC) showed the patient was IgG and IgM positive,\nboth strong evidence of a suspect SARS case. In accordance with the program\non SARS prevention for medical systems nationwide, the Beijing Health\nBureau then reported the case to MOH on 22 Apr 2004.\nChina's national CDC tested the patient and also obtained the result of IgG\nand IgM positive. The MOH expert team then determined the patient a suspect\nSARS case. worldwide (15): animal reservoirs", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205592", "date": "2004-04-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (15): ANIMAL RESERVOIRS\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 17 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The China Daily, Sat 17 Apr 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2004-04/17/content_324179.htm>\n\nFox and Cat Join Civet Cat as Confirmed Carriers of the SARS Coronavirus\n---------------------------------------------------\nChinese scientists have found that the coronavirus that causes severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS) is also carried by foxes and [domestic?] cats,\nnot just civets, according to the Guangzhou Evening Newspaper. Lin Jinyan,\nthe leader of a SARS control and prevention research team in south China's\nGuangdong Province, reported in a seminar held in Guangzhou that other wild\nanimals were also found to carry the virus.\nThe team had tested thousands of people [for] SARS antibodies in 16 cities in\nGuangdong and found that among 994 people working in animal markets, 10.6\npercent carried positive antibodies, and among 123 civet cat husbandry staff,\nonly 3.25 percent tested positive.\nExperts have also tested foxes, hedge-shrews and cats collected in the\nprovince and discovered that some carried the SARS coronavirus. On 16 Jan\n2004, World Health Organization experts claimed that the SARS coronavirus\nor a SARS-like coronavirus was linked to civet cats. WHO epidemiologist\nRobert Breiman said it's possible that other animals were also involved in\nthe spread of SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These observations extend the range of animal species known to harbour the\nSARS coronavirus (or a closely related coronavirus). The results of the\nhuman antibody study suggest that the transmission of SARS coronavirus from\ncivets to humans, if it occurs at all, is less efficient than from some\nother animals. What is certain is that a very large number of civet cats\nwas destroyed unjustifiably. These data do not establish the direction of\ntransmission of infection -- from animal to man, or the reverse. The origin\nof the SARS coronavirus remains obscure, and it is possible that the virus\nhas been present in the human population for some time, only developing\nvirulence recently. - Mod.CP]\n[Thanks to Alfonso Rodriguez, who sent in another version of this article.\nThis report is also interesting in apparently showing a significant number of\nSARS survivors in the animal handling population. One might wonder at the\nspecificity of the antibody test used. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The team had tested thousands of people [for] SARS antibodies in 16 cities in\nGuangdong and found that among 994 people working in animal markets, 10.6\npercent carried positive antibodies, and among 123 civet cat husbandry staff,\nonly 3.25 percent tested positive. The results of the\nhuman antibody study suggest that the transmission of SARS coronavirus from\ncivets to humans, if it occurs at all, is less efficient than from some\nother animals. The origin\nof the SARS coronavirus remains obscure, and it is possible that the virus\nhas been present in the human population for some time, only developing\nvirulence recently. Lin Jinyan,\nthe leader of a SARS control and prevention research team in south China's\nGuangdong Province, reported in a seminar held in Guangzhou that other wild\nanimals were also found to carry the virus. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n On 16 Jan\n2004, World Health Organization experts claimed that the SARS coronavirus\nor a SARS-like coronavirus was linked to civet cats. \nChinese scientists have found that the coronavirus that causes severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS) is also carried by foxes and [domestic?] Apr 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/english/doc/2004-04/17/content_324179.htm>\n\nFox and Cat Join Civet Cat as Confirmed Carriers of the SARS Coronavirus\n SARS - worldwide (183): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204962", "date": "2003-11-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (183): ETIOLOGY\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 28 Nov 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Lancet, vol. 362, no. 9398, Fri 29 Nov 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journal/vol362/iss9398/abs/llan.362.9398.original_research.27886.1>\n\nHong Kong: Genotype of the SARS coronavirus from the Amoy Gardens outbreak\n---------------------------------------------------\n[The following is the summary of a Research Letter in the current\nissue of the Lancet, in which the authors conclude that the different\nfeatures of the hospital-based outbreak and the Amoy Gardens outbreak\nare the result of extraneous factors rather than differences in virus\ngenotype. - Mod.CP]\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a global health concern.\nIn Hong Kong, 2 major outbreaks, one hospital-based and the other in\nthe Amoy Gardens apartments, were identified. The frequency of\ndiarrhoea, admission to intensive care, and mortality differed\nsignificantly between the 2 outbreaks. We carried out genomic\nsequencing for viral isolates from 5 Amoy Gardens patients. The virus\nsequence was identical in 4 of these 5 patients. The sequence data\nfrom one hospital case and the 4 identical community cases had only 3\nnucleotide differences. Alterations in the SARS coronavirus genome\nare unlikely to have caused the distinctive clinical features of the\nAmoy Gardens patients, and these results highlight the importance of\nnon-viral genomic factors in this outbreak.\n(By S S C Chim, S K W Tsui, K C A Chan, T C C Au, E C W Hung, Y K\nTong, R W K Chiu, E K O Ng, P K S Chan, C M Chu, J J Y Sung, J S Tam,\nK P Fung, M M Y Waye, C Y Lee, K Y Yuen, Y M D Lo, and members of the\nCUHK Molecular SARS Research Group. From the Departments of Chemical\nPathology (S S C Chim PhD, K C A Chan MRCP, Y K Tong MPhil, R W K\nChiu MB, E K O Ng PhD, Prof Y M D Lo DM), Biochemistry (S K W Tsui\nPhD, T C C Au MPhil, K P Fung PhD, M M Y Waye PhD, Prof C Y Lee PhD),\nPaediatrics (E C W Hung MB), Microbiology (P K S Chan MRCPath, J S\nTam PhD), and Medicine and Therapeutics (Prof J J Y Sung MD), Chinese\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong, China;\nDepartment of Medicine, United Christian Hospital, Hong Kong (C M Chu\nFRCP); and Department of Microbiology, Queen Mary Hospital,\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Hong Kong (Prof K Y Yuen MD)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "University of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong, China;\nDepartment of Medicine, United Christian Hospital, Hong Kong (C M Chu\nFRCP); and Department of Microbiology, Queen Mary Hospital,\nUniversity of Hong Kong, Hong Kong (Prof K Y Yuen MD)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [The following is the summary of a Research Letter in the current\nissue of the Lancet, in which the authors conclude that the different\nfeatures of the hospital-based outbreak and the Amoy Gardens outbreak\nare the result of extraneous factors rather than differences in virus\ngenotype. - Mod. Alterations in the SARS coronavirus genome\nare unlikely to have caused the distinctive clinical features of the\nAmoy Gardens patients, and these results highlight the importance of\nnon-viral genomic factors in this outbreak.\n The sequence data\nfrom one hospital case and the 4 identical community cases had only 3\nnucleotide differences. The frequency of\ndiarrhoea, admission to intensive care, and mortality differed\nsignificantly between the 2 outbreaks. Genotype of the SARS coronavirus from the Amoy Gardens outbreak\n---------------------------------------------------\n SARS - WORLDWIDE (183): ETIOLOGY\n********************************\n Ng, P K S Chan, C M Chu, J J Y Sung, J S Tam,\nK P Fung, M M Y Waye, C Y Lee, K Y Yuen, Y M D Lo, and members of the\nCUHK Molecular SARS Research Group.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["9398-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "607", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (19) - China: cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=607", "date": "2004-04-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (19) - CHINA: CASES\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] WHO update\n[2] China - measures taken (newswire)\n[3] USA response (CDC Health alert network)\n[4] Canada response (Health Canada)\n[5] European Union response (Eurosurveillance e-alert)\n[6] South Korea response (newswire)\n****\n[1] WHO update\nDate: 23 Apr 2004\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mhj12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO CSR [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2004_04_23/en/>\n\nChina reports additional SARS cases - update\n-------------------------\nThe Chinese Ministry of Health has today reported an additional 3 cases of\nSARS, including one death. This brings the current number of persons with a\nclinical illness compatible with SARS in China to 4.\nChinese authorities have reported a diagnosis of clinically confirmed SARS\ncoronavirus infection in 2 of these persons. These are the 20-year-old\nnurse in Beijing, reported yesterday, who remains in intensive care, and a\n26-year-old female laboratory researcher, from Anhui Province. During 2\nweeks in March 2004, the researcher worked at the Chinese National\nInstitute of Virology in Beijing, which is part of China's Center for\nDisease Control. This institute is known to be engaged in research\ninvolving the SARS coronavirus. She developed symptoms on 25 Mar and was\nattended, while in a Beijing hospital, by the nurse. Her mother also\nprovided bedside care.\nThe mother became ill in Anhui on 8 Apr and died on 19 Apr. Her clinical\nsymptoms were compatible with SARS, and health authorities have\nretrospectively diagnosed her as a suspected SARS case.\nThe 4th person is a 31-year-old male laboratory researcher who also worked\nat the Beijing virology institute. He developed symptoms on 17 Apr and was\nhospitalized in isolation on 22 Apr. Health authorities have diagnosed him\nas a suspected SARS case.\nIn line with WHO definitions of SARS coronavirus infections, WHO has\nclassified 2 of these persons, the 20-year-old nurse and the 26-year-old\nlaboratory researcher, as probable cases of SARS. The 2 additional persons\nremain under investigation; further laboratory tests are being conducted by\nChinese authorities.\nAccording to WHO guidelines for the global surveillance of SARS,\nclassification as a confirmed case requires independent verification of\nresults by an external international reference laboratory. Such procedures\nare considered necessary in view of the implications that confirmed SARS\ncases can have for international public health.\nWHO is working closely with Chinese health authorities to confirm the\nstatus and full extent of this cluster, and to prevent further spread. The\nsituation is considered potentially serious because of the multiple\nopportunities for exposures. To date, more than 300 contacts have been\nidentified and placed under medical observation.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2] China measures taken\nDate: 24 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/24/international/asia/24SARS.html>\n\nThe Chinese government began screening travelers at airports and train\nstations on Friday and closed its main SARS laboratory after what appeared\nto be a safety breach at the lab led to 4 confirmed [cases are still\npending confirmation from an independent international laboratory] and\nsuspected cases, including a death, in a new outbreak.\nOfficials are hurriedly trying to determine how widely the disease has\nspread. At least 260 people who came into close contact with the patients\nare being observed, and at least 5 others with fevers have been isolated.\nThere is also concern about the recent travels of one of the patients [the\nindex case], a 26-year-old medical graduate student, who studied at the\nSARS lab. She traveled on at least 3 trains; 2 of the trips came after she\nhad developed a fever and other symptoms. [Her] mother, who cared for her\nand traveled with her, fell ill with pneumonia symptoms this month and died\nMonday.\nThis is the 3rd outbreak from a laboratory accident in the past year; the\nothers were in Singapore and Taiwan. Dr. Alfred Sommer, an epidemiologist\nand dean of the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health in\nBaltimore, said Friday, 'The good news is this is not a new emergence of\nyet another strain of virus that we do not know anything about, or how to\ncontain,' like SARS, severe acute respiratory syndrome, was when first\ndetected in 2003. 'The bad news is that this is the 3rd laboratory release\nof this virus, which keeps taking people by surprise,' he added.\nChinese officials, who were harshly criticized for their mismanagement of\nthe original SARS outbreak, appeared to be responding swiftly. Efforts were\nunder way to find people who had come into contact with the SARS patients.\nOfficials also closed the Institute of Virology at China's Centers for\nDisease Control in Beijing, where the infections originated, according to a\nstatement on the Ministry of Health Web site.\nThe director of Beijing's health bureau, Jin Dapeng, said Friday that the\nchain of transmission had been identified and that authorities had the\nsituation under 'effective control.' The pattern of the outbreak, however,\nhas raised questions about how a safety breach could have occurred at the\nlaboratory and whether medical officials moved quickly enough to isolate\n[the index case] after she exhibited symptoms. The 4 patients were cared\nfor in different hospitals but not initially isolated. Another student\nworking in the lab, developed symptoms more than 3 weeks later and is now\nlisted as suspected of having SARS.\nDr. Julie Hall, the SARS team leader for the Beijing office of the World\nHealth Organization, said health officials held a meeting on Friday with\nthe Chinese Ministry of Health. She said the ministry had asked for their\nhelp in trying to determine what went wrong and to limit exposures.\nAt World Health Organization headquarters in Geneva, a spokesman for the\nUnited Nations agency said that under its rules it could not call the cases\nconfirmed until scientists in a laboratory in its network outside of China\nhad tested specimens from the patients. Until then, the agency is\nconsidering as 'probable' the 2 cases that China has called 'confirmed.'\nThe agency said it is classifying the other 2 cases as 'under investigation.'\nEarly Friday evening, the Chinese Ministry of Health issued a detailed\nchronology that appeared to trace the outbreak to some sort of mishap in\nthe lab. [The index case], a medical graduate student in Anhui Province,\nbegan study at the lab on 7 Mar 2004. She and the other [post doctoral\nstudent case] both studied in a laboratory that handled samples of the SARS\nvirus, according to Dr. Hall.\nThe Health Ministry said that [the index case's] stint at the lab ended 22\nMar 2004 and that the next day she returned by train to Anhui Province. On\n25 Mar 2004, she developed a fever. At some point, she returned by train to\nBeijing for treatment. On 29 Mar 2004, she was admitted to Jiangong\nHospital as a pneumonia patient.\nAt the hospital, one of [the nurses who cared for her], the woman\nidentified Thursday by Chinese officials as suspected of having SARS. On\nFriday, officials reclassified [this case] as a confirmed SARS patient.\nFor reasons that are not clear, [the index case] was discharged from\nJiangong on 2 Apr 2004 and returned by train with her mother to a hospital\nin Anhui. There, she was transferred to a second hospital. The person\napparently most often by [her] side during her illness was her mother. She\nhad started caring for her daughter on 31 Mar 2004 and developed a fever on\n8 Apr 2004. She was hospitalized as a pneumonia patient at the same\nhospital as her daughter. On Monday, [the index case's mother] died.\nThe official New China News Agency reported that [the index case] tested\npositive for SARS antibodies on Wednesday. Health officials from Beijing\nwent to Anhui and tested her again. She again tested positive on Friday and\nwas deemed a confirmed SARS patient. Dr. Hall, said she 'died of pneumonia\nof an unknown cause that is likely to be SARS.'\nMeanwhile, [the other graduate student] developed a fever on 17 Apr 2004\nand was hospitalized Thursday. He is now classified as suspected of having\nSARS.\nDr. Hall said the timetable raised questions about why [the index case] was\nnot promptly isolated when she first developed a fever, particularly\nbecause physicians should have known she had studied in a SARS laboratory.\n'Those alarm bells appear not to have gone off,' she said.\n[Byline: Jim Yardley and Lawrence K. Altman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3] USA response\nDate: 23 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Health Alert Network [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/han/han_China042304.htm>\n\nCDC is recommending that U.S. physicians maintain a greater index of\nsuspicion for SARS in patients who 1) require hospitalization for\nradiographically confirmed pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome\n(ARDS) and 2) who have a history of travel to mainland China (or close\ncontact with an ill person with a history of recent travel to mainland\nChina) in the 10 days before onset of symptoms . When such patients are\nidentified, they should be considered at high risk for SARS-CoV infection,\nand the following actions should be taken:\nPatients should immediately be placed in appropriate isolation precautions\nfor SARS (i.e., contact and airborne precautions along with eye protection).\nPatients should promptly be reported to the state or local health\ndepartment. Health departments should immediately report any SARS-CoV\npositive test result to CDC. Health departments should also inform CDC of\nother cases or clusters of pneumonia that are of particular concern by\ncalling 770-488-7100.\nPatients should promptly be tested for evidence of SARS-CoV infection as\npart of the diagnostic evaluation (see Appendix 2, 'Guidelines for\nCollecting Specimens from Potential SARS Patients,' in the CDC document,\n'In the Absence of SARS-CoV Transmission Worldwide: Guidance for\nSurveillance, Clinical and Laboratory Evaluation, and Reporting' at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/absenceofsars.htm>\nThe health department should identify, evaluate, and monitor relevant\ncontacts of the patient, as indicated. In particular, the health status of\nhousehold contacts or persons who provided care to symptomatic patients\nshould be assessed.\nHealth care providers are reminded to obtain a travel history for patients\npresenting with acute respiratory illness. In addition, this new case of\npossible SARS provides a reminder to all healthcare settings, especially\nphysician offices, outpatient clinics, and emergency departments, of the\nimportance of implementing infection control precautions at the point of\n1st contact with patients who have symptoms of a respiratory infection.\nThese include respiratory hygiene/cough etiquette, hand hygiene, and\ndroplet precautions (i.e., masks for close patient contact). For additional\ninformation, see ' Respiratory Hygiene/Cough Etiquette in Healthcare Settings.'\nThe reported possible cases of SARS in China represent an evolving\nsituation, and CDC will distribute updates as additional information is\nlearned. For more about SARS and the current U.S. SARS control guidelines,\nplease visit the CDC SARS website.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5] Canada response (Health Canada)\nDate: 24 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/cases_china.html>\n\nHealth Canada has alerted health care officials to the importance of\ncollecting a travel history from people with severe respiratory illness. As\nper the Department's guidelines, Health Canada recommends that health\nprofessionals be alert for severe respiratory illness (fever, cough,\ndifficulty breathing and evidence of pneumonia or acute respiratory\ndistress syndrome) in patients who have a history of travel to China or in\npatients having close contact with a symptomatic person with a history of\ntravel to China in the 10 days before symptoms appeared.\nWe continue to provide ongoing, up-to-date information from Health Canada\nto our provincial and territorial partners on SARS, influenza, avian\ninfluenza, and other emerging severe respiratory illnesses.\nHealth Canada continues to maintain Quarantine Services at the Toronto,\nVancouver, Montreal (Mirabel, Pierre Elliot Trudeau), Calgary, Edmonton,\nHalifax and Ottawa international airports. Quarantine Officers on site at\nthese airports provide health assessments for international travellers who\nare identified to be ill. Health Canada has advised Quarantine Officers of\nthe SARS situation in China and has asked them to increase vigilance of any\nreported passengers with respiratory illness. They have been advised to be\nespecially alert to reports of travellers on flights from Beijing who\nappear to be ill from a respiratory illness. We also continue to provide\ninfectious disease brochures with information on SARS at the airports.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5] European Union response (Eurosurveillance e-alert)\nDate: 24 Apr 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance e-alert 23 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org>\n\nThe European Commission Directorate General for Public Health and Consumer\nProtection (DG SANCO, <http://europa.eu.int/comm/health/index_en.htm>) has\npreviously issued several technical guidance documents outlining the\ncommunication procedures if a probable case of SARS is detected within\nEuropean Union countries. This document also includes case definitions (see\n<http://europa.eu.int/comm/health/ph_threats/com/sars/com_procedure.pdf>).\nAn early warning, regarding the current Beijing suspect case of SARS, has\nbeen sent to national public health bodies through the European Union's\nEarly Warning and Response System.\nThe United Kingdom (UK) Health Protection Agency (HPA) recently issued\ninterim guidance (algorithm) for identification of possible cases of SARS\nand avian influenza\n(<http://www.hpa.org.uk/infections/topics_az/avianinfluenza/pdfs/Algorithm140\n404.pdf>). The HPA has urged clinicians and health professionals in the UK\nto remain vigilant and report any unusual clusters of severe respiratory\nillness in people returning from China.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[6] South Korea\nDate: 24 Apr 2004\nFrom: Alfonso Rodriguez <arodriguezm@SaludFMV.org>\nSource: Yahoo News, Asia [edited]\n<http://asia.news.yahoo.com/040424/ap/d8256gu00.html>\n\nSouth Korea heightens health checks against travelers from China amid new\nSARS scare\nHealth inspections of travelers from Beijing and Shanghai were intensified\nSaturday at South Korean airports and seaports after China reported new\nSARS cases.\nThe National Institute of Health ordered quarantine offices to check\ntemperatures of all travelers from the 2 Chinese cities, and asked them to\nfill out health questionnaires upon arrival.\nThe institute also ordered anyone showing symptoms of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, such as a high fever, be reported immediately.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours there have been no reports of additional cases other\nthan those reported in the ProMED-mail posting of yesterday SARS -\nworldwide (18): China (cases) 20040423.1125. [reference below] have reported experiments involving\nexperimental transmission of SARS coronavirus to 2 distantly related\ncarnivores in addition to those previously associated with the SARS\ncoronavirus. The Abstract of their paper reads as follows:\n\n'The reservoir of the coronavirus isolated from patients with severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is still unknown, but is suspected to\nhave been a wild animal species. Here we show that ferrets (_Mustela\nfuro_) and domestic cats (_Felis domesticus_) are susceptible to\ninfection by SARS coronavirus (SCV) and that they can efficiently\ntransmit the virus to previously uninfected animals that are housed with\nthem. The observation that these 2 distantly related carnivores can so\neasily be infected with the virus indicates that the reservoir for this\npathogen may involve a range of animal species.'\n\n[Reference; Byron E. Participants agreed on the priority research\nquestions to be addressed in the coming months.\nQuestions fall into the main areas of epidemiology, laboratory\ndiagnostics, outbreak management, case management, including\ntreatment outcomes and infection control, and social impact. The\nresearch agenda, which will undergo further review by participants,\nis expected to be finalized for public release within a week.\nPreparation of the research agenda was based on a discussion of\nseveral problems that emerged during the outbreak and an analysis\nof subsequent data, including areas where additional scientific\nevidence was needed to identify the most cost-effective control\nstrategies. Participants expressed a great need to ensure that the\nworld can recognize and respond to a recurrence of SARS in ways\nthat work faster to achieve control and are less costly and socially\ndisruptive. The following topics were discussed.\nThe Global SARS Alert System\n----------------------------\nConcerning the level of operational preparedness to detect new\ncases, participants noted that the system of alert now in place will\nprobably work well to pick up clusters of severe disease. False-\nalarms are fully expected and have already occurred. They\nprovide reassurance that the alert system is working well. However,\nparticipants agreed that sporadic cases of SARS may not be\ndetected early.\nMild SARS cases and cases with atypical symptoms could be\ninitially missed, hence the importance for several lines of defence\nin which the intensity of surveillance is determined by the level of\nrisk (zone of re-emergence, nodal areas, and low-risk areas).\nMoreover, the system for global alert is weakened by the fact that\nat least half of the world's population has no access to services\nthat can perform simple chest X-rays.\nSome countries are continuing a policy of heightened alert for\npersons with a recent travel history to one of the initial outbreak\nsites. Failure to elicit such a history should not automatically\nexclude SARS as a diagnosis if other clinical, laboratory, and\nepidemiological features are consistent with the diagnosis. The\nHotel Metropole incident, in which contact with a single infected\nperson seeded the outbreak's international spread, was a random\nevent illustrating the limitations that travel history can have in the\npost-outbreak situation. Any major transportation hub near an\ninternational airport could be the scene for a similar seeding of\ninternational spread.\nPreparedness in Resource-poor Settings\n--------------------------------------\nFollowing the global alerts of 12 and 15 Mar 2003, most countries\nexperiencing imported cases were able to prevent any further\ntransmission or hold the number of cases to very small numbers,\nindicating the effectiveness of a high level of alert. It is hoped\nthat, should SARS re-emerge, the disease would occur in small\npockets of cases that could, with the present level of vigilance, be\nrapidly detected and contained.\nA major concern is the occurrence of cases in resource-poor\nsettings, where health infrastructures might not be able to cope\nwith the demands of case detection, isolation, intensive care, and\ncontact tracing. Outbreak dynamics in such settings could take on\ndimensions different than those seen during the initial outbreak. In\nthe absence of sophisticated hospital facilities and treatment\nprocedures, which are known to amplify transmission, developing\ncountries might not experience explosive increases in cases for\nthe same reasons as seen elsewhere. Many other factors, such as\ncrowding on wards and lack of adequate isolation facilities, could\ncontribute to so-called 'super-spreading' events.\nSome discussion centered on ways to identify areas that might be\nat particular risk. One approach would be to assess air passenger\nflows to determine which cities are most vulnerable to international\nspread. Support for enhanced surveillance and preparedness\nplans could then be targeted to areas considered at greatest risk.\nDiagnosis\n--------\nDiagnosis of SARS is difficult, and all currently available\nlaboratory tests have limitations. At present, there is no single\n'gold standard' that can be recommended for laboratory testing.\nDifferent tests are appropriate for different stages of the disease.\nAnother problem affecting the reliability of available serological\ntests is cross-reaction with other human coronaviruses, which are\nwidespread.\nThe laboratory confirmation of 2 or more cases in the same health\ncare unit during a 10-day period would have great significance in\nthe post-outbreak setting, perhaps signalling the start of another\nglobal emergency. For this reason, and in view of the inadequacy of\ndiagnostic tests, the experts recommended a policy of rigorous\nverification, whereby positive tests in one laboratory would need to\nbe confirmed by an external, internationally recognized reference\nlaboratory. A system of quality assurance of tests was also judged\nessential, as were internationally-agreed algorithms that could help\nclinicians make difficult diagnostic choices. These issues are being\ndiscussed further at the SARS Laboratory Network Meeting on\nWed 22 Oct 2003.\nDiagnosis would also benefit from some method of identifying,\nperhaps through immunological or genetic markers, which patients\nmight develop severe illness and which patients might contribute to\nsuper-spreading events. An additional concern is the development\nof diagnostic tests suitable for use in resource-poor settings.\nPossible Evolution of the SARS Coronavirus\n----------------------------------------\nStudies of coronaviruses in a number of animal species indicate\nthat some of these viruses readily cross from one species to\nothers, lending weight to theories that the SARS virus originally\njumped from some natural animal host to humans. Recent\nexperimental studies have easily infected 2 animal species with the\nSARS virus, suggesting that the range of animal hosts where the\nSARS virus could 'hide' between outbreaks is much wider than\ninitially suspected.\nIn animal diseases caused by coronaviruses, the severity of\ndisease can be exacerbated by such factors as co-infection with\nother respiratory viruses, including influenza viruses, some forms of\ntreatment, and stress, especially during transport. Virus shedding is\nlonger, and respiratory symptoms are more severe following\nexposure to aerosolized virus. These features may shed some\nlight on super-spreading events, which remain poorly understood.\nIn Hong Kong, for example, transmission was amplified in hospitals\nwhere certain aerosol-producing procedures, including the use of\nnebulizers, were performed during the earliest days of the outbreak.\nAnimal studies indicate that coronaviruses can be spread\nmechanically. This mode of spread may have contributed to\nevents, such as the Amoy Gardens outbreak, in which some\nenvironmental contact with the virus clearly played a role.\nSome coronaviruses are believed to survive in their animal hosts\ndespite seasonal changes in temperature. Others have mutated\ninto strains causing much milder disease. While these features\ncould hold true for the SARS virus, much more research is needed\nbefore any conclusions about the future evolution of the SARS\nvirus can be reached.\nAmplification in Hospitals: the Role of Infection Control\n------------------------------------------------\nThe amplification of transmission within well-equipped hospitals\nwas a striking feature of SARS. In some cases, staff became\ninfected despite wearing full protective equipment. Participants\npresented further compelling evidence that certain sophisticated\nprocedures, especially those that generate aerosols, greatly\namplify the risks of infection; less sophisticated hospitals fared\nbetter.\nSome cases of hospital-based infection could be attributed to clear\nlapses in infection control. In this and several other cases,\nresearch in the social sciences could assist in improving behaviour\nwhile also helping staff cope with the considerable stress of dealing\nwith a new disease, a new type of patient, and new requirements\nfor care.\nA disproportionately large amount of resources is needed to\nprevent transmission of airborne infections. The required infection\ncontrol procedures are also extremely demanding for staff. As\nSARS is not thought to be an airborne infection, research should\nclarify the need for these measures compared with measures\nneeded to prevent transmission via droplets and contact with body\nfluids. It was also agreed that the need for protective equipment is\nrelated to procedures, and that, in advance of another emergency,\nconsideration needs to be given to equipment that provides a good\nstandard of care and adequate protection while also being\naffordable and sustainable.\nLaboratory Biosafety\n--------------------\nBetter measures are needed internationally to prevent the\nrecurrence of SARS following a laboratory biosafety accident.\nHealth authorities should be encouraged to produce inventories of\nall facilities conducting research on the virus or holding samples.\nThis information should then be communicated internationally to\nWHO.\nControl Interventions\n---------------------\nRapid case detection and isolation, along with contact tracing and\nfollow-up, were generally regarded as an effective way to deal with\nthe emergence of a new disease. It reduces the pool of infectious\nindividuals circulating in the community and, in the case of contacts,\nheightens the level of clinical suspicion, especially in the absence\nof reliable diagnostic tests. However, good support from information\ntechnologies is needed to manage the data required for more\nefficient contact tracing. Research on the most effective\napproaches to contact tracing is also needed.\nAnother important need is for the real-time compilation of data from\nepidemiological, clinical, and laboratory sources, and their\nintegration into a single data-set available to the international\ncommunity. Access to such a database would contribute greatly to\nassessment of the effectiveness of all interventions, including\ntreatment, in real time as a SARS outbreak -- or outbreak of any\nother emerging disease -- unfolds.\n--\nDr. Christian Drosten\nVirology/Molecular Diagnostics\nBernhard Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine\nBernhard-Nocht Str. 74\n20359 Hamburg Germany\n<drosten@bni-hamburg.de>", "summary": "In this and several other cases,\nresearch in the social sciences could assist in improving behaviour\nwhile also helping staff cope with the considerable stress of dealing\nwith a new disease, a new type of patient, and new requirements\nfor care.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Preparation of the research agenda was based on a discussion of\nseveral problems that emerged during the outbreak and an analysis\nof subsequent data, including areas where additional scientific\nevidence was needed to identify the most cost-effective control\nstrategies. In\nthe absence of information on the nature of the tests and the\nreagents employed, it is difficult to comment on this report in any\ndetail. Nonetheless, it provides invaluable data on the presence of a\nSARS coronavirus-like agent in asymptomatic humans approximately one\nyear before the appearance of SARS in Guangdong. However, the report\ndoes not indicate whether any of the 16 positive samples originated\nfrom Guangdong. Further information is awaited. - Mod.CP]\nBeijing Military District Air Force General Logistics Department\nstudied 1621 samples of cryopreserved blood from healthy youths in\n169 counties in China. Blood had been drawn between 2001 and 2002.\nAfter conducting 4 tests at 3 'authoritative' institutions, it was\ndetermined that 16 samples had a positive reaction to the SARS virus\nantigen.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n After conducting 4 tests at 3 'authoritative' institutions, it was\ndetermined that 16 samples had a positive reaction to the SARS virus\nantigen.\n In\nthe absence of information on the nature of the tests and the\nreagents employed, it is difficult to comment on this report in any\ndetail. Nonetheless, it provides invaluable data on the presence of a\nSARS coronavirus-like agent in asymptomatic humans approximately one\nyear before the appearance of SARS in Guangdong. However, the report\ndoes not indicate whether any of the 16 positive samples originated\nfrom Guangdong.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-09-24 00:00:00", "2003-09-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "CHINA", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204873", "headline": "PRO/AH> SARS - worldwide (182): medical ecology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204873", "date": "2003-11-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (182): MEDICAL ECOLOGY\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 6 Nov 2003\nFrom: Luis A Ruedas <ruedas@pdx.edu>\n\nEpidemiological Models: Comments on the Nature of a Viral Host\n--------------------------------------------------\n[Different interpretations have been placed on the demonstration by Martina\net al. of experimental SARS virus infection of cats and ferrets (see: SARS\n- worldwide (181): host range 20031030.2701). My presumption has been that\nMartina et al. did not suggest that either ferrets or domestic cats are\nalternate reservoirs of the SARS coronavirus. Rather, their intention was\nto demonstrate experimentally that many animal species (not just captive\nraccoon dogs and civet cats) might transmit SARS coronavirus and that it is\npremature to jump to conclusions about the source of SARS coronavirus\ninfection on the basis of rather arbitrary studies of captive animals in\nChinese markets.\nMy assumption has been that ferrets and cats were used in these experiments\nbecause these animals were available and convenient laboratory subjects.\nDr. Ruedas presents a critique of these experiments from the standpoint of\nthe discipline of Medical Ecology, which although mathematical in content,\ndeserves consideration. - Mod.CP]\nIn their brief communication on SARS virus infection in wild animals (ref.\n1) indicated that -- based on their findings -- distantly related\ncarnivores (in their instance, ferrets and cats) could act as reservoirs\nfor the SARS coronavirus (SCV). There are some potential pitfalls in their\nreasoning. Susceptibility is defined in medical terms as diminished\nimmunity to a disease, especially an infection, or not having immunity to\nan infectious disease and thus [being] at risk of infection (ref 2). Can a\nreservoir, or host species, be susceptible to the virus it hosts? In\ncertain instances of host-parasite co-evolutionary frameworks, the answer\nis yes: a malarial protozoan, _Plasmodium_, is conferred evolutionary\nadvantage if its human host is incapacitated, because a healthy human\neasily could evade a mosquito, the flight speed of which is estimated at 5\nto 7 Km/h. Incapacitation of the host therefore increases the feeding\nopportunities for the mosquitoes and perpetuates the epidemic and enzootic\ncycles of malaria. In such a system, the vectorial capacity equation of\nMacdonald (ref. 3) may be arranged (ref. 4) to, VC = ma (P/F)(e^(-n/E))E\nwhere: ma = number of bites per human per day (estimated from human bait\ncatches); P = proportion of blood meals taken on human hosts; F = days\nbetween blood meals (from lab studies); n = extrinsic incubation period\n(lab studies); and E = vector's life expectancy.\nIt may be readily appreciated that incapacitation will significantly\nincrease ma and P, hence the vectorial capacity will be significantly\nenhanced, to the benefit of _Plasmodium_. Anderson and May (ref. 5) listed\na number of complicating factors in this system including the effects of\nlongevity (on both human host and vector): decreased life-span in the human\nsignificantly impacts the dynamics of the disease (e.g., their mu [defined\nin next paragraph] less than 1 percent in equation 14.7 et seq.).\nA directly transmitted zoonosis such as SARS is at once a simpler and more\ncomplicated framework to model. A basic SIR\n(susceptible-infected-recovered) model of disease dynamics (ref. 6)\nconsists of the 3 host cell categories (complicating for age, a, at time,\nt), thus: N(a, t) = X(a, t) + Y(a, t) + Z(a, t), where X, Y, and Z\ncorrespond to populations of each of the modeled categories (SIR); an\nadditional category for a latent category (infected but not infectious), H,\nmay be added. A basic set of differential equations describing this\nframework (ref. 5) is beyond the scope of this correspondence, but includes\nage-specific host death rate mu, recovery rate upsilon, disease induced\nmortality rate alpha, and a 'force of infection' component, lambda. An\nideal host species for a directly transmitted viral disease would have a\nnegligible age-specific or otherwise alpha(a), hence upsilon(a) would be an\nirrelevant component of the epidemiological dynamics.\nIn such a situation, the total number of hosts, N, is not equivalent to the\ntraditional equation shown above, rather Z ~= 0, and Y would be a\nproportion of X, but because alpha(a) ~= 0, (i.e., mu + alpha ~= mu) the\nentire host population N can be uniformly modeled.\nAn additional biological factor critical to adequate representation of the\nsystem is the basic reproductive rate, Rsub0, of the virus. Although\ntechnically this should represent the intrinsic reproductive rate of an\norganism, in terms of its representation in disease dynamics, Rsub0\ngenerally is symbolic of infections produced by an infected, infectious\nhost or victim -- given that evolutionarily a virus is dead if it does not\ncolonize a new host. In order to establish itself in a host (or victim)\npopulation -- or establish an equilibrium -- a virus would within this\nframework have Rsub0 > 1. Departures from equilibrium lead to R,\nthe effective reproductive rate, discounted by the fraction of the host\npopulation being susceptible, x*, where R = Rsub0x* =1. Anderson and May\n(ref. 5) lucidly pointed out that Rsub0 must be proportional to the number\n(or density) of hosts candidate for infection such that Rsub0 = N/NsubT,\nwhere N is the population size and NsubT the threshold magnitude. For\ncondition Rsub0 > 1, the corollary condition N > NsubT must hold.\nSynthesizing, it can readily be appreciated that a certain minimal number\nof intrinsic biological factors determine the suitability of an organism to\nbe a potential host for a given virus. In the situation described by\nMartina et al. (ref. 1) it is clear that the ferret cannot in any way be\nconsidered a host. This is because the disease-induced mortality rate\nalpha, as Martina et al (ref. 1) suggest, would be so high that the total\npopulation mortality rate alpha+mu would not support the disease dynamics\nin a sustainable manner. Furthermore, ferrets exist in the wild in\nextremely low numbers (ref. 7). Hence the directly transmitted SCV would\nhave an even lesser probability of transmission given the density-dependent\ndynamics of the epidemiological framework.\nThere is, of course, a more essential flaw: the name _Mustela furo_ applies\nto domestic ferrets only. These animals are reproductively -- hence\ngenetically -- identical to _M. putorius_, the polecat. That is to say, _M.\nfuro_ as a species does not really exist, being no more than a series of\nindividuals drawn from _M. putorius_. The natural range of _M. putorius_ is\nmost of Europe east to the Ural Mountains. (ref. 8). Therefore, even were\nit not for the epidemiological dynamic considerations alluded to above, _M.\n'furo'_ perforce cannot be considered a potential host for SCV. If _M.\n'furo'_ are available in markets in Guangdong these are, by definition,\nimported, and beg the question: why is there no SARS in Europe? An allied\nspecies occupying a range including the epicenter of the SARS epidemic\n(ref. 8, 9), _M. sibirica_, could be considered as a potential host.\nHowever, the low densities prevalent in _M. putorius_ likewise exist in _M.\nsibirica_ and indeed in all species of the genus _Mustela_. As a\nconsequence of the foregoing, mustelids it would seem should be discounted\nas hosts of SCV.\nIn contrast, the situation reported by Martina et al. (ref. 1) regarding\ncats is far more worthy of note. The correct name (by first designation)\napplicable to these organisms is _Felis catus_ (ref. 8) (by Linnaeus in\n1758), rather than _F. silvestris_ (by Schreber in 1775) or _F. domesticus_\n(by Erxleben in 1777), all of which, despite their distinct names, cona = 0\nmakes for highly effective transmission dynamics, as has been shown in\nhantaviruses and their rodent hosts (ref. 10).\nThe typically exponential rise in proportion of infected hosts P(t), has\nbeen shown (ref. 5) to depend on the rate at which new infectives are being\nproduced, lambda, such that P(t) = P(0)exp(lambda t). Furthermore, the\nbiological quality lambda, depends on Rsub0 and on the parasite lifespan,\nD, such that lambda = (Rsub0 - 1)/D. Finally, in a host-virus framework\nsuch as SARS, D represents the duration of infectiousness; however, for\nchronically infected hosts (e.g., rodent hosts of Hantaviruses) D is\neffectively equivalent to the life-span of the host since the host is\ninfected for life and sheds virus for life. Recall that in ferrets, D is\nseverely curtailed by SCV infection due to the high mortality rate, alpha.\nIn contrast, if cats are asymptomatically infected, alpha = 0, and if they\nare shown to be capable of chronic infection with a magnitude of D\nequivalent to their life-span (2-5 years in the wild and 12-14 years as\npets), then the epidemiological potential of cats-SCV vis-a-vis humans-SARS\nwould be of enormous extent. For these reasons, _Felis catus_ also must be\ndiscounted from consideration as the natural host of SCV. If it were the\nnatural host, SCV and the consequent SARS infection of humans would be a\nquotidian affair on a global scale. Instead, it is arguably the first\nemergent infection of the 21st century with a focus in Guangzhou, Guangdong\nprovince, China. The fact that _F. catus_ is capable of asymptomatic\ntransmission is, however, highly suggestive that perhaps another felid\ncould be the host. In the focal area, the wild species _Prionailurus\nbengalensis_ (leopard cat) and _Catopuma temmincki_ (Golden cat) both\noccur, although the range of the former, including most of India,\nIndochina, and the Greater Sunda islands, makes it an unlikely candidate\nspecies for the natural host of SARS.\nMathematical models representing epidemiological frameworks are of\ntremendous heuristic utility, as was recently shown in the pages of the\njournal Nature with respect to smallpox (ref. 6). These frameworks can and\nshould also be used to determine probabilities of particular species being\nhosts, given certain minimal biological properties inherent to the species\n(e.g., geographic range). Medical ecology, integrating as it does disparate\nfields from mathematics, across epidemiology and medicine, to basic and\napplied ecology, has much to offer in the search for viral hosts: because\nof the medical impact of SARS on humans, discounting from consideration\nspecies that cannot be potential hosts is of particular importance in\nelucidating the epidemiology of this fascinating disease. Furthermore,\ngiven that cats are able to be infected but -- unlike humans -- do not\nmanifest any clinical sign of disease, they are not an adequate animal\nmodel for testing therapies against the human virus.\nReferences:\n1. Martina, B. E. E. et al. Nature 425, 915 (2003).\n2. Dorland, W. A. N. Dorland's illustrated medical dictionary, 29th ed. (W.\nB. Saunders, London, 2000).\n3. MacDonald, G. Trop. Dis. Bull. 49, 813-828 (1952).\n4. Molineaux, L. et al. Bull. WHO 56, 565-571 (1978).\n5. Anderson, R. M., May, R. M. Infectious diseases of humans: dynamics and\ncontrol. (Oxford Univ. Press, Oxford, 1991).\n6. Ferguson, N. M. et al. Nature 425, 681-685 (2003).\n7. Baghli, A., Verhagen, R. Mammal Rev. 33, 57-68 (2003).\n8. Wozencraft, W. C. Pp. 279-348 in: Wilson D. E., Reeder, D. M. (eds.)\nMammal species of the world: a taxonomic and geographic reference, 2nd. Ed.\n(Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington D.C., 1992).\n9. Corbet, G. B., Hill, J. E. The mammals of the Indomalayan region: a\nsystematic review. (Oxford Univ. Press, Oxford, 1992).\n10. Mills, J. N. et al. Emerg. Infect. Dis. 5, 135-142 (1999).\n--\nLuis A. Ruedas\nDepartment of Biology,\nPortland State University,\nPortland, Oregon 97207-0751\n<ruedas@pdx.edu>\n[While on the whole, Martina et al. concentrated on the potential use of\ncats and ferrets as animal models to test antiviral drugs or vaccines\nagainst the SARS coronavirus (SCV), they made certain bold comments that\ndeserved questioning. In their first paragraph, they indicated that --\nbased on the data they presented -- the reservoir for SCV could potentially\ninvolve a large number of animal species.\nSecondly -- and most importantly -- they indicated that their data\nsupported the use of cats and ferrets as model animals. Dr. Ruedas seized\non these items and argued from the perspective of mathematical epidemiology\nthat neither species should be considered either as the natural host or as\nan animal model. Ruedas argued that the data provided by Martina et al.\nstrongly argue in favor of considering a wild felid as a potential natural\nhost, but the domestic cat would have caused human cases of SARS over a\nbroad geographic area long before had it been the host.\nFerrets, Ruedas argues, also are unlikely hosts due to their population\nbiology: their densities are likely too low to support an enzootic cycle of\nSCV transmission. In addition, the ferret species examined in the Martina\net al. paper does not naturally occur in China. The jury is still out on\nwhether ferrets should be considered animal models. By Martina et al.'s\nown admission, although a large number of their 6 experimental ferrets died\npost-inoculation, none died of SARS or SARS-associated symptoms. Since\nnone of the animals displayed chronic infection, the dynamics of the\ndisease to some extent mirror those of humans. As such, ferrets should\nremain under consideration. However, the small sample size and high\nmortality from other causes (hepatic lipidosis and emaciation) for now\npreclude definitive conclusions. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "In\ncertain instances of host-parasite co-evolutionary frameworks, the answer\nis yes: a malarial protozoan, _Plasmodium_, is conferred evolutionary\nadvantage if its human host is incapacitated, because a healthy human\neasily could evade a mosquito, the flight speed of which is estimated at 5\nto 7 Km/h. Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n3 months into the SARS epidemic, I proposed 4 questions to the ProMED list:\n'Why Asia? Why now? Why young adults? \u0085Why the panic?' \u0085 and suggested an\nhypothesis. (Archive Number 20030405.0833).\nThe origin and nature of the outbreak bore many similarities to those of\ninfluenza, suggesting the possibility of an Asian animal reservoir and the\nexistence of significant background immunity in the affected population.\nThis week's study in MMWR indicates that animal contact may indeed promote\ninfection; however, the most striking finding seems to have eluded the\nauthors: 1.2 percent to 2.9 percent of individuals in a healthy control\ngroup of adults were also found to be seropositive!\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5241a2.htm>)\nThe population of Guangdong Province is 86.42 million (2001), of whom 61.14\nmillion are adults over age 14. If we assume that the seropositivity rates\namong controls is representative of the province as a whole, 734 000 to 1\n773 000 adults in Guangdong have at some time been infected by the SARS\nvirus. These figures are 87- to 211-fold the total number (8422) of SARS\npatients reported worldwide to date!\nUnfortunately, the control groups examined in the present study consisted\nof persons who might have been directly exposed to SARS patients: 1)\nhealth-care workers involved with SARS control in 2 city hospitals, 2)\npublic health workers in the Guangdong CDC facility, and 3) healthy adults\nvisiting a clinic for routine physical examinations. Furthermore, the ELISA\nassay utilized detects IgG antibody, and cannot determine the timing of\nexposure to the virus. Hopefully, additional studies will examine humans\nand animals from other regions. If documented, the existence of a\nsignificant level of background seropositivity will have far-reaching\nconsequences. Although further attempts at case-finding and isolation will\nprove futile, the fact that only a small percentage of persons acquiring\nthe virus develop significant disease will relegate SARS to the status of\n'just another flu.'\n--\nSteve Berger MD\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n[Dr. Berger raises important issues that still await resolution. While the\nresults of this study are very interesting and seem to point to wild\nanimals as the possible origin species for the SARS-associated coronavirus\n(SARS-CoV), questions remain. The identification of 1.2 to 2.9 percent of\notherwise healthy controls with positive antibodies to the SARS-CoV is a\ncurious finding. Is it due to reduced specificity of the ELISA test used\nfor this study? Were these controls really healthy controls or did they\nhave a history of a serious or significant febrile respiratory illness in\nrecent years that may have been sporadic cases of illness associated with\nthe SARS-CoV? The sensitivity and specificity of measuring IgG on or\nafter the 11th day of illness was 91.1 percent and 97.0 percent,\nrespectively. Similar results could be seen when IgG was detected by\nELISA. Hence, the IgG positivity seen in 'normal healthy controls' could\nbe false positive results.\nDuring a review of the laboratory presentation at the first Global SARS\nconference held in Malaysia in Jun 2003, the lack of standardization of\nlaboratory tests was identified as a significant issue. If the former\nis the case, a follow-on question is whether asymptomatically infected\nindividuals are significant for continued transmission of this virus. During a review of the laboratory presentation at the first Global SARS\nconference held in Malaysia in Jun 2003, the lack of standardization of\nlaboratory tests was identified as a significant issue. Dr. Berger asks whether there evidence of asymptomatic infection with the\nSARS-CoV as seen with many other viral infections, or is this one of the\nunusual viruses with a very low asymptomatic infection rate. The study, conducted by the Academy of Military Medical\nSciences (AMMS), states that while the SARS coronavirus 'has been\nconfirmed' as the cause of SARS, the presence of reovirus in 24 of 38 serum\nsamples taken from SARS patients, and only 1 of 35 subjects in a healthy\ncontrol group, suggests the possibility of co-infection. The authors\nconclude, with due caution, that SARS could be a combination of the [SARS]\ncoronavirus and [a] reovirus.\nThis week, following a conference on SARS in Guangzhou on 14 Oct 2003,\nChinese media has given extensive coverage to this study, labeling reovirus\nthe other possible 'culprit' behind SARS. The AMMS study is available\nonline in English in the Chinese Science Bulletin:\n<http://www.scichina.com/ZTYJ/SARS/ky1293.pdf>.\nArticles in China's popular press on the AMMS studycan be accessed at the\nfollowing:\n<http://www.jxnews.com.cn/n768/ca536146.htm>\n<http://health.enorth.com.cn/system/2003/10/16/000651155.shtml>\n--\nDan Silver\nRockville, Maryland, USA\n<daniel.silver6@verizon.net>\n[The study in the Chinese Science Bulletin (Vol. 48 No. 13 1293-1296,\n2003), referred to above by Dan Silver, states that the initial diagnosis\nof reovirus infection was on the basis of electron microscopy. Subsequently\nprimers designed to detect reovirus (presumably the orthoreoviruses types\n1, 2 and 3, which infect mammals) amplified several genome fragments, one\nof which was sequenced (an S2 -- core protein -- gene fragment), confirming\nthe presumption of reovirus co-infection. Preliminary animal experiments\nshowed that inoculation of the orthoreovirus into mice caused death with\natypical pneumonia.\nThe significance of these data is unclear. It is conceivable that the\nexpression of the disease known as SARS is dependent on the presence of one\nor more co-factors, which may or may not be other infectious agents.\nPreviously published data have suggested that Human metapneumovirus, a\ncommon respiratory virus, might be such a co-factor, but this has not been\nuniversally substantiated. The evidence for identification of an\northoreovirus as a co-factor is similarly circumstantial; certainly the\nfrequency of detection of orthoreovirus in SARS patients was greater than\nthat in the normal population, but not all (14 of 38) SARS patients were\northoreovirus-positive. The concern is that viruses such as human\nmetapneumovirus and the 3 types of mammalian orthoreovirus are ubiquitous\nin the normal population. Whereas an orthoreovirus might be a good\ncandidate for inclusion in a general class of co-factors, it is less likely\nto be a specific co-factor. The transmission of orthoreoviruses is by the\nenteric or respiratory route. Orthoreoviruses infect a wide range of\nanimals and are distributed worldwide. Human orthoreoviruses are generally\nbenign, but may cause upper respiratory tract illness or rarely -- in\ninfants and children -- enteritis. Experimentally in mice, orthoreoviruses\nmay cause a wide spectrum of disease, and viruses isolated from primates\nhave been associated with neurological disease. Avian orthoreoviruses can\ncause severe disease outbreaks in domestic flocks but do not infect\nmammals. - Mods.CP/MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Subsequently\nprimers designed to detect reovirus (presumably the orthoreoviruses types\n1, 2 and 3, which infect mammals) amplified several genome fragments, one\nof which was sequenced (an S2 -- core protein -- gene fragment), confirming\nthe presumption of reovirus co-infection. (full\nreference below). This publication includes a map of the geographical\ndistribution of SARS cases in Guangdong province from Nov 2002 to Feb 2003.\nThe full text is accessible online. The discussion section, which provides a\nbalanced summary of the results of this investigation, is reproduced below. -\nMod.CP]\nVirological surveillance in Guangdong Province in mid-February, 2003, showed\nthat the outbreak of a disease fitting the WHO case definition of SARS\nstarted in mid-November, 2002. Epidemiological investigations suggest that\nSARS probably first emerged in satellite cities of Guangzhou, circulating for\nat least 2 months before causing a major outbreak in Guangzhou itself.\nSerological tests and virus isolation confirmed that SARS CoV was the primary\ninfectious agent of these early cases of SARS. Genetic analysis of these SARS\nCoV isolates showed that they belonged to two different subgroups, one\nclosely related to that noted in Hong Kong and other countries, and one that\nseemingly had not spread to people in other regions. Phylogenetic analysis\nalso suggests that all SARS CoV share the same origin and most probably first\noriginated in Guangdong, southern China.\nIn this report, our investigation covered 55 patients with SARS from\nGuangzhou and its neighbouring cities in the early phase of the SARS\noutbreak. The findings of our study show that most of the patients had\nserological evidence of infection with the novel SARS CoV, while healthy\ncontrols did not. Information generated here suggests that SARS CoV was also\nthe primary infectious agent in the outbreaks in Guangdong Province. Because\nmost people who had SARS in other countries were directly or indirectly\nlinked to Hong Kong or Guangdong Province, we believe that the coronavirus\nmight have originated from this region. Thus, SARS, a new emerging infectious\ndisease that has become the first pandemic of the 21st century, probably\noriginated in Guangdong.\nOur epidemiological findings suggest that SARS had been spreading in an\nunusual pattern. The pandemic began with just a few index cases clustered\nmainly in families and hospital health-care workers in cities around\nGuangzhou. That specific antibodies were not present in any serum samples\nfrom healthy controls suggests that this coronavirus has not previously been\npresent in human beings in Guangzhou.\nOur analyses of genome function segments excludes the possibility that SARS\nCoV was generated by a recombination between human and animal -- or animal\nand animal -- coronavirus. SARS virus might be zoonotic and could have been\nintroduced to humans by inter-species transmission quite recently. Since SARS\nCoV had very low homologies with all known coronaviruses, our postulation is\nthat the new virus might have originally been resident in animals that have\ninfrequent contact with humans, rather than in domestic animals.\nThe strains GZ43 and GZ60 from 2 health-care workers affected within the same\nhospital seem phylogenetically similar; whereas GZ50, which is an independent\ncase from the community, is a distinct lineage. This finding suggests that\nthere were multiple lineages of viruses circulating in Guangdong. One of\nthese lineages (GZ50) maintains an outgroup relation to the major cluster of\ncases in Hong Kong and could represent the precursor virus of the Hong Kong\noutbreak. Whether some lineages are more transmissible than others is not\nclear. An analysis of more strains from Guangdong is needed to address this\nissue.\nThe spread of SARS CoV in Foshan and Zhongshan in November and December,\n2002, did not lead to an outbreak of the same scale as that in Guangzhou in\nJanuary and February, 2003. Foshan and Zhongshan, like Guandong, are large\nurban conurbations of more than 1 million people. One possibility is that the\nvirus was adapting to human beings -- i.e. human transmission with time.\nHowever, spread of the disease might have been promoted by the movement of\npeople during the Chinese New Year holiday season that, in 2003, occurred at\nthe end of January. Furthermore, Guangzhou, being a premier medical centre,\nreceived transfers of several patients with respiratory complications\nassociated with SARS.\nViruses that undergo inter-species transmission tend to undergo more rapid\ngenetic change as they adapt to a new host. In fact, we noted that the\ngenetic variation in the S gene was associated with mutations that were\nmainly non-synonymous. The SCoV isolated in our study are some of the\nearliest isolates in the global outbreak. Further genetic analysis of these\nisolates might enable us to understand the origins of this virus and how it\nbecame established in human beings.\nThe index case of the Guangzhou outbreak actually functioned as the trigger\nfor the pandemic that generated a large number of secondary infections.\nRetrospective analysis of the pathway of the SARS spread from satellite\ncities to Guangzhou, then Hong Kong and other countries, showed that the\nmajor outbreak around the world could be linked to just a small number of so-\ncalled super-spreading incidents. This finding implies that effective human-\nto-human transmission is firmly established and suggests that SARS CoV has\nbecome well-adapted to human beings.\nOne important question that has arisen from the SARS outbreak is why the new\ncoronavirus emerged in Guangdong, southern China. There might be a link to\nthe culinary habits of some southern Chinese, who consume wild game meat as a\ndelicacy. To satisfy this demand, different kinds of wild animals have been\nhunted for consumption, or raised in captivity. These animals are a likely\nsource of new emergent infectious disease to human beings. In fact, the\nemergence of the highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza virus in humans in 1997 and\nin early 2003 (unpublished data) is also zoonotic. The SARS outbreak provides\nevidence to support the hypothesis that southern China could be a site for\nemerging pandemic infectious disease in the future.\nThe investigation of the infectious agent in SARS emphasises the importance\nof international collaboration as an effective strategy to control emerging\ndiseases in people, especially for those diseases with the potential to\nbecome pandemic. The lesson from SARS outbreaks associated with coronavirus\nis that we cannot ignore or underestimate the effect of a new emerging\ninfectious disease. The best way to control a new emerging infection is to\nintervene at an early stage in the outbreak.\n[Reference: Epidemiology and cause of severe acute respiratory syndrome\n(SARS) in Guangdong, People's Republic of China, in February, 2003. N S\nZhong et al.\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journal/vol362/iss9393/full/llan.362.9393.original_r\nesearch.27546.1>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The virological data, although suggestive that the SARS coronavirus exists\nas a zoonotic infection in southern China, do not yet provide direct proof\nthat the SARS outbreak originated as the result of recent transmission of an\nanimal virus into the human population. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [The results of an investigation of the epidemiology and cause of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Guangdong, People's Republic of China\nhave been published by research workers based at several institutions in\nGuangzhou, Guangdong province, and at the University of Hong Kong, University\nPathology Building, Queen Mary Hospital, Pokfulam, Hong Kong SAR. esearch.27546.1>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n [The virological data, although suggestive that the SARS coronavirus exists\nas a zoonotic infection in southern China, do not yet provide direct proof\nthat the SARS outbreak originated as the result of recent transmission of an\nanimal virus into the human population. It was led by Dr Antony\nDella-Porta, a WHO biosafety expert. The Panel has completed its\ninvestigation and submitted its Report to the Ministry.\nEpidemiologic Investigation\nFrom the results of its investigations, the Panel has concluded that\nthe patient most likely acquired the infection in the Environmental\nHealth Institute (EHI) laboratory where he had worked.\nInappropriate laboratory procedures and a cross-contamination of West\nNile virus samples with SARS coronavirus in the laboratory led to the\ninfection of the doctoral student. No evidence could be found of any\nother source of infection.\nThe Panel's conclusion is further supported by the results of the\ngenome sequencings on the laboratory strain of SARS coronavirus and\nthat of the patient's. Both genome sequences were found to be closely\nrelated.\nThe Panel also established that there is no evidence of secondary\ntransmission and this is an isolated case of SARS.\nBiosafety Standards\nThe Panel also reviewed the 3 existing BSL3 laboratories and found a\nlarge range of biosafety structures and practices.\nThe Panel recommended that we take the opportunity to put in place a\nnational legislative framework for ensuring international standards\nin biosafety in our laboratories. Where gaps in biosafety standards\nwere identified, the Panel has made specific recommendations to\nrectify them. The details are in their Report.\nIn particular, the Panel highlighted the need for laboratory\ncertification covering both structural integrity and operating\nprocedures. A regular audit process should also be put in place for\nall BSL3 facilities. Competency based training in biological safety\nshould also be adopted and all personnel involved in BSL3 facilities\nbe properly trained.\nFollow Up\nThe Ministry thanks the Panel for their thorough investigation and\ncomprehensive recommendations. The Ministry will work with the\nrelevant agencies to follow up on the recommendations.\nThis case of accidental laboratory contamination has provided us with\nthe opportunity to improve our laboratory practices and to raise our\nbiosafety standards in all our laboratories.\nThe full report of the Panel is available at\n<http://www.moh.gov.sg/sars/pdf/Report_SARS_Biosafety.pdf>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[For those who are interested, we highly recommend reading the\noriginal report in its entirety. In addition to an in-depth\ndiscussion of possible breaches in BSL3 laboratory procedures, along\nwith recommendations for correction, there is mention that the case\nin fact did have a clinical illness consistent with SARS, including\nfever, dry cough, and both conventional x-ray and CT-documented\npneumonia. Laboratory confirmation of SARS-associated coronavirus\n(Co-V) included stool and sputum specimens positive by reverse\ntranscriptase polymerase chain reaction confirmed by 2 other\nlaboratories. Serial serum samples also documented seroconversion to\nthe SARS Co-V.\nThe report presents the following analysis:\nTransmission Hypotheses\n1) Patient acquired infection a while ago and carried it latently.\nEvidence against:\na) Patient has recent documentation of seroconversion that coincides\nwith clinical infection.\nb) Patient denies contact with any known SARS case or travel to\npreviously SARS affected areas.\n2) Patient recently acquired infection from someone\nEvidence against:\na) One work contact had recent illness, but clinical picture was not\nconsistent with SARS (nausea and vomiting; no fever). This person did\nnot work with live SARS coronavirus. Serum taken from this person 27\ndays after illness onset was negative for antibodies to the SARS\ncoronavirus.\nb) Patient denies contact with any other ill person. Interviews with\nfamily and work colleagues support this assertion.\n3) Patient acquired infection through laboratory contamination\nEvidence for:\na) Patient worked in BSL-3 laboratory 3.5 days before his illness\nonset. This is consistent with the expected incubation period for\nSARS. Although the patient reported working only on West Nile virus,\nthe laboratory was doing live SARS work around that time.\nb) Poor record keeping makes it difficult to ascertain whether there\nwas live virus in the BSL-3 laboratory on the day of his visit, but\nwe do know it was there 2 days before.\nc) Procedures for laboratory safety differed widely between\nlaboratory personnel at EHI and were not always appropriate.\nd) Testing of the frozen specimen that patient worked with on 23 Aug\n2003 was positive by RT-PCR for the SARS coronavirus and West Nile\nvirus, suggesting contamination.\ne) The laboratory works on only one strain of the SARS coronavirus,\nso the laboratory strain and patient strain were sequenced for\ncomparison. Approximately 91 percent of the genome was sequenced from\npatient and found to be most closely related to the sequence of the\nlaboratory strain. Minor differences observed are likely the results\nof the natural mutation rate for the virus.\nTo date there have been no secondary cases. The recommendation was\nmade to retest all laboratory personnel and contacts of this patient\nat 28 days following exposure to ensure no secondary transmission.\nAn interesting and sobering report. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "In addition to an in-depth\ndiscussion of possible breaches in BSL3 laboratory procedures, along\nwith recommendations for correction, there is mention that the case\nin fact did have a clinical illness consistent with SARS, including\nfever, dry cough, and both conventional x-ray and CT-documented\npneumonia.
