It is believed that the man caught\nSARS from live virus samples in one of 2 labs he worked in.\nSingapore reported the case -- its first in 4 months -- on Monday [8 Sep\n2003], making the city-state the first country to announce a new [case]\nsince the WHO declared SARS under control in July [2003].\nThe infected man, who's name has not been released, is in isolation at Tan\nTock Seng Hospital's Communicable Diseases Center. He no longer has a fever\nand is said to be recovering well.\n25 friends, colleagues and relatives of the man are under 10 days'\ncompulsory home quarantine as a precaution.\nBey also said that one of two WHO officials arrived in Singapore on\nSaturday as part of a team that will review safety procedures at both labs\nto try and determine how the man caught the virus.\nThe 10-member team -- comprised of the WHO experts, local officials and\nrepresentatives from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will\nbegin work Monday. It is headed by Dr. Anthony Della-porta, an Australian\nbio-safety expert who is expected to arrive in Singapore Sunday, Bey said.\nSingapore recorded 33 deaths from 239 infected with the virus. Globally,\nthe disease killed over 900 and sickened more than 8,400.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the prior ProMED-mail posting (SARS - worldwide (172): Singapore,\nprobable case 20030910.2276) , pending issues included confirmation of\nlaboratory findings by an independent international laboratory. According\nto this newswire, this has been completed by the USA Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention. As has been stated in prior postings, it does not\nappear as though this isolated incident is heralding a return of\ntransmission of the SARS coronavirus (Co-V) at this time, if none of the\npatient's contacts develop illness associated with SARS Co-V infection (as\nthe diagnosis was made on 8 Sep 2003, the far end of the 2 incubation\nperiod watch for additional cases prior to implementation of full\nrespiratory isolation would be 28 Sep 2003). The rapid response and\nopenness of the Singapore Ministry of Health is to be commended. We await\nthe results of the investigation as to how this apparent laboratory\naccident occurred. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "As has been stated in prior postings, it does not\nappear as though this isolated incident is heralding a return of\ntransmission of the SARS coronavirus (Co-V) at this time, if none of the\npatient's contacts develop illness associated with SARS Co-V infection (as\nthe diagnosis was made on 8 Sep 2003, the far end of the 2 incubation\nperiod watch for additional cases prior to implementation of full\nrespiratory isolation would be 28 Sep 2003). Source: The Star Online\n<http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2003/9/14/latest/14043USlabt&sec=latest>\n\nU.S. lab tests confirm that Singapore researcher had SARS\n SARS - WORLDWIDE (173): SINGAPORE, LABORATORY CONFIRMATION\n***************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-07-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2003-09-14 00:00:00", "2003-09-08 00:00:00", "2003-09-28 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SINGAPORE", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "U.S.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204739", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> SARS - worldwide (176): serosurvey China animal traders", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204739", "date": "2003-10-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (176): SEROSURVEY CHINA ANIMAL TRADERS\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 16 Oct 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity Mortality Weekly Report 17 Oct 2003 52(41);986-987 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5241a2.htm>\n\nPrevalence of IgG Antibody to SARS-Associated Coronavirus in Animal Traders\n-- Guangdong Province, China, 2003\n---------------------------\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) was identified in 2003 as an\ninfectious disease caused by the SARS-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV), a\nmember of the coronavirus family not observed previously in humans (1,2).\nBecause its sequence data differ from those of known human coronaviruses,\nSARS-CoV is suspected to have crossed the species barrier between an animal\nhost and humans.\nThe SARS outbreak began in China's Guangdong Province, where approximately\n1500 probable cases were identified during November 2002--June 2003 (3).\nDetection of SARS-like coronavirus has been reported previously in masked\npalm civets (sometimes called civet cats) and a raccoon dog for sale in a\nlive animal market in Shenzhen municipality (4).\nThis report summarizes results of an investigation conducted by public\nhealth authorities in Guangdong Province, which compared the seroprevalence\nof SARS-CoV IgG antibody in animal traders (i.e., workers in live animal\nmarkets) with that of persons in control groups. The results indicated that\n13 percent of the animal traders, none of whom had SARS diagnosed, had IgG\nantibody to SARS-CoV, compared with 1-3 percent of persons in 3 control\ngroups. Although the results provide indirect support for the hypothesis of\nan animal origin for SARS, they also underscore the need for detailed\npatient histories and more focused animal studies to confirm an animal\norigin for SARS.\nThe seroprevalence study was conducted by the Guangdong Center for Disease\nControl and Prevention (CDC) in conjunction with the Guangzhou CDC, Baiyun\nDistrict CDC, and Shijing Township Hospital. Traders in 3 animal markets in\nGuangzhou, Guangdong Province, were offered participation in the study, and\nsamples were collected on 4 May 2003 from those who gave consent. The\ntrader test results were compared with those for persons in 3 control\ngroups: 1) health-care workers involved with SARS control in 2 city\nhospitals, 2) public health workers in the Guangdong CDC facility, and 3)\nhealthy adults visiting a clinic for routine physical examinations.\nCompared with the overall control population, the animal traders were more\nlikely to be male and older; the majority of persons in both the trader and\ncontrol groups were aged 20-39 years. A sample of blood (5 mL) was drawn\nfrom each subject, and IgG antibody to SARS-CoV was tested by enzyme-linked\nimmunosorbent assay (ELISA) by using the test kit (batch no. 20030501)\nmanufactured by Beijing Huada GBI Biotechnology Co. Ltd., Beijing.\nOf 792 persons tested, IgG antibody to SARS-CoV was detected in 72 (9.1\npercent). Positive rates were highest in the trader group (13.0 percent),\ncompared with the 3 control groups (range: 1.2-2.9 percent) (Table 1\nbelow). The prevalence of IgG antibody in the trader group was\nstatistically significantly higher than that of the overall control\npopulation (chi square = 26.1; p<0.01). In contrast, no statistically\nsignificant difference was determined in the prevalence of antibody\ndetected among the 3 control groups (chi square = 0.89; p = 0.64).\nAmong animal traders, the highest prevalence of antibody was found among\nthose who traded primarily masked palm civets (72.7 percent), wild boars\n(57.1 percent), muntjac deer (56.3 percent), hares (46.2 percent), and\npheasant (33.3 percent) (Table 2). The prevalence of traders with IgG\nantibody to SARS-CoV varied by market (6 percent, 11 percent, and 20\npercent, respectively; p<0.001); no correlation was found between SARS-CoV\nantibody and sex, age, or number of years worked in a live animal market.\nNone of the subjects had SARS or atypical pneumonia diagnosed during the\nGuangdong Province outbreak.\nReported by: D Yu, MD, H Li, R Xu, MPH, J He, J Lin, L Li, W Li, H Xu, S\nHuang, J Huang, Guangdong Center for Disease Control, Guangzhou, China.\nMMWR Editorial Note:\nThis study found serologic evidence suggesting that asymptomatic infection\nwith SARS-CoV or an antigenically related virus occurred in Guangdong\nProvince. Seroprevalence of IgG antibody to SARS-CoV was substantially\nhigher among traders of live animals than among persons in control groups,\nconsistent with the hypothesis that SARS-CoV crossed the species barrier\nfrom animals to humans. The results are consistent with preliminary\ndeterminations of a joint research team from China's Ministry of\nAgriculture and Guangdong Province, which found that sequences of\ncoronavirus detected by polymerase chain reaction in bats, monkeys, masked\npalm civets, and snakes were identical to or similar to those of human\nSARS-CoV isolates. In addition, a joint study by Shenzhen CDC and Hong Kong\nUniversity determined that the sequence of coronavirus isolated from masked\npalm civets is 99 percent identical to human SARS-CoV (4). These\ndeterminations appear consistent with the hypothesis that an animal\nreservoir exists for SARS-CoV or an antigenically related virus; however,\nthe findings are not sufficient to identify either the natural reservoir\nfor SARS-CoV or the animal(s) responsible for crossover to humans.\nPrimary modes of SARS transmission probably are direct contact or droplet\nspread from a patient symptomatic with SARS; however, other routes of\ntransmission might exist (5). Approximately 63 percent of Guangdong\nProvince patients with clinically defined SARS had no known history of\nexposure to other SARS patients, and the percentage increased after April\n2003 (6). This trend of unknown exposure also was observed in other areas\n(7). Therefore, the possibility of unrecognized sources of infection or\ninfection from asymptomatic carriers of the virus cannot be excluded,\nalthough some patients might also have pneumonia caused by etiologies other\nthan SARS-CoV.\nThe findings in this report are subject to at least 4 limitations. 1st,\nalthough subjects were categorized as primarily traders of the animals they\nwere selling at the time of the survey, a substantial portion traded or\nhandled more than one type of animal. 2nd, the small number of subjects\nwith reported exposure to certain types of animals limits the ability to\ndifferentiate risk among specific groups of animal traders. 3rd, although\nthe animal traders worked at 3 markets in Guangzhou, risk might differ\namong traders in other parts of Guangdong Province or elsewhere in China.\nFinally, as with other urgently developed tests, validation of the ELISA\nkit employed has not been completed, and the IgG antibody cannot\ndistinguish recent from remote infection.\nThis report provides indirect support for the hypothesis that SARS-CoV\nmight have originated from an animal source and identifies multiple animals\nfor further study. However, none of the traders in this study had SARS, and\nonly 2 SARS patients in Guangdong Province were identified as animal\ntraders (i.e., a snake seller and a pigeon seller) (6). In contrast,\ncomparative analysis of early Guangdong cases, unlinked to other SARS\ncases, indicated an overrepresentation of food handlers (6). Whether the\nantibody detected in the animal traders in this report might represent\ninfection with a related coronavirus that cross-reacts with SARS-CoV, or\nwhether that antibody provides protection from SARS, is not known. Efforts\nto identify a possible animal reservoir for SARS might benefit from prompt\nattention to collecting detailed histories from any future SARS patients\nregarding animal and other environmental exposures and initiating\ntracebacks to animal supply sources (e.g., markets, farms, and wildlife areas).\nAcknowledgments\nThis report was based on contributions by Guangzhou Municipal Center for\nDisease Control (CDC), Baiyun District CDC; Shijing Township Hospital,\nGuangdong Province; CK Lee, MD, World Health Organization (WHO)--China SARS\nTeam, Beijing, China. A Schuchat, MD, WHO-China SARS Team and National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases, CDC.\nReferences\n1. Drosten C, Gunther S, Preiser W, et al. Identification of a novel\ncoronavirus in patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome. N Engl J\nMed 2003;348:1967--76.\n2. Ksiazek TG, Erdman D, Goldsmith CS, et al. A novel coronavirus\nassociated with severe acute respiratory syndrome. N Engl J Med\n2003;348:1953--66.\n3. Li LH, Peng GW, Liang WJ, et al. Epidemiological analysis on SARS\nclustered cases in Guangdong province. South China J Prev Med 2003;29:3--5.\n4. Guan Y, Zheng BJ, He YQ, et al. Isolation and characterization of\nviruses related to the SARS coronavirus from animals in southern China.\nScience 2003;302:276--8.\n5. Ng SK. Possible role of an animal vector in the SARS outbreak at Amoy\nGardens. Lancet 2003;362:570--2.\n6. He JF, Xu RH, Yu DW, et al. Severe acute respiratory syndrome in\nGuangdong Province of China: epidemiology and control measures. Chin J Prev\nMed 2003;37:227--32.\n7. Beijing Joint SARS Expert Group. Large outbreak of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS) in Beijing, 2003. Emerg Infect Dis (in press).\nTable 1 - Prevalence of IgG antibody to SARS-associated coronavirus in\nanimal traders and persons in 3 control groups -- Guangdong Province,\nChina, 2003\nGroup: No. tested / Testing positive (No./percent)\nAnimal traders 508 / (66/ 13.0)\nHospital workers 137 / (4/ 2.9)\nGuangdong CDC workers 63 / (1/1.6)\nHealthy adults in clinic 84 / (1/1.2)\nChi square 26.1 p less than 0.02 animal traders versus other groups\n\nTable 2 - Prevalence of IgG antibody to SARS-associated coronavirus in\nselected animal traders, by primary animal traded -- Guangdong Province,\nChina, 2003\nPrimary animal traded *: No. traders/ testing positive (No./percent) /\nrelative risk/ (95 percent CI)\nMasked palm civet: 22/ (16/ 72.7) / 7.9 / (5.0-12.6)\nWild boar 28/ (16/ 57.1) / 6.2 / (3.8-10.3)\nMuntjac deer 16/ (9/ 56.3) / 6.1 / (3.4-10.9)\nHare 13/ (6/ 46.2) / 5.0 / (2.5-10.2)\nPheasant 9/ (3/33.3)/ 4.9 / (0.7-24.8) **\nCat 43/ (8/ 18.6)/ 2.0 (1.0-4.2)\nOther fowl 25/ (3/ 12.0)/ .3 (o.2-5.0) **\nSnake 250/ (23/ 9.2)/ Reference group\n* Categories not mutually exclusive, except for snakes\n** Odds ratio and 95 percent confidence interval by Fisher exact test\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These data are interesting and tantalizing although not definitive. In\naddition to the questions posed in the discussion above, there is the\nquestion of asymptomatic infection with the SARS-associated coronavirus\n(SARS-CoV), and its relevance to possible transmission. Anecdotal\ninformation (hearsay) gathered by this moderator is that some individuals\nwith positive IgG for the SARS-CoV (presumed to be indicative of prior\ninfection with the virus) when interviewed were noted to have had a history\nof respiratory illness, but in the absence of hospitalization, were not\nconsidered to have had 'the disease'.\nIt would be interesting to know whether the definition used in the above\nstudy for diagnosis of 'SARS or atypical pneumonia' in the study group was\nbased on a systematic interview of study participants to determine whether\nthere had been a history of a significant respiratory illness on the part\nof those animal traders with IgG evidence of infection with the SARS-CoV,\nor whether illness was defined as having been hospitalized with a diagnosis\nof SARS. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "It would be interesting to know whether the definition used in the above\nstudy for diagnosis of 'SARS or atypical pneumonia' in the study group was\nbased on a systematic interview of study participants to determine whether\nthere had been a history of a significant respiratory illness on the part\nof those animal traders with IgG evidence of infection with the SARS-CoV,\nor whether illness was defined as having been hospitalized with a diagnosis\nof SARS. SARS - WORLDWIDE (176): SEROSURVEY CHINA ANIMAL TRADERS\n***************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2003-05-01 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-05-04 00:00:00", "1972-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Guangzhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong \n Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Schuchat", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong \n University", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Guangdong Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Baiyun District CDC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204534", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (172): Singapore, probable case", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204534", "date": "2003-09-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (172): SINGAPORE, PROBABLE CASE\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Sep 2003\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO CSR website 10 Sep 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_09_10/en/>\n\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Singapore\n------------------------\nSingapore has a laboratory-confirmed case of SARS coronavirus (CoV)\ninfection. This single case is in a 27-year-old postgraduate medical\nstudent who worked in a virology laboratory in Singapore. The patient\ndeveloped fever, was hospitalized and isolated, and his fever has now\nresolved. Contact tracing is continuing, but it has not identified any\nsecondary cases arising from this infection.\nIt is well recognized that most viruses can cause a range of illness from\nmild to severe. The goal of WHO's SARS guidance in the post-outbreak period\nis to rapidly identify threats to global public health. Consequently, WHO's\ncase definitions are designed to provide early warning and give health\nofficials direction for responding to a new outbreak of SARS. The Singapore\ncase is mild, isolated, and has not produced secondary cases, and therefore\nis not regarded as a public health concern.\nWHO continues to applaud Singapore's public health officials for the\nopenness with which they have responded to this event and the rapid\nprecautions taken to contain a possible threat.\nSince there is a suggestion that this case may have resulted from a\nlaboratory accident, WHO will be addressing the issue of laboratory safety\nat its meeting of SARS scientific advisors in October 2003 in Geneva.\nTo conclude, in relation to SARS, Singapore continues to be a safe\ndestination for travellers, and travellers from Singapore pose no risk to\nother countries.\nThis event is not an international public health concern.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The occurrence of this single case in Singapore not only raises a number\nof questions, but it also may be an anecdotal case report providing answers\nto some other questions.\nIf this is a case of a laboratory accident, the questions raised deal with\nsafety issues for those laboratories dealing with the SARS-associated\ncoronavirus (Co-V). According to the information available, the case in\nquestion visited a laboratory that had handled the SARS Co-V 3 days prior\nto his visit. How did this infection occur? What was the laboratory\ncontamination method that allowed for transmission of the virus\napproximately 3 days after the virus was worked with?\nAgain, according to the information available, the date of onset of the\nfebrile disease was 26 Aug 2003, the date of admission to the first\nhospital 3 Sep 2003, and the tentative date of identification of the SARS\nCo-V as the etiologic agent approximately 8 Sep 2003. The case description\nmentioned the onset of a dry cough after the day of admission to hospital\n(approximately 3 Sep 2003). There are currently 25 individuals who had\ncontact with this patient prior to implementation of SARS recommended\nisolation measures, with dates of exposure presumed to be ranging from 26\nAug 2003 through approximately 8 Sep 2003. The high index of suspicion of\nthe Singapore health sector, combined with the rapid implementation of\ncontrol measures, including case isolation, contact tracing, and home\nquarantine, may well have averted further transmission of the SARS Co-V in\nSingapore.\nThat being said, if there are no further cases associated with this\nincident, one wonders whether mild infection with the absence of\nsignificant pulmonary involvement produces a 'dead-end' infection that is\nnot transmitted to others, as the viral load excreted by these infected\nindividuals may be too low for continued transmission. Similarly, in the\nabsence of a significant aerosolization of the virus, either as droplets,\nfomites, or fine aerosol 'mist' (as seen with the use of nebulizers), a\nlaboratory accident transmission may not produce a high enough viral load\nto result in serious disease in immuno-competent individuals.\nWe await further information on the investigation of this case, on\ninternational laboratory validation of the laboratory diagnostics\nperformed, and on the outcome of the identified contacts, both those with\nperson-to-person contact with this case prior to diagnosis, as well as\nother laboratory personnel potentially exposed to the SARS Co-V in the same\ntime frame. It appears to be a single, isolated case. The patient is currently\nisolated at the Communicable Disease Centre [CDC]. Investigations are\non-going to establish the source of infection. His contacts have largely\nbeen followed up and all of them are well. As a precautionary measure, MOH\nhas served HQOs on his close contacts.\nChronology of event\nThe patient is a 27-year-old Chinese Singaporean post-doctoral student\nworking on West Nile virus at a microbiology laboratory in the National\nUniversity of Singapore (NUS). He also does some work at the Environment\nHealth Institute (EHI) laboratory of the National Environment Agency. He\nlast visited the EHI laboratory on 23 Aug 2003. He has no history of travel\nto previously SARS-affected areas and no known contact with SARS patients.\nOn 26 Aug 2003, he went to work at the NUS lab and was well but he\ndeveloped fever around midnight. On 27 Aug 2003, he consulted a general\npractitioner [GP] and was given a course of antibiotics. The fever\npersisted and he sought treatment at the SGH A&E [Emergency Department] on\n29 Aug 2003. His chest X-ray was normal. He was diagnosed to have a viral\nfever and discharged from the A&E. As he did not feel better, he consulted\na Chinese physician on 1 Sep 2003. Two days later, on 3 Sep 2003, he sought\ntreatment again at the SGH A&E and was admitted.\nFrom the time he became unwell on midnight of 26 Aug 2003 till his\nadmission to SGH on 3 Sep 2003, he remained at home apart from his two\nvisits to SGH A&E, the GP and Chinese physician.\nWhen he was admitted to the SGH, he complained of fever, muscle aches and\njoint pains, but did not have any significant respiratory symptoms. He\ndeveloped a dry cough after admission. Three serial chest X-rays at SGH\nwere all normal. However, on 8 Sep 2003, when his PCR and serology test\nresults were returned positive, the patient was transferred to the CDC for\nfurther management. He remains well.\nDiagnosis\nA repeat of his PCR tests was done in NUH lab today and was confirmed\npositive. In view of his positive PCR and serology results, MOH is treating\nhim as a probable SARS case.\nSource of infection\nInvestigations are underway to identify the patient's source of infection.\nPrecautionary measures at the laboratories\nPending investigation, the 2 laboratories have suspended all their research\nactivities. Meanwhile, the staff members of the laboratories have also been\nasked to stay at home until the all-clear is given. No staff member has\nfever or feels unwell.\nPrecautionary measures at the SGH\nAlthough the patient was isolated throughout his stay in the SGH and the\nstaff who had contact with him were in protective gear, the SGH is not\ntaking any chances and has ramped up its precautionary measures to Orange\nAlert Level. These include restrictions to visitation of the affected wards\nand more intensive temperature surveillance of staff.\nHome Quarantine Order\nGroup Number\nFamily members of case 8\nTCM [Traditional Chinese Medicine Practicioner] Sinseh 2\nSGH A&E outpatients 8\nVisitors 3\nDischarged patients 4\nTotal 25\nConclusion\nMOH has notified the WHO of the incident and the details of the case. WHO\nhas informed us that the case does not fulfill the case definition for SARS\nunder the new WHO guidelines post-SARS.\nMOH's assessment is that this case was a low public health risk as the\npatient was picked up and isolated early.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The above press release from the Singapore Ministry of Health is very\ninformative on the status of the investigation and control measures\nimplemented. The statement that the case does not meet the case definition\nfor SARS under the new WHO guidelines post-SARS refers to the guidelines\nissued by WHO on 14 Aug 2003 (available for review at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/postoutbreak/en/>, and covered in ProMED-mail\nposting SARS - worldwide (166): cases 20030817.2061). In this\ndocument there is the statement:\n'In the post-outbreak period, all countries must remain vigilant for the\nrecurrence of SARS and maintain their capacity to detect and respond to the\nre-emergence of SARS should it occur. The WHO case definitions during the\noutbreak period relied heavily on epidemiological criteria to increase the\nspecificity of syndromic clinical criteria for atypical pneumonia or\nrespiratory distress syndrome (RDS). However, epidemiological links to\ncases of SARS and areas reporting recent local transmission are no longer\nof use in helping to define incident cases. Furthermore, the non-specific\nclinical features of SARS, the lack of a current rapid diagnostic test that\ncan reliably detect SARS-CoV (SARS associated coronavirus) in the first few\ndays of illness, and the seasonal occurrence of other respiratory diseases,\nincluding influenza, may confound any surveillance for SARS or demand a\nlevel of quality and intensity which few health care system worldwide can\nsustain. Even with the most sophisticated surveillance systems, the first\ncase of SARS in the post-outbreak period may escape early detection.'\nThe background piece goes on to discuss recommendations for surveillance\nfor re-introduction of SARS, dividing countries into 3 groups -- those\nconsidered a Potential zone of re-emergence of SARS ('Identified as\nsource(s) of the previous outbreak in November 2002 or areas with an\nincreased likelihood of animal to human transmission of SARS-CoV infection'),\nNodal areas ('Sustained local transmission experienced during the previous\noutbreak or entry of large numbers of persons from the potential zone of\nre-emergence of SARS-CoV.') and Low risk areas ('Never reported cases,\nreported only imported cases or experienced only limited local transmission\nduring the previous outbreak.').\nThe WHO document also provides a clinical case definition for a probable\ncase of SARS as:\n'A person with a history of: Fever (= 38\u00b0C) AND One or more symptoms of\nlower respiratory tract illness (cough, difficulty breathing, shortness of\nbreath) AND Radiographic evidence of lung infiltrates consistent with\npneumonia or RDS OR autopsy findings consistent with the pathology of\npneumonia or RDS without an identifiable cause. AND No alternative\ndiagnosis can fully explain the illness.' and then provides a laboratory\ncase definition of SARS.\nThat being said, the above case described by the MOH press release does not\nmeet the full clinical case definition as there is no mention of Chest X\nRay abnormalities. Of note is that according to the description given, the\nonset of cough began sometime after admission to hospital on 3 Sep 2003, or\n6 days prior to this press release. The laboratory work presented --\nvalidation of PCR testing by the NUH laboratory and the serology results,\nis consistent with a laboratory diagnosis of infection with the SARS Co-V.\nAs we are very much on the upward slope of the learning curve with respect\nto SARS including it's full spectrum of clinical presentation, the\nepidemiology and transmission of the disease and etiologic agent, and the\nlaboratory diagnostic testing, the approach of the MOH of Singapore in\ntreating this case as a probable case, implementing control measures and\ninvestigations consistent with this being a probable case are commendable\nand highly prudent at this point in time. Singapore would classify as a\n'nodal area' where heightened surveillance is recommended. The source of\ninfection/exposure to the SARS CoV at this time is unknown, albeit the\nbackground information that this case is post-doctoral student working on\nWest Nile virus at a microbiology laboratory in the National University of\nSingapore (NUS) and also does some work at the Environment Health Institute\n(EHI) laboratory of the National Environment Agency, raises the possibility\nthat there may have been an occupational exposure in the laboratory that\nresulted in infection with the SARS CoV.\nWe await further information as it becomes available. - Mod.MPP]\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Pablo Nart for submitting a newswire on\nthis as well. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "The source of\ninfection/exposure to the SARS CoV at this time is unknown, albeit the\nbackground information that this case is post-doctoral student working on\nWest Nile virus at a microbiology laboratory in the National University of\nSingapore (NUS) and also does some work at the Environment Health Institute\n(EHI) laboratory of the National Environment Agency, raises the possibility\nthat there may have been an occupational exposure in the laboratory that\nresulted in infection with the SARS CoV. The World\nHealth Organization said the reported recoveries were expected, but it was\nstill on alert, given the possibility the disease could rebound in China or\nelsewhere.\nThe 12 patients were still in hospital receiving treatment for other\nillnesses but no longer showed symptoms of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome and were not infectious, the Communist Party newspaper People's\nDaily quoted Beijing's deputy health chief Liang Wannian as saying.\n'Beijing has no more SARS patients,' he said.\nAs of Monday, the Ministry of Health said on its Web site China had 12\nremaining SARS patients in hospital, all in Beijing. At the height of the\nepidemic, the capital had the world's highest number of SARS cases.\nLiang's declaration that Beijing was SARS-free was reported a day after a\nnational anti-SARS conference, at which President Hu Jintao attributed\nChina's successful SARS battle to Communist Party leadership.\nAsked about the timing of the announcement clearing Beijing of SARS cases,\na WHO spokesman said the U.N. body had no reason to suspect China, which\ndrew widespread condemnation for initially concealing the extent of the\noutbreak, was not telling the truth. 'No alarm bells went off here,' said\nWHO Beijing spokesman Bob Dietz. 'This would be the way this thing would\ntail off in the end.'\nBut he added: 'Our greater problem, and not just in China, is when and if\nthis stuff comes back. And we're very much on the alert for that,' he said.\nSome medical experts say SARS may only be dormant and could return once the\nhot summer weather cools off. Others say it is possible there are milder,\nmutated versions of the disease that are virtually impossible to detect and\nmay be circulating among the wider population.\nSARS first surfaced in southern China in November 2002 and was spread\naround the world by travelers, infecting more than 8000 people and killing\nmore than 800. Air travel was badly hit by the scare, as were the leisure\nand tourism industries.\nThe virus killed more than 340 people in China -- 190 in Beijing alone --\nand infected more than 5300 people nationwide. SCoV-like viruses were isolated from\nHimalayan palm civets found in a live animal market in Guangdong, China.\nEvidence of virus infection was also detected in other animals, including a\nraccoon-dog, and in humans working at the same market. All the animal\nisolates retain a 29-nucleotide sequence, which is not found in most human\nisolates. The detection of SCoV-like viruses in small wild mammals in a\nlive retail market indicates a route of inter-species transmission,\nalthough the natural reservoir is not known.'\nThe following extract from the paper contains most of the important\nconclusions derived from this analysis. 'When the full genome of 2 animal\n[Himalayan palm civet] and 5 human viruses were compared, the most striking\ndifference was that these human viruses have a 29-nucleotide deletion\n(5'-CCTACTGGTTACCAACCTGAATGGAATAT -3', residue 27869 to 27897) at 246\nnucleotides upstream of the start codon of the N gene. Of human SCoV\nsequences currently available in GenBank, there was only one (GZ01) with\nthis additional 29-nucleotide sequence.\n'In addition to that, there were 43 to 57 nucleotide differences observed\nover the rest of the genome. Most of these differences were found in the S\ngene coding region. The existence of the additional 29-nucleotide sequence\nin the animal viruses results in [disruption of] open reading frames (ORFs)\n10 and 11 and merging these 2 ORFs into a new ORF encoding a putative\nprotein of 122 amino acids. This putative peptide has a high homology to\nthe putative proteins encoded by ORF10 and ORF11. Since ORF11 does not have\na typical transcription regulatory sequence for SCoV the putative ORF11\nreported by others may just be the direct result of the deletion of the 29\nnucleotide sequence. BLAST search of this peptide yields no significant\nmatch to any other known peptide. Further investigation is required to\nelucidate the biological significant of this finding.\n'When the S-gene sequences of 4 animal viruses [3 Himalayan palm civet and\none raccoon dog] were compared with 11 human SCoV viruses [HKU65806,\nUrbani, Tor 2, HKU 39849, HKU 66078, CUHK-W1, HKU 36871, GZ50, GZ01, GZ60\nand GZ43], 38 nucleotide polymorphisms were noted, with 26 of them being\nnon-synonymous changes. The S genes among the 4 animal viruses had 8\nnucleotide differences, whereas there were 20 nucleotide differences among\n11 human viruses. Thus the animal viruses, though isolated from [the same]\nmarket, are no less divergent than the human viruses isolated from Hong\nKong, Guangdong, Canada, and Vietnam. However, whereas 14 (70 per cent) of\nthe 20 polymorphisms among the human viruses were non-synonymous mutations,\nonly 2 (25 percent) of the 8 nucleotide substitutions within the animal\nviruses were. An amino acid deletion (nucleotide positions: 21690-21692)\nwas observed in 2 of the human viruses (GZ43 and GZ60). Of the 38\npolymorphisms, there were 11 consistent nucleotide signatures that appeared\nto distinguish animal and human viruses. [Phylogenetic analysis showed\nthat] the human and animal viruses [form distinct clusters], which makes it\nhighly unlikely that the isolation of SCoV-like viruses in these wild\nanimals is due to the transmission of SCoV from human to animals.\n'Our findings suggest that the markets provide a venue for the animal\nSCoV-like viruses to amplify and transmit to new hosts, including humans,\nand this is critically important from the point of view of public health.\nIt is not, however, clear whether any one or more of these animals are the\nnatural reservoir in the wild. It is conceivable that civets, raccoon dogs,\nand ferret badgers were all infected from another as-yet-unknown animal\nsource that is in fact the true reservoir in nature. However, because of\nthe culinary practices of southern China, these market animals may be\nintermediate hosts that increase the opportunity for transmission of\ninfection to humans.\n'Further extensive surveillance on animals will help to better understand\nthe animal reservoir in nature and the inter-species transmission events\nthat led to the origin of the SARS outbreak.'\n*[The full reference for this paper is as follows: Isolation and\ncharacterization of viruses related to the SARS coronavirus from animals in\nsouthern China. Y Guan, BJ Zheng, YQ He, XL Liu, ZX Zhuang, CL Cheung, et\nal. <http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/rapidpdf/1087139>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Complete sequencing of the genome of 2 coronaviruses isolated from\nHimalayan civet cats and partial sequencing of the genomes of virus from\nanother civet and a raccoon dog indicated that these viruses are\nphylogenetically distinct from viruses recovered from humans at different\ngeographic locations during the course of the SARS outbreak. The authors\ninterpret their results with due caution and suggest that the animals held\nin captivity in markets may not be the direct source of the virus\nresponsible for the outbreak of SARS in humans, but may merely have\nthemselves been infected from an-as-yet-unidentified source. The failure of\na WHO team to find evidence of SARS coronavirus in domestic poultry and\nfarmed animals reinforces the view that the wild animal markets common in\nSouth China may constitute a suitable environment for exposure to exotic\nviruses. The observation that most, but not all, of the human isolates have\na 29-nucleotide deletion of sequence in comparison with the market animal\nvirus sequences is intriguing but difficult to interpret, since it has been\nreported that a deletion of sequence in the same region occurred during a\nfew passages of the Frankfurt 1 strain of SARS coronavirus in cultured\ncells. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The observation that most, but not all, of the human isolates have\na 29-nucleotide deletion of sequence in comparison with the market animal\nvirus sequences is intriguing but difficult to interpret, since it has been\nreported that a deletion of sequence in the same region occurred during a\nfew passages of the Frankfurt 1 strain of SARS coronavirus in cultured\ncells. 'What is\nsurprising is we got positive results from mammals, from birds and from\nreptiles,' said Francois Moutou, a French expert on epidemic disease. 'This\nis very strange, because usually we don't find viruses ... affecting so many\n[different] animals,' he told a briefing in Beijing.\nAfter a week-long trip to Guangdong, where the atypical pneumonia erupted\nlate in 2002, the search for an animal carrier remains a 'work in progress,'\naccording to health officials.\nOne of the main findings by the expert group was the realization that finding\nthe origin and nature of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) may be a\nmuch more complex task than initially hoped.\n'There may be many animals that are capable of being infected, but they\nmight not be capable of transmitting the virus to people,' Hume E. The training program is meant to\nbetter equip health workers to prevent infectious diseases from spreading\nin hospitals, said Alan Schnur, a WHO communicable diseases expert. Finding its origin will most\nlikely take years,' says Dr Formenty, 'Right now, the need for information\nis of such urgency that even limited information will be helpful in taking\nthe right control measures. Because SARS is a global threat, international\ncollaboration is essential if we are to detect and rapidly contain any new\noutbreaks.'\nAmong the measures recommended by the joint team of specialists include the\nstrengthening of regulations in the farming, trading, and consumption of\nwildlife. This achievement means that all known chains of\nperson-to-person transmission of the SARS virus have now been broken.\n'With the last known chain of transmission interrupted in Taiwan, the\nwhole world can breathe an initial sigh of relief,' said Dr David\nHeymann, the WHO Executive Director for communicable diseases. 'At\nthe same time, public health must not let down its guard, as more\ncases could still surface somewhere in the world. SARS has taught us\nthat a single case is capable of igniting an outbreak.'\n'Taiwan was unlucky. A lapse in infection control in a single\nhospital allowed the outbreak, which had been under good control, to\nescalate. But the authorities reacted quickly and appropriately. In\ndoing so, they have also strengthened capacity to deal with any\nfuture outbreaks.'\nThe last reported probable case in Taiwan, and--for the moment--in\nthe world, was detected and isolated on 15 June. Two consecutive\n10-day incubation periods have now passed with no further cases\ndetected.\nThe achievement comes just slightly more than four months since the\nvirus began moving around the world, in late February, along the\nroutes of international air travel.\nTaiwan's first case of SARS occurred in a 54-year-old businessman\nwith a travel history, in late February, to Guangdong Province,\nChina, where the earliest cases of SARS are now known to have\noccurred. The businessman was hospitalized on 8 March.\nTaiwan eventually had to cope with the third largest outbreak on\nrecord, including 674 cases and 84 deaths. The largest outbreaks\noccurred in mainland China (5327 cases and 348 deaths) and Hong Kong\n(1755 cases and 298 deaths).\nThe outbreak in Taiwan initially grew slowly, with only 23 probable\ncases detected in the first month. Of these, a single health care\nworker, a doctor, became infected when he treated the wife of the\nbusinessman. All of the earliest cases could be directly linked to\nclose contact with a SARS patient, or had a history of recent travel\nto an area where local transmission was known to be occurring. Only 4\nof the early cases resulted from secondary spread within Taiwan.\nThe outbreak began to escalate in mid-April following a lapse in\ninfection control procedures, which allowed the disease to spread\nrapidly within the hospital setting and then into the wider\ncommunity. In dealing with the emergency that followed, health\nauthorities rapidly introduced a series of sweeping measures. The\nsurveillance system was upgraded and began to deliver the kind of\ninformation needed for prompt and targeted action. Hospital\nprocedures for infection control were tightened, and a logistics\nsystem was developed to ensure the efficient delivery of protective\nequipment and other supplies.\nMass education campaigns persuaded the population to check frequently\nfor fever and report promptly at fever clinics, which greatly reduced\nthe time between onset of symptoms and isolation of patients. The\nestablishment of a mechanism for coordinating the response of all\nrelevant sectors was another key to Taiwan's success.\nThe global SARS outbreak developed quickly and dramatically, creating\nchallenging and stressful demands on staff and health authorities at\nevery outbreak site. The containment of SARS required heroic efforts\nand extraordinary measures that are difficult to sustain over time.\n'Interruption of the last known chain of person-to-person\ntransmission has come just in time. Health systems at every major\noutbreak site were strained to the limits of their capacity.' said Dr\nHeymann.\nWHO continues to receive rumours of possible cases, which indicates\nthat surveillance systems are working well. To date, all recently\nreported possible cases have been aggressively investigated and\ndetermined to have other causes. Failure to detect new cases over the\nnext two weeks will greatly increase confidence that the SARS\ncoronavirus has indeed been pushed out of its new human host,\nalthough a return of the disease cannot be ruled out completely on\nthe basis of current knowledge.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Let us hope this is truly the end of the alarming SARS outbreak.\nWHO deserves congratulations in its skillful management of this first\nglobal emerging infectious disease of the 21st century. The outbreak began to escalate in mid-April following a lapse in\ninfection control procedures, which allowed the disease to spread\nrapidly within the hospital setting and then into the wider\ncommunity. Taiwan's first case of SARS occurred in a 54-year-old businessman\nwith a travel history, in late February, to Guangdong Province,\nChina, where the earliest cases of SARS are now known to have\noccurred. Hospital\nprocedures for infection control were tightened, and a logistics\nsystem was developed to ensure the efficient delivery of protective\nequipment and other supplies. The global SARS outbreak developed quickly and dramatically, creating\nchallenging and stressful demands on staff and health authorities at\nevery outbreak site. All of the earliest cases could be directly linked to\nclose contact with a SARS patient, or had a history of recent travel\nto an area where local transmission was known to be occurring. The largest outbreaks\noccurred in mainland China (5327 cases and 348 deaths) and Hong Kong\n(1755 cases and 298 deaths). A lapse in infection control in a single\nhospital allowed the outbreak, which had been under good control, to\nescalate. At\nthe same time, public health must not let down its guard, as more\ncases could still surface somewhere in the world. Health systems at every major\noutbreak site were strained to the limits of their capacity.' said Dr\nHeymann. Source: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_07_05/en/>\n\nUpdate 96 - Taiwan, China: SARS transmission interrupted in last\noutbreak area ------------------------------------- With the last known chain of transmission interrupted in Taiwan, the\nwhole world can breathe an initial sigh of relief,' said Dr David\nHeymann, the WHO Executive Director for communicable diseases. ' Mass education campaigns persuaded the population to check frequently\nfor fever and report promptly at fever clinics, which greatly reduced\nthe time between onset of symptoms and isolation of patients. The achievement comes just slightly more than four months since the\nvirus began moving around the world, in late February, along the\nroutes of international air travel. To date, all recently\nreported possible cases have been aggressively investigated and\ndetermined to have other causes. Two consecutive\n10-day incubation periods have now passed with no further cases\ndetected.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-06-15 00:00:00", and irrespective of\nimmediate cause of death\n** Includes imported cases in HCWs occupationally exposed\n*** Following discarding of 3 cases, new breakdown by sex pending\n******\n[2]\nDate: 16 Aug 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website (14 Aug 2003) [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/postoutbreak/en/>\n\nAlert, verification and public health management of SARS in the\npost-outbreak period\n--------------------------------------------------------\n1. Rationale for continued vigilance for SARS\nFirst recognized as a global threat in mid-March 2003, severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS) was successfully contained in less than 4\nmonths. On 5 Jul 2003, WHO reported that the last human chain of\ntransmission of SARS had been broken. While much has been learned about\nthis syndrome since March 2003, including its causation by a new\ncoronavirus (SARS-CoV), our knowledge about the epidemiology and ecology of\nSARS coronavirus infection and of this disease remains limited. Resurgence\nof SARS remains a distinct possibility and does not allow for complacency.\nIn the post-outbreak period, all countries must remain vigilant for the\nrecurrence of SARS and maintain their capacity to detect and respond to the\nre-emergence of SARS should it occur. The WHO case definitions during the\noutbreak period relied heavily on epidemiological criteria to increase the\nspecificity of syndromic clinical criteria for atypical pneumonia or\nrespiratory distress syndrome (RDS). However, epidemiological links to\ncases of SARS and areas reporting recent local transmission are no longer\nof use in helping to define incident cases. Furthermore, the non-specific\nclinical features of SARS, the lack of a current rapid diagnostic test that\ncan reliably detect SARS-CoV in the first few days of illness, and the\nseasonal occurrence of other respiratory diseases, including influenza, may\nconfound any surveillance for SARS or demand a level of quality and\nintensity which few health care system worldwide can sustain. Even with the\nmost sophisticated surveillance systems, the first case of SARS in the\npost-outbreak period may escape early detection.\nThis document describes a SARS alert mechanism for the post-outbreak\nperiod. It provides guidance for managing a SARS 'alert' through to\nlaboratory confirmation or exclusion of people under investigation as SARS\ncases. The document does not address complex surveillance issues or case\ncategorization for SARS.\nIt also provides guidance to clinicians on the clinical presentation,\nlaboratory and radiological findings to assist in diagnosis of SARS and in\ndecisions to implement transmission-based infection control.\n2. Risk assessment\nIdeally, each member state should determine the intensity of its\nsurveillance for SARS in the post-outbreak period on the basis of a risk\nassessment. WHO has defined 3 major areas that take into account the\nexperience during the recent outbreak of SARS and the potential for resurgence:\nPotential zone of re-emergence of SARS-CoV\nIdentified as source(s) of the previous outbreak in November 2002 or areas\nwith an increased likelihood of animal to human transmission of SARS-CoV\ninfection.\nNodal areas\nSustained local transmission experienced during the previous outbreak or\nentry of large numbers of people from the potential zone of re-emergence of\nSARS-CoV.\nLow risk areas\nNever reported cases, reported only imported cases or experienced only\nlimited local transmission during the previous outbreak.\nThus, WHO recommends a staged approach to surveillance:\nPotential zone of re-emergence of SARS\n-SARS Alert AND\n-enhanced surveillance for SARS AND\n-special studies for SARS-CoV infections in animal and human populations\nNodal areas\n-SARS Alert AND\n-enhanced surveillance for SARS\nLow risk areas\n-Surveillance for clusters of 'alert' cases among health care workers,\nother hospital staff, patients and visitors in the same health care unit\n(see section 3 \u00ad The SARS Alert)\n3. The SARS Alert\nThe SARS Alert is an operational definition to ensure that appropriate\ninfection control and public health measures are implemented until SARS has\nbeen ruled out as a cause of the atypical pneumonia or RDS.\n3.1 Objectives of the SARS Alert\nProvide early warning of the potential recurrence of SARS to:\n-rapidly implement appropriate infection control measures\n-expedite diagnosis\n-activate the public health response\nRaise a global alert if indicated\nDefinition of a SARS Alert: 2 or more health care workers in the same\nhealth care unit fulfilling the clinical case definition of SARS (see\nsection 3.3) and with onset of illness in the same 10 day period;\nOR\nhospital acquired illness in 3 or more people (health care workers and/or\nother hospital staff and/or patients and/or visitors) in the same health\ncare unit fulfilling the clinical case definition of SARS (see section 3.3)\nand with onset of illness in the same 10 day period.\nA jurisdiction may chose, based on its experience, to increase the minimum\nnumber of 'alert' cases defining a cluster. The definition of the health\ncare unit in which the cluster occurs will depend on the local situation.\nUnit size may range from an entire health care facility if small, to a\nsingle department or ward of a large tertiary hospital.\n3.2 Case description of SARS\nSee Annex 1 Clinical description of SARS. The case description provides\ndetails of the clinical evolution of SARS and radiological and laboratory\nfindings to assist clinicians with its diagnosis. It provides information\non the spectrum of the disease, including atypical presentations.\n3.3 Case Definitions\nClinical case definition of SARS\nThe following clinical case definition has been developed for public health\npurposes.\nA person with a history of:\n- fever (= 38\u00b0C)\n-AND one or more symptoms of lower respiratory tract illness (cough,\ndifficulty breathing, shortness of breath);\n-AND radiographic evidence of lung infiltrates consistent with pneumonia or\nRDS OR autopsy findings consistent with the pathology of pneumonia or RDS\nwithout an identifiable cause;\n-AND no alternative diagnosis can fully explain the illness.\nLaboratory case definition of SARS\nA person with symptoms and signs that are clinically suggestive of SARS AND\nwith positive laboratory findings for SARS-CoV based on one or more of the\nfollowing diagnostic criteria:\na) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positive for SARS-CoV\nPCR positive using a validated method from:\nat least 2 different clinical specimens (for example, nasopharyngeal and\nstool) OR\nthe same clinical specimen collected on 2 or more occasions during the\ncourse of the illness (for example, sequential nasopharyngeal aspirates) OR\n2 different assays or repeat PCR using a new RNA extract from the original\nclinical sample on each occasion of testing.\nb) Seroconversion by ELISA or IFA\nNegative antibody test on acute serum followed by positive antibody test on\nconvalescent phase serum tested in parallel OR\nfourfold or greater rise in antibody titre between acute and convalescent\nphase sera tested in parallel.\nc) Virus isolation\nIsolation in cell culture of SARS-CoV from any specimen AND PCR\nconfirmation using a validated method. Testing should only be undertaken in\na national or regional reference laboratory as per WHO recommendations (Use\nof laboratory methods for SARS diagnosis). WHO will assist resource poor\ncountries to confirm their first cases of SARS through laboratory\ncollaboration.\n3.4 Public health management of a SARS Alert\nWhen a SARS Alert is raised:\n1. Patient(s) should be immediately isolated and transmission-based\nprecautions instituted, if not already in place (see clinical management\nguidelines)\n2. The diagnosis should be expedited (see Annex 2 Guidance regarding the\ndiagnosis of SARS in the post-outbreak period \u00ad A concern for all health\ncare workers). WHO will assist in the investigation of SARS alerts as\nappropriate, including the facilitation of access to laboratory services\n(see Annex 3 WHO Focal Points for SARS).\n3. Contacts of people under investigation for SARS should be traced and\nquarantined until SARS has been ruled out as the cause of the illness.\n3.1 A contact is a person who is at greater risk of developing\nSARS because of exposure to a SARS case. Risky exposures include having\ncared for, lived with, or having had direct contact with the respiratory\nsecretions, body fluids, and/or excretions (such as faeces) of cases of SARS.\n3.2 Individuals with risky exposures to a person or persons in a\nSARS alert cluster should be managed as contacts until SARS has been ruled\nout as the cause of the illness.\n3.3 Contact within the health care setting should be managed in\nthe following way:\nInpatient contacts should be isolated or cohorted away from unexposed\npatients and transmission-based precautions instituted. They should be\nplaced on fever surveillance. Exposed staff should be placed on active\nfever surveillance, and either cohorted to care for exposed patients (as\nabove) or placed on home quarantine depending on local circumstances.\n3.4 Community contacts should be:\n- given information on the clinical picture, transmission, etc. of SARS\n- placed under active surveillance for 10 days and voluntary home\nquarantine recommended\n- visited or telephoned daily by a member of the public health care team\n- temperature recorded daily.\n- if the contact develops disease symptoms, they should be investigated\nlocally at an appropriate health care facility.\n- the most consistent first symptom that is likely to appear is fever.\n3.5 National public health authorities should report every\nlaboratory confirmed case of SARS to WHO (see below).\nInternational reporting of SARS\nA new outbreak of SARS is defined as the occurrence of one or more\nclinically compatible, laboratory-confirmed cases of SARS in any country\nbased on definitive laboratory investigations. The reappearance of SARS in\nthe human population would be considered a global public health emergency.\nFor the purposes of the international reporting of SARS in the\npost-outbreak period, Member States are requested to inform WHO of\nlaboratory-confirmed cases only.\nLaboratory confirmed cases of SARS could be detected through a SARS alert\nverification process but also as sporadic case(s) of acute respiratory\nillness on which SARS-CoV testing was undertaken (that is, fulfil the case\ndefinition described in section 3.3). Reporting to WHO should include both\nof these scenarios but should exclude asymptomatic people with a positive\nlaboratory test or symptomatic people without laboratory confirmation. No\nnil reporting is required.\nWHO requests that member states immediately inform the focal points at\nregional offices or headquarters of every person meeting the\nlaboratory-confirmed case definition of SARS (see Annex 3 WHO Focal Points\nfor SARS). This will allow WHO to assess the need for a global alert and\nre-institute global surveillance for SARS on the basis of that notification\nas appropriate.\nThe development of new case definitions applicable to the new situation,\nsurveillance standards and a step-down strategy may be required once\nlaboratory-confirmed cases have been reported.\nIn the event of an international traveller being investigated for SARS, all\nmember states involved in international contact tracing around the case(s)\nshould communicate directly with each other during the investigation. WHO\nshould be informed only when the incident is laboratory confirmed.\nWHO will continue to identify and verify rumours of events of international\npublic health concern, including rumours about SARS, through its usual\nwell-established mechanisms.\nIndicators of the quality of the SARS alert mechanism\nWHO recommends that national public health authorities monitor the quality\nof the SARS alert mechanism -- for example, by establishing indicators\nbased on:\n- the number of alerts expected and reported by health facilities over time\n- the time taken to implement transmission-based precautions and expedite\ndiagnosis\n- the time taken to alert local public health authorities, national public\nhealth authorities\n- the time taken to complete contact tracing and quarantine contacts.\nThis list is not meant to be exhaustive but rather a suggested approach to\nmonitoring the alert mechanism.\n4. Enhanced surveillance and special studies for SARS-CoV infections in\nanimal and human populations\nJurisdictions in nodal areas and areas of potential re-emergence have\nmaintained heightened SARS surveillance established during the outbreak\nperiod, and continue doing so for the foreseeable future. WHO will\nencourage these jurisdictions to make available to the global community the\ndetails of these surveillance activities and will offer its assistance in\nsummarizing and updating available information on its website.\nDepending on risk assessment and available resources, nodal areas and areas\nof potential re-emergence may include one or more of the following activities:\nSurveillance for atypical pneumonia in settings such as nursing homes,\nrehabilitation units, community health care centres and in private practice\n(see Annex, Guidance regarding the diagnosis of SARS in the post-outbreak\nperiod - A concern for all health care workers)\nsurveillance of people discharged from hospital with a diagnosis of\nunspecified atypical pneumonia\nsurveillance for absenteeism among health care workers\nlaboratory-based surveillance of SARS-CoV infection\nsurveillance for requests for laboratory testing of respiratory pathogens\nor SARS-CoV\nsurveillance for unexplained deaths following an acute respiratory illness\nserological surveillance of high risk populations (health care workers,\nanimal handlers, market vendors, hunters, etc)\ncommunity-based serological surveys to monitor changes in the\nseroprevalence of SARS-CoV infection\nserosurveys among animal populations.\nThis list is not meant to be exhaustive but rather a suggested approach to\nenhanced surveillance.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As of 7 Aug 2003 there have been a cumulative total of 8422 cases of SARS\nwith 916 deaths (case fatality rate 11.0 per cent) attributable to SARS\nreported (note that during the past week there have been 2 additional\ndeaths reported in Canada thereby raising the total number of deaths due to\nSARS in Canada to 43, and overall to 918 with the case fatality rate still\nat 10.9).Sixty-four cases of SARS are still in hospital; 7442 cases have\nrecovered (88.4 per cent). Of the reported cases, 1725 (20 per cent) were\nhealth care workers. The above table presents additional information by\ncountry including the male/female distribution of cases, the median age of\ncases and the range of ages, the number of imported cases and the dates of\nonset of the first and last probable case reported.\nThe second part of this posting contains the key strategies for heightened\nsurveillance in the post-SARS period. The full information can be found at\nthe web address shown. In addition the laboratory case definition of SARS\nused is: a person with symptoms and signs that are clinically suggestive of\nSARS AND with positive laboratory findings for SARS-CoV based on one or\nmore of the following diagnostic criteria presented.) Thus, in accordance\nwith the currently established case definitions, the ongoing outbreak in\nBritish Columbia is not currently considered to be an outbreak of SARS. -\nMod.MPP]", "summary": "Depending on risk assessment and available resources, nodal areas and areas\nof potential re-emergence may include one or more of the following activities:\nSurveillance for atypical pneumonia in settings such as nursing homes,\nrehabilitation units, community health care centres and in private practice\n(see Annex, Guidance regarding the diagnosis of SARS in the post-outbreak\nperiod - A concern for all health care workers)\nsurveillance of people discharged from hospital with a diagnosis of\nunspecified atypical pneumonia\nsurveillance for absenteeism among health care workers\nlaboratory-based surveillance of SARS-CoV infection\nsurveillance for requests for laboratory testing of respiratory pathogens\nor SARS-CoV\nsurveillance for unexplained deaths following an acute respiratory illness\nserological surveillance of high risk populations (health care workers,\nanimal handlers, market vendors, hunters, etc)\n A person with symptoms and signs that are clinically suggestive of SARS AND\nwith positive laboratory findings for SARS-CoV based on one or more of the\nfollowing diagnostic criteria:\na) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positive for SARS-CoV\nPCR positive using a validated method from:\nat least 2 different clinical specimens (for example, nasopharyngeal and\nstool) OR\nthe same clinical specimen collected on 2 or more occasions during the\ncourse of the illness (for example, sequential nasopharyngeal aspirates) OR\n2 different assays or repeat PCR using a new RNA extract from the original\nclinical sample on each occasion of testing. <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, News, Mon 21 Jul 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cbc.ca/stories/2003/07/21/sars030721>\n\nConfirmation of the Identity of the SARS Agent\n----------------------------------------------\nAn international team of scientists say they have conclusively identified\nthe virus responsible for SARS. As suspected since the height of the\noutbreak, a [novel] coronavirus is responsible for the disease. 'The\nsignificance of the paper [published online in the journal 'The Lancet' on\nTue 22 Jul 2003; see below. - Mod.CP] is confirming that this [novel]\ncoronavirus does produce very serious disease,' said Frank Plummer,\nScientific Director at the National Microbiology lab in Winnipeg. The\nresearchers [confirmed the identity of] the virus by looking at clinical\nand post-mortem samples from 436 SARS patients in 6 countries. They also\ninjected the virus into 4 macaques (a species of monkey common in Southeast\nAsia), 3 of which went on to develop SARS-like symptoms.\n'Collectively, these results of laboratory studies of SARS patients and\nexperimental infections of macaques prove that the newly discovered\nSARS-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV) is the primary causal agent of\nSARS,' said the study's lead author, Prof. Albert Osterhaus of Erasmus\nUniversity, the Netherlands, in a press release.\nPlummer's team at the National Microbiology Centre was able to find\nSARS-CoV in only 60 percent of samples from SARS patients that they\nexamined. He thinks there's something else going on that scientists don't\nyet understand. One possibility is that some people listed as probable\ncases actually had something else that looked like SARS. Microbiologist Dr.\nDonald Low of Mount Sinai Hospital in Toronto said that it is vital to have\na definitive diagnosis for SARS. 'That's going to help us, especially if we\nsee clusters of cases where we were able to get a number of different\nsamples and if they come back negative, being able to say this is not\nSARS.' Furthermore, SARS could be a seasonal disease, poised to return\nlater this year along with the usual cases of cold and influenza.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The Lancet paper can be accessed\nonline: <http://image.thelancet.com/extras/03art6318web.pdf>\nThe paper is entitled 'Newly discovered coronavirus as the primary cause of\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome', authored by Thijs Kuiken, Ron A M\nFouchier, Martin Schutten, Guus F Rimmelzwaan, Geert van Amerongen, Debby\nvan Riel, Jon D Laman, Ton de Jong, Gerard van Doornum, Wilina Lim, Ai Ee\nLing, Paul K S Chan, John S Tam, Maria C Zambon, Robin Gopal, Christian\nDrosten, Sylvie van der Werf, Nicolas Escriou, Jean-Claude Manuguerra,\nKlaus St\u00f6hr, J S Malik Peiris, Albert D M E Osterhaus. The Summary of the\npaper reads as follows:\n'The worldwide outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is\nassociated with a newly discovered coronavirus, SARS-associated coronavirus\n(SARS-CoV). We carried out clinical and experimental studies to assess the\nrole of this virus in the causation of SARS. We tested clinical and\npostmortem samples from 436 SARS patients in 6 countries for infection with\nSARS-CoV, human metapneumovirus, and other respiratory pathogens. We\ninfected 4 cynomolgus macaques (_Macaca fascicularis_) with SARS-CoV in an\nattempt to replicate SARS and did necropsies on day 6 after infection.\nSARS-CoV infection was diagnosed in 329 (75 percent) of 436 patients\nfitting the case definition of SARS; human metapneumovirus was diagnosed in\n41 (12 percent) of 335, and other respiratory pathogens were diagnosed only\nsporadically. SARS-CoV was, therefore, the most likely causal agent of\nSARS. The 4 SARS-CoV-infected macaques excreted SARS-CoV from nose, mouth,\nand pharynx from 2 days after infection. 3 of 4 macaques developed diffuse\nalveolar damage similar to that in SARS patients and characterised by\nepithelial necrosis, serosanguineous exudate, formation of hyaline\nmembranes, type 2 pneumocyte hyperplasia, and the presence of syncytia.\nSARS-CoV was detected in pneumonic areas by virus isolation and RT-PCR, and\nwas localised to alveolar epithelial cells and syncytia by\nimmunohistochemistry and transmission electron microscopy. We conclude that\nreplication in SARS-CoV-infected macaques of pneumonia similar to that in\nhuman beings with SARS, combined with the high prevalence of SARS-CoV\ninfection in SARS patients, fulfill the criteria required to prove that\nSARS-CoV is the primary cause of SARS.'\nThese data establish the principal role of the SARS-associated coronavirus\nin the causation of SARS. However, they do not exclude the participation of\nother co-factors or agents such as Human metapneumovirus, although the role\nof the latter can probably be discounted in view of its high prevalence in\nthe respiratory tract of the general population. As Dr. Low points out,\nthese concerns will persist until an accurate diagnostic test becomes\navailable. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 21 Jul 2003\n \nSARS-CoV infection was diagnosed in 329 (75 percent) of 436 patients\nfitting the case definition of SARS; human metapneumovirus was diagnosed in\n41 (12 percent) of 335, and other respiratory pathogens were diagnosed only\nsporadically. The question is crucial for understanding whether\nthe disease will reemerge, but so far, there's lots of dissent with no\nsolid answers.\n\nAt Dongmen market, almost everything that's vaguely edible is for sale. The\ncavernous 2-story concrete building in Shenzhen, close to the Hong Kong\nborder, houses hundreds of vendors selling live animals and seafood. Geese,\nducks, chickens, pigeons, doves, and wild birds are packed wing to wing in\nmetal cages stacked 2 and 3 high, their minders napping on top as they wait\nfor the next shopper. Nearby, rabbits are squashed in cages, and turtles\nand crabs in huge metal tubs scramble over each other.\n\nBut the market has lost some of its legendary variety. Masked palm civets,\nfor one, are missing. Before the SARS virus erupted out of nowhere in\nGuangdong last fall, eventually sweeping through Hong Kong, Beijing,\nTaiwan, and Toronto and killing more than 800 people, these distinctive\ncatlike creatures were readily available at Dongmen and similar markets\nacross the province. Restaurateurs bought them for meat, said to be tasty\nand fabled to strengthen the body against winter chills. Now, however, the\ncivets, raccoon dogs, and many of the other exotic species that are staples\nof Guangdong's eclectic cuisine are gone. Asking about civets brings either\nan amused chuckle or, occasionally, a glare and a dismissive wave of the hand.\n\nHere at Dongmen, a research team from the University of Hong Kong (HKU) and\nthe Shenzhen Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has found the\nmost intriguing leads yet about the possible origins of SARS. 2 different\nanimal species on sale here were found to harbor the virus: civets and\nraccoon dogs. Antibodies to the virus were detected in a Chinese ferret\nbadger. The government intervened, and since then, Shenzhen shopping has\nnot been the same.\n\nIf the virus does not have a reservoir or permanent hideout in animals, the\nworld can breathe a little more easily. But virologists suspect there is an\nanimal reservoir, an ecological niche in which the virus evolved and\ncontinues to thrive. 'Until we know what that source is and until steps\nhave been taken to neutralize the source, then clearly the potential [for\nthe virus to re-emerge] exists,' says Meirion Evans, an epidemiologist at\nthe Communicable Disease Surveillance Center in Cardiff, U.K., who has been\nworking with the World Health Organization (WHO) to understand the SARS\noutbreak. Despite the heightened awareness of the disease, 'the experience\nof SARS is that it doesn't take very long to break out of a local area and\ngo cross-border, if not global,' Evans adds.\n\nSo far, however, the hunt for the reservoir is yielding more confusion than\nclarity. Unlike the HKU-Shenzhen CDC investigators, a research team at the\nChina Agriculture University (CAU) in Beijing has been unable to find any\ntrace of the SARS virus in civets or dozens of other species it has\nsampled. The Beijing scientists have questioned the earlier work and\ncriticized the group for not sharing its data; the Hong Kong group has\nresponded in kind. But emerging-disease experts say that both groups could\nbe right, and the apparent discrepancy shows just how tricky the hunt for\nthe reservoir will be.\n\nA large, well-coordinated effort by multiple teams is needed to sort out\nthese questions and identify the reservoir, assert WHO officials, who last\nweek won permission from Chinese authorities to send in four teams of\nexperienced animal-virus hunters from the Netherlands, Australia, the\nUnited States, and Japan. 'Having no answers will not be good enough;\nthat's the clear message we're getting from our member states,' says Henk\nBekedam, who leads WHO's Beijing office.\n\nA WHO fact-finding mission in April 2003 picked up the first clues about\nthe origins of SARS. When the researchers were reviewing data on the\nearliest cases of an unusual form of pneumonia that had appeared in\nGuangdong between November 2002 and February of 2003, team member Evans was\nstruck by the fact that 'a fairly high proportion' of early SARS patients\nwere classified as 'food handlers,' a category that includes everyone from\nanimal wholesalers through the supply chain to cooks. In May, Evans led a\nsecond delegation that reviewed the data with Chinese epidemiologists and\nfound that 9 of 23 early patients worked in the food industry. People\nliving in the vicinity of markets were overrepresented as well. Evans also\nlearned that many restaurants in the province keep live animals on the\npremises and slaughter them as needed, a practice that could expose\nrestaurant workers to virus-laden blood and excrement. Yet, there was no\nevidence that the disease was spread by eating infected animals.\nSpeculation soon centered on Guangdong's palate for exotic fare.\n\nBy that time, several teams had fingered a previously unknown coronavirus\nas the cause of SARS. Its novel RNA sequence suggested that, unlike\ncoronaviruses normally found in pigs, cattle, chickens, or humans, this\nvirus had probably evolved in isolation for a long time before making the\nleap to humans. Realizing that the live animal markets provided fertile\ngrounds for animals and humans to swap infectious agents, Yi Guan, a\nvirologist and member of the HKU team that was among the first to identify\nthe virus, decided to investigate. With colleagues at the Shenzhen CDC, he\ndrove to the Dongmen market, just 15 minutes from the Hong Kong border. The\nteam sampled 25 animals, representing 8 exotic species.\n\nAnalyzing the samples back at their labs in Hong Kong, the researchers\nisolated a coronavirus almost identical to the human SARS virus from all 6\nmasked palm civets and from a single raccoon dog. They also detected\nantibodies to the virus, indicating prior exposure, in a Chinese ferret\nbadger. The 5 other species sampled, also tested by polymerase chain\nreaction (PCR), proved negative. Underscoring the disease link, the\nresearchers found evidence of antibodies to the SARS virus in a number of\nanimal market workers, whereas previous studies had shown that antibodies\nwere not present in the wider population. Only one difference appeared in\nthe viral RNA isolated from the market animals: It was 29 nucleotides\nlonger than RNA isolated from humans. This has fueled speculation that the\nvirus may have become more adept at propagating in humans after losing a\npiece of its genome. But the picture is complicated by the fact that\nresearchers at the Beijing Genomics Institute say they have found at least\n2 humans who were infected with the longer variety. Researchers hope\nfurther studies of each strain's characteristics -- including animal\nexperiments -- may clarify whether the minuscule difference really is\nimportant.\n\nAs had become the norm among researchers working on the SARS frontline, the\nHKU team on 23 May 2003 announced its findings at a press conference before\nsubmitting the results for scientific review. Although the team emphasized\nthat the study simply indicated a link between the virus and the exotic\nanimal trade, press reports implied that civets were spreading the disease,\nif not functioning as the hotly sought reservoir. Chinese authorities\nimmediately, although temporarily, banned hunting, selling, transporting,\nand exporting all wild animals. They also quarantined all farm-raised\ncivets in Guangdong.\n\nThen on 19 Jun 2003, a competing group at CAU held its own press conference\nto announce results from its exhaustive search for the reservoir. The\nresearchers, led by the university's vice president, agronomist Sun Qixin,\nhad cast a wide net, sampling 54 wild and 11 domestic animal species from 6\nprovinces and Beijing. Using the PCR technique, they found not a trace of\nthe SARS virus -- an apparent contradiction to the findings of the\nHKU-Shenzhen CDC team. Intrigued by Guan's report on infected animals, the\nBeijing team had paid extra attention to the masked palm civet, buying 3 of\nthem in Guangdong and another 73 wild and farmed animals elsewhere. All\nsamples were negative. (The researchers claim that they isolated a\ndifferent coronavirus from the civets, but its sequence is only 77 percent\nsimilar to that of the SARS virus.) Although the CAU researchers stop short\nof saying Guan's findings are wrong, they sharply criticize his team\nmembers for refusing to release additional details that might allow others\nto verify their claims.\n\nGuan says he will open access to the sequence data once his team's paper,\nwhich he says is now under review at [the journal] Science, is accepted.\nBut the difficulty lies in interpreting those results. Guan declines to\ndiscuss the details until the paper is published. But he emphasizes, 'We\nnever claimed that civets were the animal reservoir, nor even that civets\nwere the source of the human infection.' Guan says his findings simply\n'open the door for further investigations' to trace the chain of\ntransmission back to the source.\n\nGuan, Field, and Chen all agree that it's unlikely that civets are a\ncrucial part of the natural life cycle of the SARS virus. A more probable\nscenario, they say, is that the civets picked up the virus from another\nmore exotic animal, perhaps in the markets or holding facilities, where\nmany different species are confined in close quarters. Or these particular\ncivets could have been infected in the wild before being brought to market.\nField notes that the Nipah virus, which killed more than 100 in an outbreak\nin Malaysia in 1998 and 1999, was ultimately found to have traveled from\nits reservoir, fruit bats, through pigs to humans. A similarly circuitous\ntransmission route is likely for the SARS virus.\n\n[Byline: Dennis Normile and Martin Enserink, with reporting by Ding Yimin]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "When the researchers were reviewing data on the\nearliest cases of an unusual form of pneumonia that had appeared in\nGuangdong between November 2002 and February of 2003, team member Evans was\nstruck by the fact that 'a fairly high proportion' of early SARS patients\nwere classified as 'food handlers,' a category that includes everyone from\nanimal wholesalers through the supply chain to cooks.
