The\nresearchers, led by the university's vice president, agronomist Sun Qixin,\nhad cast a wide net, sampling 54 wild and 11 domestic animal species from 6\nprovinces and Beijing. Researchers hope\nfurther studies of each strain's characteristics -- including animal\nexperiments -- may clarify whether the minuscule difference really is\nimportant. Although the CAU researchers stop short\nof saying Guan's findings are wrong, they sharply criticize his team\nmembers for refusing to release additional details that might allow others\nto verify their claims. Geese,\nducks, chickens, pigeons, doves, and wild birds are packed wing to wing in\nmetal cages stacked 2 and 3 high, their minders napping on top as they wait\nfor the next shopper. 2 different\nanimal species on sale here were found to harbor the virus: civets and\nraccoon dogs. Analyzing the samples back at their labs in Hong Kong, the researchers\nisolated a coronavirus almost identical to the human SARS virus from all 6\nmasked palm civets and from a single raccoon dog. \n\nAs had become the norm among researchers working on the SARS frontline, the\nHKU team on 23 May 2003 announced its findings at a press conference before\nsubmitting the results for scientific review. (The researchers claim that they isolated a\ndifferent coronavirus from the civets, but its sequence is only 77 percent\nsimilar to that of the SARS virus.) But he emphasizes, 'We\nnever claimed that civets were the animal reservoir, nor even that civets\nwere the source of the human infection.' Using the PCR technique, they found not a trace of\nthe SARS virus -- an apparent contradiction to the findings of the\nHKU-Shenzhen CDC team. Intrigued by Guan's report on infected animals, the\nBeijing team had paid extra attention to the masked palm civet, buying 3 of\nthem in Guangdong and another 73 wild and farmed animals elsewhere. But virologists suspect there is an\nanimal reservoir, an ecological niche in which the virus evolved and\ncontinues to thrive. ' Only one difference appeared in\nthe viral RNA isolated from the market animals: It was 29 nucleotides\nlonger than RNA isolated from humans. But the picture is complicated by the fact that\nresearchers at the Beijing Genomics Institute say they have found at least\n2 humans who were infected with the longer variety.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "nipah virus", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-25 00:00:00", "1999-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-06-19 00:00:00", "2003-04-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-29 00:00:00", "2003-05-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Cardiff", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "guan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Shenzhen", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Guan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Field", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "U.K.", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Guangdong", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204525", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (171): diagnostic tests", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204525", "date": "2003-09-09 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS WORLDWIDE (171): DIAGNOSTIC TESTS\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: Mon 8 Sep 2003\nFrom: Richard Gould <rgould@avdha.nshealth.ca>\n\nA Comment on the Validity of SARS Diagnostic Tests\n--------------------------------------------------\nWatchfulness and caution are important. However, is too much weight being\nplaced on the lab tests?\nDo we have any good idea of the sensitivity and specificity of these\ntests? Perhaps they may be helpful in an outbreak. But what is the\npositive predictive value for a sporadic case with no epidemiological link\nto other cases and with nonspecific symptoms that may be similar to many\nother viruses? Turning the health care system upside down for a cold isn't\nappropriate either.\n--\nRichard Gould MD MHSc FRCPC\nMedical Officer of Health\nDistrict Health Authorities 1 - 3\n23 Earnscliffe Ave.\nWolfville, Nova Scotia, B4P 1X4\n<rgould@avdha.nshealth.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Mon 8 Sep 2003\nFrom: Chris Griot <Christian.Griot@ivi.admin.ch>\nSource: Swiss Medical Weekly,133:400\u00ad401,2003 [edited]\n<http://www.smw.ch/archive200x/2003/27/smw-10394.html>\n\nViral Etiology of Acute Respiratory Illnesses in Patients with Suspected\nSARS in Switzerland\n--------------------------------------------------\n[A letter to the Editor of the Swiss Medical Weekly from Kaiser L,\nDeffernez C, Thomas Y, Koch D, Masserey Spicher V, Uckay I, Schultze D,\nSiegl G, Perrin L, Matter HC, Wunderli W; Central Laboratory of Virology,\nDivision of Infectious Diseases, Department of Internal Medicine,\nUniversity Hospitals of Geneva, Geneva, and Federal Office of Public\nHealth, Division of Epidemiology and Infectious Diseases, Bern Institute\nfor Clinical Microbiology and Immunology, St. Gall]\nMost acute viral respiratory illnesses share clinical features with severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS), and detection of the SARS-associated\ncoronavirus may be negative in the course of the disease. It is thus of\ninterest to identify other viral infections to ensure a better assessment\nof the epidemiological situation and avoid unnecessary isolation and\ncontact tracing.\nPatients considered potential SARS cases in Switzerland were tested\nsystematically for 10 different respiratory viruses. RT-PCR for the\nSARS-associated coronavirus was negative in all cases. In contrast, other\nrespiratory virus infections were identified in 62 percent of cases\n(21/34). Influenza was the most frequent, being recovered in 14 cases (41\npercent); other viruses were rhinovirus, respiratory syncytial virus,\nparainfluenza, human metapneumovirus, and adenovirus. A negative\ncoronavirus RT-PCR, together with a positive result for another respiratory\nvirus and a consistent clinical course, made it possible to avoid\nunnecessary isolations and contact tracing. Our findings are also\nconsistent with the absence of large outbreaks of SARS in Europe during\nthis period.\nThe World Health Organisation (WHO) has provided a case definition for\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) based on travel history (or\ncontact with a known SARS case) and a spectrum of clinical symptoms in\npersons presenting with acute febrile respiratory illness. It is within the\naims of this definition to be highly sensitive and thus allow prompt\nidentification of cases. However, due to its lack of specificity, this\nstrategy has several limitations and may result in an inaccurate\ndescription of the epidemiological situation, particularly in\nlow-prevalence countries. Indeed, many common acute viral respiratory\nillnesses, such as those caused by influenza, respiratory syncytial virus,\nparainfluenza or human metapneumovirus, share clinical features with SARS.\nFurthermore, the spectrum of the disease following SARS-associated\ncoronavirus infection is not yet fully established, and self-limited\nrespiratory tract illnesses not fulfilling WHO criteria are likely to\noccur. Methods for the detection of SARS-associated coronavirus have only\nbeen partially validated, and RT-PCR specific assays may be negative in the\ncourse of the disease. For these reasons it is important to diagnose other\nviral aetiologies in patients with suspected SARS, to avoid both\nunnecessary investigations and quarantine.\nWe present here the results of virological investigations in potential SARS\npatients in Switzerland. Patients identified as potential SARS cases\naccording to WHO criteria, and those not fulfilling all the criteria but\npresenting with acute respiratory illness and either a recent travel\nhistory in a country or in an affected area or a documented contact with a\nsuspected SARS case, were tested for a wide range of viruses in upper\nrespiratory tract samples (nasopharyngeal swabs). Nasopharyngeal specimens\nwere inoculated for virus culture on 6 different cell lines (human\nfibroblast, A549, MDCK, LLC-MK2, Rita and Vero cells) in tubes and\nincubated at 2 different temperatures (37 deg C and 33 deg C). RNA was\nextracted from 200 ml of each specimen using 400 ml lysis buffer (HCV\nAmplicor Specimen Preparation Kit, Roche Diagnostics Corporation,\nIndianapolis, ID). Retrotranscription was performed using the SuperscriptTM\nII RNase H\u00ad Reverse Transcriptase (Invitrogen, Switzerland) and random\nprimers (dN)6 (Roche Diagnostics GmbH, Germany) for 60 minutes at 42 deg C.\nReal-time TaqmanPCR (ABI Prism 7900 HT, Applied Biosystems, Switzerland)\nwas performed for detection of respiratory viruses using specific primers\nand probes validated in our laboratory.\nScreening for the presence of the following viral RNA genomes was conducted\n(target gene in brackets): influenza A (M gene) and B (haemagglutinin\ngene), respiratory syncytial virus A and B (N gene), parainfluenza 1 and 2\n(haemagglutinin-neuraminidase gene), human metapneumovirus (polymerase\ngene), rhinovirus (5\u0092 non-coding-region) and enterovirus (5\u0092 non-\ncoding-region), and the SARS-associated coronavirus (polymerase gene). The\nfollowing primers and probe were used for SARS-associated coronavirus\ndetection: forward 5\u0092-TCACCGCGAAGAAGCTATT-3\u0092; reverse\nAGTTGCATGACAGCCCTCTACA- 3\u0092; and probe 5\u0092CGTTCGTGCGTGGATTGGCTTTG-3\u0092 based on\navailable sequences of the polymerase gene [7, 8]. In preliminary\nexperiments this assay proved capable of detecting fewer than 10 RNA\ncopies/mL. Positive and negative controls were included in each run.\nIn Switzerland during the first 6 weeks of surveillance following the WHO\nSARS alert, we identified 34 subjects with a median age of 36 years (range\n2 to 81), comprising 20 males and 14 females. On the basis of WHO criteria,\n3 cases were probable SARS, 16 were suspect cases, and in 15 the diagnosis\nof SARS was considered, but the WHO criteria were not met. All patients\nrecovered without suffering severe disease. RT-PCR for detection of the\nSARS-associated coronavirus proved negative in all subjects (median day 4\nof illness, range 1 to 9). In contrast, other respiratory virus infections\nwere identified in 62 percent (21/34). Among the 19 suspected or probable\nSARS cases according to WHO criteria, a virus was identified in 11 (59\npercent). In the overall population influenza viruses were identified in 14\ncases (41 percent), rhinovirus in 3, respiratory syncytial virus in 1,\nparainfluenza 1 in 1, human metapneumovirus in 1 and adenovirus in 1.\nRT-PCR for enterovirus and parainfluenza 3 were all negative. Among the 21\npositive cases, 11 were identified by RT-PCR only, 2 by cell culture only\n(parainfluenza 1 and adenovirus), and the remaining 8 by both methods\nconcomitantly.\nOur study showed that all subjects with suspected SARS in Switzerland\ntested negative for the SARS-associated coronavirus by RT-PCR. However,\nfollowing extensive testing, a viral aetiology was documented in the\nmajority of cases. Although a viral aetiology was likely in most of the\nremaining cases, we failed to identify a virus. This limited sensitivity\nwas related to several reasons including the delay between the onset of\nsymptoms and the time of sampling, and the type of the specimen.\nAs some recent observations suggest that RT-PCR may be negative in the\ncourse of SARS, it is essential to provide an alternative diagnosis to SARS\nif a negative result is obtained. In our series a negative RT-PCR together\nwith a positive result for another respiratory virus and a consistent\nclinical course made it possible to avoid unnecessary isolations,\ninvestigations, and contact tracing. In addition, in some instances\nsuspicion of local secondary transmission of SARS could be ruled out when\ninfluenza was documented in the index case. The epidemiological situation\ncould be better evaluated, since the number of cases remaining suspect for\nSARS was considerably reduced. Influenza virus was the most frequent cause\nof respiratory illness in this population, an observation consistent with\nthe fact that the SARS alert coincided with the peak of the influenza\noutbreak in Switzerland. However, since the majority of cases reported\nrecent travel to Asia, this observation also demonstrates the risk of\nacquiring influenza and other respiratory viruses abroad and their capacity\nfor subsequent transmission locally. Finally, our findings are consistent\nwith the observation that during this period SARS did not cause serious\noutbreaks in Europe.\n[The technical support of Delphine Garcia and Marianne Perroud is\nacknowledged.]\n--\nChris Griot\n<Christian.Griot@ivi.admin.ch>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 9 Sep 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Times 9 Sep 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/09/health/policy/09SARS.html>\n\nOutbreak That Wasn't: A SARS False Alarm\n----------------------------\nIt seemed like the typical viral 'summer cold' as it began spreading\nthrough a nursing home in the Vancouver area in early July. Then in August,\ntest results from the Canadian National Microbiology Laboratory suggested\nthat the 'cold' might be from a mutated SARS coronavirus.\nJust the hint created deep concerns in a country that had already been\nhobbled by an outbreak in Toronto last spring. British Columbia officials\ntemporarily imposed infection control and quarantine measures that had\ncontained the Toronto outbreak.\nThe disruptive and costly actions turned out to be excessive. British\nColumbia officials have since determined that the SARS coronavirus did not\ncause the outbreak. Rather, they said, its virological cousin, the OC43\ncoronavirus, which commonly causes colds, was the probable culprit.\nDisputes among Canadian officials over the virological findings have\nexposed deep flaws in the systems available to detect and monitor any\npotential outbreak in Canada and elsewhere. Not only did they underscore\nthe need for more uniform laboratory testing, but also prompted health\nofficials to renew calls for reliable tests to detect SARS, or severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome, in its earliest stages of infection.\n'The safety net for detecting the possible return of SARS is pretty\nfragile,' said Dick Thompson, a spokesman for the World Health\nOrganization, the United Nations agency in Geneva with responsibility for\ncontrolling the disease. 'It holds together, but it is spit and luck.'\nExamination of the disputed findings in Canada is also occurring as the\nworld is bracing for the possible resurfacing of SARS. A recent report from\nthe United States National Intelligence Council \u0097 which consists of experts\nfrom the academic and private sectors and which reports to the director of\ncentral intelligence, George J. Tenet \u0097 lays out 3 bleak possible\nsituations for the virus's re-emergence.\nThe 3 situations outlined in the report are disconcerting. One is a\nresurgence in countries with major trade centers as international travelers\nspread SARS the way they did this year. A second is that SARS cases will\noccur sporadically but will be detected before the disease can spread,\ncreating more of a public health nuisance than a crisis. The third unfolds\nin developing countries with weak public health systems.\nAll make early detection a priority. Canadian and United States health\nofficials and SARS experts are expected to discuss what steps may reliably\nbe taken to identify possible new SARS cases, among other topics, at a\n2-day closed meeting in Ottawa that begins tomorrow.\nTo some health officials, the outbreak at the Kinsmen Place Lodge nursing\nhome in Surrey, British Columbia, has not only revealed important gaps that\nneed to be addressed, but it may also provide lessons that can be used in\nthe face of a recurrence of SARS.\n'In a way, it was lucky that this outbreak happened before the influenza\nseason because it is better to learn about the problems now than then,'\nsaid Dr. Katrin Leitmeyer, a W.H.O. epidemiologist and virologist who went\nto the National Microbiology Laboratory in Winnipeg to review its findings.\nOne of the most glaring problems uncovered by the nursing home outbreak was\nthe absence of a formal agreement among scientists about precisely what\nsteps and laboratory methods should be used to make a definitive diagnosis\nof SARS.\nFor example, many test results remain in dispute, largely because the\nscientists involved in different laboratories did not use the same methods\nto test each specimen to try to identify the virus and to determine whether\nthe patients' immune systems had produced antibodies against it. And partly\nbecause little is left of the specimens collected from the nursing home\npatients, it will take weeks more to prove that the suspected OC43\ncoronavirus, is the cause.\nThe conflicting laboratory results have led Canadian scientists and\nofficials to clash over the validity and meaning of the tests performed on\nthe lodge residents and staff members.\n'We're at loggerheads with the National Microbiology Laboratory,' said Dr.\nMel Krajden, the chief virologist at the British Columbia Center for\nDisease Control.\nThe center's chief epidemiologist, Dr. David Patrick, said that from 1 Jul\n2003 through 5 Aug 2003, 95 of the 142 lodge residents, or 67 percent,\ndeveloped the summer cold and that 8 deaths were related to the outbreak.\nOf the 160 health workers there, 53, or 33 percent, developed the summer flu.\nInitially, Dr. Krajden's team found no evidence of viruses like influenza,\nparainfluenza and respiratory syncytial virus that are common causes of\nupper respiratory illness.\nSARS was low on the candidate list because the death rate among lodge\nresidents was 8 percent, far lower than the rate of 50 percent or more\nfound among people 60 and older in the SARS epidemic last spring.\nBut when a second wave struck the nursing home and the center still could\nnot identify a virus, health officials reconsidered SARS. 'So, having come\nup empty-handed, we said why not send some of the very limited remaining\nmaterials to' the national laboratory, Dr. Krajden said.\nIt was a step that many laboratories less concerned about the threat of\nSARS might not have taken under the same circumstances, health officials said.\nThe surprise came when Dr. Frank Plummer, the director of the National\nMicrobiology Laboratory, said that his team had found tentative evidence of\nwhat might be a mutant SARS virus.\nThen on 22 Aug 2003, provincial officials said the latest findings from the\nBritish Columbia Center for Disease Control and the British Columbia Cancer\nAgency's Genome Sciences Center 'provide conclusive evidence' that the\nvirus responsible for the nursing home outbreak was not the SARS\ncoronavirus, but probably its cousin, OC43.\n'We have clearly found large sequences of the virus that are not present in\nthe SARS coronavirus,' Dr. Patrick said.\nLast week, Dr. Larry J. Anderson, an expert on respiratory diseases at the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention [CDC] in Atlanta, said his team\nhad completed tests to detect antibodies to the SARS virus in the blood\nspecimens sent by Dr. Plummer. The CDC tests did not confirm the Canadian\nNational Microbiology Laboratory findings that SARS antibodies were present.\nDr. Plummer said he agreed that the virus was not the classic SARS virus,\nbut that his team had found no evidence of OC43.\n'We do not dispute their results, but we also believe our results,' Dr.\nPlummer said. 'Now what produced them is a puzzle.'\nAmong the possible explanations for the conflicting results is that 2 or\nmore viruses were simultaneously affecting the nursing home. Another\npossibility is that the specimens from the lodge were inadvertently\ncontaminated with SARS virus in the Winnipeg laboratory. Dr. Plummer said\nhe considered that unlikely because of the pattern of his test findings.\n'All these diagnostic tests are new and every laboratory has developed its\nown test,' he said.\n'We have a limited understanding of their performance, so comparing what\none laboratory is talking about to another is problematic,' Dr. Plummer\nsaid. 'This is obviously new territory for all of us. We are probably at a\nnormal state of development for a disease that has been around for a few\nmonths, and we will be learning every time one of these things happen.'\nThe Canadian laboratories have not succeeded in growing the nursing home\nvirus and then fully mapping its genome -- 2 findings that would provide\nthe most definitive evidence of the causative agent. But virologists say\nthat growing the coronavirus apparently involved in the nursing home\noutbreak is more difficult than growing the SARS virus in the laboratory.\nThe threat of SARS may prompt several changes in laboratory practices,\nvirologists said. For example, diagnostic laboratories rarely include\ncoronaviruses in screening tests for the cause of outbreaks of respiratory\nillness because they generally cause mild illness and because budgets\npreclude searching for every virus.\n'No one ever cared that much,' said Dr. Kathryn V. Holmes, a professor of\nmicrobiology at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Denver\nwho has studied coronaviruses for 20 years.\nDr. John MacKenzie, an Australian virologist who is temporarily helping WHO\ndeal with the threat of SARS and other emerging diseases, said the nursing\nhome episode pointed out 3 major worries about laboratory testing for SARS\nthat an advisory panel of WHO would need to address in October.\nOne is the lack of quality assurance. The various methods have not been\ntested in different laboratories under different conditions, Dr. MacKenzie\nsaid, and 'this is a big concern.'\nSecond, there is no internationally accepted standardization of the\nbiological materials known as reagents used in testing in different\nlaboratories. Dr. MacKenzie said he was particularly concerned about the\nlack of standardization of the control tests, which play a routine part in\nlaboratory testing.\nThird, Dr. MacKenzie said, 'we need to look very carefully at what we do if\nwe have a positive case.'\n'What's crucial is that a second laboratory, preferably an international\nreference laboratory outside the country that found the positive, confirms\nthe tests,' Dr. MacKenzie said. 'Some countries are not keen on this,' he\nadded, yet 'it is a major issue.'\nAt the October meeting, he said, 'We're going to go into detail about what\nis known, what isn't known, what needs to be done, and then prioritize some\nthings that need to be looked at.'\nBut because the WHO meeting will not be held until late October, it may be\ntoo late to be effective, Mr. Thompson, the agency spokesman,\nacknowledged. By then the Northern Hemisphere may be experiencing the\nusual seasonal outbreaks of influenza and other respiratory illnesses.\nUnder such circumstances, the continuing lack of a reliable diagnostic test\nfor SARS could create chaos from the continuing inability to distinguish\nSARS from other illnesses that, by coincidence, were producing similar\nsymptoms like fever, headache and cough.\n[By: Lawrence K. Altman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Dr. Gould points out the recognized and well discussed dilemma with\nrespect to the interpretations of laboratory testing conducted for\nidentification of infection with the SARS associated coronavirus (SARS CoV)\n-- the deficiencies in knowledge on the sensitivity and specificity of the\nlaboratory tests currently available. (Dr. Gould's comment was submitted\nin response to the ProMED-mail posting on a suspected case of SARS in\nSingapore 'SARS - worldwide (169): Singapore, suspected, RFI\n20030908.2249). The information from a letter to the editor of the Swiss\nMedical Weekly by L Kaiser et al and provided by Chris Griot further\nhighlights how in the absence of a clear cut outbreak of SARS,\napproximately 62 percent of patients clinically/epidemiologically\nclassified as potential SARS cases (including suspected, probable and\nothers with a history of epidemiologic potential exposure and an acute\nrespiratory illness) were found to have other viral etiologies for their\nrespiratory illness (a reminder of earlier definitions of SARS as 'a\ndiagnosis of exclusion').\nThe New York Times article gives a good overview of the dilemma faced in\nCanada following the initial laboratory reports that the SARS CoV (or\nmutant) was the etiologic agent of an outbreak of mild respiratory illness\nin a nursing home. This was later ruled out after further testing was\ndone. The points raised by Dr. MacKenzie in the interview with the NY\nTimes on the issues confronting the laboratories are very valid\npoints. First, the lack of quality assurance. The various methods have not\nbeen tested in different laboratories under different conditions. Second,\nthere is no internationally accepted standardization of the reagents used\nin testing in different laboratories. and third there is the need to look\nvery carefully at what is done if there is a laboratory positive case. He\nalso points out the crucial need of a second laboratory, preferably an\ninternational reference laboratory outside the country that found the\npositive, confirms the tests.\nThat being said, the probable case of SARS CoV infection being monitored\nand investigated in Singapore right now will further add to the above\nmentioned discussion as more information becomes available. At present the\ninitial laboratory tests have been validated by a second laboratory in the\nsame country. We await the results of further testing by an international\nreference laboratory outside of Singapore. Toronto removed from list of areas with recent local transmission\n-------------------------------------\nWHO has today removed Toronto, Canada, from its list of areas with\nrecent local transmission of SARS. The last probable case was\ndetected on 12 Jun 2003 and immediately isolated. When 20 days, or\ntwice the incubation period, have passed without detection of a new\ncase, the chain of human-to-human transmission is considered broken.\n'This is a great achievement for public health in what we hope is the\nfinal phase of the global emergency,' said David Heymann, the WHO\nExecutive Director for communicable diseases. 'Toronto faced an\nespecially challenging outbreak. As we have learned, SARS is a\ndifficult disease that produces many surprises and setbacks.'\n'We should all pay tribute to the health workers and others in Canada\nwho had their lives disrupted and threatened by this disease. When\nthe virus returned to start a second outbreak, health workers\ncontinued the fight and have now won it. We also need to remember the\ncommitment of Canada's scientists, who rapidly provided information\nabout the virus and its epidemiology that has benefited public health\naround the world.'\nToronto was among the first areas affected after the virus moved out\nof southern China, in late February 2003, and began to spread\ninternationally. WHO advised travellers to avoid all but essential\ntravel to Toronto on 23 Apr 2003. The advice was lifted a week later.\nOn 14 May 2003, Toronto was removed from the list of areas with\nrecent local transmission, only to return on 26 May after the virus\nsurfaced in a second outbreak.\nAll of the earliest and most severe SARS outbreaks have been traced\nto contact with an infected medical doctor from Guangdong Province,\nChina, who spent a single night (21 Feb 2003) on the 9th floor of the\nMetropole Hotel in Hong Kong. At least 16 guests and visitors to the\nsame floor became infected. One has been identified as the source\ncase, at the Princes of Wales Hospital, for the Hong Kong outbreak.\nOthers, who carried the virus with them when they returned home,\nseeded outbreaks in Toronto, Viet Nam, and Singapore.\nThe mechanisms by which the virus spread from one infected person to\nso many guests and visitors are still not fully understood. No hotel\nstaff were infected.\nAnother mystery is why the SARS virus spreads more efficiently in\nsophisticated hospital settings -- another factor that may have\ncontributed to the severity of Toronto's outbreak. Both\nepidemiological and anecdotal evidence suggests that certain\nprocedures, such as difficult intubation and use of nebulizers, that\nare more common in sophisticated hospitals also increase the risk of\ninfection.\nWhen the outbreak began in Toronto and, simultaneously, at the other\ninitial sites, no one was yet aware that a new disease, capable of\nrapid spread within hospitals, had surfaced in China. Hospital staff,\nstruggling to save lives, were unaware of the need to protect\nthemselves. As a result, the SARS virus spread rapidly within\nhospitals and then out into the wider community as other patients,\nhospital visitors, and close contacts of staff became infected.\nAfter WHO issued the first global alert to SARS, on 12 Mar 2003, all\ncountries experiencing imported cases, with the notable exception of\nTaiwan, have been able to either prevent any further cases or keep\nthe number of additional cases very small.\nWith today's change in the status of Toronto, Taiwan now remains the\nlast area in the world to have experienced recent local transmission\nof SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Barring new cases, Taiwan should be dropped from the list around 9\nJul 2003. The date of isolation of this case was 6 Jun 2003.\n[B] Update 91 SARS research: the effect of patents and patent applications\n30 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_30/en/>\nAs no new probable cases of SARS have been reported anywhere in the world\nsince 15 Jun 2003, WHO is moving from an emergency response to a\nresearch-based agenda aimed at protecting the world against any future\nresurgence of SARS.\nThe world must be considered vulnerable to a return of SARS pending better\nunderstanding of the origins of the virus and the circumstances that\nallowed it to jump from an animal host or environmental source to infect\nhumans. Without such an understanding, predictions of the future evolution\nof the outbreak including its end cannot be made with certainty.\nThe SARS coronavirus was detected within a month by a virtual network of\nlaboratories, working around the clock. The complete sequencing of the\nvirus genome followed almost immediately.\nThese breakthroughs have supported progress in the development of\ndiagnostic tests and greatly facilitated the investigation of unusual\noutbreaks, such as the Amoy Gardens housing cluster that affected more than\n320 persons in late March 2003. They also facilitated initial efforts to\nlink an animal species with the first human cases, which were detected in\nsouthern China in mid-November of last year [2002].\nFurther progress in the scientific understanding of SARS will depend on\ncontinued international collaboration. WHO is establishing an additional\nnetwork to expedite much-needed animal studies.\nWHO also intends to monitor the effects of patents and patent applications\non the speed with which SARS diagnostic tests, treatments, and vaccines are\ndeveloped and made available for use, and on the manner in which prices are\nset for these technologies.\nAt the moment, it is too early to know all the effects that the patenting\nof SARS-related discoveries will have. However, the filing of patent\napplications does not in itself erect any barriers to continued scientific\ncollaboration on SARS.\nThe defensive use of patents can be a legitimate part of a researcher's\nefforts to make a discovery, and related discoveries in the future, widely\navailable to other researchers, in the best collaborative tradition of\nbiomedical science.\nIn the longer term, the manner in which SARS patent rights are pursued\ncould have a profound effect on the willingness of researchers and public\nhealth officials to collaborate during future outbreaks of new infectious\ndiseases.\nWHO will therefore examine whether the terms of reference for such\ncollaborations need to be modified to ensure that the credit for any\nintellectual property developed is appropriately attributed, that revenues\nderived from licensing such property are devoted to suitable uses, and that\nlegitimate rewards for innovative efforts do not impose undue burdens on\nefforts to make tests, therapies, and preventive measures available to all.\nAs SARS has clearly demonstrated, the appearance of a new disease in a\nhighly mobile, interconnected, and interdependent world can have serious\nrepercussions outside the health sector and far beyond the areas worst hit\nby the outbreak. This sense of shared vulnerability is considered a strong\nmotivation for continued international collaboration.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\n\nAs of 30 Jun 2003 there are no new reports of either suspected or probable\ncases in Canada. Case totals stand as follows: 8461\ntotal cases, 804 deaths, 7218 recovered. The most recent probable cases\nanywhere were 2 reported from Taiwan yesterday (19 Jun 2003).\n[B] Update 85 - WHO case definition for diagnostic purposes, Hong Kong\nclose to being removed from list of areas with local transmission\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_20/en/>\nWHO case definition for diagnostic purposes\nAn article published in this week's British Medical Journal (BMJ) has\nquestioned whether the WHO case definitions for suspected and probable SARS\nare adequate to pick up infected cases at the earliest stage when patients\nare said to be most infectious <http://bmj.com/cgi/content/full/326/7403/1354>.\n[BMJ 2003; 326: 1354-8, June 21: WHO guidelines for detecting SARS need to\nbe reconsidered: The WHO guidelines for diagnosing SARS have an 83 per cent\naccuracy in detecting suspected cases. In an observational study of 556\npeople screened for SARS in Hong Kong, Timothy Rainer and colleagues found\nthat the best predictor of SARS was radiological evidence of pneumonic\nchange, which often preceded the onset of fever. The main discriminatory\nsymptoms in the early stages of the disease were fever, chills, malaise,\nmyalgia, and rigor -- not respiratory tract symptoms, as stated in the WHO\nguidelines. The guidelines had a specificity of 95 per cent and a\nsensitivity of 26 per cent for detecting SARS.]\nThe WHO case definition takes a 'wide net' approach, and is intended to\nassist in the identification and prompt isolation of any person who might\nhave been exposed to the SARS virus. WHO continues to recommend that\nsuspect cases be immediately isolated and remain so until either a probable\ndiagnosis is made or another agent is determined to be the cause.\nWhile this definition has worked well to contain the outbreak in this\ninitial emergency response, WHO is fully aware that a more precise\ndefinition is needed for longer term surveillance.\nPending the development of a reliable point-of-care diagnostic test, case\ndefinitions, based on an evaluation of symptoms and history of possible\ncontact with a SARS patient, remain the only way to find possibly infected\npersons and reduce opportunities for further spread. WHO therefore welcomes\nthe BMJ study, which suggests that additional symptoms might contribute to\na more sensitive definition. However, this is a single study based on\npatients presenting at a single hospital. Moreover, by inclusion of\nsymptoms such as diarrhoea, this definition risks picking up even more\nfalse positive cases.\nDuring the Kuala Lumpur global conference on SARS, WHO established a\nworking group specifically charged to develop better case definitions. The\ngroup will draw on data from all the main outbreak sites.\n'WHO regards an improved diagnostic test as a top priority,' said David\nHeymann, WHO's executive director for communicable diseases. 'The next\ninfluenza season will result in a large number of patients with symptoms\neasily confused with SARS. In addition to a good diagnostic test, a more\nprecise and sensitive case definition is absolutely essential to keep\nhealth services from being overwhelmed. We will be producing this as an\ninternational collaborative effort, based on the best available evidence.'\nDr Heymann estimates that SARS surveillance will need to continue for at\nleast a year. WHO recommendations for surveillance and reporting are also\nbeing revised for this second phase, which moves from an emergency response\nto sustainable vigilance.\nHong Kong close to being removed from list\nOn Sunday 22 June, 20 days will have passed since the last probable case of\nSARS in Hong Kong was placed in isolation on 2 June. If no new cases are\ndetected over the weekend, Hong Kong will be removed from the list of areas\nwith recent local transmission on Monday.\nBoth WHO and health authorities in Hong Kong are taking a cautious approach\nto what would be a very significant achievement in the history of SARS\ncontrol. WHO was given details today about a suspect SARS case who has been\nin isolation since 9 June. The results of 3 PCR tests have been negative.\nSerology tests, conducted 20 days after the onset of symptoms, have also\nbeen negative.\nToday's report on this case confers another layer of assurance that\nsurveillance remains intense and that new cases continue to be quickly\ndetected and isolated. As Hong Kong scientists and laboratories rank among\nthe best in the world, WHO has full confidence that the case in question is\nnot SARS.\nRemoval from the list means that the chain of person to person transmission\nhas been broken, thus eliminating the risk of infection for both local\nresidents and travellers. On 2 April, WHO advised the public to consider\npostponing all but essential travel to Hong Kong. That recommendation was\nremoved more than 7 weeks later, on 23 May. Travel recommendations are\npresently in place only for Beijing, China.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[While the BMJ paper is only one study, the finding of a sensitivity of 26\nper cent would suggest that a more sensitive case definition should be used\nfor screening purposes (for example, to determine which patients should be\nplaced in respiratory isolation and which should receive further testing).\nAs the WHO commentary points out, any such broadening of the case\ndefinition will necessarily reduce the specificity of the definition until\nbetter rapid testing methodologies become available. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate:20 Jun 2003\n An article published in this week's British Medical Journal (BMJ) has\nquestioned whether the WHO case definitions for suspected and probable SARS\nare adequate to pick up infected cases at the earliest stage when patients\nare said to be most infectious <http://bmj.com/cgi/content/full/326/7403/1354>.\n [While the BMJ paper is only one study, the finding of a sensitivity of 26\nper cent would suggest that a more sensitive case definition should be used\nfor screening purposes (for example, to determine which patients should be\nplaced in respiratory isolation and which should receive further testing). ProMED-mail will continue to cover new events as they occur with\nrespect to SARS. - Mod.MPP]\n[ProMED-mail thanks to Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for continued\nmonitoring of WHO reports - Mod.MPP]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_07_01/en/>\nWHO Update 92 \u0096 Chronology of travel recommendations, areas with local\ntransmission 1 Jul 2003\n-------------------------\nIf no unexpected events occur, the last two areas in the world \u0096 Toronto\nand Taiwan \u0096 to have experienced local transmission of SARS will be\ndeclared later this week to have broken the chain of person-to-person\ntransmission. This achievement will mean that the SARS coronavirus is no\nlonger thought to be circulating in the human population.\nFrom the outset, WHO\u0092s objective in combating SARS has been to seal off\nopportunities for the disease to become established in its new human host.\nInterruption of human transmission will be a milestone on the way to\nachieving this goal.\nHowever, scientists cannot at present guarantee that SARS has been\nvanquished, as questions remain about the origins of the virus and its\npossible seasonal occurrence. In addition, transmission may be occurring\nsomewhere in the world at such a low level as to defy detection.\nIn line with the WHO objective, recommendations to postpone travel to\ndesignated areas were periodically issued. Evidence that SARS was being\nexported from areas with local transmission was of particular concern, as\nthis contributed to further international spread and created a heavy burden\nin terms of isolation and infection control, contact tracing, and quarantine.\nThe list of areas with recent local transmission was initially developed to\nsupport the case definitions of suspect and probable cases, as both\ndefinitions depend on a history of close contact with a SARS patient.\nApplication of the case definitions required knowledge of areas where the\nvirus was spreading. Inclusion on the list also provided the basis for\nrecommended exist screening of all departing passengers as a measure for\npreventing further international spread.\nThe chronology below provides a record of travel recommendations issued by\nWHO and of changes in the status of local transmission.\nBackground\n12 Mar 2003: WHO issues first global alert to cases of atypical pneumonia\nrapidly spreading among hospital staff.\n15 Mar 2003: WHO issues first emergency travel advisory, calling on all\ntravellers to be aware of the main symptoms and signs of SARS. The disease\nappears to be spreading along the routes of international air travel.\n24 Mar 2003: Hong Kong officials report 9 cases of atypical pneumonia among\nmembers of a tour group that travelled together on 2 flights, raising the\npossibility of in-flight transmission. Subsequent investigations revealed\nthat one infected passenger, on a 15 Mar 2003 flight from Hong Kong to\nBeijing, may have infected 22 fellow passengers and 2 flight attendants.\n25 Mar 2003: WHO reminds travellers to remain alert, but sees no need for\ntravel restrictions to any destinations. Most new cases are being quickly\nidentified and immediately isolated, thus reducing opportunities for\ntransmission outside confined areas, such as the health care setting.\n27 Mar 2003: WHO recommends exit screening of air passengers departing from\nareas where transmission is known to be occurring in local chains. No cases\nof suspected in-flight transmission are reported following this date.\n31 Mar 2003: A large cluster of almost simultaneous cases, linked to the\nAmoy Gardens housing estate in Hong Kong, raises the possibility of an\nenvironmental source of infection and provides strong evidence that SARS\nhas moved out of the hospital setting and into the community at large. In\naddition, several areas link their first imported cases to a history of\ntravel in Guangdong or Hong Kong. These events set the stage for the first\ntravel recommendations.\nTravel recommendations (postpone all but essential travel)\n2 Apr 2003: Issued for Hong Kong and Guangdong Province, China.\n23 Apr case SARS case was also\n12 Jun 2003.\nThe date of onset of the most recent probable SARS case in China was 3 Jun\n2003, the last date of isolation of a probable case SARS case was also 3\nJun 2003.\n[B] Update 89 \u0096 What happens if SARS returns? 26 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_26/en/>\n\nEarlier this week, WHO removed Hong Kong and Beijing \u0096 the world\u0092s 2 most\nseverely affected cities \u0096 from its list of areas with recent local\ntransmission of SARS. Only Toronto and Taiwan continue to experience chains\nof local transmission, and these outbreaks are likewise being brought close\nto containment.\nAfter almost 4 months, the global public health emergency caused by the\nsudden appearance and rapid spread of SARS is coming to an end.\nThe SARS virus, a new and unique member of the coronavirus family, first\nemerged in mid-November [2002] in southern China. One of the key questions\nnow is whether SARS \u0096 pushed out of its new human host as chains of\ntransmission are broken \u0096 will return.\nThe question arises because of the behaviour of other comparatively new and\npoorly understood viruses, including those that cause the Ebola and Marburg\nhaemorrhagic fevers. These viruses periodically surface to cause outbreaks,\nusually limited to a defined geographical area, and then fade away to hide\nin some animal or environmental reservoir until conditions again become\nripe for spread to humans.\nThe question of whether SARS will likewise resurface must remain open\npending better understanding of the circumstances that allowed the new\ndisease to emerge. The SARS virus is thought to have jumped to humans from\nsome animal or environmental source.\nMany new viruses that jump from animals to humans, including the Nipah,\nHendra, and hanta viruses, do not spread efficiently from one person to\nanother and thus do not cause large and sustained outbreaks with a\npotential for rapid international spread. The SARS virus, however, spreads\nreadily from person to person. Factors in the hospital environment have\nworked to amplify this efficient transmission considerably. In addition,\nthough SARS has a high case fatality (around 15 percent), it allows enough\nof its victims to survive long enough to spread the disease to others \u0096 an\neffective survival strategy for a new virus.\nThe WHO scientific coordinator for SARS, Dr Klaus Stohr, is presently in\nChina working together with scientists there to develop and prioritize a\nSARS research agenda. Research on the origins of the SARS virus is expected\nto top the agenda.\nIn the meantime, WHO has good reason to believe that, should SARS resurface\nlater this year, the global impact will be milder than experienced during\nthe initial global emergency. 5 reasons support this view.\nFirst, the world\u0092s public health systems have demonstrated their capacity\nto move quickly into a phase of high alert. The prompt detection and\nisolation of imported cases in African and India are good examples of both\nthe level of vigilance and its effectiveness in preventing further spread.\nSome of the former SARS hotspots, including Hong Kong and Singapore, plan\nto maintain a high level of vigilance, supported by measures for screening\nand detection, until at least the end of the year.\nSecond, the world knows what to do. Control measures, though centuries old,\nhave demonstrated their capacity to completely halt outbreaks, as most\nrecently seen in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Beijing.\nThird, the intensive research effort currently under way can be expected to\nimprove scientific understanding of SARS and yield better control tools,\nmost notably a rapid and reliable point-of-care diagnostic test.\nFourth, resolutions adopted during the May World Health Assembly have\nstrengthened WHO\u0092s capacity to respond to outbreaks in important ways. In\neffect, these resolutions allow WHO to move from a passive reliance on\nofficial government notifications to a proactive role in warning the world\nas soon as evidence indicates that an outbreak poses a threat to\ninternational public health.\nFinally and perhaps most importantly, SARS has underscored the importance\nof immediately and fully disclosing cases of any disease with the potential\nfor international spread. In the present climate of opinion, influenced by\nthe lessons learned from SARS, it appears unlikely that any country would\nchoose to conceal cases, should SARS resurface. In addition, SARS is simply\ntoo big a disease to hide for long.\nFor these reasons, WHO is optimistic that, should SARS return, it will not\ndo so with a vengeance.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 26 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/cn-cc/numbers.html>\nThe cumulative number of probable and suspected cases reported by Health\nCanada has not changed from yesterday's posting. In the past 24 hours\nthere have been no new probable or suspected cases reported.\nThe most recent date of onset of illness for a probable case is June 12,\n2003, and this person was quarantined on June 4, 2003. The most recent date\nof isolation for a probable case is June 12, 2003, and this person had\nonset of illness on 8 Jun 2003.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 26 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC - Taiwan\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\nNo new probable cases have been reported since 15 Jun 2003. The\nconclusions that the public health infrastructure worldwide responded\nappropriately with rapid intervention, and therefore there is reason for\noptimism should this virus reappear are reasonable. It is noteworthy that\nthe person-to-person transmission was significantly enhanced in the health\ncare setting, and that widespread community transmission did not appear as\na major component of this outbreak. The majority of cases were in urban\nareas with a strong association with the health care environment. Major\noutbreaks in rural areas were not observed. worldwide (153): diagnostic testing", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204007", "date": "2003-06-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (153): DIAGNOSTIC TESTING\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 18 Jun 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\nSource: Candad.com [edited]\n<http://www.canada.com/ottawa/story.asp?id=E60188B4-623A-4098-B38C-CDBB44DFE6C3>\n\nNational lab finds an extra 120 people may have had SARS\n--------------------------------------------------------\nTORONTO (CP) - As many as 120 people not on the list of Canada's probable\nor suspect SARS cases may actually have had the disease, testing done by\nHealth Canada's National Microbiology Laboratory has shown.\nExperts say it's crucial to find those individuals and figure out whether\nthey actually had SARS and whether they have spread it to others. 'It's a\nworry. It's an important thing to try to figure out why, (and) what this\nmeans,' said scientific director Dr Frank Plummer.\nThe Winnipeg lab, in conjunction with Ontario officials and public health\nauthorities in the locations where the individuals live, is beginning a\nstudy to track down the people, their doctors, and their contacts to ensure\nthat other SARS cases aren't simmering, undetected, in Toronto and other\nsouthern Ontario communities.\n'Look what happened at North York,' said leading SARS expert Dr Donald Low,\nreferring to North York General Hospital, the epicentre of Toronto's second\nSARS outbreak. 'There was a cluster in a family that wasn't recognized.\nMaybe there's a cluster in Belleville that we just haven't recognized.'\nEven if further study shows that no new clusters are simmering, the\nfindings suggest Ontario must have dodged a few SARS bullets, the experts\nadmit.\nCanada has officially recorded 245 probable and 193 suspect cases of SARS\nsince the disease hit these shores in late February, the vast majority in\nthe Toronto area. One of the puzzling positive test results that Plummer's\nlab has turned up was for a woman from Belleville, which is why Low\nreferred to that city, about 2 hours drive east of Toronto. Another was for\na man from the Grey Bruce area, north of Toronto, who had been listed as a\nsuspect SARS case in March. The man, who had been believed to have\ncontracted SARS in Singapore, was eventually struck from the list when it\nwas found he had influenza B, which could have caused his symptoms. But\nPlummer's lab recently informed his local medical officer of health that\nthe man probably had SARS as well.\nThat case and another like it at North York General suggest it may be time\nto again rewrite the definitions of probable and suspect SARS, Low said. A\npsychiatric patient at North York who appeared to have SARS in April but\nwho was not known to have been in contact with a SARS case was eventually\nruled out when lab tests showed he had mycoplasma, a pathogen that causes\npneumonia. Weeks later blood tests revealed the man also had SARS.\nThe current definitions allow authorities to rule out a case if another\nreasonable diagnosis is discovered. The North York and Grey Bruce cases\nsuggest that that's no longer an option, Low said, noting that 10 to 15 per\ncent of community acquired pneumonias are caused by more than one agent.\n'It's naive to think to think that people only have infection with one\norganism. It's naive to think that because somebody has influenza B that\nthey couldn't have SARS,' he said. Since the SARS outbreak began, the\nWinnipeg lab has been working overtime, processing samples submitted from\nabout 2100 people so far.\nPlummer doesn't have enough information on each individual case to\ndetermine whether these 120 people are false positives, people who were\ninfected but whose symptoms were so mild they didn't meet case definitions\nor actual SARS cases who somehow slipped through public health's nets. He\ndoesn't even know if they all would have been quarantined, though some,\nlike the Grey Bruce man, definitely were. Dr Andrew Simor, chief\nmicrobiologist at Toronto's Sunnybrook and Women's College Health Sciences\nCentre, said testing done by their lab corroborates the Winnipeg lab's\nfindings. 'Of course of most importance is are these people who are\npotentially infectious? And to this point in time, I'm not aware that any\nof these people ... have actually been responsible for transmission of\ndisease. And ultimately that's what's most important.'\nBut public health officials cannot afford to assume that just because they\nhaven't identified that kind of below-the-radar transmission doesn't mean\nit hasn't happened.\n[byline: Helen Branswell]\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nInstructor in Surgery (Bioengineering)\nHarvard Medical School\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[Many details are unavailable from this newswire report: the methodology of\ntesting (presumably serology, IgM, IgG?, threshold for positivity), the\ndenominator (that is, the total number of tests done of which 120 were\npositive), the population from which they were drawn (community-acquired\natypical pneumonia cases?), any contact or clinical data, and so forth.\nWhile the law of parsimony is often cited in clinical medicine, it is true\nthat it is very possible to have multiple simultaneous infections -- indeed\nsome respiratory infections predispose to others. It is also likely that a\nproportion of these are false positive tests and that some represent true\ninfection. Update 86 - Hong Kong removed from list of areas with local\ntransmission 23 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_23/en/>\nWHO has today removed Hong Kong from its list of areas with recent\nlocal transmission of SARS. 20 days, which is twice the maximum\nincubation period, have passed since the last case was isolated on 2\nJun 2003.\nWhen 20 days have passed since removal of the last case from the\ncommunity at large, the chain of human-to-human transmission is\nconsidered broken, thus eliminating the risk of infection for both\nlocal residents and travellers.\n'This is a very significant achievement,' said Dr David Heymann,\nExecutive Director of Communicable Diseases at WHO. 'Hong Kong, with\nits dense population and fluid border with China, had one of the\nhardest outbreaks to control. This success means that the whole world\ncan now feel safer from the SARS threat.'\nSARS was first carried out of southern China into Hong Kong, and then\non to Hanoi, Toronto, and Singapore in late February. Some 16\nvisitors and guests to the ninth floor of a Hong Kong hotel became\ninfected through contact, in ways that remain mysterious, with a\nsymptomatic medical doctor from Guangdong Province, who stayed in the\nhotel's room 911. The index case for Hong Kong's first outbreak, in\nthe Prince of Wales Hospital, visited an acquaintance staying on the\nsame floor during the critical days in February. Additional clusters\nwere also subsequently linked to the hotel.\nSARS had not yet been identified as a dangerous new disease when the\noutbreak hit Hong Kong's hospitals. Doctors and nurses, unaware of\nthe need to isolate patients and protect themselves, became the first\nvictims as they struggled to save lives. In a particularly\nunfortunate incident, the index patient at Prince of Wales, admitted\non 4 Mar 2003, was treated 4 times daily with a jet nebulizer, which\nprobably aerosolized the virus and greatly increased opportunities\nfor spread.\nIn late March [2003], Hong Kong suffered a major setback when a\nlarge cluster, eventually numbering more than 300, of almost\nsimultaneous new cases was traced to a single building in the Amoy\nGardens housing state. That event, which raised the possibility of an\nenvironmental source of infection or even airborne spread of the\nvirus, was investigated by teams of local specialists. The outbreak\nwas attributed to an 'unlucky' convergence of environmental\nconditions that allowed the contamination of vertically-linked\napartments. This conclusion, subsequently confirmed by additional\nstudies, calmed fears that the SARS virus might be airborne.\nFrom the day when the first cluster of cases was recognized, Hong\nKong officials have provided open, honest, and abundant information\nabout SARS to both the public and the media. Hong Kong also benefited\nfrom the contribution of its outstanding scientists, epidemiologists,\nand clinicians, who were at the forefront of efforts to track down\nsource cases in the various clusters, identify the causative agent,\ndevelop diagnostic tests, and work out treatment protocols.\nFaced with the largest outbreak outside mainland China, Hong Kong\nalso pioneered many of the control measures used to successfully\ncontain smaller outbreaks elsewhere. It is gratifying that these\nmeasures have now brought Hong Kong to the point of victory over the\nvirus, although continued vigilance remains vital.\nOn 2 Apr 2003, WHO advised the public to consider postponing all but\nessential travel to Hong Kong. That recommendation was removed more\nthan 7 weeks later, on 23 May 2003.\nC. Update 87 - World Health Organization changes last remaining\ntravel recommendation -- for Beijing, China 24 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_24/en/>\nEffective today, the World Health Organization (WHO) is removing its\nrecommendation that people should postpone all but essential travel\nto Beijing, China. Beijing was the last area in the world to which\nthis advice still applied.\nThe recommendation to consider postponing all but essential travel to\nBeijing was issued on 23 Apr 2003 in order to minimize the\ninternational spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). WHO\nis changing this recommendation as the situation in the Chinese\ncapital has now improved significantly. The last new case in Beijing\nwas isolated on 29 May 2003, since when a number of suspect cases\nhave been considered but ruled out as SARS. No cases have recently\nbeen exported from Beijing and all recent cases have been traced to\nknown chains of transmission.\n'We are changing the travel advice for Beijing effective Tuesday, 24\nJun 2003,' said Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, Director-General of the\nWHO. 'Beijing is the last area to which WHO recommended that people\nshould postpone all but essential travel. This is very good news and\nshows the great progress the world has made against SARS.'\nBeijing, with a cumulative total of 2521 probable cases and 191\ndeaths, has had the largest outbreak of SARS anywhere in the world,\nfollowed by Hong Kong, with 1755 cumulative cases and 296 deaths, and\nGuangdong Province, China, with 1511 cumulative cases and 57 deaths.\nFor reasons that are not yet fully understood, areas of mainland\nChina have experienced a lower case fatality ratio than seen in most\nother outbreaks.\nChina began daily reporting of SARS cases in early April [2003], when\nBeijing reported 29 cases and 4 deaths. At the peak of the outbreak,\ntowards the end of April, Beijing was reporting more than 100 new\ncases each day. Containment of an outbreak of such dimensions is a\ntribute to the effectiveness of centuries-old control measures,\nincluding isolation, contact tracing, and quarantine, supported by\ngovernment commitment at the highest levels.\nRecommendations to postpone travel have been issued following\nconsideration of several factors, including the magnitude of probable\nSARS cases, the pattern of recent local transmission, and the last\ndates of export of cases.\nOn 27 Mar 2003, WHO recommended that all areas with recent local\ntransmission should screen all international departing passengers to\nensure that those who are showing symptoms of SARS or have had recent\ncontact with a SARS patient do not travel. Since then, a number of\nrecommendations have been made that people should postpone all but\nessential travel to areas with large outbreaks of SARS which posed a\npotential threat to travellers.\nMore than 20 days have now passed since the last new case was\nisolated in Beijing. Therefore, Beijing has also been removed from\nthe list of areas with recent local transmission.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 24 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail (152): CASES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] USA - MMWR\n******\n[1]\nDate: 19 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO) SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cases\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/country/2003_06_19/en/>\nA total of 2 new cases and 3 additional deaths were reported worldwide on\nthe WHO website today, making a total of 8462 cases and 804 deaths. The\nfull table is available at the link above.\n[B] Update 84 - Can SARS be eradicated or eliminated?\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_19/en/>\nThe first global conference on SARS, held on Tuesday and Wednesday in Kuala\nLumpur, Malaysia, was convened by WHO to provide technical guidance for the\nongoing and long term response to SARS.\nAs the number of new cases continues to dwindle, one of the most important\nquestions for the future is whether SARS can be eliminated or eradicated\nfrom its new human host. Experience with many other infectious diseases,\nincluding smallpox and poliomyelitis, has shown that complete eradication\nof an infectious disease is possible only when 3 precise requirements can\nbe met.\nFirstly, an effective intervention capable of interrupting transmission --\nideally, a vaccine -- must be available. Secondly, easy-to-use diagnostic\ntools are needed, with sufficient sensitivity and specificity to detect\nlevels of infection that can lead to transmission of the disease. Finally,\ninfection of humans must be essential to the life-cycle of the causative\nagent -- if the chain of human-to-human transmission is broken, the agent\ncannot survive. Existence of an animal reservoir greatly complicates\neradication, but does not preclude it, provided interventions exist to\nbreak the chain of transmission in the animal species as well.\nTo achieve eradication at the global level, the control intervention must\nbe safe, simple, and affordable. Current control measures for SARS,\nincluding case detection and isolation, tracing and follow up of contacts,\nand quarantine, are effective but extremely time-intensive, costly, and\nsocially disruptive. Few if any countries can sustain such efforts over time.\nAs noted during yesterday's conference sessions, an adequate point-of-care\ndiagnostic test is still not available for SARS and remains a top priority.\nSuch a test would likewise need to be sufficiently simple and affordable to\nbe used in countries having a range of different health systems and\nresources for health care.\nResearchers at the conference also confirmed that far too little is\nunderstood about the origins of the SARS virus and the possible role -- if\nany -- that animals play in the transmission cycle. Some studies have\nsuggested that the earliest cases of SARS, in Guangdong Province, China,\nmay have had contact, during slaughter or due to proximity to so-called\n'wet' markets, with certain wild animal species consumed as delicacies in\nsouthern China. In addition, a SARS-like virus has been detected in a few\nof these wild animal species. Additional studies are urgently needed before\nany firm conclusions can be reached. Answers to these questions will also\ngreatly assist predictions of the future evolution of SARS.\nFor the time being, WHO continues to stress the need to break the chain of\nhuman-to-human transmission through use of currently available control\ntools. In many of the most severely affected areas, these measures have\nalready demonstrated their ability to eliminate SARS in a defined\ngeographical area.\nHowever, the long term response to SARS, which includes the prevention of\nimportation or re-importation of cases into SARS-free areas, will clearly\nrequire different strategies for surveillance and response, as current\nmeasures cannot be sustained over time.\nMoreover, scientists cannot, on the basis of the very limited data\navailable, rule out the possibility that SARS will resurface when\nenvironmental conditions or seasons again favour transmission among humans.\nShould this occur, countries will need to be ready with alert surveillance\nsystems and good preparedness strategies.\n******\n[2]\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC. Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2003; 52(24):570, 20 Jun [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5224a4.htm>\n\nUpdate: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome -- United States, June 18, 2003\n-----------------------------------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) continue to work with\nstate and local health departments, the World Health Organization (WHO),\nand other partners to investigate cases of severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS). This report updates reported SARS cases worldwide and in\nthe United States and summarizes changes in travel recommendations for\nprovinces in China with the exclusion of Beijing, where a travel advisory\n[notice] remains.\nFrom 1 November 2002 to 18 June 2003, a total of 8465 probable SARS cases\nwere reported to WHO from 29 countries, including 75 from the US; 801\ndeaths (case fatality rate 9.5 per cent) have been reported, with no\nSARS-related deaths reported from the US (1). In the US, a total of 409\nSARS cases have been reported from 42 states and Puerto Rico, with 334 (82\nper cent) cases classified as suspect SARS and 75 (18 per cent) classified\nas probable SARS (more severe illnesses characterized by the presence of\npneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome) (2). Serologic testing\nfor antibody to SARS-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV) infection has been\ncompleted for 136 suspect and 45 probable cases. None of the suspect cases\nand 8 (18 per cent) of the probable cases have demonstrated antibodies to\nSARS-CoV, all of which have been described previously (3,4). Of the 8\nlaboratory-confirmed SARS patients in the US, 7 had traveled to areas with\ndocumented or suspected community transmission of SARS within the 10 days\nbefore illness onset. Of these, 4 reported travel to Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region, China; 2 to Toronto, Canada; and one to both\nSingapore and Taiwan. The remaining laboratory-confirmed SARS patient is\nthe spouse of a laboratory-confirmed SARS patient who had traveled to Hong\nKong.\nOn 17 June, CDC downgraded its travel advisory [notice] for Mainland China\nto alert status for all provinces except Beijing, where the travel advisory\nremains in effect (5). These changes reflect data reported to WHO by the\nChinese Ministry of Health which indicate that SARS transmission in\nMainland China (other than in Beijing) is limited to a small number of\nspecific settings through direct person to person spread; no evidence\nexists of ongoing community transmission, and monitoring by the Ministry of\nHealth indicates that no new outbreaks of illness in these provinces.\nReported by: State and local health departments. SARS Investigative Team, CDC.\nReferences\n1. WHO. Cumulative number of reported cases of severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS). 2003.\n[B] Update 88 \u0096 New cases reported in China and Japan 25 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_25/en/>\nWHO has today received reports of new probable cases of SARS in China and\nJapan.\nChina\nThe Chinese Ministry of Health has today reported a new probable case of\nSARS involving a 77-year-old woman who fell ill in Guangdong Province. The\ncase had previously been classified as a suspect case and, according to WHO\nrecommendations, was placed in isolation on 3 Jun 2003.\nThis is the first new case reported in Guangdong since 17 May 2003. The\nlast new case reported anywhere in mainland China was on 11 Jun 2003.\nWHO is stressing that this is a reclassification of a suspect case as a\nprobable case and, as such, should not be taken as an indication that local\ntransmission has occurred. WHO is awaiting further details about the case\nand its relationship to documented chains of transmission that may point to\nthe source of infection and the timing of exposure.\nThe most likely explanation is that the case, with its onset in early June\n2003, will be linked to a chain of transmission that was subsequently broken.\nMeticulous records kept by Hong Kong authorities have revealed that the\nwoman was hospitalized in Hong Kong and treated for other illnesses from 20\nto 21 May 2003. As her room was on the same ward as a SARS patient, she was\nplaced under health surveillance until 1 Jun 2003. No SARS symptoms\ndeveloped during this period, which represents the maximum incubation period.\nHowever, a possible link with the Hong Kong hospital cannot be entirely\nruled out at this time. As became apparent during last week\u0092s global\nconference on SARS, the disease does not always follow a clinically\npredictable course in elderly patients, particularly when they have been\ntreated for co-morbidity with other diseases.\nGuangdong, which saw the first cases of SARS in mid-November of last year\n[2002], was removed from the list of areas with recent local transmission\non 13 Jun 2003. This retrospective reporting of a case newly classified as\na \u0093probable\u0094 case does not constitute a reason for any change in the status\nof Guangdong.\nJapan\nThe Japanese Ministry of Health has today reported a probable case of SARS\ninvolving a 33-year-old man who arrived in Tokyo, for sightseeing, on 21\nJun 2003 and developed symptoms 2 days later. He was immediately\nhospitalized and managed according to WHO recommendations.\nInitial diagnostic tests have ruled out other common causes of severe\nrespiratory disease. Further testing is under way and epidemiological\ninvestigations have been initiated. As the patient is a resident of Taiwan,\nhealth officials there are contributing to the investigation.\nComment on new cases\nWhen an outbreak wanes while vigilance is still high, a few additional\ncases are almost always detected. Their prompt reporting provides further\nassurance that surveillance systems are alert. However, WHO anticipates\nthat many reported cases during this phase of the outbreak will turn out,\non further investigation, to be \u0093background noise\u0094 \u0096 that is, cases of\ncommunity-acquired pneumonia caused by agents other than the SARS virus.\nIn areas that have experienced large outbreaks and therefore accumulated\nconsiderable skill in the clinical and laboratory diagnosis of cases,\nreports of newly detected probable cases are less likely to be discarded\nupon further investigation.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Yet by 10 Feb 2003 news of a 'fatal flu in Guangdong' had\nreached 120 million people through text messaging, say some reports, and an\nuntold extra number through email and internet chatrooms. Chinese\nauthorities had little choice but to acknowledge the outbreak and try to\nrestore calm. The government had been taught a painful lesson about\ncontrolling the news in a burgeoning high-tech society.\nBy mid-February 2003, officials began complaining about the use of text\nmessaging to spread 'rumours', deeming them subversive activity and a\nthreat to stability. Then they began arresting people. By the end of May\n2003, 117 people in 17 provinces had been arrested and charged with\ndisturbing social order by spreading SARS-related rumours, the Xinhua news\nagency reported. But [it was not stated] how those rumours were spread.\nWith its control slipping, the government's response [to the situation] has\nbeen to combine cutting-edge technology with repression. Its technology\nallows it, for example, to search the country's entire volume of email\ntraffic for words such as 'Falungong', or to monitor any individual's text\nmessages. Anyone snared in its high-tech web can expect surveillance,\nintimidation, arrest, and prison. The publicity surrounding the arrests and\nprison sentences helps the government achieve what experts say is its\nstrategy of creating a climate of fear in which the people begin censoring\nthemselves.\n'The cyberpolice, which have tens of thousands of members, are capable of\narresting internet users anywhere in the country if they send a few\nmessages considered 'subversive' or likely to 'jeopardise the state's\nsecurity',' wrote the watchdog group Reporters Without Borders in a report\nreleased last month. One topic subject to nearly blanket censorship in\nearly April 2003 was SARS. A second message about SARS was submitted to\nthe site 5 days later. It met the same fate.\n'The authorities seem to have asked the websites to add the term SARS to\nthe long list of banned words.
