Jun. 14, 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?\npagename=thestar/Layout/Article_Type1&c=Article&cid=1052251834438&call_pageid=\n968332188854&col=968350060724>\n\nExperts expand criteria for diagnosing SARS\nFever not always present in older patients\n--------------------\nHONG KONG - About one in 4 elderly people suffering from SARS show no signs\nof fever during their illness, making diagnosis more difficult, researchers\nhere reported yesterday.\nAnd the incubation period for typical patients can range well beyond the\nstandard of 10 days to as much as 16 days, according to studies of Hong Kong\npatients, said Dr. Tim Rainer of the Prince of Wales Hospital here.\nHis and other researchers' findings were presented yesterday to a conference\norganized jointly by the World Health Organization and the Hong Kong\ngovernment to compare notes on diagnosis and treatment methods for severe\nacute respiratory syndrome.\nMedical experts at the conference noted that the WHO's original guidelines --\ncough, fever, shortness of breath and lung x-rays -- were not always helpful\nin predicting who had the disease. Other symptoms, such as loss of appetite,\nchills and fever could be more accurate, said Rainer. He noted the\ndisparities in incubation periods and wide variations in body temperatures\namong patients. Among people over age 65, only 76 percent showed signs of\nfever above 38C, according to Dr. S.Y. Au of Tuen Mun Hospital. By\ncomparison, 90 per cent of patients below age 65 showed fever.\nThe absence of fever in some elderly patients could complicate efforts by\npublic health authorities to curb the spread of SARS by installing thermal\ndetection devices at airports and border points in Hong Kong and around the\nworld. If body temperature is subject to individual variations, potential\nSARS carriers could slip through the net.\nAu suggested that the absence of high temperature readings could be due to\ncertain medications being taken by elderly patients that mask fevers, and\nsaid doctors should search carefully for atypical symptoms and whether the\nperson had recently been hospitalized. Indeed, one of the best ways for\nelderly people to avoid a SARS infection is to 'avoid hospitalization,' he\nsuggested, drawing a few chuckles from his fellow physicians.\nThe meeting of more than 100 researchers and doctors was a sombre affair,\nhowever, with the group observing a one-minute silence for their colleagues\nand patients who died from the virus. Only a handful of the delegates wore\nsurgical masks, however, with most people removing them when they entered the\nconference centre.\nResearchers quickly agreed yesterday that the original WHO guidelines for\ndiagnosing SARS were outdated and said they'd had to incorporate the latest\nfindings early on in Hong Kong's outbreak last March [2003]. Symptoms shown\nby patients can also vary widely. Indeed, methods of diagnosis may even have\nto change depending on whether physicians are dealing with widespread\noutbreaks or seeing only a trickle of cases, said Dr. Mike Ryan, the WHO's co-\nordinator for global alerts and response. 'In 6 months, the same set of\nclinical symptoms may not be useful,' Ryan observed, after hearing Hong Kong\ndoctors describe the need for updated diagnostic guidelines in times of\ncrisis.\nAnother researcher, Professor Joseph Sung from the University of Hong Kong,\nadded that about 50 percent of the cases seen in Hong Kong were not typical.\nThese patients often had diarrhea and liver problems.\nThe 2-day meeting is laying the groundwork for a consensus document to be\npresented next week at a larger WHO conference in Malaysia with\nrepresentatives from around the world. However, the document is not scheduled\nto be publicly released until Tuesday.\nHong Kong has accumulated significant experience because it has suffered the\n2nd-largest number of cases after mainland China. To date, 1755 people have\nbeen diagnosed with SARS in Hong Kong, of whom 293 have died.\n[Byline: Martin Regg Cohn]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Several factors are at work here. First, as experience with a new entity\naccumulates, the full spectrum of disease becomes clearer. At first, only\nclassic or 'textbook' presentations are recognized and then the less\nclassical presentations, often more common, become apparent. Second, as\nlaboratory diagnostic techniques improve, more subtle or subclinical forms of\nthe illness are noted. Finally, variations in the manifestations of\ninfections among different age groups are the norm for infectious diseases.\nOften, the very young and the elderly fail to mount a fever in response to\ninfection. - Mod.LM]\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Fri, 6 Jun 2003 16:37:47 +0200\nFrom: Michael Koch <michael.koch@k3.mil.se>\n\nThe following paper is available to ProMED readers on request to *the author*\n[do NOT hit your REPLY button!]:\nSARS \u0096 epidemiological considerations about\n(a) the statistical 'background noise' of atypical pneumonias,\n(b) the implications of a symptomatic disease definition in the presence of\nhighly functional global networks for speedy communication and\n(c) the possible role of co-infections for the natural course of the disease\nand its highly variable CFR.\nAuthor: MG Koch, MD\nEpidemiologist\nK3, SE-546\n81 Karlsborg, Sweden\n(A longer version of 5-6 pages in English and/or a more comprehensive article\non SARS in German are available by request to my e-mail address:\n<michael.koch@k3.mil.se>)\n[This is an interesting analysis. The man fell ill\nafter hip surgery but his symptoms went undetected for weeks.\nDr Barbara Yaffe, associate medical officer of health for Toronto, said the\nelderly man caught SARS from a nurse on his floor at North York General\nHospital. The nurse had contracted SARS from her mother, who had been at\nsuburban Scarborough Grace Hospital where the city's first outbreak surfaced\nin March after the virus was brought in from Hong Kong.\nFinding a link between the 2 affected hospitals was a crucial part of the\ncity's battle against the virus, which has killed 33 people in and around\nToronto in 3 months. News of the link came just hours after the WHO decided\nagainst issuing a 2nd travel advisory for the city.\n*****\n[B]\nDate: 15 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Toronto Star 14 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?\npagename=thestar/Layout/Article_Type1&c=Article&cid=1052251834735&call_pageid=\n968332188492&col=968793972154>\n\nHow SARS experts untangled the threads of the second outbreak\nHealth Canada, CDC link cases\nNorth York nurse thought to be key\nSARS II likely came from SARS I.\n--------------------------\nResearchers trying to figure out the origin of the SARS II outbreak at North\nYork General Hospital in April 2003 believe the missing link is a patient at\nScarborough Grace Hospital, where Toronto's first outbreak began in March\n2003.\nThe patient got SARS at Grace Hospital, passed it to her daughter, who is a\nnurse at North York General. The theory is that the nurse somehow infected a\n96-year-old patient at North York Hospital, and the disease spread rapidly\nfrom there. Investigators are still not sure how the virus would have passed\nto the elderly man since he was not one of her patients.\nThe link was made by a team of researchers that included the Centers for\nDisease Control in Atlanta and Health Canada. 'As pieces come together, this\nlooks very likely,' said Dr. Barbara Yaffe, an associate medical officer of\nhealth at Toronto Public Health.\nThe link between SARS I and SARS II is heartening news for Toronto, which has\nbeen criticized by the World Health Organization for not being able to trace\nsome of the cases. Knowing how everybody with the disease contracted it is\nvital to managing, and eventually stopping, an outbreak.\nThis is what happened to cause the North York outbreak, according to\ninterviews with investigating doctors, medical research papers, and nurses\nand doctors at North York General.\nToronto's first SARS outbreak began on 7 Mar 2003. The son of a woman who had\ncontracted the disease in Hong Kong went to Scarborough Grace Hospital with a\nrespiratory illness.\nThe son's pneumonia-like infection, and those of others in his family, were\ninitially dismissed as tuberculosis by Grace doctors and Toronto Public\nHealth officials. By 14 Mar 2003, they knew it was SARS.\nSARS spread through Grace Hospital over the next few weeks. Among the\nhospital wards affected was the coronary care unit. A female patient there\n(age unknown) got sick, possibly getting SARS from a fellow heart patient, a\nman. That male patient, a so-called super spreader, was then transferred to\nYork Central Hospital on 16 March 2003, causing an outbreak there.\nMeanwhile, the female patient was ill at Grace Hospital. Chest X-rays showed\na SARS-like infection, but she was not diagnosed at the time. She was\ndischarged from hospital on 17 Mar 2003. The woman lived with her daughter, a\nsenior nurse who worked on the eighth floor of North York General Hospital.\nThat floor is now known as the SARS ward, but in March it cared for patients\nrecovering from other problems, such as injuries.\nBlood tests returned to Toronto Public Health last week confirm the elderly\nwoman had the SARS coronavirus. She was suffering from a mild case of the\nvirus when she passed it on to her daughter in late March. On 30 March 2003,\nthe nurse developed a fever and felt lethargic. She went home early from\nwork. She did not know she had SARS.\nAlso on the 8th floor at the time was a 96-year-old man who had fractured his\npelvis. The man went to North York General Hospital emergency unit and was\ntransferred to the nurse's floor.\nResearchers believe the 96-year-old man somehow contracted SARS from the\nnurse, but they say there is 'no obvious link' because she was not caring for\nhim. The nurse also infected 3 fellow nurses, likely in a lunchroom. On 6 Apr\n2003 the nurse was admitted to hospital and her SARS case was reported to\nToronto Public Health.\nThe 96-year-old man first developed his SARS symptoms on 4 Apr 2003, not 19\nApril as researchers initially thought. His first bout in early April was\ncalmed by antibiotics. On 19 Apr 2003 the disease resurfaced. The 4 nurses\nbecame the first patients of a new SARS ward on the 8th floor of North York\nGeneral Hospital. But nobody [caught on] to the fact that the 96-year-old man\nwas developing SARS. To make room for the new SARS unit, the 96-year-old man\nwas transferred down to the 4th-floor orthopedic ward on 2 Apr 2003. He\ninfected almost a dozen nurses on that floor.\nAt the same time, 3 patients (2 women and a man) on the 7th-floor psychiatric\nward contracted the disease in mid-April. Health officials don't know how the\npsychiatric patients got SARS. One theory is the male psychiatric patient may\nhave visited another hospital that had SARS. [It must be hard to get a\nreliable history from a psychiatric patient. - Mod.JW]\nAs April progressed, SARS spread rapidly through North York General Hospital,\nhelped by increasingly lax mask and gown precautions among some doctors and\nnurses. By early May 2003, when the province told hospitals to relax their\nprecautions, many more health-care workers were contracting the disease.\nDespite nurses raising the alarm at the hospital and despite the fact that\n4 members of the 96-year-old man's family were visibly sick with SARS,\nthe disease went unchecked until 23 May 2003.\nIn the tale of 2 hospitals -- York Central and North York -- York Central\nHospital was the one that responded quickly to the transmission from Grace\nHospital, the epicentre of Toronto's original outbreak. The doors at York\nCentral Hospital were closed and tight precautions taken when the hospital\nrealized that it had imported SARS from North York General Hospital.\nThe York Central Hospital outbreak was contained. Out of 16 SARS cases, 2\ndied, including the SARS patient transferred from Scarborough Grace Hospital.\nYork Central started reopening on 19 Apr 2003, when the disease was spreading\nunchecked through North York General Hospital. Hospital president Dr. Richard\nSchabas credited a strict infection control procedure and teamwork as tools\nthat defeated SARS at his hospital.\nSo, how was SARS allowed to fester at North York General Hospital? The cases\nwere dismissed as non-SARS despite what now appears to be overwhelming\nevidence to the contrary. North York General Hospital's chief infectious\ndisease specialist Dr. Barbara Mederski has refused interview requests from\nthe Star. She was involved in the assessment of the SARS patients.\nWhile North York General Hospital has declined to comment, the hospital has\nsent a statement to its doctors and nurses, which reads: 'This is a sensitive\nissue for patients and their family, as well as our staff and physicians. At\nthis time we need to continue to support each other. The hospital will\ncontinue to fully cooperate with the investigation. It is in the interest of\nall us to advance the knowledge and prevention of SARS.'\nA Scarborough Grace Hospital spokesperson said last night the hospital\nwelcomes the investigation.\nThroughout April and into May 2003, the 96-year-old man, his relatives, and\nthe psychiatric patients were assessed by a team of doctors, including public\nhealth officials and Toronto microbiologists. But these patients were\ndismissed as SARS cases because there was no link to a previous SARS case.\nThe 96-year-old man died 1 May 2003. His wife died later in May. The rest\nrecovered.\nWhat is now clear is that the link was in the hospital, a nurse who had\nbeen doing her job and inadvertently contracted the virus from her sick\nmother. This fact was unearthed by CDC and Health Canada investigators who\ndid an audit of patient records and their contacts by computer this week. At\nToronto Public Health, the job has been more difficult. For most of the 2\noutbreaks, they have sifted through paperwork by hand. 'We've been fighting\na nineteenth century type of disease with nineteenth century technology,'\nsaid one official.\n[By: Kevin Donovan and Tanya Talaga]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[C]\nDate: 15 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: Newsday 14 Jun 2003 [Edited]\n<http://www.newsday.com/news/health/ny-lisars143332355jun14,0,5598067.story?\ncoll=ny-health-headlines>\nA 52-year-old Nassau woman has become the first person suspected of\ncontracting SARS within New York State, health officials said Friday. The\nhealth care worker is believed to have been exposed while overseeing a\npatient hospitalized with possible SARS.\nAll of the other individuals in the state with a suspect or probable SARS\ndiagnosis are believed to have acquired it during travel to endemic regions,\nsuch as China or Canada. The man went to North York General Hospital emergency unit and was\ntransferred to the nurse's floor.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars", "tuberculosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-05-23 00:00:00", "2003-04-02 00:00:00", "2003-03-30 00:00:00", "2003-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-05-01 00:00:00", "2003-04-25 00:00:00", "2003-04-19 00:00:00", "2003-04-04 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2003-06-14 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "North York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North York General", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "New York State", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Nassau County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Long Island", "country": "Bahamas"}, {"location": "Suffolk County & 7", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North York General \n Hospital", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203972", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (145): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203972", "date": "2003-06-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (145): CASES\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Canada - MMWR\n[2] USA - MMWR\n[3] UK - HPA mild infections?\n******\n[1]\nCanada\n-------\nDate: 13 June 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity & Mortality Weekly Report 13 Jun 2003 /\n52(23);547-550\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5223a4.htm>\n\nUpdate: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome --- Toronto, Canada,\n2003\n-----------------------------------------------\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) was first recognized in\nToronto in a woman who returned from Hong Kong on 23 Feb 2003\n(1). Transmission to other persons resulted subsequently in an\noutbreak among 257 persons in several Greater Toronto Area (GTA)\nhospitals. After implementation of provincewide public health\nmeasures that included strict infection-control practices, the number\nof recognized cases of SARS declined substantially, and no cases\nwere detected after 20 Apr 2003. On 30 Apr 2003, the World Health\nOrganization (WHO) lifted a travel advisory issued on 22 Apr 2003\nthat had recommended limiting travel to Toronto.\nThis report describes a second wave of SARS cases among\npatients, visitors, and health-care workers (HCWs) that occurred at\na Toronto hospital approximately 4 weeks after SARS transmission\nwas thought to have been interrupted. The findings indicate that\nexposure to hospitalized patients with unrecognized SARS after a\nprovincewide relaxation of strict SARS control measures probably\ncontributed to transmission among HCWs. The investigation\nunderscores the need for monitoring fever and respiratory\nsymptoms in hospitalized patients and visitors, particularly after a\ndecline in the number of reported SARS cases.\nDuring 23 Feb - 7 Jun 2003, the Ontario Ministry of Health and\nLong-Term Care received reports of 361 SARS cases (suspect: 136\n[38 percent]; probable: 225 [62 percent]) [see Figure 1 at weblink\nabove for epidemic curve - Mod.MPP]; as of 7 Jun 2003, a total of\n33 (9 percent) persons had died. Of 74 cases reported during 15\nApr - 9 Jun 2003 to Toronto Public Health, 29 (39 percent) occurred\namong HCWs, 28 (38 percent) occurred as a result of exposure\nduring hospitalization, and 17 (23 percent) occurred among hospital\nvisitors [see Figure 2 at weblink above]. Of the 74 cases, 67\n(90 percent) resulted directly from exposure in hospital A, a 350-bed\nGTA community hospital.\nThe majority of cases were associated with a ward used primarily\nfor orthopedic patients (14 rooms) and gynecology patients (7\nrooms). Nursing staff members used a common nursing station,\nshared a washroom, and ate together in a lounge just outside the\nward. SARS attack rates among nurses assigned routinely to the\northopedic and gynecology sections of the ward were approximately\n40 percent and 25 percent, respectively.\nDuring early and mid-May [2003], as recommended by provincial\nSARS-control directives, hospital A discontinued SARS expanded\nprecautions (i.e. routine contact precautions with use of an N95 or\nequivalent respirator) for non-SARS patients without respiratory\nsymptoms in all hospital areas other than the emergency department\nand the intensive care unit (ICU). In addition, staff no longer were\nrequired to wear masks or respirators routinely throughout the\nhospital or to maintain distance from one another while eating.\nHospital A instituted changes in policy on 8 May 2003; the number\nof persons allowed to visit a patient during a 4-hour period remained\nrestricted to one, but the number of patients who were allowed to\nhave visitors was increased.\nOn 20 May 2003, 5 patients in a rehabilitation hospital in Toronto\nwere reported with febrile illness. One of these 5 patients was\ndetermined to have been hospitalized in the orthopedic ward of\nhospital A during 22-28 Apr 2003, and a second was found on 22\nMay 2003 to have SARS-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV) by\nnucleic acid amplification test. On investigation, a second patient\nwas determined to have been hospitalized in the orthopedic\nward of hospital A during 22-28 Apr 2003. After the identification of\nthese cases, an investigation of pneumonia cases at hospital A\nidentified 8 cases of previously unrecognized SARS among patients.\nThe first patient linked to the second phase of the Ontario outbreak\nwas a man aged 96 years who was admitted to hospital A on 22 Mar\n2003 with a fractured pelvis. On 2 Apr 2003, he was transferred to\nthe orthopedic ward, where he had fever and an infiltrate on chest\nradiograph. Although he appeared initially to respond to\nantimicrobial therapy, on 19 Apr 2003, he again had respiratory\nsymptoms, fever, and diarrhea. He had no apparent\ncontact with a patient or an HCW with SARS, and aspiration\npneumonia and _Clostridium difficile_-associated diarrhea appeared\nto be probable explanations for his symptoms. In the subsequent\noutbreak investigation, other patients in close proximity to this patient\nand several visitors and HCWs linked to these patients were\ndetermined to have SARS. At least one visitor became ill before the\nonset of illness of a hospitalized family member, and another visitor\nwas determined to have SARS although his hospitalized wife did not.\nOn 23 May 2003, hospital A was closed to all new admissions other\nthan patients with newly identified SARS. Soon after, new provincial\ndirectives were issued, requiring an increased level of infection-\ncontrol precautions in hospitals located in several GTA regions.\nHCWs at hospital A were placed under a 10-day work quarantine\nand instructed to avoid public places outside work, avoid close\ncontact with friends and family, and to wear a mask whenever public\ncontact was unavoidable. As of 9 Jun 2003, of 79 new cases of\nSARS that resulted from exposure at hospital A, 78 appear to\nhave resulted from exposures that occurred before 23 May 2003.\nReported by: see original on web.\nMMWR Editorial Note:\n--------------------\nOn 14 May 2003, WHO removed Toronto from the list of areas with\nrecent local SARS transmission because 20 days (i.e., twice the\nmaximum incubation period) had elapsed since the most recent\ncase of locally acquired SARS was isolated or a SARS patient had\ndied, suggesting that the chain of transmission had terminated.\nBefore recognition of the second phase of the outbreak, the most\nrecent case of locally acquired SARS in Toronto was reported\nbefore 20 Apr 2003. However, unrecognized transmission, limited\ninitially to patient-to-patient and patient-to-visitor transmission,\napparently was continuing in hospital A. After directives for\nincreased hospitalwide infection-control precautions were lifted, an\nincrease in the number of cases was observed, particularly among\nHCWs.\nThe findings from this investigation underscore the importance of\ncontrolling health-care--associated SARS transmission and highlight\nthe difficulty in determining when expanded precautions for SARS\nno longer are necessary. Investigations in Canada and other\ncountries have identified HCWs to be at increased risk for SARS,\nand methods for performing surveillance among HCWs have been\nrecommended (2). The Toronto investigation suggests that\nunrecognized patient-to-patient and patient-to-visitor transmission of\nSARS might have been occurring with no associated cases of HCW\nillness until after a provincewide lifting of the expanded precautions\nfor SARS. Transient carriage of pathogens on the hands of HCWs\nis the most common form of transmission for several nosocomial\ninfections, and both direct contact and droplet spread appear to be\nmajor modes for transmitting SARS-CoV (3). HCWs should be\ndirected to use gloves appropriately (e.g., change gloves\nafter every patient contact and avoid their use outside a patient's\nroom) and to pay scrupulous attention to hand hygiene before\nputting on and after removing gloves.\nIn addition to active and passive sureillance for fever and respiratory\nsymptoms among HCWs, early detection of SARS cases among\npersons in health-care facilities in SARS-affected areas is critical,\nparticularly in facilities that provide care to SARS patients.\nIdentifying hospitalized patients with SARS is difficult, especially\nwhen no epidemiologic link has been recognized and the\npresentation of symptoms is nonspecific. Patients with SARS might\ndevelop symptoms common to hospitalized patients (e.g., fever\nor prodromal symptoms of headache, malaise, and myalgias), and\ndiagnostic testing to detect cases is limited. Available nucleic acid\namplification assays for SARS-CoV have reported sensitivities as\nlow as 50 percent (4). Although serologic testing for SARS-CoV\nantibody is available, definitive interpretation of an initial negative\ntest requires a convalescent specimen to be obtained greater than\n21 days after onset of symptoms (5).\nSeveral potential approaches for monitoring patients might improve\nrecognition of SARS in hospitalized patients. A standardized\nassessment for SARS (e.g., clinical, radiographic, and laboratory\ncriteria) might be used among all hospitalized patients with new-\nonset fever, especially for units or wards in which clusters of febrile\npatients are identified. In addition, some hospital computer\ninformation systems might allow review of administrative and\nphysician order data to monitor selected observations that might\nserve as triggers for further investigation.\nThe Toronto investigation found early transmission of SARS to both\npatients and visitors in hospital A. In areas affected recently by\nSARS, clusters of pneumonia occurring in either visitors to health-\ncare facilities or HCWs should be evaluated fully to determine if they\nrepresent transmission of SARS. To facilitate detection and\nreporting, clinicians in these areas should be encouraged to obtain\na history from pneumonia patients of whether they visited or worked\nat a health-care facility and whether family members or close\ncontacts also are ill. Targeted surveillance for community-acquired\npneumonia in areas recently affected by SARS might provide\nanother means for early detection of these cases.\nThe findings from the Toronto investigation indicate that continued\ntransmission of SARS can occur among patients and visitors during\na period of apparent HCW adherence to expanded infection-control\nprecautions for SARS. Maintaining a high level of suspicion for\nSARS on the part of health-care providers and infection-control staff\nis critical, particularly after a decline in reported SARS cases. The\nprevention of health-care-associated SARS infections must involve\nHCWs, patients, visitors, and the community.\nReferences\n---------\n1. Poutanen SM, Low DE, Henry B, et al. Identification of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome in Canada. N Engl J Med\n2003;348:1995--2005.\n2. CDC. Interim domestic guidance for management of exposures to\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) for health-care settings.\nAvailable at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/exposureguidance.htm>.\n3. Seto WH, Tsang D, Yung RW, et al. Effectiveness of precautions\nagainst droplets and contact in prevention of nosocomial\ntransmission of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Lancet\n2003;361:1519--20.\n4. Peiris JS, Lai ST, Poon LL, et al. Coronavirus as a possible\ncause of severe acute respiratory syndrome. Lancet 2003;361:1319-\n-25.\n5. Stohr K. A multicentre collaboration to investigate the cause of\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome. Lancet 2003;361:1730--3.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nUSA\n---\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Morbidity & Mortality Weekly report 13 Jun 2003 /\n52(23);550\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5223a5.htm>\n\nUpdate: Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome --- United States,\nJune 11, 2003\n-----------------\nDuring November 1, 2002-June 11, 2003, a total of 8,435 probable\nSARS cases were reported to WHO from 29 countries, including 70\nfrom the United States; 789 deaths (case-fatality proportion: 9.4\npercent) have been reported, with no SARS-related deaths reported\nfrom the United States (1).\n\nIn the United States, a total of 393 SARS cases have been reported\nfrom 42 states and Puerto Rico, with 323 (82 percent) classified as\nsuspect SARS and 70 (18 percent) classified as probable SARS\n(i.e., more severe illnesses characterized by the presence of\npneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome) (2). Of the 70\nprobable patients, 68 (97 percent) had traveled to areas with\ndocumented or suspected community transmission of SARS\nwithin the 10 days before illness onset; the remaining 2 (3 percent)\npatients were a health-care worker who provided care to a SARS\npatient and a household contact of a SARS patient (3). Of the 68\nprobable SARS cases attributed to travel, 35 (51 percent) patients\nreported travel to mainland China; 17 (25 percent) to Hong Kong\nSAR, China; 5 (7 percent) to Singapore; one (1 percent) to Hanoi,\nVietnam; 14 (21 percent) to Toronto, Canada; and 5 (7 percent) to\nTaiwan; of these, 7 (10 percent) reported travel to more than one of\nthese areas.\nSerologic testing for antibody to SARS-CoV has been completed for\n134 suspect and 41 probable cases. None of the suspect cases and\n8 (20 percent) of the probable cases have demonstrated antibodies\nto SARS-CoV, 7 of which have been described previously (3).\nThe 8th serologically confirmed probable SARS case occurred in a\nNorth Carolina [USA] resident who traveled to Toronto, Canada, on\n15 May 2003 and visited a relative in a health-care facility on 16 and\n17 May 2003. The relative's hospital roommate and another visitor\nin the room during these visits both subsequently had SARS\ndiagnosed. The patient returned to the USA on 18 May 2003, and\nhad a fever on 24 May 2003, followed by respiratory symptoms. He\nwas treated as an outpatient for these symptoms beginning on 27\nMay 2003, and a chest radiograph on 3 Jun 2003 documented\npneumonia. The patient has remained in isolation at home. All\nof the exposed health-care workers and family contacts are under\nactive surveillance for SARS.\nSerologic testing on this patient was negative for antibody to SARS-\nCoV at day 10 of illness and positive at day 11. SARS-CoV RNA\nwas not detected by RT-PCR in nasopharyngeal and oropharyngeal\nswabs collected from the patients 11 days after onset of symptoms.\nReferences\n----------\n1. World Health Organization. Cumulative number of reported cases\nof severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Available at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_06_10/en>.\n2. CDC. Updated interim U.S. case definition of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS). Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>.\n3. CDC. Update: Severe acute respiratory syndrome---United\nStates, 2003. MMWR 2003;52:525--6.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nUK\n--\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: UK Health Protection Agency Press release 12 Jun 2003\n<http://www.hpa.org.uk/news/120603_sars.htm>\nLaboratory testing for SARS shows people with mild illness have\nbeen exposed to the virus. 12 Jun 2003\n--------------------------------\nIn a new development in testing for SARS in the UK, the Health\nProtection Agency has found antibodies to the SARS coronavirus in\nsamples taken from 2 people who had had only mild illness. [How\nconfident are they that these are not false positive results? -\nMod.JW]\nSince receiving these positive laboratory results, local investigations\nhave been undertaken to check that these people had recovered\nand that none of their close contacts have suffered any clinical\nsymptoms of SARS-like illness in recent weeks. Local health\nprotection teams are satisfied that there has been no ongoing public\nhealth risk.\nThe development is a significant step in building knowledge about\nthe behaviour of the SARS coronavirus. A great deal of further\nresearch needs to be carried out before any conclusions can be\nreached, but the finding suggests that there is a spectrum of SARS\nillness, with a few people only experiencing a very mild illness before\ncomplete recovery.\nDr Maria Zambon of the HPA\u0092s Central Public Health Laboratory\nsaid \u0093Since early March [2003], we have been carrying out\ncontinuous testing on patients who were classified as probable and\nsuspected cases of SARS and of the 4 probable cases currently\nlisted, one was recently reported as testing positive. In addition to\nthis, we have also received samples from patients with milder\nsymptoms who had all travelled to areas where SARS cases have\nbeen reported, but are thought to have had limited opportunity for\nexposure to the virus. This testing has been undertaken as part of\nour precautionary approach to SARS, because so little was known\nabout the extent to which infection with the SARS coronavirus\nmight be associated with mild symptoms.\u0094\n\u00932 such people have tested positive for SARS corona virus through\nshowing an antibody response to the virus. This shows that these\nindividuals have almost certainly been exposed to the virus, and\nhave had a mild illness but have now fully recovered.\u0094\nOne further case who required hospitalisation has also tested\npositive for antibodies to SARS coronavirus and has since\nrecovered. Although these people have almost certainly been\nexposed to the SARS coronavirus, they have not been classified as\nprobable cases of SARS as they don\u0092t meet the case definition in\nterms of either severity of symptoms or travel history\u0094\nDr Zambon concluded \u0093It is still early days in terms of testing for\nSARS coronavirus, and these results show that there is a great deal\nwe still don\u0092t understand about the spectrum of illness caused by\ninfection with this virus. The majority of people tested so far have\nbeen very sick in hospital and these latest results may represent\ncases at the more mild end of the spectrum. Further testing and\nresearch is needed worldwide before we find out if there are more\npeople who may have suffered a similar mild illness. We are likely to\nfind this out in areas where there has been local transmission of\nSARS and more people have come into contact with the infection.\nWe will be sharing our data with WHO\u0092s international laboratory\ncollaboration to see if other countries have had similar cases.\u0094\nNotes to Editors\n-----------\nThe HPA has also received 2 further positive antibody results on UK\ncitizens, who were ill whilst outside the UK and were tested on their\nreturn. On 14 May 2003, WHO removed Toronto from the list of areas with\nrecent local SARS transmission because 20 days (i.e., twice the\nmaximum incubation period) had elapsed since the most recent\ncase of locally acquired SARS was isolated or a SARS patient had\ndied, suggesting that the chain of transmission had terminated. While 3 probable SARS cases have tested negative for SARS\ncorona virus (see second paragraph), WHO advise that they should\nremain in the probable category, as we have no other laboratory\nexplanation for their illness.\n Although these people have almost certainly been\nexposed to the SARS coronavirus, they have not been classified as\nprobable cases of SARS as they don\u0092t meet the case definition in\nterms of either severity of symptoms or travel history\u0094\n A standardized\nassessment for SARS (e.g., clinical, radiographic, and laboratory\ncriteria) might be used among all hospitalized patients with new-\nonset fever, especially for units or wards in which clusters of febrile\npatients are identified. To facilitate detection and\nreporting, clinicians in these areas should be encouraged to obtain\na history from pneumonia patients of whether they visited or worked\nat a health-care facility and whether family members or close\ncontacts also are ill. HCWs should be\ndirected to use gloves appropriately (e.g., change gloves\nafter every patient contact and avoid their use outside a patient's\nroom) and to pay scrupulous attention to hand hygiene before\nputting on and after removing gloves. A great deal of further\nresearch needs to be carried out before any conclusions can be\nreached, but the finding suggests that there is a spectrum of SARS\nillness, with a few people only experiencing a very mild illness before\ncomplete recovery. After implementation of provincewide public health\nmeasures that included strict infection-control practices, the number\nof recognized cases of SARS declined substantially, and no cases\nwere detected after 20 Apr 2003. This report describes a second wave of SARS cases among\npatients, visitors, and health-care workers (HCWs) that occurred at\na Toronto hospital approximately 4 weeks after SARS transmission\nwas thought to have been interrupted. Patients with SARS might\ndevelop symptoms common to hospitalized patients (e.g., fever\nor prodromal symptoms of headache, malaise, and myalgias), and\ndiagnostic testing to detect cases is limited. The investigation\nunderscores the need for monitoring fever and respiratory\nsymptoms in hospitalized patients and visitors, particularly after a\ndecline in the number of reported SARS cases. Hospital A instituted changes in policy on 8 May 2003; the number\nof persons allowed to visit a patient during a 4-hour period remained\nrestricted to one, but the number of patients who were allowed to\nhave visitors was increased. 6793\nNotes:\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\nAs SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion, the status of a reported case may change\nover time. This means that previously reported cases may be discarded after\nfurther investigation and follow-up.\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_13/en/>\nThe situation in Toronto has been changed since the last update (see below).\nUpdate 80 - Change in travel recommendations for parts of China, situation in\nToronto\nFor complete information on WHO travel recommendations see:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/2003_06_13/en/>\n[C] Change in travel recommendations 13 June 2003\nEffective today, the World Health Organization (WHO) is removing its\nrecommendation that people should postpone all but essential travel to Hebei,\nInner Mongolia, Shanxi and Tianjin regions in China.\nRecommendations to consider postponing all but essential travel to these\nregions of China were issued on 23 April and 8 May in order to minimize the\ninternational spread of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS). WHO is\nchanging this recommendation as the situation in these areas has now improved\nsignificantly. Information about the decline of the outbreaks in Hebei, Inner\nMongolia, Shanxi and Tianjin has been carefully reviewed by WHO and suggests\nthat SARS is no longer a potential threat to international travellers to\nthese regions.\nRecommendations to postpone travel are issued following consideration of\nseveral factors, including the magnitude of current SARS cases, the pattern\nof recent local transmission, and the last dates of export of cases.\nIn addition, WHO is removing Guangdong, Hebei, Hubei, Inner Mongolia, Jilin,\nJiangsu, Shaanxi, Shanxi and Tianjin from the list of areas with recent local\ntransmission. This follows confirmation that there have been no new cases\nisolated in any of these areas for more than twice the maximum incubation\nperiod, in other words more than 20 days.\nOn 27 March 2003, WHO recommended that areas with recent local transmission\nshould screen all international departing passengers to ensure that those who\nare sick with SARS or are contacts of SARS cases do not travel. This\nrecommendation is still valid for Beijing, Hong Kong and Taiwan in China, and\nToronto, Canada. For a summary of travel recommendations, see the table below.\nDuring a recent trip to Beijing, Dr David Heymann, WHO's Executive Director\nfor Communicable Diseases, commented on the measures now in place in China to\ncontain the spread of SARS. 'We've seen that there has been a massive effort\nto mobilize the population both in urban and rural areas across the country,\nencouraging people to monitor themselves for fever and to ensure that SARS\ncases are quickly identified, isolated and treated.'\n'China has made huge strides in its effort to contain the outbreak of SARS,'\nsaid Dr Heymann. 'The key thing now is to maintain vigilance and build up\nChina's disease surveillance system. Public health authorities in China and\naround the world must continue to watch out for new cases of SARS to ensure\nthat it does not emerge again elsewhere.'\nSituation in Toronto\n-------------\nThe category of pattern of SARS transmission for the city of Toronto\nhas been changed from 'B' to 'C'. This is because a probable case\nwith laboratory confirmation of SARS coronavirus exported from\nToronto had not been previously identified as a contact and put into\nvoluntary home isolation.\n'Pattern B' transmission is defined as an area having more than one\ngeneration of local probable SARS cases, but only among persons who have been\npreviously identified and followed-up as known contacts of probable SARS\ncases.\n'Pattern C'\ntransmission is defined as an area having local probable cases occurring\namong persons who have not been previously identified as known contacts of\nprobable SARS cases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 14 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\nNo. new probable cases reported: 1\nCumulative no. cases: 694\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 693)\nCumulative no. It is also the 30th day in a row on which the\nnumber of case has fallen below five since May 16.\nThe number of patients recovered and discharged from hospital\ncontinues to rise to 1382. Of them, two were discharged today.\nThe number of SARS patients in intensive care unit is 16. These cases\nare part of the 53 cases under treatment in hospitals. Most of the\npatients are showing positive responses to the treatment protocol. In\naddition, 26 are recovering patients in convalescence and in\npreparation for discharge.\nA 69-year-old woman who has a history of chronic disease died in\nAlice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital, bringing to 294 the total\nnumber of deaths relating to SARS.\nMeanwhile, temperature checks for all passengers at the airport,\nports and border points continue to be implemented to watch for\ntravellers displaying symptoms of SARS. In addition, all incoming\ntravellers are required to complete a health declaration. Four\npassengers were screened out during temperature checks at these\npoints yesterday. After undergoing further medical checks, all four\nwere however cleared of SARS symptoms.\nThe cumulative total of persons covered by home confinement remains\nat 1 262 (from 493 households). Thanks to the co-operation of the\nconfinees and members of the community, no new warning letter has\nbeen issued since May 16 and the scheme is running smoothly.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with SARS since March 12 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(change in past 24 hours presented in parentheses, minus used for decrease)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 386\n(0)/ 364 (1)/ (n/a)\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1369/ 1018 (2)/ (n/a)\nTotal: 1755 (0)/ 1382 (2)/ 294 (1)\nTotal no. patients in hospital: 79 (-3)\nRecovering patients in convalescence: 26\nCases under treatment: 53 (-1) (including 16 patients in Intensive Care Unit)\nSuspected cases: 1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[5]\nDate: 14 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update80.html>\nPlease note that the next version of the Latest Canadian Numbers on\nSARS will be posted on Monday, June 16.\n'Active' cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------\nDate: May 28/ May 29/ May 30/ Jun 2/ Jun 3/ Jun 4/ Jun 5/ Jun 6/ Jun\n9/ Jun 10/ Jun 11/ Jun 12/ Jun 13\nProbable (Active)\n13/ 19/ 43/ 62/ 64/ 67/ 68/ 70/ 66/ 64/ 65/ 60/ 55\nSuspect (Active)\n20/ 25/ 15/ 12/ 15/ 14/ 15/ 11/ 9/ 9/ 7/ 4/ 4/\nTotal:\n33/ 44/ 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75/ 73/ 72/ 64/ 59\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the\nrecent cluster in Ontario since yesterday are as follows: 1 new\nprobable and 1 new suspect case have been identified, 1 suspect case\nhas been delisted. The most recent date of onset of illness is June\n6, 2003.\nNo new probable or suspect cases have been reported from other\nprovinces and territories.\nAs of June 13, 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 435\nprobable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)\nin Canada. There have been 34 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission\nhas been limited to specific transmission settings such as\nhouseholds, hospitals and specific community settings. The\ninformation contained in this update is based on the information\navailable to Health Canada at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n* Ontario is reporting 239 probable (55 active) and 133 suspect\n(4 active) cases.\n* British Columbia is reporting 4 probable (0 active) and 46\nsuspect (0 active) cases.\n* Saskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect (0 active) case.\n* New Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases (0 active).\n* Alberta is reporting 6 suspect cases (0 active).\n* Prince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases (0 active).\nTotal # of probables discharged or at home: 156\nTotal # of suspects discharged or at home: 186\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 pm. Niman Ph.D. <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\nSource: Associated Press [edited]\n\nHealth officials say co-worker of US SARS patient dies of pneumonia\n----------------------------------------------\nA co-worker of the man with the first confirmed case of SARS in North\nCarolina died Friday of heart failure and pneumonia, state health\nofficials said.\nThe 45-year-old man was one of 2 pneumonia victims who worked in the same\nbuilding as the SARS patient. In preliminary tests, both showed no signs of\nhaving SARS, but more thorough examinations were pending, health officials\nsaid.\nThe SARS patient and the dead man, had overlapping work hours on 3 successive\ndays last month in the same building at the University of North Carolina at\nChapel Hill.\nThe SARS patient showed no symptoms at the time, and state health director\nLeah Devlin said there are no reported cases anywhere in the world in which a\nco-worker outside a medical setting passed the disease to a colleague.\nThe man who died had suffered a chronic cough for weeks and his condition\nsuddenly deteriorated Monday, the News & Observer reported Friday. State\nepidemiologist Dr. Jeffrey Engel would only say Friday that they were still\ninvestigating the background of his condition.\nThe 2nd pneumonia patient was being monitored at home after being treated\nat Duke University Medical Center.\n'Follow-up testing is being conducted to see if we can completely rule out the\npossibility of SARS in both cases,' Devlin said.\n['Very peliminary' tests from CDC] showed both men negative for SARS; the\nsame kind of test, involving swabs from the nose or the back of the throat,\nconfirmed the diagnosis of SARS in the first man.\n'Right now we're calling it definitely heading down the right track,' Engel\nsaid. 'But you cannot rule out a case of SARS until several days after the\ninitial onset of illness.'\nBlood test results from the CDC on the 2 pneumonia patients could be back as\nearly as Monday. Engel said the most conclusive test can only be done 21 to 28\ndays after onset of symptoms.\nThe SARS patient and the dead man had overlapping work times May 21-23 in the\nGiles F. Horney Building, which houses facilities services offices off the\nuniversity's main campus. A spokeswoman for the state Department of Health and\nHuman Services, Carol Schriber, said she did not know how long the men were in\nthe same building. 'The disease investigation so far has not shown close\npersonal contact between the two people,' Schriber said.\nThe university has offered health screenings to 500 employees who worked in\nthe building or for the energy services department, as well as their immediate\nfamily members. As of Friday afternoon, 35 people had been examined and none\nshowed symptoms related to SARS.\nThe SARS patient, an Orange County resident, could be released from isolation\nat home on Saturday -- 10 days after his last symptom disappeared, state\nhealth officials said.\nTest results from the CDC confirmed the Orange County man's diagnosis Monday,\nmaking him the 8th confirmed case of SARS in the United States. He\napparently contracted SARS after encountering an infected person during a\nvisit to a Toronto geriatric rehabilitation center. None of his family has\nshown any symptoms. State health officials quarantined 12 people at an Orange\nCounty doctor's office, 3 from a UNC-CH hospital and 2 family members of the\nSARS patient. The quarantine was to end Saturday.\nAlso, 9 members of the staff at Duke University Medical Center and 2 at\nWestern Wake Medical Center were being monitored for symptoms. 4 health\ncare workers at Western Wake were on furlough because they had close exposure\nto the man who died, though they did not show any symptoms of SARS.\n[Byline: Jay Cohen]\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nInstructor in Surgery (Bioengineering)\nHarvard Medical School\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[As of yesterday, the number of SARS cases worldwide stood at 8454, with only\n10 new cases from around the world. The reassignment of Toronto to category\nC (disease occurring in those not previously known to have had contact with a\nSARS patient) is indicative of the seriousness with which WHO views the\nsituation in that area. If the North Carolina contact of the SARS case in\nthat state is confirmed to have had SARS, it will represent the first U.S.\ndeath from this disease. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "Suspected cases: 1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Pattern C'\ntransmission is defined as an area having local probable cases occurring\namong persons who have not been previously identified as known contacts of\nprobable SARS cases.\n The changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the\nrecent cluster in Ontario since yesterday are as follows: 1 new\nprobable and 1 new suspect case have been identified, 1 suspect case\nhas been delisted. 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (138): ETIOLOGY\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 7 Jun 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nComment: Sequence Analysis Update\n---------------------------------\n[There are now complete genome sequences in GenBank for 18 isolates\nof human SARS coronavirus and 2 partial genome sequences. 17 of the\n18 complete sequences of isolates of the human SARS coronavirus\nexhibit the same 29-nucleotide deletion relative to the genome\nsequences of at least 2 civet cats -- and one of the 18 human\nisolates (the GZ01 sequence). The additional 29 nucleotides in the\nGZ01 and the civet cat sequences bring open reading frame (ORF) 10 in\nframe with ORF 11 and may generate a protein with 122 amino acids and\na transmembrane domain. This protein (if real) would be missing in 17\nout of 18 SARS coronavirus infections. Dr. Niman has sent the\nfollowing additional comments. - Mod.CP]\nThe updated sequences of GZ01 (including the sequence of the\n122-amino-acid protein created by the 29-nucleotide insert), BJ02,\nBJ03, BJ04 have just been made available at GenBank.\nThe completed genomes of BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, and GZ01 allow for a full\ndata set for the 5 Metropole Hotel Mutations. Not surprisingly, none\nare found in GZ01, BJ02, or BJ03. However, 2 are found in BJ04\n(C9404T and A21721G).\nBJ04 is the first reported isolate that has only some of the 5\nMetropole Hotel Mutations. All 5 mutations are found in Tor2,\nUrbani, HKU39849, SIN2500, SIN2677, SIN2679, SIN2740, SIN2774,\nCUHK-Su10, TW1, and ZJ01. None of the 5 mutations are found in GZ01,\nBJ01, BJ02, BJ03, or CUHK-W1.\nDetails on the BJ04 patient are not widely known, but since the BJ04\nisolate was the most recent submission to GenBank by the Beijing\nGenomics Institute and since, at the time of initial submission it\nwas the least completed sequence, it seems possible that the isolate\nwas from a patient who developed SARS later than patients from whom\nGZ01, BJ01, BJ02, and BJ03 were isolated by the Beijing Genomics\nInstitute.\nTherefore, it seems that evolution of the viruses isolated from\nvisitors to the Metropole Hotel may have gone through the following\nsequence of mutations.\n(1) A 29-nucleotide deletion -- found in all human isolates except\nGZ01 (and 2 civet cats);\n(2) 2 Metropole Hotel Mutations (C9404T, A21721G) -- found in BJ04;\n(3) 3 additional Metropole Hotel Mutations (G17564T, C22222T,\nC27827T) -- all 5 Metropole Hotel mutations found in the 11 isolates\nlisted above.\nFurther examination of the revised sequences suggest that there are 7\nMetropole Hotel specific mutations, in addition to the 29-nucleotide\ndeletion. 2 of the mutations which were initially just found in\nBeijing isolates have now also been found in GZ01. Thus, it seems\nthat the sequence of mutations is as follows:\n(1) The 29 nucleotide deletion (found in all isolates except GZ01);\n(2) Two mutations (A19838G and C27243T) in CUHK-W1;\n(3) Two mutations (C9404T and A21721G) in BJ04.\nCombining the 4 mutations above with G17565T, C22222T, and C27827T\nproduces the 11 isolates with all 7 mutations plus the 29-nucleotide\ndeletion.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nInstructor in Surgery (Bioengineering)\nHarvard Medical School\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[ProMED-mail is not an appropriate forum for further discussion of\nfine sequence analysis of this type. Interested subscribers wishing\nto pursue this analysis should contact Dr. Niman directly. -Mod.CP]", "summary": "(1) A 29-nucleotide deletion -- found in all human isolates except\nGZ01 (and 2 civet cats);\n(2) 2 Metropole Hotel Mutations (C9404T, A21721G) -- found in BJ04;\n(3) 3 additional Metropole Hotel Mutations (G17564T, C22222T,\nC27827T) -- all 5 Metropole Hotel mutations found in the 11 isolates\nlisted above. 17 of the\n18 complete sequences of isolates of the human SARS coronavirus\nexhibit the same 29-nucleotide deletion relative to the genome\nsequences of at least 2 civet cats -- and one of the 18 human\nisolates (the GZ01 sequence). exclusion, the status of a reported case may\nchange over time. This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_11/en/> and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_11/en/> and is unchanged\nsince the last update.\n[C] Update 78 \u00ad Situation in Toronto 11 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_11/en/>\nWHO is deeply concerned by the resurgence of SARS cases in Toronto,\nreported to WHO on 22 May 2003, and is following the situation closely.\nToronto, which had been removed from the list of areas with recent local\ntransmission on 14 May 2003, was again added to the list on 26 May 2003\nfollowing evidence that more than one generation of new cases had occurred.\nSince the disease first resurfaced in Toronto, over 90 new probable cases\nhave been reported.\nHealth authorities in Toronto are again on high alert, and are treating all\nhospital-associated clusters of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms\nas possible SARS cases until proven otherwise. Possible cases are\nimmediately isolated. All contacts are being traced and, when warranted,\nplaced in home quarantine. Infection control measures are being followed in\nall affected facilities. WHO welcomes these precautionary measures.\nCanadian authorities have most recently reported a possible cluster of SARS\npatients in a hospital east of Toronto. Although no clear epidemiological\nlink has been established that could explain this new cluster, officials\nhave adopted a cautious approach. Over the last 3 days, 15 dialysis\npatients at the Lakeridge Health Centre in Whitby exhibited respiratory and\nfebrile illnesses. After clinical review and laboratory investigations to\ndetect other causative agents, around half of these patients have now been\nexcluded from consideration as possible SARS cases. The remaining patients\nare being closely monitored.\nThere are other investigations ongoing, and many questions remain to be\nanswered before firm conclusions can be reached.\nWHO is also awaiting further information on cases in other countries that\nmay have been exported from Toronto. WHO is not yet convinced that such\ncases have been conclusively documented.\nOne of the most dangerous stages in the evolution of any outbreak, and most\nespecially one caused by a new and poorly understood disease, occurs when\ncases begin to decline and previous levels of high alert and precautionary\nmeasures likewise begin to level off. Much about the clinical behaviour of\nSARS and its mode of transmission requires further research. Until\nknowledge improves, precautionary measures such as those being followed in\nToronto are the best approach from a public health perspective.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 10 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\nNo. new probable cases reported: 1\nCumulative no. cases: 687\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 686)\nExplanation: 1 previously reported susp. case reclassified as prob. case; 1\npreviously reported prob. case exluded by reporting MDs.\nCumulative no. This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow up.\n\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_16/en/>.\n\n[C] Update 82 - Change in travel recommendations for Taiwan\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_17/en/> 17 June\nWHO has today removed Taiwan, Province of China from its list of areas to\nwhich travellers are advised to avoid all but essential travel. The move\nfollows vast improvements in case detection, infection control, and the\ntracing and follow up of contacts that led to a steep drop in the daily\nnumber of new cases.\n\n'The SARS crisis in Taiwan has been taken very seriously at all levels,'\nsaid Dr Cathy Roth, a WHO virologist who was in Taiwan in May to assess the\nneed for a strengthened response. 'SARS stimulated vast and very rapid\nimprovements in the health infrastructure, especially in the areas of\nhospital infection control procedures, systems for data collection and\nreporting, mobilization of the public, and coordination of all agencies\ncontributing to the outbreak response. We hope these improvements are\npermanent.'\n\nWHO recommends that all areas which have experienced local transmission of\nSARS maintain a high level of vigilance, as a single imported case or lapse\nin infection control can re-ignite an outbreak.\n\nThe decision to lift a travel advisory notice is based on consideration of\nseveral criteria, including the number of active cases, the number of new\ncases being reported daily, patterns of local transmission, and evidence\nthat cases are no longer being exported elsewhere. The adequacy of\nsurveillance measures, including screening for new cases and tracing and\nfollow up of contacts, is also considered. Together, these factors help\ndetermine whether travellers, as well as local residents, are at risk of\nacquiring infection outside confined settings, such as the health care\nenvironment.\n\nTaiwan, which has experienced the third largest outbreak on record,\ninitially had only a few imported cases, all clearly linked together in\nchains of person to person transmission. Following lapses in infection\ncontrol practices in a hospital, the outbreak escalated dramatically, with\nas many as 70 new cases per day being reported in mid-May. The large number\nof new cases reported daily was also partly due to a large backlog of cases\npending investigation.\n\nWHO continues to recommend that people planning to travel to Beijing, China\nconsider postponing all but essential travel. No other travel-related\nrecommendations are in place.\n\n[D]\nWHO global conference on SARS 17/18 June 2003, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia\nThis conference has just concluded. Complete texts of many of the talks can\nbe found at <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/conference/june_2003/materials/en/>.\nDr Gro Harlem Brundtland, director general of WHO, closed the meeting with\nthe following remarks: 'It is only with hindsight that we can more clearly\nsee what has happened. That is certainly the case with SARS. When many of\nus were caught up in the frantic day-to-day business of managing a growing\nepidemic, few had time either to stop or think. Today and yesterday, for\nthe first time for some of us, we have all had an opportunity to reflect on\nwhat we have achieved and on the lessons we can learn. We now know so much\nabout SARS and yet we also know how much knowledge is still lacking. We\nhave also learnt vital lessons to be better prepared for the next emerging\ndisease - and we know there will be one. Our capacity to respond and to\ncooperate should be more advanced and better tested.'\n\n[E]\nUpdate 83 \u00ad One hundred days into the outbreak\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_18/en/> June 18 [edited]\nTomorrow will mark the 100th day since WHO first alerted the world, on 12\nMarch, to the SARS threat. From the 55 cases recognized on that day,\nalarmingly concentrated in hospitals in Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Singapore,\nthe outbreak exploded within a month to cause some 3000 cases and more than\n100 deaths in 20 countries on all continents. By that time, too, the public\nface of SARS had come to be symbolized by a mask \u00ad- an appropriate image\nfor a disease still shrouded in mystery. Although the causative agent was\nconclusively identified on 17 April, the disease had no vaccine, no\neffective treatment, an overall case fatality of 15 per cent, and many\nunexplained features. As the coming weeks would reveal, SARS was also full\nof surprises.\n\nSARS was carried out of southern China, where the first cases are now known\nto have occurred in late November 2002, by an infected medical doctor who\nspent a single night on the 9th floor of a Hong Kong hotel in late\nFebruary. He infected at least 16 other persons staying on or visiting the\nsame floor. From this single event, which is still not fully understood in\nterms of the dynamics of transmission, SARS spread internationally.\n\nThe number of cases passed 4000 on 23 April and then rapidly soared to 5000\non 28 April, 6000 on 2 May, and 7000 on 8 May, when cases were reported\nfrom 30 countries. During the peak of the global outbreak, near the start\nof May, more than 200 new cases were being reported each day. Detection of\nnew infections subsequently slowed, passing 8000 on 22 May. During June,\nthe number of new cases has gradually dwindled to the present daily\nhandful. WHO is confident that all countries that have experienced\noutbreaks are disclosing cases fully and promptly \u00ad- SARS is too big a\ndisease to hide for long. The global outbreak, at least in this initial\nphase, is clearly coming under control.\n\nThe reduced number of cases is not a 'natural phenomenon' that can be\nattributed to a change in the virulence or infectivity of the SARS virus,\nas often happens with new diseases that quickly 'burn out'. Instead, the\ndramatic reduction in the number of SARS cases is the result of monumental\nefforts on the part of governments and health care staff, supported by a\nwell-informed and cooperative public.\n\nSARS is the first severe and readily transmissible new disease to strike a\nglobalized society. As such, its history to date illustrates the favorable\nconditions, both for the devastating spread of a new disease and solidarity\nin its containment, that have come to characterize a closely\ninterconnected, interdependent, and highly mobile world. On the negative\nside, the volume of international air travel allowed SARS to spread quickly\naround the world, the close interdependence of economies and markets\namplified the economic impact of SARS considerably, and instantaneous\nelectronic communications elevated public concern \u00ad- often to the point of\npanic -\u00ad and further added to the social and economic disruption caused by\nSARS.\n\nJust as Ebola came to symbolize the fear inspired by a new disease, SARS\nhas vividly depicted a truism of the infectious disease situation in a\nglobalized world: an outbreak anywhere places every country at risk. The\ncontainment of SARS \u00ad or any other epidemic-prone disease \u00ad requires\nunprecedented solidarity and makes such an effort a matter of self-interest\nfor every nation.\n\nOn the positive side, the power of electronic communications allowed the\nestablishment of 'virtual' networks of researchers, epidemiologists, and\nclinicians, who set aside competition and collaborated around the clock to\nidentify the SARS causative agent, sequence its genome, define clinical\nfeatures, and investigate modes of transmission in record time. The world\u0092s\nelectronic interconnectedness also contributed to the effectiveness of the\nfirst global alerts to SARS. The initial 12 March alert, followed three\ndays later by a stronger and more specific warning, provided a clear line\nof demarcation in the early history of SARS. Areas with cases prior to the\nalert experienced the most devastating outbreaks. These occurred in Hong\nKong, Hanoi, Singapore, Toronto, and China. Prior to 12 March, in all these\ncases, hospital staff, unaware that a new disease had surfaced and was\nspreading in health care settings, took no precautions to protect\nthemselves as they fought to save the lives of patients. SARS spread\nrapidly in these hospitals, and then spilled over into the wider community,\nresulting in the exportation of cases elsewhere.\n\nWith the notable exception of Taiwan, all other areas experiencing imported\ncases after the alerts were able to prevent further transmission altogether\nor hold the number of additional cases to a very small number. Most\nobservers attribute this success to the high level of awareness and\npreparedness that followed the alerts, greatly aided by responsible\nreporting in the media.\n\nKey weapon: the thermometer\nOne of the most important lessons learned to date is the decisive power of\nhigh-level political commitment to contain an outbreak even when\nsophisticated control tools are lacking. SARS has been brought close to\ndefeat by the diligent and unrelenting application \u00ad- on a monumental scale\n\u00ad- of centuries-old control measures: isolation, contact tracing and follow\nup, quarantine, and travel restrictions. Other successful measures include\nthe designation of SARS-dedicated hospitals to minimize the risk of spread\nto other hospitals, mass media campaigns to educate the public and\nencourage prompt reporting of symptoms, and the establishment of fever\nclinics to relieve pressure on emergency rooms, which have also been the\nsetting for many new infections. Screening at airports and other border\npoints and, through fever checks, throughout selected population groups has\nalso been effective.\n\nViet Nam broke the chain of transmission on 28 April, as did the\nPhilippines on 20 May, and Singapore on 31 May. Recommendations to postpone\nall but essential travel have been removed for all areas except Beijing, China.\n\nIn reaching these landmarks in the containment of SARS, the most severely\naffected countries and areas have identified and rapidly corrected\nlong-standing weaknesses in their health systems in ways that will mean\npermanent improvements for the management of all diseases. In addition,\nsystems of data collection and reporting, and new patterns of openly and\nfrankly communicating information to the public will hold the world in good\nstead when the next new disease emerges and the next influenza pandemic\nbreaks out.\n\nContinued surveillance and vigilance needed for a year\nSARS has repeatedly demonstrated its resilience, most recently with the\nresurgence of cases in Toronto. As underscored by researchers at this\nweek\u0092s meeting in Kuala Lumpur\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/conference/june_2003/materials/en/>, SARS has\nfeatures that can thwart even the best preparedness plans and slip past\neven the highest levels of awareness and suspicion. Under the right\nconditions, which remain poorly understood, single highly infectious people\nhave been known to set off trains of transmission that have led, in the\nworst cases, to almost 100 additional infections. In Singapore, 5 patients\naccounted for 103 of the total 206 cases in the outbreak.\n\nAnother significant problem occurs when SARS symptoms are masked by other\ndiseases. Many surprising clusters of cases have been fanned by such\npatients, as they do not arouse suspicion, are not isolated or managed\naccording to strict procedures of infection control, have no restrictions\non visitors, and are frequently transferred to other hospitals for further\ntreatment or tests.\n\nAlthough SARS is clearly coming under control, the need for continued\nvigilance is now greater than ever. The world still has a chance to\ninterrupt the chain of person to person transmission everywhere. However,\nbecause of the many unanswered scientific questions, particularly\nconcerning the origins of the virus and the contribution of environmental\ncontamination to overall transmission, WHO sees a need for at least a full\nyear of surveillance to determine whether the disease has established\nendemicity and to ensure that no cases have spread, undetected, to\ncountries with poor surveillance and reporting systems. If the disease has\nnot become endemic, the next big hurdles will concern the questions of a\npossible animal reservoir and possible seasonal recurrence. Scientists\ncannot rule out the possibility that the SARS virus hides somewhere in\nnature, as the Ebola virus does, only to return when conditions are once\nagain ripe for the efficient spread of infection to its new human host.\n\nFinally, as underscored in today\u0092s conference sessions, the development of\na reliable point-of-care diagnostic test must be given high priority.\nPending the availability of such a test, and for a while yet to come, every\ncase of atypical pneumonia has the potential to arouse suspicion and spark\na panic. Any hospital-based cluster of febrile patients with respiratory\nsymptoms will need extensive investigation. And any person with a fever or\ncough could be barred from international travel.\n\nAs long as a single case of SARS exists or is suspected anywhere in the\nworld, and as long as fundamental questions about the origins of the virus\nremain unanswered, all countries need to remain on guard.\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 18 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website/ Beijing Government SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/entity/csr/sars/en/china2003_06_18.pdf>\n<http://www.beijing.gov.cn/english/englishsars/beijingen/detail.asp?ResourceID=63257>\n\n\nIt is noteworthy that no new probable cases were reported in the past 24 hours\nAs of 18 Jun 2003 a cumulative total of 5326 probable cases with 347 deaths\nhave been reported. At present there are a total of 220 suspected cases\nstill pending in China.\n\nThese 22 provinces have not reported a new probable case in the past 20 or\nmore days: Hebei, Shanxi, Inner Mongolia, Shanghai, Hubei, Guangxi,\nGuangdong, Tianjin, Jilin, Gansu,Jiangsu, Anhui, Shaanxi, Zhejiang, Henan,\nChongqing, Jiangxi, Ningxia, Shandong, Fujian, Hunan and Xinjiang..\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 18 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update82.html>\n\n\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------------\n'Active' cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\n\nDate: May: 28 / 29 / 30 / Jun: 2 / 3 / 4 / 5 / 6 / 9/ 10 / 11 / 12 / 13 /\n16 / 17\nProbable (active)\n13 / 19 / 43 / 62 / 64 / 67 / 68 / 70 / 66 / 64 / 65 / 60 / 55 / 44 / 37\nSuspect (active)\n20 / 25 / 15 / 12 / 15 / 14 / 15 / 11 / 9 / 9 / 7 / 4 / 4 / 4 / 5\nTotal:\n33 / 44 / 58 / 74 / 79 / 81 / 83 / 81 / 75 / 73 / 72 / 64 / 59 / 48 / 42\n\nAs of June 17, 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 439 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. Other successful measures include\nthe designation of SARS-dedicated hospitals to minimize the risk of spread\nto other hospitals, mass media campaigns to educate the public and\nencourage prompt reporting of symptoms, and the establishment of fever\nclinics to relieve pressure on emergency rooms, which have also been the\nsetting for many new infections. Australia: 5 / 0 / 0 / 5 / 12 May 2003 / 13 Jun 2003\nBrazil: 3 / 0 / 0 / 2 / 9 Jun 2003 / 9 Jun 2003\n On the positive side, the power of electronic communications allowed the\nestablishment of 'virtual' networks of researchers, epidemiologists, and\nclinicians, who set aside competition and collaborated around the clock to\nidentify the SARS causative agent, sequence its genome, define clinical\nfeatures, and investigate modes of transmission in record time. As underscored by researchers at this\nweek\u0092s meeting in Kuala Lumpur\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/conference/june_2003/materials/en/>, SARS has\nfeatures that can thwart even the best preparedness plans and slip past\neven the highest levels of awareness and suspicion. The decision to lift a travel advisory notice is based on consideration of\nseveral criteria, including the number of active cases, the number of new\ncases being reported daily, patterns of local transmission, and evidence\nthat cases are no longer being exported elsewhere. From the 55 cases recognized on that day,\nalarmingly concentrated in hospitals in Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Singapore,\nthe outbreak exploded within a month to cause some 3000 cases and more than\n100 deaths in 20 countries on all continents. The move\nfollows vast improvements in case detection, infection control, and the\ntracing and follow up of contacts that led to a steep drop in the daily\nnumber of new cases. Jun 2003\nSouth Africa: 1 / 0 / 1 / 0 / 9 Apr 2003 / 3 May 2003\n We hope these improvements are\npermanent.'\n\nWHO recommends that all areas which have experienced local transmission of\nSARS maintain a high level of vigilance, as a single imported case or lapse\nin infection control can re-ignite an outbreak. Prior to 12 March, in all these\ncases, hospital staff, unaware that a new disease had surfaced and was\nspreading in health care settings, took no precautions to protect\nthemselves as they fought to save the lives of patients. \n\nSARS was carried out of southern China, where the first cases are now known\nto have occurred in late November 2002, by an infected medical doctor who\nspent a single night on the 9th floor of a Hong Kong hotel in late\n Under the right\nconditions, which remain poorly understood, single highly infectious people\nhave been known to set off trains of transmission that have led, in the\nworst cases, to almost 100 additional infections. Instead, the\ndramatic reduction in the number of SARS cases is the result of monumental\nefforts on the part of governments and health care staff, supported by a\nwell-informed and cooperative public. As such, its history to date illustrates the favorable\nconditions, both for the devastating spread of a new disease and solidarity\nin its containment, that have come to characterize a closely\ninterconnected, interdependent, and highly mobile world. Although the causative agent was\nconclusively identified on 17 April, the disease had no vaccine, no\neffective treatment, an overall case fatality of 15 per cent, and many\nunexplained features. SARS has been brought close to\ndefeat by the diligent and unrelenting application \u00ad- on a monumental scale\n\u00ad- of centuries-old control measures: isolation, contact tracing and follow\nup, quarantine, and travel restrictions. Scientists\ncannot rule out the possibility that the SARS virus hides somewhere in\nnature, as the Ebola virus does, only to return when conditions are once\nagain ripe for the efficient spread of infection to its new human host. In reaching these landmarks in the containment of SARS, the most severely\naffected countries and areas have identified and rapidly corrected\nlong-standing weaknesses in their health systems in ways that will mean\npermanent improvements for the management of all diseases. Together, these factors help\ndetermine whether travellers, as well as local residents, are at risk of\nacquiring infection outside confined settings, such as the health care\nenvironment. Most\nobservers attribute this success to the high level of awareness and\npreparedness that followed the alerts, greatly aided by responsible\nreporting in the media. The\ncontainment of SARS \u00ad or any other epidemic-prone disease \u00ad requires\nunprecedented solidarity and makes such an effort a matter of self-interest\nfor every nation.
