This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n\n(1) These 2 new probable cases, with onsets of illness 25 and 27 Feb 2003,\nwere identified retrospectively in the United Kingdom. They both most\nlikely acquired their infection in Hong Kong SAR and became ill and\nrecovered while in the Philippines.\n\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_12/en/> and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_12/en/> and is unchanged\nsince the last update.\n\n[C] Update 79 \u0096 Situation in China 12 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_12/en/>\n\nChina\u0092s Executive Vice Minister of Health, Mr Gao Qiang, and Dr David\nHeymann, WHO\u0092s Executive Director for Communicable Diseases, briefed the\npress this morning on the situation of SARS control in China. Also in\nattendance were Dr Qi Ziaoqiu, Director-General of the Department of\nDisease Control in the Chinese Ministry of Health, and Dr Henk Bekedam, WHO\nRepresentative to China.\n\nThe briefing marked the first joint news conference between high-ranking\nChinese and WHO officials since the SARS outbreak began. The briefing\nfollowed a day of intensive meetings during which WHO officials reviewed\ndata and statistics from selected provinces, voiced their concerns, and\nreceived frank and detailed answers.\n\nDr Heymann praised the openness with which the WHO team was welcomed by the\nMinistry of Health, and described the measures now in place to control and\nprevent SARS as \u0093excellent\u0094. He cited the high level of commitment and\ndetermination at all levels of the health system as largely responsible for\nthe dramatic recent decline in the number of cases seen throughout mainland\nChina.\n\nOne purpose of the visit was to determine how China had succeeded in\nbringing down the number of cases so rapidly, and to encourage officials to\nshare their experiences with the rest of the world. Indications of the\neffectiveness of control measures, cited by Dr Heymann, include the very\nshort time now occurring between the onset of symptoms and the detection\nand isolation of cases, and the speed and efficiency of contact tracing.\nSuch measures are important as they limit the amount of time that an\ninfected person is capable of spreading the virus to others and thus bring\ncontrol efforts closer to the stage when the chain of person-to-person\ntransmission can be broken.\n\nOther effective measures include systems for both passive and active\nsurveillance, such as fever checks at train and bus stations and airports,\na nationwide mass media campaign to inform and educate the public, and a\nvery large number of fever clinics to assess those who suspect they may\nhave symptoms. \u0093We\u0092ve seen that there has been a massive effort to\nmobilize the population both in urban and rural areas across the country,\nencouraging people to monitor themselves for fever and to ensure that SARS\ncases are quickly identified, isolated and treated.\u0094\n\nSpecific concerns expressed by the WHO team include the lack of a\nsustainable surveillance system that can be relied on to detect the first\nhints of a resurgence of cases, some delays in meeting WHO requests for\nfurther information, and wide variations in application of the national\ncase definitions, which can lead to under-reporting of cases. Some problems\nrelated to prompt sharing and analysis of data are considered to arise from\ninstitutional and administrative problems, particularly concerning the\ninformation flow from provinces to the central level.\n\nAnother major concern is the large number of cases that have no known\nsource of exposure, thus making it extremely difficult to trace patterns of\ntransmission. In Beijing, the number of cases with no known contact with a\nSARS patient has recently increased from 50 percent to more than 70 percent.\n\nIn the interest of protecting against a further resurgence of cases, WHO\nofficials singled out strengthening of surveillance capacity as the top\npriority. Experience to date has shown that a single case, especially if\nhighly infectious, can rapidly ignite an explosive outbreak.\n\n\u0093With SARS seemingly on the decline for now, there is a great need to\nstrengthen the SARS control and surveillance system in China,\u0094 said Dr\nBekedam. \u0093The system now in place grew out of an emergency response and has\nto be strengthened for the long run.\u0094 He expressed doubt that the present\nsystem would be strong enough \u0093to hold back the tide\u0094 when confronted with\na resurgence of the disease.\n\nIn his assessment of the long-term SARS situation in China, Dr Heymann also\nstressed the need for systematic studies of the origins of SARS. \u0093We still\ndon\u0092t know exactly where SARS came from, or how it was transferred to the\nhuman population. We don\u0092t know if this disease is seasonal and will\ndecrease this year but come back next year.\u0094 Until proper research into\nthe origins of SARS has been conducted, it will be impossible to predict\nwhen the conditions that first allowed the virus to jump to humans from a\nsuspected animal reservoir might be repeated in the near or distant future.\n\nWHO initial assessments of the SARS situation in China, issued in late\nApril [2003] following a visit to Guangdong Province, expressed serious\nconcern over the lack of urgency in reporting cases of SARS in China, and\ncriticized the government for not immediately treating the outbreak as a\npublic health emergency requiring extraordinary measures for its\ncontrol. Dr Heymann and other members of the WHO team are now satisfied\nthat these measures are in place, at least for the immediate response to\nSARS. Recent visits to selected provinces, jointly conducted by the Chinese\nMinistry of Health and WHO, found a high level of public awareness of SARS,\nits symptoms and mode of transmission, and the need for twice-daily fever\nchecks.\n\nChina is regarded as the epicentre of the SARS outbreak. The country was\nhome to the first cases, detected in mid-November of last year [2002], and\npresently accounts for almost two thirds of all reported cases worldwide.\nThe WHO visit was arranged to secure reassurance that control measures in\nthis vast country are adequate to continue the downward trends in cases\nand, equally important, to ensure that a sustainable system is in place to\ndetect and contain a resurgence of cases. WHO is also anxious to ensure\nthat the considerable knowledge and experience acquired in managing the\nlargest SARS outbreak on record is shared for the benefit of all countries.\n\nThe SARS outbreak has revealed substantial weaknesses in the disease\nsurveillance system in China. When investment in health infrastructure is\nneglected, conditions are ripe for the unchecked spread of any\nepidemic-prone disease, often at tremendous cost to a nation\u0092s economy. In\nthe view of WHO, the surveillance system in China needs to be made more\nflexible and capable of a much more rapid and consistent response to any\nnew infectious disease threat.\n\nDuring the visit, Chinese officials expressed deep concern about the\ncountry\u0092s capacity to deal with the next influenza season against a\nbackground of possible SARS cases. The presence of influenza could greatly\ncomplicate the detection and accurate diagnosis of SARS cases, while also\nincreasing the caseload of suspect cases considerably.\n\nThe containment of SARS remains the overriding objective of WHO. If SARS is\nnot contained, the world will face a situation in which every case of\natypical pneumonia, and every hospital-based cluster of febrile patients\nwith respiratory systems will have the potential to rouse suspicions of\nSARS and spark widespread panic.\n\nIn an earlier report, a WHO assessment team reached the following\nconclusion: \u0093If SARS is not brought under control in China, there will be\nno chance of controlling the global threat of SARS. Achieving control of\nSARS is a major challenge especially in a country as large and diverse as\nChina. Effective disease control and reporting are the cornerstone of any\nstrategy to do this.\u0094\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 12 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nNo. new probable cases reported: 2\nCumulative no. cases: 688\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 687)\nExplanation: 1 previously reported prob. case excluded by reporting MD.\n\nCumulative no. Together with local health\nauthorities, WHO epidemiologists are investigating the cause of this latest\nhospital cluster.\n\nThere is one new probable case of SARS in Hong Kong. This is the 25th consecutive day on which the number of\ncases has fallen below 5 since 16 May 2003. There is no case involving\nhealthcare workers today.\n\nThe number of patients recovered and discharged from hospital is 1365. Of\nthem, one was discharged today. The number of SARS patients in intensive\ncare units is 19. These cases are part of the 66 cases under treatment in\nhospitals. 34 are recovering patients in convalescence and in preparation\nfor discharge.\n\nOne patient died, bringing the total number of deaths attributable to SARS\nto 288. The deceased was a 34-year-old male.\n\nMeanwhile, temperature checks for all passengers at the airport, ports, and\nborder points continue to be implemented to watch for travellers displaying\nsymptoms of SARS. In addition, all incoming travellers are required to\ncomplete a health declaration. 5 passengers were screened out at these\npoints yesterday. After undergoing further medical checks, 3 were cleared\nof SARS symptoms and continued their journey, and 2 others were referred to\nhospitals for observation.\n\nAll household contacts of confirmed or suspected SARS patients are required\nto undergo home confinement for monitoring and treatment up to a maximum of\n10 days. So far, a total of 1262 persons (from 493 households) had been\ncovered, of whom 34 had been found to have SARS.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with SARS since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(change in past 24 hours presented in parentheses with minus for decrease)\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 386 (0)/ 359\n(0)/ (n/a)\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1367 (1)/ 1006 (1)/ (n/a)\n\nTotal: 1753 (1)/ 1365 (1)/ 288 (1)\n\nTotal no. in hospital: 100 (-1)\nRecovering patients in convalescence: 34\nCases under treatment: 66 (including 19 patients in Intensive Care Unit)\n\nSuspected cases: 4\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 9 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update76.html>\n\n\n'Active' cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\n\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------\nDate: May 27/ May 28/ May 29/ May 30/ June 2/ June 3/ June 4/ June 5/ June\n6/ June 9\n\nProbable (Active)\n12/ 13/ 19/ 43/ 62/ 64/ 67/ 68/ 70/ 66\nSuspect (Active)\n21/ 20/ 25/ 15/ 12/ 15/ 14/ 15/ 11/ 9\n\nTotal:\n33/ 33/ 44/ 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75\n\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the recent\ncluster in Ontario since Friday [6 Jun 2003] are as follows: 6 new probable\nand 3 new suspect cases have been identified, 1 probable case and 1 suspect\ncase previously reported have been delisted, 1 suspect case has been\nupgraded to probable. The most recent reported date of onset of illness is\n4 Jun 2003.\n\nNo new probable or suspect cases have been reported from other\nProvinces/Territories.\n\nAs of 9 Jun 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 424 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 33 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals, and specific\ncommunity settings.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 225 probable (66 active) and 136 suspect (9 active)\ncases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable (0 active) and 46 suspect (0\nactive) cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect (0 active) case.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases (0 active).\nAlberta is reporting 6 suspect cases (0 active).\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases (0 active).\nTotal no. of probables discharged or at home: 131\nTotal no. of suspects discharged or at home: 185\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 9 Jun 2003.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6]\nDate: 9 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News brief [edited]\n\n[A] Canada from Canada.com\n<http://www.canada.com/health/story.html?id=B4D154E3-AD2E-42C3-AA69-C509DF0377B0>\n\nAn unexplained cluster of respiratory illnesses at a hospital east of\nToronto has Ontario's SARS containment team worried about the possibility\nof a new outbreak of the disease. 15 dialysis patients of the Whitby site\nof the Lakeridge Health Centre have pneumonia or respiratory symptoms and\nare under investigation as possible SARS patients, Dr. James Young,\nOntario's commissioner of public security, said Monday. In addition, 'there\nhave been some staff reports of illness today which we are looking into,'\nsaid Dr. Donna Reynolds, from the Durham Region public health\ndepartment. The ages of those who are sick range from 28 into their 80s.\n\n'We will not know whether they are SARS or not until we have seen them go\nthrough this clinical course over the next 10 days,' said Dr. David Ross,\nLakeridge's SARS consultant and chief respirologist. 'They are all in\nisolation.' The first person became sick 1 Jun 2003. By Thursday [5 Jun\n2003], as more patients fell ill, management of the facility ordered staff\nto don full gown and glove protection. On Friday [6 Jun 2003], the local\npublic health authorities were called. By Saturday [7 Jun 2003], officials\nrealized they had 'around 10' people who were ill.\n\nDr. Don Atkinson, the chief of staff, said the first person to come down\nwith a respiratory illness had received dialysis at one of the hospital's\n27 satellite sites, so it wasn't immediately apparent there might be a\nproblem. Atkinson added that they cannot, at this point, link the first\npatient to the other 14.\n\nYoung, who only learned of the possible cluster on Saturday, said doctors\nare performing tests to see whether there might be another cause for the\nillnesses. But in the meantime, all are being treated like SARS cases. They\nare in respiratory isolation; public health is tracing their contacts and\nordering them into quarantine.\n\nThe hospital has been effectively moved to a Level 3 designation,\nindicating the highest level of SARS contamination. That designation puts\nall sorts of restrictions on admissions and transfers of patients as well\nas the ability of staff to work at other facilities.\n\nLakeridge officials told an afternoon news conference that 2 brothers --\nnot linked to the Whitby cluster -- arrived at their Oshawa site 9 days ago\nand were being treated for SARS. They're in critical and deteriorating\ncondition. The pair had visited their ailing mother at North York General\nHospital during an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome at that\nfacility. But there is no known link between those 2 cases and the\nunexplained illnesses in Whitby.\n\nEfforts are under way to determine how the patients could have contracted\nSARS, if indeed they have the disease. No epidemiologic or 'epi' link to\nknown SARS cases has yet been identified for the group. An epi link is\nneeded to officially diagnose a probable or suspect case of SARS. But the\nexperience in Toronto's second SARS outbreak showed officials the early\nlack of an epi link is no guarantee a case isn't SARS. The current\noutbreak was sparked after officials at North York General Hospital, who\nwere alerted to suspicious pneumonias by worried nurses, decided the\npatients couldn't be suffering from SARS because they couldn't discover a\nlink to prior cases. As a consequence, the disease festered among patients\nin the orthopedic ward for weeks before eventually infecting staff.\nInfected patients transferred from the facility took the disease to several\nother hospitals in Toronto.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of 9 Jun 2003 there have been a cumulative total of 8421 probable cases\nof SARS with 784 deaths reported from 29 countries. Since the last WHO\nupdate there have been 21 new cases of SARS reported. Canada has reported\n11 new cases, Taiwan 4 new cases, Hong Kong 3 new cases, and one each from\nChina, Thailand, and the United States.\n\nIn the above newswire, there is a discussion on a new cluster of febrile\nrespiratory illness in a health care facility. At present it is a\nsuspected outbreak of SARS and has led to implementation of infection\ncontrol procedures that assume this outbreak is due to SARS. We await\nofficial follow-up as to whether another etiology for this outbreak is\nidentified or whether this is another health care environment-related SARS\noutbreak in Ontario. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "15/ 11/ 9\n\nTotal:\n33/ 33/ 44/ 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75\n\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the recent\ncluster in Ontario since Friday [6 Jun 2003] are as follows: 6 new probable\nand 3 new suspect cases have been identified, 1 probable case and 1 suspect\ncase previously reported have been delisted, 1 suspect case has been\nupgraded to probable. 6457\nNotes:\nAs SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion, the status of a reported case may\nchange over time. This means that previously reported cases may be\ndiscarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n[B] Areas with recent local transmission and travel recommendations can be\naccessed at: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/areas/2003_06_10/en/> and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_10/en/> and is unchanged\nsince the last update.\n[C] Update 77 - WHO officials to visit China 10 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_10/en/>\nDr David Heymann, Executive Director for Communicable Diseases at WHO, is\ntravelling today to China, where he will confer with health officials about\nthe SARS outbreak and discuss plans for the future. Other members of the\nteam include Dr Guenael Rodier, Director of Communicable Disease\nSurveillance and Response, and Dr Thomas Grein, who coordinates global\nresponse operations for SARS.\nThe purpose of the visit is to take stock of the current SARS situation in\nChina and exchange views on the next steps forward. In particular, WHO\nwould like to develop, in collaboration with the Chinese government, a\nresearch agenda that fully exploits the many intriguing lines of evidence\nuniquely associated with the SARS experience in China. WHO officials also\nwant to assess areas where Chinese authorities may require more support to\nensure that the disease is securely contained and to protect against a\nfuture recrudescence of cases.\n'SARS is a serious disease with many puzzling features,' said Dr Heymann.\n'Long-term containment depends on finding answers to a long list of\nscientific questions. China has much to offer the rest of the world.'\nSome immediate issues for discussion concern case definitions, procedures\nfor contact tracing, and the extent of local transmission in specific\nareas. The WHO team further seeks reassurance that hospital equipment and\nsupplies for infection control are adequate, especially in the poorer\nprovinces.\nMeasures may need to be found for sustaining China's present monumental\neffort to contain SARS, particularly as programmes for responding to other\npriority diseases, such as HIV/AIDS and TB, may suffer in the long run.\nWeaknesses in the health infrastructure, notably inadequate surveillance,\nreporting, and hospital facilities in some of China\u0092s poorer provinces,\nhave been of concern since the first report of a WHO assessment team was\nissued in early April [2003]. Both WHO and the Chinese Ministry of Health\nregard the emergency response to SARS as an excellent opportunity to\nstrengthen, throughout the mainland, systems for detecting and responding\nto all emerging and epidemic-prone infectious diseases. Such long-term and\ncomprehensive improvements will also strengthen China\u0092s capacity to respond\nto the next influenza pandemic, which many experts now regard as imminent.\nWHO officials are also hoping to learn which measures taken by China have\nso rapidly brought the country\u0092s SARS outbreak -\u00ad- the largest in the world\n-\u00ad- under control.\nThe first cases of SARS were detected in Guangdong Province, China, in\nmid-November of last year [2002]. That outbreak has since been brought\nunder control. Initial studies suggest a lower case fatality ratio than\nseen elsewhere, and high cure rates. In addition, a report on the\nepidemiology of the outbreak, issued in mid-May [2003] by the Chinese\nCenter for Disease Control and Prevention, provides evidence suggesting\nthat close contact with wild game animals is linked to the first sporadic\ncases, supporting a hypothesis that the SARS virus may have jumped to\nhumans from an animal reservoir. In addition, the outbreak in Guangdong\nProvince shows some features, in terms of incubation period and groups at\nhighest risk, that differ from the clinical picture seen in outbreaks\nelsewhere.\nAnswers to these and other questions will help build a solid scientific\nbasis for understanding SARS, predicting its future evolution, and knowing\nhow to respond should cases surface in new areas or resurface in areas\nwhere the disease has been contained.\nUnlike many new diseases that have emerged in the past 2 decades, SARS\nshows no sign of burning out on its own. If the disease is pushed back out\nof its new human host, this will result from the persistent application of\nsimple yet highly effective control tools: prompt detection and isolation\nof cases, strict infection control in hospitals, and tracing and\nappropriate follow-up of all contacts.\nBoth Viet Nam and Singapore have successfully broken the chain of\ntransmission and have since remained free of SARS. However, the risk of\nimportation of cases remains as long as cases are occurring anywhere in the\nworld.\nThe visit to China is one in a series in which WHO officials, including the\ncurrent Director-General, Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, and the Director-General\nelect, Dr J.W. Lee, confer with health authorities at SARS outbreak sites\nhaving the greatest experience to date. Dr. Brundtland will be visiting Hong\nKong SAR later this month.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 10 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\nNo. new probable cases reported: 4\nCumulative no. cases: 686\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 680)\nExplanation: 2 previously reported suspected cases reclassified as probable\ncases by reporting MDs.\nCumulative no. This is the 26th consecutive day on which the number\nof cases has fallen below 5 since 16 May 2003.\nToday's case involved a 65-year-old man [with a family member that had\nearlier been confirmed to have SARS infection]. He was admitted to Alice Ho\nMiu Ling Nethersole Hospital on 23 May 2003 and is now in stable condition.\nThe number of patients recovered and discharged from hospital is 1368. Of\nthem, 3 were discharged today. The number of SARS patients in intensive\ncare units is 17. These cases are part of the 62 cases under treatment in\nhospitals. 34 are recovering patients in convalescence and in preparation\nfor discharge.\n2 patients with underlying diseases died, bringing the total of deaths\nattributable to SARS to 290.\nMeanwhile, temperature checks for all passengers at the airport, ports, and\nborder points continue to be implemented to watch for travellers displaying\nsymptoms of SARS. In addition, all incoming travellers are required to\ncomplete a health declaration. 5 passengers were screened out at these\npoints yesterday. After undergoing further medical checks, 4 were cleared\nof SARS symptoms and continued their journey and the other was referred to\nhospital for observation.\nAll household contacts of confirmed or suspected SARS patients are required\nto undergo home confinement for monitoring and treatment up to a maximum of\n10 days. So far, a total of 1262 persons (from 493 households) had been\ncovered, of whom 34 had been found to have SARS.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with SARS since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(change in past 24 hours presented in parentheses, minus used for decrease)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 386 (0)/ 360\n(1)/ (n/a)\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1368 (1)/ 1008 (2)/ (n/a)\nTotal: 1754 (1)/ 1368 (3)/ 290 (2)\nTotal no. patients in hospital: 96 (-4)\nRecovering patients in convalescence: 34\nCases under treatment: 62 (-4) (including 17 patients in Intensive Care Unit)\nSuspected cases: 1\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5]\nDate: 10 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update77.html>\n'Active' cases include those hospitalized, currently ill at home, or under\ninvestigation.\nActive SARS cases in Canada\n---------------------\nDate: May 28/ May 29/ May 30/ Jun 2/ Jun 3/ Jun 4/ Jun 5/ Jun 6/ Jun 9/ Jun 10\nProbable (Active)\n13/ 19/ 43/ 62/ 64/ 67/ 68/ 70/ 66/ 64\nSuspect (Active)\n20/ 25/ 15/ 12/ 15/ 14/ 15/ 11/ 9/ 9\nTotal:\n33/ 44/ 58/ 74/ 79/ 81/ 83/ 81/ 75/73\nThe changes in the case count and status of the SARS cases in the recent\ncluster in Ontario since Monday are as follows: 1 new probable. His diagnosis raised the possibility of SARS spreading from\npeople carrying the virus but not showing any symptoms. Atkinson said because the facility\nwasn't an acute-care hospital, which is where institutional SARS outbreaks\nhave taken place in the Greater Toronto Area, it wasn't required to put up\nprotective barriers, although it did do the same screening. Those barriers\nwere put up Thursday [5 Jun 2003] after it became clear a problem might be\ndeveloping, he said. 5 staff are being monitored for possible infection,\nhe said.\n2 other cases in Oshawa General Hospital, however, are being investigated\nas potential SARS deaths. Whitby and Oshawa are located east of Toronto\noutside the GTA. Those 2 individuals were in intensive care. 'We review all\ndeaths in the intensive care unit,' Atkinson said, but the timing and\nsymptoms of those 2 cases were of special concern. Almost 500 to 1000\npeople will end up in quarantine as a result of this possible outbreak,\nsaid Dr. Donna Reynolds, medical officer of health for Durham region.\nNo linkage has been established yet between the people under investigation\nand any known SARS cases, Atkinson said. One symptomatic person was from a\nlong-term care facility, Reynolds said. There is no evidence of SARS\nspread in the community, she said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As of 10 Jun 2003 there have been a cumulative total of 8430 probable\ncases with 789 deaths reported from 20 countries. The\nslides can be used as an indirect immunofluorescence test (IIFT). A\nlarge number of SARS patients have already been analyzed by IIFT\nusing these slides. Positive reactions were observed in almost all\nsera from more than 150 SARS patients, while more than 500 sera from\nhealthy blood donors, contact persons, or patients with other virus\ninfections, e.g. HIV, HCV, or HBV, were all negative. The slides can\nnow be ordered from EUROIMMUN. the last update.\n[C] Update 72 - Situation in China 3 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_03/en/>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com\nfor continued monitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\nThe daily number of reported new probable cases of SARS in mainland\nChina has declined considerably in recent weeks, from an average of\n166 cases during the first week of May [2003], to 90 cases during the\nsecond week, 27 cases in the third week, and 16 in the fourth week.\nOver the past 6 days, the daily number of reported new cases has\ndropped to an average of 2.5.\nAs in other areas with large and challenging SARS outbreaks, this\nprogress over the past month demonstrates the decisive importance of\nhigh-level political commitment and determined application of control\nmeasures that have proven their effectiveness. At the same time,\nexperiences elsewhere demonstrate the need for maintaining a vigilant\nand cautious approach to SARS, particularly in a country as large and\ndiverse as China.\nThe resurgence of cases in Toronto demonstrates how difficult it can\nbe to maintain control over a new disease characterized by many\npuzzling epidemiological and clinical features. The continued\nalertness of Singapore, which has most recently broken the chain of\nSARS transmission, demonstrates the importance of staying on guard,\nwith a high level of vigilance and preparedness, to ensure that a\nsingle imported case does not reignite an outbreak.\nBased on recent experiences and the many uncertainties about the\nbehaviour of SARS, WHO sees a need for caution in interpreting the\ndownward trend in the number of reported new cases in China.\n'SARS is still present in China, and WHO continues to regard China as\nthe epicentre of SARS,' said Dr David Heymann, Executive Director for\nCommunicable Diseases at WHO. 'It is our job, together with Chinese\nauthorities, to try to prevent this disease from becoming permanently\nestablished in such a vast country.'\nThe next few months will prove crucial in the attempt to contain SARS\nworldwide, which now greatly depends on whether the disease can be\ncontrolled in China. Otherwise, cases in China -- with its long\nporous borders and large migrant populations -- could seed outbreaks\nelsewhere and would thus make SARS a continuing threat for the rest\nof the world.\nDr Heymann believes that the international community has much to\nlearn from Chinese experiences in controlling SARS, initially in\nGuangdong Province and increasingly in other parts of China. 'It is\nalso our job to work with the government to determine the factors\nthat have led to such a rapid fall in SARS cases compared to other\nsites where outbreaks have occurred.'\nWHO Director-General Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland has stressed the\nimportance, for the security of all populations, of fully\nunderstanding the situation within any country experiencing an\noutbreak of a disease that can threaten neighbouring countries or be\nspread internationally by the travelling public. 'This allows, within\na country, for WHO to do what needs to be done to help the rest of\nthe world,' she said, speaking on a SARS-related issue during last\nweek\u0092s World Health Assembly.\nAlthough great improvements in surveillance, reporting, infection\ncontrol, and public awareness have occurred in China in recent weeks,\nWHO remains concerned about the sensitivity of case detection in some\nprovinces, and about the capacity of the health infrastructure to\ncope with a challenge on the scale of SARS. A particular problem is\nthe large number of new cases reported (approximately half) without\ninformation on the source or setting of exposure. The absence of this\ninformation makes it difficult for WHO to assess the extent of local\ntransmission.\nLocal transmission of SARS, especially when it occurs outside a\nconfined setting, such as the health care environment, is one measure\nof the risk of infection for both residents and international\ntravellers. The pattern of local transmission is also an important\nconsideration when WHO issues travel advice designed to prevent\nfurther international spread of SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 3 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Taiwan CDC [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nDate: 2 Jun 2003\nNo. new probable cases reported: 1\nCumulative no. cases: 679\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 684)\nExplanation: 6 probable cases have been cancelled by reporting physician\nCumulative no. The categories of HCW include\ndoctors, nurses, therapists, hospital aides, as well as nurses who\nare self-employed or from private nursing agencies, and locum doctors.\nPrivate sector Healthcare Institutions (HCIs)\n- Effective today, HCWs in the private sector will be allowed to move\nfreely across private HCIs without restriction.\n- HCWs in the private sector will be allowed to practise or work in\npublic HCIs effective 16 Jun 2003.\nPublic sector Healthcare Institutions (HCIs)\nThe lifting of the restrictions on HCWs in the public HCIs will be\ndone in several phases:\n- The first group of HCWs allowed to move across the public HCIs were\nMedical Officers who were rotated to new postings in public HCIs on 2\nJun 2003.\n- On 9 Jun 2003, advanced specialist trainees will move to their new\npostings in public HCIs.\n- Effective 16 Jun 2003, all other HCWs in the public HCIs will be\nallowed to work in other public HCIs. In addition, HCWs in public\nHCIs will also be allowed to work in the private HCIs from 16 Jun\n2003.\nSystems for monitoring HCWs in public and private sector hospitals\nAs a safeguard against cross-institutional spread of infection, all\nHCIs will be required to closely monitor all HCWs working in their\nHCI who were practising within the last 10 days in another HCI, to\nensure that they are afebrile and well.\nNeed to maintain a high level of vigilance\nThe Ministry has reminded all HCIs of the need to maintain the\ncurrent high level of vigilance and infection control. Surveillance\nfor clusters of patients and staff with fever in hospitals and\nnursing homes will also continue.\nSituation Update\nSince the last MOH press update on 31 May 2003, there have been no\nnew probable cases, no discharges, and no deaths.\nSuspect cases\nSince 31 May 2003, there are no new suspect cases admitted to TTSH.\nThe 47-year-old man reported as a suspect case on 31 May 2003 has\nsince been diagnosed to have a non-SARS illness and discharged well.\nObservation cases\nFrom 31 May 2003 to 3 June 2003, a total of 14 cases were admitted\nfor observation for fever. Of these, 9 have since been diagnosed as\nnon-SARS cases, while 5 are still under observation. Of the 5 cases\nunder observation, 2 had travelled to China and Hong Kong. The other\n3 do not have any contact history at this point in time.\nQuarantine Figures*\n**Discharged patients under home quarantine = 61\nContacts under home quarantine = 0\nTotal under home quarantine orders = 61\n*Quarantine cases refer to those who are required to stay at home for\nprecautionary reasons as they may have had contact with a SARS\npatient. These are healthy individuals.\n** This is an added precautionary measure for discharged SARS\npatients as well as those with co-morbidities.\nA summary of SARS cases is as follows:\nDischarged: 165\nHospitalised: 9 (including 4 in ICU)\nDeaths: 31\nProbable cases: 206*\nSuspect cases: 0\nObservation cases: 5\n*Includes 1 case who died from non-SARS causes\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As of 3 Jun 2003, there have been a cumulative total of 8398\nprobable cases of SARS with 772 deaths reported to WHO from 29\ncountries. and is\nunchanged since the last update.\n[C] Update 75 - Update on Situation in Singapore 6 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_06/en/>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nfor continued monitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\nAs cases of SARS continue to decline, areas that have brought the\ndisease under control, often at great cost, are now seeking ways to\nprotect these hard-won gains against the hazards of imported cases.\nBecause even a single new case could spark another outbreak, it is\nimportant for national authorities to remain vigilant even as current\nnumbers of probable cases are diminishing.\nOfficials from Singapore and Malaysia met today at Woodlands, a\nSingapore border checkpoint, to strengthen cross-border efforts aimed\nat containing the spread of SARS. Officials from both countries\nagreed that travellers detected with fever at the land checkpoint\nwould be isolated and subsequently sent back to their point of\nembarkation. The Singaporean and Malaysian delegations agreed to\nupdate each other on health screening measures introduced at land,\nair, and sea checkpoints. Singapore has also announced that it will\ncontinue all current pre-departure screening measures until the\nregional SARS situation improves.\nIn addition, since the start of the SARS outbreak, when it became\napparent that travel could spread the disease globally, WHO has\ncollaborated with non-governmental organizations such as the\nInternational Air Transport Association and the International Civil\nAviation Organization to promote the adoption of measures aimed at\npreventing the spread of SARS via air travel.\nSingapore's Changi International Airport will soon become the world's\nfirst airport to implement new measures to guard against the spread\nof SARS, in accordance with procedures set out by the International\nCivil Aviation Organization. Changi was chosen as the test case\npartly due to Singapore's rapid response to SARS; it was the first\nairport to introduce thermal scanners to screen passengers for\nfevers. Since then, Singapore has also provided such scanners on loan\nto Toronto for use in that city's airport exit screening.\nIf Changi is determined to take all the necessary steps in accordance\nwith the International Civil Aviation Organization guidelines, which\nare in turn based on WHO recommendations, the airport will receive a\ncertificate. The global aviation body is readying a scheme to\nevaluate how well airports enforce anti-SARS measures, which include\nspecific procedures for screening passengers and airport workers. The\nmeasures also include distributing SARS information to passengers and\nguidance on handling suspected cases already on board aircraft and at\ntheir destinations.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 6 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nNo. new probable cases reported: 0\nCumulative no. cases: 676\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 677)\nExplanation: 2 probable cases have been cancelled by reporting\nphysician; 1 previously reported [suspected] case has been\nreclassified as a probable case by reporting physician\nCumulative no. As a scientist who had been\ninvolved since the beginning of the SARS outbreak in Singapore and\nwho is still part of the current investigation, I wish to comment on\n2 points that were brought up in ProMED-mail dated Fri 30 May 2003,\nentitled 'SARS-worldwide (126).'\n(1) Singapore used its military forces to assist in contact tracing\nand enforcement of home quarantine. In addition to the above,\nSingapore also used military-related Research Institutes to assist in\nthe investigation of the SARS epidemic and to provide diagnostic\ntesting for SARS clinical samples. In mid-March 2003, the Defense\nMedical Research Institute (DMRI) commenced the SARS investigation\ntogether with the Virology Unit from the Singapore General Hospital.\nAnother military-related Research Institute which came on later in\nthe outbreak investigation was the DSO National Laboratories\n[information on the DSO laboratories can be found at the following\nURL <http://www.dso.org.sg/>. It is a not-for-profit research and\ndevelopment organization that works with the military in Singapore].\n(2) Management of the outbreak benefited from support from\nhigh-quality laboratory services. The Virology Unit of the Singapore\nGeneral Hospital [SGH] is our front-line national laboratory,\nproviding virological testing for a wide range of pathogens. However,\nin the situation of the SARS outbreak in Singapore, a number of other\nlaboratories formed these 'high-quality laboratory services'\nmentioned in point 2.\nIn mid-March 2003, right from the beginning, and before the\netiological finding that the unusual atypical pneumonia was caused by\nSARS, DMRI was already working alongside the Virology Unit of SGH.\nAlthough DMRI was not an official member of the WHO laboratory\nnetwork, information was released by WHO through the Virology Unit of\nSGH. The results from DMRI were fed back to the WHO in the same\nmanner. On 24 Mar 2003, WHO released the CDC primers for [the\nSARS-associated] coronavirus, and 3 days later we used the primers to\nobtain a positive PCR reaction from a primary contact of the first\nindex case. DNA sequencing revealed 100 percent match with the\nnucleotide sequence from the Bangkok index case. By then, positive\nPCR reactions and Coronavirus-like sequences using the Germany\nprimers BNIoutS2 and BNIoutAs were also obtained. Up to this point in\nthe SARS investigations, we had a lot of assistance and advice from\nChristian Drosten, Germany, and Leo Poon, HongKong, on the various\naspects of PCR reactions.\nThe findings were presented in the WHO meeting on SARS Etiology and\nDiagnosis: Current Status and Future Development, on 16 Apr 2003 in\nGeneva. The Virology unit in SGH also attempted to isolate the SARS\nvirus in a range of cell lines including Vero cells provided by DMRI\nwhile waiting for the shipment of Vero E6 to arrive from CDC,\nAtlanta. These were the isolates that were used for sequencing of the\ncomplete virus genomes (The Lancet, published online May 2003).\nLike all other scientists involved in the SARS investigation, DMRI\nalso explored the possibility of co-infection with a metapneumovirus\nand found no evidence whatsoever for it. By then the SARS epidemic\nhad become a crisis not only in Singapore, but worldwide. Colleagues\nfrom the Infectious Disease group in DMRI stopped all research work\nimmediately. Initial attempts to sequence the virus from infected\nVero cell cultures were also put aside as the group reorganised\nitself into a full-scale diagnostic laboratory to fulfill our\nnation's needs.\nOn 26 Apr 2003, the Singapore SARS Clinical Consortium was officially\nformed. The first objective of the consortium was to ensure that\nhealthcare and research laboratories in Singapore could undertake\ndiagnostic testing of the SARS clinical samples. By then, the volume\nof clinical samples submitted for SARS testing had exceeded the\ncapacity of the laboratories then involved. Various laboratories in\nSingapore were drawn into the consortium; these were from the 3\nhospitals -- National University Hospital, Tan Tock Seng Hospital,\nand of course, Virology Unit in SGH; and from 5 Research Institutes,\nDMRI, DSO National Laboratories (who also reorganised into a\ndiagnostic laboratory), Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology (who\nassisted the diagnostic setup in Tan Tock Seng Hospital), Singapore\nGenomic Institute (who took over the sequencing of virus genomes),\nand the National Environment Agency (who prepared the virus antigens\nfor serological testing).\nHowever, we must not forget the contribution from non-members of the\nSARS consortium. They include the clinicians and nurses who risk\ninfection to collect the best clinical specimens; our special courier\nservice involved in the logistics of sample distribution; and lastly\nour colleagues from the National University of Singapore, who\nassisted during the early days of the investigation with Electron\nMicroscopy (Electron Microscopy unit), and optimisation of the PCR\nprimers for diagnostic testing (Department of Microbiology). Together\nwith members of the SARS Consortium, they contributed to the\n'high-quality laboratory services'.\n--\nDr Boon-Huan Tan, PhD\nResearch Scientist\nDefence Medical Research Institute\nDefence Science & Technology Agency\nSingapore\n<nmiv2@nus.edu.sg>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[7]\nDate: 6 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] Taiwan from Japan Today 7 Jun 2003\n<http://www.japantoday.com/e/?content=news&cat=7&id=262355>\n\nA hospital in Taipei on Friday reported 6 new cases of SARS, raising\nconcerns of a new outbreak after a 3-day lull, the Health Ministry\nsaid. the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat, 31 May 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE press release, 28 May 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_last.htm>\n\nSARS virus in civet cat\n------------------------\nOn the basis of recent information of the World Health Organization\nwhich traced the SARS virus to a civet cat and 2 other small mammals\nin China, the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) states the\nfollowing:\n- as mentioned in its previous information (see press release of 11\nApr 2003), the OIE still does not dispose of any scientific evidence\nto suggest that SARS-related disease has occurred in animals.\n- Therefore, the OIE continues the monitoring of the evolution of the\ndisease and undertakes a very close collaboration with the World\nHealth Organization as well as with the scientists of the OIE\nReference Laboratories on the subject.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 31 May 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Nature 31 May 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/cgi-taf/Gateway.taf?g=5&file=/drugdisc/news/articles/423467a.html&filetype=&_UserReference=>\n\nVirus detectives seek source of SARS in China's wild animals\n-----------------------------\nResearchers investigating the source of severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS) have turned their attention to the wild-animal\nmarkets of southern China. The move follows reports that workers and\nanimals at the markets show high rates of infection with\ncoronaviruses, the family to which the virus believed to cause SARS\nbelongs.\nThe possible link to wild animals emerged on 23 May 2003, when a team\nfrom the University of Hong Kong revealed that a coronavirus\nresembling the SARS virus had been isolated from 6 masked palm civets\n(_Paguma larvata_) and a raccoon dog (_Nyctereutes procyonoides_) in\na market in Shenzhen, in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong.\nAntibodies against the virus were also found in a Chinese ferret\nbadger (_Melogale moschata_) from the same market.\nAlthough the virus is not the same as that believed to cause SARS --\na member of the Hong Kong team describes it as 'genetically very\nclose, but not identical' -- 5 out of the 10 civet handlers at the\nmarket had antibodies against the SARS virus in their blood. A\nChinese government team has since released results showing that 66\nout of 508 animal handlers tested at markets in Guangdong had\nantibodies against the SARS virus.\nMicrobiologist Kwok-yung Yuen, who led the Hong Kong team, notes that\nin the general population, the level of antibodies against the SARS\nvirus is much lower. 'This suggests that the virus is jumping from\nwild animals to humans,' he says.\nBecause the animal virus is similar to the SARS virus, but different\nfrom other coronaviruses, it is now a prime suspect in the hunt for\nthe origins of SARS. The likelihood that the virus is moving the\nother way -- from humans to animals -- is diminished by ongoing work\non genetic sequences of the 2 viruses. These analyses suggest that\nthe animal version has an extra stretch of 29 nucleotide bases.\n'Viruses tend not to gain stretches of nucleotides when they jump\nacross species,' says Klaus Stoehr, a SARS expert at the World Health\nOrganization (WHO) in Geneva.\nBut uncertainties remain over the exact source of the virus. Only 6\ncivets were present in the market, and the fact that they all had the\nvirus suggests that they were infected recently. 'They could have\ngotten it from another animal during transport to the markets,' says\nZhang-liang Chen, a molecular biologist and president of the China\nAgricultural University in Beijing. Chen's group did not find the\nSARS virus in samples from 8 civets taken from other markets and in\nthe wild in Guangdong.\n[Byline: David Cyranoski and Alison Abbott]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[See ProMED-mail's moderator's comment in posting 20030525.1290.\nAuthentic, detailed, first-hand data on the findings from the cited\ninvestigators will improve our ability to evaluate the role of\nanimals as a source of SARS in China. We would also appreciate\ninformation on the identity of the incriminated species. According to\nthe World Chelonian Trust web-site\n<http://www.chelonia.org/Articles/Palm_Civits_SARS.htm>, the relevant\nanimal is the Palm Civet, _Paguma larvata_. - Mod AS].\n[Perhaps the most significant aspect of the above report from Nature\nis that some animals in other markets or in the wild have tested\nnegative for the SARS coronavirus. So it is possible that the animals\nin the market in Shenzhen may have been infected from an unknown\nanimal or human source. A potential animal reservoir and the\ndirection of transmission of the virus are still unresolved issues.\nDr. Henry L Niman, (Instructor in Surgery (Bioengineering) Harvard\nMedical School <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>) has observed that,\nirrespective of the biological data, the molecular story remains\nclear at this time. 16 of the 17 available SARS coronavirus genome\nsequences have the same 29-nucleotide deletion (the GZ01 sequence\nbeing the single exception), whereas the genome sequences of at least\n2 civet cats (and the GZ01 sequence) have the same corresponding\n29-nucleotide insertion. It is clear, however, that more data are\nrequired before the biological relevance of this 29-nucleotide\ndeletion/insertion can be assessed. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "On the basis of recent information of the World Health Organization\nwhich traced the SARS virus to a civet cat and 2 other small mammals\nin China, the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) states the\nfollowing:\n- as mentioned in its previous information (see press release of 11\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although the virus is not the same as that believed to cause SARS --\na member of the Hong Kong team describes it as 'genetically very\nclose, but not identical' -- 5 out of the 10 civet handlers at the\nmarket had antibodies against the SARS virus in their blood. and\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/travel/travel2003_06_05/en/> and is\nunchanged since the last update.\n\n[C] Update 74 - Global decline in cases and deaths continues 5 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_05/en/>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nfor continued monitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\n\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 8403 probable cases with 775\ndeaths has been reported from 29 countries. This represents an\nincrease of 6 new cases and 3 deaths compared with yesterday.\n\nThe new cases occurred in Canada (5) and Taiwan (1). New deaths were\nreported in China (2) and Hong Kong (1).\n\nHealth authorities in some of the earliest areas to experience severe\noutbreaks are maintaining measures to protect against a resurgence of\ncases. Hong Kong authorities have announced their intention to\nmaintain current screening procedures at all border points for at\nleast one year.\n\nThe measures, which began at the end of March [2003], include use of\ninfrared temperature scanners at border points, and obligatory health\ndeclarations from all travellers. No new imported cases have occurred\nsince these measures were introduced.\n\nHong Kong is also setting up a master list of imported cases.\nApproximately 6 percent of all SARS cases in Hong Kong are now\nthought to have been imported. To date, Hong Kong has experienced\n1748 cases and 284 deaths, making it the second most severely hit\narea, with mainland China at the top.\n\nHong Kong shares a border with Guangdong Province, China. The disease\nwas first brought to Hong Kong in late February [2003], when an\ninfected medical doctor from the province spread the virus to at\nleast 13 guests and visitors, all on the same floor of the hotel\nwhere he stayed. They carried the disease with them when they\nreturned home, seeding the earliest outbreaks in Viet Nam, Singapore,\nand Toronto as well as Hong Kong.\n\nIn these initial outbreaks, SARS first took root in hospital\nsettings, where staff, unaware that a new disease had surfaced and\nfighting to save the lives of patients, exposed themselves to the\ninfectious agent without barrier protection. All of these initial\noutbreaks were subsequently characterized by chains of secondary\ntransmission outside the health care setting.\n\nAt present, local chains of transmission are occurring only in\nToronto and several parts of China. All other countries with imported\ncases have managed either to prevent transmission entirely or limit\nadditional cases to very small numbers.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nDate: 4 Jun 2003\nNo. new probable cases reported: 0\nCumulative no. cases: 677\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 678)\nExplanation: 2 probable cases have been cancelled by reporting\nphysician; 1 previously reported [suspected] case has been\nreclassified as probable cases by reporting physician\n\nCumulative no. update.\n\n[C] Update 73 - No new deaths, but vigilance needed for imported\ncases 4 Jun 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_04/en/>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com\nfor continued monitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 8402 probable SARS cases with 772\ndeaths has been reported from 29 countries. This represents an\nincrease of 10 new cases compared with yesterday. The new cases were\nreported in Canada (5), Hong Kong (1), Taiwan (2), Germany (1), and\nthe USA (1).\nNo new deaths were reported today. This marks the first day with no\nnew SARS deaths since 28 Mar 2003, when the cumulative totals stood\nat 1485 cases and 53 deaths.\nThe peak numbers of deaths occurred during the second week of March\n2003, when as many as 20 new deaths were being reported on some days.\nWith outbreaks at all the initial 'hot zones' either contained or\ncoming under control, SARS is clearly in decline, indicating that\nrecommended control measures are effective when combined with\npolitical commitment and determination.\nThe fact that the chain of transmission has been broken in Viet Nam\nand Singapore underscores the WHO position that SARS can be\ncontained, despite the absence of a vaccine, robust diagnostic test,\nand specific treatment. Control currently depends on prompt detection\nand isolation of cases, good infection control in hospitals, and the\ntracing and quarantine of contacts.\nViet Nam has remained free of new SARS cases since 8 Apr 2003. In\nSingapore, the last locally acquired probable case was isolated on 11\nMay 2003. No new cases have since been detected in either country\ndespite a high level of alert and aggressive investigation of all\nrumoured cases.\nThe experience in Toronto, where more than 70 new cases have been\nreported since 26 May 2003, underscores the risk of a resurgence of\ncases and the constant need for vigilance. A single imported case can\nreignite an outbreak or bring cases to a new area, if preparedness\nmeasures are weak.\nThe new case reported today in Germany, in a man recently returned\nfrom Taiwan, has resulted in the quarantine of around 50 contacts.\nThe man has been hospitalized in isolation.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 4 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Taiwan CDC [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/sarsen/>\n\nDate: 3 Jun 2003\nNo. new probable cases reported: 0\nCumulative no. cases: 678\n(cumulative no. cases in last update: 679)\nExplanation: 3 probable cases have been cancelled by reporting\nphysician; 2 previously reported [suspected] cases have been\nreclassified as probable cases by reporting physician\nCumulative no. worldwide (131): diagnostic testing", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203907", "date": "2003-06-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (131): DIAGNOSTIC TESTING\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 2 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_02a/en/>\n\nUpdate 71 - Status of diagnostic tests, training course in China 2 Jun 2003\nStatus of diagnostic tests\nThe development of commercial diagnostic tests for SARS has\nprogressed more slowly than initially hoped. Part of the problem\narises from certain unusual features of SARS that make this disease\nan especially difficult scientific challenge.\nFor many viral diseases, the greatest quantities of the causative\nagent are excreted during the initial phase of illness, usually in\nthe first few days following the onset of symptoms. This is often the\nperiod during which patients pose the greatest risk of infecting\nothers.\nSARS, however, follows a different pattern. During the initial phase\nof illness, virus shedding is comparatively low. Virus shedding peaks\nin respiratory specimens and in stools at around 10 days after onset\nof clinical illness. In effect, this unusual behaviour creates the\nneed for tests with a particularly high sensitivity.\nSuch tests do not yet exist. Because small quantities of the virus\nare initially shed, available tests, though developed with impressive\nspeed, are unable to detect SARS virus or its genetic material\nreliably during the earliest days of illness. The low sensitivity of\ncurrent virus detection tests is a particular challenge for SARS\ncontrol, as patients are capable of infecting others during the\ninitial phase and therefore need to be reliably detected and quickly\nisolated.\nIn SARS patients, detectable immune responses do not begin until day\n5 or 6. Reliable antibody tests can detect virus only by around day\n10 following the onset of symptoms.\nWHO continues to recommend use of its case definitions, based on\nclinical presentation, distinct chest X-rays, and history of possible\ncontact with SARS patients, to detect suspect and probable cases and\nmake management decisions.\nTo expedite the development of better diagnostic tests, laboratories\nin the WHO collaborating network have made critical biological\nmaterials and reagents available to any laboratory having a sustained\ninterest in the development of diagnostic tests, including the\ncommercial sector. A comprehensive bank of clinical specimens,\nincluding respiratory specimens and samples of blood, urine, and\nfaeces from SARS patients, has been established. The bank holds\nspecimens representing all stages of the disease, ranging from the\nonset of symptoms to recovery.\nDuring the development of diagnostic tests, such specimens are needed\nto assess how well a test will perform with real patients' specimens,\nas opposed to under the artificial conditions of a laboratory.\nSpecimens from the bank, which was set up by the Hong Kong Department\nof Health and the Hospital Authority, are being supplied by a\ncollaborating laboratory, at no charge, to developers of diagnostic\ntests. As a sample from a single specimen can be subdivided into 6 to\n8 identical sub-samples, laboratories can work in parallel on\nidentical specimens, which will further facilitate the assessment of\ncomparative performance. Identical samples also support\nstandardization of diagnostic tests to ensure consistent accuracy.\nLaboratories in the WHO network have also made available\nstandardizing reagents for virus and antibody tests. These reagents,\nwhich include samples of the inactivated virus and blood from\npatients in both acute and convalescent stages of illness, will allow\nuniform assessment of diagnostic results around the world against a\n'gold standard.'\nSera have been made available by collaborating laboratories in the\nUnited Kingdom and Hong Kong. Inactivated virus was prepared by the\nBernard-Nocht Institute in Germany. Distribution of these reagents\nwill be the responsibility of the Robert-Koch Institute, also in\nGermany. In return for the supply of these exclusive materials,\nrecipients of WHO support have agreed to offer test kits, once\navailable, at preferential prices to developing countries.\nTraining course in China\nWHO is currently coordinating a series of training courses in Beijing\naimed at establishing an efficient laboratory infrastructure for SARS\ndiagnosis in all provinces throughout China. Work of the WHO\nlaboratory network has made it possible to support the training\ncourses with test materials and reagents.\nTraining in the use of currently available tests is being provided by\nrepresentatives of the labs where they were developed, thus ensuring\nthat Chinese professionals benefit from the best first-hand\nexperience the world can offer. Trainers come from laboratories in\nthe USA, the UK, and Hong Kong.\nChina has already developed a highly promising ELISA diagnostic test.\nFor early detection of SARS virus, the PCR molecular test offers the\ngreatest potential under average hospital conditions. The Singapore\nGenomic Institute has made its PCR test available, at no cost, to\nsupport SARS diagnosis in China.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 2 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/lab/eia/index.htm>\n\nCoronavirus Antibody Testing at State Public Health Laboratories 30 May 2003\nCDC has made reagents for SARS coronavirus antibody testing available\nto state public health laboratories. To meet U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration (FDA) regulations for use of non-licensed tests in\nlaboratories outside of CDC, the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of\nCDC has approved the following consenting documents and additional\ninformational material for use in conjunction with the collection and\ntesting of specimens in state public health laboratories. Clinicians\nare encouraged to obtain, if possible, informed consent prior to\ncollecting such specimens, and to contact their state public health\nlaboratories for additional information on submitting specimens.\nThese documents and additional information also are available on the\nwebsite of the Association of Public Health Laboratories (APHL).\nInformed Consent (30 May 2003)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/lab/eia/consent.htm>\nParticipant Information Sheet (30 May 2003)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/lab/eia/participant.htm>\nHealth-Care Providers Information (12 May 2003)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/lab/eia/hcpletter051203.htm>\nInterim Guidance for Those Patients With Mild or Asymptomatic\nInfection (30 May 2003)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/lab/icguidance.htm>\nFact Sheet for Clinicians (30 May 2003)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/testresultsc.htm>\nLetter from Deputy Associate Director for Science, CDC (15 May 2003)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/lab/adsletter051503.htm>\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 3 Jun 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times, Tue 3 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/03/health/03DETE.html>\n\nRace to Develop New Generation of SARS Diagnostic Tests\n-------------------------------------------------------\nA number of experimental tests have been developed or are being\ndeveloped, scientists, government officials, and corporate executives\nsaid in recent interviews and at a meeting on SARS research at the\nNational Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda on\nFri 30 May 2003. But such development 'has progressed more slowly\nthan initially hoped' because people produce only small amounts of\nthe SARS virus in the first few days of illness, unlike most other\nviral diseases, the World Health Organization said yesterday. This\nunusual feature of SARS will require highly sensitive tests, and it\nwill probably be several months before doctors will be able to use a\nsingle test to determine whether a person must be isolated because he\nor she has SARS.\nBefore a test can be relied upon, it must be run on specimens known\nto contain the virus to make sure it is accurate. And it has been\ndifficult, scientists said, to procure enough specimens from patients\nat different stages of the disease to do this. An accurate test is\nvital for public health because the consequences of a wrong diagnosis\ncan be severe. If SARS is missed, the disease can spread. And a false\ndiagnosis can mean unnecessary isolation, quarantines, and economic\nhavoc.\nA diagnosis of probable SARS is now based on a checklist of symptoms,\nchest X-rays, and information about whether a person has been exposed\nto someone with the disease or has traveled to a region where SARS is\nwidespread. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has\ndeveloped a test that detects antibodies to the SARS virus in blood.\nBut it usually takes 21 days for a person to make enough antibodies\nto be detected. So the usefulness of such tests is generally limited\nto epidemiological studies. Most efforts to develop quicker tests\nrely on a technique called PCR (polymerase chain reaction). This\ntechnique can detect tiny amounts of a virus's genetic material.\nScientists have to initiate the test [by adding oligonucleotide\nprimers to anneal specifically to the target genome]. The CDC has\ndeveloped a PCR test, and a number of companies have developed their\nown [versions].\nOne of the first was developed by Artus in Germany, which is already\nproviding its test to labs around the world. Abbott Laboratories, one\nof the largest companies in diagnostic testing, [is licensed] to sell\nthe Artus test in the United States, Canada, and other countries.\nRoche, another leader in diagnostics, said it hoped to have a test\ndeveloped in a few weeks. Others developing tests include EraGen\nBioSciences of Madison, Wisconsin, and Prodesse of Waukesha,\nWisconsin. Polymerase tests can theoretically produce results in 2 to\n6 hours, though in actual practice results may not be ready for a day\nor 2, especially if the samples have to be sent somewhere for testing.\nDr. Heymann of the WHO said some of the early SARS tests produced\n'many false negatives,' meaning that they [did not detect] the virus\n[when it was present]. The CDC says PCR tests also tend to produce\nfalse positives, so that any positive finding should be confirmed by\nrepeating the test or having the specimen tested by another\nlaboratory.\nOne of the biggest problems now is that scientists do not yet know\nhow and when to take samples to have the best chance of finding the\nvirus. It can be found at different times in nasal and lung fluids,\nstool, and blood. Less SARS virus seem to be present in the first 5\ndays of illness than later, presenting a major challenge in\ndeveloping diagnostic tests, said Dr. Malik Peiris of the University\nof Hong Kong.\nPatients for testing have been hard to come by. That is a common\nquandary for companies, said Dr. Peter Heseltine, medical director\nfor infectious diseases at Quest Diagnostics, the nation's largest\nclinical laboratory company, which is developing its own SARS test.\nPart of the problem, especially for American companies, is that most\nSARS cases are in Asia. Doctors there are often too busy coping with\nthe immediate crisis to send samples to researchers developing tests.\nAlso some package delivery services had refused to carry SARS\nspecimens. The authorities say, however, that there has been no known\ncase of SARS infection from shipment of samples.\nTommy G. Thompson, US Secretary of Health and Human Services, and\nsenior officials of the CDC and the Food and Drug Administration met\nwith 9 diagnostic companies in Washington on Thursday. The officials\nurged the companies to develop SARS tests and promised to work with\nthe companies. 'We are trying to work with the Chinese government to\nimprove our access to samples from patients in China,' Dr. Mark B.\nMcClellan, the commissioner of the FDA, said in an interview. Dr.\nKlaus Stoehr, who directs the WHO's scientific investigation of SARS,\nsaid his agency had developed a specimen bank in Hong Kong that\nscientists could tap at no charge. 'We ask in return that if\ncompanies develop a licensed test they donate or sell it at a low\nprice' to poor countries, Dr. Stoehr said.\nSo far no company has applied for approval of a SARS diagnostic test.\nTests that are offered as a service by clinical laboratories or used\nfor research do not require FDA approval, so some test developers are\ndistributing tests without approval. But if a test is to be widely\nsold and used to guide treatment, the FDA expects the developers to\nseek approval, agency officials said. Several scientists said that\nbecause of the severe consequences of a missed diagnosis, a SARS test\nshould have rates of false negatives and false positives of less than\n5 percent, and preferably much smaller. Some first-generation tests\ncan detect the SARS virus but not the amount present.\nSuch quantitative information could be useful in determining who\nmight spread the virus or in monitoring a treatment. The tests also\nare not likely to provide results fast enough to be used, for\nexample, for airport screening. Participants at Friday's meeting in\nBethesda urged development of a type of test that looks for viral\nproteins that might be able to [meet such needs].\n[Byline: Andrew Pollack and Lawrence K. Altman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n To expedite the development of better diagnostic tests, laboratories\nin the WHO collaborating network have made critical biological\nmaterials and reagents available to any laboratory having a sustained\ninterest in the development of diagnostic tests, including the\ncommercial sector. A number of experimental tests have been developed or are being\ndeveloped, scientists, government officials, and corporate executives\nsaid in recent interviews and at a meeting on SARS research at the\nNational Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda on\n The low sensitivity of\ncurrent virus detection tests is a particular challenge for SARS\ncontrol, as patients are capable of infecting others during the\ninitial phase and therefore need to be reliably detected and quickly\nisolated. These reagents,\nwhich include samples of the inactivated virus and blood from\npatients in both acute and convalescent stages of illness, will allow\nuniform assessment of diagnostic results around the world against a\n'gold standard.' This\nunusual feature of SARS will require highly sensitive tests, and it\nwill probably be several months before doctors will be able to use a\nsingle test to determine whether a person must be isolated because he\nor she has SARS. Because small quantities of the virus\nare initially shed, available tests, though developed with impressive\nspeed, are unable to detect SARS virus or its genetic material\nreliably during the earliest days of illness. Less SARS virus seem to be present in the first 5\ndays of illness than later, presenting a major challenge in\ndeveloping diagnostic tests, said Dr. Malik Peiris of the University\nof Hong Kong. The CDC says PCR tests also tend to produce\nfalse positives, so that any positive finding should be confirmed by\nrepeating the test or having the specimen tested by another\nlaboratory. Specimens from the bank, which was set up by the Hong Kong Department\nof Health and the Hospital Authority, are being supplied by a\ncollaborating laboratory, at no charge, to developers of diagnostic\ntests. But such development 'has progressed more slowly\nthan initially hoped' because people produce only small amounts of\nthe SARS virus in the first few days of illness, unlike most other\nviral diseases, the World Health Organization said yesterday. Training in the use of currently available tests is being provided by\nrepresentatives of the labs where they were developed, thus ensuring\nthat Chinese professionals benefit from the best first-hand\nexperience the world can offer. That is a common\nquandary for companies, said Dr. Peter Heseltine, medical director\nfor infectious diseases at Quest Diagnostics, the nation's largest\nclinical laboratory company, which is developing its own SARS test. Several scientists said that\nbecause of the severe consequences of a missed diagnosis, a SARS test\nshould have rates of false negatives and false positives of less than\n5 percent, and preferably much smaller. Clinicians\nare encouraged to obtain, if possible, informed consent prior to\ncollecting such specimens, and to contact their state public health\nlaboratories for additional information on submitting specimens. As a sample from a single specimen can be subdivided into 6 to\n8 identical sub-samples, laboratories can work in parallel on\nidentical specimens, which will further facilitate the assessment of\ncomparative performance. To meet U.S. Food and Drug\nAdministration (FDA) regulations for use of non-licensed tests in\nlaboratories outside of CDC, the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of\n WHO continues to recommend use of its case definitions, based on\nclinical presentation, distinct chest X-rays, and history of possible\ncontact with SARS patients, to detect suspect and probable cases and\nmake management decisions. Dr.\nKlaus Stoehr, who directs the WHO's scientific investigation of SARS,\nsaid his agency had developed a specimen bank in Hong Kong that\nscientists could tap at no charge. ' Participants at Friday's meeting in\nBethesda urged development of a type of test that looks for viral\nproteins that might be able to [meet such needs].\n A diagnosis of probable SARS is now based on a checklist of symptoms,\nchest X-rays, and information about whether a person has been exposed\nto someone with the disease or has traveled to a region where SARS is\nwidespread. Altman]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org> During the development of diagnostic tests, such specimens are needed\nto assess how well a test will perform with real patients' specimens,\nas opposed to under the artificial conditions of a laboratory. Tests that are offered as a service by clinical laboratories or used\nfor research do not require FDA approval, so some test developers are\ndistributing tests without approval. Polymerase tests can theoretically produce results in 2 to\n6 hours, though in actual practice results may not be ready for a day\nor 2, especially if the samples have to be sent somewhere for testing. Source: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_06_02a/en/>\n\nUpdate 71 - Status of diagnostic tests, training course in China 2 Jun 2003\n Dr. Heymann of the WHO said some of the early SARS tests produced\n'many false negatives,' meaning that they [did not detect] the virus\n Source: New York Times, Tue 3 Jun 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/03/health/03DETE.html>\n\nRace to Develop New Generation of SARS Diagnostic Tests\n------------------------------------------------------- Abbott Laboratories, one\nof the largest companies in diagnostic testing, [is licensed] to sell\nthe Artus test in the United States, Canada, and other countries. A comprehensive bank of clinical specimens,\nincluding respiratory specimens and samples of blood, urine, and\nfaeces from SARS patients, has been established. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has\ndeveloped a test that detects antibodies to the SARS virus in blood.\n We ask in return that if\ncompanies develop a licensed test they donate or sell it at a low\nprice' to poor countries, Dr. Stoehr said. Virus shedding peaks\nin respiratory specimens and in stools at around 10 days after onset\nof clinical illness. CDC has approved the following consenting documents and additional\ninformational material for use in conjunction with the collection and\ntesting of specimens in state public health laboratories. The officials\nurged the companies to develop SARS tests and promised to work with\nthe companies. ' In return for the supply of these exclusive materials,\nrecipients of WHO support have agreed to offer test kits, once\navailable, at preferential prices to developing countries. Source: CDC SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/lab/eia/index.htm>\n\nCoronavirus Antibody Testing at State Public Health Laboratories 30 May 2003\n Work of the WHO\nlaboratory network has made it possible to support the training\ncourses with test materials and reagents.
