asymptomatic infection from Australian Broadcasting Company 31\nMay 2003\n<http://www.abc.net.au/science/news/scitech/SciTechRepublish_868748.htm>\nChina has found that some people infected with SARS do not show any\nsymptoms of the disease and are not infectious after their bodies develop\nantibodies to fight the disease, according to state media.\nThe findings, by Government scientists in Heyuan city in southern China's\nGuangdong province, add further mystery to Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (SARS), for which there is no known vaccine or cure. The China\nNews Service (CNS) reports that scientists have concluded that SARS can be\nasymptomatic, after studying people who had come in contact with Heyuan's\nfirst SARS case. Heyuan SARS experts checked [the case's] family members,\nhealth workers who treated him, the doctor in his village, and conducted\nblood tests on 5 of these people. CNS reports they found some of the 5\npeople have the SARS virus in their blood, but have not fallen ill and have\ndeveloped antibodies to fight the virus. The scientists believe people who\nhave developed antibodies for the SARS virus are not infectious. The\nreport could not immediately be confirmed.\n[B] Democratic Republic of the Congo from All Africa 30 May 2003\n<http://allafrica.com/stories/200305300538.html>\nSeveral persons suspected of being carriers of the SARS virus were put in\nquarantine last Sunday, 25 May 2003 at Kinshasa airport. The DR Congo's\nminister of health, L\u00e9onard Mashako Mamba, announced on Monday that all had\ncome from Hong Kong via South Africa. 2 Gambian citizens, a Congolese\nnational and a unspecified number of Hong Kong Chinese traveled in the same\nflight from the Far East to Johannesburg with passengers who showed the\nsymptoms of the disease, said Congolese health officials. The Congolese\nministry of health says the passengers were allowed to board the flight to\nKinshasa despite their request to the South African authorities, before the\nplane's departure, not to allow them to do so. The 2 Gambians and the\nCongolese were quarantined at Kinkole, to the east of Kinshasa, in a\nspecial clinic designed to host suspect SARS cases. worldwide (82): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203716", "date": "2003-04-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (82): ETIOLOGY\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon 28 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\nFurther Analysis of Variable Sites in Isolates of SARS Virus\n------------------------------------------------\nAs noted in my previous post [see: SARS - worldwide (68): etiology\n20030425.1010], one hot-spot for variation among SARS coronavirus\nisolates is position 5768 in the orf1ab gene product [the viral\npolymerase]. In that position a E [Glu] is found in isolates\nCUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, and BJ04. All 6 of these isolates\nare closely linked to mainland China. In contrast, the isolates\nlinked to the Metropole Hotel in Hong Kong (Urabani, Tor2, YKY, and\npossibly HKU-39849) all have a D [Asp] at that position.\nA review of [corresponding] sequences of [other virus species in the\nfamily _Coronaviridae_ ] indicates that this position is well\nconserved [with 4 strains of bovine coronavirus (LUN, ENT, Quebec,\nMebus)] and human coronavirus (229E), all having an E at that\nposition, like the mainland isolates [of the SARS coronavirus].\nHowever, 5 strains of murine hepatitis virus (A59, 2, ML-10, ML-11,\nPenn 97-1, JHM) all have a D at that position.\nThus, this position is well conserved within species, and the fact\nthat 2 sets of human isolates have distinct amino acids at this\nposition is likely to be significant and may explain the virulent\nnature of the isolates that established SARS in Hanoi, Toronto,\nSingapore, and possibly Hong Kong.\nThe position is also species-specific [in coronavirus isolates from]\npigs (Purdue, PUR-46-MAD, CV777) and chickens (Beaudette, LX4), all\nof which have a P [Pro] at that position.\nOf interest is a similar situation at position 244 in E2 [a putative\nglycoprotein]. This region is not well conserved in isolates other\nthan SARS, but of the 10 SARS isolates, the 6 mainland isolates have\na T [Thr], whereas the other 4 have an I [Ile], suggesting this is\nanother hot-spot.\nThe above data strongly suggest that the amino acids found at\nposition 5768 are not due to sequencing errors and that the position\nchange may have biological and clinical consequences.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[Dr. Niman has observed a regularity in amino acid substitution at\nposition 5768 in several isolates of SARS virus and in isolates of\nsome other species in the family _Coronaviridae_, which perhaps has\nsome biological significance. It is premature to conclude, however,\nthat this particular site (and the others discussed by Dr. Niman) has\nany direct relevance to the epidemiologic characteristics and\nvirulence of the SARS virus. ProMED-mail is not a suitable vehicle\nfor discussion of fine sequence analysis of this type, despite its\ninherent interest. Therefore, with regret this thread is now cut. -\nMod.CP]", "summary": "A review of [corresponding] sequences of [other virus species in the\nfamily _Coronaviridae_ ] indicates that this position is well\nconserved [with 4 strains of bovine coronavirus (LUN, ENT, Quebec,\nMebus)] and human coronavirus (229E), all having an E at that\nposition, like the mainland isolates [of the SARS coronavirus]. "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203713", "date": "2003-04-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (79): CLINICAL ASPECTS\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 29 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Lancet online [edited]\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journal/journal.isa>\n\nClinical presentations and outcome of severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome in children\nK L E Hon, C W Leung, W T F Cheng, P K S Chan, W C W Chu, Y W Kwan, A\nM Li, N C Fong, P C Ng, M C Chiu, C K Li, J S Tam, T F Fok\nHong Kong has been severely affected by severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS). Contact in households and health-care settings is\nthought to be important for transmission, putting children at\nparticular risk. Most data so far, however, have been for adults. We\nprospectively followed up the first 10 children with SARS managed\nduring the early phase of the epidemic in Hong Kong. All the children\nhad been in close contact with infected adults. Persistent fever,\ncough, progressive radiographic changes of chest, and lymphopenia\nwere noted in all patients. The children were treated with high-dose\nribavirin, oral prednisolone, or intravenous methylprednisolone, with\nno short-term adverse effects. 4 teenagers required oxygen therapy\nand 2 needed assisted ventilation. None of the younger children\nrequired oxygen supplementation. SARS seems to have a less aggressive\nclinical course in younger children than it does in adults and\nteenagers.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The full paper is available at:\n<http://image.thelancet.com/extras/03let4127web.pdf>\nThis short paper is a welcome addition to the growing body of\nknowledge on SARS. In looking at the age distributions of reported\nSARS cases where available, it is apparent that children appear to be\nunder-represented.\nIn the 25 Apr 2003 SARS bulletin produced by the Hong Kong Department\nof health (see SARS - worldwide (70): cases 20030425.1013 and data\navailable at\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/ap.htm>) 6 percent of reported cases were\nless than 15 years of age, and an additional 11 percent of reported\ncases were between 15 and 24 years of age. This observed lower\nincidence of SARS in younger age groups may very well indicate that\nthey exhibit milder clinical illness that is not being recognized as\nSARS. This issue awaits a definitive laboratory diagnostic testing\nprocess that will allow for an identification of infected individuals\nwho may not have clinical illness. At that time, a serosurvey of the\ngeneral population will allow for a cross-sectional look at the\nproportion of individuals with evidence of infection, by age group\nand history of clinical illness during the period of the SARS\noutbreak in the area.\nIn this article/letter, there is mention short-term ribavirin with\nsteroids as the treatment protocol. Readers are reminded that,\neffective yesterday (28 Apr 2003 - see SARS -worldwide (77): cases\n20030428.1048 ), Health Canada has withdrawn the use of ribavirin for\nthe routine treatment of SARS, and the drug will be available only\nfor use as part of clinical trials. 'After reviewing the existing\nanecdotal clinical experience with ribavirin, negative results from\nin vitro testing with ribavirin against the SARS-related coronavirus,\nand knowledge of reports of serious and unexpected adverse drug\nreactions, the working group reached a consensus that there is no\ndata to support the continued use of ribavirin outside of clinical\ntrials at this time.'\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update42.html>\n- Mod.MPP]", "summary": "After reviewing the existing\nanecdotal clinical experience with ribavirin, negative results from\nin vitro testing with ribavirin against the SARS-related coronavirus,\nand knowledge of reports of serious and unexpected adverse drug\nreactions, the working group reached a consensus that there is no\ndata to support the continued use of ribavirin outside of clinical\ntrials at this time.'\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update42.html>\n- Mod. A summary on use of\nexisting laboratory tests and their characteristics can be found at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/diagnostictests/en/>.\nDiagnostic samples should be suitable for viral culture, polymerase\nchain reaction (PCR), antigen detection, immuno-staining, and/or\nserological antibody assays. For research purposes, to enhance\nunderstanding of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) disease\nprocess, WHO recommends that clinicians collect and store sequential\nsamples from patients with SARS for testing when diagnostic tests\nbecome readily available. This is particularly important for the\nfirst case(s) recognized in countries that have not previously\nreported SARS. Data on clinical and contact history should be\ncorrelated with laboratory findings to better understand the shedding\npattern of the virus and the period of transmissibility.\nSummary of sampling possibilities:\n---------------------------------\nFor practical reasons, and based on evidence provided by WHO\nlaboratory network, upper respiratory specimens are most suitable for\nvirus detection (isolation and RNA detection). Sampling from multiple\nsites will increase detection rate.\n[Abstract of Table]\n(a)\nType of specimen: Nasopharyngeal\nMethod: Aspirate; specimen of choice for respiratory viruses\nShipment: Ship on ice (+4 degrees C); Sterile vial\nTiming: Any time in course of illness; Particularly useful during\ninitial phase of disease\nPotential use: Viral culture; PCR; EM\n(b)\nType of specimen: Nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal\nMethod: Swab: Use only sterile Dacron or rayon swab with plastic shaft\nShipment: Sterile vials with viral transport medium; Ship on ice (+4 degrees C)\nTiming: Any time in course of illness; Particularly useful during\ninitial phase of disease\nPotential use: Viral culture; PCR; EM\n(c)\nType of Specimen: Tracheal, Bronchalveolar lavage, pleural fluid\nMethod: Aspirate; pleural tap\nShipment: Centrifuge half: cell pellet fixed in formalin. Unspun\nfluid in sterile vial. Ship on ice; or fixed cells at RT, unfixed\ncells frozen.\nTiming: When clinically appropriate: intubated, severe lung disease,\nor pleural effusion; Both during initial phase and more advanced\ncourse of the disease\nPotential use: Standard cultures; Viral cultures PCR; EM; On stained\nor unstained slides: immunofluorescence, molecular biology\n(d)\nType of Specimen: Urine\nMethod: Clean catch, sterile container\nShipment: Centrifuge, resuspend sediment in 2-3 ml sterile transport\nmedium, tissue culture medium, or phosphate-buffered saline.\nTiming: Acute phase\nPotential Use: Antigen detection; PCR; Viral culture\n(e)\nType of Specimen: Stool\nMethod: 10-50 ml in a stool cup or urine container.\nShipment: Ship on ice\nTiming: Best sample at around day 10\nPotential Use: Viral culture; PCR; EM\n(f)\nType of Specimen: Conjunctiva\nMethod; Swab: Use only sterile Dacron or rayon swab with plastic shaft\nShipment: Sterile vials with viral transport medium; Ship on ice\nTiming: As soon as possible in course of illness\nPotential Use: Viral culture; PCR; EM\n(g)\nType of Specimen : Serum\nMethod: -\nShipment: >= 200 ml preferred; Ship on ice or frozen\nTiming: Convalescent; after 3-4 weeks\nPotential Use: Specific antibody detection (IgM, IgA, rising IgG titers)\n(h)\nType of Specimen: Whole blood\nMethod: -\nShipment: EDTA; Ship on ice\nTiming: Any time in illness\nPotential Use: -\n(i)\nType of Specimen: Blood\nMethod: -\nShipment: Standard blood culture bottle\nTiming: -\nPotential Use: Standard culture; PCR\n(j)\nType of Specimen: Tissue (biopsy , autopsy)\nMethod: Lung; Upper airway\nShipment: Sterile container with viral transport medium or saline.\nFresh frozen: -70 deg C\nTiming: -\nPotential Use: EM; immunofluorescence; molecular biology\n(k)\nType of Specimen: Tissue (biopsy, autopsy)\nMethod: Major organs\nShipment: Formalin fixed or paraffin embedded. Ship at room temperature\nTiming: -\nPotential use: EM\nSampling procedures for respiratory tract specimens\n---------------------------------------------------\na. Nasopharyngeal wash/aspirate\nThis is the specimen of choice for detection of respiratory viruses.\nHave the patient sit with head tilted slightly backward. Instill 1 -\n1.5 ml of non-bacteriostatic saline into one nostril. Flush a plastic\ncatheter or tubing with 2-3 ml of saline. Insert the tubing into the\nnostril parallel to the palate. Aspirate nasopharyngeal secretions.\nRepeat this procedure for the other nostril. Collect specimens in\nsterile vials.\nb. Nasopharyngeal swabs\nInsert swab into nostril parallel to the palate and leave in place\nfor a few seconds to absorb secretions. Swab both nostrils\nc. Oropharyngeal swabs\nSwab both posterior pharynx and tonsillar areas, avoiding tongue\nd. Lower respiratory tract\n[See above table abstract]\nBiosafety:\nBiosafety precautions for handling, processing and shipment of\nspecimens are detailed in Interim Laboratory Biosafety Guidelines for\nHandling and Processing Specimens Associated with Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome (SARS)\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/sarslabguide.htm>)\nPersonal protection equipment should be worn by the health care\nworker taking specimens from suspect or probable SARS patients:\ntight-fitting mask (high filtering efficiency: N, R, P 95/99/100, FFP\n2/3), goggles, gloves, and disposable gown. See: Hospital Infection\nControl Guidance for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n(SARS).(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/sarslabguide.htm>)\nTubes and vials containing body specimens should be properly sealed\nto avoid spillage, clearly labelled with a biohazard label, as well\nas with identity of sample and date of sampling.\nFor shipment, appropriate packaging for diagnostic specimens should\nbe used and adequately labelled. WHO biosafety guidelines for\nhandling of SARS specimens:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/biosafety2003_04_25/en/>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 29 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website, Tue 29 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/diagnostictests/en/>\n\nSARS: Laboratory Diagnostic Test Update as of 29 Apr 2003\n-----------------------------------------------\nResearchers in several countries are working towards developing fast\nand accurate laboratory diagnostic tests for the SARS coronavirus\n(SARS-CoV). However, until standardized reagents for detection of\nvirus and antibodies are available and methods have been adequately\nfield-tested, SARS diagnosis remains based on the clinical and\nepidemiological findings: acute febrile illness with respiratory\nsymptoms not attributed to another cause and a history of exposure to\na suspect or probable case of SARS or their respiratory secretions\nand other bodily fluids.\nThose requirements are reflected in the current WHO case definitions\nfor suspect or probable SARS\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/casedefinition/en/>). However, in\nseveral countries (Canada, France, Germany, Hong Kong SAR, Italy,\nJapan, the Netherlands, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United\nStates of America) samples from suspected and probable SARS cases are\nbeing tested for SARS-CoV.\nLaboratory test result criteria for confirming or rejecting the\ndiagnosis of SARS remain to be defined.\n1. Molecular tests (PCR)\nPolymerase chain reaction (PCR) can detect genetic material of the\nSARS-CoV in various specimens (blood, stool, respiratory secretions\nor body tissues [see: Sampling for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n(SARS) diagnostic tests at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/sampling/en/>]). Primers, which are the\nkey pieces for a PCR test, have been made publicly available by WHO\nnetwork laboratories on the WHO web site. A ready-to-use PCR test kit\ncontaining primers and positive and negative controls has been\ndeveloped. Testing of the kit by network members is expected to\nquickly yield the data needed to assess the tests performance, in\ncomparison with primers developed by other WHO network laboratories\nand in correlation with clinical and epidemiological data.\nPrincipally, existing PCR tests are very specific but lack\nsensitivity. This means that negative tests cannot rule out the\npresence of the SARS virus in patients. Furthermore, contamination of\nsamples in laboratories in the absence of laboratory quality control\ncan lead to false positive results.\nPositive PCR results, with the necessary quality control procedures\nin place are very specific and mean that there is genetic material\n(RNA) of the SARS-CoV in the sample. This does not mean that there is\nlive virus present, or that it is present in a quantity large enough\nto infect another person. (see: Recommendations for laboratories\ntesting for SARS-coronavirus at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/coronarecommendations/en/>)\nNegative PCR results do not exclude SARS. SARS-CoV PCR can be\nnegative for the following reasons:\n- The patient is not infected with the SARS coronavirus; the illness\nis due to another infectious agent (virus, bacterium, fungus) or a\nnon-infectious cause.\n- The test results are incorrect ('false-negative'). Current tests\nneed to be further developed to improve sensitivity.\n- Specimens were not collected at a time when the virus or its\ngenetic material was present. The virus and its genetic material may\nbe present for a brief period only, depending on the type of specimen\ntested.\n2. Antibody tests\nThese tests detect antibodies produced in response to the SARS\ncoronavirus infection. Different types of antibodies (IgM and IgG)\nappear and change in level during the course of infection. They can\nbe undetectable at the early stage of infection. IgG usually remains\ndetectable after resolution of the illness.\nThe following test formats are being developed, but are not\ncommercially available yet:\n- ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay): a test detecting a\nmixture of IgM and IgG antibodies in the serum of SARS patients\nyields positive results reliably at around day 21 after the onset of\nillness.\n- IFA (Immunofluorescence Assay): a test detecting IgM antibodies in\nserum of SARS patients yields positive results after about day 10 of\nillness. This test format is also used to test for IgG. This is a\nreliable test requiring the use of fixed SARS virus on an\nimmunofluorescence microscope.\nPositive antibody test results indicate a previous infection with\nSARS-CoV. Seroconversion from negative to positive or a 4-fold rise\nin antibody titre from acute to convalescent serum indicates recent\ninfection.\nNegative antibody test results: No detection of antibody after 21\ndays from onset of illness seems to indicate that no infection with\nSARS-CoV took place.\n3. Cell culture\nVirus in specimens (such as respiratory secretions, blood, or stool)\nfrom SARS patients can also be detected by inoculating cell cultures\nand growing the virus. Once isolated, the virus must be identified as\nthe SARS virus with further tests. Cell culture is a very demanding\ntest, but currently (with the exception of animal trials) is intended\nonly to show the existence of a live virus.\nPositive cell culture results indicate the presence of live SARS-CoV\nin the sample tested.\nNegative cell culture results do not exclude SARS (see negative PCR\ntest result).\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 29 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website, Tue 29 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/coronarecommendations/en/>\n\nRecommendations for Laboratories Testing by PCR for Presence of SARS\nCoronavirus RNA; As of 29 Apr 2003\n-------------------------------------------------\nWHO encourages each country to designate a reference laboratory for\ninvestigation and/or referral of specimens from possible SARS\npatients. National reference laboratories are welcome to send\nspecimens and isolates to the members of the WHO multicentre\ncollaborative network (<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/testing/en/>)\nafter appropriate contact and shipment arrangements have been made.\nLaboratories performing SARS-specific PCR tests should adopt quality\ncontrol procedures and/or identify a partner laboratory in their\ncountry or among the WHO collaborating research laboratories\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/testing/en/>) to cross-check their\npositive findings.\nLaboratories performing SARS-specific PCR tests should adopt strict\ncriteria for confirmation of positive results, especially in\nlow-prevalence areas, where the positive predictive value might be\nlower:\n- The PCR procedure should include appropriate controls in each run,\nwhich should yield the expected results. They should include:\n1 negative control for the extraction procedure, 1 water control for\nthe PCR run, 1 positive control for extraction and PCR run, and the\npatient sample spiked with a weak positive control to detect PCR\ninhibitory substances (inhibition control)\n- If a positive PCR result has been obtained, it should be confirmed\nby: repeating the PCR starting from the original sample, OR having\nthe same sample tested in a second laboratory.\nAmplifying a second genome region will increase test specificity.\nA test kit with positive and negative control has been made available\nthrough the WHO collaborative multicentre research project\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/project/en/>) on SARS diagnosis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "However, until standardized reagents for detection of\nvirus and antibodies are available and methods have been adequately\nfield-tested, SARS diagnosis remains based on the clinical and\nepidemiological findings: acute febrile illness with respiratory\nsymptoms not attributed to another cause and a history of exposure to\na suspect or probable case of SARS or their respiratory secretions\nand other bodily fluids. Personal protection equipment should be worn by the health care\nworker taking specimens from suspect or probable SARS patients:\ntight-fitting mask (high filtering efficiency: N, R, P 95/99/100, FFP\n2/3), goggles, gloves, and disposable gown. The committee\nsaid, however, that it is still discussing with other government\nbodies [how to deal with] reclassified persons. It refused to release\nthe number of people here that it now regards as having contracted\nSARS. The virus testing was conducted using a technique that is\nregarded by many experts as only a first step in coming up with a\nreliable test for the disease.\n'Even though these patients do not show signs of pneumonia, which the\nWorld Health Organization has set as the most important criterion in\ndiagnosis of the disease', a committee member said, 'we decided that\npersons exposed to the virus would be regarded as SARS-infected.'\nAnother member of the committee said the number of cases regarded as\nconfirmed would probably rise when more recently developed test kits,\nregarded as more reliable, arrive and are put into use.\nAt a separate meeting yesterday, the government changed its\nregulations under the quarantine law to force arriving passengers who\nhave symptoms into a 10-day quarantine. Earlier, officials said they\nwould ask the legislature to change the law to allow such forced\nquarantine on all persons suspected or confirmed as having the\ndisease.\nPrime Minister Goh Kun said military medical staff will be dispatched\nto 4 quarantine offices. In addition to an isolation unit to be set\nup on Youngjong island near Incheon International Airport, 2 more\nfacilities to isolate passengers who have symptoms of SARS would be\nestablished in areas near Gimhae airport and Jeju airport, he added.\nSeoul will also allocate an additional 6 billion won (USD 5 million)\nto fight the disease.\nOne more SARS suspect was reported yesterday, bringing the total to\n13 in Korea. A woman in her 20s, who traveled to Beijing recently,\ndeveloped symptoms consistent with the disease and checked into a\nhospital.\n[Byline: Chung Cheol-geun]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[It is not entirely clear which of the available laboratory tests\n(antigen detection or RT-PCR amplification of viral RNA sequences) is\nreferred to in this report. In the case of RT-PCR based molecular\ntests, the WHO recommends the following: Laboratories performing\nSARS-specific PCR tests should adopt strict criteria for confirmation\nof positive results, especially in low-prevalence areas, where the\npositive predictive value might be lower.\nThe RT-PCR procedure should include appropriate negative and positive\ncontrols in each run, which should yield the expected results:\n(a) a negative control for the extraction procedure and a water\ncontrol for the PCR run;\n(b) a positive control for extraction and PCR;\n(c) an inhibition control -- the patient sample spiked with a weak\npositive control to detect PCR inhibitory substances.\nIf a positive PCR result has been obtained, it should be confirmed by:\n(a) Repeating the PCR starting from the original sample; or\n(b) Having the same sample tested in a second laboratory.\nAmplifying a second genome region could further increase test specificity.\nHowever, until those tests have been adequately field-tested and\nshown to be reliable, SARS diagnosis must depend on the clinical\nfindings of an atypical pneumonia not attributable to another cause\nand a history of exposure to a suspect or probable case of SARS or\ntheir respiratory secretions and other bodily fluids. A\ncolleague of mine in Singapore, who has had the SARS illness and was\ndiagnosed with the SARS coronavirus by RT-PCR culture and electron\nmicroscopy, has informed me that SARS coronavirus RNA has continued\nto be detected in stool samples by RT-PCR, although it has not yet\nbeen successfully grown in culture. This continued for sometime after\nthe quarantine period of 10-14 [days?] after recovery from illness\n(up to 3 weeks post-recovery).\nIf such is the case for most -- or even some -- of the recovered SARS\npatients, perhaps this may account for the ongoing transmission we\nare seeing in places like Singapore in household and workplace\ncontacts of clinically recovered SARS patients. Perhaps the\nlaboratories of the WHO collaborating network should ask for\nconvalescent stool samples as well as sera to monitor and\ncharacterise this phenomenon.\n--\nDr. Julian W. Tang MA PhD MRCP\nClinical Academic Training Fellow/ Lecturer in Virology\nDepartment of Virology\nWindeyer Building\nUniversity College London Hospitals\nLondon W1T 4JF, UK\n<jwtang49@hotmail.com>\n[The current RT-PCR tests utilize primers that amplify short\nsequences of the polymerase gene of the putative SARS coronavirus.\nThese tests may do no more than detect the presence of defective\nvirus in gut contents. The replication of many RNA viruses is\naccompanied by the progressive accumulation of defective interfering\nparticles (the equivalent of deletion mutants), which are thought to\nbe a determining factor in the self-limiting characteristics of some\nacute virus infections. The failure to isolate infectious virus from\nthe patient after recovery suggests that transmission of SARS via gut\ncontents post-recovery does not represent substantial risk.\nNonetheless, it is not possible to discount this route of\ntransmission of SARS virus without knowledge of the relative\nsensitivity of the cell culture employed, and Dr. Julian Tang has\ndrawn attention to an important question. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A\ncolleague of mine in Singapore, who has had the SARS illness and was\ndiagnosed with the SARS coronavirus by RT-PCR culture and electron\nmicroscopy, has informed me that SARS coronavirus RNA has continued\nto be detected in stool samples by RT-PCR, although it has not yet\nbeen successfully grown in culture. 2427\nNotes:\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n1. A decrease in the number of cumulative cases and discrepancies in\nthe difference between cumulative number of cases of the last and the\ncurrent WHO update are attributed to the discarding of cases.\n2. Includes cases who are 'discharged' or 'recovered' as reported by\nthe national public health authorities.\n3. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in\nwhich local chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas\nare provided on the list of Affected Areas.\n4. The number of new cases reported from China includes reports\nreceived on 28 and 29 April 2003. The report of 28 April was not\nincluded in yesterday's update due to difficulties with information\ntechnology.\n5. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] The list of affected areas can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_29/en/> and is unchanged\nsince yesterday's report.\n[C] Update 42 - Travel advice for Toronto, situation in China 29 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_29/en/>\nWHO Director-General Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland announced this evening\nthat the travel advisory for Toronto will be lifted, effective\ntomorrow. Travel advisories for Beijing, Hong Kong SAR, and\nGuangdong and Shanxi provinces, China, remain in effect. Travel\nadvisories are issued following consideration of several factors,\nincluding the magnitude of probable SARS cases, the last dates of\ncases of community transmission, and the last dates of export of\ncases.\nDr Brundtland cited 3 changes in Toronto over the last week. The\nmagnitude of probable SARS cases has decreased. 20 days have passed\nsince the last cases of community transmission occurred. No new\nconfirmed exportation of cases has occurred. WHO has also been\nassured by Canadian authorities that proactive screening measures at\nairports will be implemented, as recommended by WHO.\nThere is no change in Toronto's status as an 'affected area.' Viet\nNam, which is the first country to have contained its SARS outbreak,\nwas removed from the list of affected areas yesterday. SARS is the\nfirst major new infectious disease of the 21st century and is taking\nfull advantage of the opportunities for rapid international spread\nafforded by a closely interconnected and highly mobile society. The\npurpose of travel advisories is to reduce opportunities for further\ninternational spread of what is a new, severe, and poorly understood\ninfectious disease.\nTravel advisories are reviewed daily. Advice is issued on the basis\nof a set of epidemiological criteria. The risk to international\npublic health, which is the principal concern for WHO, occurs when\nthe magnitude and dynamics of an outbreak allow an infected person to\nslip past control measures and undertake international travel,\npossibly seeding an outbreak elsewhere.\nSituation in China\nA total of 202 new probable SARS cases were reported across China\ntoday, bringing the total number of cases in the country to 3303. 9\ndeaths were also reported today.\nProbable SARS cases have now been reported from 21 of China's 31\nprovinces. An additional 4 provinces have reported suspected cases.\nBeijing continues to report a high number of SARS cases, with 152 new\nprobable cases and 9 deaths reported today. China's capital city now\nhas a cumulative total of 1347 probable cases and 59 deaths.\nChina's largest number of cumulative cases remains concentrated in\nGuangdong Province, where the SARS outbreak began in mid-November\n[2002]. Only 10 percent of these cases are current. As 1201 patients\nhave been discharged and 51 have died, there are less than 150 SARS\ncases remaining in Guangdong's health care system.\nIn contrast, the rapidly growing number of new cases in Beijing\nimposes a heavy burden on the health care system and particularly its\nhospital capacity. In Beijing, 86 percent of cases (1198 cases) are\ncurrent.\nThe situation in western China continues to be of concern. New\nprobable cases in Shanxi (23) and Inner Mongolia (7) increase the\ncumulative totals to 266 and 120, respectively.\nWHO is working with local health authorities in Beijing to review and\nimprove the data needed to better monitor the SARS situation and\nassess the success of current control strategies. The WHO team of\nexperts also visited hospitals which will soon be opened as SARS\nreferral hospitals to assess their level of preparedness.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 5462 probable cases with 353\ndeaths have been reported from 27 countries. This represents an\nincrease of 226 new cases and 24 deaths when compared with yesterday.\nOf the 226 new cases, 202 were reported today from China, of which\n152 occurred in Beijing. Due to difficulties of information\ntechnology, figures received from Chinese authorities yesterday were\nnot included in yesterday's cumulative update. The 24 deaths\noccurred in Canada (2), China (9), Hong Kong SAR (12), and Singapore\n(1).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 29 Apr 2003\nFrom: Jack Soo One is the\n37-year-old brother of the probable SARS case (the 41-year-old man)\nannounced on 26 Apr 2003. The other new case is a 43-year-old man\nwho worked as a taxi driver. He developed a fever on Friday, 11 Apr\n2003. On the morning of 19 Apr 2003, he complained of sudden onset of\nbreathlessness and collapsed at home. He was pronounced dead on 19\nApr 2003. A post mortem was conducted on 20 Apr 2003. Microscopic\nexamination of the tissues showed lung damage from a possible\ninfection. Tissues taken for further investigations have been\nreported as being positive for coronavirus. Investigations are\nunderway to determine the source of his infection, and contact\ntracing is in progress.\nSituation Update of Pasir Panjang Wholesale Market (PPWM)\nAs of today, 2 suspect cases (1 visitor and 1 friend) related to the\nPPWM has been discharged. There are currently 12 suspect cases\nadmitted in relation to PPWM. They consist of 1 worker, 9 visitors to\nthe market, and 2 family and friend contacts.\nSuspect Patients\nThere were 17 patients who were admitted as new suspect cases today.\nOf these, 1 had been on home quarantine. 2 were persons with fever\nwho had visited the PPWM during the period of 5 -19 Apr 2003. 3 were\npersons with fever who had travelled overseas. For healthcare\nworkers, those detected as having high or prolonged fever by their\nhospitals' staff temperature monitoring system are admitted to [Tan\nTock Seng Hospital] TTSH for observation as suspect cases. 6 such\nhealthcare workers were admitted today. The remaining 5 patients were\npersons with fever admitted for further investigations.\nQuarantine Figures*\nNo. discharged patients under home quarantine**: 419\nPPWC Quarantine: 1917\nContacts under home quarantine: 665\nTotal under home quarantine orders: 3001\n*Quarantine cases refer to those who are required to stay at home for\nprecautionary reasons, as they may have had contact with a SARS\npatient. This brings a\ntotal number of probable, suspect, and pending cases to 304, and 74\nof them were discharged, while the remaining 230 cases are still\nbeing cared for in negative pressure rooms.\nAs of 26 Apr 2003, a total of 4094 close contacts of probable SARS\ncases had been assigned to home quarantine; 1808 of them have\ncompleted their quarantines.\nControl Measures\nMore vigorous measures have been performed in response to the\nincreasing number of probable SARS cases as below.\nThe SARS referral center was established and [began operating]\nfunctionally 2 days ago. 18 suspect and 7 probable SARS cases of\nHoping Hospital and 2 suspect cases from some medical center had been\ntransferred to qualified hospitals equipped with negative pressure\nwards. All the negative pressure wards must report to the referral\ncenter twice per day.\nAll incoming passengers from SARS foci areas arriving in Taiwan must\ncomply a compulsory 10-day quarantine. Foreigners are required to\ncomplete their 10-day quarantine ONLY at the international airport\nhotel; native passengers can complete their 10-day quarantine either\nat the international airport hotel or wearing a mask and reporting\nwithin 24 hours to a health authority or a chief of township where\nlisted as residence [?] on the SARS survey form upon arrival to\nprevent imported cases.\nTaiwan SARS Advisory Committee decided to close JenChi Hospital for\n14 days to control nosocomial infection of SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[6]\nDate: 29 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n[A] Update\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/sars_numbers.html>\nAs of 29 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 346 probable\nor suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nCanada. Chlamydia-like and coronavirus-like agents found in dead\ncases of atypical pneumonia by electron microscopy. National Medical\nJournal of China 2003; 83 (8): 632-6.\n*Institute of viral Disease Control and Prevention, China CDC, Beijing\n100052,China. (corresponding author: HONG Tao <hungt@public3.bta.net.cn>)\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective: To explore the causative agents of the atypical pneumonia (also\nknown as SARS) observed recently in some regions of our country.\nMethods: Organ samples of 7 fatal cases of SARS were collected from\nGuangdong, ShanXi, Sichuan Provinces and Beijing for electron microscopic\nexamination. The 293 cell line was inoculated with materials derived from\nthe lungs to isolate causative agent(s). The agents in the organs and cell\ncultures were revealed by immunoassay.\nResults: Both chlamydia-like and coronavirus-like particles were found in\nelectron micrographs. Inclusion bodies containing elementary bodies,\nreticulate antibodies, and intermediate bodies of a chlamydia-like agent\nwere visualized in multiple organs from the 7 dead cases, including lungs\n(7 cases), spleen (2 cases), liver (2 cases), kidney (3 cases), and lymph\nnodes (1 case), by ultrathin section electron microscopy. In some sections,\ncoronavirus-like particles were seen concurrently. A coronavirus RNA\npolymerase segment (440 bp) was amplified from the lung tissues of 2 cases\nof SARS. After inoculation with materials from the lung samples, the 293\ncell cultures were also found to have chlamydia-like particles. Since the\nchlamydia-like agents visualized in both organs and cell cultures did not\nreact with genus-specific antibodies against chlamydia or monoclonal\nantibodies against _Chlamydia pneumoniae_ and _C. psittaci_, the results\nmight well be suggestive of a novel chlamydia-like agent.\n--\nJack Soo\n<jack.soo@kyip.net>\n[The detection of a chlamydia-like agent in all 7 cases and a\ncoronavirus-like agent in 2 cases may reflect merely the relative\nsensitivities of the detection methods employed rather than differential\npresence of the 2 organisms. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Inclusion bodies containing elementary bodies,\nreticulate antibodies, and intermediate bodies of a chlamydia-like agent\nwere visualized in multiple organs from the 7 dead cases, including lungs\n(7 cases), spleen (2 cases), liver (2 cases), kidney (3 cases), and lymph\nnodes (1 case), by ultrathin section electron microscopy. Since the\nchlamydia-like agents visualized in both organs and cell cultures did not\nreact with genus-specific antibodies against chlamydia or monoclonal\nantibodies against _Chlamydia pneumoniae_ and _C. psittaci_, the results\nmight well be suggestive of a novel chlamydia-like agent.\n A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n [The detection of a chlamydia-like agent in all 7 cases and a\ncoronavirus-like agent in 2 cases may reflect merely the relative\nsensitivities of the detection methods employed rather than differential\npresence of the 2 organisms. - Mod. China now\naccounts for more probable cases than the rest of the world combined.\nBeijing reported the highest number of new cases (101) and deaths\n(9), for a cumulative total of 1440 probable cases and 75 deaths. Of\nthese new cases, 31 were previously reported as suspect cases while\n70 were reported for the first time.\n9 hospitals in the Chinese capital now deal exclusively with SARS\npatients. Just outside Beijing, a 1000-bed complex has been built to\naccommodate incoming patients. Health authorities have expressed\nconcern that the SARS outbreak could overwhelm Beijing's already\ncrowded hospitals.\nXiong Ke Chest Hospital will open a new wing with 100 more beds for\nSARS patients tomorrow, hospital officials told a WHO expert during a\nvisit to the hospital today. With 235 beds all occupied by SARS\npatients, the hospital already has the largest number of SARS\npatients in the country.\nDr James Maguire, from the WHO team of experts, said that despite\nextremely difficult working conditions, hospital staff had risen to\nthe occasion. 'Their esprit de corps is excellent. They are taking\ngreat pride in what they are doing and working very hard,' he said,\nadding that some staff work 45 days without seeing their families.\nThe rigorous infection control procedures included heavy and hot\nprotective clothing.\nDr Maguire, an epidemiologist with the US Centers for Disease Control\nand Prevention in Atlanta, Georgia, said there was a need for more\nspecialized equipment such as masks, gloves, ventilatory equipment,\nlayer protective gear, and ambulances to transport patients between\nhospitals. WHO staff are aware that other hospitals in the city may\nneed more or better supplies.\nThe disease continued to make its mark elsewhere in the country.\nJiangsu Province, which borders Shanghai, reported its first case\ntoday. More cases were reported in western China, with 34 more\nprobable cases from Shanxi and 7 more from Inner Mongolia, giving a\ntotal of 299 and 127 probable cases respectively. One fifth of the\ncases (65) in Shanxi Province are among health workers.\nHebei also continued to report more cases, with 9 more probable\ncases, giving a total of 48. Tianjin reported 5 more probable cases\nfor a total of 49 cases, while Guangdong reported 6, for a total of\n1405.\nUpdate on countries and cases\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 5663 probable cases with 372\ndeaths have been reported from 26 countries. This represents an\nincrease of 211 new cases and 19 deaths when compared with yesterday.\nThe new deaths were reported in China (11), Hong Kong SAR (7), and\nChina, Taiwan (1). This was the first death in Taiwan, where the\nnumber of probable SARS cases has more than doubled, from 37 to 78,\nover the past week. China, Macao SAR reported its first probable case\ntoday.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 30 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health 30 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 30 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 30 Apr 2003, there are an additional 17 patients confirmed\nto have atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals\nearlier. The date of onset of the most recent probable\ncase with a non-health care, non-household contact, non-travel\nrelated exposure was 14 Apr 2003. - Mod.MPP]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[6]\nDate: 30 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website\nThe most recent reports available on the number of probable and\nsuspected cases by state can be found at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm> and are data reported to\nthe WHO on 28 Apr 2003, unchanged from yesterday's posting.\nIn today's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report dispatch, updated\nguidelines for reporting of cases with information on laboratory\ndiagnostics were given and can be accessed at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm52d429a1.htm>\nApril 29, 2003 / 52(Dispatch);1-3\nUpdated Interim Surveillance Case Definition for Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome (SARS) --- United States, April 29, 2003\nCDC's interim surveillance case definition for severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS) has been updated to include laboratory\ncriteria for evidence of infection with the SARS-associated\ncoronavirus (SARS-CoV) [see Figure and Box at website link provided\nabove]. In addition, clinical criteria have been revised to reflect\nthe possible spectrum of respiratory illness associated with\nSARS-CoV. Epidemiologic criteria have been retained. The majority of\nU.S. cases of SARS continue to be associated with travel*, with only\nlimited secondary spread to household members or health-care\nproviders (1).\nSARS has been associated etiologically with a novel coronavirus,\nSARS-CoV (2,3). Evidence of SARS-CoV infection has been identified in\npatients with SARS in several countries, including the United States.\nSeveral new laboratory tests can be used to detect SARS-CoV.\nSerologic testing for coronavirus antibody can be performed by using\nindirect fluorescent antibody or enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays\nthat are specific for antibody produced after infection. Although\nsome patients have detectable coronavirus antibody during the acute\nphase (i.e., within 14 days of illness onset), definitive\ninterpretation of negative coronavirus antibody tests is possible\nonly for specimens obtained >21 days after onset of symptoms. A\nreverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test\nspecific for viral RNA has been positive within the first 10 days\nafter onset of fever in specimens from some SARS patients, but the\nduration of detectable viremia or viral shedding is unknown. RT-PCR\ntesting can detect SARS-CoV in clinical specimens, including serum,\nstool, and nasal secretions. Finally, viral culture and isolation\nhave both been used to detect SARS-CoV. Absence of SARS-CoV antibody\nin serum obtained <21 days after illness onset, a negative PCR test,\nor a negative viral culture does not exclude coronavirus infection.\nReported U.S. cases of SARS still will be classified as suspect or\nprobable; however, these cases can be further classified as\nlaboratory-confirmed or -negative if laboratory data are available\nand complete, or as laboratory-indeterminate if specimens are not\navailable or testing is incomplete. Obtaining convalescent serum\nsamples to make a final determination about infection with SARS-CoV\nis critical.\nNo instances of SARS-CoV infection have been detected in persons who\nare asymptomatic. However, data are insufficient to exclude the\npossibility of asymptomatic infection with SARS-CoV and the\npossibility that such persons can transmit the virus. Investigations\nof close contacts and health-care workers exposed to SARS patients\nmight provide information about the occurrence of asymptomatic\ninfected persons. Similarly, the clinical manifestations of SARS\nmight extend beyond respiratory illness. As more is learned about\nSARS-CoV infection, clinical and laboratory criteria will provide a\nframework for classifying the full spectrum of infection [see Figure\nat website link provided above -- the figure divides cases by\nclinical and laboratory criteria -- clinical criteria being mild\nrespiratory illness/asymptomatic, moderate respiratory illness\n(suspected case)/, and severe respiratory illness (probable case);\nthe possible laboratory criteria are laboratory confirmed/\nundetermined/ negative - Mod.MPP].\nThis surveillance case definition should be used for reporting and\nclassification purposes only. It should not be used for clinical\nmanagement or as the only criterion for identifying or testing\npatients who might have SARS or for instituting infection-control\nprecautions (4,5). This definition will be updated as new data become\navailable or if changes in the epidemiology of SARS occur in the\nUnited States.\nReferences\n1. CDC. Update: Severe acute respiratory syndrome --- United States,\n2003. MMWR 2003;52:357--60.\n2. Ksiazek TG, Erdman D, Goldsmith C, et al. A novel coronavirus\nassociated with severe acute respiratory syndrome. N Engl J Med.\nAvailable at <http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030781v3.pdf>.\n3. Drosten C, Gunther S, Preiser W, et al. Identification of a novel\ncoronavirus in patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome. N\nEngl J Med. Available at\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030747v2.pdf>.\n4. CDC. Updated interim domestic guidelines for triage and\ndisposition of patients who may have severe acute respiratory\ndistress syndrome (SARS). Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/triage_interim_guidance.htm>.\nCDC. Interim guidance on infection control precautions for patients\nwith suspected severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and close\ncontacts in households. Available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/ic-closecontacts.htm>.\n* In this updated case definition, Taiwan has been added to the areas\nwith documented or suspected community transmission of SARS; Hanoi,\nVietnam is now an area with recently documented or suspected\ncommunity transmission of SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[7]\nDate: 30 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs\n[A] India from the Atlanta Journal Constitution\n<http://www.ajc.com/health/content/shared/health/ap/ap_story.html/Health/AP.V0141.AP-India-SARS-Viru.html>\nThe number of SARS cases in India doubled to 19 on Wednesday as 9\nstaff members of a hospital that treated an infected family came down\nwith the flu-like disease and another man tested positive after\nvisiting Singapore.\nThe 9 staff were among 22, including 3 doctors, of the Siddharth\nHospital in the western Indian city of Pune who quarantined\nthemselves in the hospital after it was shut down last week following\ntreatment of 4 infected family members. "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203699", "date": "2003-04-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (72): TREATMENT\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2003\nFrom: David Pulleyblank <david.pulleyblank@utoronto.ca>\n\nA comment on p38 MAP-kinase inhibitors and treatment of SARS\n------------------------------------------------------------\nTwo publications have described the effect of the p38 MAP-kinase\n(mitogen-activated protein kinase) inhibitor SB203580 on mouse hepatitis\nvirus strain 3 (MHV)(McGilvray ID, et al. J Biol Chem 1998; 273(48):\n32222-9 and Banerjee S, et al. J Virol 2002; 76(12): 5937-48). In the\nlatter paper the authors state that MHV activation of the p38 MAP-kinase\npathway results in phosphorylation of the translation initiation factor\neIF4E, which in turn contributes to a high level production of virus.\nSB203580 reduced MHV particle production by a factor of 3.\nAlthough there is as yet no direct evidence to suggest that the SARS\ncoronavirus uses the p38 MAP-kinase pathway, phosphorylation of eIF4E is\nlikely to prove a conserved coronaviral mechanism for directing cellular\nprotein synthesis towards production of viral particles. SB203580 also has\npotent anti-inflammatory activity: (see: Ermert M, et al.\nCyclooxygenase-2-dependent and thromboxane-dependent vascular and bronchial\nresponses are regulated via p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase in control\nand endotoxin-primed rat lungs. Lab Invest 2003; 83(3): 333-47).\nThese findings suggest p38 MAP-kinase may prove a useful target for the\ncontrol of SARS symptoms and possibly also to limit replication of the\nvirus. Perhaps p38 MAP-kinase inhibitors could have application in in the\ntreatment of SARS? I gather that 3 such compounds (SB281832, BiRB0797, and\nRo320-1195) have gone through phase II clinical trials for treatment of\nasthma and/or rheumatoid arthritis and that pharmacokinetics and potential\ntoxicities of these compounds must therefore have been characterized.\n--\nDavid E Pulleyblank\nProfessor of Biochemistry\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n<david.pulleyblank@utoronto.ca>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2003\nFrom: David Pulleyblank <david.pulleyblank@utoronto.ca>\n\nUse of salicylate in treatment of SARS - possible contraindication\n------------------------------------------------------------------\nIn a follow-up to my earlier posting [see part 1 above] concerning the\npossible utility of p38 MAP-kinase inhibitors in the treatment of SARS, I\nhave located a number of references [see: (1) and (2) below] where p38\nMAP-kinase has been reported to be ACTIVATED by salicylates.\nAssuming that, as in the case of mouse hepatitis coronavirus (MHV),\nactivation of p38 MAP-kinase contributes to SARS virus replication, these\nresults suggest that salicylates should NOT be given to SARS patients. In\nview of the antipyretic effects of ASA (acetylsalicylic acid, aspirin) this\ndrug is likely to be in widespread use among early-stage SARS patients. It\ncould be a factor contributing to the severity of the syndrome. For this\nreason I believe it imperative that ASA use among SARS patients be assessed\nas rapidly as possible in order to determine whether it has contributed to\nthe severity of individual cases.\nReferences:\n(1) Ordan O, et al. Stress-responsive JNK mitogen-activated protein kinase\nmediates aspirin-induced suppression of B16 melanoma cellular\nproliferation. Br J Pharmacol 2003; 138: 1156-62 (and references cited\ntherein).\n(2) Liao C-L, et al. Salicylates inhibit flavivirus replication\nindependently of blocking nuclear factor kappa B activation. J Virol 2001;\n75 (17): 7828-39.\n--\nDavid E Pulleyblank\nProfessor of Biochemistry\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n<david.pulleyblank@utoronto.ca>\n[Normally ProMED-mail does not post reports on development of drugs,\nvaccines, or treatment protocols, but the possible contraindication to the\nuse of ASA in treatment of SARS patients identified by Professor\nPulleyblank deserves wider consideration. - Mod.CP\nOf course these ideas are highly speculative but they may represent one\nrational place to start looking for antiviral agents active against the\nSARS coronavirus. Most currently used antiviral agents exploit pathways\nthat are distinct from those in the uninfected host, for example reverse\ntranscriptase in HIV or thymidine kinase in herpesviruses. The possible\nlink of the MAP-kinase pathway with aspirin is intriguing -- salicylates\nare contraindicated in influenza infection because their use has been\nlinked to Reyes syndrome. - Mod.LM]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n In a follow-up to my earlier posting [see part 1 above] concerning the\npossible utility of p38 MAP-kinase inhibitors in the treatment of SARS, I\nhave located a number of references [see: (1) and (2) below] where p38\nMAP-kinase has been reported to be ACTIVATED by salicylates.\n Professor of Biochemistry\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n<david.pulleyblank@utoronto.ca>\n***** Professor of Biochemistry\nUniversity of Toronto\nCanada\n<david.pulleyblank@utoronto.ca>\n Although there is as yet no direct evidence to suggest that the SARS\ncoronavirus uses the p38 MAP-kinase pathway, phosphorylation of eIF4E is\nlikely to prove a conserved coronaviral mechanism for directing cellular\nprotein synthesis towards production of viral particles. Since the last\nupdate, VietNam has been removed from the list [see [2] below].\n\n[C] Viet Nam removed from list of affected countries, more than 5000\nprobable cases worldwide 28 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_28/en/> [edited]\n\nViet Nam contains SARS\nWHO has today removed Viet Nam from the list of affected areas,\nmaking it the first country to successfully contain its SARS\noutbreak. The change in Viet Nam's status follows 20 consecutive days\n(the duration of 2 incubation periods) since the last new case was\ndetected. 'It's a big day for all of us in Viet Nam and also\nthroughout the world,' said Pascale Brudon, the WHO representative in\nHanoi. 'WHO congratulates Viet Nam for being the first country to\nsucceed in containing the SARS epidemic.'\n\nThe Vietnamese government first made the announcement this morning,\nbut added that the country needs to remain vigilant. The health\nministry affirmed its determination to work with WHO to guard against\nthe importation of the virus.\n\nWHO believes Viet Nam should still maintain a high level of alert\nsince even a single new case of SARS could spark another outbreak.\nLast week, the Vietnamese health ministry asked the Prime Minister to\nauthorize the closing of the country's land borders with China. Viet\nNam has currently heightened its border surveillance with China, but\nhas stopped short of closing the border.\n\nMore than 5000 cases worldwide\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 5050 probable SARS cases with 321\ndeaths have been reported from 26 countries. This represents an\nincrease of 214 cases and 28 deaths when compared with the last\nreport, issued on Saturday [26 Apr 2003]. The new deaths were\nreported from China (9), Hong Kong SAR (17), and Singapore (2).\n\nDue to time differences, today's figures include cases and deaths\nfrom China for Sunday [27 Apr 2003], but not for today.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 28 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO press release 28 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/pr_sars/en/>\n\n\nViet Nam SARS-Free\n-----------------\n28 Apr 2003 -- The World Health Organization (WHO) is today removing\nViet Nam from the list of countries with local transmission of Severe\nAcute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).\n\nThis comes after careful monitoring of the country's current\nsituation, in which there have been no new reported cases of SARS\nsince 8 Apr 2003 and no cases of spread to other countries. 'Viet Nam\nhas stopped the outbreak within its borders,' says Dr Pascale Brudon,\nWHO Representative to Viet Nam.\n\nViet Nam becomes the first country to be removed from the list of\ncountries with local transmission of SARS. The status change for Viet\nNam is especially significant because it was one of 4 countries\ninitially identified by the WHO on 15 Mar 2003 as having local\ntransmission of SARS. Viet Nam reported a total of 63 SARS cases and\n5 deaths prior to 8 Apr 2003.\n\nThe absence of any new cases for a continuous 20-day (as of 28 Apr\n2003) period is an encouraging indicator that appropriate detection\nand protection measures, as recommended by the WHO, are able to\ncontain outbreaks and prevent their further spread. Viet Nam is one\nof several countries affected by local transmission of SARS that have\nconscientiously implemented detection and protection measures\nincluding:\n\n-prompt identification of persons with SARS, their movements and contacts;\n-effective isolation of SARS patients in hospitals;\n-appropriate protection of medical staff treating these patients;\n-comprehensive identification and isolation of suspected SARS cases;\n-exit screening of international travelers;\n-timely and accurate reporting and sharing of information with other\nauthorities and/or governments.\n\n'Viet Nam has effectively worked in partnership with other\ngovernments, WHO, and WHO's partners to stop its outbreak of SARS,'\nsays David Heymann, the Executive Director of the WHO's Communicable\nDiseases Cluster, adding, 'we are pleased that other countries in the\nregion with local transmission of SARS are also following appropriate\ndetection and protection measures, and cooperating with each other to\ndo so.'\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 28 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 28 Apr 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1PM 28 Apr 2003, there are an additional 14 patients confirmed\nto have atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals\nearlier. They include 3 healthcare workers (2 from Tuen Mun Hospital\nand one from Princess Margaret Hospital). The remaining 11 are other\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n\nA total of 710 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and\nhave been discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 42 were\ndischarged today. There are also 103 recovering patients who are in\nconvalescence and preparation for discharge. 93 patients are\nreceiving treatment in intensive care unit.\n\n5 male patients died in Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital (AHNH),\nPrincess Margaret Hospital (PMH), Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH), and Tai Po\nHospital (TPH). This brought to 138 the total number of deaths\nrelating to atypical pneumonia. The deceased are aged from 43 to 82,\nand 3 of them have a history of chronic disease. There were\nno new probable cases reported today.\n\nThere was one SARS death today: a 77-year-old man who had accompanied\nhis wife to the [Singapore General Hospital] SGH Radiology Centre on\n1 Apr 2003. He became unwell on 9 Apr 2003. At the Radiology Centre\nhe had contact with the index case [?] of the SGH Ward 57/58 cluster.\n\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market was closed on 20 Apr 2003 for a period\nof 10 days. It has been decided that the closure of PPWM will be\nextended for another 5 days till Sunday 4 May 2003. During this\nperiod, nurses will visit those on home quarantine orders to check\nthat they and their family members have no fever or other symptoms.\nThis is an extra precaution to ensure that all those involved are\nwell when the quarantine is lifted. This cautious approach is\nnecessary because of the large number of people involved. There are\ncurrently 12 suspect cases admitted in relation to PPWM. They consist\nof 1 worker, 8 visitors to the market, and 2 family members and\nfriends. A total of 1917 persons who had frequented the Market\nbetween 5 and 19 Apr 2003 were identified as possible contacts, and\nthey comprised 964 tenants and stall holders, 616 employees and\nworkers, and 337 regular customers.\n\nSummary of SARS cases\n\nA summary of the SARS cases to date:\n\nDischarged: 137\nHospitalised: 39 (including 15 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 22 + 1 (pending further post mortem test results)\nProbable Cases: 198\n\nSuspect Cases: 123 (including 9 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine: 2807\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 28 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n\n[A] Latest Canadian Numbers on SARS 28 Apr 2003\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update42.html>\n\nAs of 28 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 344 probable\nor suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nCanada. There have been 21 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission\nhas been limited to specific transmission settings such as\nhouseholds, hospitals, and specific community settings.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 142 probable and 122 suspect cases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable and 63 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 6 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\n\nTotal no. of probables discharged: 75\nTotal no. of probables recovering at home: 2\nTotal no. of suspects discharged: 85\nTotal no. of suspects recovering at home: 70\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 28 Apr 2003.\n\nHealth Canada Rescinds Routine Access to Ribavirin\nHealth Canada, through its Special Access Programme, will no longer\nprovide routine access to ribavirin for the treatment of SARS. This\ndecision stems from a recommendation by a working group advising\nHealth Canada, comprised of health experts and clinicians from across\nCanada and representatives from the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention in the United States. After reviewing the existing\nanecdotal clinical experience with ribavirin, negative results from\nin vitro testing with ribavirin against the SARS-related coronavirus,\nand knowledge of reports of serious and unexpected adverse drug\nreactions, the working group reached a consensus that there is no\ndata to support the continued use of ribavirin outside of clinical\ntrials at this time. On 27 Apr 2003, Health Canada notified\nphysicians that the continued access to the drug is contingent upon\nthe submission and review of data in the possession of physicians\nwith respect to the use, safety, and efficacy of ribavirin for the\ntreatment of SARS. Physicians currently treating patients with\nribavirin are also strongly advised to critically re-examine the\nrisk/benefit for each patient before continuing treatment.\n\n[B] SARS Epidemiologic Summaries: 26 Apr 2003\nSummary of SARS cases potentially exposed in Canada and diagnosed\ninternationally\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/pef-dep/sars-es-int20030426_e.html>\n\nHealth Canada is working with our international partners to\ninvestigate reports of SARS cases diagnosed abroad who were thought\nto have been exposed in Canada. This report covers cases reported\ninternationally in Australia, Germany, United States, and the\nPhilippines. Health Canada was notified 24 Apr 2003 of a reported\nBulgarian case of SARS; this is being investigated and information\nwill be provided when available.\n\nAustralia:\nA family of five (2 adults, 3 children) residing in the Greater\nToronto Area departed Toronto on 28 Mar 2003 and arrived in Australia\non 29 Mar 2003. Child A had onset of influenza-like illness symptoms\non 31 Mar 2003 and was hospitalized on 3 Apr 2003 with high fever and\nrespiratory distress; a chest x-ray revealed infiltrates. Child A was\ndiagnosed as a SARS case according to the WHO case definition, which\ndiffers from the Canadian SARS case definition by including Toronto\nas an 'affected area'. Child B had onset of cough on 25 Mar 2003.\nChild C had onset of cough 1 Apr 2003. Both Child B and Child C were\nsubsequently reported as probable SARS cases according to the WHO\ncase definition. All 3 children have since recovered. Both adults\nremained well. No clear epidemiologic link to any known SARS cases in\nCanada could be established. No secondary transmission was observed.\n\nIn Canada, none of the children would have met the case definition\nfor a probable or suspect case of SARS. Child A would have been\nclassified as GEO-linked, that is, a person with fever and symptoms\nconsistent with severe atypical pneumonia who has been in an area\nwith local chains of transmission of at least 3 generations, who does\nnot have an epidemiologic link. Children B and C would have been\nclassified as Persons Under Investigation (PUI).\n\nGermany:\nA 26-year-old woman was temporarily residing in Toronto. On 31 Mar\n2003 she flew from Toronto to Germany. She was asymptomatic until 3\nApr 2003, when she developed headache, nausea, and vomiting. She\nsubsequently developed fever (maximum 37.8 C) and cough. She was\nadmitted to hospital on 7 Apr 2003 and diagnosed with pneumonia.\nChest x-ray revealed infiltrates. No clear epidemiologic link to any\nknown SARS cases in Canada could be established. No secondary\ntransmission was observed.\n\nIn Canada, this woman would not have met the case definition for\nprobable or suspect SARS. Rather, because of her sub-38 C temperature\nand lack of epidemiologic link, she would have been classified as a\nPerson Under Investigation.\n\nUnited States:\nA 52-year-old man residing in Pennsylvania travelled alone by car to\nToronto on 28 Mar 2003. He drove back to Pennsylvania alone on 1 Apr\n2003. On 3 Apr 2003 he became symptomatic with chills, fatigue,\nmyalgia, headache, and diaphoresis (excessive sweating). On 6 Apr\n2003 a fever of 38.2 C was documented, and on 7 Apr 2003 he developed\nrespiratory symptoms and was hospitalized on 14 Apr 2003 with\npneumonia. worldwide (69): diagnostic testing", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203687", "date": "2003-04-25 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (69): DIAGNOSTIC TESTING\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Fri 25 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organization (WHO), CSR, Thu 24 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/testing2003_04_18/en/>\n\nSARS: availability and use of laboratory testing\n------------------------------------------------\nResearchers in several countries are working towards developing fast and\naccurate laboratory tests for the SARS [virus]. Until those tests have been\nadequately field tested and shown to be reliable, however, SARS diagnosis\ndepends on the clinical findings of an atypical pneumonia not attributed to\nanother cause and a history of exposure to a suspect or probable case of\nSARS or their respiratory secretions and other bodily fluids. This\nrequirement is reflected in the current WHO case definitions for suspect or\nprobable SARS. Several countries (Canada, France, Germany, Hong Kong SAR\n[China], Japan, the Netherlands, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the\nUnited States of America) are, nonetheless, testing samples for suspected\nand probable SARS cases in research settings.\nInterpretation of test results\n------------------------------\nPositive test results: Positive test results indicate that SARS patients\nare, or recently were, infected with the SARS virus. Specificity of the\ndifferent tests still needs to be established.\nNegative test results: A negative SARS virus test does not mean that the\npatient does not have SARS. The reasons for negative test results in a\npatient with SARS include the following:\n(1) The patient is not infected with the SARS virus; the illness is caused\nby another infectious agent (virus, bacterium, fungus) or non-infective cause;\n(2) Test results are incorrect ('false-negative'). Current tests need to be\nfurther developed to improve sensitivity;\n(3) Specimens were not collected at a time when the virus or its genetic\nmaterial was present (pertains to polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and cell\nculture). The virus and its genetic material may be present for a brief\nperiod only, depending on the type of specimen tested; and\n(4) Specimens were collected early in the course of the illness and before\nantibodies had been produced (pertains to enzyme linked immunosorbent assay\n(ELISA) and immunofluorescence assays).\nSampling for research: To enhance the future understanding of the SARS\ndisease process, WHO recommends that clinicians collect and store\nsequential samples from patients with SARS for testing when diagnostic\ntests become readily available. This is particularly important for the\nfirst case(s) recognized in countries that have not previously reported\nSARS. Guidelines on sample handling of suspected or probable SARS patients\ncan be found at the web site of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC), United States of America.\nStatus of laboratory tests currently under development\n------------------------------------------------------\n(1) Antibody tests:\n-- ELISA detects antibodies in the serum of SARS patients reliably as from\nday 21 after the onset of clinical symptoms and signs.\n-- immunofluorescence assays detect antibodies in serum of SARS patients\nafter about day 10 of illness onset. This is a reliable test requiring the\nuse of fixed SARS virus, an immunofluorescence microscope, and an\nexperienced microscopist. Positive antibody tests indicate that the patient\nwas infected with the SARS virus.\n(2) molecular tests (PCR):\nPCR can detect genetic material of the SARS virus in various specimens\n(blood, stool, respiratory secretions, or body tissue). Primers, which are\nthe key pieces for a PCR test, have been made publicly available by WHO\nnetwork laboratories on the WHO website. The primers have since been used\nby numerous countries around the world. A ready-to-use PCR test kit\ncontaining primers and a positive and negative control has been developed.\nTesting of the kit by network members is expected to quickly yield the data\nneeded to assess the test's performance in comparison with primers\ndeveloped by other WHO network laboratories.\nExisting PCR tests are very specific but lack sensitivity. That means that\nnegative tests can't rule out the presence of the SARS virus in patients.\nVarious WHO network laboratories are working on their PCR protocols and\nprimers to improve their reliability.\nLaboratories performing SARS-specific PCR tests should adopt quality\ncontrol procedures and identify a partner laboratory in their country or\namong the WHO collaborating research laboratories to cross-check their\npositive findings.\nLaboratories performing SARS-specific PCR tests should adopt strict\ncriteria for confirmation of positive results, especially in low-prevalence\nareas, where the positive predictive value might be lower. The PCR\nprocedure should include appropriate negative and positive controls in each\nrun, which should yield the expected results:\n(a) a negative control for the extraction procedure and a water control for\nthe PCR run;\n(b) a positive control for extraction and PCR;\n(c) an inhibition control -- the patient sample spiked with a weak positive\ncontrol to detect PCR inhibitory substances.\nIf a positive PCR result has been obtained, it should be confirmed by:\n(a) Repeating the PCR starting from the original sample; OR\n(b) Having the same sample tested in a second laboratory.\nAmplifying a second genome region could further increase test specificity.\n(3) Cell culture:\nVirus in specimens (such as respiratory secretions, blood, or stool) from\nSARS patients can also be detected by infecting cell cultures and growing\nthe virus. Once isolated, the virus must be identified as the SARS virus\nwith further tests. Cell culture is a very demanding test but is the only\nmeans to show the existence of a live virus.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As noted previously (SARS - worldwide (64): etiology 20030423.0996),\ndiagnostic results reported from the Canadian National Microbiology\nLaboratory in Winnipeg contradict those reported earlier from Hong Kong.\nThe Hong Kong team found that 90 per cent of probable SARS cases harbored\nthe SARS-associated coronavirus, and found no trace of it in healthy\ncontrols. None of 40 respiratory secretions from patients with other\nrespiratory diseases contained evidence of coronavirus RNA, and none of 200\nserum samples from blood donors had serum antibody to this new coronavirus\n(SARS - worldwide (34): etiology 20030408.0857).\nBy contrast (see the Mod. comment included as part of SARS - worldwide\n(67): cases 20030424.1007), the Canadian group detected SARS-associated\ncoronavirus in about 20 per cent of 250 people who were not suspected of\nhaving SARS, but who were tested because they had come to Canada from\naffected areas in Asia or who had mild symptoms not thought to be SARS\n(that is, a slightly biased control group).\nThis discrepancy urgently needs to be resolved, as it casts doubt on the\nsensitivity, specificity, and relevance of the current diagnostic\nprocedures. Inclusion of an unbiased control group of patients should be\npart of the protocol for the evaluation of the currently available\nlaboratory tests in the diagnosis of SARS. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The PCR\nprocedure should include appropriate negative and positive controls in each\nrun, which should yield the expected results:\n(a) a negative control for the extraction procedure and a water control for\nthe PCR run;\n(b) a positive control for extraction and PCR;\n(c) an inhibition control -- the patient sample spiked with a weak positive\ncontrol to detect PCR inhibitory substances.
