Since these\nmutations were well conserved among mainland isolates, but not found in\nother isolates linked to the Metropole Hotel, I thought that the data\nsupported a Metropole source containing a mixture of variants. Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. This patient had\ntraveled to Thailand and mainland China shortly before developing SARS\nsymptoms, suggesting an origin outside of Hong Kong, consistent with the\nshared mutations found with mainland China isolates.\nIn addition to the D-to-E mutation at position 5768 in orf1ab, which is\nfound in CUHK-W1, GZ01, BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, there is another mutation\nof a T changing to I at position 244 in E2. This amino acid is found in all\n6 isolates. Thus, these 2 sets of shared mutations define 2 hot spots where\n6 of the sequenced isolates have one amino acid while the other 4 have\nanother. This distribution raises the possibility that the true mutations\nare the amino acids shared by the Tor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849\nisolates. I have not yet been able to obtain the history of the HKU-39849\nisolate. However, there is another shared mutation at position 577 of E2 in\nwhich S replaces A. This mutation is found in KYK, which is from a tourist\nwho stayed at the Metropole Hotel. However, the mutation is shared with,\nBJ01 and GZ01, isolates from the mainland. This mutation is not seen in\nTor2 or Urbani, 2 isolates closely linked to the Metropole Hotel. Thus, the\ndistribution of this mutation supports the notion that the infections at\nthe Metropole Hotel involved a number of variants. As noted above, however,\nTor2, Urbani, KYK, and HKU-39849 share amino acids found at position 5769\nin orf1ab and position 244 in E2, which supports a more closely related\nsource of the infections at the Metropole Hotel.\nThese shared mutations, especially the 2 loci that are shared by the 5\nmainland isolates and CUHK-W1, support an etiological role for SARS\ncoronavirus in SARS.\nHere is the list of shared mutations:\n(1) orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]:\n3047 V to A [Val to Ala] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, CUHK-W1\n3072 V to A [Val to Ala] in CUHK-W1*\n3196 A to V [Ala to Val} in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03\n5768 D to E [Asp to Glu] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n(2) E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]:\n77 G to D [Gly toAsp] in BJ03, CUHK-W1\n244 T to I [Thr to Ile] in BJ01, BJ02, BJ03, BJ04, GZ01, CUHK-W1\n577 A to S [Ala to Ser] in KYK, BJ01, GZ01\n(3) N [putative nucleoprotein gene]\n387 N to P [Asn to Pro] in GZ01, BJ02\n* This change is only in CUHK-W1, not BJ01, BJ02, BJ03 as reported\nyesterday [see: SARS - worldwide (63): etiology 20030423.0994] - the 3\nBeijing isolates have a shared mutation at position 3196, which is A to V,\nas well as V to A change at position 3047.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[For the benefit of readers, the key to the virus isolates identified above\nis the following:\nTor2 (Toronto)\nCUHK-W1 (Hong Kong)\nUrbani (Hanoi/Bangkok)\nKYK (Singapore)\nHKU-39849 (Hong Kong)\nGZ01 (Guangzhou)\nBJ01 (Beijing)\nBJ02 (Beijing)\nBJ03 (Beijing)\nBJ04 (Beijing)\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: Henry L Niman, PhD <henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n\n2 distinct SARS virus variants from the same patient\n----------------------------------------------------\nThis issue of SARS mutations will likely be viewed with increased interest.\nMore information is now available on the 5 isolates from mainland China\n<http://www.genomics.org.cn:8080/bgi/news/zhongxin/news030416-2_fasta.htm>.\nOne area of interest is a comparisons of mutations in 2 isolates (BJ01 and\nBJ03) from the same individual. The partial data have been submitted to\nGenebank, and it is possible that there are some sequencing errors, but the\ndata are quite strong for multiple variants in the same individual.\nThere are 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03. 2 of them are found in\nall 5 mainland china isolates as well as CUHK-W1, and the 4 other isolates\nmay be the true mutations. The 2 widely shared alterations are at position\n5768 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene] (D changing to E) and I\nchanging to T at position 244 in E2 [putative glycoprotein gene]. Another\nmutation shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1 (V\nchanging to A at position 3196). This change is found in BJ02 and CUHK-W1\nat position 3047 in orf1ab [the putative polymerase gene]. The fourth\nchange shared between BJ01 and BJ03 is also found in BJ02 (A changing to V\nat position 3196 in orf1ab).\nHowever, in addition to the 4 mutations shared between BJ01 and BJ03, each\nisolate has mutations not shared. BJ01 has 3 additional mutations not\nshared with the 9 other isolates. All 3 changes are in orf1ab at positions\n1718 (L to W), 2230 (A to V), and 2770 (V to I). Since these changes have\nnot been seen elsewhere, sequencing errors remain a possibility (although\nnot likely).\nIn contrast, BJ03 also has 3 mutations not found in BJ01, but 2 of these\nmutations have been found in other isolates, reducing the likelihood that\nthey are due to sequencing errors. The mutation unique to BJ03 is also in\norf1ab at position 3426 (V to I). Of interest are the 2 other mutations in\nE2. At position 78, the change of G to D is also found in CUHK-W1, while\nthe A to S change at position 577 is also found in KYK and GZ01, which were\nfrom patients in Singapore and Guangzhou, respectively.\nThe finding of this A to S mutation in isolates from 2 other geographically\ndistinct regions, but not in another isolate from the same patient, raises\nissues of multiple variants within the same patient as well as tissue\ntropism linked to specific amino acid changes.\n--\nHenry L Niman, PhD\nDepartment of Bioengineering\nShriners' Burn Center\n51 Blossom Street, Room 422\nBoston, MA 02114 USA\n<henry_niman@hms.harvard.edu>\n[All RNA viruses by their nature are inherently highly mutable; while these\nsequence comparisons of a small number of SARS coronavirus isolates are\nintriguing, it is perhaps too early to speculate on the biological\nsignificance of any of these variable sites. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Although\nCUHK-W1 was isolated from a patient from the Prince of Wales Hospital, I\nhave been informed by Dennis Lo and Stephen Tsui, who were involved in the\nsequencing of this isolate, that the patient was not one of the 138\npatients linked to the visitor of the Metropole Hotel. In Canada, more than 300 are either\n'probable' or 'suspected' of having SARS, and 15 are reported to have died.\nThe outbreak centers on the city of Toronto.\nThe World Health Organization says it is reasonably certain that SARS is\ncaused by infection with a new strain [species] of coronavirus. However,\nCanadian scientists have carried out hundreds of tests on samples from\npatients diagnosed as suspected or probable cases of SARS in Canada. They\nhave found that only 40 per cent of people carried the new [species] of\ncoronavirus. In addition they found evidence of the strain [the new species\nof coronavirus] in healthy people enlisted as 'controls' for the experiment.\nThe results, from the Canadian National Microbiology Laboratory in\nWinnipeg, contradict those from scientists in Hong Kong, where more than\n100 people have so far died from the illness. The Hong Kong team found that\n90 per cent of probable SARS cases harboured the [new] coronavirus, and\nfound no trace of it in healthy controls. Researchers around the world are\nscrambling to provide diagnostic tests and treatments, and even working\ntowards vaccines, on the basis that coronavirus is the root cause. If it is\nnot actually caused by coronavirus, then these efforts would be in vain.\nMany experts believe it will be some years before an effective vaccine for\nthis new strain of coronavirus is available.\nDr Frank Plummer, who led the Canadian research, said that: 'There remain\nsome very puzzling things we are finding. They include 2 health care workers (one from Caritas\nMedical Centre and one from Tuen Mun Hospital). The remaining 14 are other\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 668 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 36 were discharged today.\nThere are also 115 recovering patients who are in convalescence and\npreparing for discharge. 100 patients are being treated in intensive care\nunits.\n12 patients died in Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital, Prince of Wales\nHospital, Kwong Wah Hospital, Princess Margaret Hospital, Tuen Mun\nHospital, Tai Po Hospital, and United Christian Hospital. This brought to\n133 the total number of deaths related to atypical pneumonia. The deceased\nare aged from 45 to 91 and include 8 women and 4 men. 8 of them have a\nhistory of chronic disease. [None of these deaths was in an otherwise\nhealthy individual less than 50 years of age.]\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases / total no. discharged patients / total no. deaths\nHealth care workers of hospitals/clinics and medical students: 347 / 147 / ?\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1196 / 521 / ?\nTotal: 1543 * / 668 / 133\nSuspected cases 24\n* There are 115 recovering patients in convalescence.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 27 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 27 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6580>\n\nSituation Update on SARS 27 Apr 2003\n------------------------------------\nToday, only one new SARS case has been reported. The patient was a\nphysician who died on 22 Apr 2003. Postmortem results confirmed his case as\nSARS. Besides this, there are no other new cases. 3 more patients have been\ndischarged, bringing the total number of patients who have recovered from\nSARS to 131; 47 SARS patients remain hospitalised, of whom 17 are in\nintensive care.\n'No visitor' rule\nStarting from 29 Apr 2003, all public hospitals will implement a no visitor\nrule for their patients. Of the 199 SARS cases reported so far, about 38\nper cent of them were visitors to hospitals. The no visitor rule is an\nadded precautionary measure to cut down the chances of visitors being\ninfected while in the hospital. It will also help prevent infection from\nbeing brought out of the hospitals into the community at large The no\nvisitor rule will not apply for departments or hospitals treating children\nor providing obstetric care, where the 1-visitor-per-patient-per-day policy\nwill continue.\nPostmortem results of the physician fatality\n[A] consultant vascular surgeon with the Department of General Surgery,\nSingapore General Hospital (SGH), passed away on 22 Apr 2003. [He] may have\nbeen infected by a critically ill patient from the Ward 57 & 58 cohort,\nwhom he cared for during the week of 7 to 13 Apr 2003. A postmortem was\ncarried out on 23 Apr 2003 [? date]. Postmortem testing of tissues\nsubsequently confirmed SARS.\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market (PPWM): update\nOn 19 Apr 2003, PPWM was closed down when 2 workers with probable SARS were\nidentified. These 2 had come in contact with the brother of the SGH index\ncase who worked in PPWM. Active contact tracing was initiated immediately\nto trace all people who might have come into close contact with the 3 SARS\ncases. A total of 1825 people who had frequented the market between 5 and\n19 Apr 2003 were identified as possible contacts, and they comprised 935\ntenants and stall holders, 553 employees and workers, and 337 regular\ncustomers. As a precautionary measure, these people were placed under home\nquarantine and monitored for fever for 10 days from 20 to 29 Apr 2003. The\nquarantine will be lifted on 30 Apr 2003. There have been 20 deaths in Canada. To\ndate, transmission has been limited to specific transmission settings such\nas households, hospitals, and specific community settings.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows: (These numbers are\naccurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 26 Apr 2003).\nOntario is reporting 138 probable and 130 suspect cases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable and 60 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 6 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nTotal no. of probables discharged: 75\nTotal no. of probables recovering at home: 2\nTotal no. of suspects discharged: 85\nTotal no. of suspects recovering at home: 69\n[B] SARS epidemiological summaries: SARS among Ontario health care workers\n26 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/pef-dep/sars-es20030426_e.html>\nTransmission of SARS in the Greater Toronto Area (GTA) is believed to have\nbegun with a travel-related index case in February 2003. Her family\ncontacts, after developing symptoms compatible with SARS, were treated at a\nhospital within the GTA and subsequently transmitted the illness to\nhospital workers and other patients at that hospital. Over 100 hospital\nworkers at 3 GTA hospitals have since become ill. Initial descriptive\nepidemiology suggests that transmission occurred in association with the\ncare of patients who were not diagnosed with SARS and were not in isolation\nprecautions, as well as ill family members visiting in hospital.\nDisease control strategies included implementation of strict infection\ncontrol precautions in institutional settings, isolation of cases and\nsymptomatic contacts, and quarantining asymptomatic close contacts.\nInitially, SARS cases were isolated in hospital in negative pressure rooms.\nBy early April 2003, however, there was a critical shortage of standard\nairborne isolation beds within the GTA. In response, SARS negative pressure\nunits were created within some GTA hospitals to increase capacity to care\nfor SARS patients in controlled circumstances.\nSince these control strategies were implemented, transmission of SARS to\nhospital workers has decreased substantially. Nevertheless, transmission\nhas continued to occur in both high and low risk hospital settings within\nthe GTA despite these measures. High risk procedures have been identified\nand include intubation, suction, nebulized aerosol therapy, and positive\npressure non-invasive ventilation. Transmission of SARS to hospital staff\nduring difficult intubations of SARS patients has occurred in 3 different\nhospitals. In 2, undiagnosed patients were identified as the source of\ntransmission for 7 hospital staff. Although infection control precautions\nwere in place, compliance may not have been complete. In the third, a SARS\npatient was identified as the source of infection for 7 hospital staff; an\nadditional 6 remain under investigation. Although staff were reportedly\ncompliant with infection control precautions, one break in technique in one\ncaregiver was identified (a face shield was accidentally dislodged).\nTransmission of SARS to 10 to 11 hospital staff has also been identified in\nlower risk settings. Affected staff include physicians, nurses, and service\nassistants (such as porter/housekeeper) working in 4 different low risk\nSARS units and one community hospital. Initial investigation suggests that\ntransmission occurred while staff were wearing required personal protective\nequipment and following all recommended infection control precautions.\nIn response to the continued transmission of SARS to hospital workers,\nHealth Canada is leading an urgent investigation in collaboration with the\nCenters for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Province of Ontario,\nand Toronto Public Health. The investigation will include descriptive\nepidemiology, case control studies, air ventilation studies, and surface\ncontamination studies. In addition, an infection control directive\nspecifically for SARS Units is being developed.\n[C] Epidemiology update: interim report on the SARS outbreak in the Greater\nToronto Area, Ontario, Canada 24 Apr 2003\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/pef-dep/gta-20030424_e.html>\n1. Background\nSARS, a new atypical pneumonia, originated in Guangdong Province, China in\nNovember 2002. This syndrome appears to have some association with\ninfection with a novel coronavirus. While isolated travel-related cases\nhave been reported in Greater Toronto Area (GTA) and other parts of Canada,\nprogression to a large outbreak occurred in Toronto in March 2003\noriginating from a single traveler who returned from Hong Kong in late\nFebruary.\nThe outbreak now involves more than 250 people in the province of Ontario.\nHealth Canada is currently working with international partners in\ninvestigating reports of SARS cases exposed in Canada and diagnosed\nelsewhere. Countries include Australia, Philippines, United States,\nGermany, and Bulgaria. A summary of the international investigations\nassociated with travel to Canada will be reported separately. This interim\nreport describes the current results of the epidemiological investigation\nof the SARS outbreak in the GTA.\nThe outbreak in the GTA has proceeded through 5 major stages, listed below:\n- spread of SARS infection within the family of the index case;\n- amplification of the SARS outbreak through hospital-based spread;\n- transmission within immediate household members of the health care\nworkers, patients, and visitors to these hospitals;\n- isolated sporadic cases due to limited transmission in the workplace;\n- transmission in an extended family and associated religious group.\nThe following provides an overview of the epidemiology of the outbreak in\nthe GTA as of 19 Apr 2003.\n2. Spread of SARS infection within the family of the index case\nThe index case of SARS in Canada (case A) was a 78 year old woman who was\ninfected during a stay at a hotel in Kowloon district of Hong Kong between\n17 and 21 Feb 2003. She returned to Toronto on 23 Feb 2003; there was no\ntransmission of SARS to other passengers on her return flight. The\ninfection spread to her family members, 3 of whom visited their family\nphysician, who also became ill. 6 of the 11 members of this family\ndeveloped develop SARS and 2 died. Poutanen SM and colleagues have\ndescribed these cases in the New England Journal of Medicine\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJM.oa030634v3.pdf>. These events\noccurred before 12 Mar 2003, at which time the World Health Organization\n(WHO) issued an alert about SARS and initiated global surveillance.\n3. Transmission in hospitals\n3.1. Hospital A\nThe son (case B) of the index case presented with respiratory symptoms at\nthe emergency room (ER) of hospital A on 7 Mar 2003. He was managed in a\ngeneral observation area of the ER and received a bronchodilator via a\nnebulizer. During this time, SARS was transmitted to 2 other patients who\nwere also in the ER general observation area (cases C and D).\nCase C began to exhibit symptoms of SARS 3 days later. He was brought to\nhospital A on 16 Mar 2003. Case C was admitted to the intensive care unit\n(ICU and placed in isolation. On the same day, his wife also became ill.\nSARS was transmitted to 2 paramedics and a firefighter by case C and to 4\nER staff, one housekeeper and 7 visitors who were in the ER at the same\ntime. The infection was also spread to 3 other members of the family. The 7\nER visitors transmitted the infection to 5 household members and other\nfamily contacts. In the ICU, case C was intubated by a physician who wore a\nface shield, mask, gown, and gloves when performing the procedure. He did\nnot use precautions when he was in contact with case C's wife. He\nsubsequently developed SARS and transmitted the infection to one member of\nhis family. In total, case C infected 15 other people.\nCase D became ill on 13 Mar 2003 and was admitted to hospital A. He\npresented with a myocardial infarction, SARS was not recognized, so\ninfection control precautions were not used. After 3 days in the Cardiac\nCare Unit (CCU), he was transferred to hospital B. Case D transmitted the\ninfection to 11 people in hospital A, including a paramedic, ER staff, CCU\nstaff, and a CCU patient.\nDue to the ongoing spread of infection in the hospital setting and concerns\nthat this potential for spread would result in more cases in hospital A,\nhospital A was closed to new patients and active surveillance for SARS was\nestablished. The crude attack rates in the ER were 13 per cent, the ICU 14\nper cent, and the CCU 50 per cent.\n3.2. Hospital B\nCase D was transferred to the ICU of hospital B and was not placed in\nisolation. Case D's wife was subsequently admitted to the surgical unit on\n21 Mar 2003. The couple was assumed to be the source of the hospital\noutbreak. Following the identification of 5 staff members ill with SARS,\nstrict infection control policies were applied. One staff member was a\ndialysis nurse who worked one shift while symptomatic. Follow-up with\ndialysis patients has failed to reveal any further transmission among this\ngroup. A total of 9 staff and one patient were infected by case D and his wife.\n4. Transmission in households\nTransmission of SARS in the household settings has resulted in 33 cases.\nFrom the analysis of the hospital A cluster of 129 cases, about 85\nhouseholds were involved. Transmission to family members occurred in 21 of\nthose households (25 per cent).\n5. Sporadic cases in workplaces\nThere have been 3 episodes in which occupational transmission of SARS has\nbeen suspected in settings other than health care facilities. In one\nworksite, a worker broke quarantine, became symptomatic, and worked with\none other person in a small room while symptomatic. This close contact\nbecame a probable case of SARS. Possible exposures have occurred in 2 other\nworksites, but at the time of writing this report, neither has evidence of\ntransmission of SARS.\n6. Transmission in an extended family and religious group\nThe elderly grandfather of a large family was taken to the ER of hospital A\non the evening of 16 Mar 2003, at the same time that case C and his wife\nwere there. 3 members of this family developed SARS. The infection\nsubsequently spread to their extended family. The grandfather died on 1 Apr\n2003. Visitation for this deceased person occurred on 3 Apr 2003 and ill\nfamily members were in attendance.\nMembers of this family are also part of a religious group that engaged in\nfrequent worship and social activities. This group held 2 large church\nevents on 28 and 29 Mar 2003 attended by 500 and 250 people, respectively.\nThe attendees at the second event were a subset of those who attended the\nfirst event. This family is also part of an extensive social network that\nincludes many extended families.\nTo date, a total of 31 probable and suspect cases of SARS have been\nidentified in this cluster. This number includes 14 members of the index\nfamily, 3 health care workers, and 14 other members of the religious group.\nActive surveillance and quarantine measures are being used to control the\nspread of SARS outside of this group.\n7. Epidemiological description of the outbreak as a whole\nThis section provides the descriptive epidemiology of the overall outbreak.\nThese data are presented as of 19 Apr 2003. At this time, there were 249\nreported cases of SARS, of which 129 (52 per cent) were listed as probable.\n7.1. Geographic location of residence\nCases of SARS have been reported by 4 of the 5 health units in GTA. The\ncity of Toronto and York region account for 84 per cent of all suspect and\nprobable cases.\n7.2. Distribution by age and sex\nOf the 249 reported cases, 155 (62 per cent) were female. This percentage\nis the same for both suspect and probable cases and probably reflects the\ndemographics of workers in the health care system. The distribution by age\nindicates a peak among people aged 36 to 64 years. This peak again reflects\nthe population who work in health care settings, which is one of the\nlargest risk groups for this outbreak. The mean and median ages are 44.6\nand 42.0 years, respectively. There have been 12 reported cases of SARS\namong children aged 16 and under.\n7.3. Distribution over time\nFigure 2 [see website link above] shows the distribution over time by\nsource of infection. There was early transmission in the family, followed\nby a large increase in cases due to transmission at hospitals A and B. With\nthe introduction of infection control procedures and public health\nmeasures, however, the number of new cases has decreased.\n7.4. Incubation period\nBased on the cases associated with hospital A, the incubation period ranges\nfrom 2 to 10 days, with a mean of 5 days and median of 4. This incubation\nperiod was calculated using 42 cases that had a single known contact with a\nSARS case.\n7.5. Period of communicability\nThere has been no observed transmission before the onset of symptoms.\n7.6. Mortality\nAs of 19 Apr 2003, there have been 14 deaths associated with SARS. The age\nof those who died ranged from 43 to 99 years of age (mean 74 years). Of\nthose with known medical histories, all deaths have been in those with an\nassociated medical condition. Further investigation is under way to\ndetermine the factors that are associated with an increased risk of death.\n7.7. Disposition of patients\nAs of 19 Apr 2003, 120 people with SARS (48 per cent) have been discharged\nhome following their illness. A further 4 have never been admitted to\nhospital and 14 have died. The remaining people are in hospital being\ntreated or monitored. Data on the average length of stay and the percentage\nof patients requiring ventilation are being collected for analysis.\nSource: Ontario Ministry of Health and Long Term Care, Ontario SARS\nScientific Advisory Committee and Health Canada.\n******\n[4]\nDate: 27 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Taiwan CDC [edited]\n\n[A] Taiwan SARS update 27 Apr 2003\n<http://203.65.72.83/En/dpc/ShowPublication.ASP?RecNo=871>\nAs of 9:00 AM on 27 Apr 2003, there were 250 possible SARS cases reported\n[my addition, and comparison with 26 Apr report suggests 288. - Mod.SH]: 55\nprobable, 72 suspected, 91 excluded, and 70 pending cases. I do not think this judgement is correct.\nMany -- and probably most -- infectious diseases cause a wide range of\ndisease severity, from asymptomatic through mild symptoms to severe and at\ntimes lethal illness (just a few examples include Japanese B encephalitis,\nWest Nile fever, hepatitis A, etc.). Few would argue that someone with a\npositive IgM test to hepatitis A associated with mild non-icteric illness\ndoes not have hepatitis A infection simply because they are not jaundiced.\nSyndromic diagnosis has low sensitivity and specificity compared to\nlaboratory diagnosis. Syndromes usually only represent the more severe tip\nof the iceberg in any infectious disease.\nBecause the current definition of SARS is syndromic, many cases of\ninfection with the SARS agent are likely to be missed, because the severity\nof the illness is not great enough to be classified as SARS. Also there are\nother pathogens (some of which are difficult to identify in the laboratory\nor may be currently unknown) that will cause a similar clinical picture in\nsevere cases and still be correctly classified as SARS -- even though not\ndue to the SARS agent. The Canadian results, far from casting doubt on the\nsensitivity and specificity of current SARS-related coronavirus tests, are\nconsistent with what we should expect, especially away from the main focus\nof the epidemic.\nA lot of the confusion in the reporting of the SARS epidemic is caused by\npeople forgetting the difference between a clinical syndrome and an\ninfectious disease caused by a particular pathogen. I further suggest this\nconfusion may also be delaying a proper epidemiological investigation, as\nno such investigation can be complete unless the underwater part of the\niceberg (non-SARS infections with the SARS agent) is fully investigated.\n--\nPaul R Hunter MD FRCPath MFPHM\nProfessor of Health Protection\nEuropean Editor - Journal of Water and Health\nSchool of Medicine, Health Policy and Practice\nUniversity of East Anglia\nNorwich NR4 7TJ England\n<paul.hunter@uea.ac.uk>\n[Professor Hunter's comments have merit. The point we were trying to\nemphasize is that there is no substitute for experimental data and that an\nobvious control has not been included in the recommended diagnostic\nprotocol to date. We agree that syndromic surveillance alone does have a\nlow sensitivity and specificity when compared with laboratory diagnosis of\nan infection. In the case of the ongoing SARS epidemic, and in the quest to\nidentify an etiologic agent and appropriate laboratory diagnostic tools to\nconfirm the infection, there remains cause for concern if, in the middle of\nan outbreak of an unusual pneumonia, only 40 per cent of the 'probable\ncases' are positive using the currently available laboratory diagnostic\ntools. It would be highly unusual to have so many epidemiologically linked\ncases with an 'atypical pneumonia' that would not be caused by the same\netiology. Yes, we do expect to see mild cases and asymptomatics that are\nalso positive, so that the absence of a healthy control group not\nepidemiologically linked to this outbreak is lamentably lacking in this\nscientific process. Nevertheless, a 60 per cent false (?) negative rate is\na bit disconcerting and warrants further study. - Mods.CP/MPP]\n******\n[6]\nDate: 27 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n\n[A] North Korea from Hoover's Online 27 Apr 2003 (from the Korean Times)\n<http://hoovnews.hoovers.com/fp.asp?layout=displaynews&doc_id=NR20030427670.2_3cf50006dd42d285>\nThe North was put on alert as a patient suspected to have been infected\nwith the epidemic was reported in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.\nNorth Korea's Central TV Station reported 24 Apr 2003 that a suspected SARS\npatient was detected in the Moranbong district of Pyongyang. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR China occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] The list of affected areas can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_26/en/> and is unchanged from\nprior reports.\n[C] Update 40 - Situation in Shanghai, Hong Kong and Viet Nam 26 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_26/en/>\nPreliminary findings of the WHO Shanghai team\nA WHO team of 6 experts, in Shanghai since Monday [21 Apr 2003], has\nprovided a preliminary report of its findings. The team was invited by\nShanghai authorities to assess the SARS situation in China's second largest\ncity.\nAmong its activities, the team examined the SARS surveillance and reporting\nsystem, investigated rumours that the case burden might be higher than\nofficially reported, and visited 10 health facilities, 3 district Centres\nfor Disease Control, and the municipal Centre for Disease Control. The team\nwas given free access to all requested data, patient registries, and\nfacilities, which were visited at very short notice.\nThe team found no evidence of systematic underreporting of cases, and\nconcluded that the level of preparedness and response was good. Reporting\nof cases appeared to be open, frank, and accurate. Over the past 3 to 4\nweeks, authorities designated 2 hospitals as dedicated to the treatment of\nSARS patients and set up cough and fever clinics. The team also found a\nvery high level of government commitment to tackle the SARS problem.\nMany questions remain about why Shanghai has been spared a SARS outbreak on\nthe scale of that seen in Beijing. Had a larger number of cases occurred,\nit is not certain whether the systems presently in place would have been\nable to cope.\nSituation in Hong Kong\nHealth authorities announced 17 new cases, including 3 in health care\nworkers, and 6 deaths, including the youngest SARS fatality in Hong Kong to\ndate. This was a previously healthy 28 year old man from the Amoy Gardens\nhousing estate cluster. The other deaths occurred in men aged 38, 40, 61,\nand 70 years, and a 45 year old woman. Only one of these patients, the 70\nyear old man, had a history of chronic disease. Of the 6 deaths announced\nyesterday, 3 were from the Amoy Gardens cluster.\nAuthorities are continuing to investigate a small cluster of cases in the\nTung Tau housing estate, where 6 cases have occurred in vertically linked\nflats. Presently available epidemiological evidence gives no reason to\nanticipate an outbreak at the estate on the scale of Amoy Gardens cluster,\nwhich involved more than 320 residents of a single building.\nA WHO team of environmental and 'sick building' experts arrived in Hong\nKong to assist local experts in the investigation of possible environmental\nsources of the virus.\nNo new cases in Viet Nam for 18 days\nThe SARS situation in Viet Nam has remained stable, at 63 cases and 5\ndeaths, for 18 consecutive days. Active investigation of numerous rumours\nhas failed to detect a new case of SARS throughout this period. If the\ntrend continues, the country will be removed from the list of affected\nareas on Monday, making Viet Nam the first country to contain its SARS\noutbreak. WHO officials in Viet Nam cautioned against a lapse in the\npresent high state of alert, as the risk persists that a single imported\ncase could seed an outbreak, as happened in February [2003]. However, the\ngovernment showed strong commitment at the highest level from the beginning\nof the outbreak. Task forces and provincial teams were established and have\nworked well. Good procedures of infection control were rapidly established\nand eventually proved effective in preventing further spread among hospital\nstaff.\nShould the country experience an imported case, this newly established\ninfrastructure would most likely be effective in preventing another large\noutbreak.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today [26 Apr 2003], a cumulative total of 4836 cases with 293 deaths\nhave occurred in 26 countries. This represents an increase of 190 new cases\nand 19 deaths compared with yesterday. The new deaths occurred in Canada\n(3), China (7), Hong Kong SAR (6), the Philippines (1), and Singapore (2).\n******\n[2]\nDate: 26 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 26 Apr 2003\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 26 Apr 2003, there are an additional 17 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 3 health care workers (one from Caritas Medical Centre, one\nfrom Tai Po Hospital, and one from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital).\nThe remaining 14 are other patients and contacts of patients with atypical\npneumonia.\nA total of 632 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. worldwide (66): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203682", "date": "2003-04-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (66): CASES\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 23 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada 23 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update37.html>\n\nUpdate 37 - SARS 23 Apr 2003 5:00 PM\n------------------------------------\nAs of 23 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 330 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 16 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals, and specific\ncommunity settings. This update is based on the information available to\nHealth Canada at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows: Ontario is reporting 136\nprobable and 131 suspect cases. British Columbia is reporting 4 probable\nand 47 suspect cases. New Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case. Alberta is reporting 5 suspect\ncases. Prince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases. So far, 127\npeople have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario. These people were\ntreated as suspect cases or as probable cases. These numbers are accurate\nas of 1:00 PM EDST 23 Apr 2003.\nHealth Canada Reaction to WHO Travel Advice\nOn 23 Apr 2003, the World Health Organization (WHO) extended its\nrecommendation to postpone non-essential travel to include Toronto. Health\nCanada does not support the WHO's position; it is safe to travel to\nToronto. We have a clear understanding of the specific settings in which\nthis virus has been transmitted in Canada and confidence in the steps being\ntaken to manage infection control.\nA travel alert from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\nprovides a more accurate assessment of the situation in Canada. It states\nthat: 'Currently, all cases in Toronto are linked to Toronto's original\nindex case and spread has been through person-to-person contact. SARS\ntransmission in Toronto has been limited to a small number of hospitals,\nhouseholds, and specific community settings.'\nHealth Canada will be formally challenging the WHO's assertion that Toronto\nis an unsafe place to visit through a letter to be sent today to the WHO.\nHealth Canada Investigation with Officials from CDC:\nOn 20 Apr 2003, Health Canada invited officials from CDC to come to Canada\nto lend their expertise to a Health Canada-led investigation. They will be\nassisting Health Canada officials as they spend time in hospitals in\nToronto, gathering information in order to compare the circumstances\nsurrounding those who were infected to those not infected. Health Canada\nand the CDC will report as soon as possible, outlining the probable cause\nof the transmission among health-care workers and recommendations for\nadditional measures that may be taken to prevent further spread.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmaill.org>\nSource: NY Times, 23 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/24/science/24CANA.html>\n\nWHO added Toronto today to its list of places that travelers should avoid\nbecause of an outbreak of a contagious respiratory disease, shattering this\ncity's image as a safe place to live and visit. The decision stunned local\nleaders and highlighted the impact of an illness that mysteriously emerged\nfrom the Chinese countryside only a few months ago. Toronto is the first\nlocality outside China to be designated as a threat to international health\nbecause of the respiratory disease. The group also added Beijing and Shanxi\nProvince in China to its list, joining Hong Kong and Guangdong Province as\nthe hot spots for severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS.\nOnly 2 weeks ago, health care officials here expressed optimism that the\ndisease could be stopped. Efforts to trace every case and isolate everyone\nwho came in close, unprotected contact with every patient appeared to be\nworking because of what seemed to be efficient public health efforts and a\nlargely obedient public's accepting of volunteer quarantine. The\nmetropolitan Toronto area had 136 probable cases Tuesday, a more than 40\nper cent rise in the last 2 weeks, although no new cases were reported today.\nEven before WHO urged travelers to go to Toronto only if necessary -- a\nmessage with enormous potential economic consequences -- the local hotel\nindustry had been devastated by almost daily cancellations of conventions.\nChinese malls and restaurants, the source of thousands of jobs in the large\nAsian immigrant community, are almost empty. A forecast by JP Securities\nCanada on Tuesday estimated that the epidemic in Toronto, Canada's largest\ncity and financial center, would cost the country $30 million a day. The\nfirm reduced its forecast for a 2 per cent to 2.5 per cent national\neconomic growth rate in the current quarter to 1 per cent.\nCity officials were livid about the WHO advice today, saying it was an\nover-reaction that would worsen the economic impact of the disease. 'I have\nnever been so angry in my whole life,' Toronto's mayor, Mel Lastman, said.\n'If it's safe to live in Toronto, it's safe to come to Toronto. This isn't\na city in the grips of fear and panic.'\nSeveral health officials acknowledged this week that they were confounded\nby the challenge of keeping SARS from racing through hospital wards, among\nfamily members of the sick, and then gradually spilling into the population\nat large. Many are beginning to conclude that no quarantine system can be\nfoolproof for a disease that is hard to detect and easily confused with\nother ailments in its initial phases.\nAbout two thirds of the 330 probable and suspected cases in Canada have\nbeen reported in Toronto. Perhaps more worrisome still is a report that a\nwoman who died a few days ago in the Philippines has now been determined to\nhave been infected with SARS in Toronto -- the first known death abroad\nlinked to the Canadian outbreak. WHO officials said that they took their\naction against Toronto, in part, because of evidence that the disease had\nbeen exported from the city.\nA WHO official said the international spread included the death of the\nPhilippine woman, a nurse, and 3 probable cases in Australia linked to\ntrips to Toronto.\nA US CDC team, invited by Canadian officials, arrived on Tuesday night to\nmonitor infection controls in Toronto hospitals. By the end of the week,\nCDC will issue health warning cards to travelers entering the United States\nfrom Toronto, urging them to see a doctor if they feel ill.\nThe daily number of new cases of SARS, brought here 2 months ago by an\nelderly Chinese immigrant, was coming down. The vast majority of more than\n7000 people put in quarantine had been released. 3 schools that had been\nclosed reopened. And most people infected were getting better. But the mood\namong doctors has changed drastically in recent days.\nThe Mistakes: a chain of missteps adds to the risks\n'SARS Rides the Rails,' blared a front-page headline in The Toronto Sun\nthis week, echoing the first hints of a mood change in this otherwise\nthoroughly stoical city.\nA nurse who was not yet aware she was infected with the mysterious\nrespiratory disease had taken 2 commuter trains at rush hour. When news got\nout, hundreds of panicky passengers called health hotlines to see whether\nthey might be in danger. 4 people have been found to have SARS in one north\nToronto condominium, and experts have been unable to tie one of them to any\npreviously known cluster. Some of the leaks are due to their own mistakes,\nhealth officials acknowledge. In one early miscalculation, an infected\npatient was transferred from one hospital to another, producing an entire\nnew pathway for the disease.\nLast week, an infected doctor, who has said he was unaware of his disease,\nwent to a well-attended funeral only 2 days before going into the hospital.\nAnd over the last weekend new reports indicated that the apparent breakdown\nin isolation techniques caused a new cluster of cases among up to 15\nemployees at a major city hospital. Officials hypothesize that the workers\nmay have been prematurely taken off protective gear while in contaminated\nrooms, with the virus apparently surviving on surfaces for as long as 24 hours.\nThe biggest potential leak surfaced 2 weeks ago, when health care officials\nbelatedly notified and isolated a church group of 500 people that had been\nexposed at a 3 Apr 2003 funeral and subsequent prayer meetings. Many\nmembers of the group were not notified until well after the incubation\nperiod of the disease, usually around 10 days, meaning they could already\nhave exposed others outside the group. One infected man from this group was\nturned away from as many as 3 hospitals before he received medical\nattention for SARS, as officials misdiagnosed his mild symptoms. 29 people\namong the church group, made up mostly of Philippine immigrants, have\nbecome sick, with probable or suspected cases. Several are in critical\ncondition. 2 traveled to Pennsylvania and Montreal before they were\nquarantined, fueling fears of further spread.\nHit hardest are the city's hospitals, where the forced quarantine of\nhundreds of health workers and the closing of several emergency rooms and\nother clinics has stretched manpower and resources to the limit. The\ninfection rate has grown so high in hospitals that this week workers were\nordered to wear 2 gloves and shields covering their entire faces when\ntreating patients. The use of full-body biohazard suits is being considered.\n[byline: Clifford Krauss]\n******\n[3]\nDate: 23 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Gulf-Daily News [edited]\n<http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/Articles.asp?Article=49880&Sn=BNEW>\n\nThere are fears that the disease had reached the Philippines, especially\nfollowing the death of the Philippines' first 'probable' SARS [case] last\nweek. [The woman], who worked as a nursing attendant in a home for the\nelderly in Toronto, Canada, returned to the Philippines on 3 Apr 2003 to\nlook for a doctor for her cancer-stricken father. She rapidly developed\npneumonia-like symptoms and died on 14 Apr 2003.\nHer 74 year old father, who was quarantined after his daughter's death,\ndied last Tuesday from 'probable' SARS. Toronto, Canada's largest city, is\nthe center of the largest SARS outbreak outside Asia. The new figures\nbring the cumulative number of reported probable cases in China to 2422. 21\nprovinces have now reported probable cases, with another 5 provinces\nreporting suspected cases.\nOf the 125 new cases, 24 occurred among health workers, including 17 in\nBeijing. Altogether, China has reported 541 cases in health workers during\nthe course of its SARS outbreak, which began in mid-November 2002.\nBeijing has reported the highest number of new cases (89), followed by\nGuangdong (15), and Inner Mongolia (11). Beijing reported 4 new deaths,\nbringing the cumulative number of SARS deaths in China to 110.\nWith a cumulative total of 1359 cases, Guangdong has the highest total\nnumber of probable cases, followed by Beijing, with 774 probable cases.\nThe number of reported cases in Beijing is increasing on a daily basis, and\nWHO is following the situation there closely. Data provided to date do not\nallow determination of whether newly reported cases are old SARS cases only\nnow coming to light, or newly detected cases. Better interpretation of\nreports and a more complete assessment of the underlying situation require\ninformation on date of onset and location of cases. WHO has proposed to\nBeijing city government officials a meeting (scheduled for 25 Apr 2003) of\nWHO technical staff with Beijing disease experts in order to review\nreporting procedures.\nYesterday Beijing authorities closed elementary and middle schools early as\nan extension of the already planned national May Day holidays. Schools have\nbeen asked to inform parents, teachers, and visitors about the symptoms of\nSARS. People with symptoms have been asked not to visit schools. School\nauthorities have been asked to conduct close monitoring and to send home\nany students, teachers, other staff, and visitors showing symptoms\nsuggestive of SARS.\nIn Shanghai, the WHO team of experts continued visits to hospitals and the\nShanghai Centre for Disease Control. The team has also examined procedures\nfor contact tracing. The team will present its findings tomorrow and return\nto Beijing on Saturday [26 Apr 2003].\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 4439 cases with 263 deaths have been\nreported from 26 countries. This represents an increase of 158 new cases\nand 12 deaths compared with yesterday. The deaths occurred in Canada (2),\nChina (4), Hong Kong SAR (4), and Singapore (2). Bulgaria reported its\nfirst case today.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 24 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 24 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 24 Apr 2003\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 24 Apr 2003, there are an additional 30 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 3 health care workers (one from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole\nHospital, one from St Teresa's Hospital, and one from Baptist Hospital).\nThe remaining 27 are other patients and contacts of patients with atypical\npneumonia.\nA total of 567 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. At the time of access of this\nwebsite, the data were current for reports to WHO on 22 Apr 2003, and\nincluded reports of 37 probable cases (from 18 states) and an additional\n202 suspected cases (a total of 36 states are reported suspected and/or\nprobable cases).\n[B] MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2003; 52(16): 357-360. (25 Apr) [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5216a1.htm>\nUpdate: SARS -- United States, 2003 -- CDC continues to work with WHO and\nother partners\n-----------------------------------\nThis report updates information on reported SARS cases worldwide and among\nUS residents and summarizes information on one additional case with\nlaboratory evidence of infection with the SARS-associated coronavirus\n(SARS-CoV).\nDuring 1 Nov 2002--23 Apr 2003, a total of 4288 SARS cases were reported to\nWHO from 25 countries, including the United States; 251 deaths\n(case-fatality proportion: 5.8 per cent) have been reported (1). In the US\nas of 23 Apr 2003, a total of 245 SARS cases were reported to CDC from 37\nstates. Of these, 39 (16 per cent) had illnesses characterized by the\npresence of pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome consistent\nwith the interim US surveillance case definition for probable SARS (2). The\nremaining 206 (84 per cent) had fever and respiratory symptoms. Of the 39\nprobable SARS patients, 37 (94 per cent) had traveled to mainland China,\nHong Kong, Singapore, Hanoi, or Toronto; one (3 per cent) was a health care\nworker (HCW) who provided care to a SARS patient, and one (3 per cent) was\na household contact of a SARS patient. 27 (69 per cent) of the probable\nSARS patients were hospitalized, and one (3 per cent) required mechanical\nventilation.\nAs of 23 Apr 2003, of the 245 reported SARS cases, 45 (18 per cent) have\ndiagnostic SARS-CoV laboratory findings (positive findings based on\ndetection of antibody to SARS-CoV in serum; evidence of virus in\nrespiratory specimens by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction\nanalysis; or negative findings based on absence of antibody to SARS-CoV in\nconvalescent serum obtained >21 days after symptom onset). 39 reported\ncases (32 suspect and 7 probable based on SARS case definition) tested\nnegative for SARS-CoV; 6 have been identified with laboratory-confirmed\nSARS-CoV infection, all of which were classified as probable cases. 5 of\nthese 6 patients were described previously (3). Clinical information for\nthe one additional patient and the related public health investigation and\nactions are summarized below.\nPennsylvania\nOn 3 Apr 2003, a man aged 52 years developed symptoms including fatigue,\nmyalgia, headache, chills, and sweating. The patient had diarrhea on 5 Apr\n2003 and sought care at the emergency department (ED) of hospital A on 6\nApr 2003. A temperature of 100.7 F (38.2 C) was recorded, but diagnostic\ntesting was not performed, and he was discharged with a diagnosis of acute\nviral syndrome. By 10 Apr 2003, despite initiation of oral amoxicillin, his\nsymptoms progressed to include a dry cough, prompting him to visit his\nprimary-care provider. He had no fever or abnormal findings on physical\nexamination. A chest radiograph was normal. On 14 Apr 2003, the patient\nwent to the ED of hospital B with dehydration, cough, and severe shortness\nof breath. Bilateral interstitial infiltrates were present on chest\nradiograph. In the ED, he was identified as a suspect SARS patient about\n2.5 hours after arrival. He was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis\nof atypical pneumonia and possible SARS, and was placed in an isolation\nroom with negative pressure. Serum samples collected on 15 Apr 2003 (day 12\nof illness) demonstrated SARS-CoV antibodies. The patient received\nsupportive care and antibiotic treatment (levofloxacin for pneumonia and\nmetronidazole for diarrhea associated with laboratory-confirmed\n_Clostridium difficile_). By 17 Apr 2003, the patient's shortness of breath\nimproved considerably, and he was discharged on 21 Apr 2003.\nThe patient had traveled to Toronto, Canada, for a religious retreat during\n29--30 Mar 2003; the event has been linked to subsequent SARS cases among\nthe attendees (4). On 17 Apr 2003, a CDC team traveled to Pennsylvania to\nassist the Pennsylvania Department of Health in its investigation of this\npatient and his contacts. 23 HCWs (from hospitals A and B, the physician's\noffice, and the outpatient laboratory) who had contact with the patient\nbefore he was isolated in the hospital were evaluated for their types and\ndurations of contact with the patient, their use of personal protective\nequipment, and their subsequent health. 6 HCWs with unprotected, close\ncontact were furloughed for 10 days after exposure and advised to monitor\ntheir temperatures twice daily and to report fever and respiratory symptoms\nto the hospital's occupational health clinic. The 6 furloughed HCWs\nincluded 3 people from hospital B exposed on 10 Apr 2003 and 3 people from\nhospital B exposed on 14 Apr 2003. While furloughed, 2 HCWs had mild\nsymptoms (sore throat, rhinorrhea, mild cough, or headache), which resolved\nwithout treatment. 2 additional HCWs (one each from hospital B and the\noutpatient laboratory) who had mild respiratory symptoms subsequently were\nfurloughed from work, although neither had fever >100.4 F (>38.0 C) or\nevidence of SARS on clinical evaluation. After the man was identified as a\npotential SARS patient, HCWs in hospital B used fit-tested N95 respirators\nand wore gowns and gloves but did not wear eye protection.\nThe patient had close contact with 4 family members before SARS was\ndiagnosed. Beginning 9 Apr 2003, the patient and his family members\nreported intermittently wearing surgical masks during close contact. One\nfamily member reported illness consistent with the case definition for\nsuspect SARS, but the symptoms began before contact with the index patient;\nthis family member's illness has resolved and people who had contact with\nthis family member are being monitored. Among 6 additional non-family\ncontacts, one reported new respiratory symptoms since exposure, but\ncontinues to be without fever or other symptoms of SARS. The investigation\nis ongoing and SARS-CoV testing of specimens from all contacts is under way.\nMMWR Editorial Note:\nThe majority of suspect and probable cases of SARS in the United States\ncontinue to be travel-associated, with only limited secondary spread to\ncontacts such as family members and HCWs. Toronto has been added to the\nlist of areas with suspected or documented community transmission of SARS\nincluded in the interim US SARS case definition (2). SARS transmission in\nToronto has been limited to a small number of hospitals, households, and\nspecific community settings. In particular, cases of SARS have been\ndocumented among some members of a religious community who attended a large\ngathering in Toronto in late March [2003]; some of these people infected\nmembers of their households and other close contacts (4). In response to\nthese reports, CDC recommended that US travelers to Toronto observe\nprecautions to safeguard their health, including avoidance of places in\nwhich SARS is most likely to be transmitted (such as Toronto health care\nfacilities) (5). The Pennsylvania resident who attended this religious\nmeeting is the only reported US patient with SARS associated with travel to\nToronto. The availability of diagnostic testing for SARS-CoV is critical to\nthe more precise characterization of the epidemiology and clinical spectrum\nof the SARS epidemic, both worldwide and in the US. Many US patients,\nparticularly those with milder clinical illness, have tested negative for\nSARS-CoV, reflecting the low specificity of the current case definition,\nwhich captures people with respiratory infections caused by other\ninfectious agents, and underscoring the importance of obtaining\nconvalescent serum samples to make a final determination about infection\nwith SARS-CoV. CDC is planning to update its interim surveillance case\ndefinition for SARS to include laboratory criteria in addition to the\nclinical and epidemiologic criteria.\nCareful attention to infection control precautions, both in home and health\ncare settings, remains critical to containment of SARS. Symptomatic people\nshould use infection control precautions to minimize the potential for\ntransmission and should seek health care evaluation (6). Patients should\ninform health care providers about the symptoms in advance so arrangements\ncan be made, if necessary, to prevent potential transmission to others in\nthe health care setting. Patients in ambulatory settings should be screened\npromptly for fever, respiratory symptoms, recent travel, and close contact\nwith SARS patients (7). The investigations summarized in this report\nsuggest that, although both patients and health care providers are aware of\nappropriate infection control precautions, additional efforts are needed to\nensure that recommended precautions are instituted immediately when SARS is\nsuspected and that such precautions are used consistently and correctly\nthereafter.\nReferences\n1. Available\nat <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/triage_interim_guidance.htm>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As of 24 Apr 2003 WHO has reported a cumulative total of 4439 probable\ncases and 158 deaths attributable to SARS. In today's update [1][C] there\nis more information about the outbreak in China, including the fact that\nprobable cases of SARS have now been reported from 21 provinces, with\nsuspected cases reported from an additional 5 provinces. From available\ndata, a cumulative total of 2422 probable cases of SARS have been reported\nby China, of which 541 cases (22 per cent) were in health care workers.\nWorldwide, cases have been reported in 26 countries. The investigations summarized in this report\nsuggest that, although both patients and health care providers are aware of\nappropriate infection control precautions, additional efforts are needed to\nensure that recommended precautions are instituted immediately when SARS is\nsuspected and that such precautions are used consistently and correctly\nthereafter. Includes cases who are 'discharged' or 'recovered' as reported by the\nnational public health authorities.\n2. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] The list of affected areas can be accessed at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_25/en/> and is unchanged from\nprevious reports.\n[C] Update 39 - Optimism in Viet Nam, caution urged when using diagnostic\ntests 25 Apr 2003 <http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_25/en/>\nViet Nam may soon become the first country to contain SARS. No new cases of\nSARS have been detected in Viet Nam for 17 days in a row, despite a high\nlevel of awareness and good surveillance. Although numerous rumors have\nbeen reported, all have been investigated by WHO and government officials,\nand all suspect cases have been determined to have other causes.\nThe most recent probable case was detected on 8 Apr 2003, bringing the\ncumulative total in Viet Nam to 63 cases. Detection of that case initially\nbrought disappointment, as it occurred after no new cases had been reported\nover an 8 day period. Since the outbreak was first recognized in Hanoi in\nlate February [2003], 5 deaths have occurred. As of today, 5 patients\nremain in hospital.\nViet Nam was the second country to experience a SARS outbreak. The first\nwas China, where an outbreak began in Guangdong Province in mid-November\n[2002].\nIf no new cases are detected by 30 Apr 2003 (a date which marks the end of\n2 incubation periods), Viet Nam could become the first country to be taken\noff the list of SARS-affected countries. This achievement would also make\nViet Nam the first country to successfully contain its SARS outbreak.\nSARS was first identified by Dr Carlo Urbani, a WHO infectious disease\nspecialist. Dr Urbani alerted the world to SARS when cases of an unusual\nand severe respiratory disease began appearing among health staff treating\na Chinese-American businessman at the French Hospital in Hanoi. The\npatient, a 48 year old resident of Hong Kong, was admitted to hospital on\n26 Feb 2003 with fever and respiratory symptoms. His recent travel history\nincluded trips to Guangdong Province, Shanghai, and Macao SAR. By 20 Mar\n2003, at least 22 staff at the Hanoi hospital were ill with influenza-like\nsymptoms. 20 had signs of pneumonia, and 2 were in serious condition. The\nChinese-American businessman died of SARS in Hong Kong on 13 Mar 2003. Dr\nUrbani died of SARS in Thailand on 29 Mar 2003. WHO country staff attribute\nViet Nam's success in combating SARS to the quick manner in which the\ncountry initially reacted. 'After Carlo identified the disease, we were\nable to influence the hospital to take the right infection control measures\nvery quickly,' said Pascale Brudon, the WHO representative in Viet Nam.\nThe commitment of the Vietnamese government came soon thereafter, including\nhigh-level support for a WHO coordinated response in Hanoi. 'The first\npriority was to contain the disease and monitor each case,' said Brudon.\nInternational collaboration to combat SARS came quickly via the Japanese\ngovernment and Medecins sans Frontieres, who both worked under the umbrella\nof the WHO initiative in Viet Nam.\nViet Nam was fortunate in that the country had only a single index case,\nwho spent less than 3 days in Hanoi prior to hospitalization. This short\ntime in the community effectively limited opportunities to transmit the\nSARS virus to a contained hospital environment.\nViet Nam's northern Quang Ninh province recently began barring Chinese\ntourists at its overland border with China in an effort to prevent\nimportation of SARS. This move comes ahead of any decision by the\nVietnamese national government to seal its border with China indefinitely,\nas has been recommended by the country's ministry of health.\nWHO is currently working with 4 major laboratories to develop a clinically\nvalidated diagnostic test for SARS. Standard test reagents are being\nestablished to assess the quality of the test and ensure its reliability.\nWhen the test has been developed and clinically validated, it can be used\nreliably to confirm cases of SARS. However, test development and validation\nare expected to take at least another 2 weeks.\nIn the meantime, laboratories in a growing number of countries have\ndeveloped SARS diagnostic tests, often based on information made available\nat the WHO web site. It is extremely important for national authorities and\nmedical and hospital staff to understand the limitations of currently\navailable tests. Their use as the basis for treatment decisions may give a\nfalse sense of security that can allow persons carrying the SARS virus, and\ntherefore capable of infecting others, to escape detection.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 4649 cases with 274 deaths have been\nreported from 26 countries. This represents an additional 210 cases and 11\ndeaths when compared with yesterday. The new deaths were reported in China\n(5) and Hong Kong SAR (6).\nIn China, the Ministry of Health has today informed WHO of 180 newly\nreported probable cases. The breakdown by location is Beijing (103), Inner\nMongolia (23), Guangdong (15), Tianjin (13), Hebei (12), Shanxi (11), and\none case each in Henan, Guangxi, and Sichuan. These latest figures bring\nthe cumulative number of probable cases reported in China to 2601. Among\nhealth workers, a total of 38 new probable cases were reported from Beijing\n(17), Tianjin (9), Hebei (5), Inner Mongolia (5), Shanxi (1), and Guangdong\n(1).\nBeijing reported 3 deaths, Shanxi 1, and Guangdong 1, bringing the\ncumulative number of deaths in China to 115. The fact that cases continue\nto occur in health workers underscores the need for better infection\ncontrol in hospitals. In Beijing, WHO is still awaiting data giving dates\nof onset and the location of cases in order to fully assess the situation.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 25 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 25 Apr 2003\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 25 Apr 2003, there are an additional 22 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 4 health care workers (one from Caritas Medical Centre, one\nfrom Union Hospital, one from Tseung Kwan O Hospital, and one from Tuen Mun\nHospital). This morning,\nsenior Health Canada and Ontario Ministry of Health officials met with WHO\nofficials by teleconference. They reiterated our position that the WHO\ndecision is based on outdated data and asked that they rescind the advice\nimmediately. Health minister Anne McLellan also outlined our objections in\na call today with Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, the director general of WHO.\nHealth Canada does not support the WHO's position; it is safe to travel to\nToronto.\nWe have a clear understanding of the specific settings in which this virus\nhas been transmitted in Canada and confidence in the steps being taken to\nmanage infection control.\nA CDC travel alert provides a more accurate assessment of the situation in\nCanada. It states that: 'Currently, all cases in Toronto are linked to\nToronto's original index case and spread has been through person-to-person\ncontact.
