17 Apr 2003\nTotal: 3947 / 80 / 229 / 1935\nNotes\n1. Includes cases who are 'discharged' or 'recovered' as reported by the\nnational public health authorities.\n2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of (See Affected Areas).\n3. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] Affected areas can be accessed at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_22/en/> and are unchanged from\nprior reports on 21 Apr 2003.\n[C] Update 36 - Situation in Singapore and China 22 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_22/en/>\nSingapore\nSingaporean officials closed a large wholesale fruit and vegetable market\non Sunday following detection of a small cluster of 3 cases linked to the\nmarket. To date, 8 probable and 14 suspect SARS cases have been linked to\nthe market.\nThe first case in the cluster, a 64 year old worker at the market, died on\n12 Apr 2003. His illness has been linked to a 31 Mar 2003 visit to a\nrelative in hospital at Singapore General Hospital. Other probable cases in\nthis cluster include 2 other workers at the market, a taxi driver who\ncarried the first patient from his home to the market, and 4 relatives,\nincluding 3 grandchildren of market workers.\nRigorous contact tracing has linked all 14 suspected SARS cases, associated\nwith the market, to workers, visitors, and family members.\nIn an effort to contain the outbreak, health authorities have issued some\n1200 home quarantine orders. Visitors to the market during the period of 5\nto 19 Apr 2003 have been urged to watch for symptoms and call a hotline for\nimmediate medical assistance should symptoms arise.\nData available to WHO indicate that early diagnosis and prompt supportive\ncare improve clinical prognosis. As of today, Singapore has reported 186\nprobable SARS cases, with 16 deaths. Tracing and follow up of contacts and\nisolation of patients in designated wards of a single SARS hospital have\nbeen key features of the government's response to SARS.\nChina\nChinese authorities have now reported a cumulative total of 2001 SARS\ncases, with 92 deaths. Of the 482 cases reported in Beijing, 78 are said to\nbe health care workers. In the first reports of atypical pneumonia in China\nsubmitted in mid-February [2003], about 30 per cent of cases were said to\nbe among health care workers.\nRecent reports indicate that SARS has now spread to some of China's poorest\nprovinces, including western Guangxi, northern Gansu, and Inner Mongolia.\nChinese authorities have announced plans to send SARS prevention teams to\nShanxi, Inner Mongolia, Henan, and Ningxia, where cases have also been\nrecently reported, as well as to Guangdong.\nA WHO team is in Shanghai investigating the extent of the SARS outbreak in\nthe country's largest city. Officials from Beijing, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and\nMacau will meet tomorrow in Beijing to coordinate policies for responding\nto SARS. The meeting underscores the international dimensions of the SARS\noutbreak, which is increasingly being viewed as a problem beyond the\ncontrol of any single government acting alone.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 3947 probable cases with 228 deaths have\nbeen reported to WHO from 25 countries. The 11 new deaths were reported in\nChina (6) and Hong Kong SAR (5).\n[Our thanks to Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for continuous monitoring\nof WHO update reports. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 22 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 22 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 22 Apr 2003 (issued jointly by the\nDepartment of Health and the Hospital Authority)\nAs of 1 PM 22 Apr 2003, there are an additional 32 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 10 health care workers (3 from United Christian Hospital, 2\nfrom Prince of Wales Hospital, 2 from Tai Po Hospital, one from Princess\nMargaret Hospital, one from Yan Chai Hospital, and one from Tuen Mun\nHospital). The remaining 22 are other patients and contacts of patients\nwith atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 461 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 25 were discharged today.\n109 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care units.\n5 patients died in Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital (AHNH), Prince of\nWales Hospital (PWH), Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH), and Princess Margaret\nHospital (PMH). This brought to 99 the total number of deaths relating to\natypical pneumonia. The 5 deceased, aged from 66 to 88, include 4 men who\nhave a history of chronic disease and an elderly woman.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases / total no. discharged patients / total no. deaths *\nHealth care workers of hospitals/clinics and medical students: 331 / 122 / ?\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1103 / 339 / ?\nTotal: 1434 / 461 / 99\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of chronic\ndiseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively late stage\nof infection.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 22 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 22 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6360>\n\nSARS situation update 22 Apr 2003\n---------------------------------\nAs of 22 Apr 2003, 6 additional SARS patients have been discharged,\nbringing the total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to 110.\n60 SARS patients remain in hospital; 19 are in intensive care.\nSARS Cases\nTwo more SARS cases have been reported today. One is the 41 year old\ndaughter of the 72 year old man who was admitted as a suspected SARS case\non 19 Apr 2003 and who works in the Pasir Panjang Wholesale Market. The\nother case is a 39 year old inpatient of Singapore General Hospital (SGH)\nward 57.\nUpdate on Pasir Panjang Wholesale Market (PPWM)\nTo date 8 probable SARS cases have been linked to the Pasir Panjang\nWholesale Market:\nPatient 1: 64 year old man who works at the PPWM. He had visited his\nbrother at SGH Ward 58 on 31 Mar 2003. He became unwell on 5 Apr 2003, was\nadmitted to the National University Hospital (NUH) on 8 Apr 2003 and died\nat Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) on 12 Apr 2003 [index case from PPWM\nrelated to SGH cluster/transmission? - Mod.MPP].\nPatient 2: 54 year old taxi driver who ferried patient 1 from his home to\nPPWM on 5 Apr 2003. He became unwell on 14 Apr 2003 and was admitted to\nTTSH on 18 Apr 2003.\nPatient 3: 45 year old man who works at PPWM. He became unwell on 8 Apr\n2003 and was admitted to TTSH on 16 Apr 2003.\nPatient 4: 45 year old who works at PPWM. He became unwell on 20 Apr 2003\nand was admitted on 21 Apr 2003.\nPatients 5-7: The 3 grandchildren (aged 4, 8, and 9 years) of a 72 year old\nman who was admitted as a suspect SARS case on 19 Apr 03 and who works at\nthe PPWM. The 3 children became unwell on 15 and 16 Apr 2003 and were\nadmitted to TTSH on 19 Apr 2003.\nPatient 8: 41 year old daughter of a 72 year old man who was admitted as a\nsuspect SARS case on 19 April 03 and who works at the PPWM.\nCases 2 to 7 are in a stable condition; patient 1 who died on 12 Apr 2003.\nIn addition to the 8 probable cases, 14 suspected SARS cases linked to the\nmarket have been admitted: 8 people with direct links to the PPWM (3\nworkers and 5 visitors) and 6 of their family members. Among the family\nmembers are 2 children, aged 18 months and 10 years, respectively. So far,\n1204 home quarantine orders have been issued.\nKandang Kerbau Hospital Women's and Children's Hospital (KKH): a 16 month\nold toddler admitted to KKH for severe asthma died on Tuesday, 15 Apr 2003.\nThe child died from severe asthma and lung infection, leading to acute\nrespiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Postmortem findings confirm that this\nchild died from ARDS. To date, tests for coronavirus are negative. A\nspecimen taken from the child's airway showed the presence of adenovirus.\nSiblings of the toddler were admitted to TTSH for observation. A child who\nshared a cubicle with toddler at KKH was admitted to TTSH for observation\nof pneumonia. All 3 children have been discharged well from TTSH. The older\nsibling of the toddler was also found to have adenovirus.\nAdenovirus is not a new virus, but neither is it a common respiratory\nvirus. It is one of several causes of community-acquired pneumonia. People\ninfected with adenovirus usually have symptoms such as cough, high fever,\nand red eyes. ARDS is also not new. KKH sees about 6 cases a year. The\nusual causes of ARDS include viral infection, severe pneumonia, near\ndrowning, and aspiration pneumonia (choking). The mortality rate for ARDS\nis up to 80 per cent.\nSummary of SARS cases\nDischarged: 110\nHospitalised: 60 (including 19 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 14 + 2 (pending postmortem findings)\nTotal: 186\nSuspected: 87 (including 5 children under 18 years)\nUnder home quarantine: 1798\n[The identification of adenovirus infection in the infant death related to\nARDS serves as a reminder that other causes of ARDS continue to occur\nduring the current outbreak of SARS. This also serves as a reminder that\nSARS is still a diagnosis of exclusion, after other etiologies have been\nruled out. We still do not have laboratory diagnostic tests to confirm\nSARS. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[4]\nDate: 22 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Taiwan - CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://203.65.72.83/En/dpc/ShowPublication.ASP?RecNo=865>\nTaiwan SARS update(22 Apr 2003)\n-------------------------------\nPremier Yu announced yesterday that beginning on 23 Apr 2003, all\npassengers will be required to have their temperature checked before\ndeparture. He reminds the public to follow the precautionary measures to\nprotect themselves and others from SARS infection.\n[The] Department of Health, Hong Kong announced that a flight attendant who\nhad been on duty for the flight CX714 from Singapore to Hong Kong was\nidentified as a probable case of SARS. Taiwan CDC urges those who were on\nthe same flight to contact their local health authorities for further\nevaluation.\nAs of 9:00 AM 22 Apr 2003, there were 196 possible SARS cases reported: 28\nprobable, 46 suspected, 87 excluded, and 35 pending. In accordance with WHO\nguidelines, 20 of the 28 probable cases and 31 of the 46 suspected cases\nhave been discharged to home quarantine, while the remaining 8 probable\ncases and 15 suspected cases are still being cared for in negative pressure\nrooms. A total of 103 possible SARS cases have been discharged from hospitals.\nSince the Taiwan SARS Advisory Committee meeting is re-scheduled to be 3\ntimes per week, it is anticipated that the update information may be\nreleased at the same frequency.\nAs of 21 Apr 2003, a total of 1909 close contacts of probable SARS cases\nhad been given home quarantine notifications; 1579 of them have completed\ntheir quarantines [330 are still under quarantine - Mod.MPP].\nOn 21 Apr 2003, 7 passengers at CKS International Airport [Taiwan\nInternational Airport] had fever, but they were not required [to undergo]\nfurther evaluation. A total of 27 passengers had fever since 10 Apr 2003,\nand 5 of them were reported as possible cases: 2 suspected, 2 pending, and\n1 excluded.\n******\n[5]\nDate: 22 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada 21 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/numbers.html>\n\nCanadian SARS update 21 Apr 2003 5:00 PM\n----------------------------------------\nAs of 21 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 316 probable or\nsuspect cases of SARS in Canada, with 14 deaths. To date, transmission has\nbeen limited to specific transmission settings such as households,\nhospitals, and specific community settings. The details of the cases to\ndate are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 135 probable and 124 suspect cases.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable and 41 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nSo far, 129 people have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario. These\npeople were treated as suspect cases or as probable cases. These numbers\nare accurate as of 1:00 pm. Eastern Daylight Saving Time, 21 Apr 2003. For\nspecific information on the provincial numbers, please contact the\nappropriate provincial health department.\nThe World Health Organization has concluded that the coronavirus is the\ncause of SARS. Health Canada's data are still unable to allow us to come to\nthat conclusion; however, national and international laboratory testing and\ncollaboration are ongoing.\n[CDC added an interim travel advisory to Toronto, Ontario, Canada to the\nwebsite on 21 Apr 2003, which can be read at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/travel/other/sars_can.htm>. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[6]\nDate: Tue, 22 Apr 2003 14:55:25 +0430 (IRST)\nFrom: Ali Karami <alika95@nrcgeb.ac.ir>\n\nConcerning Dr Compton's question about survival of human coronavirus in the\nenvironment a material safety data sheet about human coronavirus states:\nName: Human coronavirus\nSection II - Health Hazard\nPhysical inactivation: Sensitive to heat\nSurvival outside host: Survives up to 24 hours on metal surfaces at ambient\nconditions\nDate prepared: March 2001\nPrepared by: Office of Laboratory Security, PPHB\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/msds-ftss/msds83e.html>\n--\nDr Ali Karami\nBagyatallah University of Medical Science\nTehran- IRAN\n<alika95@nrcgeb.ac.ir>\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Karami for this additional background information.\nAs Mod. CP pointed out on 21 April (in SARS - worldwide (61): cases\n20030421.0977), the route of transmission of a virus will affect the\nduration of survival of infectious material in the environment, and in the\ncase of the SARS virus, there may well be more than one route of\ntransmission. The SARS virus is not closely related to the 2\nwell-characterized human coronaviruses, which differ in stability. The SARS\nvirus may well differ from both of them. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[7]\nDate: 22 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n\n[A] China from the NY Times 22 Apr 2003\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/22/international/asia/22CND-SARS.html>\nReported cases in Beijing of the dangerous new respiratory disease have\nincreased sharply again in the past 2 days, climbing by 249 to 588, as the\ngovernment has continued its belated campaign to provide honest figures and\nearn public trust. The number of confirmed cases in Beijing as of 8 PM on\nMonday rose to 588, including 28 deaths, according to the New China News\nAgency in a dispatch on Monday afternoon.\nThe sudden increase in official figures did not reflect a major surge in\nillness, but the confirmation of suspected cases 'after further\nexamination,' the agency reported. [There were reports of 402 suspected\ncases in the first report from China, with increased case numbers from\nBeijing -- see ProMED-mail posting SARS - worldwide (60): cases\n20030420.0972 - Mod.MPP] The number of patients in the city labeled as\nsuspect cases, meanwhile, rose to more than 600 due to 'improved\nsurveillance and reporting efforts,' the news agency said.\nThe national total of diagnosed SARS cases -- as of 9:20 PM on Monday,\naccording to another report by the official news agency -- was 2158, with\nanother 918 suspect cases. 97 patients had died. Apart from Guangdong and\nBeijing, a few cases have now been reported in each of 14 other provinces\nor municipalities.\n[B] India from the International Herald Tribune 22 Apr 2003\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/94037.html>\nIn India, a bride infected with SARS, who insisted on celebrating her\nwedding against the advice of doctors, may have infected guests along with\nthe groom and the priest, health officials in the state of Maharashtra\nsaid. That the Indian wedding took place with a SARS infected bride showed\nhow ill-prepared the country remains for combatting the disease, said\nSanjeev Malik, secretary-general of the Indian Medical Association.\nFollowing the ceremony at a Methodist Church in Pune, about 160 kilometers\n(100 miles) southeast of Bombay, the bride was immediately sent to join her\nmother and brother in a hospital isolation unit while health officials\nquarantined 25 members of the wedding party. The bride and her mother had\ntested positive for the disease after coming in contact with the bride's\nbrother, the second confirmed case of SARS in India. He had traveled for\nthe wedding from Jakarta via Singapore, health officials said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's worldwide update from WHO gives a cumulative total of 3947\nprobable cases with 228 deaths, reported from 25 countries. Noteworthy is\nthe mention/discussion of multilateral meetings between health officials\nfrom Beijing, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Macau scheduled for 23 Apr 2003 in\nBeijing to coordinate policies for responding to SARS. Taking into account\nprior political impediments, such a meeting is a sign of the seriousness of\nthe countries in the region towards developing a coordinated effort for\ndisease control measures.\nThe lay press have been covering the apparent increases in case fatality\nrates observed during the course of this outbreak. Some have commented on\nhow unusual this is, as the usual situation is a decrease in the case\nfatality rate as increasing numbers of cases are reported, including milder\nclinical presentations. The Health Canada data presented in [5] above are\nworth a comment. With 14 deaths reported, the case fatality rate is 4.4 per\ncent if one uses all suspected and probable cases reported as the\ndenominator (316); but is 10.1 per cent if one uses only probable cases\nreported (129) as the denominator. A key distinction between a suspected\ncase and a probable case is the presence of pneumonia on chest radiograph\nin the definition of a probable case. This factor alone makes the\ndenominator of probable cases likely to be those with a more serious\nclinical presentation, and eliminates potential milder clinical\npresentations from the 'pool of cases' used as the denominator for the\ncalculation of the case fatality rate.\nKeeping this in mind, until we are able to confirm cases of SARS with\ncertainty -- and until we are able to confirm milder clinical presentations\nas due to the same etiologic agent as the one responsible for the more\nsevere cases of pneumonia that meet the clinical and epidemiological\ncriteria for probable case of SARS -- we may continue to show apparently\nhigher case fatality rates. Another point to keep in mind is that at\npresent, the denominators in use are 'all cases', not just cases whose\nfinal outcomes are known; hence the denominator contains many cases whose\nfinal outcomes are unknown. The proportions of these cases who will recover\nor die is presently unknown -- another caution in current interpretations\nof reported case fatality rates.\nIn the news briefs section, the numbers of reported cases in China is\ngreater than the number contained in today's WHO update, which probably\nreflects reporting after official reports were sent to WHO for 22 Apr 2003\n(one of the challenges in presenting 'real-time data' when dealing with a\nworldwide outbreak involving all time zones of the world - (see [7][A]).\nThe last sentence mentions cases reported from 14 provinces within China.\nGiven the size of the country and its population, it would be of interest\nto see regular official reports giving disease occurrence by province where\ncases have been reported/identified. To date, we do have information that\ncases have been occurring in the north and the west of the country, in\nprovinces that border other countries where cases have not as yet been\nreported.\nAdditional information on the reported cases from India in the news briefs\nsuggests local transmission, as the newer cases had close contact with\nanother suspected case with a history of travel through Singapore. None of\nthese additional cases in India (3) has been reported to WHO as probable\ncases in today's update. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Keeping this in mind, until we are able to confirm cases of SARS with\ncertainty -- and until we are able to confirm milder clinical presentations\nas due to the same etiologic agent as the one responsible for the more\nsevere cases of pneumonia that meet the clinical and epidemiological\ncriteria for probable case of SARS -- we may continue to show apparently\nhigher case fatality rates. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR of China occurred in a case\nmedically transferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] Affected areas - can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_23/en/> and is unchanged from\nprior postings.\n[C] Update 37 - WHO extends its SARS-related travel advice to Beijing and\nShanxi Province in China and to Toronto Canada 23 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_23/en/>\nAs a result of ongoing assessments as to the nature of outbreaks of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Beijing and Shanxi Province, China,\nand in Toronto, Canada, WHO is now recommending, as a precaution, that\npeople planning to travel to these destinations consider postponing all but\nessential travel. This temporary advice, which is an extension of travel\nadvice previously issued for Guangdong Province and Hong Kong SAR, China\nwill be reassessed in 3 weeks.\nSubsequent information from the Chinese government about the magnitude of\nthe SARS outbreaks in Beijing and Shanxi Province has been reviewed by WHO.\nThis assessment has considered the size of the outbreak, including both the\nnumber of prevalent cases and the daily number of new cases, the extent of\nlocal chains of transmission, and evidence that travellers are becoming\ninfected while in one area and then subsequently exporting the disease\nelsewhere. On the basis of this assessment, WHO is extending its 2 Apr 2003\ntravel advice to include Beijing and Shanxi Province.\nUsing the same criteria, WHO has assessed the SARS situation in Toronto,\nCanada. The outbreak in this area has continued to grow and has affected\ngroups outside the initial risk groups of hospital workers, families,\nvisitors, and other close person to person contacts. In addition, a few\npeople with SARS, now in other countries in the world, appear to have\nacquired the infection while in Toronto. On the basis of this information,\nWHO is also including Toronto in the extension of its SARS-related travel\nadvice.\nThis advice will be re-examined in 3 weeks time, which is twice the maximum\nincubation period of SARS. The WHO travel advice is issued in order to\nprotect public health and reduce opportunities for further international\nspread. SARS is a new disease, first recognized in late February [2003],\nthat has spread along the routes of international air travel. As of 22 Apr\n2003, a cumulative total of 3947 cases had been reported from 25 countries\non 5 continents. Precautionary measures aim to reduce the impact of SARS\nand contain the disease while it is still in a relatively early stage.\nThe SARS situation is assessed daily to determine whether other areas need\nto be included in the travel advice and if additional precautionary\nmeasures are required.\n[ProMED-mail thanks Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for monitoring WHO\nreports. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 23 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 23 Apr 2003\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 23 Apr 2003, there are an additional 24 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 4 healthcare workers (2 from Princess Margaret Hospital, one\nfrom Prince of Wales Hospital, and one from Caritas Medical Centre). The\nremaining 20 are other patients and contacts of patients with atypical\npneumonia.\nA total of 522 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 61 were discharged today.\nThere are also 133 recovering patients who are in convalescence and\npreparation for discharge. 110 patients are receiving treatment in\nintensive care units.\n6 patients died in Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital (AHNH), Princess\nMargaret Hospital (PMH), and Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH) This brought to\n105 the total number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia.\nThe 6 deceased, aged from 34 to 81, include 4 men and 2 women. 3 of them\nhave a history of chronic disease. [There were 2 deaths in otherwise\nhealthy individuals under the age of 50 - Mod.MPP]\nCumulative no. cases / total no. discharged patients / total no. deaths*\nHealth care workers of hospitals/clinics and medical students 335/ 124/ ?\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1123/ 398/ ?\nTotal: 1458 **/ 522/ 105\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of chronic\ndiseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively late stage\nof infection.\n** There are 133 recovering patients in convalescence.\n[A daily SARS bulletin with epidemiological information on the outbreak in\nHong Kong is available at the Hong Kong Department of Health website\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/ap.htm>. The epidemic curve current as of 22 Apr\n2003 presents the number of cases by date of onset. Numbers of cases peaked\nwith dates of onset 24 and 25 Mar 2003. The shape of the curve suggests\ndecreased transmission over the past week, but caution should be exercised\nin interpretation, as it is too soon to draw firm conclusions, given\ndelayed presentation of cases to the health sector, 'non-classical' (if one\ncan use this term here) presentation of symptoms, and other possible\nvariables that might influence the appearance of new areas of transmission.\n- Mod.MPP]\n******\n[3]\nDate: 23 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6380>\n\nSARS situation update 23 Apr 2003 [edited]\n---------------------------------\nAs of 23 Apr 2003, 58 SARS patients remain in hospital. There are 3\nadditional SARS cases reported today. One case of SARS died today -- a 74\nyear old male inpatient of Singapore General Hospital (SGH) Ward 58.\nThe 3 additional cases are:\n- a 28 year old female staff nurse from National University Hospital (NUH),\nwho was a contact of the NUH SARS patient admitted to NUH on 8 Apr 2003,\ntransferred to [Tan Tock Seng Hospital] TTSH on 9 Apr 2003, and who died on\n12 Apr 2003;\n- a 60 year old woman who is a friend of a probable SARS case; and\n- a 68 year old woman; investigations are still underway to determine her\nsource of infection.\nUpdate on Pasir Panjang Wholesale Market (PPWM)\nThere are no new probable cases linked to the Pasir Panjang Wholesale\nMarket. There are 14 suspected SARS cases linked to the market who have\nbeen admitted, comprising 8 people with direct links to the market (1\nworker and 7 visitors) and 6 of their family members. Among the family\nmembers are 2 children, aged 18 months and 10 years.\nUpdate on Jurong Shipyard workers\nA 47 year old Malaysian who lived and worked in Singapore was admitted to\nAlexandra Hospital on 12 Apr 2003 for pneumonia and later transferred to\nintensive care at TTSH, where he died on 13 Apr 2003. He had travelled to\nPontian, Johore from 24 to 30 Mar 2003 to attend his father's funeral and\nreturned to Singapore on 31 Mar 2003. He was a welder in Jurong Shipyard.\nLaboratory investigations have revealed that he had a pneumococcal blood\ninfection and postmortem samples of the lung, spleen, intestine, and lymph\nnodes were negative for coronavirus. His death has been determined to be\nnon-SARS related.\nIt was reported that another Malaysian Jurong Shipyard worker, who lived in\nJohore, was classified by the Malaysian health authorities as an imported\nSARS case from Singapore. His last day in Singapore was on 25 Mar 2003, and\nhe became ill on 11 Apr 2003. It is therefore unlikely that he was infected\nin Singapore, as this would give an incubation period of 17 days.\nInvestigations have revealed that the 2 cases are not linked to each other.\nUpdate on the admissions and discharges (SGH cluster)\nThe SGH cluster of infection in Wards 57 and 58 could be traced to the\nChinese man in his 60s who was previously discharged from TTSH and\nre-admitted to SGH Ward 57 on 24 Mar 2003 and subsequently to Ward 58 on 29\nMar 2003. On 5 Apr 2003, a cohort of staff from Wards 57 and 58 were noted\nto have low-grade fever. As part of the isolate-and-contain strategy, the\ndecision was made to transfer all inpatients from Wards 57 and 58 to TTSH.\nAt the same time, a team consisting of doctors from the Department of\nGeneral Surgery, nurses, and Allied Health workers moved over to TTSH to\ncontinue the care for these patients.\nOn 14 Apr 2003, it was noted that 3 patients in a cubicle in Ward 74 had\nfever. As a precautionary measure, the decision was made to transfer all\npatients from Ward 74 to TTSH. Again doctors and nurses accompanied the\npatients in the move. So far, none of the patients have become probable\ncases and the staff remained well. Since the transfer, no new cases have\ndeveloped in SGH thus far.\nA total of 166 health care workers, patients, visitors, and contacts were\nadmitted to TTSH as a result of the SGH cluster of infections. Of these, 52\nare probable, 65 are suspect, and 45 are under observation. 4 patients are\nnon-SARS. 88 of this cohort have been discharged, leaving 70 still in\nhospital. There were 8 deaths, of whom 5 had multiple medical illnesses.\nA summary of the SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 114\nHospitalised: 58 (including 18 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 15 + 2 (pending further post mortem test results)\nTotal: 189\nSuspected: 95 (including 5 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 2467\n******\n[4]\nDate: 23 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Taiwan - CDC Taiwan [edited]\n<http://203.65.72.83/En/dpc/ShowPublication.ASP?RecNo=867>\n\nTaiwan SARS Update 23 Apr 2003\n------------------------------\nAs of 3:00 PM on 23 Apr 2003, there were 205 possible SARS cases reported:\n38 probable, 50 suspected, 88 excluded, and 29 pending cases. Compared with\nthe previous day, this represents an increase of 9 probable cases,\nconsidered to be a small cluster that occurred in a hospital. Since most\npatients were considered to be infected on B8 and A7 wards, Taiwan CDC\nimmediately asked the hospital to follow the Hospital Infection Control\nGuidance for SARS and to take all precautionary measures, including\nrequiring health care workers to wear masks, disinfecting the hospital,\nstopping medical service for new patients, treating SARS suspected cases in\nthe negative pressure rooms, isolating people who were in close contact\nwith SARS patients, implementing handwashing and health education, etc. In\nan effort to contain the outbreak, Taiwan CDC has issued home quarantine\norders for 12 family members and 61 health care workers. Visitors to the\nHoping Hospital during the last 3 weeks are urged to watch for symptoms and\ncall the toll-free hotline (0800-024582) for immediate medical assistance\nshould symptoms arise.\nIn accordance with WHO guidelines, 21 of the 38 probable cases and 31 of\nthe 50 suspected cases have been discharged to home quarantine, while the\nremaining 17 probable cases and 12 suspected cases are still being cared\nfor in negative pressure rooms. A total of 110 possible SARS cases have\nbeen discharged from hospitals.\nTaiwan CDC announces that an Amoy Garden (Hong Kong) resident came to\nTaiwan and was identified as a probable SARS case. She was discharged from\nhospital without fever for 3 consecutive days and took flight BR857 at 6:27\npm on 22 Apr 2003 back to Hong Kong. Since she has not completed 14 days\nhome quarantine (ordered in accordance with the guideline for patients\ndischarged), Taiwan CDC urges passengers who were on the same flight to\nwatch for symptoms and seek immediate medical assistance should symptoms arise.\nAs of 2:00 PM on 23 Apr 2003, a total of 1980 close contacts of probable\nSARS cases had been given home quarantine notifications; 1639 of them have\ncompleted their quarantines.\n******\n[5]\nDate: 23 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030422_e.html>\n\nSummary of SARS cases, Canada 22 Apr 2003\n-----------------------------------------\nSince 21 Apr 2003, one additional probable case of SARS has been reported\nin Canada (as of 22 Apr 2003). A total of 140 individuals who meet the\nprobable case definition and 184 who meet the suspect case definition of\nSARS have been reported, including 14 deaths. In addition to British\nColumbia and Ontario, which are reporting probable cases, Alberta,\nSaskatchewan, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island are also reporting\nsuspect cases of SARS (Table 1).\nAt the present time, the case fatality rate in Canada is estimated at about\n4.3 per cent of probable or suspect cases (14 of 324 probable or suspect\ncases). Most of the case fatalities have occurred in patients with\nunderlying illness, and nearly all were elderly patients over the age of 70\nyears.\nTable 1: Cumulative number of SARS cases reported in Canada: 22 Apr 2003\nProvince/Territory: probable cases (1) / suspected cases (1) / deaths\nBritish Columbia: 4 / 47 / 0\nAlberta: 0 / 5 / 0\nSaskatchewan: 0 / 1 / 0\nOntario: 136 / 125 / 14 (2)\nNew Brunswick: 0 / 2 / 0\nPrince Edward Island: 0 / 4 / 0\nTotal: 140 / 184 / 14\n(1)These people may be excluded the probable or suspect case list if\nanother cause is identified to fully explain their illness\n(2) 13 of 14 deaths were probable cases, while 1 was a suspect case.\nAnother death, not included in this total count, was a 46 year old woman\nwho died in the Philippines on 13 Apr 2003. It is believed she may have\ncontracted SARS while in Toronto.\nA summary of the current status of probable cases of SARS in Canada as of\n22 Apr 2003 is presented in Table 2. 65 individuals have been discharged\n(46.8 per cent) and of the 59 individuals currently in hospital, 49 (83.1\nper cent) are improving or in a stable condition. In addition, nearly all\nof the suspect cases reported in Ontario, British Columbia, Alberta,\nSaskatchewan, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island have either recovered\nor are presently recovering.\nTable 2: Currently known reported status of probable cases of SARS in\nCanada: 22 Apr 2003\n(n=139, excludes 1 whose status is unknown)\nCurrent Status: Number (per cent) Probable Cases\nHospitalised: 59/139 (42.4 per cent)\nImproving: 14/59 (23.7 per cent)\nStable: 35/59 (59.3 per cent)\nCritical/Deteriorating: 5/59 (8.5 per cent)\nUnknown: 5/59 (8.5 per cent)\nDischarged (1): 65/139 (46.8 per cent)\nAt Home (2): 2/139 (1.4 per cent)\nDeaths: 13/139 (9.4 per cent)\nTotal number of probable cases whose current status is known: 139 (100 per\ncent)\n(1) Includes cases who have either recovered or are recovering\n(2) Refers to individuals who have never previously been hospitalised.\nThe current evidence suggests that respiratory droplet transmission,\nrequiring close contact with a case of SARS, is the predominant mode of\ntransmission. The mean incubation period is 5 days (median 4 days, range 2\nto 10). This estimate is based on data available from 42 probable or\nsuspect cases with a single known contact with a SARS case.\nIn the province of Ontario the majority of cases have been associated with\nspecific transmission settings, such as household, hospital, and specific\ncommunity groups or settings. As of 18 Apr 2003, a total of 20 probable and\n11 suspect cases of SARS have been identified in a religious community\ncluster. 4 members of the index family who are members of the religious\ngroup had contact with a SARS case in the emergency room of a Toronto\nhospital on 16 Mar 2003. 3 of them developed SARS after the exposure, and\nthe infection subsequently spread through their extended family. Key\ntransmission settings include a mass held on 28 Mar 2003, attended by about\n500 members; a seminar on 29 Mar 2003, where 250 members were registered; a\nfuneral visitation for the index case held on 3 Apr 2003; as well as other\nsocial gatherings during and after these dates. Currently, 14 members of\nthe index family, 3 health care workers, and 14 other religious group\nmembers are affected. 1671\nNotes:\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\nAs SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion, the status of a reported case\nmay change over time. This means that previously reported cases may\nbe discarded after further investigation and follow-up.\n1. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a\nnational level, probable cases are reported by all countries except\nthe United States of America, which is reporting suspected cases\nunder investigation.\n2. One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of\nChina occurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n[B] A list of affected areas can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_18/en/> and is unchanged\nfrom prior days.\n[Our continuing thanks to Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for her\nmonitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[C] Update 33 - Update on Hong Kong and China, first SARS case\nreported in India 18 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_18/en/>\nHong Kong: investigation of Amoy Gardens cluster\nThe Hong Kong Secretary for Environment, Transport and Works, in\ncollaboration with 8 other government agencies, has released the\nresults of an extensive investigation of an unusual cluster of SARS\ncases concentrated in the Amoy Gardens housing estate.\nThe investigation, which drew on epidemiological, environmental, and\nlaboratory studies, has identified sewage contaminated with the SARS\nvirus as the probable point source of exposure. Epidemiological\ninvestigation has focused on the role of a 33-year-old man who\ndeveloped symptoms of SARS on 14 Mar 2003 and visited a relative in\nBlock E, Amoy Gardens on 14 and 19 Mar 2003. His symptoms at that\ntime included diarrhea.\nBased on the epidemiology of the outbreak, officials believe that\nthis patient, who is linked to the infection of 2 relatives and 2\nnurses, was the source of the outbreak. Subsequent rapid spread to\nother residents (321 cases of as 15 Apr 2003) is thought to have\ninvolved defective U-traps in bathrooms, an amplifying effect of\nbathroom exhaust fans, a cracked sewer vent pipe serving Block E, and\nan aerodynamic effect in a lightwell to which bathroom windows opened.\nLaboratory investigations confirmed the presence of the SARS virus in\na swab from the toilet bowl in the bathroom of a SARS patient, but\nnot in numerous other environmental samples.\n'This is a plausible hypothesis,' says David Heymann, Executive\nDirector of communicable diseases at WHO. 'This is the kind of study\nthat is needed to find what it is in the environment that is\ntransmitting this disease.' Further work will be needed to reach\nfirm conclusions about the source of the outbreak and the unusual way\nin which infection has spread.\nThe study found no epidemiological or laboratory evidence that the\nSARS virus was transmitted by air, water, or infected dust aerosols.\n'It is reassuring that speculations about a possible airborne\ntransmission have not been borne out by the evidence available to\ndate,' says Heymann. The transmission of SARS within the Amoy\nGardens estate is the first known instance involving a possible\nenvironmental spread of the virus. Thorough multi-disciplinary\ninvestigation of this unusual outbreak, as is now under way, is fully\nwarranted. Once the outbreak is fully understood, the next important\nstep will be to develop measures that can prevent other instances of\nenvironmental spread occurring under similar circumstances.\nChina advises officials on SARS\nChina's top leaders cautioned officials this morning not to cover up\nthe spread of SARS. Yesterday, during an urgent meeting of China's\nhighest ruling body, presided over by President Hu Jintao, Beijing\nexplicitly warned against the covering up of SARS cases and demanded\nthe 'accurate, timely, and honest reporting of the SARS situation,'\naccording to Xinhua, the country's official news agency. China's\nleaders called SARS a serious threat to the nation's reform,\ndevelopment and stability, adding that party and government leaders\nwould be held accountable for the situations in their respective\njurisdictions.\nEarlier this week, the WHO Beijing team estimated that Beijing may\nhave as many as 200 cases of SARS, rather than the 37 officially\nreported. The team recommended that Beijing improve its reporting\nsystem, possibly using as a model procedures followed in Guangdong\nProvince, where the daily SARS reports are considered reliable and\ntransparent. WHO experts also recommended that Beijing revise its\ndefinition of what constitutes a 'suspect' SARS case.\nAt present, many patients reported by Beijing as 'suspect' would be\nclassified as 'probable' according to the case definition set out by\nWHO and used in official notifications of cases to WHO. As WHO\nreports only probable cases in its daily cumulative totals, such a\nchange on the part of Beijing would result in a large increase in the\nnumber of cases notified to WHO.\nFirst SARS case reported in India\nIndia reported its first case of SARS yesterday. The National\nInstitute of Virology in the western coastal state of Goa confirmed\nthe presence of the new coronavirus which causes SARS, in samples\nfrom the patient. He is said to have recovered and is still being\nkept in isolation after visiting Singapore, Hong Kong, and briefly\nstopping over in Mumbai.\nThere have been fears that if the SARS virus reached India, it could\nspread rapidly in the subcontinent's crowded cities and health\nfacilities. WHO officials believe it is good news that the one case\nhas been detected and reported, as this indicates that the\nsurveillance system is on high alert and working well. As has been\ndemonstrated in many countries, prompt detection of new cases, proper\nmanagement, and efficient contact tracing can prevent isolated cases\nfrom infecting others.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 3461 cases with 170 deaths have\nbeen reported from 25 countries on 5 continents. This represents an\nincrease of 72 new cases and 5 deaths since the last WHO update. The\ndeaths occurred in Hong Kong SAR (4) and Singapore (1).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In addition to today's cumulative statistics on worldwide cases and\ndeaths as stated at the end of this piece, there have been 72 new\ncases and 5 deaths reported to WHO in the past 24 hours. Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 20 Apr 2003\nAs of 1 PM 20 Apr 2003, there were an additional 22 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 4 healthcare workers (2 from Prince of Wales Hospital, one\nfrom Caritas Medical Centre, one from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole\nHospital). The remaining 18 were other patients and contacts of patients\nwith atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 409 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 46 were discharged today.\n102 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care units.\n7 patients died among Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital (AHNH), Kwong\nWah Hospital, Princess Margaret Hospital (PMH), Queen Elizabeth Hospital\n(QEH), Tseung Kwan O Hospital (TKO)and Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH). This\nbrought to 88 the total number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia.\nThe deceased include an 88-year-old man and 2 elderly women aged 71 and 75\nrespectively, who have a history of chronic disease. The remaining are 3\nwomen and one man, aged between 35 and 47.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths *\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 315/ 116/\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1065/ 293/\nTotal: 1380/ 409/ 88\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively\nlate stage of infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6320>\n\nSARS Situation Update 20 Apr 2003\nAs of 20 Apr 2003, 4 additional SARS patients have been discharged,\nbringing the total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to 104.\n58 SARS patients remain hospitalised. There is one additional SARS case\nreported today. She is a 28-year-old female visitor who was in contact with\na SARS patient in [National University Hospital] NUH Emergency Department.\nThe SARS patient was admitted to NUH on 8 Apr 2003, transferred to [Tan\nTock Seng Hospital] TTSH on 9 Apr 2003 and died on 12 Apr 2003.\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market\nActive contact tracing is currently underway for persons who might have\ncome into contact with the 3 SARS cases from the Pasir Panjang Wholesale\nMarket. They include their family members, and the [General Practitioner]\nGP and sinsehs [Chinese traditional doctors] that the patients had visited.\nThey will be served home quarantine orders.\nIn addition, as a precaution, all the stallholders and employees at the\nPasir Panjang Wholesale Market will also be placed on home quarantine\norders for a period of 10 days. Persons who are served the Home Quarantine\nOrder must stay at home at all times for the duration stated in the Order.\nIf they breach the order, they will be liable for a fine or jail term. The\ngovernment would provide financial assistance to those served with the Home\nQuarantine Orders for the period of the quarantine.\nThe Ministry of Health would like to strongly urge members of the public\nwho have been to the Pasir Panjang Wholesale Market during the period from\n5 to 19 Apr 2003 and who have a fever or symptoms of muscle ache, cough, or\ndifficulty in breathing, to call the MOH Special Ambulance Hotline at\n9-178-8477 / 9-178-8478 immediately. An ambulance will be despatched to\nbring them for screening at the Emergency Department, Tan Tock Seng Hospital.\nIt is critical that we minimise the risk of community spread of SARS. The\nstrong pre-emptive measures being taken are in line with this, but we also\nneed the full cooperation of the public; those who have visited Pasir\nPanjang Wholesale Market should come forward to TTSH for assessment, as\nsoon as they have fever or feel unwell.\nIt is Safe to go to TTSH\nThe public can be assured that they will not catch SARS by coming to Tan\nTock Seng Hospital for SARS screening or follow-up. Tan Tock Seng Hospital\nis safe because of the stringent infection controls. No TTSH staff looking\nafter known SARS patients have caught the infection after the enhanced\ninfection control precautions were put in place in TTSH. Strict infection\ncontrol measures are in place at TTSH to ensure the safety of those who go\nthere for SARS screening. Masks are given to all patients. All staff wear\nmasks, gowns, and gloves so they cannot infect patients or get infected.\nSpacious waiting areas are provided. Patients with low risks of SARS are\nseen by separate doctors in separate clinics. Patients admitted for\nobservation are provided individual rooms. They are never made to stay with\nother Suspect patients or Probable SARS patients. All precautions are taken\nso that patients are protected from catching the infection.\nSummary of SARS cases\nA summary of the SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 104\nHospitalised: 58 (including 19 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 14 + 2 (pending further post mortem test results)\nTotal: 178\nSuspected: 87 (including 7 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 467\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: NY Times 20 Apr 2003 8:02 AM [edited]\n[A] China Admits a Tenfold Increase of SARS Cases in Beijing\n<http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/science/AP-SARS-Virus.html>\n\nChina reported a jump in SARS deaths on Sunday and a 10-fold increase of\ninfected people in the capital -- an embarrassing admission that cost the\nhealth minister and the Beijing mayor their Communist Party\nposts. Struggling to stop the spread of the disease, officials canceled a\nmajor week-long holiday in May, when tens of millions of people usually go\ntraveling.\nThe demotion of Health Minister Zhang Wenkang and Beijing Mayor Meng\nXuenong came shortly after officials held a 2-hour news conference to\nannounce the sharp increases in SARS cases. Zhang lost his post as\nsecretary of the leading party members' group of the Ministry of Health.\nMeng was removed as the deputy secretary of the party's Beijing Municipal\nCommittee.\nThe government said Sunday the flu-like illness has killed 12 more people\nand that the number of infections in Beijing has soared from 37 to\n346. The new figures raised China's total number of deaths to 79 and its\ncases to 1814, Gao Qiang, an executive vice health minister, said at a news\nconference. 'With such a situation, with more than 300 patients in\nBeijing, the situation is already very serious,' Gao said. He added there\nwere 402 more suspected cases in the capital.\nGao also made a rare admission that his ministry was not properly prepared\nfor the outbreak. The ministry 'has not given out clear instructions or\neffective guidance,' he said. But Gao denied reports that SARS cases were\nintentionally hidden from investigators. 'We have not discovered any\nlocality or place that has intentionally hidden these statistics,' he said.\nIn recent weeks, several nations have urged their citizens to avoid\nunnecessary travel to China. However, the Chinese government continued to\nencourage the public to stick with plans to go on vacations during the\nweek-long May Day holiday, which was to start 1 May 2003. Marking a major\nshift in how China is viewing the SARS danger, Gao said that officials were\ncanceling the vacation period, which has been extended in recent years to\nboost the travel industry and encourage consumer spending. 'The purpose of\nsuch an act is to prevent the massive movement of people and the possible\nspread of the disease,' Gao said. He acknowledged that the advisory could\ndeal a big blow to China's economy. 'I'm sure this measure will mean\nmassive losses in tourism revenue, but people's lives and health had to be\nput above everything else,' Gao said.\nSo far, officials have not detected the spread of SARS in large rural\nareas, he said. He noted that farmers have lower incomes and less access to\nmedical care. If the outbreak hit the countryside, 'the consequences would\nbe grim,' he said.\n[B] China Admits Much Higher Number of SARS Cases\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/20/international/asia/20CND-CHIN.html>\nWith bureaucratic shuffling and an apologetic, 2-hour news conference, a\nsenior health official, .... admitted to the existence of a large number of\npreviously undisclosed SARS patients in military hospitals and revealed\nwhat he called the first aggressive survey of cases in some 70 scattered\nhospitals. 'Accurate figures have not been reported to high authorities in\na timely manner,' he added, though he later argued that incompetence rather\nthan deliberate deceit was the main problem. In an unusual move for such\nsensitive and embarrassing news, the news conference was broadcast live on\na national television channel.\nThe unveiling of markedly higher disease figures as well as the firings\n(perhaps the first of many) capped a tense week in which China's efforts to\nplay down SARS, especially in Beijing, were assailed by experts from the\nWorld Health Organization and questioned by medical whistleblowers here and\nby Beijing residents, who through word of mouth began hearing about far\nmore patients than officials had acknowledged.\nToday, Mr. Gao of the Health Ministry repeatedly tried to heap blame on the\nministry's shortcomings, and to the disarray in Beijing where several\npolitical jurisdictions, including municipal, national, military, and\nothers, overlap but have not coordinated disease-control efforts. As of\ntoday, Beijing city health officials will oversee all anti-SARS measures\nthroughout the urban area, including at military hospitals, Mr. Gao\nannounced. Mr. Gao also expressed concern about the spreading reports of\nSARS in several inland provinces, while some outside experts said the case\nreports from some distant provinces seemed too low. A major source of\nerror in previous Beijing reports was the exclusion of patients in several\nmajor hospitals that are run by the military, but which also hold civilian\npatients. The angry public assertion by a retired military surgeon that\nmore than 100 SARS patients were in the military system and being omitted\nfrom public reports was a major blow to the government's credibility and\ntoday, Mr. Gao revealed that the discrepancy was still greater. Of 353 SARS\npatients still in the hospital on Friday [18 Apr 2003], he said, 235 of\nthem were in military hospitals, a high proportion that no one has explained.\nOver the last week, Mr. Gao said, hundreds of officials were dispatched to\nall of Beijing's hospitals to check for possible SARS patients and to\nverify whether they had been reported to the city or national authorities.\nThey came up with totals that well surpassed the rough estimate of a World\nHealth Organization team, which on Wednesday [16 Apr 2003] caused\nconsternation here by declaring that Beijing had undercounted and that the\ntotal might be in the range of 100 to 200. Mr. Gao urged the public to\nunderstand that the sudden multiplication of cases did not imply a sudden\nnew surge in disease, but rather that the official numbers were catching up\nto reality. 'In days to come, more of the `suspect' cases will be\nconfirmed,' he added. With more complete SARS data only now compiled, Mr.\nGao said, the trend in the epidemic is unclear, and he could not say\nwhether new cases each day are now rising or falling.\n[Byline: Erik Eckholm]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 20 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n[A] Mongolia from VOA news 20 Apr 2003, 11:47 UTC\n<http://www.voanews.com/article.cfm?objectID=13E3640F-F168-41B2-ABB5C590DD5A9905&title=Mongolia%20Adopts%20Tough%20Anti%2DSARS%20Measures&catOID=45C9C78B-88AD-11D4-A57200A0CC5EE46C&categoryname=Asia%20Pacific>\nChina's neighbor, Mongolia, has introduced tough measures to cut the risk\nof infection after 5 people were suspected, but not confirmed, to have the\nvirus. Those being monitored had all visited a hospital in Hohhot, China.\nAlthough they had gone to China for non-SARS related ailments, 4 of the 5\ncame back with a fever.\nDoctor Udval Natsag, second in charge at the Ministry of Health, ....says\nthe Hohhot hospital had several confirmed cases of SARS, and so the\npossibility that the illness has spread north from China's Inner Mongolia\nregion is very real. 'There has been contact with their friends and\nfamily, and Mongolia is a high risk [area], because we have a border with\nInner Mongolia [in China],... many Mongolians travel to Inner Mongolia\nevery day.' In the capital, Ulaanbaatar, public gatherings have been\nbanned, which has forced the shutdown of theaters and movies houses. And at\nnight, there is an eerie calm, as bars and restaurants have been ordered\nshut by 10 PM.\n[B] Canada from Canada.com 20 Apr 2003\n<http://www.canada.com/toronto/story.asp?id=08A84C1A-93F2-488C-B1EE-825A520429D4>\nA new cluster erupted at Sunnybrook and Women's College Health Sciences\nCentre in suburban Toronto, which has treated about half the region's SARS\npatients over the past month. As of yesterday, 4 staff members, including\nat least one doctor, a nurse, and a respiratory therapist, were in\nhospital. Another 8 hospital staff members were sent into home quarantine\nas potential SARS cases.\nOfficials said they believe the [above] infections occurred during\ndifficult intubations, including one [on 13 Apr 2003] that took 4 hours.\nIntubation involves placing a tube down a patient's throat to facilitate\nbreathing. Some staff started feeling symptoms associated with SARS on [16\nand 17 Apr 2003]. The hospital's head of infection, prevention and\ncontrol, said one worker's eye shield slipped during the Sunday intubation\nprocedure, but there is no other known breach of the staff's 'full-droplet'\nprotection. That includes gowns, gloves, eye shields, and N-95 masks. 'We\nwere using what both Health Canada and the (Atlanta-based) Centers for\nDisease Control consider to be maximal precautions for these patients,' she\nsaid, adding 'it's possible some potentially infected staff members were\nnot present at the intubations. We're examining everything we do and we're\nlooking at a number of different options in terms of making that particular\nprocedure safer for the health care workers,' she said. One option is\nanesthetizing patients for intubation to reduce saliva spread.\nThe hospital's head of microbiology, in a conference call with Health\nCanada and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said a CDC\nexpert surprised the others by revealing that the virus can remain potent\non objects much longer than previously thought. '....in their studies, they\nfound that you could still culture viable virus from surfaces after as much\nas 24 hours, which is longer than we normally expect viruses to be able to\nsurvive in the environment.'\n[C] Canada, Ontario from CBC Canada 20 Apr 2003 16:29 EDST\n<http://www.cbc.ca/stories/2003/04/20/sars_train030420>\nA woman thought to be infected with [the virus that causes] severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome was aboard a commuter train travelling west of Toronto\nlast week, public health officials said [today 20 Apr 2003]. She took the\ntrain on 2 separate occasions. Both times she was in a 4-passenger 'pod'\nwith 3 other people who should watch themselves for symptoms, said the\nmedical officer of health for Halton Region. The woman had symptoms of the\nillness when she took the GO Train on 14 Apr 2003, leaving Union Station at\n4:30 PM, heading to Appleby station in Burlington, said [a] Toronto public\nhealth spokesperson. The next morning, the woman took the train again at\n7:32 AM to go to work as a nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital. She had a fever\nand was 'feeling unwell,' but was not coughing. The woman was admitted to\nMount Sinai for treatment of SARS later on [15 Apr 2003].\n[D] China, Shanxi, Zhejiang, Jilin and Liaoning from the Times of India 20\nApr 2003 10:18 PM\n<http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/cms.dll/xml/uncomp/articleshow?msid=43993118>\nSARS has spread to 3 more provinces, while 2 more deaths were reported in\nnorth China's Shanxi province, taking the national toll to 81. A total of\n7 new cases of SARS have been reported in 3 Chinese provinces -- 3 in\nZhejiang (east China), 3 in Jilin, and one in Liaoning, both in northeast\nChina, the official Xinhua news agency reported.\nZhejiang's health bureau publicised the details of the diagnostic process\nand the measures taken with regard to the 3 patients. The SARS experts in Jilin said\nthat they have 3 confirmed [probable] cases and 2 suspected cases.\nMeanwhile, a report from Taiyuan, capital of north China's Shanxi province,\nreported that [as of 19 Apr 2003] 9 people had died of SARS in the province\nand there were 112 registered SARS cases in the province. 11 of these have\nrecovered and been discharged from hospitals.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Today's update reports an additional 22 cases and 7 deaths reported in the\nprevious 24 hours by Hong Kong. Of these 7 deaths, 4 were in otherwise\nhealthy individuals less than 50 years of age. In Singapore, there has\nbeen one new case reported in the previous 24 hours, but there is concern\nabout potential exposure in a large market area. In response, the Ministry\nof Health has closed the market put all market vendors into home\nquarantine, alerted the public of the possibility of exposure, and\nrecommended they seek medical assistance at the SARS reference center (Tan\nTock Seng Hospital) if symptoms of SARS-like illness appear.\nThe news article on the political repercussions in China as a result of an\nunder-reporting of SARS cases in Beijing is highly significant [4]. It\nappears a clear signal to the international community that China is serious\nabout collaboration with the international community with respect to\ndisease surveillance and control, in this case with respect to SARS, but\nmost quite possibly with respect to disease surveillance and control in\ngeneral for the future. This was an unfortunate situation, possibly\ncontributing to increased transmission if the under-reporting and possible\n'denial' of the disease burden was associated with lack of implementation\nof appropriate infection control procedures in the health care setting,\ncombined with a lack of awareness of risk and need to seek early medical\nattention on the part of the general population, thereby having more\npotential contacts contributing to disease transmission. The above article\nat present denies the rumors of actual patient hiding, as was covered in\nthe CNN and Time articles mentioned in an 18 Apr 2003 ProMED-mail posting,\n(SARS - worldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952). Given this occurrence, one\nmight expect to see increases in numbers of cases SARS reported from\nelsewhere in China in the near future as well, if there has been\nintroduction and transmission of the SARS-related coronavirus. It will be\nof interest to see epidemic curves based on dates of onset of illness,\ndemonstrating the true course of the outbreak, as compared with looking at\nnumbers of cases reported each day which will reflect the 'outbreak' of\nreporting, rather than the outbreak of disease.\nThe news article from Canada [5][B] points out continuing concerns related\nto the difficulties in interruption of transmission that are being seen in\nCanada. Apr 2003 16:29 EDST\n<http://www.cbc.ca/stories/2003/04/20/sars_train030420>\n [B] China Admits Much Higher Number of SARS Cases\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/20/international/asia/20CND-CHIN.html>\n Apr 2003, 11:47 UTC\n<http://www.voanews.com/article.cfm?objectID=13E3640F-F168-41B2-ABB5C590DD5A9905&title=Mongolia%20Adopts%20Tough%20Anti%2DSARS%20Measures&catOID=45C9C78B-88AD-11D4-A57200A0CC5EE46C&categoryname=Asia%20Pacific>\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2057-03-25 00:00:00", "1814-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2003-04-20 00:00:00", "2003-05-01 00:00:00", "2021-03-26 00:00:00", "2021-03-28 00:00:00", "2003-04-18 00:00:00", "2003-04-14 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-04-12 00:00:00", "2003-04-08 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Liaoning", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Jilin", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Hong Kong - Department of Health", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203664", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (58): diagnostic tests", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203664", "date": "2003-04-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (58): DIAGNOSTIC TESTS\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sat 19 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organisation (WHO), SARS website, Fri 18 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/testing2003_04_18/en/>\n\nSARS: Availability and Use of Laboratory Testing\n------------------------------------------------\nAs of 17 Apr 2003, research workers in several countries are working\ntowards developing fast and accurate laboratory tests for SARS.\nHowever, until those tests have been adequately field-tested and\nshown to be reliable, SARS diagnosis remains dependant on the\nclinical findings of an atypical pneumonia not attributed to another\ncause and a history of exposure to a suspect or probable case of SARS\nor their respiratory secretions and other bodily fluids. This\nrequirement is reflected in the current WHO case definitions for\nsuspect or probable SARS. However several countries (Canada, France,\nGermany, Hong Kong SAR, Japan, the Netherlands, Singapore, United\nKingdom, and the United States of America) are testing samples for\nsuspected and probable SARS cases in research settings.\nInterpretation of test results\nPositive test results: A positive test result indicates that a SARS\npatient is, or recently was, infected with the SARS virus. The\nspecificity of the different tests still needs to be established.\nNegative test results: A negative SARS virus test does not mean that\nthe patient does not have SARS. The reasons for negative test results\nin a patient with SARS include the following: (1) The patient is not\ninfected with the SARS virus; (2) the illness is caused by another\ninfectious agent (virus, bacterium, fungus) or non-infective cause;\n(3) the test results are incorrect ('false-negative') -- current\ntests need to be further developed to improve sensitivity; (4)\nspecimens were not collected at a time when the virus or its genetic\nmaterial was present (pertains to PCR and cell culture) -- the virus\nand its genetic material may be present for a brief period only,\ndepending on the type of specimen tested; (5) specimens were\ncollected early in the course of the illness and before antibodies\nhad been produced (pertains to ELISA and immunofluorescence assays).\nSampling for research\nTo enhance the future understanding of the SARS disease process, WHO\nrecommends that clinicians collect and store sequential samples from\npatients with SARS for testing when diagnostic tests become readily\navailable. This is particularly important for the first case(s)\nrecognised in countries that have not previously reported SARS.\nGuidelines on sample handling of suspected or probable SARS patients\ncan be found at the website of the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC), United States of America.\nStatus of laboratory tests currently under development\n(1) Antibody tests:\n-- ELISA (Enzyme Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay) detects antibodies in\nthe serum of SARS patients reliably as of day 21 after the onset of\nclinical symptoms and signs.\n-- Immunofluorescence Assays detect antibodies in serum of SARS\npatients after about day 10 of illness onset. This is a reliable test\nrequiring the use of fixed SARS-virus, an immunofluorescence\nmicroscope, and an experienced microscopist. Positive antibody tests\nindicate that the patient was infected with the SARS virus.\n(2) Molecular tests (PCR):\nPolymerase chain reaction( PCR) tests can detect genetic material of\nthe SARS-virus in various specimens (blood, stool, respiratory\nsecretions, or body tissue). [The sequences for oligonucleotide]\nprimers, which are the key components for a PCR test, have been made\npublicly available by WHO network laboratories on the WHO web site.\nThe primers have since been used by numerous countries around the\nworld. A ready-to-use PCR test kit containing primers and positive\nand negative control has been developed. Testing of the kit by\nnetwork members is expected to quickly yield the data needed to\nassess the test's performance, in comparison with primers developed\nby other WHO network laboratories. Existing PCR tests are very\nspecific but lack sensitivity. That means that negative tests cannot\nrule out the presence of the SARS virus in patients. Various WHO\nnetwork laboratories are working on their PCR protocols and primers\nto improve their reliability.\n(3) Cell culture:\nVirus in specimens (such as respiratory secretions, blood, or stool)\nfrom SARS patients can also be detected by infecting cell cultures\nand propagating the virus. Once isolated, the virus must be\nidentified as the SARS virus with further tests. Cell culture is a\nvery demanding test, but the only means to show the existence of a\nlive virus.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 19 Apr 2003\nFrom: Ngiam Shih Tung <stngiam@pobox.com>\nSource: Straits Times Interactive, Sat 19 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://straitstimes.asia1.com.sg>\n\nTesting for the SARS Virus: Hopes - and Realities\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe SARS virus has struck Singapore and Asia with a vengeance. Since\nit was first described in February 2003, more than 3200 individuals\nworldwide have been afflicted with the severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS), and over 150 have [died]. The international medical\nand research communities responded with unprecedented speed so that,\nwithin 2 months, they unequivocally identified the causative agent as\na new coronavirus, now called the SARS virus, and confirmed its mode\nof infection. Just this week, scientists from Canada, Hong Kong,\nSingapore, and Atlanta in the United States each simultaneously\nreported the entire sequence of the SARS virus genetic code. This\nknowledge paves the way for the development of sensitive diagnostics\nand even therapeutics.\nIt was no wonder then that when a DNA-based test to detect the SARS\nvirus was announced, hopes rose. Is there now a single test that can\ndefinitively identify those infected with the virus before the\nsymptoms appear? The answer, however, is more complex than a simple\nyes or no. Although we can now construct an extremely sensitive test,\nfactors beyond human control, such as the natural course of the\ndisease, the timing of viral shedding, and statistical realities,\nwill decide the ultimate usefulness of such a test. In truth, the\nperfect diagnostic test -- which can tell with certainty, with just\none examination, whether someone has a disease or not -- simply does\nnot exist.\nWhat makes a good diagnostic test? First, there is a need to [ensure]\nbiochemical specificity. This means that the chemicals used must\nreact only with the targets in the virus. In the case of the DNA\ndiagnostic test for the SARS viral genes, there is no doubt that\nspecificity is there. Second, there needs to be sensitivity. Again,\nusing current DNA diagnostic approaches (such as polymerase chain\nreaction, or PCR) we can detect down to 500 to 1000 particles per\nmillilitre. Biochemical specificity and sensitivity are real and can\nbe provided now. The difficulty lies, however, in the behavior of the\nvirus. The amount of virus actually shed can vary 10 000-fold in any\none patient, and one million-fold between patients. When and where\nthe virus is shed is also unclear, but we know that there is only a\nwindow of time that the virus can be detected from various body\nfluids -- first in the sputum, then in the blood, and lastly in the\nstool.\nUnlike [influenza] virus, which has been studied for decades, SARS is\nso new that little is known about its infectious course. So, as the\nfirst SARS diagnostic tests are used, we will also be learning how to\nuse them wisely. For example, while a positive SARS-PCR result from\nthe sputum of a sick patient very likely means he has SARS, a\nnegative result may simply mean that we missed a window of viral\nshedding. Therefore, a single negative test does not mean that the\nperson is disease-free. Does a positive test mean that someone is\ninfectious? We simply do not know. Our PCR tests detect viral nucleic\nacids and cannot tell us whether the infectious particle is still\nintact. So if a recovered SARS patient still excretes viral nucleic\nacids in his stool, does this mean he is still infectious? And if so,\nhow infectious? We will need to continue the study of these\nindividuals as we treat them.\nDo we stick with one test 'kit' or use others? As our understanding\nof the SARS virus is still changing day by day, it would be a grave\nerror to believe in one test and not explore others. A simple reality\nis that there are more than 29 000 [nucleotides] in the SARS virus\ngenome. Our current PCR diagnostics only test for 200 to 500 of these\n[nucleotides]. It remains to be determined which genomic segment\n[region; coronaviruses are not segmented genome viruses - Mod.CP]\nwould be the best target for the diagnostic reagent, so changes in\nthe diagnostic tests should be expected. The medical community must\ndevelop a strategy that will quickly operationalise the best test at\nany one time, and have systems to switch when a better one emerges.\nCan we detect people who carry and excrete the virus but who have no\nsymptoms -- that is, asymptomatic carriers? Again, we do not know\nright now, but we need to study this problem immediately. Here,\nhowever, the use of a SARS-PCR test for asymptomatic carriers will be\ndifferent from its use on clinically active and sick patients. The\ndifference is due to statistical and technical realities.\nStatistically, the less likely that the SARS virus is present in a\ntested population (individuals without symptoms), the higher the\nfalse positive rates (that is, the test results indicating that the\nindividual has SARS when he/she does not), lowering the usefulness of\nthe test.\nCost is also a consideration. Testing 100 patients hospitalised for\nSARS symptoms at $200 a test (using a commercial diagnostic test) is\nwell within the means of the health-care system, even if multiple\ntests need to be drawn. But the cost of following 1000 asymptomatic\nindividuals over a single quarantine duration, testing them every day\nfor 10 days, would be astronomical. The cost of the tests alone would\nbe $2 million, and this does not include funding for more laboratory\nworkers, space, and specialised equipment. Within the context of the\npublic health-care system, therefore, the use of commercial\ndiagnostic kits is not financially wise. For this reason, common\nreagents dedicated for public health screening are often used instead\nof commercial kits.\nWith recent diagnostics developments, we have much to hope for in the\nbattle against SARS. The key has been the identification of the virus\nand the sequencing of its genome. These have enabled Singapore and\nothers to develop sensitive diagnostic tests. Who has the best test\nnow is irrelevant because, no matter what, the tests will improve\nover time. Our challenge now is to use these tests to better\nunderstand the course of SARS, and the nature of the infection. Here\nis where the most important message must be taken to heart. We have a\ngood test, but we do not have a clinically 'hardened' test - that is,\na diagnostic that has been battle-tested for a long period of time.\n[Byline: Edison Liu and Ling Ai Ee]\n[Dr Edison Liu is director of the Genome Institute of Singapore; Dr\nLing Ai Ee is a virologist with the Singapore General Hospital and a\nprincipal investigator in the Singapore SARS team.]\n--\nNgiam Shih Tung\n<stngiam@pobox.com>\n[Some of these considerations in the application and interpretation\nof SARS diagnostic tests were discussed in the preceding post (SARS -\nworldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952) by moderator MPP in relation to\na SARS case reported from India with confirmation by PCR. The patient\nwas a New Zealander arriving from Bangkok, which to date has not been\nreported as having areas of local transmission. The point was made\nthat a PCR test is capable of producing not only false negative\nresults (negative when there is a real infection), but also false\npositives (positive when the individual is not infected with the\nvirus). Isolation of virus in cell culture remains the gold standard,\nas it is the only test that indicates (albeit in retrospect) the\nability of an individual to transmit infection. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The patient is not\ninfected with the SARS virus; (2) the illness is caused by another\ninfectious agent (virus, bacterium, fungus) or non-infective cause;\n(3) the test results are incorrect ('false-negative') -- current\ntests need to be further developed to improve sensitivity; (4)\nspecimens were not collected at a time when the virus or its genetic\nmaterial was present (pertains to PCR and cell culture) -- the virus\nand its genetic material may be present for a brief period only,\ndepending on the type of specimen tested; (5) specimens were\ncollected early in the course of the illness and before antibodies\nhad been produced (pertains to ELISA and immunofluorescence assays).
