To enhance the future understanding of the SARS disease process, WHO\nrecommends that clinicians collect and store sequential samples from\npatients with SARS for testing when diagnostic tests become readily\navailable. [Some of these considerations in the application and interpretation\nof SARS diagnostic tests were discussed in the preceding post (SARS -\nworldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952) by moderator MPP in relation to\na SARS case reported from India with confirmation by PCR. For example, while a positive SARS-PCR result from\nthe sputum of a sick patient very likely means he has SARS, a\nnegative result may simply mean that we missed a window of viral\nshedding. Again,\nusing current DNA diagnostic approaches (such as polymerase chain\nreaction, or PCR) we can detect down to 500 to 1000 particles per\nmillilitre. Since\nit was first described in February 2003, more than 3200 individuals\nworldwide have been afflicted with the severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS), and over 150 have [died]. However several countries (Canada, France,\nGermany, Hong Kong SAR, Japan, the Netherlands, Singapore, United\nKingdom, and the United States of America) are testing samples for\nsuspected and probable SARS cases in research settings. For this reason, common\nreagents dedicated for public health screening are often used instead\nof commercial kits.\n --\nNgiam Shih Tung\n<stngiam@pobox.com>\n Interpretation of test results\nPositive test results: A positive test result indicates that a SARS\npatient is, or recently was, infected with the SARS virus. \nNegative test results: A negative SARS virus test does not mean that\nthe patient does not have SARS. We have a\ngood test, but we do not have a clinically 'hardened' test - that is,\na diagnostic that has been battle-tested for a long period of time. Isolation of virus in cell culture remains the gold standard,\nas it is the only test that indicates (albeit in retrospect) the\nability of an individual to transmit infection. This is a reliable test\nrequiring the use of fixed SARS-virus, an immunofluorescence\nmicroscope, and an experienced microscopist. As our understanding\nof the SARS virus is still changing day by day, it would be a grave\nerror to believe in one test and not explore others. Is there now a single test that can\ndefinitively identify those infected with the virus before the\nsymptoms appear? Here,\nhowever, the use of a SARS-PCR test for asymptomatic carriers will be\ndifferent from its use on clinically active and sick patients. Who has the best test\nnow is irrelevant because, no matter what, the tests will improve\nover time. Status of laboratory tests currently under development\n(1) Antibody tests:\n-- ELISA In the case of the DNA\ndiagnostic test for the SARS viral genes, there is no doubt that\nspecificity is there. [The sequences for oligonucleotide]\nprimers, which are the key components for a PCR test, have been made\npublicly available by WHO network laboratories on the WHO web site. The medical community must\ndevelop a strategy that will quickly operationalise the best test at\nany one time, and have systems to switch when a better one emerges. CP]\nwould be the best target for the diagnostic reagent, so changes in\nthe diagnostic tests should be expected. Source: Straits Times Interactive, Sat 19 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://straitstimes.asia1.com.sg>\n\nTesting for the SARS Virus: Hopes - and Realities\n Our PCR tests detect viral nucleic\nacids and cannot tell us whether the infectious particle is still\nintact.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-04-17 00:00:00", "2057-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-02-25 00:00:00", "2058-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "the United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hong Kong SAR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "United", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "United States of America", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bangkok", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Atlanta", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealander", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203665", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (59): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203665", "date": "2003-04-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (59): CASES\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] News briefs\n[A] Saudi Arabia\n[B] Canada - British Columbia\n***********\n[1]\nDate: 19 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n[A] Cumulative number of reported probable (1) cases of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_19/en/>\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002To: 19 Apr 2003, 18:00 GMT+2\nCountry: Cumulative no.case(s)/ no. new cases since last WHO\nupdate/ no. deaths/ no. recovered (2)/ local chain(s) of transmission\n(3)/ date of last report\nAustralia: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ None/ 17 Apr 2003\nBrazil: 2/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None/ 16 Apr 2003\nCanada: 132/ 6/ 12/ 54/ Yes/ 19 Apr 2003\nChina: 1512/ 30/ 65/ 1140/ Yes/ 19 Apr 2003\nChina, Hong Kong SAR (4): 1358/ 31/ 81/ 363/ Yes/ 19 Apr 2003\nChina, Taiwan: 29/ 0/ 0/ 17/ Yes/ 18 Apr 2003\nFrance: 5/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nGermany: 6/ 0/ 0/ 4/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nIndia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nIndonesia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nItaly: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nJapan: 4/ 2/ 0/ 0/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None/ 9 Apr 2003\nMalaysia: 5/ 0/ 1/ 0/ None/ 16 Apr 2003\nMongolia: 3/ 0/ 0/ 3/ None/ 17 Apr 2003\nPhilippines: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None/ 14 Apr 2003\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nSingapore: 177/ 5/ 16/ 100/ Yes/ 18 Apr 2003\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None/ 9 Apr 2003\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nSweden: 3/ 2/ 0/ 0/ None/ 19 Apr 2003\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nThailand: 7/ 0/ 2/ 6/ None/ 18 Apr 2003\nUnited Kingdom: 6/ 0/ 0/ 5/ Yes/ 19 Apr 2003\nUnited States: 220/ 12/ 0/ not available/ Yes/ 18 Apr 2003\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 46/ Yes/ 17 Apr 2003\nTotal: 3547/ 86/ 182/ 1749\nNotes\n1. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a\nnational level, probable cases are reported by all countries except\nthe United States of America, which is reporting suspected cases\nunder investigation.\n2. Includes cases who are 'discharged' or 'recovered' as reported by\nthe national public health authorities.\n3. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in\nwhich local chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas\nare provided on the list of affected areas\n4. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 19 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_19/en/>\nCountry: Area\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Beijing, Guangdong, Hong Kong SAR, Inner Mongolia, Shanxi\nTaiwan Province*\nUnited States of America: Areas not reported*\nUnited Kingdom: London*\nViet Nam: Hanoi\nAn 'affected area' is an area in which local chain(s) of transmission\nof SARS is/are occurring as reported by the national public health\nauthorities.\n*Area with limited local transmission and no evidence of\ninternational spread from area since 15 March 2003 and no\ntransmission other than close person-to-person contact reported.\n[Inner Mongolia has newly been added to the list of affected areas\nsince the last update. - Mod.MPP]\n[C] Update 34 - Unanswered questions: a critical point in the\nevolution of SARS - 19 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_19/en/>\nAs probable SARS cases continue to be reported from a growing number\nof countries, WHO is taking stock of what is known about the new\ndisease, particularly concerning its mode of spread, and what remains\na puzzle.\nThe agent that causes SARS has now been conclusively identified. The\nSARS virus is a new coronavirus unlike any other known human or\nanimal virus in the Coronavirus family. Because the virus is new,\nmuch about its behaviour is poorly understood. Key questions, which\nare undergoing intense study, include stages in the course of\ninfection when virus shedding may be highest, and the various\nconcentrations of virus in different body fluids. Scientists are also\nworking to determine the amount of time the virus can survive in the\nenvironment on both dry surfaces and in suspension, including in\nfaecal matter.\nThe vast majority of countries reporting probable SARS cases are\ndealing with a small number of imported cases. Experience has shown\nthat when these cases are promptly detected, isolated, and managed\naccording to strict procedures of infection control, further spread\nto hospital staff and family members either does not occur at all or\nresults in a very small number of secondary infections. These\nexperiences confirm abundant early evidence that the SARS virus\nspreads, in the vast majority of cases, through exposure to\nrespiratory droplets during close face-to-face contact.\nHowever, information now emerging from outbreaks in Hong Kong and\nCanada is raising some important new questions about SARS. In Hong\nKong, a large and sudden cluster of almost simultaneous cases (321)\nseen in residents of the Amoy Gardens housing estate has raised the\npossibility of transmission from an environmental source.\nIn addition, reports from Hong Kong health authorities indicate that\npatients in this cluster depart in some ways from the previously\nestablished clinical picture. The disease appears to be more severe\nboth in Amoy residents and in related cases among hospital staff.\nAround 20 percent of Amoy-related cases require intensive care,\ncompared with 10 percent seen in non-Amoy cases. Some deaths are now\noccurring in younger, previously healthy persons as well as in the\nelderly and persons with underlying disease. Around 66 percent of\nAmoy Gardens patients present with diarrhoea as a symptom, compared\nwith 2 to 7 percent of cases in other outbreaks.\nSpeculation centres on whether these cases represent infection with\nhigh virus loads, as might occur following exposure to a concentrated\nenvironmental source, or whether the virus may have mutated into a\nmore virulent form. Viruses in the Coronavirus family are known to\nmutate frequently.\nIn Canada, concern has centred around a cluster of 31 suspect and\nprobable cases in members of a charismatic religious group, the\nhealth care workers who have treated them, and close family and\nsocial contacts. The outbreak is particularly disturbing because of\nits potential to move into the wider community. Large meetings of the\nreligious group at 2 events, on 28 and 29 Mar 2003, may have led to\nmultiple additional exposures, especially among the members of this\nclose-knit religious group.\nIntense contact tracing, home quarantine, and close follow-up by\nhealth officials may work to prevent further spread of cases in the\ngeneral community. The index case in this cluster has been traced to\ncontact, in a hospital emergency room, with a subsequently fatal SARS\ncase. The outbreak is regarded as a test case of whether rigorous\ncontact tracing and other stringent public health measures can\ncontain further spread even when very large numbers of persons may\nhave been exposed.\nThis index case has also been linked to 3 of 4 SARS cases\nconcentrated in the same block of a 247-unit condominium in Toronto.\nAs the fourth case could not be linked to direct contact with a SARS\npatient, some speculation arose concerning possible environmental\ncontamination within the building as the source of the fourth\ninfection. However, all 4 cases occurred in early April, with 4 Apr\n2003 being the date of onset of the fourth case. The incubation\nperiod has now passed with no further cases detected. There appears\nto be little risk that the case arose from an environmental source.\nViet Nam\nA week has passed since Viet Nam officials reported a new probable\ncase of SARS. No new deaths have occurred during this period. The\nsituation in Hanoi seems to have stabilized. Following the\nintroduction of infection control measures in the French Hospital,\nthe transmission of SARS appears to have been contained. 10 patients\nare now listed as recovering from SARS, none of whom is listed as in\ncritical condition.\nThe Vietnamese government is considering closing its land border with\nChina in an attempt to prevent the importation of SARS cases. In a\nproposal submitted to the Prime Minister by the Ministry of Health,\nthe 1130 kilometre border with China would be sealed indefinitely to\noverland visitors.\nWHO officials in Viet Nam said earlier this week that while Viet Nam\nappears to have controlled the SARS outbreak within its borders, it\nstill faces the threat of massive importation of the disease from\nChina.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 3547 cases with 182 deaths have\nbeen reported from 25 countries. Compared with yesterday, 12 new\ndeaths, all in Hong Kong SAR, have been reported.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 19 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 19 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 19 Apr 2003, there are an additional 31 patients confirmed\nto have atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals\nearlier. They include 2 healthcare workers (both from Alice Ho Miu\nLing Nethersole Hospital). The remaining 29 were other patients and\ncontacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 363 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and\nhave been discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 41 were\ndischarged today. 109 patients are receiving treatment in intensive\ncare unit.\n12 patients died in Kwong Wah Hospital (KWH), Princess Margaret\nHospital (PMH), Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH), Tseung Kwan O\nHospital (TKO), Tuen Mun Hospital (TMH) and United Christian Hospital\n(UCH). This brought to 81 the total number of deaths relating to\natypical pneumonia. The deceased include 7 men, aged from 71 to 86,\nwho have a history of chronic diseases. The remaining are 3 men and 2\nwomen, aged between 37 and 75. Since 20 Apr 2003 the United States of America is reporting to WHO\nprobable cases of SARS, therefore the number of new cases since last WHO\nupdate is not applicable [in today's report - Mod.MPP].\n[B] Affected areas list - can be accessed at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_21/en/> and is unchanged from\nprevious posting on 19 Apr 2003\n[C] Update 35 - Update on China: New numbers, May Day holiday reduced -- 21\nApr 2003 <http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_21/en/>\nChina\nThe Chinese government today announced a further 109 SARS cases in Beijing.\nThis latest report comes after Sunday's announcement of 339 previously\nundisclosed SARS patients. There is no breakdown of the number of patients\nin regular and military hospitals. The new numbers bring the total of\nconfirmed cases in China to 1959.\nIn an indication that the Chinese leadership is now taking seriously the\nneed for transparency in SARS reporting, the health minister and Beijing\nmayor, both of whom played down the seriousness of SARS, were removed from\ntheir Communist Party posts.\nChina also reduced its traditional week-long May Day holiday to a single\nday, a period when hundreds of thousands of people generally travel\nthroughout the country. 'The purpose of such an act is to prevent the\nmassive movement of people and the possible spread of the disease,' said\nGao Qiang, an executive vice health minister.\nA 6 member WHO team also arrived this morning to investigate SARS in\nShanghai. Shanghai has officially confirmed 2 probable cases of SARS. No\ndeaths have yet been reported in Shanghai.\nThe WHO team will conduct a 4 day probe in which they will confer with\nlocal health authorities, inspect hospitals, and examine measures taken to\nprevent and control the spread of SARS.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 21 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 21 Apr 2003\n--------------------------------------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 21 Apr 2003, there are an additional 22 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 6 health care workers (2 from Princess Margaret Hospital, 2\nfrom Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole, one from Queen Elizabeth Hospital, and\none from Tsuen Wan Adventist Hospital). The remaining 16 were other\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 436 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 27 were discharged today.\n105 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care units.\n6 patients died in Kwong Wah Hospital (KWH), Princess Margaret Hospital\n(PMH), Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH), and United Christian Hospital (UCH).\nThis brought to 94 the total number of deaths relating to atypical\npneumonia. The 6 deceased, aged from 48 to 79, include 2 women and 4 men\nwho all have a history of chronic disease.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths*\nHealth care workers of hospitals/clinics and medical students: 321 / 120 / ?\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1081 / 316 / ?\nTotal: 1402 / 436 / 94\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of chronic\ndiseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively late stage\nof infection.\n******\n[3]\nDate: 21 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore -- Ministry of Health\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6341>\n\nSARS Situation Update 21 Apr 2003\n---------------------------------\nAs of 21 Apr 2003, 64 SARS patients remain in hospital. There are 6\nadditional SARS cases reported today. One is a 63 year old man who was\nadmitted to the National University Hospital (NUH) on 8 Apr 2003 for\nuncontrolled high blood pressure and was a contact of a SARS patient who\nwas admitted to NUH on 8 Apr 2003, transferred to [Tan Tock Seng Hospital]\nTTSH on 9 Apr 2003, and died on 12 Apr 2003.\nThe second case, a 45 year old man, works in Pasir Panjang Wholesale\nCentre. The third case is a 22 year old domestic worker of a patient who\nwas in Singapore General Hospital (SGH) Ward 58. She had attended to her\nemployer while she was in hospital at SGH. The 61 year old employer herself\nwas diagnosed with SARS on 16 Apr 2003.\nThe 3 remaining cases are the grandchildren of a 72 year old man who was\nadmitted as a suspect SARS case on 19 Apr 2003 and works in the Pasir\nPanjang Wholesale Centre. The children are aged 4, 8, and 9 years. One is\nin kindergarten and the other 2 are in primary school. They had not\nattended school since the closure of all national schools and pre school\ncentres on 27 Mar 2003.\nPrecautionary measures in private hospitals\nTo minimise the risk of cross infection between private hospitals, [from]\nTuesday, 22 Apr 2003, all doctors who are employed or working in private\nsector hospitals are required to register to work in only one hospital.\nThis also applies to nurses who are self-employed or from private nursing\nagencies and locum doctors.\nSimilarly, with immediate effect, inter-hospital transfer of inpatients has\nbeen stopped. However, any patients who require specialised care that is\nnot being provided by the hospital in which they have been warded can be\ntransferred to the appropriate public sector hospital for management. For\nemergency medical situations, however, hospitals may call upon the services\nof the specialists required, even if they are not on the registered list\nfor the hospital. Similarly, should the patient require urgent transfer to\nanother medical facility, public or private, for emergency treatment, this\ncan proceed. Similar to current practice in public hospitals, patients\nrequiring re-admission within 21 days of their discharge from a private\nhospital will be re-admitted to the same hospital. The only exception is\nwhere they prefer to be admitted to a public sector hospital, which will be\nallowed due to financial considerations.\nContact tracing for Pasir Panjang Wholesale Centre\nAs of this afternoon, 728 tenants of the Pasir Panjang Wholesale Centre\nhave been contacted. A total of 410 home quarantine orders have been served\nso far. Contact tracing is still in progress.\nSummary of SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 104\nIn hospital: 64 (including 18 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 14 + 2 (pending further postmortem test results)\nTotal: 184\nSuspected: 82 (including 4 children under 18 years)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 793\n******\n[4]\nDate: 21 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) SARS website\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\nReport of SARS cases in the United States\n-----------------------------------------\nData reported to the World Health Organization on April 20, 2003.\nState: Total Cases/ Suspect Cases/ Probable Cases\nAlabama: 1 / 1 / 0\nArizona: 1 / 1 / 0\nCalifornia: 45 / 33 / 12\nColorado: 8 / 6 / 2\nConnecticut: 4 / 2 / 2\nFlorida: 14 / 14 / 0\nGeorgia: 3 / 3 / 0\nHawaii: 5 / 3 / 2\nIllinois: 13 / 12 / 1\nIndiana: 1 / 1 / 0\nKansas: 1 / 0 / 1\nKentucky: 2 / 1 / 1\nMaine: 2 / 2 / 0\nMassachusetts: 12 / 11 / 1\nMichigan: 3 / 3 / 0\nMinnesota: 7 / 7 / 0\nMississippi: 2 / 1 / 1\nMissouri: 2 / 2 / 0\nNevada: 2 / 2 / 0\nNew Hampshire: 1 / 1 / 0\nNew Jersey: 3 / 2 / 1\nNew Mexico: 1 / 0 / 1\nNew York: 26 / 21 / 5\nNorth Carolina: 6 / 6 / 0\nOhio: 11 / 8 / 3\nOregon: 1 / 1 / 0\nPennsylvania: 6 / 5 / 1\nRhode Island: 1 / 1 / 0\nSouth Carolina: 2 / 2 / 0\nTexas: 7 / 7 / 0\nUtah: 5 / 4 / 1\nVermont: 2 / 2 / 0\nVirginia: 6 / 4 / 2\nWashington: 21 / 20 / 1\nWisconsin: 1 / 1 / 0\nTotal: 228 / 190 / 38\n******\n[5]\nDate: Mon 21 Apr 2003\nFrom: Susan Compton <susan.compton@yale.edu>\n\nSurvival of Coronaviruses in the environment\n--------------------------------------------\nProMED-mail post 'SARS - worldwide (60): cases 20030420.0972', quotes a CDC\nexpert as saying that the virus can remain potent on objects much longer\nthan previously thought: '....in their studies, they found that you could\nstill culture viable virus from surfaces after as much as 24 hours, which\nis longer than we normally expect viruses to be able to survive in the\nenvironment.'\nI am unaware of any literature on the environmental stability of human\ncoronaviruses, but rat coronavirus, which causes a pneumonia in rats, when\ndried on plastic and then rehydrated 48 hours later is still viable. The\ndecrease in viral titer is 1000-fold after 24 hours and 10 000-fold after\n48 hours (Laboratory Animal Science 43: 403-4).\n--\nSusan Compton\nResearch Scientist\nSection of Comparative Medicine\nYale University School of Medicine\n<susan.compton@yale.edu>\n[The survival time of the SARS-associated coronavirus in the environment is\nhighly relevant to interpretation of the epidemiology of SARS. Like other\nrespiratory viruses with lipid envelopes coronaviruses are susceptible to\ninactivation by heat, desiccation, lipid solvents, oxidising agents,\nnonionic detergents, and ultraviolet irradiation. Some coronaviruses\nexhibit unexpected (pH (3.0) stability. Survival times will depend on virus\ngenotype (for example, human coronavirus 229E is more thermolabile than\nhuman coronavirus OC43), composition of the carrier and substrate (Susan\nCompton has given an example for rat coronavirus), and specific\ncircumstances (for example, bovine coronavirus can remain infectious in\nmilk for many days). In general respiratory viruses transmitted in aerosols\nor in droplets would be expected to have a limited range and duration of\ninfectivity, whereas viruses transmitted in a more protective medium, such\nas feces, might be expected to contaminate the environment for longer\nperiods. The epidemiological situation in Hong Kong suggests that more than\none route of transmission is being observed in the case of the SARS virus.\n- Mod.CP]\n******\n[6]\nDate: 21 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs\n\n[A] Taiwan (from Channel Asia News)\n<http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/38009/1/.html>\nTaiwan may have registered its first SARS death after an elderly man\nsuspected of suffering from the disease died over the weekend. The resident\nof the offshore island of Kinmen died at Taipei's Veterans General\nHospital. Officials are investigating the case.\n[B] India, Maharashtra (from ) 21 Apr 2003 20:16 IST\n<http://www.rediff.com/news/2003/apr/21sars1.htm>\n3 SARS cases in Maharashtra\n---------------------------\nThree members of a family have tested positive for SARS, according to\nMaharashtra's minister for health, Digvijay Khanvilkar. [The 3], who came\nto India 3 weeks ago, have been isolated in a ward of the Siddhartha\nHospital, he said. The family had visited Jakarta and [other parts of? -\nMod.JW] Indonesia recently. [One of them] was admitted to the hospital on\n17 Apr 2003 and the other 2 on 19 Apr 2003. Their samples were sent to the\nNational Institute of Virology in Pune, and tested positive, Khanvilkar said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to today's worldwide update from WHO [1][A] a cumulative total\nof 3861 cases of SARS and 217 deaths (case fatality rate of 5.6 per cent)\nhave been reported through 21 Apr 2003. Since the last reported update, 495\nnew cases have been reported, reflecting to a large extent the additional\n447 cases reported from China, which include 'old cases' that had not been\nreported (as discussed in [1][C] and in ProMED-mail posting SARS -\nworldwide (60): cases 20030420.0972) as well as the new cases identified\nsince the last update on 19 Apr 2003. In addition, the United States has\nnow begun reporting only probable cases of SARS, so today's report from the\nUS reflects a decrease in the number of cases reported in the previous\nupdate when suspected and probable cases were reported daily. As of 21 Apr\n2003, 1873 SARS cases have been reported as having recovered, giving a\nreported recovery rate of 48.5 per cent. As an aside, it would be helpful\nto see an official Chinese analysis, either daily or weekly, by province to\nhelp monitor the outbreak, rather than to rely upon newswires and speculation.\nThe newswire report from India [6][B] is a bit disturbing. As mentioned in\nprior ProMED-mail postings, the current case definition for probable cases\nof SARS is based on clinical and epidemiological criteria and NOT on\nlaboratory diagnostic testing, as the sensitivity and specificity of the\ncurrent diagnostic tests is unknown and under investigation. It appears\nthat the Indian cases had traveled to Indonesia, where local transmission\nhas not been documented as yet. The cases traveled 3 weeks before the onset\nof this illness, whereas the current estimate of the incubation period for\nSARS is 2 to 10 days. The newswire does not provide the clinical symptoms\nof this supposed family cluster, but the epidemiological information\nprovided seems incompatible with SARS, unless there is local transmission\nin Indonesia previously undetected, the incubation period can be as long as\n3 weeks, or there is local transmission ongoing in India that has not been\ndetected as yet. We await further clarification of this, but are concerned\nto read newswires now confirming cases based on laboratory diagnostic\ntesting. (This is not the first instance of this -- see ProMED-mail posting\nSARS - worldwide (57): cases 20030418.0952). - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "--------------------------------------------\nProMED-mail post 'SARS - worldwide (60): cases 20030420.0972', quotes a CDC\nexpert as saying that the virus can remain potent on objects much longer\nthan previously thought: '....in their studies, they found that you could\nstill culture viable virus from surfaces after as much as 24 hours, which\nis longer than we normally expect viruses to be able to survive in the\nenvironment.' Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 18 Apr 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nAs of 1 PM 18 Apr 2003, there are an additional 30 patients confirmed\nto have atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals\nearlier. They include 2 healthcare workers (one from Pamela Youde\nNethersole Eastern Hospital and one from Princess Margaret Hospital).\nThe remaining 28 were other patients and contacts of patients with\natypical pneumonia.\n\nA total of 322 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and\nhave been discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 50 were\ndischarged today. 112 patients are receiving treatment in intensive\ncare unit.\n\n4 patients died in hospitals, bringing to 69 the total number of\ndeaths relating to atypical pneumonia. A 63-year-old female and 2\nmen, aged 73 and 67, all with a history of chronic disease, died in\nPrincess Margaret Hospital, Prince of Wales Hospital, and Pamela\nYoude Nethersole Eastern Hospital, respectively. A 42-year-old male\ndied in Queen Elizabeth Hospital.\n\nThe cumulative figures for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths*\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 309/ 106\nPatients, family members & visitors: 1018/ 216\n\nTotal: 1327/ 322 / 69\n\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a\nrelatively late stage of infection.\n\n[The total number of deaths is given for all reported cases and is\nnot provided by type of case (healthcare environment related vs.\nother close contact cases). Apparently this table was erroneously\ninterpreted in prior postings. - Mod.MPP]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 18 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6240>\n\n\nAs of 18 Apr 2003, 2 additional SARS patients have been discharged,\nbringing the total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to\n97. 59 SARS patients remain hospitalised.\n\nOne additional SARS case was reported today. She is the wife of a\nprobable SARS case who had been previously admitted to [Tan Tock Seng\nHospital] TTSH as a suspect case. Her husband had visited the\nRadiology Department at [Singapore General Hospital] SGH on 1 Apr\n2003 and later developed clinical signs consistent with SARS.\n\nSituation Update at SGH\nSo far, 62 persons are linked to the SGH cluster, comprising 25 SGH\nstaff, 20 inpatients, and 17 contacts. 48 are probable cases.\n\nPrecautionary measures for SGH Ward 74\nSGH had moved all patients who had been through Wards 57 & 58 to TTSH\non 6-7 Apr 2003. A patient who was previously in Ward 57 between 26\nand 28 Mar 2003, and subsequently transferred to Ward 74 between 28\nMar 2003 and 6 Apr 2003 for neurological management, was later\ntransferred to TTSH on 7 Apr 2003. In view of this, Ward 74 was\nplaced on close surveillance. On 9 and 10 Apr 2003, 3 nurses from\nWard 74 B2 station (Neurology ward) were noted to have low-grade\nfever (37.6 degrees C). They were given medical leave. 2 of them were\nadmitted to our Isolation Ward for observation. All 3 of them became\nafebrile after 1 day and were sent home with further medical leave.\n\nOn 14 Apr 2003, one of the medical officers in the Neurology unit\nalso reported sick with a low-grade fever for a day. He was put on\nmedical leave. On 14 Apr 2003, SGH noted that there were 3 patients\nin one cubicle in Ward 74 who had fever. However, these were patients\nwho had had fever intermittently for some time, in part due to the\nnature of their underlying illnesses. As a precaution, we transferred\nall 6 patients in that cubicle to our Isolation Ward on the same day\n(14 Apr 2003). One of these 3 patients was admitted on 27 Mar 2003\nwith a fever. He was diagnosed with pneumonia on 29 Mar 2003, treated\nwith antibiotics and improved. However, on 17 Apr 2003, he became\nchesty and breathless. On 17 Apr 2003 evening, as a further\nprecaution, a decision was made to transfer all 3 patients to TTSH.\nThey have been classified as suspect cases.\n\nAs a further precaution, the 3 Ward 74 nurses have also been recalled\nto be re-evaluated in TTSH today. SGH will also move all 55 patients\nof Ward 74 to TTSH starting tonight (17 Apr 2003). The neurologists\nat TTSH, who are part of the [National Neuroscience Institute] NNI,\nwill look after these patients. The clinical management of these\npatients will not be disrupted. 2 neurologists have been assigned to\nhandle communication issues with the patients' relatives. One will be\nstationed at SGH and the other at TTSH to update patients' relatives\non the transfer of patients and the management of their medical\ncondition at TTSH. This is to ensure a smooth transfer of patients to\nTTSH.\n\nSGH's clinical departments started working on a modular system on 10\nApr 2003. Each team is mapped to a fixed location (such as a part of\na ward or an outpatient clinic). With this mapping of persons to\nplace, the risk of exposure is reduced. As such, SGH's neurology\noutpatient service can still continue to function while the inpatient\nneurology doctors are put on Hospital Enforced Quarantine. 2 of the\nneurologists from the outpatient service team will now be deployed to\ncover the inpatient area.\n\nAs a precaution, some 100 staff from this latest development in Ward\n74 will be put on Hospital Enforced Quarantine. Active contact\ntracing of patients, visitors, and staff of Ward 74 is in progress.\nVisitors to Ward 74 after 26 Mar 2003 to date should monitor their\ntemperature.\n\nThese strong precautionary measures are in line with SGH's intention\nto do everything possible to deal with the SARS outbreak.\n\nAdded Precautions in Public Hospitals\nStarting today, all public hospitals will restrict visitors to one\nper patient per day. This is an added precaution to reduce the risk\nof the virus spread.\n\nA summary of the SARS cases to date:\nThere was one additional death today, bringing the total deaths to 16\n(of which 2 are pending further post mortem test results). This was\nthe [National University Hospital] NUH inpatient who was in contact\nwith a previous NUH SARS case.\n\nDischarged: 97\nHospitalised: 59 (including 17 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 14 + 2 (pending further post mortem test results)\nTotal: 172\n\nSuspected: 80 (including 5 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 444\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 18 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030418_e.html>\n\n\nSummary of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) Cases: 18 Apr 2003\n\nSince yesterday, no additional probable cases of SARS have been\nreported in Canada. A total of 132 individuals who meet the probable\ncase definition and 172 who meet the suspect case definition of SARS\nhave been reported, including 13 deaths. In addition to British\nColumbia and Ontario, which are reporting probable cases, Alberta,\nSaskatchewan, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island are also\nreporting suspect cases of SARS (Table 1).\n\nAt the present time, the case fatality rate in Canada is estimated at\napproximately 4.3 percent of probable or suspect cases (13 of 304\nprobable or suspect cases). Most of the case fatalities occurred in\npatients with underlying illness, and nearly all were elderly\npatients over the age of 70 years.\n\nTable 1: Cumulative Number of SARS Cases Reported in Canada: 18 Apr 2003\n\nProvince/Territory: Individuals meeting the criteria for probable\ncase (1)/ suspected case (1)/ deaths\n\nBritish Columbia: 4/ 41/ 0\nAlberta: 0/ 5/ 0\nSaskatchewan: 0/ 1/ 0\nOntario: 128/ 119/ 13 (2)\nNew Brunswick: 0/ 2/ 0\nPrince Edward Island: 0/ 4/ 0\n\nTotal: 132/ 172/ 13\n(1)These persons may be excluded the probable or suspect case list if\nanother cause is identified to fully explain their illness\n(2) 12 of 13 deaths were in probable cases, and one of the 13 deaths\nwas recently re-classified as a suspect case.\n\nA summary of the current status of probable cases of SARS in Canada\nas of 18 Apr 2003 is presented in Table 2. 54 individuals have been\ndischarged (41.5 percent) and of the 64 individuals currently\nhospitalised, 41 (64.1 percent) are improving or in stable condition.\nIn addition, nearly all of the suspect cases reported in Ontario,\nBritish Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, New Brunswick, and Prince\nEdward Island have either recovered or are presently recovering.\n\nTable 2: Currently known reported status of probable cases of SARS in\nCanada: 18 Apr 2003\n(N=130, excludes 2 for whom status is unknown)\n\nCurrent Status: Number/ probable cases (percent)\nHospitalised: 64/130 (49.2 percent)\nImproving 14/64 (21.9 percent)\nStable 27/64 (42.2 percent)\nCritical/Deteriorating 13/64 (20.3 percent)\nUnknown 10/64 (15.6 percent)\nDischarged(1) 54/130 (41.5 percent)\nDeceased 122/130 (9.2 percent)\nTotal no. probable cases for whom current status is known: 130 (100 percent)\n\n(1) includes cases who have either recovered or are recovering\n(2) 1 death not accounted for in this table, has recently been\nre-classified as a suspect case\n\nThe current evidence suggests that respiratory droplet transmission,\nrequiring close contact with a case of SARS, is the predominant mode\nof transmission. In the province of Ontario, the majority of cases\nhave been associated with specific transmission settings, such as\nhousehold, hospital, and specific community groups or settings. There\nare currently 30 cases reported amongst approximately 500 members of\na religious group in Toronto. The index case of this community\ncluster is linked to the first hospital cluster. The disease spread\nto a total of 14 members of the index case's extended family as well\nas to other members of the religious group. The key transmission\nsettings include a gathering held on 28--29 Mar 2003, the funeral\nvisitation for the index case held on 3 Apr 2003, and other social\ngatherings during and after these dates. Local health authorities\nhave implemented isolation of all contacts of suspect and probable\ncases, including all 500 members of the religious group, in an effort\nto contain any further spread within and outside of this social\nnetwork. Case finding and contact tracing efforts in the group are\ncontinuing.\n\nTravellers who have returned from an affected area in Asia and their\nclose contacts account for the remaining cases in Ontario and the\nother provinces. The number of probable cases by reported symptom\nonset date and type of exposure (where known) is provided in (Figure\n1) [see webpage\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030418_e.html>\nfor epidemic curve by type of exposure - Mod.MPP]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 18 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>\n\n\n[A] Severe acute respiratory syndrome report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\n*Case definition <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>\n[the case definition has been revised on 18 Apr 2003 to follow the\nWHO definitions of suspected vs. probable cases. Mod.MPP]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[B]\nDate: 18 Apr 2003\nFrom: Susan Rossmann <srossman@giveblood.org>\n\nSubject: FDA issues guidance on blood collection regarding SARS\n\nOn their website <http://www.fda.gov/cber/gdlns/sarsbld.htm>\nand the associated Talk Paper\n<http://www.fda.gov/bbs/topics/ANSWERS/2003/ANS01215.html>\n\nThe recommendation is to ask donors whether they have had SARS or\nsuspected SARS in the last 28 days, whether they have had close\ncontact with a person with SARS or suspected SARS in the last 14\ndays, and whether they have travelled to an area with SARS in the\nlast 14 days (using the geographic areas in the CDC case definition,\nto be modified as the CDC updates).\n\n--\nSusan N. Rossmann, M.D., Ph.D, Medical Director\nGulf Coast Regional Blood Center\n1400 La Concha Dr, Houston TX 77054\n<srossman@giveblood.org>\n\n[Full details on the proposed position paper with recommendations for\nblood banks can be found at:\n<http://www.fda.gov/cber/gdlns/sarsbldgd.htm>. A similar action was\nimplemented by Health Canada several weeks ago upon the recognition\nof the transmission chains of SARS in Ontario. The rationale for\nexcluding individuals for 2 weeks following possible exposure is\nallowing for passage of the accepted incubation period for SARS,\nwhich is currently described as 2-10 days. Waiting 28 days following\nthe diagnosis of SARS allows for termination of infection, so that\nthe virus would presumably no longer be present in blood of an\ninfected individual. Both of these time frames are based on\nepidemiologic investigations and not on laboratory studies of large\nnumbers of cases. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 18 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: News briefs [edited]\n\n[A] India from the India Express 18 Apr 2003\n<http://www.indianexpress.com/full_story.php?content_id=22298>\n\nOne more patient 'assumed to be normal' by the health authorities has\ntested positive for SARS in the preliminary Polymerase Chain Reaction\n(PCR) tests. The patient is a 42-year-old tourist from New Zealand\nwho landed at the Indira Gandhi International Airport, New Delhi,\nfrom Bangkok at around 11 PM on Thursday night [17 Apr 2003]. He has\nbeen admitted to the Ram Manohar Lohia hospital. According to\nsources at the National Institute of Communicable Diseases, New\nDelhi, genetic sequencing is being matched and the results will be\ndeclared in the next 24 hours.\n\nThe New Zealander was moved to the hospital with symptoms such as\ncough and breathlessness. The official version this evening was that\nthe patient was 'afebrile' with no symptoms. 'His X-ray is normal and\nhe has no fever,' they said. According to sources at the airport, the\npatient had attracted attention of the doctors at the health\ncounters, as he showed breathlessness. According to the NICD, the\npassenger had travelled to Australia, where he stayed in New Port\nwith his brother, who was suspected to be infected and had been\nquarantined. He had also stayed in Bangkok for 13 hours before flying\nto India.\n\n[B] China - Beijing - reported on Time.com\n<http://www.time.com/time/asia/news/daily/0,9754,444684,00.html>\nand on CNN\n<http://www.cnn.com/2003/WORLD/asiapcf/east/04/18/sars.china/index.html>\n\n[Our thanks to Jack Steinmann <jsteinmann@CLYNCH.COM> for submitting\nthe Time.com report on this - Mod.MPP]\n\nBoth reports mentioned an intentional physical hiding of suspected\ncases of SARS from the WHO teams during the visits of the teams to\nthe hospitals: '...hospital officials removed dozens of SARS patients\nfrom their isolation wards and transferred them to locations where\nthey could not be observed by the inspectors' (from the Time.com\narticle).\n\nThe full reports of these allegations apparently made by physicians\nworking at the involved hospitals can be read at the above given URL\nlinks.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the news brief section there is a report of another suspected\ncase in India, with mention that preliminary results of PCR testing\nwere positive. According to that report, the patient (an individual\nfrom New Zealand) travelled from Bangkok, which to date has not been\nreported as having areas of local transmission. We await further\ninformation on this case, and possible exposure. It should be\nmentioned that the PCR test is capable of producing not only false\nnegative results (negative when there is a real infection), but also\nfalse positives (positive when the individual is not infected with\nthe virus). Therefore, a positive PCR at present does not 'confirm'\nthat this is a case of SARS (see discussion in [4][A] related to\nchange in case definitions used by the USA for reporting).\n\nThe WHO is recommending -- and all countries to date have been\ncomplying with -- the application of a case definition based on\nclinical and epidemiologic criteria, and not based on results of\nlaboratory diagnostic testing, now that tests are available. Data\nfrom laboratory testing are being collected and analyzed to better\ndefine the sensitivity (ability to detect the virus when present,\nresulting in a low false negative rate) and specificity (ability to\nrule out the presence of the virus when not present, resulting in a\nlow false positive rate) of the tests currently available.\n\nThe reports on the possible 'hiding' of SARS patients from the WHO\nteam involved in the inspections come on the eve of the Chinese\npolitical leadership mandating that full international cooperation be\nprovided in the ongoing investigation and control measures related to\nthe SARS outbreak. This announcement was made by the Chinese\npresident (see SARS - worldwide (56): cases 20030418.0951), and\nincluded full disclosure and reporting of all suspected and probable\ncases to the Ministry of Health and from the Ministry of Health to\ninternational organizations. The above newswires are very critical\nand make serious allegations regarding intentional underreporting of\nSARS cases. Confirmation might be expected soon, in the form of\nmarked increases in numbers of probable cases reported in a very\nshort time frame. In the absence of this, one must speculate that\nthese accusations were not based on fact. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a\nnational level, probable cases are reported by all countries except\nthe United States of America, which is reporting suspected cases\nunder investigation.\n2. Includes cases who are 'discharged' or 'recovered' as reported by\nthe national public health authorities.\n3. One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of\nChina occurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] The list of affected areas can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_17/en/> and is unchanged\nfrom previous reports\n[C] Update 32 - Situation in China and Hong Kong, status of\ndiagnostic tests 17 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_17/en/>\n[Our thanks to Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for her continued\nassistance in following WHO reports on a daily basis. - Mod.MPP]\nChina\nChinese authorities have today reported 12 new cases of SARS. 9 new\ncases were reported from Guangdong Province, and one each from Inner\nMongolia and Sichuan provinces. Ningxia, a poor province in the\nremote western part of the country, announced its first case today.\nBeijing reported no new cases and no new deaths. Today's figures do\nnot include cases in Beijing's military hospitals. The military\nhospitals, which are not obliged by Chinese law to report cases to\nhealth authorities, have been the focus of considerable rumours over\nthe past several days. A WHO team began visits to Beijing's military\nhospitals yesterday. The recent decision of military hospitals in\nGuangdong Province to report SARS cases to the authorities may set an\nimportant precedent. WHO staff in China have been further encouraged\nby the presence of national surveillance and reporting teams in\nprovinces that are now reporting cases. The presence of national SARS\nteams actively searching for cases is a welcome sign that the\nseverity of the SARS threat is being taken seriously by the\ngovernment.\nAn additional WHO team will be travelling to Shanghai next week.\nHong Kong: investigation of the Amoy Gardens cluster\nThe Hong Kong Department of Health, together with the Department of\nEnvironment, Transport and Works, has today released the results of\nan extensive investigation into the possible cause of a large cluster\nof SARS cases among residents in the Amoy Gardens housing estate. The\nreport draws on findings from numerous studies designed to determine\nwhether an environmental source of the SARS virus might explain the\nlarge and unusual cluster of SARS cases.\nAs of 15 Apr 2003, health authorities had reported a total of 321\nindividuals affected by SARS who are residents in Amoy Gardens. A\nlarge proportion of cases are concentrated in vertically linked flats\nin a single building, Block E.\nAttention has focused on possible transmission via the sewage system.\nAmong several unusual features, the Amoy cluster includes a high\nproportion of cases presenting with diarrhoea, estimated at about 60\npercent. In most other clusters of cases, diarrhoea has typically\nbeen seen in only 2 to 7 percent of cases. WHO epidemiologists are\nnow studying the report, which was submitted to WHO earlier today by\nHong Kong's Department of Health.\nStatus of diagnostic tests\nScientists in the WHO network of collaborating laboratories met in\nGeneva yesterday to map out research priorities for the coming month.\nThe network also announced conclusive proof, from animal trials, that\na new coronavirus, discovered by the group last month, is the agent\nthat causes SARS.\nWith the cause of SARS now proven, network scientists are giving top\npriority to the development of better diagnostic tests. The first\nstep is the development of a data bank of specimens from a range of\nSARS patients in different countries. The scientists are also\nbuilding a bank of specimens taken from individual patients at\ndifferent stages of disease, including recovery.\nSuch a time-series of specimens will be vital in developing a test\nthat is capable of detecting virus at the first stage when people\nbecome capable of infecting others. It will also help identify the\nstage in the course of the illness when recovered patients can safely\nreturn to their jobs and families with no risk of infecting others.\nOther plans for the coming weeks include the development of a genetic\nlibrary of specimens from SARS patients from different parts of the\nworld. It is not yet known whether genetic differences in the\ncoronavirus, which has now been fully sequenced by several network\nlaboratories, will have significance for work on drug and vaccine\nresearch and development.\nExisting PCR diagnostic tests are insufficiently powerful to rule\nout, with confidence, the presence of the virus in suspect or\nprobable SARS cases early in the course of the disease.\nWHO has been concerned that use of the current PCR test kit, which is\nbeing made available by a German biotechnology company initially at\nno cost, may produce test results that give a false sense of\nsecurity, allowing persons carrying the virus to slip past undetected.\nWithout a more reliable diagnostic tool, hospital staff confronted\nwith a suspect SARS case have no option other than to isolate\npatients and manage them according to strict infection control\npractices as precautionary measures. Such measures are stressful for\npatients and place a considerable strain on health services.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 3389 cases with 165 deaths have\nbeen reported from 25 countries. Countries reporting their first\nprobable cases on today's list include Australia (3) and Mongolia\n(3). A large number of suspect SARS cases turn out, on further\ninvestigation, to have other, common causes.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 17 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 17 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 17 Apr 2003, there are an additional 29 patients confirmed\nto have atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals\nearlier. One of them\nis an inpatient of Ward 57 who had been transferred to [Tan Tock Seng\nHospital] TTSH for observation on 7 Apr 2003, while the other is a\nvisitor. The third case is a patient who was in the same ward as a\nSARS patient in [National University Hospital] NUH before this\npatient was diagnosed as SARS on 9 Apr 2003. As a precaution the 6\nother patients who were warded in the same cubicle as the SARS\npatient were transferred to isolation rooms in NUH for observation on\n9 Apr 2003 The third case reported today is one of them. He developed\nfever on 14 Apr 2003 and was transferred to TTSH on the same day. As\nof today, the other 5 patients remain well.\nThe fourth case is a 53-year-old Chinese man who developed fever,\nbody aches, and diarrhoea on the evening of 9 Apr 2003 when he was\nhome. He works as a taxi driver. On 10 Apr 2003, he consulted a\n[General Practitioner] GP after working from 6 AM to 9 AM. He\nremained at home for the rest of that day and the next. On 12 Apr\n2003, he consulted a GP again. As he was still unwell, he was\nadmitted to TTSH that afternoon. Apart from the 3 hours on 10 Apr\n2003, he did not work on 11 and 12 Apr 2003. On 14 Apr 2003, his\nchest x-ray showed changes and he was diagnosed as atypical\npneumonia. He was not classified as SARS as there was no history of\ncontact. However, as a precaution, home quarantine orders where\nissued to 10 of his close contacts. So far they are all well except\nfor his 54-year-old wife, who was admitted on 15 Apr 2003 for fever.\nToday, laboratory samples taken from the patient were positive for\ncoronavirus. In view of this finding, he has been classified as a\nprobable SARS case and his wife as a suspect SARS case. They are both\nin stable condition. He gives a history of ferrying passengers to\nhospitals. He does not ply the airport route. Investigations to\ndetermine the source of infection are still on going.\nUpdate on Jurong Shipyard\nA 47-year-old Malaysian who lived and worked in Singapore travelled\nto Pontian, Johore [Malaysia] from 24 to 30 Mar 2003 to attend his\nfather's funeral. He returned to Singapore on 31 Mar 2003. He was a\nwelder in Jurong Shipyard and returned to work from 1 to 7 Apr 2003,\nexcluding 2 Apr 2003, as it was his day off. On 8 Apr 2003 he stayed\nat home and did not work as he was feeling unwell. He consulted a GP\non 9 Apr 2003 for fever, cough and breathlessness. He did not return\nto work from 8 to 12 Apr 2003. He was admitted to Alexandra Hospital\non 12 Apr 2003. On admission his chext x-ray showed evidence of\npneumonia. As his condition was serious, he was intubated and later\ntransferred on the same day to TTSH Intensive Care. He died on 13 Apr\n2003. As a precautionary measure, home quarantine orders were served\nto 13 of his contacts. Laboratory investigations have revealed that\nhe had an infection of the blood caused by a bacterium,\n_Streptococcus pneumoniae_. So far, post-mortem samples of the lung,\nspleen, intestine, and lymph nodes are negative for coronavirus.\nFurther post-mortem test results are still pending.\nDeceased child\nSo far, the preliminary laboratory investigations for the child who\ndied of acute respiratory distress syndrome at KKH on 15 Apr 2003 are\nnegative for coronavirus. Further post-mortem test results are still\npending.\nSummary of SARS cases\nBelow is the summary of the SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 95\nHospitalised: 61 (including 17 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 13 + 2 (pending post mortem findings)\nTotal: 171\nSuspected: 80 (including 8 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 467\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[As of 17 Apr 2003 the cumulative totals are 3389 cases and 165\ndeaths reported to WHO from a total of 25 countries. Australia and\nMongolia were newly added to the list of countries, with 3 cases\nreported by each country in the preceding 24 hours. There were 29\nnew cases reported from Hong Kong, 25 from China, and 5 from\nSingapore within the past 24 hours. worldwide (53): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203652", "date": "2003-04-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (53): ETIOLOGY\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Wed 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organisation (WHO), Press Briefing, Wed 16 Apr 2003\n[edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/2003_04_16/en/>\n[The following are extracts from the transcript of a WHO Press Briefing held\nin Geneva on Wed 16 Apr 2003 and attended by the following. From:\nWorld Health Organization; Dr David Heymann, Executive Director,\nCommunicable Diseases Dr Mark Salter, Clinical Management\nCoordinator; Dr Klaus Stohr, SARS Etiology Coordinator; Project\nLeader, WHO Global Influenza Programme; Mr Dick Thompson,\nCommunications Officer. From the SARS laboratory network: Dr\nChristian Drosten, Institut fur Medizinische Virologie im Klinikum\nder Johann Wolfgang, Goethe-Universitat, Frankfurt am Main (in\ncollaboration with the Institute for Tropical Medicine, Hamburg,\nUniversity of Marburg); Dr Robin Gopal, Central Public Health\nLaboratory, United Kingdom; Dr James Le Duc, Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention, National Centers for Infectious Diseases,\nUnited States; Dr Aiee Ling, Singapore General Hospital, Singapore;\nDr Albert Osterhaus, Erasmus Universiteit, National Influenza Centre,\nthe Netherlands; Dr Masato Tashiro, National Institute of Infectious\nDiseases, Tokyo, Japan; Dr Sylvie van der Werf, Institut Pasteur,\nNational Influenza Centre, France]\n...Three questions from the floor: 'The first concerns the PCR test\nthat WHO put on the web site. Can this test detect asymptomatic\npatients of SARS? The second concerns medication. In Hong Kong, they\nuse ribavirin and steroids. We have seen that they have a lot of\nside-effects in babies and pregnant women. I wonder what are those\nmedications your countries use and what would be your recommendation.\nAlso, the possibility of a combination of Chinese medicine and\nwestern medicine. The third question concerns the situation of Amoy\nGardens. Not only is atypical in terms of the means of transmission,\nalso it seems that patients in Amoy Gardens do not respond well to\nribavirin and steroids. They have other symptoms such as diarrhoea.\nAlso, unlike in most SARS cases where patients who die and became\nseriously ill are aged over 40, in Hong Kong we have cases aged 30 or\n40 with no chronic diseases in the past, but they also die of SARS\nand they are all from Amoy Gardens. What are your views on this?\nThank you.'\nReply by Dr Stohr: 'Thank you for the question. I would like to give\nthe floor to Dr Drosten to talk about the PCR test. What I would like\nto emphasize is that with the identification of the coronavirus as\nthe causative agent, now we can develop more specific diagnostic\ntests for this pathogen. It is also now possible to fully focus on\none pathogen and not be forced perhaps to develop other diagnostic\ntests for other possible agents.'\nReply by Dr Christian Drosten: 'We were of course not the only\nlaboratory within the network that did this, so for the time being\nthere are some molecular diagnostic tests which in principle all work\nthe same and should in principle all have the same performance\ncharacteristics. We have done some evaluation of this. What I can\ntell is that we can analytically find about 500 viruses per\nmillilitre of respiratory material. But what epidemiology has now to\nconfirm is how useful this will be in clinical terms, for clinicians.\nThere are of course some hints from beforehand that I can tell from\nnow. This is that, most probably, through most of the symptomatic\nperiod that the patients show, we can see the virus in these tests,\nbut we cannot for the time being say this will have any consequence\nto real clinical acting. For this we need more patients and more\nepidemiology and more evaluating of these tests.'\nComment by Dr Stohr: 'We would like to better understand what the\nperformance criteria are of these tests. With PCR you can only detect\ngenetic material. You cannot detect, you are not sure whether what\nyou are seeing is a live virus or is only an immature virus that\ncannot cause disease. So from that perspective, even finding of\ncoronavirus traces, in possibly non-clinically ill patients, is not\nvery indicative. I would briefly like to go with the ribavirin\nquestions. Ribavirin has been tested in Hong Kong for a relatively\nlong period of time. It is no more than two weeks that the Department\nof Health has been recommending ribavirin treatment in combination\nwith high doses of corticosteroids. They are\nreporting a significant improvement of the clinical course of the disease.\nRibavirin is known for very many years. It has side-effects. They are\nnot unusual, they are not unexpected. On the other hand, in vitro\ntesting, the testing outside the human body, of ribavirin with\ncoronavirus has shown that coronaviruses are resistant. So all this\nhas to be verified. These tests are\nongoing. There is a battery of other antiviral drugs that are currently\nbeing tested. This is the reason why we believe the finding of this\ncoronavirus as the causative agent after we have now fulfilled the\nKoch postulates is so important. Now the research can be focusing on\nthis virus. This virus will help us, or let us say that the research\nwill help us to develop new drugs. Now we can focus on one pathogen,\nwhich has now been sequenced, which provides additional information\nfor the development of\ntests. Now one can also think perhaps about vaccine, if there is a need be.\nWe are still I think optimistic that we can control the disease with\nthe measures that have been implemented and the understanding of the\ngenetic\ncomposition of the virus will certainly also help to implement global\nsurveillance.'\nComment by Dr Heymann: 'Re Amoy Gardens, as Klaus just said, they\nhave found that the virus particles at least are in faeces and in\nurine. It is normal that if it is in faeces that it may be causing\ndiarrhoea, and actually 10% of patients do have diarrhoea worldwide.\nSo diarrhoea is a symptom. In fact, I went through Paris airport and\non their alert for SARS they do list diarrhoea as one of the\nsymptoms. It is a common symptom. That is some of the intrigue of\nknowing why people in Amoy Gardnes might be different than other\nplaces. It may be the way in which they are getting infected. There\nare all kinds of theories that you could use in saying why they get\ndiarrhoea. Maybe that they are getting infected by the mouth, that it\nis only to be determined as time goes on and as the studies are\ndone.'...\n...Question from Fuji from Kyoto News Japan. 'Previously there was\nsome speculation that paramyxovirus and/or chlamydia could have been\nplaying a role in causing SARS. Now today that you have identified\nthe causative agent as coronavirus, can we now safely say that it is\ncaused solely by coronavirus and that paramyxovirus and chlamydia\ndoes not play any role in this? Secondly, there has also been some\nspeculation and concern that the SARS virus may still be evolving,\ncould change its composition or shape. Can you comment on this issue\nas well?'\nReply by Dr Albert Osterhaus: 'As to the cause of the disease, I think that\nif you look, what happens is that first of all this paramyxovirus _Human\nmetapnuemovirus_ (HPV)' was found. HMPV is a virus that we discovered about\ntwo years ago as the cause of serious respiratory infections in children,\nthe elderly and also immuno-compromised individuals. But we were quite\nastonished that this virus as such should be the cause of this new disease;\nnow that would not make sense. Then we were very happy to learn that\noriginally in Malik Pierce's work in Hong Kong, identified the virus\nthat we have all followed up. So we ended up with two different\nviruses: the coronavirus and HMPV. There is also discussion about\nthis chlamydia agent. This led us to postulate that it would not be\nimpossible that we would perhaps have a double etiology, so one virus\ncoming first and the other one coming later and then aggravating the\nsituation. This is the reason why in discussions with the network, we\ndiscussed that in our telephone conferences. Then we decided to do an\nexperiment in monkeys. This experiment was set up in such a way that\nwe infected monkeys either with the coronavirus that was cultured or\nwith HMPV. A third group we infected first with coronavirus and then\nwith HMPV. The interesting thing we found, and that goes back to the\nKoch's postulates that were formulated more than 100 years ago, that\nthe animals infected with the coronavirus alone developed full-blown\ndisease. They developed SARS, they developed clinical symptoms, and\nthey also developed the pathological lesions that are identical to\nwhat we have seen in people who have died from SARS. The animals with\nHMPV, the first virus that was found, developed only a very mild\nrhinitis, they had very mild symptoms, and definitely not the typical\nSARS pattern. The third group of animals, first infected with the\ncoronavirus and then super-infected with HMPV, did not develop more\nserious disease.\n***Koch's postulates are firstly that the agent should be present in basically\nall the individuals that are suffering from the disease. That holds true\npredominantly for the coronavirus and not for HMPV because it is less than\n50% of the people infected or having SARS that were infected with HMPV me.\nThe second postulate is that you should be able to cultivate the virus. That\nholds true for the two viruses. The third postulate is that you should be\nable to reproduce the disease in the host or a related host. That is what we\nhave done for the coronavirus, and coronavirus only. The last postulate then\nis that you should reisolate the virus back from the animals that you have\ninfected with that virus. Those four things have been fulfilled for\ncoronavirus and only three of those for HMPV.***\nThe conclusion today, the people in the network agreed, that the coronavirus\nalone is capable of causing the typical symptoms. We cannot formally exclude\nthat other agents, such as HMPV, and the chlamydia that has been found in\nChina, or a number of other viruses after you have this primary infection\nwith the coronavirus, would eventually aggravate the situation. We cannot\nexclude this, but the data especially from Hong Kong, suggest that where we\nhave coronavirus alone, also in humans, those data together with the monkey\ndata I think quite strongly show that the coronavirus is the primary cause\nof this disease the new coronavirus that was identified a couple of weeks\nago.'...\n...Question from Stefan Tile, Newsweek: 'I have two questions. One\nis, can you give us an update on countries where first cases were\nrecently reported, like Brazil or South Africa, how they are dealing\nwith the situation, what measures governments there are undertaking?\nAnd the second question is, now that the virus has been pin-pointed\nand the genome has been sequenced, can you tell us what that means\nfor a) the diagnostics, b) the development of antiviral therapy and\nc) the search for a vaccine? And to what extent any of this research\nis either under way or specifically planned. Thank you.'\nReply by Dr Aiee Ling: 'With regard to the sequencing of the virus,\nit of course gives us tremendous ability to develop more specific\nprimers. Because, as has been stated before, this virus is quite\ndistinct in its grouping. Which means that the previous primers that\nwe were using were not as specific and therefore not as sensitive. So\nthat, of course, the specific primers that we should be able now to\ndevelop will go a long way to improving the sensitivity of test.\nThat's with regard to diagnostics. With regard to vaccines, again of\ncourse the sequencing will have a direct ability for us to form\nclones, to produce the necessary requirements for vaccine.\nComment by Dr Sylvie van der Werf: 'So, about other developments that\none can expect from the availability of the sequence. Apart from\ndeveloping other primer sets for molecular diagnostics, also this\nshould prove extremely useful for serological diagnostics, producing\nantigens by molecular techniques that can be made readily available.\nAnd there are a number of laboratories in the network working on\nthis. Different vaccine strategies can also be explored using\nrecombinant vaccine approaches. Again, based on the possibility to\nexpress various proteins through molecular cloning techniques from\nusing the genes from this virus. And finally, this will also allow to\nset up, probably, maybe some [in vitro] tests for testing of\nantivirals that might be of use against this virus. So, really using\nmolecular techniques based on the sequence information, it will be\npossible to develop methodologies that will not have to rely anymore\non infectious virus, which will also allow to work at a different\ncontainment level and make things easier...\n...Two questions from the floor: 'One is, do you have any new\nfindings on the way of transmission? And the second is, how many\npeople do you have right now in China and are you planning to send\nmore people? Thank you.'\nReply by Dr Stohr: 'This morning the network members presented overviews on\nthe excretion patterns of this coronavirus and the people you are\nseeing here, and those you unfortunately cannot see because they are\nlinked by video conference, are those who know most about how this\nvirus is being excreted, for how long, by which means. But still the\nmatrix of excretion which we have drawn is still incomplete. We are\nstill not fully aware how much virus is being excreted, by which\n[route] and for how long. Is virus excreted before the clinical signs\nwould occur? Would virus continue to be excreted when persons are\nalready discharged? All this has to be looked into. And its ongoing...\n...Question from Warren Giles, Bloomberg News: 'A couple of things. I\nwonder, is there any evidence that the mortality rate of this virus\nis increasing just because of the evolution we see in cases and\ndeaths in Hong Kong? And secondly, I wonder at what point a virus\nthat's not contained becomes an epidemic? Is there any kind of model\nthat suggests theres a critical point of infections at which point\ninfections become exponential in some way? Thanks.'\nReply by Dr Salter: 'The first question was: has the case mortality\nrate increased? No, it hasn't but what we have seen across the globe\nis that there are variable case fatalities rates with the different\ncountries. And that probably reflects to some degree the level of\nfacilities available in those countries and the rapidity with which\nthose individual countries have\nbeen able to implement their infection control measures........\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A article published in the New York Times on Wed 16 Apr 2003\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/16/science/sciencespecial/16INFE.html?ex=105\n1495315&ei=1&en=c86134d71cbb7821>, forwarded by Rashid Chotani\n<rchotani@jhsph.edu>, gives an alternate account of the\nthe WHO Press Briefing.]\n[The most significant information communicated during this press briefing\nwas the account by Dr. Osterhaus of the primate experiments undertaken in\nRotterdam, and the conclusion that Koch's postulates have been confirmed\nexperimentally in the case of the SARS-associated coronavirus, and not in\nthe case of the human metapneumovirus isolated from SARS patients. - Mod.CP]\n[There's an excellent description of the discussion of the\nfulfillment of Koch's postulates in the body of the press release\nhighlighted by ***. - Mod.MPP]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: David Cowhig <david.cowhig@verizon.net>\nSource: Beijing Genomics web-site, Wed 16 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.gpbjournal.org/sars2.jsp>\n\nGenomes of Four Mainland China SARS Viral Samples Sequenced\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nThis afternoon scientists at collaborating research institutes in\nmainland China, the Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology of the\nAcademy of Military Medical Sciences and the Beijing Genomics\nInstitute of Chinese Academy of Sciences, obtained draft genome\nsequences from four samples containing the SARS-associated\ncoronavirus from SARS patients.\nAll four samples of the SARS-associated coronavirus were isolated\nfrom patients in Beijing and Guangdong Province, where the first case\nof SARS was treated. Two of the isolates were from autopsies of the\nlung tissue of deceased patients, one from Beijing and the other from\nGuangdong. The third one was from a mixed autopsy sample of the liver\nand lymph nodes isolated from the same Beijing patient from whom the\nlung tissue was taken. The fourth sample was from nasal/throat swabs\nof several patients with SARS in Beijing.\nThe DNA sequences reverse-transcribed from the RNA virus isolated\nfrom the mainland Chinese samples were compared to genome sequences\npreviously reported by Canadian and US scientists. A few nucleotide\ndifferences among individual genomes were detected as the virus is\nexpected to mutate very fast and easily.\nThe SARS-associated coronavirus is believed to be a member of the\n_Coronaviridae_ family. RNA viruses, such as the human\nimmunodeficiency\nvirus (HIV) and Influenza virus, are known to change their genetic\nmakeup readily in different tissues during their rapid propagation\n(genome replication and viron assembly) in living cells over a short\nperiod of time. For effective diagnosis and treatment of these viral\ninfections, it is essential to study the mutation spectra of the\nvirus. The detailed comparative analyses from different viral\nisolates both at the genome sequence and protein levels will be an\nimportant contribution to SARS research efforts currently underway in\nthe\ninternational biomedical research community and help scientists\nworldwide to develop accurate diagnostic tests, effective disease\ntreatments and vaccines to prevent further spread of the virus.\nComplete genome sequences will be updated and released to public\ndatabases as soon as they become available. Efforts to identify viral\nproteins with proteomic tools are underway, and findings are expected\ntomorrow.\nBackground Information [from the web-site]:\nA coronavirus is believed to be the causative agent of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS). Coronaviruses belong to a viral family,\n_Coronaviridae_ (from Latin, corona or 'crown-like'), infect\nvertebrates especially the warm-blooded vertebrates, including\nseveral mammalian species (e.g. human, cattle, cat, pig, and rat),\nand a few avian species (e.g. turkey and chicken). Virions of\ncoronavirus contain a single stranded RNA molecule in a linear\npositive-sense form, ranging between 29,000 and 31,000 nucleotides in\nlength.\nScientists from several countries, Canada, United States and China\nincluding Hong Kong, have carried out heroic sequencing efforts,\nattempting to decipher the genetic code of the unknown human\ncoronavirus believed to be responsible for the global epidemic of\nSARS.\nThe sequencing result first came on 12 Apr 2003 from the Canadian group at\nCanada's Michael Smith Genome Sciences Center of the British Columbia Cancer\nAgency, in collaboration with the British Columbia Center for Disease\nControl and the National Microbiology Laboratory, Winnipeg. A draft assembly\nof the SARS-associated Coronavirus (TOR2) genome (Release 1) is 29 736\nnucleotides in length. It was deposited in the NCBI Genbank database under\naccession AY274119. On 14 Apr 2003, the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC) announced that it has sequenced the genome of the\ncoronavirus. The CDC sequence is nearly identical to that determined\nby a Canadian group. The significant difference is that the\nCDC-determined sequence has 15 additional nucleotides, which provides\nthe important beginning of the sequence. The virus from a throat\nculture taken from one of the SARS patients was grown in Vero cells\n(African green monkey kidney cells) to reproduce enough RNA for\nsequencing experiments. The new sequence has 29 727 nucleotides,\nwhich places it well within the typical RNA boundaries for\ncoronaviruses.
