worldwide (55): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203657", "date": "2003-04-17 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (55): CASES\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Canada\n[2] USA\n[3] News briefs\n[A] India\n[B] China - Shanxi province\n[C] China - Ningxia Hue autonomous region\n[D] Bulgaria - case denied\n******\n[1]\nDate: 17 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n[A] Update 33 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 17 Apr 2003 4:30 PM\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update33.html>\n\nAs of 17 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 306 probable\nor suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nCanada. There have been 13 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission\nhas been limited to specific transmission settings such as\nhouseholds, hospitals, and specific community settings. This update\nis based on the information available to Health Canada at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 123 probable and 128 suspect cases. All cases\nhave occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact\nwith SARS cases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable and 39 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nSo far, 100 people have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario.\nThese people were treated as suspect cases or as probable cases.\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 17 Apr 2003.\n[B] From the 16 Apr 2003 Health Professional's update available at:\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030416_e.html>\nThe current evidence suggests that respiratory droplet transmission,\nrequiring close contact with a case of SARS, is the predominant mode\nof transmission.\nIn the province of Ontario the majority of cases have been associated\nwith specific transmission settings, such as household, hospital, and\nspecific community groups or settings. There are currently 30 cases\nreported amongst approximately 500 members of a religious group in\nToronto. The index case of this community cluster is linked to the\nfirst hospital cluster. The disease spread to a total of 14 members\nof the index case's extended family as well as to other members of\nthe religious group. The key transmission settings include a\ngathering held 28-29 Mar 2003, the funeral visitation for the index\ncase held on 3 Apr 2003, and other social gatherings during and after\nthese dates. Local health authorities have implemented isolation of\nall contacts of suspect and probable cases, including all 500 members\nof the religious group, in an effort to contain any further spread\nwithin and outside of this social network. Case finding and contact\ntracing efforts in the group are continuing.\n[There is an excellent epidemic curve contained in the full article\nat\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030416_e.html>\nshowing the number of cases by date of onset of illness and type of\ncontact transmission. - Mod.MPP]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 17 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website 17 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>\n\n[A] Severe acute respiratory syndrome report of suspected cases\nunder investigation in the United States\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on 16 Apr 2003.\nState: Suspected cases under investigation\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 42\nColorado: 6\nConnecticut: 4\nFlorida: 13\nGeorgia: 3\nHawaii: 5\nIllinois: 11\nIndiana: 1\nKansas: 1\nKentucky: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 9\nMichigan: 3\nMinnesota: 6\nMississippi: 2\nMissouri: 2\nNevada: 1\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 3\nNew Mexico: 1\nNew York: 25\nNorth Carolina: 6\nOhio: 10\nOregon: 1\nPennsylvania: 5\nRhode Island: 1\nSouth Carolina: 2\nTexas: 7\nUtah: 5\nVermont: 2\nVirginia: 5\nWashington: 20\nWisconsin: 1\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 208\n[B] Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR) Update: Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome --- United States, 2003. 18 Apr 2003\n52(15);332-336 [edited] (the full article can be accessed at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5215a2.htm>).\nIn the United States, as of 17 Apr 2003, a total of 208 suspected\nSARS cases were reported to CDC from 34 states. Of these, 35 (17\npercent) had illness consistent with the WHO case definition for\nprobable SARS which requires the presence of pneumonia or acute\nrespiratory distress syndrome (RDS) (3), and the remaining 173 ( 83\npercent) had fever and milder respiratory symptoms. Of the 35\nprobable patients, 33 (94 percent) had traveled to mainland China,\nHong Kong, Singapore, or Hanoi; one (3 percent) was a health-care\nworker (HCW) who provided care to a SARS patient, and one (3 percent)\nwas a household contact of a SARS patient. As previously reported, 5\nof these 33 patients, all of whom were travelers, had laboratory\nevidence of recent infection with a novel coronavirus (4). Although\nno additional coronavirus infections have been documented among other\nU.S. suspected SARS cases, collection and testing of convalescent\nsera (i.e., sera obtained greater than 21 days after illness onset)\nfor coronavirus infection is ongoing. [Table 1 is a presentation of\nepidemiologic data on the reported cases including age distribution\nand exposure history; Table 2 is a presentation of characteristics of\nthe 2 described local transmission pairs. Figure 1 is an updated\nepidemic curve by type of exposure and date of onset of case, with\nthe most recent date of onset recorded as 12 Apr 2003 - Mod.MPP]\nSARS Patients with No History of Recent Travel Outside the United States\nA total of 19 U.S. residents reported with SARS have no history of\ntravel to mainland China, Hong Kong, Singapore, or Hanoi. All\nreported close contact with a SARS patient who had traveled recently\nto one or more of these areas. 5 of these cases occurred among HCWs\nwho were exposed to a suspected SARS patient and either did not use\npersonal protective equipment or removed it while examining the\npatient; in only one instance was the SARS patient provided a\nsurgical mask. Among the 19 close contacts, 2 had illness consistent\nwith the WHO case definition for a probable case, 4 required\nhospitalization, and none is currently hospitalized. 10 have had\nacute specimens that tested negative for the novel coronavirus. One\npatient also has had a negative convalescent serum.\nThese 19 patients were close contacts of 16 index patients. Of the 16\nindex patients, one (6 percent) tested positive for coronavirus\ninfection, 3 (19 percent) have had a negative serologic test on a\nconvalescent specimen; results from 12 (75 percent) are pending. 2\n(11 percent) index patients had illness consistent with the WHO\ndefinition of a probable SARS case; the 2 instances of local\ntransmission in the United States involving these patients are\nsummarized [and can be found in the full text at the given link].\nMMWR Editorial Note:\nThe primary focus of SARS surveillance activities in the United\nStates is early identification and isolation of patients who have\nsuspected SARS. Many suspected SARS patients in the United States\nhave had relatively mild illness and have not required\nhospitalization or chest radiographs. The majority of these reported\npatients are not likely to have the novel coronavirus infection, as\nrespiratory illness is common in travelers (5,6). A small number of\npersons reported with SARS in the United States had more severe\nillness that was consistent with the WHO case definition of probable\nSARS. Cases reported to WHO from other countries are probable SARS\ncases, whereas the United States has reported all of its suspected\ncases (7).\nIn the United States, local transmission of suspected SARS has been\nlimited to HCWs and close contacts of suspected SARS patients who\nwere travelers. Identifying persons who might be at risk for SARS on\narrival to a medical facility or office is difficult and requires\nchanges in the way medical evaluations are conducted. Revised interim\nguidelines for triage recommend that all patients in ambulatory-care\nsettings be screened promptly for fever, respiratory symptoms, recent\ntravel, and close contact with a suspected SARS patient (8). CDC has\nprovided guidance to state and local health departments for\nconducting surveillance of HCWs following exposure to a SARS patient.\nTo prevent secondary transmission, close contacts of SARS patients\nshould be vigilant for fever or respiratory symptoms. If such\nsymptoms develop, exposed persons should avoid contact with others,\nseek immediate medical attention, and practice infection-control\nprecautions recommended for SARS patients (9). Household members and\nother close contacts of SARS patients should be actively monitored by\nthe local health department for illness.\nCDC continues to develop and refine laboratory testing for the novel\ncoronavirus that has been implicated as the cause of SARS and has\nrecently published the nucleic acid sequence of the genome (10).\nIncorporating laboratory evidence of coronavirus infection into the\ncase definition will be important to characterize the clinical\nmanifestations of coronavirus infection and understand the relation\nbetween infection with this novel coronavirus and SARS.\nReferences\n1. 'We\nhave received a sample from Goa and it is positive for the corona\nvirus that is responsible for SARS,' said Dr A.C. Mishra, director of\nthe institute in the western city of Pune. The case involved a man in\nthe western state of Goa, officials said. 'He fell sick 2 days ago.\nHe is from Goa, but he had been travelling in Hong Kong, Singapore,\nBombay, and then returned to Goa,' he said.\n[Another newswire report from the Hindustani Times\n<http://www.hindustantimes.com/news/181_235567,0008.htm> gave the\nfollowing additional information:\nSARS has finally hit India, with the government on Thursday\nannouncing that the virus has been found in the blood, urine, and\nsputum samples of a 32-year-old marine engineer in Goa, who is,\nhowever, no longer infective. "2003-04-16 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (51): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Wed 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: World Health Organisation, Press release, Wed 16 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/pr31/en/>\n\nConfirmation that a Novel SARS-associated Coronavirus is the Cause of SARS\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nGENEVA: Today, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced that a new\npathogen, a member of the coronavirus family [the family _Coronaviridae_]\nnever before seen in humans, is the cause of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (SARS). The speed at which this virus was identified is the result\nof the close international collaboration of 13 laboratories from 10\ncountries. While many lines of evidence have found strong associations\nbetween this virus and the disease over the last weeks, final confirmation\ncame today. 'The pace of SARS research has been astounding,'said Dr. David\nHeymann, Executive Director, WHO Communicable Diseases programmes. 'Because\nof an extraordinary collaboration among laboratories from countries around\nthe world, we now know with certainty what causes SARS. The successful\nidentification of the coronavirus means that scientists can now confidently\nturn to other SARS challenges. For example, various laboratories continue\nto work to unravel the genetic information of the SARS virus and compare\nthe sequences obtained from viruses in different parts of the world.\nExperts are gathering at WHO this week to map future work on SARS.'\n'Today, the collaboration continues as top laboratory researchers have come\nto WHO to design the next steps, a strategy for transforming these basic\nresearch discoveries into diagnostic tools which will help us to\nsuccessfully control this disease,' said Heymann. 'Now we can move away\nfrom methods like isolation and quarantines and move aggressively towards\nmodern intervention strategies including specific treatments and eventually\nvaccination. With the establishment of the causative agent, we are a\ncrucial step closer.' This collaboration has brought together leading\nscientific expertise, and was established after WHO issued a global alert\non SARS on 12 March 2003. The priority has been to find the cause and to\ndevelop diagnostic tests. Two laboratories in China recently joined this\nnetwork of laboratories from Canada, France, Germany, Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region of China, Japan, the Netherlands, Singapore, the\nUnited Kingdom, and the United States of America.\n'Today, the first part of the mission of our network has been fulfilled, as\nresearchers have both detected a hitherto unknown virus and established it\nas the cause of SARS. The new coronavirus has been named by WHO and member\nlaboratories as SARS virus, 'said Dr Albert Osterhaus, the Director of\nVirology at Erasmus Medical Centre in Rotterdam. The Erasmus Medical Centre\ncompleted the work to definitely prove that the new coronavirus causes SARS\n[see following report].\nOver the past three weeks, due to the urgency surrounding the worldwide\nthreat to health of SARS and early indications this was a new member of the\nfamily _Coronaviridae_, research has proceeded under the assumption that\nSARS was caused by a new coronavirus. The 13 laboratories have been working\non meeting Koch's postulates, necessary to prove disease causation. These\npostulates stipulate that to be the causal agent, a pathogen must meet four\nconditions: it must be found in all cases of the disease, it must be\nisolated from the host and grown in pure culture, it must reproduce the\noriginal disease when introduced into a susceptible host, and it must be\nfound in the experimental host so infected. Credit for the coronavirus\nfindings, which definitively pinpoints the cause of SARS, is attributed to\nthe 13 laboratories, working in conjunction with WHO.\n'The people in this network have put aside profit and prestige to work\ntogether to find the cause of this new disease and to find way new ways of\nfighting it,'said Dr Klaus St\u00f6hr, WHO virologist and the coordinator of the\ncollaborative research network. 'In this globalized world, such\ncollaboration is the only way forward in tackling emerging diseases.'\nWHO and the network of laboratories dedicate their detection and\ncharacterization of the SARS virus to Dr Carlo Urbani, the WHO scientist\nwho first alerted the world to the existence of SARS in Hanoi, Vietnam, and\nwho died from the disease in Bangkok on 29 March 2003.\nFor more information contact: Dick Thompson, Communication Officer, WHO,\nGeneva <thompsond@who.int>.\n[A more informative version of the WHO statement is given below. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Wed 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: BBC News online, Wed 16 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/2953285.stm>\n\nScientific Confirmation that a Novel Coronavirus is the Etiologic Agent of SARS\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe World Health Organization said tests prove severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS) is a [novel] coronavirus,. These latest tests were carried\nout by scientists at the Erasmus Medical Centre, University of Rotterdam,\nthe Netherlands. This laboratory is one of 13 laboratories from 10\ncountries working with the WHO to combat the virus. The scientists infected\nmonkeys with the strain of coronavirus suspected of causing SARS. They\nfound that the animals developed the same symptoms of the disease as\nhumans. The test was a crucial step in verifying the cause of the disease.\nAlthough experts have thought that a new [species] of coronavirus was the\nmain cause of SARS, it had remained unclear whether infection with a second\n[unrelated] type of virus, Human metapneumovirus, makes the illness worse.\nTheir tests were made possible by studies published last week, which\nsuggested SARS was a new virus [see: SARS - worldwide (48): etiology\n20030414.0909, and the following report]. Scientists from eight countries,\nincluding Germany and the United States, found it was not consistent with\nany other known virus. They also carried out genetic tests on the virus,\nwhich found it was 'only distantly related' to known coronaviruses.\nDr David Heymann, executive director of WHO communicable diseases\nprogrammes, hailed scientists' efforts to identify the virus. 'The pace of\nSARS research has been astounding,' he said. 'Because of an extraordinary\ncollaboration among laboratories from countries around the world, we now\nknow with certainty what causes SARS.' Dr Heymann said the discovery would\nnow enable scientists to concentrate on developing diagnoses kits and\ntreatments. 'Now we can move away from methods like isolation and\nquarantines and move aggressively towards modern intervention strategies\nincluding specific treatments and eventually vaccination. 'With the\nestablishment of the causative agent, we are a crucial step closer,' he\nsaid. The discovery will also help scientists trace the evolution of SARS\nand could help them determine whether it jumped from animals to humans.\nTests are ongoing in pigs and poultry to see how susceptible those animals\nare to [the SARS coronavirus].\nResearchers at the University of Hong Kong said a new genetic sequencing of\nthe SARS virus proves conclusively that it came from animals. [This\nconflicts with the interpretation of the British Columbia Cancer Centre\nscientists, who have obtained the the complete sequence of the SARS virus\ngenome: see below. - Mod.CP]. Malik Peiris, a microbiologist at the\nuniversity, described SARS as 'something that is new to science'. He also\ndismissed claims that it could have been spread by terrorists. 'That whole\ngenome is essentially new,' he said. 'Nature has been the terrorist\nthrowing up this virus.'\nOn Tuesday, a German biotechnology company said it was distributing a new\nhigh-speed test for SARS. Their test identifies this strain of the\ncoronavirus which has now been confirmed as causing SARS. The firm Artus is\nconfident the test can confirm the presence of the lethal respiratory\ndisease in two hours, whereas traditional tests for antibodies take more\nthan 10 days [see also: SARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901].\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Tue 15 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Genome.web, Tue 15 Apr 2003 [edited]\n\nSARS Coronavirus Genome Has 11 Novel Open Reading Frames\n--------------------------------------------------------\nNEW YORK: The sequenced coronavirus believed to cause Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome (SARS) has 11 open reading frames (ORF), and these\npredicted coding regions lack homology to sequence in existing gene\ndatabases, Steven Jones, Director of Bioinformatics at the British Columbia\nCancer Center, said today. 'People were thinking that [the SARS virus] was\nsome kind of hybrid virus between a fairly well studied human virus,\nrecombined with a non-human virus,' he said. 'A lot of those Asian flus\nhave been associated with avian viruses.' But the ORFs that Jones' group is\nfinding all have consistent phylogeny. 'They all look like they have been\nin the same organism for a long period of time,' he said. And they are\n'only modestly similar to [ORFs in] other coronaviruses.'\nJones led an all-night effort last Friday night to assemble the sequence of\nthis viral pathogen, after the raw reads began coming off of the center's\nten ABI 3700s and 3730 sequencers at 9:30 PM. 'We were continuously doing\nassemblies through the night as more and more virus accrued,' he said. As a\nresult, the small team beat the US Centers for Disease Control to the\nfinish line for the draft sequence (although nobody says there was a race).\nThe process began six days earlier, when the group received a microgram\nsample of virus from the Canadian National Microbiology lab in Winnipeg,\nManitoba --- a small sample to work with. They spent the first four days\nmaking the cDNA library out of the RNA virus, Jones said. 'On Thursday we\nwere able to pick enough colonies to start doing DNA prep on the clones,\nand by Friday virtually the entire genome's worth of sequence was loaded\nup. 'There were no real bumps in the road once the sequencing machines got\ngoing. The shotgun sequencing was at a 20-30-fold level of redundancy,\nJones said, 'because we didn't want to do any iterative finishing steps.'\nThe only problem with sequencing this deep was that the group began finding\nsingle-base mutations in different copies of the viral genome. Though\nmutations in the virus are of potential research interest, Jones said the\nlevel of mutation found was not unsurprising given the rapid rate at which\nviruses mutate, and the fact that the group had grown the virus in primate\ncells to produce more sample. Still, they have to further analyse the\nsequence for mutation sites. Now Jones' team is redesigning PCR primers to\nconfirm the sequence, and is doing further sequence analysis, including\ncomparing its draft to that released yesterday by the US Centers for\nDiseaseControl, Jones said.\nThe BC Cancer Center team is also in touch with the Canadian Centers for\nDisease Control, which is involved in efforts to establish reliable tests\nfor SARS, along with the US CDC and other bodies around the world.\nSeparately, the Singapore News reported Tuesday that the Genome Institute\nof Singapore has also sequenced the SARS coronavirus, and has prepared a\ntest kit for SARS which it plans to make available to local laboratories\nand hospitals this week.\n(By Marian Moser Jones)\n\n*****\n[4]\nDate: Tue 15 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website, Tue 15 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_15/en/>\n\nWHO Update 30 - Status of Diagnostic Test\n-----------------------------------------\nScientists participating in the WHO collaborative network of laboratories\nhave developed several diagnostic tests for SARS. These include a so-called\n'PCR' test, which allows detection of the distinctive genetic information\nof a virus. Primers, which are the key pieces for a PCR test, were made\npublicly available by network laboratories on the open WHO web site\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/primers/en/>) on 4 Apr 2003. The primers have\nsince been used by numerous countries around the world.\nWHO scientists are now increasingly optimistic that the current PCR\ndiagnostic test for SARS can rapidly be fine-tuned to a stage ready for\nroll out. Fine-tuning is needed because of important limitations in the\nability of the current test to rule out the presence of\n[non-SARS-associated] coronavirus in SARS cases. Yesterday, the\nBernhard-Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine in Hamburg, Germany informed\nWHO that primers developed there are being made available, in the form of a\nready-to-use kit, by a Hamburg-based biotechnology firm. Apart from ease of\nuse, the test kit has the advantage of built-in quality control. WHO was\nfurther informed by the Hamburg Institute that the test will be offered at\nno cost to laboratories participating in the WHO collaborative network [see\nalso: SARS - worldwide (46): diagnostic test 20030413.0901].\nInitial testing of the kit by network members is expected to quickly yield\nthe data needed to assess the test's performance, in comparison with\nprimers developed by other WHO network laboratories. The ability to detect\npersons infected with the SARS virus at an early stage is a key measure of\nperformance. WHO has been concerned that weaknesses in earlier experimental\ntests for SARS would allow too many virus carriers to slip past undetected.\nExisting PCR tests are very specific but may not detect all patients who\nare excreting coronavirus. Artus has\nteamed up with the Bernard-Nocht-Institute for Tropical Medicine (BNI) in\nHamburg and will donate the test free to laboratories for evaluation. BNI\n[and other laboratories in the WHO consortium] identified a SARS-associated\nvirus 2 weeks ago as an [atypical] coronavirus. The Artus test will be\navailable from it and its subsidiaries in both the USA and Malaysia in the\ncoming week, the company said in a statement. The assay can detect [the\nSARS-associated coronavirus] using throat swabs, sputum or faecal systems,\nand is an advance on antibody assays from blood which may take 10 or 20\ndays to process.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 13 Apr 2003\nFrom: 'Christian Drosten' <drosten@bni-hamburg.de>\n[The preceding newswire report was referred to Dr. Chrisian Drosten of the\nBernhard-Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine in Hamburg for comment, and\nDr. Drosten's reply is reproduced below. Neither ProMED-mail, nor Dr.\nDrosten, have any commercial association with the companies concerned. The\ninformation is relayed in the public interest.- Mod.CP]\nThe Bernhard-Nocht Institute (BNI) has developed and evaluated different\nRT-PCR tests for the SARS-associated coronavirus (for simplicity,\nhereinafter called SARSV - not an officially proposed name or acronym). It\nhas been our policy to make available all our tests for SARSV before\npublication to rapidly provide reliable diagnostic instruments [see\nProMed-mail posting SARS - worldwide (19): etiology 20030330.0786].\nProtocols of the BNI PCRs are available from or,\ntogether with that of other institutions, from the WHO homopage\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/primers/en/>.\nBNI currently recommends 2 different RT-PCRs for SARSV: 1. A nested PCR,\nprimers BNIoutS2, BNIoutAs; BNIinS, BNIinAs. 2. A real-time PCR, primers\nBNITMSARS1, BNITMSARAs2, probe BNITMSARP. All BNI PCRs have been published\nin an early release article in the New England Journal of Medicine on Wed\n10 Apr 2003 <http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030747v2.pdf> [See\nalso: SARS - worldwide (38): etiology 20030410.0869]. The positioning of\nthe recommended primers can also be looked up there. Both PCRs allow the\ndetection of single copies of RNA and do not cross-react with both human\ncoronaviruses and various animal coronaviruses (mouse hepatitis virus,\nbovine coronavirus, avian infectious bronchitis virus, porcine coronavirus).\nAs a latest development, BNI's real-time PCR has been transformed into a\ndiagnostic kit by Artus-biotech, a company specialized in providing PCR\nkits for diagnostic application.\nRole of the BNI: The BNI is an academic institution. BNI has asked two\nBiotech companies for assistance in distributing necessary test reagents.\nCompany 1 is Tib-Molbiol in Berlin, company 2 is Artus-biotech in Hamburg.\nBNI itself distributes free of charge a cloned and in-vitro transcribed 200\nbp fragment of the SARSV polymerase gene containing the target region of\nits SARSV PCRs. The RNA is shipped in lyophilized form to every laboratory\ninterested in establishing BNI's diagnostic tests. So far, about 80\nlaboratories worldwide have obtained the RNA. Requests are continuing.\nContact for the RNA: <drosten@bni-hamburg.de>.\nRole of Tib-Molbiol, Berlin: Tib-Molbiol has synthesized all primers and\nprobes developed by the BNI for SARSV in large scale stocks. Tib-Molbiol\nmakes the primers available from four sites: Roche Taiwan, Roche Singapore,\nRoche Hong Kong, Tib-Molbiol Berlin. The oligonucleotides can be obtained\nrapidly, i.e. without having to wait for their synthesis, and comply with\nthe highest quality criteria. The persons responsible at Tib-Molbiol for\nthis project are Olfert Landt and Uli Lass. Contact e-mail is\n<ulass@tib-molbiol.de>. Order e-mail is <dna@tib-molbiol.de>.\nIn addition to supplying oligonucleotides, Tib-Molbiol gives application\nsupport to labs establishing tests with these oligonucleotides. Detailed\nworking bench protocols are also provided. Upon request, positive control\nmaterial (plasmid) can be obtained from Tib-Molbiol.\nRole of Artus-biotech, Hamburg: Artus has made a real-time RT-PCR kit based\non BNI's test. The technical performance of the kit has been approved by\nBNI. The test can be used on different real-time machines, including Roche\nLightCylcer and Corbett Rotorgene. It contains an internal control that\nallows to monitor the presence of PCR inhibitors in each test sample. Artus\nis willing to distribute the test for free to allow laboratories to\nevaluate the kit before they decide to use it for diagnostics. Further\ninformation can be obtained from Artus project leader Thomas Laue\n(<laue@artus-biotech.de>) or via\n<http://www.artus-biotech2.com/en/framesets/index_news.php?id=24>.\nPlease note that the case definition of SARS does not include findings in PCR.\nStatement of WHO regarding the use of PCR for SARSV: 'Results of PCR ...\ncan be used to complement clinical diagnostic evaluation. However, tests\nhave not been validated for confirmation of cases or exclusion of the\ndisease. The WHO case definition remains unchanged at present. Samples from\npotential SARS patients (suspected or probable) should be performed under\nconditions of Biosafety level 3 (BSL-3). Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspected cases under investigation.\n2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of (See Affected Areas ).\n3. One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] The list of affected areas can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_14/en/> and is unchanged from the\nlist posted on 12 Apr 2003.\n[C] Update 29 - Situation in China, status of scientific and clinical knowledge\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_14/en/>\nSituation in China\nChina has today reported 109 new probable cases of SARS and 6 deaths,\nbringing the cumulative total to 1418 cases and 64 deaths. The largest\nnumber of cases occurred in Shanxi Province, where 47 new cases were\nreported. In addition, 2 provinces reported SARS cases for the first time;\n10 in Inner Mongolia and 3 in Fujian. [confirming both reports in the\nnewswire briefs in ProMED-mail posting SARS - worldwide (45): cases\n20030412.0890]\nThe reports indicate that the nationwide surveillance system recently\nintroduced by Chinese authorities is working to detect and report cases.\nHowever, questions remain about the capacity of some provinces to cope with\nthe challenge of SARS.\nLast week, the interim report of the WHO investigative team concluded that\nthe health system in Guangdong Province, where the first recognized cases\nof SARS occurred in mid-November [2002], had responded well to the\noutbreak. However, the report noted many concerns about the ability of\nother provinces, which lack Guangdong's strong health system, to respond\npromptly and effectively to SARS.\nWhile Beijing authorities appear to have contained transmission in some\nhospitals, they have not yet granted WHO experts permission to visit\nmilitary hospitals, which have been the focus of numerous rumours. WHO\nstaff in Beijing have expressed particular concern about the official\nresponse to rumours and the apparent absence of rigorous contact tracing.\nWHO is currently exploring ways to strengthen its support to China.\nShanghai has requested a visit from a WHO team. Teams to meet this request\nand follow up on other needs in China are now being assembled by WHO and\nwill soon travel to China.\nStatus of scientific knowledge\nCanadian scientists working around the clock have completed full sequencing\nof the genome of the SARS virus. This is a major step forward that will\nboost the development of better diagnostic tests and underpin work on a\nvaccine.\nThe rapid sequencing of the SARS virus genome was facilitated by\ncollaboration with numerous other scientists, also working non-stop, at\nlaboratories in a WHO network set up in mid-March [2003].\nA PCR test, developed by the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention,\nhas been shown to be 10 times more sensitive than previous PCR tests for\nSARS. WHO experts hope that the test will be ready for roll-out by the end\nof this week.\nStatus of clinical knowledge\nData available to WHO indicate that 96 percent of persons developing SARS\nrecover spontaneously. The focus now is on the roughly 4 percent who are\ndying. WHO will hold a clinical teleconference on Wednesday [16 Apr 2003]\nto gather international experiences in the management of SARS patients and\npool data on the results of various therapeutic regimens.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 3169 cases of SARS, with 144 deaths,\nhave been reported to WHO from 21 countries. This represents an increase of\n213 cases and 25 deaths since the last update on Saturday.\nIndonesia, the Philippines, and Sweden report their first probable cases (1\nin each country) today. Japan, which had previously reported 4 probable\ncases, was removed from the list as these cases were determined to have\nother causes.\nChina, with 1418 cases and 64 deaths, remains the most seriously affected\narea. In the case of coinfection with human\nimmunodifficiency virus (a member of the Retroviridae) and hepatitis C\nvirus (a member of the Flaviviridae), a more rapid progression of liver\ndisease to severe liver damage is observed, hence there is a precedent for\na potentiation of disease with active coinfection of 2 different viral\norganisms.\nThe late-breaking news from Canada on the possibility of community-based\nspread outside of the previously defined groups is disconcerting. "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (47):  cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203630", "date": "2003-04-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (47): CASES\n*********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] Canada - Health Canada\n******\n[1]\nDate: 13 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 13 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 13 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 13 Apr 2003, an additional 42 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals. They include 9 healthcare\nworkers (4 from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital, 2 from Princess\nMargaret Hospital, 2 from Prince of Wales Hospital, and one from Queen\nElizabeth Hospital) and 5 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 28 were\nnew patients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 223 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 8 were discharged today.\nMost of the patients currently in hospital are showing positive responses\nto the new treatment protocol. 122 patients are receiving treatment in\nintensive care units.\n5 patients died in hospitals last night and this morning, bringing to 40\nthe total number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia. A 40-year-old\nmale died in United Christian Hospital. 2 men, aged 41 and 52, a\n45-year-old female and a 66-year-old female with a history of chronic\ndisease died in Princess Margaret Hospital.\nThe cumulative figures for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative number of reported cases/ total no. discharged cases/ no. deaths\n(all reported cases have evidence of pneumonia)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 276/ 91/ 40\nPatients, family members & visitors: 874 / 132 / 0\nTotal: 1150 / 223 / 40\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively\nlate stage of infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 13 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 13 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6100>\n\nSARS Situation Update 13 Apr 2003\nAs of 13 April 2003, 81 SARS patients have been discharged. 58 SARS\npatients remain hospitalised.\nThere were 4 additional SARS cases reported today, 3 of whom are linked to\nthe Singapore General Hospital (SGH) cluster comprising a hospital staff\nmember and 2 visitors. The last case is the resident of the Orange Valley\nNursing Home whose death as been reclassified as SARS. There were 2 deaths\nyesterday, both linked to the SGH cluster comprising a visitor and an\ninpatient.\nSituation Update at SGH\nSo far, 60 persons are linked to the SGH cluster, comprising 30 probable\nand 30 suspect SARS cases. They comprise 28 SGH staff, 12 inpatients, and\n20 contacts.\n4 staff from SGH Urology Outpatient Centre and a visitor who was at the SGH\nDiagnostic Radiology Barium Investigation corridor were admitted to TTSH\nover the weekend. These 2 areas are adjacent and connected to each other.\nThe visitor and a staff member are probable cases. The other 3 staff are\nsuspect cases.\nInvestigations showed that these cases can be traced back to the same\nChinese man in his 60s who started the cluster at Wards 57 and 58. 2 of\nthe urology staff are healthcare assistants in the Urology Outpatient\nCentre. One of them, a new employee, started work on 1 Apr 2003 and became\nsymptomatic on 4 Apr 2003. The other was her supervisor and she became ill\non 7 Apr 2003. The other 2 urology staff are staff nurses. The visitor to\nthe Radiology Department was at the department when the 'index' case was\nthere for a procedure. He became ill on 9 Apr 2003.\nAdditional Precautionary Measures from 12 Apr 2003\nActive contact tracing of 110 staff who work in the urology and the\nradiology barium investigation corridor was started immediately and has\nbeen completed. Contact tracing of patients who may have been exposed is in\nprogress. The Urology Outpatient Centre has been closed and will remain so\nuntil 18 Apr 2003. As an added precaution, the Urology ward (Ward 55B), has\nbeen isolated. 12 patients who were in the ward at the time have been\nisolated in 12 rooms. A 'No Visitors' rule has been enforced on the ward.\nThe Radiology Barium investigation corridor affected has also been closed.\nIn addition, the Radiology archives are closed.\nAltogether 120 staff have been put on hospital-enforced quarantine. This\nincludes doctors from the Department of Urology. All inpatients will now\nhave their movement and contact history logged. All visitors to the\nHospital will be registered at each visit location.\nCluster around the resident of Orange Valley Nursing Home\nA 90-year-old Chinese woman was discharged from Tan Tock Seng Hospital\n(TTSH) to the Orange Valley Nursing Home on 23 Mar 2003. She had been\nadmitted to TTSH since 8 Mar 2003 for non-SARS related condition. When the\npatient was in TTSH, she was in the same ward for a day as a patient who\nwas later diagnosed as a SARS case. On 25 Mar 2003, she became unwell, was\nadmitted to the Changi General Hospital (CGH) Ward 18, and died of\npneumonia on 30 Mar 2003.\nThe 24-year-old Fillipino nurse from the nursing home who had been\nattending to this lady was admitted to CGH on 4 Apr 2003 for pneumonia and\ntransferred to TTSH on 6 Apr 2003 for probable SARS. A 57-year-old CGH\nhealth attendant who had attended to the 90-year-old woman was admitted to\nCGH on 10 Apr 2003 and transferred to TTSH on 11 Apr 2003 as a probable\nSARS case. They are both currently in intensive care.\nThe deceased lady's daughter-in-law, who had visited her several times at\nthe nursing home and CGH, was admitted to TTSH on 7 Apr 2003 for SARS. She\nis also in intensive care. A relative of hers and her son, a secondary\nstudent at Zhonghua Secondary, were also admitted to TTSH on 8 and 9 Apr\n2003, respectively. They are both in stable condition.\nIn view of the epidemiological evidence that persons who had close contact\nwith the older woman have been diagnosed with SARS, the cause of her death\nhas been changed to SARS.\nSituation Update at CGH\nBesides the 57-year-old CGH healthcare attendant who was exposed to the\n90-year-old Chinese lady when she was in CGH, there have been no other\ncases reported in CGH. The hospital is now contacting 35 patients who could\npossibly be exposed to the healthcare worker at Ward 18.\nThe 2 nurses who were exposed to a patient who has not been diagnosed as a\nSARs patient then were transferred to TTSH on 5 and 6 Apr 2003. They are in\nstable condition. The hospital has contacted 53 out of 59 patients who were\npossibly exposed to them. These are patients warded at Ward 15 on 29 and 30\nMar 2003 and Ward 28 on 3 Apr 2003. They are well. CGH is still trying to\nget in touch with 6 patients who remain uncontactable.\nUpdate on Super Star Virgo\nCruise ship Superstar Virgo arrived in Singapore on 9 Apr 2003 at 1900 hrs\nwith 625 passengers and 1354 crew onboard. An Indian crewmember was\nexamined by the vessel doctor and found to have high fever. The MPA and\nPort Health Office were later notified. ICA activated the ambulance to send\nthe unwell crewmember to TTSH at 2015 hrs. After examination, he was\nadmitted as a SARS suspect at TTSH.\nNurses were deployed to do visual screening of all passengers and crew who\ndisembarked from the vessel, and none were found to be unwell. All were\nrequired to fill out Health Declaration Cards (HDC), which were collected\nby the ICA officers.\nThe ship left Singapore for Port Klang on 9 Apr 2003 at 2330 hrs. The\nvessel had 188 transit passengers from the previous sailing, 677 new\npassengers, and 1353 crewmembers when it left.\nIn view of the SARS suspect case, it was decided that additional\nprecautions were to be taken when the ship returned to Singapore on 11 Apr\n2003. The ship's doctor was to take the temperature of the 125 transit\npassengers (63 of the 188 transit passengers had disembarked at Port Klang)\nand declare their temperature readings before passengers were allowed to\ndisembark in Singapore. Star Cruises would also suspend crew shore leave\nand disallow its crew to disembark.\nSuperstar Virgo returned to Singapore on 11 Apr 2003 at 1345 hrs. Based on\nthe temperature readings submitted by the ship's doctor, none of the 125\ntransit passengers had a fever. All the transit passengers and new\npassengers were thus allowed to disembark and underwent visual screening by\nnurses when they did so. No one was found to be unwell. All filled out\nhealth declaration cards and these were submitted to ICA Officers. The\nIndian crewmember, who was warded to TTSH as a SARS suspect case, is\nexpected to be discharged tomorrow, as he is no longer feverish.\nSuperstar Virgo is scheduled to depart Singapore at 2230 hrs on 13 Apr\n2003. In preparation for its next sailing, the vessel left its anchorage\nat 0700 hrs on 13 Apr 03 and arrived at the Singapore Cruise Centre (SCC)\nat 0800 hrs. About 309 crew are to be repatriated, subject to temperature\nchecks and confirmation that they are well. Star Cruises has a medical\ndoctor onboard the vessel to conduct the necessary medical checks. Once\ncleared, these crew members are to be taken straight to the airport for\ntheir flight home. As of 1700 hrs, a total of 82 crew members have been\nrepatriated after they were confirmed to be well and fit for travel. The\nrepatriation of the crew members is expected to be complete at 0115 hrs, 14\nApr 2003.\nHealth screening for incoming air passengers\nBetween 4 PM 12 Apr 2003 and 4 PM 13 Apr 2003, 35 passengers from affected\nareas required further screening by the nurses at the airport. None were\nsent to TTSH for further assessment.\nBelow is the summary of the SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 81\nHospitalised: 58\nIntensive care: 16\nDeaths: 10 + 2 (pending post mortem findings)\nTotal: 151\nSuspected: 87 (including 2 children)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 608\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 13 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n\n[A] Update: severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) 13 Apr 2003 4:00 PM\nLatest Canadian Numbers on SARS\nAs of 13 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 283 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 13 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons\nwho have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household\nor in a health-care setting. The information contained in this update is\nbased on the best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 97 probable and 135 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 3 probable and 36 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nSo far, 55 people have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario. These\npeople were treated as suspect cases or as probable cases.\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 13 Apr 2003.\n[B] Epidemiologic analysis of outbreak\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/prof_e.html>\n[Information on epidemiologic analyses of the outbreak of SARS in Toronto\nare available via the above given link. The data available as of today are\ncurrent through 12 Apr 2003 and can be accessed at:\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030412_e.html>.\nInterested readers are urged to check out the available data, as it\ncontains an excellent epidemic curve current through 2 Apr 2003 based on\ndate of onset of illness of cases, and type of contact transmission\n(travellers, healthcare-related exposure, index case household contact,\nhealthcare-related exposure household contact).\nAccording to the analyses to date, the conclusion is 'there is currently no\nevidence to suggest the presence community transmission of SARS in Canada.\nAll identified probable cases of SARS have been linked to either\ntravel-related exposures, or in healthcare and household settings.'\nAdditional information of interest from this presentation is given below. -\nMod.MPP]\nSince yesterday, no additional probable cases of SARS have been reported in\nCanada. A total of 100 individuals who meet the probable case definition of\nSARS have been reported in Ontario and British Columbia, including 13\ndeaths; 174 individuals who meet the definition of a suspect case of SARS\nhave also been reported in British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan,\nOntario, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island. Since SARS is a diagnosis\nof exclusion, the status of a reported case may change over time.\nAt the present time, the case fatality rate in Canada is estimated at\napproximately 4.7 percent of probable or suspect cases (13 of 274 probable\nor suspect cases). Most of the case fatalities occurred in patients with\nunderlying illness, and nearly all were elderly patients over the age of 70\nyears.\nTable 2: Currently reported status of probable cases of SARS in Canada: 12\nApr 2003\n(N=97, excluding 3 for whom status is unknown)\nCurrent Status: No./total in category (percent)\nHospitalised: 62/97 (64 percent)\n- Improving: 13/62 (21 percent)\n- Stable: 29/62 (47 percent)\n- Critical/Deteriorating: 7/62 (11 percent)\n- Unknown: 13/62 (21 percent)\nDischarged(1): 25/97 (26 percent)\nDeceased: 13/97 (13 percent)\nTotal: 97 (100 percent)\n(1) Includes cases who have either recovered or are recovering\nTable 3: Type of exposure to probable cases of SARS in Canada: 11 Apr 2003\nExposure type: No. cases (percent of total cases)\nHospital or healthcare-related setting: 72 (74 percent)\nHousehold: 19 (19 percent)\nTravel: 7 ( 7 percent)\nTotal 98 (100 percent)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hong Kong reported 42 new cases in the 24 hours since the last\nreport. More detailed information on the epidemiology of these cases was\nnot provided, other than the data that 9 of the new cases were health care\nworkers, 5 were residents of Amoy Gardens (the residence associated with\nunusual transmission), and the remaining 28 newly reported cases were in\nknown contacts of previously diagnosed SARS patients and new patients. The\nnumber of new patients is not specified, nor is the definition of possible\nexposure risks of these new patients given (e.g., are there other apartment\nblocks that are showing up epidemiologically to have increased numbers of\ncases? As a reminder, there is a posted list of apartment blocks where\nSARS cases have been identified on the Hong Kong Department of Health\nwebsite <http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/ap.htm>). We look forward to seeing\nmore detailed epidemiologic analyses of the current transmission patterns\nin Hong Kong.\nWe have included the report from Singapore in depth as a demonstration of\ntheir intense effort towards disease control. From the reduced numbers of\nnew cases reported on a daily basis, it appears as though these efforts\nhave been reasonably successful.\nFor those who are interested in PowerPoint presentations summarizing the\nepidemiologic points from investigations of the ongoing outbreak, we\nsuggest visiting the CDC website:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/ppt/domesticsars.ppt> for information on\nthe USA and <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/ppt/globalsars.ppt> for\ninformation on the global outbreak.\nGlobal updates on SARS cases were not available at the WHO SARS website as\nof 8:00 PM EDST (2:00 AM GMT +2 Geneva time). Similarly an update on the\nstatus of SARS cases in the USA was not available on the CDC SARS website\nas of 8:00 PM EDST. Additionally, the lay press reports did not contain\nadditional information that would add to this current posting or earlier\npostings, other than a quote in the NY Times from one of the WHO team\nleaders, Dr. James Maguire, while visiting hospitals in Beijing: 'If there\nhad been hundreds of SARS patients, it would have been very difficult to\nhide them,' in response to press speculation that there was significant\nunderreporting in Beijing.\n(<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/13/international/asia/13CHIN.html>) This\nquote was given after the team visited Chaoyang Hospital, a large general\nhospital that has seen some patients with the new ailment. We await more\nofficial details on the results of the epidemiologic investigations in\nChina. - Mod.MPP]\n[Please note that the number of prior postings on SARS is too numerous to\ninclude in the references section below. The large size of each posting is\ndue to the extensive amount of new information being generated on a daily\nbasis. For those who have not been receiving these postings in emails and\nare interested in following the history and evolution of SARS, we strongly\nsuggest you visit our website at: <http://www.promedmail.org> and follow\nthe update information in the designated SARS 'box'. In addition, the\npostings before the name 'severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)' was\ngiven to this observed clinical syndrome can be found by linking on the\nlast reference for each thread (e.g., Pneumonia - China (Guandong) (07),\nand then linking to the given references. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Additionally, the lay press reports did not contain\nadditional information that would add to this current posting or earlier\npostings, other than a quote in the NY Times from one of the WHO team\nleaders, Dr. James Maguire, while visiting hospitals in Beijing: 'If there\nhad been hundreds of SARS patients, it would have been very difficult to\nhide them,' in response to press speculation that there was significant\nunderreporting in Beijing. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspected cases under investigation.\n2. Includes cases who are 'discharged' or 'recovered' as reported by the\nnational public health authorities.\n3. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of affected areas.\n4. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR, China occurred in a case\nmedically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n[B] Affected areas can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_15/en/> and are unchanged from\nprevious posting on 14 Apr 2003\n[C] Update 30 - Significance of 'super spreaders', situation in China 15\nApr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_15/en/>\nExplanation of so-called SARS 'super-spreaders'\n'Super-spreader' is a term that has been used to describe certain\nindividuals with atypical pneumonia, now recognized as cases of SARS, who\nhave been implicated in spreading the disease to numerous other individuals.\nThe phenomenon of a 'super-spreader', which is not a recognized medical\ncondition, dates back to the early days of the outbreak. At that time, when\nSARS was just becoming known as a severe new disease, many patients were\nthought to be suffering from atypical pneumonia having another cause, and\nwere therefore not treated as special cases requiring special precautions\nof isolation and infection control.\nAs a result, stringent infection control measures were not in place. In the\nabsence of protective measures, many health care workers, relatives, and\nhospital visitors were exposed to the SARS virus and subsequently developed\nSARS.\nSince infection control measures have been put in place, the number of new\ncases of SARS arising from a single SARS source case has been significantly\nreduced.\nWhen investigating current chains of continuing transmission, it is\nimportant to look for points in the history of case detection and patient\nmanagement when procedures for infection control may have broken down.\nChina\nThe WHO team of experts in Beijing was today granted permission to visit\nmilitary hospitals. The situation of SARS cases in certain military\nhospitals has been the source of numerous rumours concerning the magnitude\nof the SARS outbreak. The WHO team has so far visited one such hospital but\nhopes to visit others soon.\nThe decision by Beijing authorities is a welcome indication of China's\nwillingness to come to terms with the SARS outbreak on the mainland.\nYesterday, China's president Hu Jintao said on state television that he was\n'very worried' by SARS.\nThe WHO Beijing team is expected to finish its preliminary investigation on\nthe status of SARS in China tomorrow. Additional WHO teams will travel soon\nto other parts of China.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 3235 cases of SARS, with 154 deaths,\nhave been reported from 22 countries. This represents an increase of 66 new\ncases and 10 deaths compared with the previous day. 9 of the 10 deaths\noccurred in Hong Kong SAR. One death was reported in Singapore.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 15 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 15 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 3 PM 15 Apr 2003, an additional 42 patients were confirmed to have\natypical pneumonia following previous admission to public hospitals. They\ninclude 11 healthcare workers (3 from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole\nHospital, 3 from Prince of Wales Hospital, 2 from Kwong Wah Hospital, 2\nfrom Princess Margaret Hospital, and one from Queen Elizabeth Hospital).\nThe remaining 31 were other patients and contacts of patients with atypical\npneumonia.\nA total of 243 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 14 were discharged\ntoday. 127 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care units.\n9 patients died in Queen Elizabeth Hospital, United Christian Hospital,\nPrincess Margaret Hospital, and Prince of Wales Hospital. This brought to\n56 the total number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia. The deceased\ninclude 4 men and one woman, aged from 45 to 84, who have a history of\nchronic diseases. The remaining are a 45-year-old man and 3 women, aged 32,\n34, and 37. [according to a table in an annex at the above website link,\nthese latter 4 deaths were in individuals without a history of chronic\ndisease. - Mod.MPP]\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nCumulative no. cases/ no. discharged cases/ no. deaths\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 291/ 95/ 56\nPatients, family members & visitors: 941/ 148/ 0\nTotal: 1232/ 243/ 56\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 15 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6160>\n\nSARS Situation Update 15 Apr 2003\nAs at 15 Apr 2003, 1 additional SAR patient has been discharged, bringing\nthe total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to 85. 64 SARS\npatients remain hospitalised.\nThere are 4 additional SARS cases reported today, all linked to the\nSingapore General Hospital (SGH) cluster. These are patients who had been\nearlier admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) as suspect cases and who\nhave now been diagnosed as having SARS, as they have developed signs of\nlung infection on chest-X-ray. They include 1 SGH staff member, 1\ninpatient, and 2 visitors. A SARS patient in intensive care died today. He\nwas a relative of one of the 3 initial index cases.\nInformation on additional probable cases\nSo far, 62 persons are linked to the SGH cluster, comprising 41 probable\nand 21 suspect SARS cases. They consist of 26 SGH staff, 16 inpatients, and\n20 visitors. They are all currently warded in TTSH.\nSummary of SARS cases\nBelow is the summary of the SARS cases to date:\nDischarged: 85\nHospitalised: 64 (including 18 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 11 + 2 (pending post mortem findings)\nTotal: 162\nSuspected: 86 (including 7 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 575\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 15 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update31.html>\n\nUpdate 31 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 15 Apr 2003\nAs of 15 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 296 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 13 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals, and specific\ncommunity settings. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 105 probable and 139 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 3 probable and 37 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nSo far, 82 people have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario. These\npeople were treated as suspect cases or as probable cases.\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 15 Apr 2003.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5]\nDate: 15 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website accessed 15 Apr 2003 6:00 PM EDST [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on 14 Apr 2003.\nState: suspected cases under investigation\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 41\nColorado: 6\nConnecticut: 4\nFlorida: 11\nGeorgia: 3\nHawaii: 5\nIllinois: 11\nIndiana: 1\nKansas: 1\nKentucky: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 8\nMichigan: 2\nMinnesota: 5\nMississippi: 1\nMissouri: 2\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 3\nNew Mexico: 1\nNew York: 22\nNorth Carolina: 6\nOhio: 10\nOregon: 1\nPennsylvania: 5\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 6\nUtah: 5\nVermont: 2\nVirginia: 5\nWashington: 19\nWisconsin: 1\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 193\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In the past 24 hours, since the last update, there have been 66 new cases\nand 10 new deaths reported. We look\nforward to further information on the collaborative investigations in China.\nThe discussion surrounding the 'super-spreaders' in today's WHO update\n[1][C] is very interesting and logical (so much for theories proposed by\nthis moderator in yesterday's posting as well as earlier postings, albeit\nthis was just in response to earlier suggestions on the part of the\nofficial agencies suggesting there were 'super-spreaders'). According to\nreports on the epidemiologic studies (which we have not seen as yet) the\n'super spreaders' were observed early on in the outbreak when infection\ncontrol procedures had not been implemented. Many of the second-generation\ncases in Hong Kong, Singapore, and Canada were related to contact within\nthe health care environment. Logically, with the introduction of infection\ncontrol procedures in the health care environment, this risk has been\nmarkedly reduced. It would be very interesting to see diagrammatic\nrepresentations of the spread in the various locations where studied (such\nas was presented in the 28 Mar 2003 MMWR article presenting the analyses\nof the cases resulting from contact in Hotel M in Hong Kong\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5212a1.htm>) for additional\nindividuals responsible for multiple next-generation cases, by type of\ncontact spread involved, and date of onset of symptoms.\nThe newswires were filled with articles related to SARS, the overwhelming\nmajority offering no new information not available on the official websites\nand presented here. There has been much mention of the economic impact of\nthis outbreak in terms of industries affected, most notably the travel\nindustry. This would include the airlines of the affected countries as\nwell as other airlines from Europe, the United States, and Australia that\nhave noted significant declines in traffic attributable to both SARS and\npolitical events.
