WHO\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] USA - CDC\n[5] Health Canada\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n\n\n[A] Cumulative number of reported probable(1) cases of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_16/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002 To: 16 Apr 2003, 12:00 GMT+2\n\nCountry: Cumulative no.case(s)/ no. new cases since last WHO update/ No.\ndeaths/ No. recovered (2)/ Local chain(s) of transmission(3)\n\nBrazil: 2/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nCanada: 103/ 3/ 13/ 37/ Yes\nChina: 1432/ 14/ 64/ 1094/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR (4) 1268/ 36/ 61/ 257/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 27/ 4/ 0/ 10/ Yes\nFrance: 5/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nGermany: 6/ 0/ 0/ 4/ None\nIndonesia: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ None\nJapan: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nMalaysia: 5/ 1/ 1/ 0/ None\nPhilippines: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nSingapore: 162/ 0/ 13/ 85/ Yes\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSweden: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nThailand: 8/ 0/ 2/ 5/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 6/ 0/ 0/ 3/ Yes\nUnited States: 193/ 0/ 0/ not available/ Yes\nViet Nam: 63/ 0/ 5/ 46/ Yes\n\nTotal: 3293/ 58/ 159/ 1548\n\nNotes:\n\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n\n1. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspected cases under investigation.\n\n2. Includes cases who are 'discharged' or 'recovered' as reported by the\nnational public health authorities.\n\n3. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of (See Affected Areas ).\n\n4. One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n[B] The list of affected areas can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_16/en/>\nand is unchanged from prior report\n\n[C] The epidemic curves can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsepicurve/epiindex/en/>\nand are current as of 14 Apr 2003.\n\n[D] There is an interesting discussion on the collaborating networks\ndeveloped as part of the operational response to SARS that can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/goarn2003_4_16/en/>\n\n[E] From a press release/conference 16 Apr 2003 found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/2003_04_16/en/>\n\n2 of the questions that were posed related to the completeness in reporting\nof cases from Beijing (and the lack of reporting of cases from the military\nhospitals), and the lay press observations of a change in profile of deaths\nin Hong Kong, where recently there have been deaths in individuals not\nolder than 60 with chronic diseases, but rather a younger/healthier group\nof people.\n\nDr. Heymann responded to these questions: ...on the age issue, it's always\nuseful to understand that this disease starts out in health workers in most\ncases, so the first patient infects health workers and they are all of a\ncertain age; they are not young people, they are middle-aged people or in\ntheir 20s to 40s or 50s, so it's natural that that would be the age that's\nfirst infected. Then as it spreads out from those workers into other\npopulations, the ages change, so it's very important to understand the\ndynamics of this disease.\n\nAs far as Beijing goes, last evening they visited the military hospital.\nThey estimated that there are at least 50 patients in this hospital with\nSARS from what they've seen. They also estimate that there are between\n100-200 probable cases in Beijing, more than has been reported, and they\nfeel that there might even be up to 1000 people who are under observation\nright now at various stages of infection; some probably are not SARS, in\nfact many are probably not SARS, but they are taking precautions in\nobserving these. It's our impression that China needs to get clear on how\nit reports these diseases and they are working very closely with the\nChinese to get better reporting. It's also the team's feeling that Beijing\nhas many resources that they can put to work on this disease and that SARS\nwill not be a problem in Beijing if they get these resources working. Their\nconcern is in the provinces, especially in the western provinces, and they\nare afraid that it will not only spread from cities into the communities\nbut into areas where there may not be health facilities that are very\nclosely accessible to people. So, the challenge now is for China to not\nonly report, but to trace infection, to do infection control in the\nhospitals, and do everything that the other countries are doing to stop the\nspread of this disease.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 16 Apr 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nAs of 3 PM 16 Apr 2003, there are an additional 36 patients confirmed to\nhave atypical pneumonia following admission to public hospitals earlier.\nThey include 7 healthcare workers (6 from Princess Margaret Hospital and\none from Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital). The remaining 29 were\nother patients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n\nA total of 257 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 14 were discharged\ntoday. 122 patients are receiving treatment in intensive care unit.\n\n5 patients died in hospitals, bringing to 61 the total number of deaths\nrelating to atypical pneumonia. A 54-year-old female and a 73-year-old\nmale, both with a history of chronic disease, died in Queen Elizabeth\nHospital. A 44-year-old male and a 62-year-old female died in Princess\nMargaret Hospital. Another chronically ill male patient, aged 73, died in\nAlice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ no. recovered/ no. deaths\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 298/ 100/ 61\nPatients, family members & visitors: 970/ 157/ 0\nTotal: 1268/ 257 /61\n\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively late\nstage of infection.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 16 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6180>\n\n\nSARS Situation Update 16 Apr 2003\n\nAs of 16 Apr 2003, 6 additional SARS patients have been discharged,\nbringing the total number of patients who have recovered from SARS to 91.\n61 SARS patients remain hospitalised.\n\nThere are 5 additional SARS cases reported today. They comprise 2 staff\nmembers of National Cancer Centre (NCC), namely a radiographer who had been\nadmitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) since 9 Apr 2003 for observation,\nand a porter who was admitted to TTSH on 14 Apr 2003. Both patients\ndeveloped lung changes on chest X-ray yesterday and hence were diagnosed to\nhave SARS. The third SARS case is an inpatient at Singapore General\nHospital (SGH) Ward 58 who has been observed in TTSH since 13 Apr 2003, and\nwho developed lung changes yesterday. The other 2 cases comprise the son of\na SARS patient, and a doctor at National University Hospital (NUH) who\nlooked after 2 patients prior to their diagnosis of SARS.\n\nSituation Update at NCC\nThere are 2 NCC staff members who have been diagnosed as probable SARS.\n\nThe radiographer developed a fever (37.8 deg C) on Saturday 5 Apr 2003. He\ndid not see a doctor. He was well with no fever over the next 3 days (6--8\nApr 2003). He worked in the radiology department of NCC on 7 and 8 Apr\n2003. Twice-daily temperature monitoring was performed and he was noted to\nhave no fever. During these 2 days, he performed CT scans and MRI on a\ntotal of 11 patients.\n\nIn the early hours of 9 Apr 2003, he developed fever of 38.4 deg C. He went\nto Changi General Hospital (CGH) and was transferred to TTSH on the same\nday. On admission he was classified as a low-risk suspect for SARS. CGH\nobserved all the infection control measures when the patient was there.\n\nAnother hospital staff (porter), who handles dispatch work, developed a\nlow-grade fever (37.5 deg C) on the morning of Thu 10 Apr 2003. He was not\nassigned any duties and during that time he only came into contact with the\ndepartmental staff. At noon, his temperature went up to 38.6 deg C. He was\nseen at the SGH Staff Clinic and was given 2 days MC [medical leave?] and\nasked to return for a review on 12 Apr 2003.\n\nHe had no fever on 11 Apr 2003. He did not return to the Staff Clinic on 12\nApr 2003 and instead saw his neighbourhood General Practitioner (GP). He\nwas given 2 more days MC. He continued to have low-grade [fever]. On 14 Apr\n2003, he went directly to the Staff Clinic and was referred to TTSH and\nadmitted on the same day.\n\nBesides these 2 staff members, the other NCC staff are currently well. As a\nprecaution, NCC has closed its radiology department until 20 Apr 2003.\nUrgent radiological x-rays will be done at SGH A&E Dept. Non-urgent\nappointments will be deferred. NCC has contacted 10 of the 11 patients who\nhad X-ray investigations done by the radiographer and they are well.\nAlthough the radiographer did not go into the waiting room of the X-ray\ndepartment, as a precaution, NCC has been contacting the 200 patients who\nhave had other X-rays done during the period 7--9 Apr 2003. Investigations\nare still in progress to trace the source of infection.\n\nSituation Update at NUH\nThe doctor attended to a patient who was being treated for heart failure.\nThe patient, who was admitted to NUH on 8 Apr 2003, had been a visitor at\nSGH Ward 57 in end March. He had multiple medical conditions and did not\nhave fever at that time. When he was reviewed in the ward, the possibility\nof concurrent pneumonia was recognised as his condition had deteriorated.\nThe patient was unstable and required transfer to the NUH Intensive Care\nUnit where he was intubated. The transfer to TTSH took place later on the\nsame day when the patient's condition stabilised. The patient passed away\non 12 Apr 2003.\n\nThe NUH doctor developed fever on 11 Apr 2003 evening and was sent to TTSH\nEmergency Department on the same day. She has been diagnosed as a probable\nSARS case on 16 Apr 2003.\n\nHome Quarantine for non-SARS patients with chronic conditions discharged\nfrom SGH and TTSH\nContact tracing at SGH has identified the patients and healthcare workers\nwho may have been exposed to SARS. These contacts have been quarantined or\nare being monitored. There are about 800 inpatients at present in SGH who\nhave not been exposed. However, as a precaution, patients discharged from\nSGH from 17 Apr 2003 onwards who have chronic co-morbid conditions will be\nissued Home Quarantine Orders (HQO) for 10 days. At end of 10 days, SGH\nwill recall them for review, following which they will be on phone\nsurveillance for a further 10 days. The other discharged patients who do\nnot have any chronic conditions will not be on HQO but phone surveillance\nfor 21 days. The same arrangement will be implemented for non-SARS patients\nwith chronic conditions discharged from TTSH.\n\nSummary of SARS cases\nThere was a SARS patient in intensive care who died late 15 Apr 2003. She\nwas the mother of a doctor who contracted SARS while looking after a SARS\npatient. The other deceased is the mother of a SARS patient. On 13 Apr\n2003, we reported 2 SARS deaths linked to the SGH cluster comprising an\ninpatient and the brother of an index patient. The preliminary findings of\nboth patients were that they died of other medical conditions unrelated to\nSARS. We are awaiting results of further investigations.\n\nBelow is the summary of the SARS cases to date:\n\nNumber Discharged: 85 plus 6\nHospitalised: 61 (including 16 in intensive care)\nDeaths: 13 + 2 (pending post mortem findings)\n\nTotal: 167\n\nSuspected: 91 (including 8 children below 18)\nUnder home quarantine orders: 582\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website 16 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\n\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States\n\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on 15 Apr 2003.\n\nState: suspected cases under investigation\n\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 42\nColorado: 6\nConnecticut: 4\nFlorida: 11\nGeorgia: 3\nHawaii: 5\nIllinois: 11\nIndiana: 1\nKansas: 1\nKentucky: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 8\nMichigan: 3\nMinnesota: 6\nMississippi: 1\nMissouri: 2\nNevada: 1\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 3\nNew Mexico: 1\nNew York: 22\nNorth Carolina: 6\nOhio: 10\nOregon: 1\nPennsylvania: 5\nRhode Island: 1\nSouth Carolina: 1\nTexas: 7\nUtah: 5\nVermont: 2\nVirginia: 5\nWashington: 19\nWisconsin: 1\n\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 199\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 16 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update32.html>\n\n\nUpdate 32: Severe acute respiratory syndrome -- 16 Apr 2003 4:30 PM\n\nAs of 16 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 303 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 13 deaths in Canada. To date, transmission has been limited to\nspecific transmission settings such as households, hospitals, and specific\ncommunity settings. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe information available to Health Canada at this time.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario is reporting 122 probable and 127 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 4 probable and 38 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\n\nSo far, 91 people have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario. These\npeople were treated as suspect cases or as probable cases.\n\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 16 Apr 2003.\n\n[These data do not mention the newswire reports of transmission within a\nreligious community related to attendance at a funeral of a probable SARS\ncase. The newswire reports have been varied, with some mentioning that\nmost of the cases had been previously reported, but according to this\nupdate there is no mention of community-based close contact, which appeared\nto be the mode of transmission in this generation of cases. More\ninformation on this observation from official sources would be appreciated.\n- Mod.MPP]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of today's update there is a cumulative total of 3293 cases of SARS\nreported to the WHO, with 58 new cases reported in the preceding 24 hours;\na total of 159 deaths (case fatality rate of 4.8 percent) and 1548 patients\nhave recovered (47 percent). In the past 24 hours, Hong Kong has reported\n36 new cases and 5 deaths; in China there have been 14 new cases\nreported. Based on the information provided by Dr. Heymann in today's WHO\npress briefing, we expect to see the numbers of cases reported from Beijing\nto increase significantly once official reports from the military hospitals\nare received. In addition, there has been the suggestion of increased\ntransmission outside of Beijing and Guangdong. It would be interesting to\nsee a breakdown of reported cases by province to determine whether new\nareas of local transmission have been identified. For example, the lay\npress has reported cases in Inner Mongolia, suggesting local transmission,\nbut this area has not officially been added to the affected areas list --\nsee ProMED-mail posting SARS - worldwide (45): cases 20030412.0890.\n\nThere are now 199 suspected cases from 32 states in the United States. This\nrepresents an increase of 6 cases from the last report on 15 Apr\n2003. There has been mention in press releases (CDC press release 14 Apr\n2003 (accessible at:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/transcripts/t030414.htm> and in many lay\npress reports) that the USA plans to change reporting practices, separating\nsuspected and probable cases using the WHO definitions. When that occurs,\nwe expect to see a marked decrease in the numbers of cases of SARS reported\non a daily basis to WHO. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Indiana: 1\nKansas: 1\nKentucky: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 8\nMichigan: 3\nMinnesota: 6\nMississippi: 1\nMissouri: 2\nNevada: 1\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 3\nNew Mexico: 1\nNew York: 22\nNorth Carolina: 6\nOhio: 10\nOregon: 1\nPennsylvania: Apr 2003 found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/2003_04_16/en/>\n\n2 of the questions that were posed related to the completeness in reporting\nof cases from Beijing (and the lack of reporting of cases from the military\nhospitals), and the lay press observations of a change in profile of deaths\nin Hong Kong, where recently there have been deaths in individuals not\nolder than 60 with chronic diseases, but rather a younger/healthier group\nof people. Severe acute respiratory syndrome report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States\n\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on 15 Apr 2003. \n\nBelow is the summary of the SARS cases to date:\n\nNumber Discharged: 85 plus 6\n The cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. \n\n5 patients died in hospitals, bringing to 61 the total number of deaths\nrelating to atypical pneumonia. \n\nAnother hospital staff (porter), who handles dispatch work, developed a\nlow-grade fever (37.5 deg C) on the morning of Thu 10 Apr 2003. \n\nA total of 257 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. worldwide (48): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203632", "date": "2003-04-14 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (48): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Sat 12 Apr 2003\nFrom: 'Stephen M. Apatow' <s.m.apatow@humanitarian.net>\nSource: Bioinformatics: Pathological Diagnostics web site, Sat 12 Apr 2003\n[edited]\n<http://www.humanitarian.net/biodefense/bioinformatics>\n\nThe SARS-associated Coronavirus Complete Genome Sequence\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe following resources are now available from the Genome Sciences Centre,\nSARS-associated virus genome sequencing project, at the British Columbia\nCentre for Disease Control and the National Microbiology Laboratory,\nWinnipeg. <http://www.bcgsc.ca/bioinfo/SARS/>\n(1) The current Genome Shotgun Data are available for download. The format\nis raw sequence reads in Fasta format, not vector or quality clipped.\n(2) Comparison to other members of the order _Nidovirales_ [which includes\nthe families _Coronaviridae_ and _Arteriviridae_ - Mod.CP]]. These images\nwere generated by the Sockeye genome viewer, developed at the Genome\nSciences Centre. The images show the comparison of the sequence of the TOR2\nisolate [i.e. a virus isolated from a Canadian patient] to the sequence of\nother related members of the order _Nidobvirales_. The tracks show Blast\ncomparison to (1) avian infectious bronchitis virus, (2) bovine\ncoronavirus, (3) human coronavirus 229E, (4) murine hepatitis virus, (5)\nporcine epidemic diarrhea virus, (6) transmissible gastroenteritis virus.\nAn annotated image is also available.\n--\nStephen M. Apatow\nHumanitarian Resource Institute\nBiodefense Reference Library\n<s.m.apatow@humanitarian.net>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sun 13 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website, Sun 13 Apr 2003\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/sequence.htm>\n\nSARS-associated Coronavirus: Sequencing Progress at CDC\n--------------------------------------------------------\nThe CDC coronavirus sequencing team has completed and assembled 17.5\nkilobases of nucleotide sequence of the Urbani strain [i.e. a virus\nisolated in Hanoi from patient Urbani] of SARS-associated coronavirus. [The\ncomplete unedited sequence determined by the BC group referred to above\nruns to 29 736 bases. - Mod.CP] These sequences represent all of the\ngenome except for the 1a region of the polymerase gene. The availability\nof this sequence provides important information relating to rapid\ndiagnosis, treatment, and prevention of SARS. The complete genome of the\nUrbani strain should be available on Mon 14 Apr 2003.\nIt should be noted that analysis of sequences from 3 different regions of\nthe genome confirm the initial observation that the Urbani strain of the\nSARS-associated coronavirus is distinct from all previously recognized\ncoronaviruses and sequence studies are not likely to identify a source for\nthis novel coronavirus.\nSequence information provided by collaborators at National Microbiology\nLaboratory, Canada, University of California at San Francisco, Erasmus\nUniversity, Rotterdam and Bernhard-Nocht Institute, Hamburg facilitated\nthis sequencing effort.\nThe partial nucleotide sequence of CoV-SARS is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/pdf/nucleoseq.pdf>. Coronavirus protein\nanalysis phylogenetic trees are available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/pdf/proteinanalysis.pdf>.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: Sun 13 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New York Times, Mon 14 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/14/science/sciencespecial/14INFE.html>\n\nNucleotide Sequencing of the Genome of the SARS-associated Coronavirus\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nScientists in Canada announced over the weekend that they had broken the\ngenetic code of the virus suspected of causing severe acute\nrespiratorysyndrome (SARS). Sequencing the genome which computers at the\nBritish Columbia Cancer Agency in Vancouver completed at 4 a.m. on Sat 12\nApr 2003 after a team slaved over the problem 24 hours a day for a mere six\ndays is the first step toward developing a diagnostic test for the virus\nand possibly a vaccine.\nThe genome appears to be that of a 'completely new' coronavirus unrelated\nto any known human or animal viruses, a scientist at the Canadian agency\nsaid. a competing United States team at the Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention in Atlanta is reaching the same conclusion, and scientists from\nboth teams said the virus's startling novelty could make it harder to trace\nwhat animal or bird it came from, if it did jump from another species.\nA spokesman for the World Health Organization called the speed at which the\ngene was sequenced 'stunning.' 'It was just three weeks ago that the\ncoronavirus was identified as the likely cause,' said the spokesman, Dick\nThompson. 'Don't forget that it took several years to find the virus that\ncauses AIDS. The way people worked together is just great.' Dr. Marco\nMarra, Director of the Genome Sciences Center at the Canadian cancer\nagency, said he hoped that 'this isn't viewed as `beating the C.D.C.';\nwe're trying to help.' Because 13 people in Canada have died of the\nsyndrome, known as SARS, and 274 more are believed to be infected with it,\nCanadian scientists feel a sense of urgency about the project, he said. No\none is believed to have died of the mysterious respiratory ailment in the\nUnited States, where 160 people are believed to be infected.Also, Dr. Marra\nsaid, samples should be sequenced in different laboratories so scientists\ncan check one another's work. Cautioning that his lab's work is 'a draft';\nthere are probably still errors in it,' he said he still expected it to be\nposted for public use today on the Web site of the National Center for\nBiotechnology Information in Bethesda, Md., part of the National Institutes\nof Health.\nThe virus appears to be unique. 'It doesn't look any more like one known\ncoronavirus than another,' he said. With 29 736 nucleotides, he said, 'it's\na biggie for a coronavirus.' Viruses usually have thousands of these base\npairs, while bacteria have millions and the human genome has over three\nbillion. [In general, the genomes of coronaviruses are larger than those of\nother RNA viruses, and the size of the SARAS-associated coronavirus genome\nis not unexpected. - Mod.CP]. Dr. Marra said the genome his lab found was\n'equidistant' from coronaviruses isolated from turkeys, cows and mice.\nIdeally, the sequence will make it possible to come up with a rapid test.\nRight now, there are three different tests for coronaviruses, but they can\ntake days, by which time a patient may have died or recovered. Because\nrapid tests for other coronaviruses exist, 'our confidence level is quite\ngood,' Dr. Marra said. Knowing the sequence of base pairs will indicate\nwhat proteins the DNA will build, which will hint at which protein-blocking\ndrugs might make the virus impotent. The possibility of a vaccine is more\nremote. While vaccines have wiped out or slowed smallpox, chicken pox,\nmeasles and other viruses, a vaccine against AIDS has eluded scientists for\nmore than a decade.\nScientists are still trying to prove that this coronavirus causes SARS. To\nthat end, a laboratory in the Netherlands is infecting primates with it to\nsee if they become sick and whether particles of the same virus can be\nfound in them. Dr. James Hughes, of the National Center for Infectious\nDisease at the C.D.C., which is working on a sample cultured from a throat\nswab on a patient who died in Asia, said it was also finding a\nnew,unrecognized virus. Known coronaviruses fall into three groups based on\ntheir surface proteins, he said, 'and it looks like this is a fourth.' 'If\nit had looked like it came from a turkey or a chicken,' he said, 'you could\nhave taken steps to diminish the likelihood of exposure.' It is impossible\nto know how much having a fully sequenced genome will trim the time it\ntakes to create a diagnostic test or a vaccine, Dr. Hughes said. A test\ncould come rapidly because another preliminary test based on pieces of the\ngenome was created within days, he said, though it is still in trials. He\nsaid he did not expect a marketable vaccine within a year.\nThe Canadian work began after Dr. Marra and the project's leader, Dr.\nCaroline Astell, volunteered to put aside their cancer research and devote\ntheir 20 scientists and 100 000-square-foot lab to the coronavirus. Last\nweek, the team received material that was isolated from a patient who had\ndied in Toronto and was grown in primate cells at the National Microbiology\nLaboratory in Winnipeg, Manitoba. The 'sensitive, very delicate' work of\nconverting the sample's RNA into DNA took about five days by a two-person\nteam, Dr. Marra said, while 'the rest of us reorganized the laboratory so\nit could run rapidly.' Dr. Simon Sutcliffe, the cancer agency's president,\ndescribed the lab scene as 'a lot of tired and excited-looking young people\nstanding in front of their machines.' Their average age is 'probably 23 or\n24,' he said, and they are 'very genome-focused and technologically adept.'\nOn Friday afternoon, the samples were ready for the sequencing computers,\nwhich identify the bases in snippets of DNA about 500 bases long, and then\nsort them, trying to build something like a whole ladder out of hundreds of\npieces of a ladder whose rungs have been sawed apart at different lengths.\n'We were on pins and needles waiting for data,' Dr. Marra said. 'It began\nto appear at around 9 or 10 Friday night, and everything looked promising.'\nAbout 4 a.m., the computers finished their draft and before 8 a.m., Dr.\nSutcliffe was being called out of the shower and was giving the\nauthorization to make the announcement.\n(By: Donald G. McNeil Jr.)\n-\nproMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The completion of sequencing of the genome of the SARS-associated\ncoronavirus is truly a remarkable achievement, as the genomes of the\n'nested set' viruses (the order _Nidovirales_, which includes the family\n_Coronaviridae_) are substantially larger than other RNA-containing\nviruses. The data released by the BC group are raw data which require\nfurther editing and refining, but they are now in the public domain which\nis a commendable initiative. Preliminary analysis confirms that the\nSARS-associated coronavirus is a unique virus not closely related to any of\nthe known species of animal and human coronaviruses. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n It should be noted that analysis of sequences from 3 different regions of\nthe genome confirm the initial observation that the Urbani strain of the\nSARS-associated coronavirus is distinct from all previously recognized\ncoronaviruses and sequence studies are not likely to identify a source for\nthis novel coronavirus. We are very grateful to\nDr. Nicoll for this submission, and recognize this as an important public\nhealth announcement to advise other countries of the possibility of SARS\ntransmission in the UK as a result of this possible close contact case of\nSARS having occurred in the Heathrow airport and vicinity. While this is\nstill preliminary information, it is important to disseminate rapidly as\nmany countries use definitions for suspected and probable cases of SARS\nthat have as part of the definition, history of travel to an area with\nknown SARS transmission, which according to WHO includes Canada\n(Toronto), China (Beijing, Guangdong province, Shanxi province), Taiwan,\nHong Kong SAR, VietNam (Hanoi) and Singapore. - Mod.MPP]\n\nDate: Sat, 12 Apr 2003 16:16:53 +0100\nFrom: Angus Nicoll <angus.nicoll@hpa.org.uk>\nPossible Transmission of SARS in the UK\nThe 6th probable case of SARS to be diagnosed in the UK was reported\nyesterday (11 Apr 2003) following an illness that started on 7 Apr 2003.\nThat patient is moderately unwell and isolated in hospital. His contacts\nare being followed up. Laboratory investigations are underway at the\nCentral Public Health Laboratory (Dr Maria Zambon). The patient had not\nbeen abroad and was diagnosed following an alert from Hong Kong about SARS\nin a Hong Kong national who travelled around Europe (Germany, UK and Spain)\nbetween 30 Mar 2003 and 4 Apr 2003. The Hong Kong man was unwell with what\nturned out to be SARS from 31 Mar 2003 onwards. The Hong Kong man met with\nthe UK 6th case for a 2 hour face to face meeting in a Hotel at Heathrow\nairport (The Heathrow Marriott) on 3 Apr 2003. There are no other relevant\ncontacts for the UK case and therefore if his diagnosis is confirmed as\nSARS transmission has almost certainly occurred in the UK. This information\nis being made public today.Investigations has not found any indication that\nthe Hong Kong man had other close contacts in the 24 hours he was in the UK\nand no related suspect or probable cases of SARS have come to light. There\nis no ill-health among the hotel staff who had any direct contact with him\nor went into the man's room. Thorough cleaning was undertaken of the man's\nroom on departure.\nTo date there have been no reports of ill health among other visitors to\nthe hotel therefore this transmission does not seem analagous to the\noutbreak of SARS cases in a hotel in Hong Kong. It seems unlikely that\nthere will have been any further transmission associated with the Hong Kong\nman in the UK. However if any national authorities become aware of a SARS\ndiagnosis being made in a person who has been in the UK in the 10 days\nbefore developing disease they should immediately contact the CDSC duty\ndoctor (+44 208 200 6868 or e-mail respcdsc@phls.org.uk ) including details\nof the cases time and contacts in the UK, for example details of any hotel\nstay.\nIt should be borne in mind that close contact transmission has already\ntaken place in the US\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5214a1.htm> and\nCanada <http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/NEJMoa030634v1> as\nwell as in the Far East though we understand the chains of transmission in\nNorth America to date are limited.\nThe UK authorities understand from WHO - Europe, and direct contact with\nGerman authorities, that investigations to identify contacts in German and\nSpain are underway.\n--\nAgnus Nicoll\nInterim Director, Communicable Disease Surveillance\nHealth Protection Agency, UK\n<angus.nicoll@hpa.org.uk>\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. To date there have been no reports of ill health among other visitors to\nthe hotel therefore this transmission does not seem analagous to the\noutbreak of SARS cases in a hotel in Hong Kong. There\nis no ill-health among the hotel staff who had any direct contact with him\nor went into the man's room. There are no other relevant\ncontacts for the UK case and therefore if his diagnosis is confirmed as\nSARS transmission has almost certainly occurred in the UK.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-04-11 00:00:00", "2044-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-04-03 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00", "6868-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-04-07 00:00:00", "2003-04-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Toronto", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Guangdong province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Hanoi", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong SAR", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "VietNam", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Shanxi", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2203622", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (45): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203622", "date": "2003-04-12 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (45): CASES\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] Canada - Health Canada\n[5] News briefs\n[A] China - Inner Mongolia\n[B] China - Xiamen, Fujian Province\n[C] Indonesia\n**[D] Canada - British Columbia lab sequences probable SARS coronavirus**\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: 12 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative number of reported probable(1) cases of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_12/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002(2) To: 12 Apr 2003,20:00 GMT+2\n\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No.new cases since last WHO update/ No.\ndeaths/ No. recovered/ Local chain(s) of transmission (3)\n\nBrazil: 2/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nCanada: 101/ 3/ 10/ 26/ Yes\nChina: 1309/ 19/ 58/ 1037/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: (4) 1108/ 49/ 35/ 215/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 23/ 2/ 0/ 7/ Yes\nFrance: 5/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nGermany: 6/ 0/ 0/ 4/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ 0/ 2/ None\nJapan: 4/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nKuwait: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nMalaysia: 4/ 0/ 1/ 0/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nRomania: 1/ 0/ 0/ not available/ None\nSingapore: 147/ 14/ 9/ 77/ Yes\nSouth Africa: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSpain: 1/ 0/ 0/ 0/ None\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ 0/ 1/ None\nThailand: 8/ 1/ 2/ 5/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 6/ 1/ 0/ 3/ Yes\nUnited States: 166/ 0/ 0/ not available/ Yes\nViet Nam: (5) 62/ 1/ 4/ 46/ Yes\n\nTotal: 2960/ 90/ 119/ 1425\n\nNotes:\n\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n\n1. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspected cases under investigation.\n\n2. The start of the period of surveillance has been changed to 1 Nov 2002\nto capture cases of atypical pneumonia in China that are now recognized as\nbeing cases of SARS.\n\n3. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas. (<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/en/>)\n\n4. One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR, China occurred in a case\nmedically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n5. One probable case was discarded and one new probable case identified,\ntherefore the cumulative number of cases for Viet Nam has not changed.\n\n\n[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 12 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_12/en/>\n\nCountry: Area\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Beijing, Guangdong, Hong Kong SAR, Shanxi, Taiwan Province*\nUnited States of America: Areas not reported.*\nUnited Kingdom: London*\nViet Nam: Hanoi\n\nAn 'affected area' is an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of\nSARS is/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.\n\n*Area with limited local transmission and no evidence of international\nspread from area since 15 Mar 2003 and no transmission other than close\nperson-to-person contact reported.\n\n[C] Epidemiologic graphics\nMapping of countries with cases can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/map2003_04_12b.gif>\nEpidemic curves, worldwide and country specific can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsepicurve/epiindex/en/>\n\n[D] Update 28 - Affected areas, status of SARS outbreaks in individual\ncountries 12 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_12/en/>\n\nAffected areas\nOn Friday, WHO added Beijing, China to its list of SARS-affected areas.\nAreas are added to the list following indication that chains of local\ntransmission are occurring. The greatest concern arises when cases occur\noutside the established risk groups of health care workers and persons in\nclose face-to-face contact with patients, such as household contacts and\nhospital visitors.\n\nIn addition to Beijing, other affected areas in China include Guangdong\nProvince, Hong Kong SAR, Shanxi Province, and Taiwan Province. Toronto,\nSingapore, and Hanoi are also listed as affected.\n\nIn most other countries reporting SARS cases, the disease remains confined\nto a few imported cases, with no or very little spread of infection to others.\n\nChina\nA WHO team of 5 experts has been invited by the Beijing Health Bureau to\nvisit health facilities and review the SARS situation in Beijing. The\ninvitation followed WHO concern about management of the SARS situation by\nhealth authorities, particularly in relation to case reporting and contact\ntracing.\n\nThe meetings, which began on Friday, will continue throughout next week.\nSpecific objectives are to support the strengthening of surveillance and\nreporting, clinical management, infection control, and laboratory\nevaluation of cases.\n\nNo reports from China were received today.\n\nHong Kong\nHong Kong has today reported a cumulative total of 1108 cases with 35\ndeaths. This represents an increase of 49 new cases admitted to hospital\nwith symptoms of SARS, and 3 deaths when compared with yesterday. Of the\ncases newly admitted to hospital, 3 are in health care workers, and 11 are\nfrom the Amoy Gardens housing estate.\n\nThe majority of Hong Kong's cases are clustered in hospitals and in the\ndensely populated Amoy Gardens housing estate. Health authorities are\ncontinuing to investigate a possible environmental factor that may explain\nthe concentration of cases in a single wing of a single building, Block E.\nHealth officials are also investigating whether an outbreak in a second\nhousing estate may be related to the Amoy Gardens outbreak.\n\nThe Department of Health has today posted on its web site a detailed list\nof buildings where residents have developed SARS. [The complete list can be\naccessed at:\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/ap.htm> - Mod.MPP]\n\nSingapore\nSingapore has today reported a cumulative total of 147 SARS cases of which\n60 remain hospitalized, with 15 in intensive care. Recent concern has\ncentered on clusters of SARS cases seen in health workers, inpatients, and\nvisitors at Singapore General Hospital and Ton Tock Seng Hospital.\n\nWHO has collaborated with health authorities in investigations and contact\ntracing that have linked most cases in the hospital outbreaks to a single\n'super-spreader.' This patient was treated at Ton Tock Seng Hospital from 5\nto 20 Mar 2003, where he is thought to have become infected. He was\nsubsequently admitted to Singapore General Hospital on 24 Mar 2003. The\npatient showed a very atypical clinical course before being isolated on 2\nApr 2003. This late isolation is thought to explain, in part, the large\nnumber of exposed and infected individuals linked to the single patient.\n\nOngoing investigations have linked the outbreaks at Singapore General\nHospital, Ton Tock Seng Hospital, and other hospitals in Singapore to clear\ntrains of transmission\n\nViet Nam\nIn Viet Nam, one new case was reported and one case was removed from the\nlist. The cumulative number of reported cases (62) remains the same as\nyesterday. High vigilance, excellent contact tracing, and good infection\ncontrol are in place and are expected to keep the number of new cases\nassociated with the initial outbreak small.\n\nCanada\nHealth Canada is today reporting 101 probable SARS cases. All Canadian\ncases have occurred in persons who have travelled to Asia or had contact\nwith SARS cases in the household or in a health-care setting. Ontario is\nreporting 98 probable cases. 3 probable cases are reported in British Columbia.\n\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today [12 Apr 2003], a cumulative total of 2960 cases, with 119\ndeaths, have been reported from 19 countries. This represents an increase\nof 70 cases and 3 deaths when compared with yesterday. No reports from\nChina were received today.\n\nThe 3 new deaths were reported in Hong Kong SAR. New cases were reported in\nCanada (3), Hong Kong (49), Taiwan, China (2), Singapore (14), Thailand\n(1), and the United Kingdom (1).\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 12 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 12 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 12 Apr 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nAs of 1 PM 12 Apr 2003, an additional 49 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals. They include 3 healthcare\nworkers (2 from Kwong Wah Hospital and one from Alice Ho Miu Ling\nNethersole Hospital) and 11 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 35\nwere new patients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n\nA total of 215 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 46 were discharged\ntoday. Most of the patients currently in hospital are showing positive\nresponses to the new treatment protocol. 120 patients are receiving\ntreatment in the intensive care unit.\n\n3 patients died in Princess Margaret Hospital last night and early this\nmorning, bringing to 35 the total number of deaths relating to atypical\npneumonia. The 3 deceased included a man and a woman, aged 39 and 35\nrespectively, and a 67-year-old male patient who has a history of chronic\ndisease.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(All patients had pneumonia)\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 267/ 88/ 35\nPatients, family members & visitors: 841/ 127 / 0\n\nTotal 1108/ 215 / 35\n\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively\nlate stage of infection.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 12 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 12 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6080>\n\n\n[A] Situation update - SARS 12 Apr 2003\n\nAs of 12 Apr 2003, 78 SARS patients have been discharged. 60 SARS patients\nremain hospitalised.\n\nThere were 7 additional SARS cases reported today, 3 of whom are linked to\nthe Singapore General Hospital (SGH) cluster comprising 2 inpatients and 1\nfamily contact. Another 3 are healthcare workers (2 from Tan Tock Seng\nHospital (TTSH) and 1 from Changi General Hospital (CGH)). The last is the\nson of the MediaCorp staff member.\n\nThe SGH Cluster\nThe SGH Cluster of 53 patients comprises 28 probable and 25 suspects. The\ncluster of patients includes 26 staff, 13 inpatients, and 14 visitors. 5\nothers (all inpatients) have also been admitted for observation.\n\nHealth screening for incoming air passengers\n\nBetween 4 PM 11 Apr 2003 to 4 PM 12 Apr 2003, there were 41 passengers from\naffected areas who required further screening by the nurses at the airport.\n5 foreign passengers were admitted to TTSH for further assessment. They\ninclude 3 Indonesian passengers coming from Hong Kong who were picked up\nduring the temperature check yesterday evening (11 Apr 2003). Another 2\nChinese passengers from Xiamen [Fujian province] China were also picked up\nduring visual screening this morning.\n\nSummary of SARS cases as of 12 Apr 2003\n\nTotal: 147 (4 children below 18 years of age)\nDischarged: 78\nHospitalised: 60\nIntensive care: 15\nDeaths: 9\nSuspected: 84\nUnder home quarantine orders: 558\n\nThere have been 12 quarantine-breakers so far, and the most recent\noffender, a relative of the patient who broke quarantine and was warded in\nNUH, was warned against repeated break of quarantine and will be issued an\nelectronic tag.\n\n[B] Additonal information from the 11 Apr 2003 press release\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/sar/sar0301.asp?id=1&mid=6060>\n\n[This was posted on the Singapore Ministry of Health website after we\n'closed' the SARS update for 11 Apr 2003. The\nseventh case is linked with the fifth SARS fatality, who passed away on 2\nApr 2003.\n\nUpdate on Superstar Virgo\nOn 9 Apr 2003, the shipping agent for the cruise ship Superstar Virgo\nreported that there was an unwell Indian crew member with a high fever\nonboard. The crew member was isolated and when the ship arrived at the\nSingapore Cruise Centre, he was sent to the TTSH as a precautionary\nmeasure. The ship set sail again. The crew member was assessed at TTSH and\nadmitted as a possible SARS suspect case.\n\nThe Superstar Virgo returned to Singapore Cruise Centre (SCC) on 11 Apr\n2003 from Port Klang, Malaysia. Additional measures were implemented which\nincluded the visual screening of all disembarking passengers and the\nconduct of temperature checks of passengers who were also on the previous\nsailing of the vessel. None of the passengers checked has fever. The crew\nhave been asked to stay on board ship. [In the 11 Apr 2003 ProMED-mail\nposting SARS - worldwide (43): cases 20030411.0883 there was a newswire\nwith information about this incident, with one suspected case admitted to\nthe hospital in Singapore, and a second suspected case in another crew\nmember admitted to a hospital in Malaysia. - Mod.MPP]\n\nHealth screening for incoming air passengers\nBetween 4 PM 10 Apr 2003 to 4 PM 11 Apr 2003, there were 35 passengers from\naffected areas who required further screening by the nurses at the airport.\n2 Singaporean women were admitted to TTSH in the evening on 10 Apr 2003 as\nsuspected SARS cases. One of them returned from Yunan Province of China.\nShe was noted to be unwell during the visual health screening. The other\nwoman who returned from Hong Kong declared herself to be feverish, and a\ntemperature check confirmed this. In addition, beginning 12 PM, 11 Apr 03,\ntemperature checks are being done for incoming passengers from Guangdong\nand Hong Kong at the airport.\n\nSummary of SARS cases\n\nTo date, the total number of people diagnosed with SARS is 140. WORLDWIDE (41):OVERVIEW\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 10 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC MMWR 11 Apr 2003 52(14);297-302 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5214a1.htm>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and Coronavirus Testing --- United\nStates, 2003\nCDC and the World Health Organization (WHO) are continuing to investigate\nthe multicountry outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).\nInfection with a novel coronavirus has been implicated as a possible cause\nof SARS (1). This report updates information on U.S. residents with SARS\nand summarizes the clinical histories of the 5 U.S. residents identified as\nof 9 Apr 2003, who have both suspected SARS and laboratory evidence of\ninfection with a novel coronavirus.\nEpidemiologic and laboratory investigations of SARS are ongoing. CDC's\ninterim suspected SARS case definition (available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>) continues to be based\non clinical criteria and epidemiologic linkage to other SARS cases or areas\nwith community transmission of SARS; abnormal radiographic findings are not\nrequired for suspected cases. The WHO case definition for probable SARS\nincludes radiographic evidence of infiltrates consistent with pneumonia or\nrespiratory distress syndrome (RDS) on chest radiograph (2). Cases reported\nto WHO outside the United States are probable SARS cases; the United States\nreports all suspected cases.\nAs of 9 Apr 2003, a total of 2722 SARS cases have been reported to WHO from\n16 countries, including the United States; 106 deaths (case-fatality\nproportion: 3.9 percent) have been reported to WHO (3). As of 9 Apr 2003,\nCDC had received 166 reports from 30 states of suspected SARS cases among\nU.S. residents [see epidemic curve on webpage\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5214a1.htm>]; 135 (81 percent)\ncases occurred among adults [see Table of characteristics of cases on\nwebpage link above]. Of the 166 persons with suspected SARS, 154 (93\npercent) had traveled within the 10 days before illness onset to one or\nmore of the areas listed in the case definition, 9 (5 percent) had\nhousehold contact with a person with suspected SARS, and 3 (2 percent) were\nhealth-care workers (HCWs) who had provided medical care to a patient with\nsuspected SARS. The majority of U.S. patients had normal chest radiographs\n[see table on webpage link]. As of 9 Apr 2003, a total of 33 (20 percent)\npatients were reported to have pneumonia or RDS. Of the 60 (36 percent)\npatients who were hospitalized for greater than 24 hours, 4 (7 percent)\nremained hospitalized as of 9 Apr 2003, and no deaths were reported.\nTravel Advisories\nTravel advisories from WHO and CDC remain in effect. CDC has issued a\ntravel advisory\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/travel/other/acute_resp_syn_multi.htm>) recommending\nthat persons planning nonessential or elective travel to mainland China,\nHong Kong, Hanoi, or Singapore consider postponing such travel until\nfurther notice. Persons who have traveled recently to these locations are\nurged to seek medical care if they develop fever of greater than 100.4 deg\nF (38.0 C), cough, or difficulty breathing within 10 days of travel and to\ninform their health-care providers about recent travel to regions where\nSARS cases have been reported.\nInfection-Control Guidelines\nInterim infection-control guidelines for health-care, household, and\ncommunity settings will be updated and revised as new information becomes\navailable. Infection-control practitioners, clinicians providing medical\ncare for patients with suspected SARS, and persons who might have contact\nwith persons with suspected SARS should consult these guidelines frequently\nto keep current with recommendations\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/index.htm>).\nDiagnostic Testing\nLaboratory diagnostic tests used at CDC to test clinical specimens for\nevidence of this novel coronavirus are still in development and are not\navailable outside a research setting. Serologic testing for coronavirus\nantibody consists of indirect fluorescent antibody testing and\nenzyme-linked immunosorbent assays that are specific for antibody produced\nafter infection. Although some patients have detectable coronavirus\nantibody within 14 days of illness onset, definitive interpretation of\nnegative coronavirus antibody tests is possible only for specimens obtained\ngreater than 21 days after onset of fever. For other suspected SARS cases\nin the United States, a second serum specimen collected greater than 21\ndays after fever onset will be necessary to determine whether infection\nwith the novel coronavirus can be documented. A reverse\ntranscriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test specific for RNA from\nthe novel coronavirus has been positive within the first 10 days after\nfever onset in specimens from some SARS patients, but the duration of\ndetectable viremia or viral shedding is unknown, and RT-PCR tests on\nsamples collected during convalescence might be negative. Viral culture\nfollowed by RT-PCR also has been used to detect the novel coronavirus in\nsome specimens.\nCase Histories\nOn 3 Apr 2003, CDC reported to the respective health departments positive\ncoronavirus test results for 5 persons with SARS. All 5 had pneumonia\nrequiring hospitalization and had traveled recently to a country in which\ncommunity transmission had occurred. The 5 patients did not travel together\nor at the same time. Although 2 patients had a common hotel exposure in\nHong Kong, no evidence of a single common exposure for all 5 patients has\nbeen found. Specimens from these 5 patients were among the first tested;\npatients were selected on the basis of their clinical and exposure\nhistories. A description of the exposure and brief clinical history for\neach of these 5 SARS patients follows.\nCase 1. Patient I is a pregnant woman aged 36 years with a history of\nintermittent chronic cough; as of 9 Apr 2003, she was in her 26th week of\npregnancy. During 19 Feb--2 Mar 2003, she traveled to Hong Kong and\nGuangdong province in China to visit her family. While in Hong Kong, she\nstayed at Hotel M during 19-22 Feb 2003 and again during 24 Feb--2 Mar\n2003. The first stay was on the same floor and during the same time as\nPatient A (the index case in a large cluster of persons with suspected SARS\ndescribed previously) (1). On 8 Feb 2003 [?typographic error - Mod.MPP],\nPatient I's intermittent cough resumed. On 24 Feb 2003, she had onset of\nfever, chills, and headache. During the next 3 days, her cough progressed,\nand she had shortness of breath, myalgia, and blood-streaked sputum. She\nsought medical care in Hong Kong and received an antibiotic. Her symptoms\nworsened, and on return to the United States on 2 Mar 2003, she was\nhospitalized with a diagnosis of pneumonia. On admission, her temperature\nwas 100.5 F (38.1 C), and rales were noted on chest examination. A chest\nradiograph showed bilateral lower lobe infiltrates, and her oxygen\nsaturation was 93 percent. Laboratory studies on admission included a white\nblood cell count (WBC) of 3300/mm3 (12 percent lymphocytes), platelets of\n103 000/mm3, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 42 U/L. During the next\n3 days, despite treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics, she worsened\nclinically with persistent fever and progressive pulmonary infiltrates. On\n5 Mar 2003 she had respiratory failure and required mechanical ventilation,\nand oseltamivir was added to her treatment. She improved gradually during\nthe next week and was extubated on 12 Mar 2003. On 17 Mar 2003, she was\ndischarged and was recovering as of 9 Apr 2003. Serologic testing of a\nserum specimen collected 12 days after illness onset was positive for\ncoronavirus antibody. RT-PCR testing for human metapneumovirus is pending.\nCase 2. Patient L is a man aged 39 years with a medical history of sleep\napnea and hypothyroidism. He traveled on vacation to Thailand on 23 Feb\n2003 and then to Hong Kong on 1 Mar 2003. During 1-6 Mar 2003, he stayed at\nHotel M, at the same time as 3 other suspected SARS patients who were ill\nduring their hotel stays (1). On 6 Mar 2003, he returned to the United\nStates. On 13 Mar 2003, he had fever, myalgia, and a mild cough. During the\nnext 3 days, he had diarrhea, vomiting, diaphoresis, and shortness of\nbreath. On 17 Mar 2003, he was hospitalized with pneumonia and a right\nupper lobe infiltrate on a chest radiograph. Laboratory studies included a\nWBC of 6600/mm3 (50 percent neutrophils and 30 percent lymphocytes) and\nplatelets of 439 000/mm3. Maximum temperature during hospitalization was\n102.4 F (39.1 C). He received broad-spectrum antibiotics but no antiviral\ntherapy and was discharged on 25 Mar 2003. Serologic testing of a blood\nspecimen collected 6 days after symptom onset was positive for coronavirus\nantibody. RT-PCR testing for human metapneumonia virus was negative. On 19\nMar 2003, his wife, who had traveled with him to Hong Kong, developed\nsuspected SARS, including pneumonia requiring hospitalization. Her illness\nonset occurred 13 days after return from Hong Kong and resulted presumably\nfrom close contact with patient L.\nCase 3. Patient X is a woman aged 49 years with a medical history of\nchronic sinusitis. She traveled to Hong Kong on business on 2 Mar 2003 and\nreturned to the United States on 8 Mar 2003. The same day, she had fever,\ncough, and shortness of breath for which she sought medical care. She was\ngiven an oral antibiotic. Her symptoms persisted; on 20 Mar 2003, she was\nhospitalized with shortness of breath, chest pain, and rigors. On\nadmission, she had a temperature of 101.4 F (38.6 C), a chest radiograph\nshowed interstitial infiltrates, and oxygen saturation on room air was 92\npercent. Laboratory studies on admission included a WBC of 5100/mm3 (68\npercent neutrophils and 28 percent lymphocytes), platelets of 156 000/mm3,\nand ALT of 25 U/L. During her hospitalization, she received broad-spectrum\nantibiotics and corticosteroids but no antiviral therapy. On 28 Mar 2003,\nshe was discharged in stable condition. An RT-PCR assay detected the novel\ncoronavirus on a sputum specimen collected 14 days after illness onset.\nRT-PCR testing for human metapneumovirus was negative.\nCase 4. Patient Y is a man aged 22 years with no notable medical history.\nHe traveled to Hong Kong on vacation on 3 Mar 2003 and returned to the\nUnited States on 6 Mar 2003. On 12 Mar 2003, he had onset of fever, chills,\nmyalgia, headache, and shortness of breath. On 13 Mar 2003, he had a cough\nand chest pain and was treated with oral antibiotics. The following day, he\nreported to an emergency department (ED) with persistent fever and cough. A\nchest radiograph demonstrated a right perihilar infiltrate. He received\nintravenous antibiotics in the ED and was discharged the same day on an\noral antibiotic. On 16 Mar 2003, he had worsening shortness of breath and\nrespiratory distress, and was admitted to a hospital intensive-care unit.\nOn admission, his temperature was 102.9 F (39.4 C), with an oxygen\nsaturation of 81 percent on room air. Chest radiograph demonstrated\nbilateral infiltrates with pleural effusion. Laboratory studies on\nadmission included a WBC of 5300/mm3 (82 percent neutrophils and 14 percent\nlymphocytes), platelets of 197 000 mm3/mL, and ALT of 74 U/L. He received\nbroad-spectrum antibiotics and oseltamavir. A direct fluorescent antibody\nassay for influenza type A and influenza type B was negative. By 20 Mar\n2003, his condition stabilized, and he was discharged on 22 Mar 2003.\nSerologic tests of specimens obtained 4, 6, and 13 days after illness onset\nwere positive for antibody to coronavirus.\nCase 5. Patient Z is a woman aged 53 years with no notable medical history.\nShe traveled to Singapore on 27 Feb 2003 and returned to the United States\non 13 Mar 2003. While in Singapore, she visited hospitals that were\nproviding care for patients with pneumonia and had close contact with\nseveral persons with probable SARS. She did not use a surgical mask or any\nrespiratory precautions while in the Singapore hospitals. On 9 Mar 2003,\nshe had a headache. During 12-15 Mar 2003, she had fever, chills, and\nmyalgia. On 15 Mar 2003, she was hospitalized with a temperature of 102.7 F\n(39.3 C). On admission, a chest radiograph indicated bilateral basilar\natelectasis. Laboratory studies on admission included a WBC of 6500/mm3 (68\npercent neutrophils and 19 percent lymphocytes), platelets of 216 000/mm3,\nand ALT of 56 U/L. She received broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics but\nno antiviral therapy. Her condition stabilized by 12 Mar 2003, and she was\ndischarged on 26 Mar 2003. Although serologic testing of a specimen\nobtained 3 days after fever onset was negative, a second specimen collected\n26 days after onset was positive for antibody to coronavirus. RT-PCR\ntesting for human metapneumovirus is pending.\nMMWR Editorial Note:\nEvidence of infection with a novel coronavirus has been identified in\npatients with suspected SARS in several countries (4--6), including the 5\npatients in the United States described in this report. These patients were\namong those selected for priority coronavirus testing because of their\nspecific clinical presentations and exposure histories. All had fever and\nrespiratory symptoms (e.g., nonproductive cough, shortness of breath, and\nradiographic evidence of pneumonia). No consistent abnormal laboratory\nfindings were noted, and the majority were within the normal ranges. Some\nlaboratory tests that have been reported to be elevated in SARS patients,\nsuch as lactate dehydrogenase and creatine phosphokinase (4,6--7), were not\nmeasured for any of these patients. All 5 patients received broad-spectrum\nantibiotics appropriate for coverage of typical and atypical respiratory\npathogens. Patients I and Y received oseltamivir, and Patient X received\ncorticosteroids; no patients received ribavirin. These clinical histories\nare similar to those reported from Canada and Hong Kong, but, as of 9 Apr\n2003, no initial characteristic signs or symptoms that clearly distinguish\nSARS from pneumonia caused by other pathogens have been described (4,6--8).\nHowever, if this novel coronavirus is the cause of SARS in these patients,\nthe clinical symptoms described in this report most likely do not represent\nthe full spectrum of illness related to coronavirus infection. Viruses that\ncause respiratory illness typically are capable of causing a range of\nclinical manifestations, and asymptomatic infections are possible.\nState and local health departments are coordinating collection of follow-up\nserum specimens from SARS patients whose initial serum specimen might have\nbeen collected too early to indicate serologic evidence of infection. These\nresults and investigations among well household and other well contacts of\nSARS patients (including travelers who were on airline flights with persons\nwith SARS symptoms) will provide additional information about the spectrum\nof illness among patients with SARS and coronavirus infection.\nThe majority of U.S. residents with SARS, including the 5 persons described\nin this report who had evidence of coronavirus infection, have recovered or\nstabilized clinically without specific antiviral therapy. The efficacy of\navailable antiviral therapies against coronavirus infection is unknown.\nRibavirin is a known teratogen, and clinicians who use it should be aware\nof all potential adverse events, including severe hemolytic anemia (9).\nPreliminary results from in vitro testing indicate that ribavirin\nconcentrations that inhibit ribavirin-sensitive viruses do not inhibit\nreplication or cell-to-cell spread of the novel coronavirus (JW Huggins,\nU.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Infectious Diseases, personal\ncommunication, 2003). However, further in vitro testing of antiviral drugs\non other coronavirus isolates, and more information on the clinical\noutcomes of patients treated with ribavirin or other antiviral drugs in\ncontrolled trials is needed.\nIn several countries, widespread community transmission, as well as\ntransmission among HCWs, has been observed. As of 9 Apr 2003, no U.S. HCWs\nwho provided care for the 5 patients with coronavirus infection described\nin this report had suspected SARS. Among the close contacts of these 5 SARS\npatients, only one (the wife of Patient L) has suspected SARS. The\ndifferent transmission patterns observed probably are not attributable to\ndifferences in infection-control practices alone. The inability to predict\nwhich patients are more capable of transmitting the virus that causes SARS\nunderscores the need to adhere strictly to infection-control\nrecommendations in both health-care and household settings. Similarly,\nclose contacts of SARS patients should be vigilant to detect fever or\nrespiratory symptoms, and persons who develop fever or respiratory symptoms\nshould seek health-care evaluation.\nOn 4 Apr 2003, the president of the United States signed an executive order\nadding SARS to the list of quarantinable communicable diseases. This act\nprovides CDC, through its Division of Global Migration and Quarantine, with\nthe legal authority to implement isolation and quarantine measures as part\nof transmissible disease-control measures, if necessary. Isolation refers\nto the practice of keeping a patient with a communicable disease separate\nfrom other persons, usually within a health-care facility or at home.\nIsolation is used routinely in hospital and health-care settings to reduce\nthe transmission of infections to uninfected patients. Quarantine refers to\nany situation in which a person or group of persons who have been exposed\nto a communicable disease and might be infected, but who are not yet ill,\nare kept apart from others to prevent disease spread. States generally have\nauthority to invoke and enforce quarantine within their jurisdictions,\nalthough quarantine laws vary among states. Quarantine is an effective\npublic health tool. Quarantine in the United States is used primarily to\nrestrict patients with pulmonary tuberculosis who remain infectious but are\nunable or unwilling to remain in settings where they are less likely to\ntransmit illness. During the previous month, health officials in Singapore,\nHong Kong, and Canada have implemented quarantine and isolation measures to\nlimit the spread of SARS.\n(<http://www.whitehouse.gov/news/releases/2003/04/iraq/20030404-8.html>)\nAlthough evidence is accumulating that a novel coronavirus is the primary\ncausative agent of SARS, more laboratory and epidemiologic data are needed\nbefore this link is established fully. Once definitive identification of\nthe cause of SARS has been achieved, an intensive focus on development of\neffective treatment regimens might reduce morbidity and mortality of\npatients with SARS. However, specific measures to prevent transmission\n(e.g., vaccination programs, prophylactic drugs, or hyperimmune globulin)\nmight require more time to develop and implement. In the interim,\nstrengthening traditional public health functions such as collection and\nrapid analysis of surveillance and epidemiologic data, and implementing\nessential infection-control measures for suspected SARS patients and their\ncontacts, will be the mainstays of SARS control. A sustained and\ncooperative global public health response will be necessary to limit\nfurther dissemination of SARS and to prepare for emerging global microbial\nthreats.\nReferences\n1. CDC. Update: outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome---worldwide,\n2003. MMWR 2003;52:241--8\n2. World Health Organization. Case definitions for surveillance of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS).\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/casedefinition/en>\n3. World Health Organization. Cumulative number of reported cases of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS).\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_02/en>\n4. Poutanen SM, Low DE, Henry B, et al. Identification of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome in Canada. N Eng J Med.\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/content/abstract/NEJMoa030634v1>\n5. World Health Organization. Summary on major findings in relation to\ncoronavirus by members of the WHO multi-centre collaborative network on\nSARS aetiology and diagnosis. <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/findings/en>\n6. Peiris JSM, Lai ST, Poon LLM, et al. Coronavirus as a possible cause of\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome. Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspected cases under investigation.\n2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n3. One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n[B] Affected areas - unchanged from previous postings, can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_11/en/>\n[C] Mapping of cases can be accessed at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/map2003_04_11.gif>\n[D] SARS epidemiology to date 11 April 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/epi2003_04_11/en/>\n- SARS is a new disease which has its origins in Guangdong Province, China.\nThe earliest known cases were identified in mid-Nov 2002. Since then,\nprobable cases of SARS have been reported in 17 countries.\n- WHO is constantly investigating and, where appropriate, verifying rumours\nabout SARS coming in from a wide range of sources.\n- The current cumulative number of cases of SARS is 2781 cases with 111\ndeaths, officially notified by ministries of health. - - The global\ncase-fatality rate for probable SARS is 4 percent.\n- Most SARS cases to date have occurred in young adults. This transmission\npattern largely reflects the age of health care workers, their family\nmembers and social contacts, and international travellers. On the basis of\npresent data, children appear to be less likely to present with SARS than\nadults.\n- SARS appears to be spread most commonly by close person-to-person contact\ninvolving exposure to infectious droplets, and possibly by direct contact\nwith infected body fluids.\n- China continues to see new cases of SARS although the numbers are\ndecreasing following a peak in cases in February 2003. To date, 1290 cases\nand 55 deaths have been reported from mainland China.\n- Hong Kong is experiencing the second largest outbreak of SARS with 998\ncases and 30 deaths. A significant outbreak at the Amoy Gardens apartment\nblock between 27 Mar 2003 to 1 Apr 2003 resulted in a peak in cases.\nStringent public health measures appear to have controlled the Amoy Gardens\noutbreak. However, cases continue to be reported in health care workers,\nand Hong Kong health authorities are strengthening their infection control\nand community-based public health measures accordingly.\n- Canada has experienced an outbreak of 97 probable SARS cases and 10\ndeaths. Up to now, the outbreak has been largely confined to Toronto. All\ncases have been epidemiologically linked to transmission related to a\nhealth care setting and transmission among close contacts of known SARS\ncases. In the Canadian outbreak, the higher case-fatality ratio appears to\nbe linked to the older age of the patients, who frequently have underlying\nchronic disease.\n- Infection control and other public health measures implemented in Viet\nNam have effectively controlled the outbreak in Hanoi. Very low levels of\ntransmission have been reported after 24 Mar 2003. Since the outbreak began\non 26 Feb 2003, 4 deaths have been reported.\n- Although Singapore continues to see new cases, including clusters in\nhospital staff, inpatients, and visitors at 2 hospitals, the daily increase\nin numbers has decreased since a peak in mid-March 2003. As of 10 Apr 2003,\na cumulative total of 126 cases with 9 deaths has been reported. Singapore\nis currently investigating a new cluster at the Singapore General Hospital\naffecting 52 persons in Wards 57 and 58, comprising 19 probable and 33\nsuspect SARS cases. The index case was admitted to this hospital on 24 Mar\n2003 for the management of unrelated chronic illness, did not show\ncharacteristic SARS symptoms initially, and therefore was not placed in\nisolation and managed according to the principles of strict infection control.\n- Cases continue to increase in the United States with 154 persons under\ninvestigation. US figures include probable and suspect cases. The US now\nreports limited transmission from patients to health care workers. No\ndeaths have so far been reported from the US.\n- Areas defined as 'affected' are updated each day according to the latest\ndata on cases and evidence of patterns of transmission. Epidemiological\ndata indicate that SARS cases occurring in all other countries became\ninfected while present in one of the affected areas or by direct contact\nwith known cases of SARS.\nAn epidemic curve of worldwide reporting by dates of onset can be found at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsepicurve/epiindex/en/index1.html>.\n\n[E] Information to Member States regarding goods and animals arriving from\nSARS-affected areas 11 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/goods2003_04_10/en/>\nWHO is aware of concern over the possibility that SARS may be caused by\ncontact with animals. WHO is therefore working closely with the Food and\nAgriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and the Office\nInternational des Epizooties (OIE), to determine whether there is any\nevidence to suggest that SARS-related disease has occurred in animals.\nWHO, FAO and OIE have reviewed reports received regarding SARS\ntransmission. To date there is no epidemiological information to suggest\nthat contact with goods, products, or animals shipped from SARS-affected\nareas has been the source of SARS infection in humans.\nFor the above reasons, WHO does not at present conclude that any goods,\nproducts, or animals arriving from SARS-affected areas pose a risk to\npublic health. WHO will continue to closely monitor the evolution of SARS,\nin collaboration with Ministries of Health and our partner agencies.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 11 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 11 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 11 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 11 Apr 2003, an additional 61 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals.
