As of 15:00 PM on 11 Apr 2003, there were 147 possible SARS cases\nreported. They include 23 probable, 37 suspected, 72 excluded, and 15\npending cases. In accordance with WHO guidelines, 7 of the probable and 15\nof the suspected cases were discharged to home quarantine while the other\n16 probable and 22 suspected cases are still being cared for in negative\npressure rooms. A total of 60 possible SARS cases have been discharged from\nhospitals.\n2. As of 11 Apr 2003, local health stations distributed SARS home\nquarantine notifications to 1458 persons who had close contact with\nprobable SARS cases. 988 of them have been relieved of the quarantine order.\n3. Since SARS is a new emerging infectious disease and its cause agent has\nnot been confirmed, a probable case is identified based on epidemiologic\ndata, clinical data, laboratory diagnosis data, and further serology is\nneeded to confirm the diagnosis. Taiwan SARS Advisory Committee did not\nrecommend the early release of the results of coronavirus test by RT-PCR to\nthe local health authorities for their reference. Taiwan CDC advises the\nlocal health authorities to take precautionary measures as soon as they\nreceive a reported SARS case, without laboratory diagnosis.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 11 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update27.html>\n\nAs of 11 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 266 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 10 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons\nwho have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household\nor in a health-care setting. The information contained in this update is\nbased on the best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 98 probable and 119 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 3 probable and 34 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nSo far, 54 people have been discharged from hospitals in Ontario. These\npeople were treated as suspect cases or as probable cases.\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST, 11 Apr 2003.\nProtecting Canada's Blood Supply\nHealth Canada issued formal direction to blood operators on 10 Apr 2003, as\na precaution to protect the blood supply in Canada and recipients from the\npossible threat of SARS. Although there is currently no evidence of\ntransmission of SARS through blood and blood components, Health Canada has\ndirected blood operators to temporarily defer from [accepting] blood (for a\nperiod of 10 days) from persons who have:\n- traveled within the previous 10 days to an affected area outside Canada.\nThe affected areas are currently: China, including the Hong Kong SAR;\nHanoi, Vietnam; Singapore and Taiwan;\n- been a patient, worked in, or visited a facility that is under quarantine\nfor SARS.\nHealth Canada has requested that provincial public health officials, when\ninvestigating possible SARS cases, ask whether the individual has donated\nblood. worldwide (38): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203608", "date": "2003-04-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (38): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Gene chip technology in diagnosis\n[2] & [3] Two early-release papers from the NEJM confirming the association\nof a novel coronavirus with SARS\n******\n[1]\nDate: Wed 9 Apr 2003\nFrom: 'George Robertson' <RobertG3@wyeth.com>\nSource: Associated Press report, Mon 7 Apr 2003 [edited]\n\nGene Chip Technology Finds Likely Cause of SARS\n-----------------------------------------------\nSAN FRANCISCO: It took just a few waves of the computer mouse for Joseph\nDeRisi to identify the prime suspect behind the sometimes deadly new\nmystery illness dubbed severe acute respiratory syndrome. Using a laser\nmicroscope to compare victim samples sent by the Centers for Disease\nControl and Prevention to genetic material from about 1000 different\nviruses imprinted on a glass slide, the University of California researcher\nfound the telltale clues of the suspect virus appearing as illuminated dots\non his computer screen.\nDeRisi placed his computer's cursor over one lighted dot and it read\n'bovine coronavirus.' Another dot outputted 'avian coronavirus.' By the\ntime he got to the turkey and human coronavirus dots, he knew he was\ndealing with something the world's scientists had never seen before. If it\nhad been a known virus --- say the human coronavirus, a cause of the common\ncold --- then only human coronavirus dots would have lighted up. 'This\nsuggests this is not a simple mutation of a human virus,' said DeRisi.\nWhatever this was, it was related closely enough to the other viruses to\nbond to their DNA [cDNA in the case of RNA viruses?] but exotic enough to\nsuggest that it was something entirely new that had crossed the species\nbarrier. DeRisi immediately e-mailed CDC researchers on 23 Mar 2003\nconfirming that a new coronavirus was probably causing the syndrome, which\nhas killed at least 82 people and sickened hundreds, hurting business and\ntravel as it spread from China, where it apparently originated.\nThe 'virus chip' DeRisi and his colleagues created could come in handy as\nepidemiologists try to identify and contain emerging diseases --- including\npathogens that bioterrorists could launch. 'It's amazingly simple and\nstraightforward,' DeRisi said. 'There's nothing revolutionary about this\nconcept except for the fact that we did it.' What DeRisi did was build upon\nthe microarray, or gene chip, an 8-year-old invention that melds DNA onto\nglass using some of the same technology that makes computer chips.\nMicroarrays allow biologists to analyze thousands of genes simultaneously\ninstead of one at a time. 'Microarrays are pretty universal,' said Henry\nNiman, a cancer researcher at Harvard Medical School, who uses chips with\nhuman genes in his own research and called DeRisi's for his results on the\nSARS finding. 'Impressive,' Niman concluded after analyzing the data.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDirector of Quality Control Operations\nWYETH VACCINES\n206 North Biddle Street\nMarietta, PA 17547-0304\n<RobertG3@wyeth.com>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 10 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: New England Journal of Medicine online, early release, Thu 10 Apr\n2003 [edited]\n<http://nejm.org/earlyrelease/sars.asp>\n\nAbstract of Paper Entitled: A Novel Coronavirus Associated with Severe\nAcute Respiratory Syndrome\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\nBackground:\nA worldwide outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has been\nassociated with exposures originating from a single ill health care worker\nfrom Guangdong Province, China. We conducted studies to identify the\netiologic agent of this outbreak.\nMethods:\nWe received clinical specimens from patients in six countries and tested\nthem, using virus isolation techniques, electron-microscopical and\nhistologic studies, and molecular and serologic assays, in an attempt to\nidentify a wide range of potential pathogens.\nResults:\nNo classic respiratory or bacterial respiratory pathogen was consistently\nidentified. However, a novel coronavirus was isolated from patients who met\nthe case definition of SARS. Cytopathological features were noted\nmicroscopically in Vero E6 cells inoculated with a throat-swab specimen.\nElectron-microscopical examination of cultures revealed ultrastructural\nfeatures characteristic of coronaviruses. Immunohistochemical and\nimmunofluorescence staining revealed reactivity with group I coronavirus\npolyclonal antibodies. Consensus coronavirus primers designed to amplify a\nfragment of the polymerase gene by reverse transcription\u00adpolymerase chain\nreaction (RT-PCR) were used to obtain a sequence that clearly identified\nthe isolate as a unique coronavirus only distantly related to previously\nsequenced coronaviruses. With specific diagnostic RT-PCR primers we\nidentified several identical nucleotide sequences in 12 patients from\nseveral locations, a finding consistent with a point source outbreak.\nIndirect fluorescent antibody tests and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays\nmade with the new coronavirus isolate have been used to demonstrate a\nvirus-specific serologic response. Preliminary studies suggest that this\nvirus may never before have infected the U.S. population.\nConclusion:\nA novel coronavirus is associated with this outbreak, and the evidence\nindicates that this virus has an etiologic role in SARS. The name Urbani\nSARS-associated coronavirus is proposed for the virus.\n--\nThomas G. Ksiazek, D.V.M., Ph.D., Dean Erdman, Dr. P.H., Cynthia\nGoldsmith, M.S., Sherif R. Zaki, M.D., Ph.D., Teresa Peret, Ph.D., Shannon\nEmery, Suxiang Tong, Ph.D., Carlo Urbani, M.D.,* James A. Comer, Ph.D.,\nM.P.H., Wilina Lim, Pierre E. Rollin, M.D., Scott Dowell, M.D., M.P.H.,\nAi-Ee Ling, M.D., Charles Humphrey, Ph.D., Wun-Ju Shieh, M.D., Jeannette\nGuarner, M.D., Christopher D. Paddock, M.D., Paul Rota, Ph.D., Barry\nFields, Ph.D., Joseph DeRisi, Ph.D., Jyh-Yuan Yang, Ph.D., Nancy Cox,\nPh.D., James Hughes, M.D., James W. LeDuc, Ph.D., William Bellini, Ph.D.,\nLarry J. Anderson, M.D., and the SARS Working Group.\n[The text of this paper is supplemented by a comprehensive account of the\nexperimental techniques employed: propagation in cell culture,\nimmunological techniques, molecular methods and information on PCR primers.\nA phylogenetic tree based on sequence alignment of 405 nucleotides of the\ncoronavirus polymerase gene open reading frame 1b provides strong evidence\nthat the SARS-associated coronavirus is genetically distinct from\npreviously known animal and human coronaviruses. The 18 patients with SARS\nexamined in this study were epidemiologically linked either to the source\nof the Hong Kong cases or to Guangdong Province, China, the origin of the\nindex patient in Hong Kong. The sequences from a limited region of the\npolymerase gene are identical to each other and to a sequence obtained from\none of the Canadian patients, and from the Fankfurt-am-Main index case\ndescribed in the following paper, all of which suggests a point source for\nthe SARS outbreak.\nAn apparent lack of antibody in all serum specimens except those from\npatients with SARS suggests that this virus has not previously circulated\nwidely in humans, which is further evidence in favor of the association\nbetween infection with this novel coronavirus and SARS.\nBecause of the death of Dr. Carlo Urbani during the investigation of the\ninitial SARS epidemic, the authors propose that the virus be named Urbani\nSARS-associated coronavirus. However, this proposal is unlikely to be\nsustained because the 'Rules for Naming Viral Taxa' used by the\nInternational Committee on Virus Taxonomy state that: 'No person's name\nshall be used when devising names for new taxa.'\nThe isolation of this novel coronavirus from the respiratory secretions of\na patient with SARS and subsequent demonstration of this virus or a\nserologic response to this virus in others is strong support for a possible\netiologic association between this virus and SARS. - Mod.CP]\n******\n[3]\nDate: Thu 10 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New England Journal of Medicine online, early release, Thu 10 Apr\n2003 [edited]\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030747v1.pdf>\n\nAbstract of Paper entitled: Identification of a Novel Coronavirus in\nPatients with Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nBackground:\nThe severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has recently been identified\nas a new clinical entity. SARS is thought to be caused by an unknown\ninfectious agent.\nMethods:\nClinical specimens from patients with SARS were searched for unknown\nviruses with the use of cell cultures and molecular techniques.\nResults:\nA novel coronavirus was identified in patients with SARS. The virus was\nisolated in cell culture, and a sequence 300 nucleotides in length was\nobtained by a polymerase-chain reaction (PCR)\u00adbased random-amplification\nprocedure. Genetic characterization indicated that the virus is only\ndistantly related to known coronaviruses (identical in 50 to 60 percent of\nthe nucleotide sequence). On the basis of the obtained sequence,\nconventional and real-time PCR assays for specific and sensitive detection\nof the novel virus were established. Virus was detected in a variety of\nclinical specimens from patients with SARS but not in controls. High\nconcentrations of viral RNA of up to 100 million molecules per milliliter\nwere found in sputum. Viral RNA was also detected at extremely low\nconcentrations in plasma during the acute phase and in feces during the\nlate convalescent phase. Infected patients showed sero-conversion on the\nVero cells in which the virus was isolated.\nConclusion:\nThe novel coronavirus might have a role in causing SARS.\n--\nChristian Drosten, M.D., Stephan G\u00fcnther, M.D., Wolfgang Preiser, M.D.,\nSylvie van der Werf, Ph.D., Hans-Reinhard Brodt, M.D., Stephan Becker,\nPh.D., Holger Rabenau, Ph.D., Marcus Panning, M.D., Larissa Kolesnikova,\nPh.D., Ron A.M. Fouchier, Ph.D., Annemarie Berger, Ph.D., Ana-Maria\nBurgui\u00e8re, Ph.D., Jindrich Cinatl, Ph.D., Markus Eickmann, Ph.D., Nicolas\nEscriou, Ph.D., Klaus Grywna, M.Sc., Stefanie Kramme, M.D., Jean-Claude\nManuguerra, Ph.D., Stefanie M\u00fcller, M.Sc., Volker Rickerts, M.D., Martin\nSt\u00fcrmer, Ph.D., Simon Vieth, Hans-Dieter Klenk, M.D., Albert D.M.E.\nOsterhaus, Ph.D., Herbert Schmitz, M.D., and Hans Wilhelm Doerr, M.D.\n[This companion paper from European workers describes an independent set of\ndata that support the same conclusion that a novel coronavirus may be the\netiologic agent of SARS. Again the methodology is described in detail and\nthe paper is supplemented by sequence alignments and a diagrammatic\nrepresentation of the location of the primers. An independently derived\nphylogenetic tree exhibits the same relationships among coronaviruses and\nindicates that the SARS-associated coronavirus is not closely related to\nany perviously known coronavirus. Whether it is a unique virus or a\nrecombinant between pre-exising viruses is an open question that must await\ncomplete sequencing of the virus genome.\nThe principal finding of the study is the identification of a novel\ncoronavirus in patients with SARS. Furthermore, it appears that patients\nwith SARS are acutely infected with this virus, since they have\nvirus-specific IgG, and sero-conversion was observed. A high rate of\npositivity among patients with probable SARS during an outbreak in Hanoi,\nin conjunction with the complete negativity among all healthy contacts of\npatients affected by the same outbreak, provides evidence of an association\nbetween the disease and the presence of this novel virus.\nThe authors caution, however, that in the past, viruses have been initially\nisolated from patients with a specific disease but subsequent\ninvestigations revealed no actual association. Thus, larger studies with\nappropriate control groups are needed to verify or eliminate the hypothesis\nthat this novel coronavirus is the cause of SARS. The assays that have been\nestablished provide an excellent tool for such studies.\nFrom a diagnostic point of view, it is important to note that nasal and\nthroat swabs seem less suitable for diagnosis, since these materials\ncontain considerably less viral RNA than sputum, and the virus may escape\ndetection if only these materials are tested.\nBy testing for a broad range of known pathogens, the authors also obtained\nevidence for infection with paramyxoviruses and _Chlamidia pneumoniae_ in\nsome patients, but human metapneumovirus, which was previously implicated\nin SARS, could be largely ruled out. This action follows concerns, connected with yesterday's report\nfrom a WHO investigative team, about SARS cases in Beijing and systems of\ncase reporting and contact tracing.\n\nChina is today reporting 10 new SARS cases, with 2 new deaths, compared\nwith yesterday.\n\nIn a separate development, 2 laboratories in China have announced detection\nof a coronavirus in specimens taken from SARS patients. The new virus,\nwhich is unlike any known human or animal virus in the coronavirus family,\nwas isolated by a WHO virtual network of 11 laboratories set up to expedite\nidentification of the etiological agent and development of a diagnostic\ntest. Detection of the coronavirus adds further evidence that the outbreak\nthat began in Guangdong Province in mid-November 2002 was caused by the\nSARS virus.\n\nHong Kong\nHealth authorities in Hong Kong have today announced that all household\ncontacts of confirmed SARS patients will be required to confine themselves\nat home for up to 10 days with immediate effect. The new measure is\nintended to facilitate early detection and treatment of SARS cases and to\nreduce to the absolute minimum the risk of further spread. With a\ncumulative total of 998 cases and 28 deaths, Hong Kong ranks just below\nChina in the severity of the SARS outbreak.\n\nHousehold contacts can choose between confinement in their homes and\nconfinement in holiday camps. No visitors are allowed during the\nconfinement period, and permission to leave homes or camps will be granted\nonly on exceptional grounds. During the confinement period, the Hong Kong\nDepartment of Health will conduct medical checks to monitor health, and the\npolice force will conduct compliance checks. Officials in the Department of\nHealth estimate that an initial 70 to 80 households, representing around\n150 persons, will be subject to the new requirement.\n\nIn a separate development, ongoing investigations of the source of\ninfection in the unusual cluster of cases in Amoy Gardens have failed to\ndetect the virus in animals. The findings refute previous hypotheses that\nthe SARS might have been spread by cockroaches or rodents, possibly through\nsome common system serving vertically connected flats. Most Amoy Gardens\ncases have been residents in a single wing of a single building, Block E.\n\nSingapore\nIn Singapore, particular concern has centered on a cluster of suspect and\nprobable SARS cases first noted on 5 Apr 2003 in 21 staff at the Tan Tock\nSeng Hospital. Intensive investigation by WHO staff and Ministry of Health\nofficials have traced most cases to a single Chinese man in his 60s was had\nbeen treated for chronic kidney disease and diabetes at another hospital\n(Singapore General Hospital) from 5 to 20 Mar 2003. The hospital\nsubsequently experienced a cluster of 19 probable and 33 suspected SARS\ncases in staff, visitors, and inpatients. Most have been linked to the\nChinese patient.\n\nThe second hospital-related cluster of SARS cases has now been linked to a\ndecision to transfer all patients at Singapore General Hospital to 2 wards\nat Tan Tock Seng Hospital. It is strongly suspected that the second cluster\narose from contact with the Chinese patient. The investigation is providing\nsome reassurance about the cause of these cases, which increasingly appear\nto fit the known pattern of exposure during close contact with patients.\n\nViet Nam\nThe number of cases in Viet Nam remains stable at 62. Upon return to\nPenang, Malaysia, the patient visited 2 private hospitals over a 2-day\nperiod. Possible contacts are now being traced.\n\nActive contact tracing is a sound and essential public health measure for\ndetecting persons who may have been exposed and alerting them to the steps\nto take should symptoms develop. There are\nmultiple curves, representing the global outbreak, and then outbreaks by\ncountry for Hong Kong, Viet Nam, Singapore, Canada, the United States, and\nthe European Region. Reviewing the curves, when looking at the epidemic\ncurve by date of onset, it does appear as though the global outbreak may\nhave already peaked, although this curve represents a small fraction of\nactual reported probable cases, as dates of onset were not available for\n2105 cases. The date of onset of the most recent reported cases was 1 Apr\n2003, 6 days preceding the last date of notification. In contrast, the\nepidemic curve plotting reported cases by date of report appears to be\nconsistent with ongoing transmission at a steady rate, with a marked\nincrease in numbers of cases reported on 1 Apr 2003 (representing the\ndelayed reports from China) and another significant increase in reported\ncases on 8 Apr 2003.\n\nThe epidemic curve by date of report in Hong Kong suggests that there was a\nlarge peak during the week of 29 Mar 2003, and a second smaller peak during\nthe week of 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic curve by date of onset for Viet Nam\nsuggests that there was a peak during the week of 8 Mar 2003, and apparent\ninterruption of transmission (or missed cases, or one incubation period\npending appearance of new cases) during the week of 29 Mar 2003 and the\nappearance of a few cases during the week of 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic\ncurve, by date of onset for Singapore shows a clear peak in cases during\nthe period 15-22 Mar 2003 and a significant tapering off of cases by the\nweek 5 Apr 2003. The epidemic curve, by date of onset, for Canada shows a\nclear peak during the period 15-22 Mar 2003, with continued transmission\nbut at a lower rate. There have not been any cases reported with dates of\nonset since 4 Apr 2003 in Canada. The epidemic curve, by date of onset\n(current as of 4 Apr 2003), for the United States shows several peak\nperiods of cases, during the weeks of 15 Mar 2003, 22 Mar 2003, and 29 Mar\n2003. The maximum number of cases with dates of onset on a single day was\n9 on 17 Mar 2003. (We do not have information on the dates of onset of the\nfew healthcare workers and family members that were contacts of imported\ncases, but the overwhelming majority of cases reported in the United States\nwere in individuals with a history of travel to affected areas (see section\n[B] above). There have not been any cases reported with dates of onset\nsince 30 Mar 2003, representing a 5-day period without new cases. In\ncontrast, the epidemic curve by date of onset for the European Region is\nmore consistent with sporadic case reports, with a maximum of one or 2\ncases per day. To date there have not been reports of any secondary\ntransmission in the European Region. - Mod.MPP]\n\n\n[D] Update 25 - Interim report of WHO team in China, status of the main\nSARS outbreaks in different countries 9 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_09/en/>\n\n[ProMED-mail would like to express our continuing gratitude to Marianne\nHopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com> for her daily monitoring of WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\n\n\nChina\n------\nThe WHO team of experts presented its interim report on the SARS outbreak\nin Guangdong Province this morning to the Chinese Ministry of Health and\nVice Premier Wu Yi in Beijing. The team began its investigations in\nGuangdong on 3 Apr 2003.\n\nThe team concluded that the health system in Guangdong responded well to\nthe outbreak. The province has a health system in which every hospital at\nevery level reports any new cases of SARS. The WHO report therefore\nconcluded that virtually all probable cases of SARS presenting at a\nhospital in Guangdong Province will be detected and rapidly reported.\n\nHowever, the team found an urgent need to improve surveillance in the\ncountryside to head off new outbreaks in rural areas. The team was further\nconcerned by an increase in sporadic cases, which could not be linked to a\nparticular transmission chain, as such cases raised questions about the\nadequacy of contact tracing.\n\nIn addition, the report noted many remaining concerns about the ability of\nother provinces, where health systems are not as strong as the one in\nGuangdong, to respond promptly and effectively to the challenge of SARS.\n\nIn Beijing, for example, only a minority of hospitals make daily reports of\nSARS cases. Contact tracing is another problem in Beijing and does not\nappear to be carried out systematically. Failure to perform careful contact\ntracing will allow the disease to spread.\n\nThe team observed that many of China\u0092s poorer provinces may not have\nadequate resources, facilities, and equipment to cope with outbreaks of\nSARS, and underscored that Guangdong\u0092s capacity was exceptional among\nChina\u0092s provinces.\n\nIn Guangdong, the SARS outbreak placed an enormous strain on the health\ncare system. The Guangdong Infectious Disease Hospital (Guangzhou No. 8\nPeople\u0092s Hospital) had 150 of its 400 beds occupied by SARS patients daily\nduring the second week of February [2003]. The team noted that the response\nof the health care system has been exemplary, and commended the dedication\nand bravery of doctors, nurses, and others working in clinics and hospitals.\n\nMicrobiological findings\n----------\nLarge banks of stored specimens from suspected and probable SARS cases,\nfrom case contacts as well as from \u0093normal controls\u0094 exist at the\ninstitutions visited and are stored under suitable conditions; detailed\ninformation about the numbers and types of these specimens are available\nand were provided to members of the WHO team. Although the patient data on\neach of these is very limited, it is sufficient to allow linkage with the\nvery detailed epidemiological and clinical information held elsewhere in\nGuangdong Provincial Centers for Disease Control and the hospitals.\n\nThese specimen banks comprise different types of respiratory specimens from\nwhich the detection of agents can be attempted and serum samples, often as\npaired acute and convalescent sera (i.e., the first sample obtained during\nthe acute phase of the illness and the second during recovery), which will\nallow determination of seroconversions. The laboratory staff agreed that\nonce a causative agent for SARS was identified, these banks should be\ntested and will provide very valuable information; they seemed, however,\nless sure whether this time had come already, i.e. whether there was\nalready sufficient evidence and whether suitable tests had been developed\nelsewhere that would make such an exercise worthwhile. They requested\nassistance from the WHO team to obtain relevant information on primer\nsequences and other matters as well as access to suitable experimental\ntests such as immunofluorescence antibody assays.\n\nMain recommendations\n---------\nThe interim report made several major recommendations, including the following:\n\n- The SARS reporting system established in Guangdong is an excellent model\nthat all provinces should follow. Team members suggest that the MOH ensures\nthat all provinces are brought up to Guangdong standards by implementing\nthis system nationwide as a matter of the utmost urgency. A programme for\nevaluating and accrediting surveillance systems through evaluation by\ntechnical experts is also suggested in order to ensure that consistent\nstandards are achieved and maintained.\n\n- The Guangdong experience should be used to develop uniform standards\nthroughout all provinces for preventing the spread of SARS in health care\nfacilities.\n\n- Careful contact tracing of SARS cases is vital to bring the outbreak\nunder control. Detailed interviewing of all newly reported SARS cases by\ntrained interviewers including a full review not only of close contacts but\npotential exposure in other crowded settings, e.g. public transport, needs\nto be routinely carried out. Contacts of cases should be provided with\ndetailed preventive advice verbally and in writing.\n\n- Much better collaboration between virological laboratories in China is\nrequired, particularly to facilitate the exchange of results, specimens,\nand reagents. The following institutions should form the nucleus of a\nnational SARS laboratory network within China:\n- National Institute of Virology, China CDC, Beijing\n- Virology Unit, Beijing Provincial CDC, Beijing\n- Virology Unit, Guangdong Provincial CDC, Guangzhou\n- Department of Virology, Zhongshan University, Guangzhou\nLaboratories from other areas with experience of SARS cases should also be\nincluded. Adequate funding and human resources need to be urgently provided\nto ensure the proper functioning and sustainability of SARS surveillance\nactivities, as they are essential to controlling spread of the disease.\nChinese institutions should form a national SARS laboratory network within\nChina to speed up the exchange of results, specimens, and reagents.\n\n- Guangdong clinicians have cared for the largest number of patients in the\nworld and their experience should be shared with the international\ncommunity through publications, meetings, and in drafting guidelines for\nthe management of SARS patients.\n\nPriority actions\nPriority actions recommended in the report to contain SARS include:\n\n- early recognition and treatment of cases\n\n- stringent infection control measures in hospitals and clinics\n\n- prompt reporting of suspected cases\n\n- meticulous investigation and contact tracing in the community - public\nawareness campaigns and education.\n\n\nHong Kong: heavy burden on the health system\n---------\nWith today\u0092s cumulative total of 970 cases and 27 deaths, Hong Kong\ncontinues to have the largest SARS outbreak, second to China. The strain on\nhealth services and staff is considerable, and strengthened measures of\ninfection control may be needed.\n\nThe isolation order placed on Block E, Amory Gardens will expire at\nmidnight, 9 Apr 2003. The Hong Kong Health Department has announced that\nresidents, temporarily housed at camps, may return home after their flats\nhave been disinfected by the Food and Environmental Hygiene Department.\n\nSingapore: role of 'super-spreaders'\n----------\nSingapore has increased measures to prevent transmission in hospitals\nfollowing an outbreak in Singapore General Hospital. Measures include\nmandatory temperature checks for all staff, limiting visitors, and\nisolation of all possible SARS cases. The Singapore General Hospital\noutbreak involved over 20 people with suspect symptoms, nearly all nurses\nand doctors. Only 7 have been diagnosed as 'probable' SARS cases. The\ndistribution of cases over time suggests a point source. The health worker\nconsidered to be the index case in this cluster of cases may be the fourth\n'super-spreader' identified in Singapore.\n\nA 'super-spreader' is a source case who has, for as yet unknown reasons,\ninfected a large number of persons. Although transmission patterns of SARS\nremain incompletely understood, evidence suggests that such\n'super-spreaders' may have contributed to the evolution of SARS outbreaks\naround the world.\n\nUntil recently, all cases in Singapore have had good epidemiological links\nto their source. Further work is now required to establish similar links\nfor the more recent cases. If confirmed, such linking of cases will show\nthat transmission is limited to those who are symptomatic and usually very\nill. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that health workers\ncontinue to be the main group diagnosed with SARS. To date, investigation\nof the SARS outbreak in Singapore have revealed few signs of community\nspread beyond family members in close face-to-face contact with patients.\nHowever, these findings are based on limited data on exposures.\n\nViet Nam: no asymptomatic transmission\n--------\nVietnam is now reporting a cumulative total of 62 cases. 4 of these cases\nhave been detected in the last few days following stable reporting of 58\ncases for several consecutive days. The stable number of cases raised hope\nthat the outbreak in the French hospital in Hanoi had been contained.\nHowever, a 59th case was reported on 31 Mar 2003.\n\nThis male patient had been in contact with his daughter, who was a patient\nat the French Hospital at the time of Viet Nam\u0092s index case. This contact\ncontinued when the daughter became an outpatient. The daughter\u0092s husband,\nwho attended the Hanoi French Hospital with his wife, had a mild febrile\nillness which was undiagnosed at the time and which resolved spontaneously.\nIt is presumed that he had mild SARS and passed the infection to his\nfather-in-law (case 59). Assuming this to be true, WHO epidemiologists\nmaintain the view that asymptomatic transmission does not appear to occur.\nNor does this case suggest a longer incubation period than currently\nassumed (2-7 days, with 10 days considered the rare maximum). Blood is\nbeing taken for testing of the husband. Case 60 is a doctor who cared for\ncase 59 while he was in a provincial hospital about 1.5 hours from Hanoi.\nCases 61 and 62 are young women who are part of the extended household who\nprovided considerable care for case 59.\n\nWHO continues to work with the Ministry of Health to investigate the\ncontacts of these cases. It is anticipated that a few more new cases will\nbe linked to case 59. Careful monitoring of contacts continues.\n\nOf the 62 cases, 44 have been discharged, 4 have died, and 14 remain in\nhospital. One of the hospitalized patients remains critically ill, although\nslightly improved. All other hospitalized patients are improving.\n\nCanada: one new probable case reported\n--------\nHealth Canada has reported a cumulative total of 94 probable cases and 10\ndeaths. Ontario has reported 91 probable cases. All cases have occurred in\npersons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the\nhousehold or in a health-care setting. The remaining probable cases are in\nBritish Columbia (3).\n\nUpdate on cases and countries\n-------------\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 2722 cases, with 106 deaths have been\nreported from 16 countries. This represents an increase of 51 cases and 3\ndeaths when compared with yesterday.\n\nNew cases were reported in Canada (3), China (1), Hong Kong SAR (42),\nSingapore (5), and the United States of America (1). The single case\nreported in Australia has been removed from the list. Deaths were reported\nin Hong Kong (2) and Singapore (1).\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Trying to synthesize the information contained in the above reports from\nWHO today, there are many positive points. In addition, the collaboration with the Chinese MOH with\nrespect to laboratory studies is also very promising and will provide a\nbank of specimens among which to check diagnostic tests as well as to\nconduct further studies. 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (42): WHO HISTORICAL OVERVIEW\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 11 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_11/en/>\n\nUpdate 27 - One month into the global SARS outbreak: Status of the\noutbreak and lessons for the immediate future 11 Apr 2003\n------------------------\nStatus of the global SARS outbreak and lessons for the immediate future\nCurrent status of the SARS outbreak\nAt this moment, public health authorities, physicians and scientists around\nthe world are struggling to cope with a severe and rapidly spreading new\ndisease in humans, severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS. This appears\nto be the first severe and easily transmissible new disease to emerge in\nthe 21st century. Though much about the disease remains poorly understood,\nincluding the exact identity of the causative virus, we do know that it has\nfeatures that allow it to spread rapidly along international air travel routes.\nAs of 10 Apr 2003, 2781 SARS cases, with 111 deaths, have been reported to\nWHO from 17 countries on 3 continents. Some outbreaks have reassuring\nfeatures. A high awareness of SARS symptoms among travellers and the\nmedical and nursing professions has often resulted in good management of\nimported cases - prompt isolation of patients and management according to\nstrict procedures of infection control. As a result, many countries having\nonly a single or a few imported cases have experienced no further spread to\nhospital staff, families of patients and hospital visitors, or the\ncommunity at large.\nThe list of countries and continents reporting suspect or probable SARS\ncases will no doubt continue to grow due to heightened global vigilance,\nknowledge about symptoms and exposures, and awareness of the need for\nimmediate isolation of cases and strict infection control. So long as these\nmeasures are followed, the detection of first cases in countries need not\nbe interpreted as evidence that SARS is continuing to spread. Tabular\ninformation on countries reporting SARS and the cumulative total of cases\nand deaths is published each day on the WHO SARS web site.\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/en/>\n'Hot zones' of concern\nDespite some positive signs that imported cases are not spreading further,\noutbreaks in China, Canada, Hong Kong, Hanoi, and Singapore have taken root\nin hospitals and beyond, and give rise to considerable concern. One of the\nmost alarming features of SARS in these areas is its rapid spread in\nhospitals, where it has affected a large number of previously healthy\nhealth care workers. Many require intensive care, placing a huge strain on\nhospital facilities and staff. In countries, such as Canada, where cases\noccurred before WHO issued its global alert, SARS is continuing to spread\ndespite the introduction of strict patient isolation and excellent\ninfection control.\nChina\nOn 9 Apr 2003, a WHO investigative team, which had conducted interviews and\nstudies in Guangdong Province since 3 Apr 2003, presented its interim\nreport on the SARS outbreak to Chinese authorities. The team concluded that\nthe health system in Guangdong responded well to the outbreak, but that\nhealth systems in all other provinces had less capacity to cope with the\nseverity of the challenge posed by SARS. Several recommendations for\nimprovements were made in the report.\nThe team also found evidence of 'super-spreaders' in Guangdong, including\none who is thought to have infected as many as 100 other persons. The\noutbreak is now thought to date back to at least 16 Nov 2002, when an\ninitial case was reported in Foshan City.\nParticular concern centres on the situation in Beijing. Yesterday, WHO\ndeepened discussions with Beijing health authorities, particularly\nconcerning the efficiency of systems for case reporting and contact tracing.\nCanada\nTo date, Canada has reported 114 probable cases and 10 deaths. All cases\nhave occurred in persons who have travelled to Asia or had close contact\nwith SARS cases in households or health care facilities. Health Canada has\ntaken several steps to protect the health of Canadians and the travelling\npublic, and to reduce opportunities of transmitting the virus to others.\nSeveral Canadian schools and hospitals are closed.\nHong Kong\nHong Kong, with 998 cases and 30 deaths, is presently the hardest-hit area.\nHealth care workers continue to become infected in a growing number of\nhospitals. WHO learned this week that the chief executive of the Prince of\nWales Hospital - the initial epicentre of the Hong Kong outbreak - is\nhospitalized with atypical pneumonia. Hospitals are becoming overwhelmed. A\ndecision to suspend all primary, secondary, special schools and\nkindergartens until 6 Apr 2003 has been extended up to 21 Apr 2003.\nMost disturbing is a large cluster of 268 SARS cases linked to the Amoy\nGardens estate of high-rise apartment buildings. The vast majority of Amoy\nGardens cases have been traced to vertically linked apartments in a single\nbuilding, Block E. This pattern of transmission indicates that the disease\nhas moved out of the health care setting and is now occurring within the\ncommunity as secondary cases. Epidemiologists investigating the Amoy\nGardens outbreak are considering the hypothesis that some form of\nenvironmental contamination, perhaps linked to a sewage or ventilation\nsystem, is the source of the large cluster of cases. Although transmission\nthrough the faecal-oral route is being considered as one possibility, no\nevidence of airborne transmission has been demonstrated to date. Virus has\nnot been detected in animals, including cockroaches and rodents.\nYesterday, health authorities in Hong Kong announced that all household\ncontacts of confirmed SARS patients will be required immediately to confine\nthemselves at home for up to 10 days. Household contacts can choose between\nconfinement in their homes and confinement in holiday camps. No visitors\nare allowed during the confinement period, and permission to leave homes or\ncamps will be granted only on exceptional grounds. During the confinement\nperiod, the Hong Kong Department of Health will conduct medical checks to\nmonitor health, and the police force will conduct compliance checks.\nViet Nam\nIn Viet Nam, an epidemiologist from the Hanoi WHO office recognized the\nfirst case of SARS on 28 Feb 2003 at a French hospital in Hanoi. The number\nof cases increased rapidly but then stabilized on 24 Mar 2003 at 58 cases\nand remained stable for 8 consecutive days. As the maximum incubation\nperiod for SARS is thought to be 10 days, the stable number of cases over\nthis period raised hope that Viet Nam's outbreak had been brought under\ncontrol. However, on 3 Apr 2003 a probable SARS case was detected in a\nprovincial hospital. Though the case could be linked back to the French\nhospital, the absence of isolation and rigorous infection control at the\nprovincial hospital suggests that many hospital staff, patients, and\nvisitors may have been exposed, thus possibly seeding further waves of\ncases. An additional 3 probable cases, known to have had close contacts\nwith cases, have been reported since 3 Apr 2003.\nSingapore\nIn Singapore, another of the earliest and hardest-hit areas, 126 persons,\nincluding several children under the age of 18 years, have been diagnosed\nwith SARS. Most disturbing are new and large clusters of suspected SARS\ncases among health workers, inpatients, and visitors in 2 interlinked wards\nat Singapore General Hospital and in a second hospital, Tan Tok Seng Hospital.\nIntense contact tracing and investigation of these clusters increasingly\npoints to contact with a single Chinese man in his 60s who was treated at\nSingapore General Hospital from 5 to 20 Mar 2003 for chronic kidney disease\nand diabetes at Singapore General Hospital. WHO epidemiologists, in\ncollaboration with national authorities, are finding increasing evidence\nthat the Chinese patient might have been a so-called 'super-spreader.'\nIn SARS outbreaks, a 'super-spreader' is a source case who has, for as yet\nunknown reasons, infected a large number of persons. It remains unknown\nwhether such 'super-spreaders' are persons secreting an exceptionally high\namount of infectious material or whether some other factor, perhaps in the\nenvironment, is working to amplify transmission at some key phase of virus\nshedding.\nNew coronavirus discovered\nThrough new mechanisms set up by WHO, progress on the research front has\nbeen unprecedented, particularly in the rapid discovery of a new\ncoronavirus and the rapid development of diagnostic tests. The best\nscientists from around the world are working on these problems around the\nclock, and in an unprecedented spirit of collaboration against a threat of\nas-yet-unknown dimensions. Nonetheless, we still do not have conclusive\nproof that the new virus is indeed the cause of SARS. The results of animal\nexperiments, which are currently being conducted by a laboratory in a WHO\nnetwork, will be available soon and may provide the last pieces of evidence\nneeded for definitive proof that SARS is caused by the newly discovered\ncoronavirus. Furthermore, the findings will provide additional evidence to\nunderstand the role of metapneumovirus as a possible 'helper virus' in\npersons co-infected with the new coronavirus.\nDiagnostic tests\nThe development of a diagnostic test has proved more problematic than\nhoped. 3 tests are now available and are helping to improve understanding\nof how the virus causes disease in humans. However, all 3 tests have\nlimitations as tools for bringing the SARS outbreak quickly under control.\nThe ELISA detects antibodies reliably but only from about day 20 after the\nonset of clinical symptoms. It therefore cannot be used to detect cases at\nan early stage before they have a chance to spread the infection to others.\nThe second test, an immunofluorescence assay (IFA), detects antibodies\nreliably as of day 10 of infection, but is a comparatively slow test that\nrequires the growth of virus in cell culture.\nThe presently available PCR molecular test for detection of SARS virus\ngenetic material is useful in the early stages of infection but produces\nmany false negatives. This means that many persons who actually carry the\nvirus may not be detected -- creating a dangerous sense of false security\nin relation to a virus that is known to spread easily in close\nperson-to-person contact.\nPresent role of tests in diagnosis\nA positive test results indicates that a person is, or recently was,\ninfected with the coronavirus. However, a negative test result does not\nguarantee that the person is not infected with the virus.\nAt present, reporting to WHO of probable SARS cases is based on an\nassessment of clinical symptoms, history -- including travel history -- of\npossible exposure to an infected person, and distinctive chest X-rays. The\n9 countries in the WHO laboratory network, namely Canada, France, Germany,\nJapan, Hong Kong SAR, the Netherlands, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and\nthe United States of America, are beginning to conduct routine laboratory\ntesting of suspect and probable SARS cases. WHO has posted on its web site\ndetails about the test methodology that allows other countries to perform\ntests. However, more work is needed to produce a robust test that is\ncapable of rapidly and reliably detecting cases at an early stage of infection.\nApart from the dimensions of the SARS outbreak apparent at this date, the\nsections below explain why this disease poses a particularly severe threat\nto international health, outline the chronology of events as SARS spread\naround the world, and discuss lessons based on strengths and weaknesses of\nthe global response for the immediate future. These lessons are of great\nimportance.\nThe SARS response is the roll-out of a global alert and response activity\nunder the revision of the International Health Regulations, which provide\nthe legal framework for the surveillance and reporting of infectious\ndisease and for the use of measures to prevent their international spread.\nSARS is showing how the alert and response activity works in practice for a\nnewly identified disease. It also indicates how the system now in operation\ncould apply to other highly significant infectious disease events,\nincluding the next influenza pandemic, the next emerging infection, and the\ndeliberate release of a biological agent in an act of warfare or terrorism.\nThe scientific community is now contending with an outbreak caused by a new\nvirus. This creates an extra step in the containment response:\nidentification and characterization of the causative agent, which then\nallows development of a diagnostic test, treatment protocols, and a\nscientifically sound basis for recommending control measures. This is a\nstep that would not be needed should a biological attack occur using a\nwell-known pathogen such as anthrax or smallpox. The response to an\ninfluenza pandemic would likewise not be dealing with an entirely new and\npoorly understood virus.\nSARS: a particularly serious threat to international health\nAlthough the last decades of the previous century witnessed the emergence\nof several new diseases, SARS needs to be regarded as a particularly\nserious threat for several reasons. If the SARS virus maintains its present\npathogenicity and transmissibility, SARS could become the first severe new\ndisease of the 21st century with global epidemic potential. As such, its\nclinical and epidemiological features, though poorly understood, give cause\nfor particular alarm. With the notable exception of AIDS, most new diseases\nthat emerged during the last 2 decades of the previous century or\nestablished endemicity in new geographical areas have features that limit\ntheir capacity to pose a major threat to international public health. Many\n(avian influenza, Nipah virus, Hendra virus, Hanta virus) failed to\nestablish efficient human-to-human transmission. Others (_Escherichia coli_\nO157:H7, variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) depend on food as a vehicle of\ntransmission. Diseases such as West Nile Fever and Rift Valley Fever that\nhave spread to new geographical areas require a vector as part of the\ntransmission cycle and are associated with low mortality, often in\nhigh-risk groups, such as the elderly, the immunocompromised, or persons\nwith co-morbidity. Still others (_Neisseria meningitidis_ W135, and the\nEbola, Marburg, and Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fevers) have strong\ngeographical foci. Although outbreaks of Ebola haemorrhagic fever have been\nassociated with case-fatality rates in the range of 53 percent (Uganda) to\n88 percent (Democratic Republic of the Congo), person-to-person\ntransmission requires close physical exposure to infected blood and other\nbodily fluids. Moreover, patients suffering from this disease during the\nperiod of high infectivity are visibly very ill and too unwell to travel.\nIn contrast, SARS is emerging in ways that suggest great potential for\nrapid international spread under the favourable conditions created by a\nhighly mobile, closely interconnected world. Anecdotal data indicate an\nincubation period of 2 to 10 days (average 2 to 7 days), allowing the\ninfectious agent to be transported, unsuspected and undetected, in a\nsymptomless air traveller from one city in the world to any other city\nhaving an international airport. Person-to-person transmission through\nclose contact with respiratory secretions has been demonstrated. The\ninitial symptoms are non-specific and common. The concentration of cases in\npreviously healthy hospital staff and the proportion of patients requiring\nintensive care are particularly alarming. This '21st century' disease could\nhave other consequences as well. Should SARS continue to spread, the global\neconomic consequences -- already estimated at around USD 30 billion --\ncould be great in a closely interconnected and interdependent world.\nChronology of events leading to an unprecedented emergency travel advisory\nSevere Acute Pulmonary Syndrome (SARS) was first identified in Viet Nam on\n28 Feb 2003, when Dr Carlo Urbani, an epidemiologist from the Hanoi WHO\noffice, examined a patient with a severe form of pneumonia for which no\netiology could be found. On 10 Mar 2003, 22 hospital workers in Hanoi\nFrench Hospital were ill with a similar acute respiratory syndrome, and by\n11 Mar 2003 similar outbreaks had been reported among hospital workers in\nHong Kong.\nSARS occurred at a time of heightened surveillance for atypical respiratory\ndisease. From 10 Feb 2003 the WHO office in Beijing, which reinforced its\nstaff with 2 epidemiologists, had been working with the government of China\nto learn more about an outbreak of atypical respiratory disease that\naffected health workers, their families and contacts in Guangdong Province,\nwith 305 cases and 5 deaths reported from 16 Nov 2002 to 7 Feb 2003. Around\n30 percent of cases were reported to occur in health care workers.\nSurveillance was heightened further when a 33-year-old man who had\ntravelled with his family to Fujian Province in China died in Hong Kong on\n17 Feb 2003. The next day, Hong Kong authorities announced that avian\ninfluenza A(H5N1) virus, the cause of 'bird flu', had been isolated from\nboth the man and his 9-year-old hospitalized son. Another member of the\nfamily, an 8-year-old daughter, died while in Fujian and was buried there.\nOn 12 Mar 2003, after an assessment of the situation in Asia with WHO teams\nin Hanoi, Hong Kong, and Beijing, a global alert was issued about cases of\nsevere atypical pneumonia with unknown etiology that appeared to place\nhealth workers at high risk.\n2 days later, on 14 Mar 2003, WHO received a report from the government of\nCanada that health authorities had taken steps to alert hospital workers,\nambulance services, and public health units across the provinces that there\nwere 4 cases of atypical pneumonia within a single family in Toronto that\nhad resulted in 2 deaths. At 02h00 Geneva time on the following day, 15 Mar\n2003, the government of Singapore notified WHO, by urgent\ntelecommunication, of a similar illness in a 32-year-old physician who had\ntreated hospital workers with a severe respiratory syndrome in Singapore,\nincluding one from the French Hanoi hospital who had self-evacuated to\nSingapore. This Singapore physician had travelled to the United States for\na medical conference, and at the end of the conference boarded a return\nflight to Singapore in New York. Before departure he had indicated to a\ncolleague in Singapore by telephone that he had symptoms similar to the\npatients he had treated in Singapore. The colleague notified health\nauthorities. WHO identified the airline and flight, and the physician and\nhis accompanying family members were removed from the flight at a stopover\nin Frankfurt, Germany, where he was immediately isolated and placed under\nhospital care, as were his 2 accompanying family members when they\ndeveloped fever and respiratory symptoms several days later. As a result of\nthis prompt action, Germany experienced no further spread linked to the 3\nimported cases.\nLater in the morning of 15 Mar 2003, with this background and chronology of\nevents, a decision was made by WHO to increase the level of the global\nalert issued on 12 Mar 2003. The decision was based on 5 different but\nrelated factors. First, the etiology, and therefore the potential for\ncontinued spread, of this new disease were not yet known. Second, the\noutbreaks appeared to pose a great risk to health workers who managed\npatients, and to the family members and other close contacts of patients.\nThird, many different antibiotics and antivirals had been tried empirically\nand did not seem to have an effect. Fourth, though the numbers were\ninitially small, a significant percentage of patients (25 of 26 hospital\nstaff in Hanoi, and 24 of 39 hospital staff in Hong Kong) had rapidly\nprogressed to respiratory failure, requiring intensive care and causing\nsome deaths in previously healthy persons. Finally, the disease had moved\nout of its initial focus in Asia and appeared to have spread to North\nAmerica and Europe.\nAt this time, the epidemiology of SARS was poorly understood. A virulent\nstrain of influenza had not been ruled out as a possible cause, even though\ntransmission patterns were not characteristic for influenza. There was also\nsome hope that the new disease, like many other new diseases of the recent\npast, would fail to maintain efficient person-to-person transmission, or\nthat it might attenuate with passage and eventually self-contain. Despite\nthe lack of understanding about the disease, its cause, and future\nevolution, the need was great to introduce a series of emergency measures\nto contain SARS outbreaks in the affected areas and prevent further\ninternational spread, thus reducing opportunities for the new disease to\nestablish endemicity. WHO thus decided, on 15 Mar 2003, to issue a rare\nemergency travel advisory as a global alert to international travellers,\nhealth care professionals, and health authorities.\nThe global alert called for increased attention to patients with atypical\npneumonia who fit the following case definition:\n- High fever (greater than 38 C)\n- One or more respiratory symptoms including cough, shortness of breath,\ndifficulty breathing\nAND\nOne or more of the following:\n- Close contact with a person who has been diagnosed with SARS\n- Recent history of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS.\nAt the same time the global alert recommended no change in patterns of\ninternational travel, but that passengers notify their health authority if\nthey should develop signs and symptoms as described above and have a\nhistory of travel to areas reporting cases of SARS. Following this alert,\nawareness increased immediately, and many potential new outbreaks were\nprevented by the prompt isolation and strict management of suspected cases.\nBy 27 Mar 2003, however, it was evident that international spread of SARS\nhad continued after the 15 Mar 2003 advisory at 2 of the earliest outbreak\nsites, namely Viet Nam and Hong Kong, and that persons on the same\naeroplanes as persons with symptoms consistent with SARS, and sitting in\nclose proximity to them, had developed signs and symptoms compatible with\nSARS. On this date it was decided to recommend new measures related to\ninternational travel, still with the intent of preventing the international\nspread of the infectious agent. These recommendations were that\nSARS-affected areas, where transmission was known to be occurring in chains\nof human-to-human transmission, institute measures to identify\ninternational passengers who had signs, symptoms and history compatible\nwith SARS, and to recommend that such persons postpone international travel\nand seek medical advice. These recommendations were instituted in most of\nthe affected areas shortly after 27 Mar 2003.\nHowever, concern continued to mount. An urgent investigation of the Amoy\nGardens outbreak in Hong Kong began on 29 Mar 2003, and the following day,\nhealth officials announced that 213 Amoy residents were probable cases of\nSARS. This followed an unusual cluster of cases, closely linked in time and\nplace, among guests and visitors who had stayed on the same floor of a\nhotel located in the same district (Kowloon) as Amoy Gardens. By this same\ndate, 9 business travellers and tourists had returned to Singapore, Beijing\nand Taiwan from Hong Kong, either sick or in the incubation period of SARS.\nOutbreaks in the hotel and housing estate indicated that SARS was showing\nan unusual pattern of transmission in Hong Kong, probably involving an\nenvironmental component, that would place persons at risk outside the\nconfined health care settings associated with outbreaks in most other\ncountries. The 9 cases of probable SARS that occurred in Singapore,\nBeijing, and Taiwan, and that were associated with travel in Hong Kong,\nindicated that the risk of international spread was continuing.\nConsultations were made with WHO teams and travel experts. On 2 Apr 2003 a\nrecommendation for voluntary postponement of all but essential travel was\nissued for travellers considering travel to Hong Kong. At the same time,\nbecause the WHO team and government of China had confirmed that the 4-month\nlong outbreak in Guangdong continued, and that cases fit the case\ndefinition being applied in Viet Nam and Hong Kong; and because\ntransmission patterns in Guangdong were not yet available, these same\nrecommendations were made for Guangdong as maximum security against spread\nof SARS outside of Guangdong in the absence of complete understanding of\ntransmission patterns of the outbreak there.\nCases of possible transmission in aeroplanes continue to be reported and\ninvestigated. As recently as 5 Apr 2003, notification of a SARS patient\ntravelling internationally by sea from Hong Kong to Vladivostak (Russian\nFederation) was received, opening a possible second route of international\ntravel for the virus.\nWHO travel recommendations are kept under constant review and will be\namended as more data about the evolution of SARS become available.\nLessons: the value of innovation and international collaboration\nThe knowledge obtained in the 3-week period since 15 Mar 2003 has been\nremarkable. It demonstrates the value of international cooperation on\nemerging infections and the importance of early detection and rapid\nintroduction of emergency measures to prevent further international spread\nand help ensure that imported cases are not allowed to cause disease in others.\nWhen WHO began to set up emergency plans on 15 Mar 2003, identification of\nthe SARS causative agent and the development of a diagnostic test were\ngiven paramount importance in the overall containment strategy. Detection\nof the disease in its early stage, confirmation of cases, understanding\nmodes of transmission, development of protocols for targeted treatment,\nvaccine research and development, and implementation of disease-specific\npreventive measures would all depend upon swift progress and results in\netiological and diagnostic research. Sound public health measures would\nalso require understanding of the presence and concentration of the\npathogen in different tissues and secretions, and patterns of excretion\nthroughout the course of illness and convalescence. So long as the\netiological agent remained unknown, specialists in infectious disease\ncontrol would be forced to resort to control tools dating back to the\n'Middle Ages' of microbiology: isolation and quarantine.\nOn 17 Mar 2003, a network of 11 leading laboratories around the world was\nset up as a mechanism for expediting identification of the SARS causative\nagent. Laboratories were selected on the basis of 3 criteria: outstanding\nscientific expertise, facilities at biosafety level III, and capacity to\ncontribute to the battery of tests and experiments that would be needed to\nfulfill Koch's 4 postulates for the identification of an infectious agent\nas the cause of a specific disease. The network was set up on the model of\nthe influenza network and provides another important lesson: models and\nsystems set up for one health emergency can be rapidly adapted to serve others.\nCollaboration is virtual. Members of the network confer in daily\nteleconferences coordinated by WHO and use a secure web site to post\nelectron microscopic pictures of candidate viruses, sequences of genetic\nmaterial for virus identification and characterization, descriptions of\nexperiments, and results. The well-guarded secret techniques that give each\nlaboratory its competitive edge have been immediately and openly shared\nwith others. Laboratories also quickly exchange various samples from\npatients and postmortem tissues. These arrangements have allowed the\nanalysis of samples from the same patient simultaneously in several\nlaboratories specialized in different approaches, with the results shared\nin real time. This collaboration has resulted in the identification of the\nsuspected causative agent, and the development of 3 diagnostic tests, with\nunprecedented speed.\nVirus isolation continues from patients with SARS, and at the same time\nvirus has been isolated from tears and faeces. Publications on these\nvarious findings are being prepared by members of this collaborating group,\nbut the need remains for a highly sensitive and specific PCR test to\ndiagnose acute infections.\nA similar collaborative group on epidemiology, made up of investigators\nfrom all sites with local transmission of SARS, continues to confirm\nperson-to-person transmission as the major route of transmission. Today,\nthe group exchanged information about the Hong Kong investigations to\nidentify a possible environmental source, which might prove useful in\nunderstanding the unusual new cluster of cases in Singapore. Key questions\ninclude the exact points during the course of incubation and infection when\ntransmission occurs and whether asymptotic cases are also capable of\nspreading SARS. These questions must be answered to better evaluate the\nextent of spread of SARS, and the success of containment activities.\nA third clinical group, which unites 80 clinicians from 13 countries having\nSARS cases, has consistently provided anecdotal information about the lack\nof efficacy of treatment with specific antibiotics and antivirals, and has\nbegun to develop systematic clinical trials of Ribaviran at 2 sites. Their\ndiscussions have shed light on features of the disease at presentation,\ntreatment and progression of the disease, prognostic indicators, and\ndischarge criteria. No therapy has been shown to demonstrate any particular\neffectiveness. The clinicians agreed that a subset of SARS patients,\nperhaps 10 percent, decline, usually around day 7, and need mechanical\nassistance to breathe. The care of these people is often complicated by the\npresence of other diseases. In this group, mortality is high. Age over 40\nyears also appears to be associated with a more severe form of disease.\nCountries have made travel recommendations for their citizens, using the\nguidance provided by WHO and other considerations such as feasibility of\nmedical evacuation of their citizens and their insurance coverage should\nthey become infected.\nOn 28 Mar 2003, at the end of the second week of the global response,\nChina, an initially reluctant partner in the global alert and response at\nthe start, became a full partner in the 3 working groups that were studying\nSARS, and concluded that the outbreaks of SARS elsewhere in Asia were\nrelated to the outbreak in Guangdong Province. The Chinese government has\nannounced that SARS is being given top priority. A system of alert and\nresponse for all emerging and epidemic-prone diseases is being developed.\nDaily electronic reporting of new cases and deaths, by province, has begun.\nEqually important, health officials have begun daily televised press\nconferences, thus taking the important step of increasing the awareness of\nthe population and hospital staff of the characteristic symptoms, the need\nto seek prompt medical attention, and the need to manage patients according\nto the principles of isolation and strict infection control.\nThe next weeks and months will tell whether the global alert and response\nwill contain the current SARS outbreaks, preventing SARS from becoming yet\nanother endemic infectious disease in human populations, or whether SARS\nwill remain confined to its origins in nature, to re-emerge at yet another\ntime and place. It is clear that the responsibility for containing the\nemergence of any new infectious disease showing international spread lies\non all countries. In a world where all national borders are porous when\nconfronted by a microbial threat, it is in the interest of all populations\nfor countries to share the information they may have as soon as it is\navailable. In so doing, they will allow both near and distant countries --\nall neighbours in our globalized world -- to benefit from the understanding\nthey have gained.\nby David L. Heymann\nExecutive Director, Communicable Diseases, WHO\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is an excellent 'historical' overview of the sequence of events over\nthe past month since the recognition of this outbreak as a major global\nconcern. A major\noutbreak Outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome in Hong Kong. This\narticle reviews the clinical course of 138 patients with SARS seen in Hong\nKong, along with clinical, laboratory, and radiographic information on\nthese cases. <http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030685v1.pdf>\nThere is a discussion and analysis on risk factors for mortality. 'In a\nmultivariate analysis, the independent predictors of an adverse outcome\nwere advanced age (odds ratio per decade of life, 1.80; 95 percent\nconfidence interval, 1.16 to 2.81; P=0.009), a high peak lactate\ndehydrogenase level (odds ratio per 100 U per liter, 2.09; 95 percent\nconfidence interval, 1.28 to 3.42; P=0.003), and a high absolute neutrophil\ncount on presentation (odds ratio, 1.60; 95 percent confidence interval,\n1.03 to 2.50; P=0.04).'\nIn addition, there was a presentation of the new treatment protocol\nreferred to in the daily Hong Kong Department of Health\nupdates. 'Oseltamivir (Tamiflu) was also given initially to treat possible\ninfluenza infection. If fever persisted for more than 48 hours and the\nblood count showed leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, or both, oral ribavirin\n(1.2 g, 3 times a day) and corticosteroid therapy prednisolone (1 mg per\nkilogram of body weight per day) was given as a combined regimen. Patients\nwith persistent fever and worsening lung opacities were given intravenous\nribavirin (400 mg every 8 hours) and corticosteroid therapy (an additional\n2 to 3 pulses of 0.5 g of methylprednisolone daily). Patients in whom\nhypoxemia developed were given oxygen through a nasal cannula. Patients\nwere admitted to the ICU if respiratory failure developed, as evidenced by\nan arterial oxygen saturation of less than 90 percent while the patient was\nreceiving 50 percent supplemental oxygen, a respiratory rate that exceeded\n35 breaths per minute, or both.' In the discussion section of the paper\nthey mention: '...the similarity of this radiographic picture to that of\nbronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia and the similarity of the\nhistologic features to those of early ARDS in postmortem studies have\nprompted us to use corticosteroid in combination with ribavirin for the\ntreatment of SARS. In ARDS and particularly in bronchiolitis obliterans\norganizing pneumonia, corticosteroid therapy has been used with some\nsuccess. The majority of our cohort appeared to have a response to\ncorticosteroid therapy, in addition to ribavirin, with resolution of fever\nand lung opacities within 2 weeks.'. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 9 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 9 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=6000>\n\nUpdate on SARS 9 Apr 2003\nAs of 9 Apr 2003, 75 SARS patients have been discharged. 42 SARS patients\nremain hospitalised.\nThere were 8 additional SARS cases reported today, 7 of whom are linked to\nthe SGH cluster comprising 5 SGH staff, 1 inpatient and 1 visitor. They include 9 healthcare\nworkers and 11 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 22 were new\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 116 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 9 were discharged today.\nMost of the patients currently in hospital are showing positive responses\nto the new treatment protocol. 108 patients are receiving treatment in\nintensive care unit.\n2 female patients, aged 71 and 68, died in Princess Margaret Hospital and\nPrince of Wales Hospital respectively today, bring to 22 the total number\nof deaths relating to atypical pneumonia.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nNature Cumulative Number\n(The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)\nTotal No. Patients/No. Discharged Patients/ No. Deaths *\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 201 (201)/\n60/ 22\nPatients, family members & visitors 641 (641)/ 56/\nTotal 842 (842)/ 116/\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively\nlate stage of infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 6 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 6 Apr 2003\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5940>\nUpdate on SARS - 6 Apr 2003\nAs of 6 April 2003, 72 SARS patients have been discharged. 28 SARS patients\nremain hospitalised.\nThere were 3 additional SARS cases reported today. 2 are hospital staff; an\nSGH doctor from Ward 57/58 and a TTSH nurse. We are still investigating the\nsource of infection for the TTSH case. The remaining new case is a man who\nhad visited his mother when she was admitted to TTSH from mid January 2003\ntill the end of March 2003. It is believed that he had come into contact\nwith a SARS patient, who had not yet been recognised as a SARS patient then.\nUpdate of cluster of 23 hospital staff from SGH\n--------------------------------------\nA total of 23 hospital staff from SGH Wards 57 and 58 have been admitted to\nTTSH. Some of the suspect cases have been downgraded to observation status.\nOf the 23 staff, 1 is a probable case, 6 are admitted for observation and\n16 are suspect cases. They are all stable.\nAs an assurance, visitors who went to Wards 57 and 58 at SGH from 20 Mar\n2003 to 5 Apr 2003 may call SGH hotline at 6321-3591 between 8.00 AM and\n10.00 PM for free health checks to ensure their well-being. Investigations\nare on-going to determine the source of infection for these hospital staff.\nCautionary Measures at SGH\n-----------------------\nTo ring-fence the source of infection and to ensure continuity of care to\ntheir patients, SGH is transferring all patients from Wards 57 and 58 to\nTTSH. All patients who were formerly in Wards 57 and 58 during the period\nfrom 20 March 2003 till 5 April 2003 and who are currently still in SGH\nwill also be transferred to TTSH. Nurses, doctors, therapists and other\nstaff working in these 2 wards will also be transferred to TTSH to care for\ntheir patients. The transfer, involving 80 patients and 91 staff will be\ncompleted tomorrow. SGH is also contacting discharged patients who were\nformerly in Wards 57 and 58 during the period from 20 March 2003 till 5\nApril 2003, as well as visitors to these wards during this period, to\nensure their well being.\nKKH\n----\nThe midwife from KKH who had SARS has recovered and been discharged. All\ndoctors and nurses in KKH who had contact with the midwife are also well.\nKKH will be reopening it's Clinic A on 7 Apr 2003 as more than 10 days\nwould have passed since the midwife last worked there on 27 Mar 2003.\nSummary of SARS cases\n---------------------\nTo date, the total number of people diagnosed with SARS is 106. Among these\nare 3 children below 18 years of age. Out of the 28 patients still\nhospitalised, 13 are in intensive care. This includes the 20-year-old Ngee\nAnn Polytechnic student and the mother of the SARS patient who was\ntransferred from NUH yesterday. Since yesterday, one patient was discharged\nfrom ICU.\nApart from the first imported case, the 6 other imported cases have not\ngiven rise to any SARS cases.\nThe number of suspect cases admitted is 61, including 3 children (below 18\nyears old). The number of people under Home Quarantine Orders is 164.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 6 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada 6 Apr 2003\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/sars/update22.html>\n\nApril 6, 2003 4:00 pm\nAdvisory\nUpdate 22 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 6 Apr 2003 4:00 PM\nLatest Canadian Numbers on SARS\n---------------------------\nAs of 6 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 217 probable or\nsuspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Canada. There\nhave been 9 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons\nwho have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household\nor in a health-care setting. The information contained in this update is\nbased on the best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 87 probable and 92 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 3 probable and 23 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM. EDST, 6 Apr 2003.\n[This represents a total of 90 probable cases and 127 suspected cases\nreported from Canada. - Mod.MPP]\nHealth Canada Support for Ontario\n----------------------------\nAt the request of Ontario, Health Canada shipped 10 000 masks to Toronto as\na stop-gap measure until the province receives additional masks from its\nsupplier. These masks are part of Health Canda's national emergency\nstockpile (National Emergency Stockpile System). Health Canada is also\nassisting in identifying sources for masks in Canada and off-shore.\nHealth Canada has deployed an additional 8 personnel to Ontario to work\nwith the Ontario team. This is in addition to the 6 staff Health Canada has\ndeployed to assist Toronto's public health unit and the Ontario Ministry of\nHealth with the investigation of the SARS cases. The department has also\nprovided guidelines for infection control and recommendations on actions\nfor public health settings.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 6 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Newswire briefs\nChina - from Yahoo News 6 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story2&cid=570&ncid=753&e=2&u=/nm/200\n30406/sc_nm/health_sars_china_dc>\nChina says SARS deaths at 51, infections at 1247 as of 5 Apr 2003, health\nofficials said on Sunday. As stated in previous postings,\nour rationale for not posting suspected cases based on rumors, either\npersonal or from the lay press, is that influenza-like illness (fever and\nrespiratory symptoms) is a rather common clinical syndrome, and pneumonia\nfrom other etiologies, bronchitis and other acute pulmonary diseases are\nalso far more common than SARS. Given the present situation, in many\ninstances, anyone with a respiratory illness is jumped upon as suspected\nSARS, especially if they are in East Asia or have travelled there.\nYes, ministries and departments of health do need to investigate all\nsuspected cases so that cases of SARS will not be missed, and health care\nprofessionals should be using infection control procedures when evaluating\nrespiratory illnesses to prevent further transmission of SARS, should that\nbe the final diagnosis on a patient presenting with compatible symptoms. WORLDWIDE (40):CASES\n*****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Hong Kong -
