Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\n[A] Situation report on atypical pneumonia 10 Apr 2003\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nAs of 1 PM 10 Apr 2003, an additional 28 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals. They include 12 healthcare\nworkers (9 from Princess Margaret Hospital, one from Prince of Wales\nHospital, one from Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole Hospital, and one from\nQueen Elizabeth Hospital) and 1 patient from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 15\nwere new patients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\n\nA total of 154 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 12 were discharged today.\nMost of the patients currently in hospital are showing positive responses\nto the new treatment protocol. 120 patients are receiving treatment in\nintensive care units.\n\n3 patients died in Princess Margaret Hospital, bringing to 30 the total\nnumber of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia. A 63-year-old male with a\nhistory of chronic disease and a 46-year-old female died yesterday. Another\n73-year-old female patient with a history of chronic disease died this morning.\n\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n\nCumulative no. cases/ total no. discharged patients/ total no. deaths\n(The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)\n\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 253 (253)/\n75/ 30\nPatients, family members & visitors 745 (745)/ 79/\n\nTotal: 998 (998)/ 154/\n\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of chronic\ndiseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively late stage\nof infection.\n\n[B] Health Surveillance for airline passengers 10 Apr 2003\n\nA spokesman for the Department of Health (DH) on 10 Apr 2003 called on\npassengers who had taken any of the following 7 flights of Lufthansa German\nAirlines between 30 Mar 2003 and 5 Apr 2003 to call DH's hotline 187 222\nfor health advice. The plea follows the detection of a confirmed case of\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) involving a 48-year-old man who\nhad taken these flights during the period.\n\nThe 7 flights are :\n\nLH 731 on 30 Mar 2003 (Hong Kong to Munich)\nLH 4316 on 31 Mar 2003 (Munich to Barcelona)\nLH 4303 on 2 Apr 2003 (Barcelona to Frankfurt)\nLH 4520 on 2 Apr 2003 (Frankfurt to London)\nLH 4671 on 3 Apr 2003 (London to Munich)\nLH 265 on 4 Apr 2003 (Munich to Frankfurt)\nLH 738 on 4 Apr 2003 (Frankfurt to Hong Kong)\n\nInitial investigation revealed that the man had developed symptoms after he\narrived at Barcelona on 31 Mar 2003. He was admitted to Pamela Youde\nNethersole Eastern Hospital on 8 Apr 2003 and confirmed to have SARS today.\n\nDH has informed the Airport Authority and the airline concerned. Advice was\nalso given to the airline concerned to disinfect the airplane. DH is\ntracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these 7 flights for\nsurveillance purpose. The spokesman reminded people who have respiratory\nsymptoms including fever, chills, malaise and cough to avoid traveling by\nplane before recovery.\n\n[C] Health surveillance for airline passengers 9 Apr 2003\n\nA spokesman for the Department of Health (DH) on 9 Apr 2003 called on\npassengers who had traveled from Hong Kong to Taipei in flight CX 402\n(Cathay Pacific) on 30 Mar 2003 to call DH's hotline 187 2222 for health\nadvice.\n\nThe plea follows the detection of a confirmed case of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome involved a man living in Taiwan. Investigation\nrevealed that the man developed SARS symptoms before taking the flight. He\nwas admitted to a Taipei hospital on 1 Apr 2003. DH has informed the\nAirport Authority and the airline concerned. Advice was also given to the\nairline concerned to disinfect the airplane. DH is tracing the crew members\nand passengers who had taken this flight for surveillance purpose.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 10 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 11 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=6040>\n\n\nSARS update - 10 Apr 2003\n\nAs of 10 Apr 2003, 77 SARS patients have been discharged. 47 SARS patients\nremain hospitalised.\n\nThere were 7 additional SARS cases reported today, 5 of whom are linked to\nthe SGH cluster comprising 1 SGH staff member, 2 inpatients, and 2\nvisitors. The other 2 additional cases are a TTSH nurse who was in contact\nwith a SARS patient before the patient was diagnosed to be a SARS case and\na family member of a SARS patient. This family member is the husband of the\nwoman who broke quarantine and was transferred from NUH to TTSH on 5 Apr\n2003. She is in intensive care.\n\nSGH Ward 57 and 58 cluster\nOn 5 Apr 2003, SGH noted that a total of 21 staff from Wards 57 and 58 had\ndeveloped fever since the 1 Apr 2003; one on 1 and 2 Apr 2003, 2 on 3 Apr\n2003, 9 on 4 Apr 2003, and 8 on 5 Apr 2003. SGH sent the affected staff to\nTTSH and, while waiting for the medical assessment of the cases, stood down\nthat surgical team.\n\nOn 6 Apr 2003, as a precautionary measure and in order to ring-fence the\nsource of infection, SGH transferred all patients from Wards 57 and 58 to\nTTSH. All patients who were formerly in Wards 57 and 58 during the period\nfrom 20 Mar 2003 till 5 Apr 2003 and who were still in SGH were also\ntransferred to TTSH. Nurses, doctors, therapists, and other staff working\nin these 2 wards were also transferred to TTSH. The transfer, involving 80\npatients and 91 staff, was completed on 7 Apr 2003. SGH also contacting\ndischarged patients who were formerly in Wards 57 and 58 during the period\nfrom 20 Mar 2003 through 5 Apr 2003, as well as visitors to these wards\nduring this period, to ensure their well-being.\n\nSo far, 52 persons have been linked to the SGH cluster at Wards 57 and 58,\ncomprising 19 probable and 33 suspect SARS cases. They comprise 26 SGH\nstaff, 14 visitors, and 12 inpatients. In addition, 2 SGH staff and 4\ninpatients were admitted for observation. All 19 are stable except for 2\nwho are in serious condition in intensive care.\n\nEpidemiological investigations have traced the source of this cluster of\ninfections to a Chinese man in his 60s who had been admitted to TTSH from 5\nto 20 Mar 2003 for chronic kidney disease and diabetes. He was admitted to\nSGH Ward 57 Intermediate Care Area on 24 Mar 2003 for gastrointestinal\nbleeding. He had a diabetic foot ulcer and was noted to have a low-grade\nfever since admission. A chest X-ray on 24 Mar 2003 was clear. He was\ntreated for his medical conditions and was started on antibiotics.\n\nOn 28 Mar 2003, he developed high fever. A repeat chest X-ray on that day\nwas normal. He was treated with antibiotics and on 29 Mar 2003, he was\ntransferred to Ward 58 B2. Tests showed that he had an infection of the\nblood by _E.coli_. Chest X-ray on 30 Mar 2003 was again normal. He was\ngiven a stronger antibiotic and on 3 Apr 2003, he no longer had fever.\nHowever, his chest x-ray on 4 Apr 2003 showed signs of pneumonia and he has\nbeen diagnosed as a SARS case by the doctors in TTSH.\n\nAlthough the clinical picture of this patient is not typical of SARS, it is\nlikely that the typical symptoms of SARS were masked by his other\nunderlying medical conditions. It is believed that he had come in contact\nwith a SARS patient who had not yet been diagnosed during the time that he\nwas admitted to TTSH.\n\nThe 19 persons with probable SARS in the SGH cluster, comprising 1 doctor,\n9 nurses, 1 radiographer, 1 housekeeper, 4 inpatients and 3 visitors, are\nall linked to Wards 57 and 58. The hospital staff attended to the Chinese\nman when he was in Wards 57 and 58. One visitor was his brother who visited\nhim while he was in SGH.\n\nApart from ring fencing the staff and inpatients from Ward 57 and 58 at\nTTSH, to prevent further spread of infection, SGH has implemented mandatory\ntwice daily temperature checks for all staff, the use of N95 masks by all\ntheir staff, and limiting visitors to 2 per patient. SGH has also\nreorganised their teams of doctors to only work in specified locations.\nThis will help localise patient-doctor interactions to specific physical\nsites and will facilitate future epidemiological investigations, if necessary.\n\nOrange Valley Nursing Home cluster\nIt was reported that a nurse from Orange Valley Nursing Home was admitted\nto CGH on 4 Apr 2003 for pneumonia and transferred to TTSH on 6 Apr 2003\nfor probable SARS. He has been in intensive care since transfer to TTSH.\n\nInvestigations have revealed that a resident of the nursing home was\nadmitted to CGH on 25 Mar 2003 and died of pneumonia on 30 Mar 2003. This\nnursing home resident had been earlier discharged from TTSH on 23 Mar 2003\nfor non-SARS related condition. When the patient was in TTSH she was warded\nnext to a patient who was later diagnosed as a SARS case. The male nurse\nfrom the nursing home had been attending to this resident. The\ndaughter-in-law of this nursing home resident, a mediaCorp staff member,\nwas admitted to TTSH on 7 Apr 2003 for SARS. She is in serious condition in\nintensive care. A friend of hers who was in contact with her when she was\nunwell has also been admitted to TTSH on 8 Apr 2003. She is in stable\ncondition.\n\nThe girlfriend of the nurse from Orange Valley Nursing Home and the teenage\nson of the MediaCorp staff member, who is a student of Zhonghua Secondary\nSchool, have been admitted as suspect SARS cases. Although it is believed\nthat the resident of Orange Valley Nursing Home was the source of\ninfection, investigations are still ongoing to exclude other sources.\n\nTTSH Rehab Dept at Ang Mo Kio Community Hospital\nAt this point, investigations suggest that the source of infection for the\nTTSH occupational therapist might have been the SARS patient who presented\nat the NUH Emergency Department on 23 Mar 2003.\n\nImplications of the SGH cluster of infections\nTo reduce the spread of SARS, Singapore has adopted an isolate-and-contain\nstrategy, involving comprehensive and practical measures, and at times\nstronger than what is being done in other affected countries. One key\nthrust is to identify symptomatic cases as early as possible so that they\ncan receive treatment and are isolated early. As a precautionary measure,\nclose contacts of SARS patients are ring-fenced through home quarantine.\nThough contact tracing is not 100 percent foolproof, it helps to\nsignificantly reduce any further transmission of SARS, especially to the\ncommunity at large.\n\nThe isolate and contain approach is also adapted for schools. When a case\nis discovered in school or institute of higher learning, it will be shut\ndown for 3 days. This will facilitate active contract tracing, and\nepidemiological investigations, while reducing the risk of exposure of\nstudents to SARS.\n\nFor healthcare facilities, Tan Tock Seng Hospital Hospital/Communicable\nDisease Centre (TTSH/CDC) is the only hospital designated to screen and\ntreat both adults and children with or suspected to have SARS. These\npatients are treated in isolation rooms under strict infection control\nprocedures. They are not allowed visitors. SARS is a very new disease, and\nwe are learning that it can present in atypical ways, particularly in\npatients with other types of medical conditions. These medical conditions\nmask the typical features of SARS and make it very difficult for the\ndiagnosis to be made early. This is illustrated by the case in SGH.\n\nIn view of this, MOH has this week further enhanced its infection control\nrequirements in all hospitals. The types of cases that hospitals need to\nidentify early and isolate has been broadened to include all cases of\natypical pneumonia and fever without a known cause, as well as healthcare\nworkers who present with fever and/or respiratory symptoms of undetermined\ncause. All hospitals are required to ensure that the temperatures of all\nits healthcare workers are checked at least twice daily, with the first\ncheck being done before the staff start work.\n\nFebrile staff should not be allowed to work. The number of visitors to\nhospitals is also being limited and their details should be noted, to\nfacilitate contact tracing should the need arise. This is on top of the\nprocedures which MOH has already established with Accident and Emergency\nDepartments in all hospitals, on how to handle patients who are unwell and\nsuspected to have SARS. Staff are required to adopt full infection control\nprecautions and if they come across any such patients, they are instructed\nto transfer them to TTSH for further examination. A system of protected\ntriage staff in SOCs and polyclinics has also been established.\n\nOur isolate-and-contain strategy seems to be holding up. SARS cases are\nreferred to TTSH as soon as they are detected in other hospitals. This will\nhelp contain the spread and chance of outbreak in other hospitals and\nreduce the risk of spread into the community. In SGH, patients in the\naffected wards were transferred to TTSH for treatment. We should expect\nthat from time to time, clusters of infections may occur in our hospitals\nmainly from atypical cases that later turn out to be SARS. The public\nshould be reassured that there is a robust system in place to minimise and\nrespond quickly to such situations.\n\nDisposal of bio-hazardous wastes\nSince 1988, our hospitals have put in place a system to ensure that all\nbio-hazardous medical wastes (including masks, gloves, needles, etc.) are\nsegregated from general waste and safely disposed of. Bio-hazardous wastes\ncan only be collected by specially licensed waste collectors (only 3 of\nthem in Singapore), transported in dedicated vehicles, and brought to\nspecially designed and dedicated incinerators for disposal. Our procedures\nfor handling bio-hazardous medical wastes are in accordance with WHO\nguidelines.\n\nIn Singapore, all wastewater is discharged into a closed sewerage system.\nThe wastewater is conveyed through deep underground pipes to wastewater\ntreatment plants for treatment. At the plants, our workers too do not come\ninto contact with the sewage. As a precaution, our workers are provided\nwith protective gear and gloves etc. when they carry out maintenance work.\nThese underground sewers keep all wastewater out of contact with the public\nthus ensuring public health safety.\n\nHome Quarantine\nFrom today, MOH is engaging the services of CISCO to serve Home Quarantine\nOrders and ensure that contacts of probable SARS cases comply with the\norders. The measure follows a limited number of incidents in which the home\nquarantine order was flouted. In one such incident, the contact who\neventually became a SARS case went down to see her General Practitioner on\n3 Apr 2003 and did not disclose that she was under home quarantine. When\nher condition did not improve, her relative also broke quarantine and\nferried her in his car to NUH instead of using the available ambulance\nservice to TTSH. This irresponsible behaviour presents not just a risk to\nthe public but can also cause other hospitals to become contaminated with SARS.\n\nThe CISCO officers who serve the Order will site an electronic picture\n(EPIC) camera at the home of each contact. The contacts will be called at\nrandom intervals daily and requested to turn on the camera and present\nthemselves in front of the camera to show their presence. Anyone found\nbreaking the quarantine will be served a written warning and given an\nelectronic wrist tag. The tag is linked to a dedicated telephone line and\nwill alert the authorities if the person leaves the house again or tries to\nbreak the tag. Under section 65 of the Infectious Diseases Act, persons\nfound guilty of an offence shall be liable on conviction to a fine not\nexceeding $5000 and in the case of a second or subsequent offence, liable\nto a fine not exceeding $10 000 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding\n6 months or to both.\n\nToday, 53 passengers from affected areas required further screening by the\nnurses at the airport. None were referred to TTSH for further assessment.\n\nSummary of SARS cases\nTo date, the total number of people diagnosed with SARS is 133. Among these\nare 3 children below 18 years of age. Out of the 47 patients still\nhospitalised, 13 are in intensive care. The Ngee Ann Polytechnic student\nwas discharged from intensive care yesterday. There were no new admissions\nto intensive care.\n\nThe number of suspect cases admitted is 82, including 5 children (below 18\nyears old). worldwide (34): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203601", "date": "2003-04-08 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (34): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Summary of Lancet paper by Peiris et al.\n[2] Commentary on Peiris et al. paper\n[3] WHO: Status of Current Diagnostic Tests\n[4] Link to EMs of SARS-associated Coronavirus\n******\n[1] Date: Tue 8 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Lancet, Sat 5 Apr 2003,Volume 361, Number 9364; published\nonline Tue 8 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journal/journal.isa>\n\nCoronavirus as a Possible Cause of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n--------------------------------------------------------------------\nBy: J S M Peiris, S T Lai, L L M Poon, Y Guan, L Y C Yam, W Lim, J\nNicholls, W K S Yee, W W Yan, M T Cheung, V C C Cheng, K H Chan, D N C\nTsang, R W H Yung, T K Ng, K Y Yuen, and members of the SARS study group.\nBackground: An outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) has\nbeen reported in Hong Kong. We investigated the viral cause and clinical\npresentation among 50 patients.\nMethods: We analysed case notes and microbiological findings for 50\npatients with SARS, representing more than 5 separate epidemiologically\nlinked transmission clusters. We defined the clinical presentation and risk\nfactors associated with severe disease and investigated the causal agents\nby chest radiography and laboratory testing of nasopharyngeal aspirates and\nsera samples. We compared the laboratory findings with those submitted for\nmicrobiological investigation of other diseases from patients whose\nidentity was masked.\nResults: Patients' age ranged from 23 to 74 years. Fever, chills, myalgia,\nand cough were the most frequent complaints. When compared with chest\nradiographic changes, respiratory symptoms and auscultatory findings were\ndisproportionately mild. Patients who were household contacts of other\ninfected people and had older age, lymphopenia, and liver dysfunction were\nassociated with severe disease. A virus belonging to the family\n_Coronaviridae_ was isolated from 2 patients. By use of serological and\nreverse-transcriptase PCR specific for this virus, 45 of 50 patients with\nSARS, but no controls, had evidence of infection with this virus.\nInterpretation: A coronavirus was isolated from patients with SARS that\nmight be the primary agent associated with this disease. Serological and\nmolecular tests specific for the virus permitted a definitive laboratory\ndiagnosis to be made and allowed further investigation to define whether\nother cofactors play a part in disease progression.\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: The Lancet, Sat 5 Apr 2003,Volume 361, Number 9364; published\nonline Tue 8 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.thelancet.com/journal/journal.isa>\n\nCommentary: Novel Coronavirus and Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n--------------------------------------------------\n'The terror of the unknown is seldom better displayed than by the response\nof a population to the appearance of an epidemic, particularly when the\nepidemic strikes without apparent cause.' This quote from 1977 by Edward\nKass (1), describing the fears surrounding the newly recognised\nlegionnaires' disease, aptly describes the public response to the recent\nappearance of an unexplained atypical pneumonia referred to as severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS).\nJoseph Peiris and colleagues provide strong evidence that SARS is\nassociated with a novel coronavirus that has not been previously identified\nin human beings or animals, and begin the process of eliminating the many\nunknowns from this new syndrome. The investigators used classic viral\nculture and serological techniques, as well as modern molecular genetic\nmethods, to characterise and to determine the cause of the disease in 50\npatients with SARS in Hong Kong. One of the strengths of their report, and\nan important means of establishing causality, is their analysis of\nspecimens from control patients. None of 40 respiratory secretions from\npatients with other respiratory diseases contained coronavirus RNA, and\nnone of 200 serum samples from blood donors had serum antibody to this new\ncoronavirus. These findings significantly strengthen the tentative\naetiological association reported by other investigators from the Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDCP) in Atlanta and from Toronto, who\nhave also isolated a novel coronavirus from patients with SARS (2,3). As\nother pathogens, such as _Human metapneumovirus_ and _Chlamydia spp_, are\nidentified in SARS patients, it will be important to use control groups to\ndetermine the role of these other agents in causality or as cofactors for\nsevere disease (2,4).\nThe clinical features associated with SARS are rapidly becoming available\nthrough Peiris\u0092 and other reports (2,5). The Hong Kong investigators\nidentified 5 clusters of patients by using a modified WHO case definition\nfor SARS, and describe the clinical manifestations of this serious disease.\nIt is notable that nearly 40 percent of the patients developed respiratory\nfailure that required assisted ventilation. Clinical descriptions will be\nimportant in modifying the case definition of this syndrome should it\nspread -- as is likely -- beyond the tightly linked clusters that have\ncharacterised the epidemiology of SARS thus far. Unfortunately, the early\nclinical appearance may not allow ready distinction from other common\nwinter-time respiratory viral infections (6,7). However, certain\ncharacteristics of SARS are noteworthy. The constellation of absence of\nupper respiratory symptoms, the presence of dry cough, and minimal\nauscultatory findings with consolidation on chest radiographs may alert the\nclinician to the possible diagnosis of SARS. The presence of lymphopenia,\nleucopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes and creatinine\nkinase may also raise suspicion.\nClinical diagnosis will become particularly problematic once the\nassociation with travel or case contact is lost. Thus, rapid and accurate\ndiagnostic tools will be critical in the management of this epidemic. Given\nthe experience with other respiratory viruses, it is likely that culture\nand direct antigen-detection from respiratory secretions will not suffice\nin view of the lethality and contagious nature of this new agent. Rapid\ndiagnosis of SARS, which is important for infection-control measures and\npotential treatment,will require very sensitive and specific methods. Real\ntime RT-PCR, currently in use for other respiratory viruses primarily in\nresearch settings, may be required as a routine test in clinical diagnostic\nmicrobiological laboratories (8,9).\nPeiris and colleagues suggest that early therapy with intravenous ribavirin\nand high-dose glucocorticosteroids may be beneficial. However, the lack of\nuntreated control patients precludes a firm conclusion about benefit.\nClinicians often find it difficult to withhold potentially beneficial, yet\nunproven, therapy in life-threatening situations. Controlled studies may be\ndifficult to do, and there are obviously no historical controls for the\ntreatment of SARS. Therefore it will be important for treating physicians\nto carefully document the dose, timing, and types of therapies used, and\nthe clinical and viral status of patients, so that experiences can be\npooled and information productively analysed.\nIt is truly remarkable and unprecedented that the progress reported by\nPeiris and colleagues, and elsewhere, on the aetiology and clinical and\nepidemiological characteristics of SARS has been achieved in less than 2\nmonths. It is fortuitous that this outbreak occurred at a time when viral\nsurveillance systems headed by WHO in collaboration with CDCP are in place\nthroughout the world. The work of individual laboratories, such as the ones\nin Hong Kong, Toronto, and CDCP, and cooperation between health authorities\nin many countries provides protection from the inevitable threat of new\nepidemic diseases.\nReferences:\n1. Kass EH. Legionnaires\u0092 disease. N Engl J Med 1977; 297: 1229\u00ad30.\n2. Poutanen SM, Low DE, Henry B, et al. Identification of severe\nrespiratory syndrome in Canada. CDC lab analysis suggests\nnew coronavirus may cause SARS. 24 Mar 2003:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/r030324.htm>\n4. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. However, several countries and areas (Canada, France, Germany, Hong\nKong SAR, Japan, the Netherlands, Singapore, United Kingdom, United States\nof America) are beginning to routinely conduct laboratory testing of SARS\nsuspect and probable cases. Tests are still being developed and improved,\nbut using them now helps to understand how SARS and human coronavirus are\nconnected.\nStatus of currently available diagnostic tests\nAntibody tests:\n(1) ELISA (IGM/IGA) detects antibodies in the serum of SARS patients\nreliably as from about day 20 after onset of clinical signs. Antibodies\nalready are detected in some patients between 14-21 days;\n(2) Immunofluorescence Assays (detecting Immunoglobulin M) in SARS\nvirus-infected VERO cells detects antibodies in serum after about day 10 of\nonset of disease. This is a reliable but demanding test requiring amongst\nothers, use of live virus in cell culture and an immunofluorescence microscope.\nMolecular tests:\n(1) PCR can detect genetic material of coronavirus in various specimens\n(blood, stool, or respiratory secretions). For this test, several primers\nhave been developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention,\nUnited States of America, Federal Laboratories for Health Canada, Hong Kong\nUniversity, and the Governmental Viral Unit of Hong Kong, and they have\nbeen shared on the WHO web site. Some laboratories in the WHO multi-centre\ncollaborative network on SARS are currently comparing these tests and first\nresults are will be forthcoming shortly.\nCell culture: Virus in specimens (respiratory secretions, blood) from SARS\npatients can also be detected by infecting cell cultures such as VERO cells.\nInterpretation of positive test results: Indicate that SARS patients are,\nor recently were, infected with the coronavirus. A negative coronavirus\ntest does not mean that the patient does not have SARS.\nInterpretation of negative test results: SARS is diagnosed not on the basis\nof laboratory tests but on clinical evaluation and possible past exposures.\nReasons for negative test results in a patient with SARS may be: (1) Tests\nare incorrect ('false-negative'). Current tests need to be further\ndeveloped to improve sensitivity. (2) Patient is not infected with the new\ncoronavirus. The cause of infection could be another pathogen (virus,\nbacteria, etc.) causing respiratory symptoms, and pneumonia.(3) Specimens\nwere not collected at a time when virus or its genetic material was\nexcreted. Excretions may be for a brief period only, depending on the type\nof specimen tested.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: Tue 8 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO website [edited]\n\nEM Images of SARS-associated Coronavirus\n----------------------------------------\nImages of the new coronavirus can be viewed at the following site:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/coronavirus/en/>\nThese are electron microscopic (EM) images of the new SARS-associated\ncoronavirus attached to the cell surface, prepared by the Department of\nMicrobiology, University of Hong Kong.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] Summary of Lancet paper by Peiris et al.\n As of Tue 8 Apr 2003 - Status of currently available diagnostic tests\n--------------------------------------------------\nSARS diagnosis is still being made on clinical grounds and exposure only\n(Case Definitions for Surveillance of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome -\nSARS). worldwide (31): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203583", "date": "2003-04-05 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (31): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 4 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: OIE press release [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/eng/press/en_last.htm>\n\nAtypical pneumonia: Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)\n------------------------\nA human epidemic of atypical pneumonia called severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS) is currently raging across the globe and particularly in\nSouth-East Asia.\nThe causative agent has not yet been identified. It appears to be a\nParamyxovirus, a Coronavirus, or a mixture. The World Health Organization\n(WHO) has hypothesised that the causative virus(es) may be of animal\norigin, from domestic or wild animals located in Guangdong Province (in\nSouth China).\nThis is why the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) has contacted\nthe Chinese Veterinary Authorities to obtain information on the animal\nhealth situation in China over the past 6 months and, in particular, in\nGuangdong Province.\nThe OIE has also approached its Reference Laboratories and Experts\nspecialising in Paramyxovirus and Coronavirus diseases.\nAs soon as it is available, the OIE, in close collaboration with the WHO,\nwill communicate the scientific information needed to confirm or invalidate\nthe animal origin of SARS and to evaluate, if necessary, the risks incurred\nby the international community.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We look forward to hearing the results of the OIE investigation. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 4 Apr 2003\nFrom: Steve Berger <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\nSARS - Deja vu ?\n----------------\nAs SARS enters its fifth month, a number of questions remain unanswered.\nWhy Asia? Why now? Why young adults? To these I would add a fourth question\n(Why the panic?) and an hypothesis.\nEvery 10 years or so, a pandemic spreads out from China and surrounding\ncountries. The 'Asian flu' of 1957 claimed 98 000 lives worldwide, and the\n'Hong Kong flu' of 1968 an additional 45 000 lives. Although the world\ncommunity was rightly concerned, I do not recall a collapse of air travel,\nimposition of quarantine, or daily front-page headlines. To date, SARS has\nclaimed 79 lives, and the etiological agent appears to be far less\ncontagious than Influenza A virus.\nCurrent evidence suggests that new strains of Influenza A virus evolve as\nrecombinants when they pass between swine and ducks, a process favored by\nclose species proximity on Asian farms. Thus, I was surprised to learn in a\nrecent ProMed-mail posting that coronaviruses also exist in poultry and\nswine, as well as cattle, cats, dogs, and rodents (see: Coronavirus,\nChicken, New - Brazil 20030403.0816). I do not know whether coronaviruses\nare capable of recombination in the manner of influenza viruses, but such a\nmechanism would partially explain the origin of SARS.\n3 years ago, a 'new' human infection was described in the Netherlands. It\nsoon became evident that Human metapneumovirus [HMP] was neither new nor\nexotic, and seems to have affected most humans in every country\ninvestigated, going back decades. The clinical features of this infection\nmimic those of Human respiratory syncytial virus, and infant deaths are not\nuncommon. Indeed, it may well be that more people die of HMP than from SARS\neach year. These facts only became evident when serological tests were\ndeveloped. I suspect that use of serological and other tests for SARS\ndeveloped over the next few weeks will reveal: (1) a high degree of\nsero-positivity in the 'healthy' community of Asia, if not other countries;\nand (2) the existence of an animal (Porcine? Avian?) reservoir.\nDuring the H1N1 pandemic of 1977, there were suggestions that elderly\npersons had a lower rate of complications than would be expected. It was\ntheorized that persons who had survived the prior H1N1 pandemic of 1918 had\nretained partial immunity into old age. If, as noted above, background\nimmunity exists from a SARS outbreak several decades ago, relatively low\ndisease rates among the elderly during the current epidemic would not be\nsurprising. The fact that few children are affected is also not surprising,\nwhen we recall that viral diseases (measles, varicella, poliomyelitis,\nmumps) are often more overt and severe among adults.\n--\nSteve Berger\nTel Aviv Medical Center, Israel\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n[Steve Berger has posed some interesting questions and made some relevant\ncomments. My response is limited to consideration of the genetic\ncharacteristics of coronaviruses. High frequency recombination is a\ncharacteristic property of coronaviruses, and is probably restricted to\nclosely related coronaviruses. An example is Feline infectious peritonitis\nvirus, a coronavirus that exists as 2 serotypes and causes peritonitis,\npneumonia, meningoencephalitis, and other immunopathologic complications in\ncats. Serotype 2 of feline infectious peritonitis virus appears to be a\nrecombinant virus incorporating genetic information from a canine\ncoronavirus, which causes diarrhea in dogs. The serotype 2 virus, in\naddition to causing peritonitis, etc., in cats can -- unlike serotype 1 --\ninfect pups (but does not cause acute disease).\nThat said, it is not necessary to hypothesize origin of the putative\nSARS-associated coronavirus by recombination with an animal or avian\ncoronavirus. There are many coronaviruses in the natural environment that\ncould become pathogenic in humans as a result of progressive mutation, or\nperhaps have existed undetected.\nThe origin of pandemic influenza A viruses by 'recombination' is an\nentirely different process and can occur between dissimilar viruses. The\ngenome of influenza viruses exists as a complement of sub-units which can\nbe interchanged when genetically distinct viruses replicate in a common (or\nintermediate) host, generating progeny with non-parental combinations of\ngenes (and potentially expressing novel combinations of antigens and\ncausing an explosive pandemic). Consequently there could be abundant\nopportunity for exchange of sub-units between human and avian viruses where\nhumans, domesticated mammals, and birds live in close proximity. This is a\ngross oversimplification, of course, but the origin of pandemic strains of\ninfluenza A virus in east Asia in the past should not be used as an\nargument favouring the origin of the SARS agent by recombination between a\nhuman virus and an animal virus.\nAt this stage we simply do not know. Nor is it certain that the coronavirus\n(and/or the human metapneumovirus) present in SARS patients is the\npathogenic agent. As Steve Berger points out, coronaviruses and\npneumoviruses are ubiquitous in the human population. Caution is required\nin advancing hypotheses at this stage until more data become available. -\nMod.CP]\n*****\n[3]\nDate: 5 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC press briefing 4 Apr 2003 [excerpted and edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/transcripts/t030404.htm>\n\nUpdate on the ongoing laboratory investigation:\n--------------------------------------\nCDC is part of an international collaborating network of laboratories led\nby WHO. There are 12 laboratories and 10 companies participating in this\nnetwork.\nEvidence for a previously unrecognized Coronavirus has been found now in\nat least 10 laboratories, including the laboratories here at CDC. The\npreponderance of the evidence continues to mount and continues to favor an\netiologic role or this previously unrecognized Coronavirus in the cause of\nSARS.\nSo far, in looking at specimens from the suspect cases in the United\nStates, we now have evidence of infection with this agent in a total of 4\npeople, and we are working with the state health departments in the states\nwhere these people reside, so that they are provided with the information\nand they, in turn, will provide the clinicians and the patients with the\ninformation.\nWe have cultured this Coronavirus from a total of 4 patients. We have\nelectron microscopic evidence from 2 patients of this virus. We have PCR\n(Polymerase Chain Reaction) results -- , the amplification technique --\nwhere we find evidence of Coronaviral nucleic acid in 11 patients.\nLooking at the antibody tests, of which we have 2 --an IFA\n[immunofluorescent antibody] test and Allose test -- there is evidence for\ninfection in a total of 5 patients. And from the standpoint of\nhistopathology, looking through the microscope at tissue from deceased\npatients, we have seen evidence of an entity that the pathologist call\ndiffuse alveolar damage, which is the pathologic correlate for the clinical\nsyndrome of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome, which has appeared in\npatients with severe forms of SARS.\nWe have seen that evidence in a total of 4 specimens. Don't try to add those\nnumbers up and get a grand total because some patients, in some cases, have\nmore than one positive result.\n[In response to a question on whether there were samples that tested\nnegative for coronavirus]:\nThere are negative results. I don't have numbers. For example though, when\nyou think about antibody tests, what you really need, [in order] to be able\nto interpret those and to say that something's negative, is 2 serum\nspecimens collected 2 or 3 weeks apart. So any negative that we have now for\nthe most part represents a single serum that's negative. So we're not in the\nposition to say that evaluation is complete. Part of our effort now, working\nwith the states, is to get paired serum specimens from patients so they can\nbe tested.\n[In response to a question re: the information that some of the earlier\ncases had eaten wild game]:\n[Dr. Hughes had not heard the reports about the wild game consumption.] But,\nwe don't know the source, the original source\nof this previously unrecognized virus. There are a number of Coronaviruses\nthat do infect animals, though. So it may well be that there is an animal\norigin for this, and it's the sequencing of the full virus that will tell us\nthis. So I'm interested actually to follow up and see what sort of wild game\nthis is and what the evidence might be.\n[In response to the question if they have run the tests on controls] :\nIn terms of PCR, yes, we have negative controls that we run, both for the\nPCR and for the serologic tests that we have done, and it looks like these\ntests are performing quite well, but it is early in their use.\nThere are several diagnostic tests that look promising. There is the ELISA\ntest for antibody, there's the Indirect Fluorescent Antibody -- or IFA --\ntest, again, for antibody, and then there's a PCR assay [for viruse] that\nlook like they have\npotential to be useful.\nWe will be collecting and testing as many specimens as we can acquire from\nsuspect cases, from health care workers exposed to them, from household\ncontacts, and from healthy controls over time to further validate them.\nWe are going to be trying very soon to transfer some of these tests to\nstate public health laboratories through the Laboratory Response Network so\nwe can get the diagnostics, such as they are at the moment, closer to where\nthe illnesses are occurring. So that's a high priority\n[In response to the question on reports ot the isolation of Chlamydia]:\nThe outbreak in Guangdong Province initially was reported based on some lab\nevidence that I don't know the details of, to be caused by _Chlamydia and\n[sic] pneumoniae_. My impression is that they had relatively few positive\nresults for that. This is why the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) has contacted\nthe Chinese Veterinary Authorities to obtain information on the animal\nhealth situation in China over the past 6 months and, in particular, in\nGuangdong Province. Thus, I was surprised to learn in a\nrecent ProMed-mail posting that coronaviruses also exist in poultry and\nswine, as well as cattle, cats, dogs, and rodents (see: Coronavirus,\n The\npreponderance of the evidence continues to mount and continues to favor an\netiologic role or this previously unrecognized Coronavirus in the cause of\nSARS. Don't try to add those\nnumbers up and get a grand total because some patients, in some cases, have\nmore than one positive result.\n It\nsoon became evident that Human metapneumovirus [HMP] was neither new nor\nexotic, and seems to have affected most humans in every country\ninvestigated, going back decades. The World Health Organization\n(WHO) has hypothesised that the causative virus(es) may be of animal\norigin, from domestic or wild animals located in Guangdong Province (in\nSouth China). Part of our effort now, working\nwith the states, is to get paired serum specimens from patients so they can\nbe tested.\n If, as noted above, background\nimmunity exists from a SARS outbreak several decades ago, relatively low\ndisease rates among the elderly during the current epidemic would not be\nsurprising. A virus in east Asia in the past should not be used as an\nargument favouring the origin of the SARS agent by recombination between a\nhuman virus and an animal virus. Serotype 2 of feline infectious peritonitis virus appears to be a\nrecombinant virus incorporating genetic information from a canine\ncoronavirus, which causes diarrhea in dogs. The serotype 2 virus, in\naddition to causing peritonitis, etc., in cats can -- unlike serotype 1 --\ninfect pups (but does not cause acute disease). Several respiratory viruses, such\nas the common cold-associated coronaviruses and human respiratory syncytial\nvirus, are distributed world-wide and affect individuals of all ages. Current evidence suggests that new strains of Influenza A virus evolve as\nrecombinants when they pass between swine and ducks, a process favored by\nclose species proximity on Asian farms. the moment the single fact that best identifies this virus as the etiologic\nagent of SARS is its apparent low nucleotide sequence homology with other\ncoronaviruses. That said, it is not necessary to hypothesize origin of the putative\nSARS-associated coronavirus by recombination with an animal or avian\ncoronavirus. The RT-PCR amplification of coronavirus sequences produced 11 positive\nresults and was the most sensitive diagnostic procedure employed, but even\nwith this technique an unspecified number of negative results was obtained. The clinical features of this infection\nmimic those of Human respiratory syncytial virus, and infant deaths are not\nuncommon. Nor is it certain that the coronavirus\n(and/or the human metapneumovirus) present in SARS patients is the\npathogenic agent. To date, SARS has\nclaimed 79 lives, and the etiological agent appears to be far less\ncontagious than Influenza A virus. I do not know whether coronaviruses\nare capable of recombination in the manner of influenza viruses, but such a\nmechanism would partially explain the origin of SARS. In terms of PCR, yes, we have negative controls that we run, both for the\nPCR and for the serologic tests that we have done, and it looks like these\ntests are performing quite well, but it is early in their use. It is curious\nthat a virus, which has such devastating pathological potential in some\npeople, is present in these specimens in such low abundance. A human epidemic of atypical pneumonia called severe acute respiratory\nsyndrome (SARS) is currently raging across the globe and particularly in\nSouth-East Asia. Consequently there could be abundant\nopportunity for exchange of sub-units between human and avian viruses where\nhumans, domesticated mammals, and birds live in close proximity. If at the CDC only specimens from suspected cases\nin the United States have been examined so far, an undetermined proportion\nof whom may not be SARS patients, this would be a limitation. We are going to be trying very soon to transfer some of these tests to\nstate public health laboratories through the Laboratory Response Network so\n We will be collecting and testing as many specimens as we can acquire from\nsuspect cases, from health care workers exposed to them, from household\ncontacts, and from healthy controls over time to further validate them. So it may well be that there is an animal\norigin for this, and it's the sequencing of the full virus that will tell us\nthis. High frequency recombination is a\ncharacteristic property of coronaviruses, and is probably restricted to\nclosely related coronaviruses. But,\nwe don't know the source, the original source\nof this previously unrecognized virus. The 4-person team, headed by John MacKenzie of Australia,\nhas been in Guangdong since Thursday 3 Apr 2003. The team was charged to\nassess the local situation and to support the strengthening of\nsurveillance, clinical management, infection control, and laboratory\nevaluation of SARS cases.\nThe team has visited Foshan City, where the earliest case is thought to\nhave occurred in mid-November 2002, and Guangzhou City, the provincial\ncapital. In a wide-ranging collaborative investigation, the team has met\nwith authorities, health and veterinary professionals, and technical\nexperts in the provincial Centers for Disease Control laboratories and the\nvirology laboratories of Zongshan Medical University. The team has\nconferred with staff at all levels and been granted full access to all\nsites, institutes, and hospitals requested.\nThe team will be reporting on the provincial surveillance system, measures\nfor community infection control, patient management, and hospital infection\ncontrol. It will also give a detailed review of microbiological findings.\nThe SARS outbreak in Guangdong Province is presently the largest and oldest\nknown outbreak of SARS and may hold important clues about both the origins\nor the virus and measures for clinical management. In one of its earliest\nreports about cases of atypical pneumonia to WHO, the Chinese Ministry of\nHealth reported 305 cases and 5 deaths, from mid-November 2002 to 9 Feb\n2003, in 6 municipalities: Foshan, Guangzhou, Heyuan, Jiangmen, Shenzhen,\nand Zhongshan.\nGuangzhou was the home of a 64-year-old professor of nephrology at\nZhongshan University, who is thought to be the index case who sparked the\noutbreak in Hong Kong. During late February 2003, he stayed in room 911 on\nthe ninth floor of the Metropole Hotel. Guests staying on the hotel\u0092s ninth\nfloor sparked outbreaks in other countries when they returned to their\nhomes in Toronto and Singapore. A 48-year-old American businessman, who\nalso stayed on the 9th floor, is believed to have originated the outbreaks\nin Hanoi and in Hong Kong\u0092s Princess Margaret [Hospital], where he was\ntransferred. One local Hong Kong resident, who visited an acquaintance on\nthe ninth floor, subsequently sparked an outbreak in a second Hong Kong\nhospital.\nElsewhere in China, Shanghai, which has reported its first SARS case, has\nrequested a visit from the WHO team to discuss SARS and be advised on how\nbest to deal with the disease.\nIn Beijing, the death on Sunday of a 53-year-old staff member of the\nInternational Labour Organization continued to cause considerable anxiety,\nparticularly at embassies and among staff of international organizations.\nEpidemiologists at the WHO Office in Beijing have conducted contact tracing\nand other investigations to determine the source of the staff member\u0092s\nexposure and to assess whether close contacts may have been exposed. To\ndate, no SARS cases or suspicious symptoms related to this death have been\nobserved. The investigations are continuing.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, 2671 SARS cases with 103 deaths have been reported from 17\ncountries. This represents an increase of 70 cases and 5 deaths when\ncompared with yesterday. The new deaths were reported in Canada (1), Hong\nKong SAR (2), and Singapore (2). The additional cases were reported in\nCanada (1), China (11), Hong Kong SAR (45), France (1), Singapore (7), and\nthe United States (7). Taiwan, China removed 2 cases from the list.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 8 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 8 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 8 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs at 3 PM 8 Apr 2003, an additional 45 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals. She is a MediaCorp staff member who\nbecome unwell on 2 Apr 2003 and was admitted to TTSH on 7 Apr 2003 as a\nSARS [patient]. Her condition is stable. She had been on leave from work\nsince 28 Mar 2003. 5 of her colleagues who visited her during the period\nshe was on leave have been advised to stay at home and will be receiving\nHome Quarantine Orders by the end of today. Her other work collegues will\nnot be served Home Quarantine Orders, as she was well prior to her starting\nher leave.\nTTSH Rehabilitation Department\nAt this point in time, the source of infection of the TTSH occupational\ntherapist is yet to be determined. Investigations are still on-going.\nHealth screening for incoming air passengers\nToday, 30 passengers from affected areas required further screening by the\nnurses at the airport. None were referred to TTSH for further assessment.\nSummary of SARS cases\nTo date, the total number of people diagnosed with SARS is 118. Among these\nare 3 children below 18 years of age. In 122 cities in the USA, with a total\npopulation much less than one quarter of China's population, there have now\nbeen 890 deaths from pneumonia + influenza reported in the 3 months ending\n29 Mar 2003 -- see: <http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5213md.htm>\nTable III. - Mod.JW]\nWe believe that the 890 deaths mentioned in the comment actually represents\ndeaths in one week (week 13) in the U.S. in the 122 cities rather than\nduring the 3 months ending 29 Mar 2003. Curious, we looked further. Table\n32 (page 127) of Health, United States, 2002 indicates that in 1999 there\nwere 63 730 pneumonia + influenza (P+I) deaths in the U.S., (weekly average\nof 1226 deaths). Table 33 (page 132) indicates that of this total, 57 282\nP + I deaths occurred in persons over 65 years of age (weekly average 1102\ndeaths), and therefore 6448 deaths occurred in persons under 65 years of\nage (weekly average of 124 deaths). In the 25-44 years age group there\nwere 1402 deaths caused by P + I in 1999 (weekly average of 27\ndeaths). These back-of-the-envelope calculations give an even more\nstriking perspective to numbers of SARS deaths.\nJudith A. Johnson and Pamela W. Smith\n--\nJudith A. worldwide (26): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203571", "date": "2003-04-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (26): ETIOLOGY\n***********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed 2 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Institut Pasteur, Paris, press release, Tue 1 Apr 2003\n[translated & edited by Mod.CP]\n<http://www.pasteur.fr/externe>\n\nSARS: Detection of a Coronavirus by Virologists at the Institut Pasteur\n-------------------------------------------------\nA coronavirus has been detected in samples obtained from SARS patients in\nHanoi by Sylvie van der Werf and colleagues in the Molecular Genetics of\nRespiratory Viruses Unit at the Institut Pasteur. Van der Werf's group had\nbeen invited by the World Health Organisation and the Direction Generale de\nla Sante francaise (DGS) to participate in the international effort to\ninvestigate the nature of the current SARS outbreak in Asia. One of the\nvirologists in her group, Dr Jean-Claude Manuguerra, was a member of the\nteam sent to Hanoi by the DGS. The unit is part of the Cellule\nd'intervention biologique d'urgence (CIBU), established in 2002 to provide\nrapid response to disease outbreaks or bioterrorist attacks. The Institut\nPasteur was assigned the task of investigating the samples from Hanoi, as\nwell as suspected cases that might arrive in France from southeast Asia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[A report in Europa Press, 31 Mar 2003 <http://www.europapress.es/>\n(submitted by Pablo Nart and translated by Maria Jacobs, ProMED-ESP) stated\nin addition that scientists at the Pasteur Institute in Paris -- presumably\nthose named above -- had identified coronaviruses in samples from 6 patients\nwith atypical pneumonia in the Hanoi Hospital in Vietnam, as well as in\nsamples obtained from a physician hospitalized in Tourcoing (north of\nFrance), the first victim of severe acute respiratory syndrome in France.\nLucien Abenhaim, France's health director-general, stated that the virus has\nan 'atypical appearance'\nwith features that correspond to the viruses discovered by other\nlaboratories around the world, in particular the Centers for Disease Control\n(USA). - Mod.CP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: Tue 1 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: New England Journal of Medicine online, March 2003 [edited]\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030634v1.pdf>\n\nDetection of Novel Coronavirus and Human Metapneumovirus Sequences in the\nSame SARS Patients\n------------------\n[The following description of the virological investigations in Canadian\nSARS patients has been extracted from the paper by Poutanen et al.,\nentitled 'Identification of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome in Canada'\nand published online in the New England Journal of Medicine. The full paper\nis accessible via the above URL. It confirms previous statements from\nCanadian sources that a human metapneumovirus had been isolated from a SARS\npatient and further appears to indicate the presence of both a novel\ncoronavirus and a human metapneumovirus in 4 of 5 virus-positive SARS\npatients. - Mod.CP]\nViral molecular testing has been completed on all respiratory and blood\nspecimens received from 9 of the 10 patients, yielding mostly negative\nresults. Specifically, DNA was extracted and PCR was completed for targets\nspecific to various DNA viruses, yielding negative results for\nadenoviruses, parvoviruses, circoviruses, herpesviruses, & orthopoxviruses.\nIn addition, RNA was extracted and reverse-transcriptase\u00ad PCR (RT-PCR) was\ncompleted for targets specific to various RNA viruses, including influenza\nvirus A and B, respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza virus subtypes 1,\n2, 3, and 4, human metapneumovirus, filoviruses (Ebola and Marburg\nviruses), arenaviruses, measles virus, mumps virus, hantaviruses, and\nCrimean\u00ad-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, yielding negative results.\nFurther studies were completed on all respiratory specimens received from 9\nof the 10 patients. These included viral cultures (including inoculation\nonto cell culture and into embryonated hen eggs and intracerebral\ninoculation of suckling mice), immune electron microscopy of nasopharyngeal\nswabs and bronchoalveolar fluids with serum obtained during the\nconvalescent phase from Patient 10, RT-PCR for conserved portions of the\npolymerase gene of RNA viruses, and genus-specific degenerative primers for\nparamyxoviruses and bunyaviruses with use of nested RT-PCR. Results for all\nof these tests have been negative, with 2 exceptions.\nHuman metapneumovirus was amplified by nested PCR from bronchoalveolar\nlavage fluid and nasopharyngeal swabs from 5 of 9 patients with SARS and\nfrom a nasopharyngeal swab from an asymptomatic contact of one of the\npatients in Toronto (Patient 3) with use of the following primers:\n5'CTTTGGACTTAATGACAGATG3' and 5'GTCTTCCTGTGCTAACTTTG3'.\nFor confirmation of these positive findings, the amplicons were sequenced\nand found to be unique, ruling out the possibility of cross-contamination in\nthe laboratory.\nIn addition, a novel coronavirus was isolated from Vero cell cultures\ninoculated with respiratory specimens from 5 of 9 patients with SARS. 4 of\nthese patients had specimens from which metapneumovirus was also\nidentified. A cytopathic effect on the Vero cell cultures was noted on day\n6 of incubation. On the basis of collaboration with investigators in Hong\nKong and at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, who\nreported isolating a novel coronavirus from patients with SARS in other\nareas of the world, RT-PCR and nested PCR were completed targeting\nconserved regions of the coronavirus polymerase gene using the following\nprimer pairs: 5'CAGAGCCATGCCTAACATG3' and 5'AATGTTTACGCAGGTAAGCG3'; and\n5'TGTTAAACCAGGTGGAAC3' and 5'CCTGTGTTGTAGATTGCG3'. A novel coronavirus\nidentical to that reported by the CDC was amplified from all 5 cultures.\nAt a different laboratory, a coronavirus was also identified independently\nby amplification directly from bronchoalveolar-lavage fluid from 2 of 4\npatients tested. Both of these patients had coronavirus isolated from cell\nculture and amplification as described above. Reverse transcription was\ncompleted using the primer 5'GCATAGGCAGTAGTTGCATC3', followed by PCR\ntargeting a highly conserved region of the coronavirus polymerase gene with\nuse of the paired primers 5'TGATGGGATGGGACTATCCTAAGTGTGA3' and\n5'TTGCATCACCACTAGTTGTGCCACCAGGTT3'.\nOne of the amplicons was sequenced, and although the nucleotide sequence was\ndifferent from that of any known coronaviruses, the deduced amino acid\nsequence had a high degree of homology (78 percent) to the polymerase amino\nacid sequence of several coronaviruses. Phylogenetic analysis suggests that\nthis is a novel virus that is not closely related to any of the known\nclusters of coronaviruses (groups 1, 2 & 3).\nFurther studies are currently being completed to determine whether the human\nmetapneumovirus and a novel coronavirus, either alone or in combination, are\nthe cause of SARS or whether other thus-far-undetected pathogens are\npossibly responsible. The possibility cannot be excluded that co-infection\nby either virus with another agent may be responsible for SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Now that a lab test is widely available for the coronavirus that was\nisolated from 2 SARS patients in Germany, there may be a danger of circular\nreasoning about the etiology. Any patient who tests positive for the\ncoronavirus will be considered confirmation of the etiology, and those that\ntest negative (often the majority) will be explained away as due to\ninadequacy of the sample for one reason or another. Nobody may be looking at\nthose that test negative to see whether they contain sequences for human\nmetapneumovirus, henipaviruses or other paramyxoviruses (the last do not\nappear to have been definitely excluded yet -- remember that 3 independent\nlaboratories identified a paramyxovirus from specimens taken from SARS\npatients). Thus the true etiologic agent may be missed altogether. One has\nto bear in mind -- or explain away -- all the conflicting findings, by\nmultiple labs, of viruses from SARS patients that were not coronaviruses.\nThe co-infection theory should not cause a distraction from the search for a\nunique etiological agent. - Mod.JW]", "summary": "In addition, RNA was extracted and reverse-transcriptase\u00ad PCR (RT-PCR) was\ncompleted for targets specific to various RNA viruses, including influenza\nvirus A and B, respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza virus subtypes 1,\n2, 3, and 4, human metapneumovirus, filoviruses (Ebola and Marburg\nviruses), arenaviruses, measles virus, mumps virus, hantaviruses, and\nCrimean\u00ad-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, yielding negative results.\n [A report in Europa Press, 31 Mar 2003 <http://www.europapress.es/>\n(submitted by Pablo Nart and translated by Maria Jacobs, ProMED-ESP) stated\nin addition that scientists at the Pasteur Institute in Paris -- presumably\nthose named above -- had identified coronaviruses in samples from 6 patients\nwith atypical pneumonia in the Hanoi Hospital in Vietnam, as well as in\nsamples obtained from a physician hospitalized in Tourcoing (north of\nFrance), the first victim of severe acute respiratory syndrome in France. Pending development of\nconfirmatory laboratory testing capacity, CDC's interim suspected SARS case\ndefinition (2) is based on clinical criteria and epidemiologic linkage to\nother SARS cases or areas with community transmission of SARS. This case\ndefinition will be updated periodically as new information becomes\navailable. Epidemiologic and laboratory investigations of SARS are ongoing.\nAs of 2 Apr 2003, a total of 2223 suspected and/or probable SARS cases\nhave been reported to WHO from 16 countries, including the United States\n(3,4). The reported SARS cases include 78 deaths (case-fatality proportion:\n3.5 percent). This report summarizes SARS cases among U.S. residents and\nsurveillance and prevention activities in the United States.\nDescriptive Epidemiology\n----------------------\nAs of April 2, CDC had received 100 reports of suspected SARS cases [see\nFigure 1 on webpage for epidemiologic curve\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5213a1.htm>] from 28 states; 81\n(81 percent) cases occurred among adults [see table 1 below]. Of these 100\nsuspected cases, 94 (94%) persons had traveled within the 10 days before\nillness onset to the areas listed in the case definition (revised on 29 Mar\n2003 to include all of mainland China as an area with documented or\nsuspected community transmission), 4 had household contact with a person\nwith suspected SARS, and 2 were health-care workers (HCWs) who provided\nmedical care to a patient with suspected SARS.\nManifestations of SARS have been relatively less severe among patients in\nthe United States than among those reported elsewhere. A majority of U.S.\npatients had normal chest radiographs, and 23 (23 percent) were reported to\nhave pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome on chest radiograph, thereby\nmeeting the WHO case definition of a probable case (4). As of 2 Apr 2003, of\nthe 40 (40 percent) patients who were hospitalized for greater than 24\nhours, 13 (33 percent of 40) remained hospitalized; one patient had required\nmechanical ventilatory support, and no deaths have been reported.\nReports on the clinical status of suspected SARS cases are being received\nby state health departments and CDC, and household and HCW contacts are\nbeing monitored for the possibility of secondary transmission. Since SARS\ninvestigations in the United States began, some persons believed initially\nto have suspected SARS have been excluded on the basis of more complete\nclinical histories (e.g., no documented fever or respiratory symptoms) or\nbecause of testing results that indicated other etiologies. Alternative\ndiagnoses have included infection with influenza virus, respiratory\nsyncytial virus, _Haemophilus influenzae_, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, and\n_Staphylococcus aureus_. Community transmission of SARS has not been\nidentified in the United States; transmission to HCWs has been observed in\none cluster involving 2 HCWs, compared with numerous reports of possible\ntransmission to HCWs in other countries (5--7).\nEnhanced Surveillance for SARS Related to Travel\n---------------------------------------------\nAs a precautionary measure, WHO has recommended that persons traveling to\nHong Kong and Guangdong Province of China consider postponing all but\nessential travel. CDC has issued a travel advisory recommending that\npersons planning nonessential or elective travel to mainland China, Hong\nKong, Hanoi, or Singapore consider postponing such travel until further\nnotice.\nTo detect possible SARS cases among travelers returning to the United States\nfrom these areas, CDC and state and local health authorities have\nimplemented enhanced surveillance. Since 16 Mar 2003, notices (available in\nEnglish, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese) have been provided to\napproximately 220 000 passengers arriving in the United States on airline\nflights originating from China, Vietnam, and Singapore to inform\ndisembarking passengers and crew about SARS. Persons disembarking from these\ncountries are urged to monitor their health for 10 days after return, to\nseek medical care if they develop fever of greater than 100.5 F (39.0 C) and\ncough or difficulty breathing within 10 days of travel, and to inform their\nhealth-care providers about recent travel to regions where SARS cases have\nbeen reported.\nLaboratory Investigations\n----------------------\nEfforts are ongoing to characterize further the role of a previously\nunrecognized coronavirus in SARS. Polymerase chain reaction-based assays,\nisolation studies, electron microscopic studies, and histologic studies are\nbeing developed to detect virus in specimens from patients with suspected\nSARS. Indirect immunoflorescence antibody assays and enzyme immunoassays to\nanti-coronavirus antibody as an indicator of infection have been developed\nand are being applied to specimens from suspected SARS patients. Laboratory\nstudies at CDC and other laboratories in the WHO-organized SARS Laboratory\nNetwork have detected this new coronavirus in SARS patients, which is\nconsistent with an etiologic role in this disease. CDC has detected human\nmetapneumovirus from one SARS patient, and other laboratories also have\ndetected metapneumovirus from SARS patients (6). The role of these viruses\nin the pathogenesis of SARS is unclear.\nMMWR Editorial Note:\n--------------------\nThe number of SARS cases, and the number of countries reporting such cases,\ncontinues to increase worldwide. Transmission within hospitals and\nhouseholds continues in some areas, and transmission within communities\n(e.g., Hong Kong) continues to be reported. In the absence of a complete\nunderstanding of how SARS is transmitted, efforts to limit transmission in\nthe United States have focused on early identification of potential cases\nthrough surveillance and implementation of infection-control measures in\nhealth-care settings and the community.\nCDC has developed interim infection-control guidelines for use in U.S.\nhealth-care and household settings (8). These recommendations are based on\nexperience in the United States to date and will be revised as more\ninformation becomes available. Infection-control practitioners and\nclinicians providing medical care for patients with suspected SARS should\nconsult these guidelines frequently to keep current with recommendations.\nTransmission in health-care settings has been documented in several\ncountries. Transmission to HCWs appears to have occurred primarily after\nclose contact with symptomatic persons before recommended infection-control\nprecautions for SARS were implemented. Because a primary strategy to reduce\ntransmission in health-care settings is early recognition and isolation of\npatients who might have SARS, triage practices in hospitals and\nambulatory-care settings might require reevaluation. CDC guidelines for\ntriage of potential SARS cases are available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/triage_interim_guidance.htm>.\nIn the United States, decisions to admit persons with suspected SARS to\nhealth-care facilities should be based on clinical criteria. Patients with\nsuspected SARS who are discharged should limit interactions outside the\nhome and not go to work, school, out-of-home child care, or other public\nareas until 10 days after resolution of fever and respiratory symptoms.\nAdditional guidance for these patients is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/ic-closecontacts.htm>.\nThe majority of U.S. residents with SARS have recovered or stabilized\nclinically without specific antiviral therapy. The U.S. case-fatality\nproportion is lower than that reported in some other countries (3).\nPossible explanations for this include differing case definitions among\ncountries or differences in the sensitivity of surveillance, leading to\nidentification in the United States of patients with less severe or early\nmanifestations of infection or of a larger proportion of patients with\nother respiratory illnesses. Until confirmatory laboratory testing is\navailable, the case definition will include clinical criteria more likely\nto identify potentially infectious persons. Various therapies, including\nantiviral agents (e.g., oseltamivir or ribavirin) and corticosteroids, have\nbeen administered to SARS patients, but the efficacy of these therapies has\nnot been determined.\nHealth-care providers of patients whose illness is consistent with the case\ndefinition for SARS should continue diagnostic evaluation for other causes\nof respiratory illness and, when appropriate, empiric therapy that includes\nactivity against organisms associated with community-acquired pneumonia of\nuncertain etiology, including both typical and atypical respiratory\npathogens (9). Health-care providers who report suspected SARS cases should\nnotify their state health departments if these patients receive\nconfirmatory testing that indicates a diagnosis other than SARS.\nInformation on suggested diagnostic testing and evaluation for persons with\npossible SARS is available at http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/diagnosis.htm.\nAirline travel\n----------\nThe potential for transmission of SARS during airline travel is unknown.\nTransmission of other infectious agents (e.g., _Mycobacterium tuberculosis_)\nduring air travel has been demonstrated (10). When an airline flight crew\nreports a passenger with respiratory illness, quarantine officials might\nboard the aircraft on arrival in the United States to assess whether the\npassenger's symptoms match the case definition of SARS and give the\npassenger information about following up. If a passenger with suspected\nSARS is identified after passengers have disembarked, public health\nauthorities will work with the airline to contact passengers and crew for\ninformation about the development of an illness suggestive of SARS.\nAlthough ill travelers have spread SARS rapidly across international\nborders, the proportion, if any, of persons who acquired SARS during\ninternational travel as a result of in-flight transmission is unknown.\nDespite vigorous efforts to identify and isolate suspected cases, reducing\ntransmission of the etiologic agents of SARS might be difficult.\nUnderstanding the epidemiology of respiratory pathogens such as those that\ncause SARS is challenging; approximately 40-60 percent of persons with\npneumonia do not have a defined etiology, even when extensive testing for\nknown respiratory pathogens is attempted (9). Minimizing transmission will\nrequire sustained attention to infection-control interventions within\nhealth-care settings and the community. The development of laboratory\ntesting techniques to identify infected persons rapidly will be an\nimportant step toward understanding and reducing transmission of SARS.\nReferences\n--------\n1. This is an increase of\n4 to 5-fold in the global totals in the last 7 days\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_25/en/> with the greatest\nproportionate and absolute increases being in China (Hong Kong & Guangdong\nProvince), and to a much lesser extent in Canada. There has been little\nabsolute rise in other country totals.\n18 countries have now reported cases but in most of these no transmission\nseems to have occurred. Local transmission has occurred in Hanoi (Vietnam),\nSingapore, Toronto (Canada), Taiwan, and the following parts of China:\nGuangdong Province;\nBeijing; Shanxi; and Hong Kong SAR. In the United Kingdom 3 probable SARS\ncases have been reported; all have now recovered. Indeed, the only areas\nwhere WHO feels there is evidence consistent with current transmission are\nHong Kong and Guangdong\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_02_02b/en/>, and the WHO has issued\nadvice to international travellers not to travel to or through either area.\nGuangdong and Hong Kong\n--------------------------\nInformation about the outbreaks in Guangdong is limited, but the latest\nreports give a significant increase of over 350 cases during March 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_02_02b/en/>. Detailed\ndescriptions from Hong Kong are now available. Following transmission\ncentering on a large hotel, there have been intense hospital outbreaks\ninvolving staff, patient and families of staff (1) where community\ntransmission has been established. There is now evidence of community\ntransmission within a large housing complex.\nMeasures introduced by Hong Kong, Singapore, and Canada to control the\nlocal spread of SARS have included school closures (Hong Kong and\nSingapore), the quarantine of entire residential buildings (Hong Kong), and\nthe restriction of non-essential access to hospitals -- all 3,\n<http://www.health.gov.on.ca/english/public/pub/disease/sars_6.html>.\nAlthough such precautions are not yet necessary in Europe, the experience\nin Canada is a sobering reminder of what could happen in any country\nreceiving a case.\nOntario, Canada\n---------------\nThe outbreak in Canada began with a Toronto woman who developed respiratory\nsymptoms 2 days after returning from Hong Kong. She died at home 10 days\nlater, but meanwhile appears to have transmitted infection to 4 members of\nher family. One of them, her adult son, was admitted to a local hospital\nwith respiratory symptoms. He spent some time in an open part of the\nemergency department before being transferred to the intensive care unit,\nwhere he remained until his death, 6 days after admission. It is now\napparent that transmission of SARS has occurred within the hospital. A\npatient who was in the next bed in the emergency department developed\nsymptoms of SARS 3 days after his visit to the emergency department, and\ndied 11 days later. A large number of hospital staff who worked in the\nemergency department and the intensive care unit where the son of the index\ncase was cared for have now presented with symptoms of SARS. Transmission\nin the intensive care unit may have been from the patient or from visiting\nfamily members, some of whom were symptomatic at the time they visited (2).\nThe Province of Ontario declared a health emergency on 26 Mar 2003, and on\n1 Apr 2003 a sixth death from SARS was reported from Toronto. As of 1 Apr\n2003, Ontario has reported 51 probable cases of SARS. The hospital has now\nbeen closed to new admissions.\nThe experience in Canada illustrates that highly developed countries can be\nvulnerable to transmission from imported cases of SARS, especially in\nhospitals (3,4). Most of the data have been consistent with transmission\nthrough large droplets or body fluids. Aerosol transmission cannot be\ntotally discounted, but if it occurs it is uncommon. If the causative\norganism had been readily transmissible by aerosol, many more cases would\nhave been expected, especially in the countries where transmission has\nslowed or never started. In Hong Kong there are some patterns of infection\nthat are most easily explained by environmental transmission such as\nfomites.\nIf the infection is not recognised early and appropriate infection control\nprecautions put in place, extensive transmission can occur. Those most at\nrisk seem to be family members and healthcare workers who have close\ncontact with symptomatic cases. It is worth noting that there have been no\nreported secondary cases from 2 hospitalised Canadian SARS cases where\nfamily members were not permitted to visit and healthcare workers adhered\nto strict infection control precautions.\nClinicians, accident and emergency, intensive treatment units, and\ninfectious disease staff in Europe should be alert to the possibility of\nSARS in people with fever and respiratory symptoms, IF they have recently\nreturned from areas where transmission of SARS is ongoing (currently Hong\nKong, and probably Guangdong) or who have had contact with a case of SARS\n<http://www.phls.co.uk/topics_az/SARS/management_guidance.htm>. When\npatients suspected of having SARS are admitted to hospital, it is vital\nthat infection control precautions are rapidly implemented and rigorously\nenforced <http://www.phls.co.uk/topics_az/SARS/hospital_guidance.htm>.\nUpdates on the developing situation are also available from WHO\n(<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>) , on ProMED\n(<http://www.promedmail.org>), and at the websites of various national\npublic health organisations, including CDC\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>), Health Canada\n(<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/index.html>), and the Health\nProtection Agency in the United Kingdom\n(<http://www.phls.org.uk/topics_az/SARS/menu.htm>)(5-7).\nEurosurveillance Weekly welcomes comments on other useful information\nsources, please send\nto elizabeth.hoile@hpa.org.uk.\nReferences:\n1.
