When an airline flight crew\nreports a passenger with respiratory illness, quarantine officials might\nboard the aircraft on arrival in the United States to assess whether the\npassenger's symptoms match the case definition of SARS and give the\npassenger information about following up. Since SARS\ninvestigations in the United States began, some persons believed initially\nto have suspected SARS have been excluded on the basis of more complete\nclinical histories (e.g., no documented fever or respiratory symptoms) or\nbecause of testing results that indicated other etiologies. Since 16 Mar 2003, notices (available in\nEnglish, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, and Vietnamese) have been provided to\napproximately 220 000 passengers arriving in the United States on airline\nflights originating from China, Vietnam, and Singapore to inform\ndisembarking passengers and crew about SARS. This is an increase of\n4 to 5-fold in the global totals in the last 7 days\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_25/en/> with the greatest\nproportionate and absolute increases being in China (Hong Kong & Guangdong\nProvince), and to a much lesser extent in Canada. As of 2 Apr 2003, 2223 cases of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) and\n78 deaths have been reported to the World Health Organization (WHO), a case\nfatality rate of 3.5 percent\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_02/en/>. Pending development of\nconfirmatory laboratory testing capacity, CDC's interim suspected SARS case\ndefinition (2) is based on clinical criteria and epidemiologic linkage to\nother SARS cases or areas with community transmission of SARS. As of April 2, CDC had received 100 reports of suspected SARS cases [see\nFigure 1 on webpage for epidemiologic curve\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5213a1.htm>] from 28 states; 81\n(81 percent) cases occurred among adults [see table 1 below]. It is worth noting that there have been no\nreported secondary cases from 2 hospitalised Canadian SARS cases where\nfamily members were not permitted to visit and healthcare workers adhered\nto strict infection control precautions. A majority of U.S.\npatients had normal chest radiographs, and 23 (23 percent) were reported to\nhave pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome on chest radiograph, thereby\nmeeting the WHO case definition of a probable case (4). Community transmission of SARS has not been\nidentified in the United States; transmission to HCWs has been observed in\none cluster involving 2 HCWs, compared with numerous reports of possible\ntransmission to HCWs in other countries (5--7). The MMWR\narticle is interesting as it presents information on suspected as well as\nprobable cases, suggesting that the suspected cases, milder forms without\npneumonia may well be part of the clinical spectrum of SARS. Patients with\nsuspected SARS who are discharged should limit interactions outside the\nhome and not go to work, school, out-of-home child care, or other public\nareas until 10 days after resolution of fever and respiratory symptoms. Because a primary strategy to reduce\ntransmission in health-care settings is early recognition and isolation of\npatients who might have SARS, triage practices in hospitals and\nambulatory-care settings might require reevaluation. As of 2 Apr 2003, of\nthe 40 (40 percent) patients who were hospitalized for greater than 24\nhours, 13 (33 percent of 40) remained hospitalized; one patient had required\nmechanical ventilatory support, and no deaths have been reported. Following transmission\ncentering on a large hotel, there have been intense hospital outbreaks\ninvolving staff, patient and families of staff (1) where community\ntransmission has been established. Understanding the epidemiology of respiratory pathogens such as those that\ncause SARS is challenging; approximately 40-60 percent of persons with\npneumonia do not have a defined etiology, even when extensive testing for\nknown respiratory pathogens is attempted (9). \nCDC and the World Health Organization (WHO) are continuing to investigate\nthe multicountry outbreak of unexplained atypical pneumonia referred to as\nsevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) (1). If a passenger with suspected\nSARS is identified after passengers have disembarked, public health\nauthorities will work with the airline to contact passengers and crew for\ninformation about the development of an illness suggestive of SARS. When\npatients suspected of having SARS are admitted to hospital, it is vital\nthat infection control precautions are rapidly implemented and rigorously\nenforced <http://www.phls.co.uk/topics_az/SARS/hospital_guidance.htm>. If the causative\norganism had been readily transmissible by aerosol, many more cases would\nhave been expected, especially in the countries where transmission has\nslowed or never started. A\npatient who was in the next bed in the emergency department developed\nsymptoms of SARS 3 days after his visit to the emergency department, and\ndied 11 days later. Polymerase chain reaction-based assays,\nisolation studies, electron microscopic studies, and histologic studies are\nbeing developed to detect virus in specimens from patients with suspected\nSARS. Laboratory\nstudies at CDC and other laboratories in the WHO-organized SARS Laboratory\nNetwork have detected this new coronavirus in SARS patients, which is\nconsistent with an etiologic role in this disease. CDC has issued a travel advisory recommending that\npersons planning nonessential or elective travel to mainland China, Hong\nKong, Hanoi, or Singapore consider postponing such travel until further\nnotice. Alternative\ndiagnoses have included infection with influenza virus, respiratory\nsyncytial virus, _Haemophilus influenzae_, _Streptococcus pneumoniae_, and\n_Staphylococcus aureus_. As of 2 Apr 2003, a total of 2223 suspected and/or probable SARS cases\nhave been reported to WHO from 16 countries, including the United States\n(3,4). Reports on the clinical status of suspected SARS cases are being received\nby state health departments and CDC, and household and HCW contacts are\nbeing monitored for the possibility of secondary transmission. Worldwide (33): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203596", "date": "2003-04-07 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (33): CASES\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] Taiwan - DOH\n[5] USA - CDC\n[6] Canada - Health Canada\n[7] Newswire briefs\n[A] China\n[B] Vietnam\n******\n[1]\nDate: 7 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website 7 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Cases of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_07/en/>\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002(1) To: 7 Apr 2003, 18:00 GMT+2\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No. deaths/ Local chain(s) of\ntransmission (2)\nAustralia: 1/ 0/ None\nBrazil: 1/ 0/ None\nCanada: 90/ 9/ Yes\nChina: 1268/ 53/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 883/ 23*/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 21/ 0/ Yes\nFrance: 3/ 0/ None\nGermany: 5/ 0/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ None\nMalaysia: 1/ 1/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ None\nRomania: 1/ 0/ None\nSingapore: 106/ 6/ Yes\nSpain: 1/ 0/ None\nSwitzerland: 1/ 0/ None\nThailand: 7/ 2/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 5/ 0/ None\nUnited States: 141\u00a7 / 0/ None\nViet Nam: 62/ 4/ Yes\nTotal: 2601/ 98\nNotes:\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n1. The start of the period of surveillance has been changed to 1 Nov 2002\nto capture cases of atypical pneumonia in China that are now recognized as\nbeing cases of SARS.\n2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n\u00a7Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national level,\nprobable cases are reported by all countries except the United States of\nAmerica, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n*One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n\n[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 7 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_07/en/>\n[unchanged from previous reports - Mod.MPP]\nCountry: Area\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Guangdong, Hong Kong SAR, Shanxi, Taiwan Province\nViet Nam: Hanoi\nAn affected area: an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of SARS\nis/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.\n[C] Update 23 - Status of the main SARS outbreaks in different countries 7\nApr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_07/en/>\nChina\nThe Chinese Ministry of Health is now providing daily updates on numbers of\ncases and deaths, nationwide by province. On 3 Apr 2003, a total of 17 new\ncases, including 2 deaths, were reported. 2 previously reported cases were\nexcluded. 11 new cases and one death occurred in Guangdong Province. One\ncase was reported from Shanghai, 4 from Beijing, and one case (fatal) from\nSichuan Province.\nOn 4 Apr 2003, 12 new cases, with no deaths, were reported, 11 from\nGuangdong and 1 from Shanxi. For 5 and 6 Apr 2003, 21 new cases and 2 new\ndeaths were reported. The breakdown by province is awaiting translation\nfrom Chinese. This brings the total number of reported cases in China to\n1268, with 53 deaths.\nChinese officials have announced that SARS is being made a high priority\nfor the government. A system of alert and response for early detection and\nreporting of all emerging and epidemic-prone diseases is being put in\nplace. The government has also begun holding daily press conferences. WHO\nwelcomes this move, which is an important way to increase awareness of the\npopulation and health care staff of the characteristic symptoms, the need\nto seek prompt medical attention, and the need to manage patients according\nto the principles of isolation and strict infection control.\nThe WHO office in China has reported considerable anxiety among the\ninternational community following the death in Beijing on Sunday of a\n53-year-old Finnish staff member of the International Labor Organization.\nThe ILO staff members was in Beijing to attend an international conference.\nAt present it is unclear how the staff member contracted SARS. He had\ntravelled to Beijing via Thailand, where no local transmission has been\nreported.\nHong Kong\nHong Kong SAR continues to report the largest number of new cases, placing\nsome hospitals under considerable strain. Today\u0092s report from the\nDepartment of Health indicates that the unusual outbreak among residents in\nthe Amoy Gardens estate, which has caused 268 cases, is coming to an end.\nInvestigation of environmental samples continues at a rapid pace with\nsupport from several government departments. Evidence that the causative\nagent is excreted in faeces has focused attention on the possibility of an\noral-faecal route of transmission, though no conclusions have been reached.\nGood data from the investigations are expected by the end of the week. The\ninvestigations have found no evidence of airborne spread.\nSingapore\nThe Singapore Ministry of Health has reported an unusual cluster of 29\nsuspected SARS cases in hospital staff from 2 wards of a single hospital.\nOf these 4 are probable SARS cases. The onset of the clustering is believed\nto be 29 Mar 2003. Officials investigating the cause of the outbreak are\nconsidering a possible point source in the environment, as it would be\nunusual for so many cases to begin on the same day if caused by contact\nwith a patient\nViet Nam\nThe outbreak in Viet Nam began at a French hospital in Hanoi, where the\nindex case, a 48-year-old Chinese-American businessman who worked for an\nimport-export company in Hong Kong, was admitted on 26 Feb 2003. The number\nof cases increased rapidly but then stabilized on 24 Mar 2003 at 58 cases\nand remained stable for 10 consecutive days. As the maximum incubation\nperiod for SARS is thought to be 10 days, the stable number of cases over\nthis period raised hope that Viet Nam\u0092s outbreak had been brought under\ncontrol. However, on 3 Apr 2003 a probable SARS case was detected in a\nprovincial hospital. Though the case could be linked back to the French\nhospital, the absence of isolation and rigorous infection control at the\nprovincial hospital suggests that many hospital staff, patients, and\nvisitors could have been exposed, thus possibly seeding further waves of\ncases. An additional 3 probable cases have been reported over the past 2 days.\nCanada\nHealth Canada has received reports of 217 probable or suspect cases of\nSARS. There have been 9 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred\nin persons who have travelled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the\nhousehold or in a health-care setting. The largest outbreak has occurred in\nOntario, where 87 probable and 92 suspect cases have been reported. British\nColumbia is reporting 3 probable and 23 suspect cases, New Brunswick is\nreporting 2 suspect cases, Saskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case,\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases, and Prince Edward Island is reporting\n4 suspect cases.\nThese reports account for the 90 probable cases included in the WHO\ncumulative table of cases and deaths for today.\nStatus of diagnostic tests\nThe development of a diagnostic test, which is being pursued around the\nclock by the WHO collaborating network of 11 laboratories, has proved more\nproblematic than hoped. 3 diagnostic tests are now available and all have\nlimitations as tools for bringing the SARS outbreak quickly under control.\nThe ELISA detects antibodies reliably but only from about day 20 after the\nonset of clinical symptoms. It therefore cannot be used to detect cases at\nan early stage before they have a chance to spread the infection to others.\nThe second test, an immunofluorescence assay (IFA), detects antibodies\nreliably as of day 10 of infection, but is a demanding and comparatively\nslow test that requires the growth of virus in cell culture. The presently\navailable PCR molecular test for detection of SARS virus genetic material\nis useful in the early stages of infection but produces many\nfalse-negatives, meaning that many persons who actually carry the virus may\nnot be detected, creating a dangerous sense of false security for a virus\nthat is known to spread easily in close person-to-person contact.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 2601 cases of SARS, with 98 deaths, have\nbeen reported from 17 countries. This represents an increase of 85 cases\nand 9 deaths compared with the last update of 5 Apr 2003. The deaths\noccurred in Canada (2), China (4), and Hong Kong SAR (3).\nThe single case reported in Belgium has been removed from the list.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Our thanks to Marianne Hopp <mjh12@yahoo.com> for her continued coverage\nof WHO reports. - Mod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 7 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 7 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 3 PM 7 Apr 2003, an additional 41 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals. They include 7 healthcare\nworkers (2 from Princess Margaret Hospital, 4 from Alice Ho Miu Ling\nNethersole Hospital and one from Tuen Mun Hospital) and 10 patients from\nAmoy Gardens. The remaining 24 were new patients and contacts of patients\nwith atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 127 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have\nbeen discharged from public hospitals. Of them, 11 were discharged today.\nMost of the patients currently in hospital are showing positive responses\nto the new treatment protocol. 116 patients are receiving treatment in\nintensive care unit.\nA 78-year-old female patient died in Queen Elizabeth Hospital last night,\nbring to 23 the total number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\nNature Cumulative No. cases/ Total No. of Discharged cases/ Total No. deaths *\n(The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 208 (208)/ 69/ 23\nPatients, family members & visitors 675 (675)/ 58/\nTotal 883 (883)/ 127\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who had a history of chronic\ndiseases or who sought treatment at a relatively late stage of infection.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 7 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 7 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5961>\n\nSARS Update - 7 Apr 2003\nAs of 7 Apr 2003, 73 SARS patients have been discharged. 31 SARS patients\nremain hospitalised.\nThere were 7 additional SARS cases reported today. All are nurses; 1 from\nTTSH, 2 from SGH, 2 from CGH, 1 from a private nursing home and 1\nradiographer from SGH.\nNurse from TTSH\nA nurse from TTSH who had come into contact with a SARS patient before the\npatient was diagnosed with SARS was admitted on 28 Mar 2003 as a suspected\nSARS patient. She has since been upgraded to a probable SARS.\nNurses from CGH\n2 nurses from CGH have been admitted to TTSH on 5 and 6 Apr 2003 as\nprobable SARS cases. One had close contact with a patient before she was\ndiagnosed with SARS and transferred to TTSH 21 Mar 2003. This SARS patient\nwas infected when she visited her sister in TTSH. At that time, a SARS\npatient who had yet been diagnosed was in warded next to her sister at\nTTSH. CGH had put the whole ward staff on voluntary quarantine and were\nfollowed up closely. On 2 Apr [2003], the nurse who had attended to the\nSARS patient was admitted to a single room at CGH as the clinical picture\nthen was suggestive of dengue fever. She was later diagnosed as a probable\nSARS when her third chest x-ray showed changes. Her colleague who attended\nto her when she admitted has now been diagnosed with SARS.\nPrivate nursing home\nA nurse from a private nursing home was admitted to CGH on 4 Apr 2003 for\npneumonia and transferred to TTSH on 6 Apr 2003 for probable SARS. He is\nnow in serious condition in intensive care.\nHis girlfriend, who is also a nurse at the same nursing home, was admitted\nto TTSH on 7 Apr 2003 as a suspected SARS. Her condition is stable.\nInvestigations have revealed that a resident of the nursing home was\nadmitted to CGH on 25 Mar 2003 and died of pneumonia on 30 Mar 2003. This\nnursing home resident had been earlier discharged from TTSH on 23 Mar 2003\nfor non-SARS related condition. When the patient was in TTSH she was warded\nnext to a patient who was later diagnosed as a SARS case. The male nurse\nfrom the nursing home had been attending to this resident.\nUpdate on cluster of SGH staff\nArising from the transfer of staff and patients of SGH Wards 57 and 58, a\ntotal of 29 have been admitted to the SARS wards. Of these, there are 4\nprobable SARS cases (a doctor and 2 nurses), 18 suspected SARS cases and 7\nadmitted for observation. They are all stable.\nThere were a total of 346 patients who were discharged from Wards 57 & 58\nduring the period 20 Mar 2003 - 5 Apr 2003. So far, 284 have been contacted\nabout their well being. All of them including their immediate family\nmembers and friends who visited them when they were in SGH are well.\nAs an assurance, visitors who went to Wards 57 and 58 at SGH from 20 Mar\n2003 to 5 Apr 2003 may call SGH hotline at 6321-3591 between 8.00 AM and\n10.00 PM for free health checks to ensure their well-being. Investigations\nare on-going to determine the source of infection for these hospital staff.\n2 SARS patients in intensive care passed away today. One is the mother of\nthe first index case and the other a TTSH doctor who had attended to a SARS\npatient before she had been diagnosed with SARS. This patient has since\npassed away on 29 Mar 2003.\nToday, 7 passengers from affected areas required further screening by the\nnurses at the airport. None were referred to TTSH for further assessment.\nNo passenger vessels that had a travel history to SARS affected areas in\nthe last 10 days arrived today.\nThe Ministry would like to reiterate that we have taken steps to safeguard\nour public transport system. There is thus no need for commuters to avoid\ntaxis, buses or the MRT in fear of contracting SARS.\nSpecial arrangements have been made for 4 categories of persons with a\nhigher likelihood of getting SARS:\n(a) Persons with Home Quarantine Order who would have come into direct\ncontact with a SARS patient\n(b) Cases identified by General Practitioners and private dentists\n(c) Incoming passengers from affected countries who received a Health Alert\nNotice; and\n(d) Cases identified during medical screening at Changi Airport and\nSingapore Cruise Centre\nPeople belonging to any of the above categories who develop SARS symptoms\nshould call the hotline number that they have been given. Upon receiving\nsuch calls, MOH will arrange for a private ambulance to pick them up and\nsend them to TTSH directly for medical assessment. These people should not\ntake public transport or call relatives for transport arrangements.\nSummary: to date, the total number of people diagnosed with SARS is 113.\nAmong these are 3 children below 18 years of age. Out of the 31 patients\nstill hospitalised, 12 are in intensive care. Since yesterday, there were 2\ndeaths and 1 new admission to intensive care who is the nurse from the\nprivate nursing home.\nApart from the first imported case, the 6 other imported cases have not\ngiven rise to any SARS cases.\nThe number of suspect cases admitted is 73, including 3 children (below 18\nyears old). The number of people under Home Quarantine Orders is 133.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 7 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Taiwan - Department of Health [accessed 7 Apr 2003 10:30 AM EST;\nedited]\n<http://203.65.72.83/En/dpc/ShowPublication.ASP?RecNo=844>\n\nThe majority SARS are imported, no community spread\nAs of 6 Apr 2003, with 3 new imported cases and one new probable case\ninfected by close contact with a Hong Kong case, a cumulative total of 19\nprobable cases have been identified in Taiwan. 5 of them have been\ndischarged, and the other 14 are still hospitalized.\nThe SARS outbreak in Taiwan is mainly sporadic and imported, with only 4\ncases resulting from close contact (limited to primary transmission.) When\nlooking into the case data, 3 close contact with probable cases raised from\nthe 1st case; the 4th close contact case could have been avoided had his\nbrother not traveled while ill.\n3 of the 4 newly identified probable cases are imported from various parts\nof China. The flights taken were CX402 on 30 Mar 2003 and BR818 on 23 Mar\n2003. One of the residents of Amoy Gardens, Hong Kong, flew to Taiwan to\nvisit his brother on 26 Mar 2003 (CX460, seat 35G). He stayed for 3 days\nand returned to Hong Kong on 28 Mar 2003 (CX511, seat 42H). He was reported\nto be symptomatic before 26 Mar 2003 and was hospitalized after returning\nto Hong Kong, and his Taiwanese brother was also hospitalized on 3 Apr 2003\nbecause of fever and pneumonia. The Center for Disease Control had the list\nof all passengers sitting in the same seat row and within 3 rows in front\nof or behind on the same flights (n=51). We have initiated follow-up for\nthe 25 Taiwanese passengers [in this possibly exposed group].\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5]\nDate: 7 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website 7 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome: Report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States (reported to the WHO on 6 Apr 2003)\n*Case definition (<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>)\nState: No. suspected cases under investigation*\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 38\nColorado: 5\nConnecticut: 2\nFlorida: 5\nGeorgia: 2\nHawaii: 5\nIllinois: 7\nKansas: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 4\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nMinnesota: 5\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 3\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 5\nNew York: 21\nOhio: 5\nOregon: 1\nPennsylvania: 5\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 4\nUtah: 5\nVermont: 2\nVirginia: 2\nWashington: 9\nWisconsin: 1\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 148\n[There are now reports of suspected cases from 30 of the 50 states in the\nUSA. There\nhave been 10 deaths in Canada. To date, all Canadian cases have occurred in\npersons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the\nhousehold or in a health-care setting. The information contained in this\nupdate is based on the best available information Health Canada has at this\ntime.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 88 probable and 100 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 3 probable and 23 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting 2 suspect cases.\nSaskatchewan is reporting 1 suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\nThese numbers are accurate as of 1:00 PM EDST 7 Apr 2003.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[7]\nDate: 7 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Newswire briefs [edited]\n\n[A] China - from ABC news 7 Apr 2003\n<http://abcnews.go.com/wire/Living/ap20030407_733.html>\nChinese officials had reported 43 SARS deaths in the southern province of\nGuangdong, where experts suspect the illness originated, with fatalities\nalso coming in Beijing and the Guangxi region. On Monday, Chinese state\ntelevision reported that there were also one SARS death each in the\nprovinces of Shanxi in the north, Sichuan in the west, and Hunan in central\nChina, the first fatalities in those areas, and an indication the disease\nwas more widespread geographically than previously acknowledged.\n[B] Vietnam - from an AFP newswire report\nThe 5 new cases, confirmed at Hanoi's Bach Mai hospital over the weekend\ninclude a doctor who treated a 67-year-old man hospitalised last Wednesday\nin serious condition and 4 members of his family. All the new patients come\nfrom Ninh Binh province, 100 kilometers (62 miles) south of Hanoi. The\n67-year-old, whose son had undergone surgery in the SARS-hit French\nhospital in Hanoi, apparently constitutes a new source of the\ndisease. Another man who came into close contact with him in Ninh Binh was\nalso hospitalized, on Thursday, bringing the province's suspected cases to\n7. Local health workers in Ninh Binh province have quarantined about 50\npeople who had contact with the initial patient.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[According to the WHO statistics presented in [1][A], as of today, there is\na cumulative total of 2601 cases of SARS, with 98 deaths, reported from 17\ncountries. The reports\nfrom both these regions suggest a few isolated incidences of secondary\ntransmission to close family contacts. Data submitted\ntoday report cases for 1 and 2 Apr 2003 and show an increase of 30 cases,\nwith 3 deaths, when compared with the previous cumulative total for 31 Mar\n2003.\nFor 1 Apr 2003, 10 cases, with 1 death, occurred in Guangdong Province, and\n7 cases and no deaths were reported in Shanxi Province. For 2 Apr 2003, 10\ncases, with 1 death were reported in Guangdong Province, 2 cases and no\ndeaths in Shanxi Province, and 1 case and 1 death in Hunan Province.\nThe new data increase the cumulative number of cases in China, up to 2 Apr,\nfrom 1190 to 1220 cases, and from 46 to 49 deaths.\nToday's table showing cumulative cases and deaths for all countries\nreporting suspected cases is being updated to reflect the new figures.\nUpdate on cases and countries\n--------------------------\nAs of today and including the new data from China, a cumulative total of\n2353 SARS cases and 84 deaths have been reported from 16 countries. This\nrepresents an increase of 83 cases and 5 deaths compared with yesterday.\nThe deaths occurred in Canada (1), China (3), and Singapore (1).\nNew cases were reported in Canada (7), China (30), Hong Kong SAR (27),\nTaiwan, China (1), Singapore (2), and the United States of America (15).\nSituation in Hong Kong SAR\n-------------------------\nThe Department of Health has reported that 27 additional patients with\nsymptoms of atypical pneumonia were admitted to public hospitals today. The\nnew patients include 5 health care workers and 8 residents of the Amoy\nGardens housing estate. The remaining 14 were new patients and contacts of\npatients with atypical pneumonia.\nOf the 26 new patients reported yesterday, 2 were health care workers, 2\nwere residents of Amoy Gardens, and 22 were new patients and contacts of\npatients with atypical pneumonia.\nHealth authorities are current investigating sewage samples at a\nconstruction site adjacent to Block E apartment building in Amoy Gardens,\nwhich has been the source of a large cluster of new SARS cases. New cases\nhave been associated with vertically linked apartments.\nA second line of investigation is concentrating on a burst sewage pipe in\nblock E that may have epidemiological links with a visitor to Amoy Gardens\nwho was subsequently admitted to Hong Kong's Prince of Wales Hospital in\nearly March 2003 and was said to have been symptomatic at the time of his\nvisit.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[There is an excellent overall review article with recommendations related\nto travel and management of suspected cases during airline travel in this\nweek's WER accessible at: <http://www.who.int/wer/pdf/2003/wer7814.pdf>.\nThe WER article also contains the template questionnaire for data\ncollection on SARS cases to allow for uniform data collection and analyses.\nThere is an additional information piece on travel advice at\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/2003_04_04a/en/>\nthat repeats the advice of 3 Apr 2003, recommending holding off\nnon-essential travel to China's Guangdong Province and Hong Kong SAR -\nMod.MPP]\n******\n[2]\nDate: 4 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 4 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 4 Apr 2003, an additional 27 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals. They include 5 healthcare\nworkers and 8 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 14 were new\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 99 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have been\ndischarged from public hospitals. Of them, one was discharged today. Most\nof the patients currently in hospital are showing positive responses to the\nnew treatment protocol. 103 patients are receiving treatment in intensive\ncare unit.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n(The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)\nTotal No. cases/ Total No. Discharged Patients/ Total No. of Deaths *\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students: 182 (182)/\n53/ 17\nPatients, family members & visitors: 579 (579)/ 46/\nTotal: 761 (761)/ 99/\n* Most of the deaths occurred in individuals who have a history of\nchronic diseases, or were patients who sought treatment at a relatively\nlate stage of infection.\nWith the approach of Ching Ming Festival, the Department of Health called\non grave-sweepers to maintain good personal and environmental hygiene to\nprevent atypical pneumonia. They should avoid touching the eyes, nose, and\nmouth, and if necessary, wash hands before touching them. Wearing a\nfacemask properly also offers satisfactory protection against respiratory\ntract infections. They should also avoid visiting crowded places and using\npublic transports that are poorly ventilated.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 4 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 4 Apr 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5880>\n\nSituation update 3 Apr 2003\n------------------------\nAs of 3 Apr 2003, there were 2 additional SARS cases reported, which\nincludes 1 more death. The total number of people who have recovered from\nSARS and have been discharged from hospital is 63. 32 patients are\nhospitalised, out of which 12 are in serious condition (including the\nfourth imported case). The cumulative total number of SARS cases [is] 100.\n5th SARS Death\n--------------\nThe first new case is a 78-year-old woman who was admitted into Tan Tock\nSeng Hospital from 20-24 Mar 2003 for steroid-induced gastritis. She has\nmultiple medical problems including severe lung disease unrelated to SARS.\nShe was admitted to NUH from 25-27 Mar for chest pain and she received\ntreatment for this. She did not have fever at that time. She was again\nadmitted to NUH on 31 Mar 2003. The diagnosis at the time of her latest\nadmission to NUH was a worsening of her lung disease. She did not have any\nfever prior to this admission to NUH. It was only on 1 Apr 2003 that she\ndeveloped a fever and was transferred to an isolation room at NUH. In view\nof her fever, worsening medical condition, and history of being admitted to\nTTSH, a diagnosis of SARS was made and she was transferred to TTSH on 2 Apr\n2003 and passed away just before midnight.\nUpdate on Ngee Ann Polytechnic Student\n---------------------------------------\nThe second new case of SARS is a 20-year-old Malay student of Class 6B03\nNgee Ann Polytechnic, who was admitted to Tan Tock Seng Hospital on 30 Mar\n2003 for suspected SARS. He is the son of the 4th SARS patient who died in\nNUH on 31 Mar 2003. The deceased was diagnosed as a SARS case on 30 Mar\n2003. The Ngee Ann student was diagnosed to be a SARS case today, and is\ncurrently in intensive care.\nOn 29 Mar 2003, he called up his project teammate to inform him that he was\nnot attending class as he was unwell. He then walked to the Bukit Batok\nPolyclinic. At the Polyclinic, he was immediately triaged according to\nstandard procedure. As he was having fever, he was separated from the rest\nof the patients. The doctor and staff who attended to him in the isolation\nroom were masked, gowned, and gloved. He was seen by the polyclinic doctor\nat about 9.20 AM. During the consultation with the doctor, he told the\ndoctor that his mother was in intensive care at the National University\nHospital.\nHe was then transferred to the Accident and Emergency Department of Tan\nTock Seng Hospital (TTSH) by ambulance at about 10.20 AM. During the\nconsultation with the doctor, he told the doctor that his mother had\ntravelled to Sarawak and that she was in NUH. There was no indication at\nthat time that his mother had visited a friend in TTSH. In view that there\nwas no contact history for SARS, he was discharged with advice to return if\nhe continued to feel unwell. He was also put on daily telephone\nsurveillance by TTSH. On 30 Mar 2003, TTSH called him at home. Since he was\nstill unwell, an ambulance was sent to bring him from his home to the A&E\nDept of TTSH at about 17.30 PM. He was then admitted to TTSH.\nSo far, 25 close contacts have been identified and Home Quarantine Orders\nhave been issued.\nSafeguarding Public Transport\n-----------------------\nTo minimise public exposure to SARS, MOH has made special arrangements for\n4 categories of persons with a higher likelihood of being SARS patients to\nbe transported to TTSH by private ambulance, so that they would not need to\nuse the public transport system. The 4 categories are :\n(a) Persons on Home Quarantine Order who develop SARS symptoms;\n(b) Cases identified by General Practitioners and private dentists;\n(c) Incoming Passengers who receive Travel Advisory and develop SARS\nsymptoms subsequently; and\n(d) Cases identified during medical screening at Changi Airport and\nSingapore Cruise Centre.\nOn notification of above cases, MOH will arrange for a private ambulance to\npick them up and send them to TTSH directly for medical assessment.\nSummary of SARS cases\n---------------------\nBoth new cases are linked to the first index case. To date, 93 cases have\narisen from the first index case, comprising 47 family members, friends or\nclose contacts, and 46 hospital staff. Among these are 3 children below 18\nyears of age.\nSo far, apart from the first imported case, the 6 other imported cases have\nnot given rise to any SARS cases.\nThe number of suspect cases admitted is 38, including 2 children (below 18\nyears old).\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 4 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Eurosurveillance Weekly 4 Apr 2003 Volume 7 Issue 14 [edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ew/2003/030403.asp>\n\nSARS: the situation in France - 3 Apr 2003\n---------------------------------\nSince an epidemic alert was released in France on 13 Mar 2003 (1), 216\npeople with symptoms of respiratory infection returning from Vietnam,\nChina, Hong Kong, or Singapore were notified to the national Public Health\nInstitute (Institut de veille sanitaire, InVS) (2). Of these, 201 were\nexcluded after clinical, radiological, biological, and epidemiological\nevaluation of their compatibility with Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n(SARS).\nAs of 3 Apr 2003, 12 patients are still under surveillance. 3 probable\ncases of SARS have been identified and are currently hospitalised in\nisolation. The first case was a traveller who returned from Hanoi (Vietnam)\non 23 Mar 2003. The date of onset of symptoms of the latter 2 cases was 26\nMar 2003 and 30 Mar 2003, respectively. Their link with other SARS cases is\nunder investigation.\nIn France, the health authorities and the ministry of foreign affairs have\nadvised against travel to Hong Kong and China (Beijing, Guangdong, and\nShanxi provinces) and recommended postponing travel to other affected areas\n(3). Travellers returning from Hong Kong, Beijing, Guangdong,and Shanxi\nprovinces in China, Taiwan, Hanoi, Toronto, and Singapore are asked to fill\nin an identification form upon arrival at the international\nCharles-de-Gaulle airport in France. A similar surveillance procedure was\nimplemented for charter flights landing in other airports in France. People\nreturning from southeast Asia who develop respiratory symptoms with a fever\nabove 38 C within 10 days of landing are advised to contact the emergency\non-call service, and not to directly consult hospital emergency wards or\ntheir physician.\nReferences :\n1. The agent causing SARS is under intensive international\nstudy, but as of today it has not been fully characterized, and there is no\nvaccine or other prophylaxis available.\nSince WHO issued the global alert on 12 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_03_12/en/> national authorities\nhave implemented heightened surveillance for cases of SARS, and where such\ncases have been identified their prompt isolation has prevented further\nspread of the disease in virtually all countries. For instance the outbreak\nin Hanoi has passed its peak and no new cases have been identified for the\nlast week. Last week WHO issued recommendations aimed at further limiting\nthe spread of SARS and protecting international air passengers. These\nrecommendations still apply -- see WHO recommends new measures to prevent\ntravel-related spread of SARS at:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_03_27/en/>\nThe SARS situation in Hong Kong SAR has developed features of concern: a\ncontinuing and significant increase in cases with indications that SARS has\nspread beyond the initial focus in hospitals. These developments have\nsuggested environmental routes of transmission from a SARS infected person\nwhich may be related to contamination of common systems that link rooms or\nflats together. Despite the implementation of strict measures to control\nthe outbreak, there have continued to be a small number of visitors to Hong\nKong who have been identified as SARS cases after their return from Hong\nKong. The epidemic in Guangdong Province of China, situated adjacent to\nHong Kong, is the largest outbreak of SARS reported and has also shown\nevidence of spread in the wider community.\n***As a measure of precaution WHO is now recommending that persons\ntravelling to Hong Kong and Guangdong Province of China consider postponing\nall but essential travel. This temporary recommendation will be reassessed\nin the light of the evolution of the epidemic in the areas currently\nindicated, and other areas of the world could become subject to similar\nrecommendations if the situation demands. Please note that this\nrecommendation applies only to travellers entering Hong Kong SAR China and\nGuangdong Province of China, not to passengers directly transiting through\ninternational airports within those areas..***[asterisks added by ProMED -\nMod.JW].\n* WHO has defined affected areas as an area in which local chain(s) of\ntransmission of SARS is/are occurring as reported by the national public\nhealth authorities. The list of areas changes over time and the latest\nupdate can be found at: Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n(SARS) <http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/en/>\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 2 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_02a/en/>\n\nUpdate 18 - SARS outbreak:WHO investigation team moves to China, new travel\nadvice announced\nPress release issued by WHO 2 Apr 2003\n------------------------------\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) today said that the Government of China\nhad announced the WHO expert team currently in Beijing will travel to\nGuangdong Province to investigate the SARS outbreak there. 'These are very\npositive steps taken today by China,' said Dr David Heymann, Executive\nDirector of Communicable Diseases at WHO. 'As a result we'll be able to\ngather even more evidence about the nature of the SARS outbreak in China.'\n***In addition, WHO began recommending that persons travelling to Hong Kong\nSAR and Guangdong Province, China consider postponing all but essential\ntravel. This updated travel advice comes as a result of new developments,\nparticularly in Hong Kong, in the multi-country outbreak of Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome (SARS). This temporary recommendation will be\nreassessed daily as the epidemic evolves. The recommendation does not apply\nto passengers simply transiting through airports in Hong Kong Special\nAdministrative Region or Guangdong Province, China.***[asterisks added by\nProMED - Mod.JW].\nThe new travel advisory is intended to limit the spread of SARS by reducing\ntravel to high risk areas. All other elements of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (SARS) WHO previous travel guidance still stand.\nThe SARS situation in Hong Kong SAR, China has developed unique features.\nThere is a continuing and significant increase in cases* with indications\nthat SARS has spread beyond the initial focus in hospitals. These\ndevelopments raise questions related to other possible routes of\ntransmission of SARS. These may involve transport of the virus from one\nperson to another via some type of environmental means. To date, no\nsatisfactory explanation has been found regarding this possibility. Also,\nsince 19 Mar 2003, 9 travellers have been identified as SARS cases on\nreturning from a visit to Hong Kong SAR of China.\nMany questions about the state of the outbreak in Guangdong Province, China\nwhich borders Hong Kong have yet to be answered. The Guangdong outbreak is\nthe largest reported and has also shown evidence of spread in the wider\ncommunity. New information provided today by provincial authorities of more\nthan 300 new cases in March [2003] alone indicates the outbreak there\ncontinues.\nUnprecedented global cooperation helps advance knowledge and containment of\nSARS\n--------------\nIn the 4 weeks that WHO has been tracking SARS much has been learned. This\nis largely because scientists, clinicians, laboratory chiefs and public\nhealth officials everywhere have collaborated closely.\nAs a result of WHO's global alert issued on 15 Mar 2003, national\nauthorities have implemented heightened surveillance for cases of SARS.\nWhile an increasing number of countries are reporting new cases, these\ncases are quickly identified, patients are isolated and local transmission\nis stopped in most countries.\nIt is now known that infection control methods work to contain the spread\nof SARS in hospitals, even in countries which do not have the most modern\nequipment.\nWHO and a network of 11 of the world's top laboratories are zeroing in on\nthe cause of SARS and a diagnostic test is being developed. This test will\nhelp distinguish between those who are infected and those who are free of\nthe SARS virus.\nThe laboratory network is continuing its investigations. So far, the agent\ncausing SARS has not been fully characterized and there is no certain\ntreatment, vaccine or known other preventative measure.\n'There will be other new diseases that will emerge in the future, and we\nwill respond just as we have with SARS -- with maximum efforts to contain\nits spread,' stated Dr Gu\u00e9na\u00ebl Rodier, Director, Communicable Disease\nSurveillance and Response, WHO.\n* Cases of SARS and the countries in which they appear are posted on the\nWHO web site every evening in Geneva, Switzerland.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 2 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website 2 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_02_02b/en/>\nUpdate 19 - China deepens its collaboration to contain SARS, WHO revises\nits advice to international travellers as new data come in\n---------------------------\nNew data from China, WHO team leaving immediately for Guangdong\nChinese authorities have today announced updated figures for the number of\ncases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and deaths in Guangdong\nProvince. This\nupdated travel advice comes as a result of new developments in the\nmulti-country outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome\n(SARS).'***[asterisks added by ProMED - Mod.JW].\n\nThe new travel advice is intended to limit further international spread of\nSARS by restricting travel [into] areas where the transmission patterns of\nSARS\nare not fully understood. The SARS situation, which is rapidly evolving, is\nunder constant assessment by WHO in collaboration with three global\nnetworks of experts. The new advice is issued as part of a series of\nmeasures that will change as more information about SARS becomes available.\nNew data on international spread\n-----------------------------\nOvernight, WHO received reports on 9 persons, with a history of travel to\nHong Kong dating from 15 Mar 2003, who subsequently developed symptoms\nsuggesting probable cases of SARS when they travelled to other countries.\nThese 9 cases of probable SARS, related to travel in Hong Kong, occurred in\nTaiwan, Province of China, and Singapore. The data on these cases, and what\nis known about the incubation period of SARS, indicate that travel to Hong\nKong can contribute to the international spread of SARS.\n15 Mar 2003 is the date when WHO issued its first SARS-related emergency\ntravel advisory, which increased global awareness of this new disease, made\ntravellers and health staff alert to symptoms, and initiated prompt\nreporting of cases.\nThe SARS outbreak in Hong Kong SAR has developed an unusual pattern of\ntransmission. This pattern is different from what is being seen in the vast\nmajority of other SARS outbreaks, and is not yet fully understood. The\nnumber of cases is continuing to increase significantly, and there is\nevidence that the disease has spread beyond the initial focus in hospitals.\nThese developments raise questions related to other routes of transmission,\nin addition to well-documented face-to-face exposure to droplets released\nwhen an infected person coughs or sneezes. Epidemiologists are considering\nwhether SARS is being transmitted in Hong Kong by some environmental means\nfor which no satisfactory explanation has been found. Particular concern\ncentres on a large cluster of cases linked to residential buildings in the\nAmoy Garden housing estate in the Kowloon [mainland] district of Hong Kong.\nHistorical perspective\n---------------\nThis is the first time in the history of WHO that such travel advice has\nbeen issued for specific geographical areas because of an outbreak of an\ninfectious disease.\nSince 1958, WHO has issued weekly lists of areas infected with\nquarantinable diseases so that national authorities can decide whether to\napply public health measures to arriving travellers. During the last years\nof the smallpox eradication campaign cases spread internationally by land.\nControls at borders between neighbouring countries were relied on to\nprevent international spread. No global recommendations were necessary.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Our continuing thanks and gratitude to Marianne Hopp <mjh12@yahoo.com> for\nher role as WHO notifications rapporteur.\nThe major increase in reported cases in the past 24 hours (from 1804 cases\nand 62 deaths to 2223 cases and 78 deaths) is primarily attributable to the\n361 cases and 9 deaths reported to have occurred in Guangdong China during\nthe period 1-31 Mar 2003, and represent a one month incidence and not a 24\nhour incidence increase. This\nrepresents an increase of 182 cases and 4 deaths compared with the previous\nday.\nThe largest increase occurred in Hong Kong, where 155 new cases were\nreported. This brings the cumulative total of cases in Hong Kong to 685\ncases with 16 deaths.\nOf the 4 new SARS deaths, 3 occurred in Hong Kong. The fourth death was\nreported in Singapore.\nChina remains the country with the largest number of cases. According to\nofficial reports, 806 cases with 34 deaths have occurred. The majority of\nthese cases and deaths were associated with an outbreak in Guangdong\nProvince. During that outbreak, authorities recorded 792 cases and 31\ndeaths from 16 Nov 2002 through 28 Feb 2003.\nOther countries reporting additional cases include Canada (9), Taiwan,\nChina (3), Italy (1) Singapore (1), Thailand (1), and the United States of\nAmerica (10). Australia and Belgium reported their first probable cases\ntoday.\nIn Viet Nam, where hospitals in Hanoi were among the earliest to experience\na rapid burst of cases within a health care setting, the number of cases\n(58) and deaths (4) remained stable for the eighth day in a row. The\nincubation period for SARS is currently believed to range from 2 to 10\ndays. WHO epidemiologists regard [this] 8-day period with no newly detected\ncases as an encouraging sign that the outbreak in Hanoi has been controlled\nand that no further spread is occurring beyond the initial hospital foci.\nSingapore, another country that was hard hit at the beginning of the\nepidemic, is likewise showing a stable pattern, with cases confined to\nwell-documented risk groups and few new cases being detected.\nAn evolving epidemic, SARS is a newly identified disease with transmission\npatterns that are only beginning to emerge and thus difficult to interpret.\nMuch about the disease remains poorly understood, despite great progress in\ncharacterization of the causative virus and development of a robust\ndiagnostic test.\nParticularly puzzling are the great differences between areas where\noutbreaks appear to have been fairly rapidly contained and confined to\nhealth care settings and persons in close face-to-face contact with\npatients, and other areas, such as Hong Kong and Toronto, where\ntransmission is continuing despite the prompt isolation of patients and\nintroduction of strict barrier nursing practices.\nWHO has established a set of priority issues requiring urgent scientific\ninvestigation. More studies are needed about how the disease is spread, the\nstages of the disease when virus is shed, which bodily secretions carry the\nvirus, and whether certain secretions are more infectious than others.\nResearchers also need to understand whether persons infected with SARS\nbecome more infectious at a certain stage in the course of the disease, and\nwhether factors such as age or underlying disease influence severity and\nprognosis.\nSome of the world's foremost scientists and clinicians are now\ncollaborating around the clock, through 3 WHO networks of 'virtual' labs\nand clinics, to find answers to these questions. Evidence can then form the\nbasis for more precise public health advice on how to prevent further\nspread both internationally and within those countries where cases have\noccurred. Based on more than 5 decades of experience, WHO maintains the\nposition that good surveillance and response will contain any infectious\ndiseases.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 1 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 1 Apr 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n[A] Daily update 1 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs at 1 PM 1 Apr 2003, 5 more patients are recovered. This brought to 84\nthe total number of patients who have recovered from atypical\npneumonia and have been discharged from public hospitals.\nMost of the 601 patients currently in hospital are showing positive\nresponses to the new treatment protocol. 67 of them are receiving treatment\nin an intensive care unit.\nMeanwhile, an additional 75 patients with symptoms of atypical pneumonia\nwere admitted to public hospitals. They include 4 healthcare workers and 52\npatients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 19 were new patients and contacts\nof patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA 83-year-old man died in United Christian Hospital, bringing to 16 the\ntotal number of deaths relating to atypical pneumonia. Most of the deaths\noccurred in individuals who have a history of chronic diseases, or were\npatients who sought treatment at a relatively late stage of infection.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows:\n(The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 168 (168)\n49 of the patients were discharged\nPatients, family members & visitors 517 (517)\n35 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admission 685 (685)\n84 were discharged\n[B] Residents of Block E moved to holiday villages 1 Apr 2003\nDeputy Director of Health, Dr P Y Leung, said residents of Block E at Amoy\nGardens were being moved tonight (1 Apr 2003) into 2 holiday villages in\nSai Kung and Lei Yue Mun.\nHe said the residents of the block, which has seen a high incidence of\natypical pneumonia, would be kept at Lady MacLehose Holiday Village and Lei\nYue Mun Park Holiday Village until the end of the isolation order.\nDr Leung said health officials were now investigating whether environmental\nfactors could have contributed to the spread of the disease at Amoy Gardens.\nThe operation was being jointly carried out by the Department of Health,\nthe Police and Civil Aid Service. Dr Leung said the residents would be\nprovided with daily necessities and food during their stay at the holiday\nvillages. They would also be given regular medical checks. He said Block E\nwas still under isolation orders and would be under Police protection to\nensure residents' flats were not broken into.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 1 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada\n[A] Update 17 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 1 Apr 2003 7:00 PM\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update17.htm\n>\nMore Health Canada Support for Ontario\nHealth Canada has deployed 6 staff to assist Toronto's public health unit\nand the Ontario Ministry of Health with the investigation of the SARS\ncases. The department has also provided guidelines for infection control\nand recommendations on actions for public health settings. Health Canada is\ndeploying an additional 6 personnel to Ontario this week.\nHealth Canada's SARS Screening Initiative at Pearson Airport is Being\nRolled-Out Today\n--------------\nEffective 1 Apr 2003, Health Canada is informing all departing travellers\nfrom Pearson International Airport about SARS through the Health Alert\nNotice (cherry cards). The local airport authority has placed the Health\nAlert Notices and posters at strategic locations at the Pearson\nInternational Airport informing travellers who meet certain criteria to\ndefer their flights. These criteria include: having SARS symptoms (fever,\ncough, shortness of breath and difficulty breathing); having been in\ncontact with a SARS-affected person in the last 10 days; and, having\nvisited a health facility that has been identified by public health\nofficials as being affected by SARS.\nIf passengers have visited a SARS-affected facility or have had contact\nwith a SARS-affected person, they are instructed to call their local health\ndepartment.\nA Health Canada SARS Team of physicians and nurses have been deployed to\nPearson to provide information to airline and airport staff.\nLatest Canadian Numbers on SARS\n----------------------------\nAs of 1 Apr 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately 151\nprobable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nCanada. There have been 6 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting. The information\ncontained in this update is based on the best available information Health\nCanada has at this time.\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting 56 probable and 68 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 12 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.\nSaskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 7 suspect cases.\nPrince Edward Island is reporting 4 suspect cases.\n[B] Summary of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) Cases: 31 Mar 2003\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/sars20030331_e.html>\nLatest Case Counts: Since yesterday, 9 additional probable cases have been\nreported in Canada. A total of 53 individuals who meet the probable case\ndefinition of SARS have been reported in Ontario and British Columbia,\nincluding 4 deaths. In addition, a total of 76 individuals who meet the\ndefinition of a suspect case of SARS have been reported in British\nColumbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan, Ontario and New Brunswick. Since SARS is a\ndiagnosis of exclusion, the status of a reported case may change over time.\nThus, previously reported cases may be discarded after further\ninvestigation and follow-up. The current number of probable cases by\nreported symptom onset date and type of exposure is also provided\n(Figure 1) [see webpage.\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/sars20030331_e.html>\nRecent Ontario Epidemiologic Findings: The Ontario Ministry of Health and\nLong-Term Care has reported a total of 51 probable cases of SARS. Of these,\nmost remain hospitalised for isolation purposes and only 2 are currently in\nintensive care. All 4 deaths were associated with individuals with\nunderlying illness, and all but one occurred in elderly patients. Using the\ninformation currently available, the average age of probable cases is 46.5\nyears (n=37, range 17 to 82 years), with 26 known females and 17 known\nmales.\nWhile it is difficult to conclusively determine the incubation period of\nthe etiologic agent, given the fact that many of the probable cases in\nOntario may have multiple exposures, the current estimated mean incubation\nperiod is 4 days (estimated range 2 to 10 days).\nIt is believed that 4 generations of transmission have occurred. The index\ncase in Ontario was an individual who travelled to Hong Kong and stayed at\nthe Metropole Hotel, where a cluster of SARS cases has since been reported.\nUpon return to Canada, disease transmission occurred in 4 members of the\nimmediate and extended family. A physician who had close contact with\nmembers of this family was also diagnosed with SARS. Following this, cases\nwere reported in individuals in a hospital setting where some of the first\ncases were treated. Most recently, SARS has been reported in a few of the\nhousehold contacts of these hospital-associated cases. An isolated case in\nOntario was reported in an individual who had travelled to Asia, but did\nnot stay in at the Metropole Hotel.\nBased on the most recent epidemiologic investigations, nearly all of the\nprobable cases of SARS that occurred in individuals outside of the initial\nfamily cluster have been linked either directly or indirectly back to\nexposure to the first hospitalised case of SARS, on 7 Mar 2003. It is\nbelieved that disease transmission occurred mainly as a result of\nperson-to-person contact. The initial hospital-associated cases are thought\nto have contracted the illness as a result of unprotected contact with the\ninitial cases prior to the recognition of SARS. Subsequent transmission may\nhave then occurred between households of these hospital-associated cases,\nand between other healthcare workers. To date, there has been no evidence\nof transmission in the general community. Furthermore, there is presently\nno evidence to suggest that disease transmission occurs prior to the onset\nof fever in a suspected or probable case of SARS.\nOther Reports: A Canadian with SARS [not counted in the official Canadian\ncase count], who is currently hospitalised in Hong Kong, stayed at the\nMetropole Hotel, as did the first identified probable case of SARS in\nBritish Columbia. However, while a second probable case reported by BC did\nnot stay at this hotel, this individual was exposed to a SARS case while in\nHong Kong. Both BC cases are currently in isolation and there is no\nevidence of further spread in the province. The 11 suspected cases\ncurrently under investigation are all associated with travel-related\nexposures.\nOntario has declared a provincial emergency and SARS is now a reportable\ndiseases under Ontario's Health Protection and Promotion Act. The province\nhas introduced a number of public measures in an effort to contain the\nspread of SARS. Key public health measures include: extensive contact\ntracing of persons who may have come in contact with SARS cases, isolation\nof suspect and probable cases, and voluntary home quarantine for\nasymptomatic contacts. Isolation wards have been established at hospitals\nand health care staff are required to observe full airborne and contact\nprecautions. Health care staff across the province are now alerted to SARS\nand have implemented infection control practices to protect themselves and\ntheir patients in an effort to prevent any further infection.\n\nTable 1\nCumulative Number of SARS Cases Reported in Canada, 31 Mar 2003\nProvince/Territory Individuals Meeting the Criteria for a:\nProbable Case(1)/ Suspect Case(1)/ Death\nBritish Columbia: 2/ 11/ 0\nAlberta: 0/ 5/ 0\nSaskatchewan: 0/ 1/ 0\nOntario: 51/ 58/ 4\nNew Brunswick: 0/ 1/ 0\nTOTAL 53 76 4\n(1) These persons may drop off the probable or suspect case list if another\ncause if identified for their illness\nFigure 1: Number of probable cases of SARS in Canada by symptom onset date\nand exposure type from: 23 Feb 2003 to 31 Mar 2003 (n=38, excluding 15 for\nwhom onset dates are missing) [see webpage for graphic representation\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/sars20030331_e.html>]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 1 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Public Health Foundation E News\n<http://www.phf.org>\n\nCDC Broadcast information\n-----------------------\n'Preventing Spread of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)'\nA Public Health Training Network Live Satellite Broadcast, Webcast &\nAudiobridge\nFriday, April 4, 2003, 10:00 AM - 11:30 AM ET - Rebroadcast 2:00 - 3:30 PM\nET\nBroadcast/webcast/audiobridge information:\n<http://www.phppo.cdc.gov/PHTN/sars> (go to course overview at bottom of\npage)\nProgram description\nThis broadcast sponsored by the World Health Organization (WHO) and\nsupported by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will provide\ninformation on Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) reported in\npatients in Asia, North America, and Europe. The information contained in this update is based on\nthe best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nHealth Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspect\ncases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country.\n'Probable' cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they have\na more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficulty\nbreathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.\nA 'suspect' case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following 2\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a 'probable'\ncase of SARS (i.e., within one metre).\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario is reporting approximately 81 probable and suspect cases. Information on a global worldwide update was not available as of\nthe time of preparation of this update.\nWith the exception of the ongoing outbreak in Hong Kong (and possibly in\nmainland China), the outbreak of SARS in other areas seems to be following\na pattern consistent with a requirement of close contact with an actively\nill case of SARS for transmission to occur. One can't help but muse on the\ndefinition of close contact in different environments, and in those areas\nwith high population density, what might be a casual, non-close contact in\nother areas is close enough to allow for transmission in an area with\nhigher population density. This moderator is reminded of studies conducted\non the baseline incidence of poliomyelitis in India back in the early\n80s. It was generally accepted that polio was more of an 'urban disease'\nwith higher incidences observed in urban areas. Results of studies on the\nbaseline incidence of polio in a highly populated state revealed that the\nrural incidence was on a par with the urban incidence. Our interpretation\nof this observation was that the standard western definition of urban vs.\nrural was based on population density, where rural areas had a markedly\nlower population density than urban areas. In the highly populated\ndistricts of India, rural areas had population densities similar to many\nwestern urban areas. Hence, rather than being an urban disease, polio was\nmore of a high population density disease. Again, food for thought here...\n- Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A 'suspect' case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following 2\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a 'probable'\ncase of SARS (i.e., within one metre).
