To date, 91 cases have arisen from the first index\ncase, comprising 45 family members, friends, or close contacts, and 46\nhospital staff. Among these are 3 children below 18 years of age.\nA 7th imported case was reported today. She is a 42-year-old Indonesian\nwoman, the mother of the 5th imported case (17-year-old Indonesian\nstudent). She left Singapore for Hong Kong and Guangdong on 15 Mar 2003 and\nreturned to Singapore on 23 Mar 2003. She became unwell on 24 Mar 2003 and\nwas admitted to TTSH as a suspect SARS case on 25 Mar 2003.\nSo far, apart from the first imported case, the 6 other imported cases have\nnot given rise to any SARS cases.\nThe total number of people who have recovered from SARS and have been\ndischarged from hospital is 57. The remaining 37 patients are hospitalised,\nout of which 11 are in serious condition (including the fourth imported\ncase).\nThe number of suspect cases is 47, including 2 children (below 18 years\nold) and the 20-year-old student from Ngee Ann Polytechnic.\nDischarge and follow-up of SARS patients\n-------------------------------------\nSARS patients are discharged from TTSH and followed up in accordance with\nthe guidelines from the World Health Organisation (WHO). Upon discharge,\nSARS patients are given medical leave for 2 weeks and are required to stay\nat home. They are reviewed by the doctors at TTSH before they return to\nwork or school. During their 2 weeks' medical leave at home, their\ncondition is monitored by staff from TTSH through daily phone calls.\nUpdate on Children with SARS\n----------------------------\nOne of the children with SARS is the 4-year-old boy from Pat's Schoolhouse\nwhose condition remains stable. None of the children in the Schoolhouse\nhave developed SARS as of today, 12 days later.\nAnother is the 17-year-old brother of the above boy, who did not attend\nschool during the school holidays. He has since been discharged, together\nwith his 13-year-old sister from Pei Cai Secondary School, who was a\nsuspect SARS case.\nThe third child with SARS is the 17-year-old Indonesian boy from Bowen\nSecondary School. His condition is stable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 2 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada [edited]\n\n[A] Summary of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) Cases: 1 Apr 2003\n[2 Apr 2003 accessed 6:00 PM EST]\nLatest Case Counts\n-----------------\nSince yesterday, 5 additional probable cases of SARS and 2 deaths have been\nreported in Canada. A total of 58 individuals who meet the probable case\ndefinition of SARS have been reported in Ontario and British Columbia,\nincluding 6 deaths; 93 individuals who meet the definition of a suspect\ncase of SARS have also been reported in British Columbia, Alberta,\nSaskatchewan, Ontario, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island.\nSince SARS is a diagnosis of exclusion, the status of a reported case may\nchange over time. At the present time, the case fatality rate in Canada is\nestimated at approximately 4.0 percent of probable or suspect cases (N=151),\nwhich is similar to that reported by other countries, depending on the\ncriteria used to define a SARS case.\nTable 1: Cumulative Number of SARS Cases Reported in Canada: 1 Apr 2003\nProvince/Territory: Probable Case(1)/ Suspect Case(1)/ Deaths(2)\nBritish Columbia: 2/ 12/ 0\nAlberta: 0/ 7/ 0\nSaskatchewan: 0/ 1/ 0\nOntario: 56/ 68/ 6\nNew Brunswick: 0/ 1/ 0\nPrince Edward Island: 0/ 4/ 0\nTotal: 58/ 93/ 6\n(1) These persons may drop off the probable or suspect case list if another\ncause is identified for their illness\n(2) This figure is included in the number of probable cases\nSummary of Disease Transmission to Date\n----------------------------------\nThe Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care has reported a total of\n56 probable cases of SARS. It is believed that 4 generations of\ntransmission have occurred. The index case in Ontario was an individual who\ntravelled to Hong Kong and stayed at the Metropole Hotel, where a cluster\nof SARS cases has since been reported. Upon return to Canada, disease\ntransmission occurred in 4 members of the immediate and extended family. A\nphysician who had close contact with members of this family was also\ndiagnosed with SARS. Following this, cases were reported in individuals in\na hospital setting where some of the first cases were treated. Most\nrecently, SARS has been reported in a few of the household contacts of\nthese hospital-associated cases. To date, transmission of disease has\noccurred in household and hospital settings. There is no evidence of\ntransmission in the general community. An isolated case in Ontario was\nreported in an individual who had travelled to Asia, but did not stay in at\nthe Metropole Hotel.\nReports of the 2 probable cases from British Columbia have been linked to\ntravel-related exposure. The first identified probable case of SARS in\nBritish Columbia stayed at the Metropole Hotel, and the second individual\nwas exposed to a SARS case in Hong Kong. Both individuals are currently in\nisolation and there is no evidence of further spread in British Columbia.\nAll of the 12 suspected cases currently under investigation in BC are also\nassociated with travel-related exposures. A Canadian with SARS [not counted\nin the official Canadian case count], who is currently hospitalised in Hong\nKong, also stayed at the Metropole Hotel.\nPreliminary Descriptive Findings\n-----------------------------\nGiven the information currently available, the average age of probable\ncases in Canada is 46.2 years (n=45, range 2 to 82 years), with 31 females\nand 20 males. The current number of probable cases by reported symptom\nonset date and type of exposure is also provided (Figure 1 - Number of\nprobable cases of SARS in Canada by symptom onset date and exposure type\nfrom: 23 Feb 23 to 1 Apr 2003 (n=45, excluding 13 for whom onset dates or\nexposure classification are unknown))\n[see webpage for epidemic curve:\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030401_e.html>]\nTable 2: Known current status of probable cases in Canada: 1 Apr 2003\n(n=23, excluding 35 individuals whose status is either unknown or missing)\nStatus: Number of Cases/ Proportion\nImproving: 5/ 21.7 percent\nStable: 15/ 65.2 percent\nDeteriorating: 2/ 8.7 percent\nCritical: 1/ 4.4 percent\nTotal no. of probable cases with known status, currently hospitalised:\n23/100 percent\nPreliminary Epidemiologic Findings\n------------------------------\nTransmission: Based on the most recent epidemiologic investigations, nearly\nall of the probable cases of SARS in Ontario that occurred in individuals\noutside of the initial family cluster have been linked either directly or\nindirectly back to exposure to the first hospitalised case of SARS, on 7\nMar 2003. It is believed that disease transmission occurred mainly as a\nresult of person-to-person contact. The initial hospital-associated cases\nare thought to have contracted the illness as a result of unprotected\ncontact with the initial cases prior to the recognition of SARS. Subsequent\ntransmission may have then occurred between households of these\nhospital-associated cases, and between other healthcare workers. To date,\nthere has been no evidence of transmission in the general community.\nFurthermore, there is presently no evidence to suggest that disease\ntransmission occurs prior to the onset of fever in a suspected or probable\ncase of SARS.\nEstimated incubation period: While it is difficult to conclusively\ndetermine the incubation period of the etiologic agent, given the fact that\nmany of the probable cases in Ontario may have multiple exposures, the\ncurrent estimated mean incubation period is 4 days (estimated range 2 to 10\ndays).\nClinical Manifestations: The main signs and symptoms seen in cases of SARS\ninclude fever (greater than 38.0 degrees Celsius), cough and shortness of\nbreath. Symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection may not be\npresent. A few cases have developed increasing respiratory distress and\nrequire mechanical ventilation. In the majority of hospitalised cases, an\ninfiltrate on chest x-ray and lymphopenia is evident. In addition,\nthrombocytopenia (less than 150 000 / cubic mm), elevated creatinine kinase\nand elevated ALT/AST may be observed. The WHO is coordinating global\nefforts to better characterize the clinical manifestations of SARS. Because\nawareness and surveillance of the disease have increased worldwide, an\nincrease in the number of suspected cases is to be expected.\nSeverity of Illness: Of all of the probable cases reported to date, most\nremain hospitalised for isolation purposes and only 3 are now in intensive\ncare. All 6 deaths have been associated with individuals with underlying\nillness and all but one occurred in elderly patients. Of 32 probable cases\nfor whom hospitalisation status is known, 3 are currently in intensive\ncare. In addition, 2 of the 3 cases that required intubation have since\ndied.\nPublic Health Measures\n---------------------\nOntario has declared a provincial emergency and SARS is now a reportable\ndiseases under Ontario's Health Protection and Promotion Act. The province\nhas introduced a number of public measures in an effort to contain the\nspread of SARS. Key public health measures include: extensive contact\ntracing of persons who may have come in contact with SARS cases, isolation\nof suspect and probable cases, and voluntary home quarantine for\nasymptomatic contacts. Isolation wards have been established at hospitals\nand health care staff are required to observe full airborne and contact\nprecautions. Health care staff across the province are now alerted to SARS\nand have implemented infection control practices to protect themselves and\ntheir patients in an effort to prevent any further infection.\nHealth Canada is supporting Ontario in its SARS response efforts by\nproviding epidemiologic and infection control expertise, as well as\nemergency supplies as needed. Health Canada, in collaboration with the\nProvinces and Territories, has implemented enhanced surveillance for the\ndetection of SARS cases, alerted laboratories, and initiated special\nlaboratory investigations in an effort to identify the cause of SARS. In\naddition, Health Canada has initiated the first phase of implementing\nscreening procedures for all domestic and international travellers\ndeparting from Toronto, in response to the WHO recommendations to prevent\ntravel-related spread of SARS. In addition, due to recent concerns\nregarding the possibility of transmission of SARS aboard aircraft, Health\nCanada has also recommended the follow-up of all passengers on flights\nwhere a suspect or probable SARS case is identified. WORLDWIDE (16): ETIOLOGY\n20030328.0774], we have received many requests to communicate our PCR\nprimers and protocols for the detection of the coronavirus suspected to be\nlinked to SARS. We are pleased to accede to this request on the\nunderstanding that ProMed-mail recipients are aware that:\n\n(1) The virus detected by this PCR is only suspected/has not been confirmed\nyet to be an etiological cause of SARS;\n\n(2) a negative finding in this PCR is not sufficient to exclude SARS;\n\n(3) healthy controls have to be tested before the test is used; and\n\n(4) the primers have not been published.\n\nThe protocol is a preliminary one that is not yet thoroughly optimized. It\nyields clear positivity in respiratory specimens of both Frankfurt cases of\nSARS. The primers used are specifically targeting a fraction of the\npolymerase gene of the coronavirus found in these patients (refer to above\nmentioned posting for further details).\n\nThe protocol is available on the Homepage of the Bernhard-Nocht-Institute,\n<http://www15.bni-hamburg.de/bni/bni2/neu2/getfile.acgi?area_engl=news&pid=620> .\n\nThe primers are available from stock at Tib-Molbiol, a German biotech\ncompany based in Berlin. Aliquots of these primer stocks have been tested\nin our laboratory to rule out mis-synthesis. Contact and order via\n<ulass@tib-molbiol.de> or <dna@tib-molbiol.de>. We do not have personal\norfinancial relations to this company.\n\nThose who are willing to establish this test can request from me (e-mail\nbelow) in-vitro transcribed positive control RNA that will be available\nfrom the middle of this week.\n\n--\nChristian Drosten\nVirology/Molecular Diagnostics\nBernhard-Nocht Inst. of Tropical Medicine\nBernhard-Nocht Str. 74\n20359 Hamburg\nGermany\nPhone 0049-40-42818-421\nFax 0049-40-42818-378\n<drosten@bni-hamburg.de.\n\n\n[ProMED-mail is pleased to assist in the rapid dissemination of this\nimportant information. worldwide (27): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2203572", "date": "2003-04-03 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (27): CASES\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nIn this update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO*\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Canada - Health Canada\n[4] USA - CDC\n*Note: With the addition of the first probable case in Brazil, SARS is now\nbeing reported on 4 continents... the single case in Spain [was] removed\nfrom the list when determined to have other causes.- WHO 3 Apr 2003.\n******\n[1]\nDate: 3 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website 3 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Cases of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n(SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_04_03/en/>\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002(1) To: 3 Apr 2003, 17:00 GMT+2\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No.deaths/ Local chain(s) of\ntransmission(2)\nAustralia: 1/ 0/ None\nBelgium: 1/ 0/ None\nBrazil: 1/ 0/ None\nCanada: 62/ 6/ Yes\nChina: 1190/ 46/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 734/ 17*/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 14/ 0/ Yes\nFrance: 3/ 0/ None\nGermany: 5/ 0/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 1/ 0/ None\nRomania: 1/ 0/ None\nSingapore: 98/ 4/ Yes\nSwitzerland: 2/ 0/ None\nThailand: 7/ 2/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 3/ 0/ None\nUnited States: 85\u00a7/ 0/ Being determined\nViet Nam: 59/ 4/ Yes\nTotal: 2270/ 79\nNotes:\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n1. The start of the period of surveillance has been changed to 1 Nov 2002\nto capture cases of atypical pneumonia in China that are now recognized as\nbeing cases of SARS.\n2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n\u00a7 Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national level,\nprobable cases are reported by all countries except the United States of\nAmerica, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n* One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 3 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_04_03/en/>\nCountry: Area\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Guangdong, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China, Shanxi,\nTaiwan Province\nViet Nam: Hanoi\nAn affected area: an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of SARS\nis/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.\n[Unchanged from previous dates. - Mod. MPP]\n[C] Update 20 - Situation in China and Hong Kong SAR 3 Apr 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_04_03/en/>\nWHO team arrives in Guangdong Province\n------------------------------------\nThe WHO team of experts arrived in Guangdong Province, China today and\nimmediately started its work. The team was authorized to travel to the\nprovince yesterday.\nMeetings were held today with senior provincial health officials. The WHO\nteam also listened to reports about the SARS outbreak, and held initial\nmeetings with health workers at all levels. These workers, who have\nfirst-hand knowledge of the outbreak, include epidemiologists and\nclinicians treating SARS patients. Discussion focused on patterns of\ntransmission, clinical profiles, and the suspected causative agent.\nChinese authorities had previously reported a cumulative total of 1153\ncases and 40 deaths in Guangdong Province from 16 Nov 2002, when the\noutbreak began, to the end of March [2003], making this province the area\nmost seriously affected by SARS to date.\nThe world's first recognized case of SARS occurred in Guangdong Province on\n16 Nov 2002. Expectations are high that important clues will emerge\nconcerning the origins of SARS, which is thought to be caused by a new\nvirus in the coronavirus family. The exact identity of the virus has proved\nelusive. Scientists, who confer daily in teleconferences organized by WHO,\ncurrently speculate that the SARS virus either jumped to humans from an\nanimal species or mutated into a more virulent form.\nIn its continuing work, the WHO team is expected to visit Foshan city,\nwhere the first case of SARS was reported, and Guangzhou city. The team\nwill also visit health care facilities, review case records, and hold\nfurther discussions before returning to Beijing early next week.\nIn Beijing, the government of China is now gearing up to fight SARS on a\npriority basis. Reports in today's media referred to a State Council\nexecutive meeting on SARS and described 3 key decisions.\nA special task force, headed by Minister of Health Dr Zhang Wenkang, will\ntake charge of the fight against SARS. A vice secretary-general of the\nState Council will coordinate actions by relevant ministries. The task\nforce will provide updates on SARS to WHO. A nationwide mechanism for\noutbreak alert and response will be set up shortly to ensure rapid\ndetection and reporting of outbreaks. Dr Zhang appeared on Chinese\nnational TV to address SARS-related issues.\nSituation in Hong Kong SAR\n-----------------------\nThe Department of Health in Hong Kong SAR reported 26 new cases today [3\nApr 2003], compared with 23 yesterday [2 Apr 2003]. These figures represent\na significant decline from the 155 cases reported on Tuesday [1 Apr 2003]\nand 60 reported on Monday [31 Mar 2003]. This trend suggests that the\nextraordinary control measures undertaken by the government are working.\nThe Department of Health further announced that 89 SARS patients have been\ndischarged from hospitals.\nUpdate on cases and countries\n------------------------\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 2270 SARS cases and 79 deaths have been\nreported from 16 countries. This represents an increase of 47 cases and 1\ndeath (in Hong Kong) compared with yesterday.\nWith the addition of the first probable case in Brazil, SARS is now being\nreported on 4 continents.\nNew cases were reported in Canada (4), Hong Kong (26), Taiwan, China (1),\nFrance (2), Singapore (3), the United States of America (13), and Viet Nam\n(1). Brazil reported [its] first probable case.\n2 of Romania's 3 reported cases, one of the 2 cases in the Republic of\nIreland, and the single case in Spain were removed from the list when\ndetermined to have other causes.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 3 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 3 Apr 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nSituation report on atypical pneumonia 3 Apr 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n------------------------\nAs at 1 PM 3 Apr 2003, an additional 26 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia were admitted to public hospitals. They include 2 healthcare\nworkers and 2 patients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 22 were new\npatients and contacts of patients with atypical pneumonia.\nA total of 98 patients have recovered from atypical pneumonia and have been\ndischarged from public hospitals. Of them, 9 are discharged today,\nincluding 2 medical students.\nMost of the patients currently in hospital are showing positive responses\nto the new treatment protocol. 85 of them are receiving treatment in\nintensive care unit.\nA 56-year-old man with a history of chronic heart disease died in Princess\nMargaret Hospital today, bringing to 17 the total number of deaths relating\nto atypical pneumonia.\nThe cumulative figure for patients who have been admitted to public\nhospitals with atypical pneumonia since 12 Mar 2003 is as follows: (number\nof cases with pneumonia are presented in parentheses).\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 177 (177)\n53 of the patients were discharged\nPatients, family members & visitors 557 (557)\n45 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admission 734 (734)\n98 were discharged\n[If any of our subscribers have official information on this new treatment\nprotocol we would very much appreciate receiving it. Our thanks to Thomas P.\nGiordano, MD <tpg@bcm.tmc.edu> for asking for these specifics. - Mod.MPP]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 3 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada SARS webpage [accessed 3 Apr 2003] [edited]\n<http://www.sars.gc.ca.>\nSummary of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) Cases: (2 Apr 2003)\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030402_e.html>\nLatest Case Counts\n-----------------\nSince yesterday, 5 additional probable cases of SARS have been reported in\nCanada. A total of 62 individuals who meet the probable case definition of\nSARS have been reported in Ontario and British Columbia, including 6\ndeaths; 98 individuals who meet the definition of a suspect case of SARS\nhave also been reported in British Columbia, Alberta, Saskatchewan,\nOntario, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island.\nTable 1: Cumulative Number of SARS Cases Reported in Canada: 2 Apr 2003\n----------------------------------------------\nProvince/Territory: Probable Case(1)/ Suspect Case(1)/ Deaths(2)\nBritish Columbia: 2/ 16/ 0\nAlberta: 0/ 7/ 0\nSaskatchewan: 0/ 1/ 0\nOntario: 60/ 69/ 6\nNew Brunswick: 0/ 1/ 0\nPrince Edward Island: 0/ 4/ 0\nTotal: 62/ 98/ 6\n(1) These persons may drop off the probable or suspect case list if another\ncause if identified for their illness\n(2) This figure is included in the number of probable cases\nPreliminary Descriptive Findings\n---------------------\nGiven the information currently available, the average age of probable\ncases in Canada is 46.2 years (n=45, range 2 to 82 years), with 31 females\nand 20 males. The current number of probable cases by reported symptom\nonset date and type of exposure is also provided [see Figure 1- Number of\nprobable cases of SARS in Canada by symptom onset date and exposure type\nfrom: 23 Feb2003 to 2 Apr 2003 on website:\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/eu-ae/sars20030402_e.html>].\nPreliminary Epidemiologic Findings\n--------------------------------\nTransmission: To date, all probable cases of SARS have been linked to either\ntravel-related exposures, or in healthcare or household settings (Figure\n1 -- see website). Thus, based on the current data available, there is no\nevidence to suggest disease transmission in the general community.\nClinical Manifestations: A summary of the clinical presentation of SARS\nbased on the first 10 cases identified in Canada has recently been\npublished (source: New England Journal of Medicine,\n<http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/NEJMoa030634v1.pdf>). Listed in order\nof observed frequency are fever (10/10), nonproductive cough (10/10),\nshortness of breath (8/10), malaise (7/10), diarrhea (5/10), chest pain\n(3/10), headache (3/10), sore throat (3/10), myalgias (2/10), and vomitting\n(1/10). Lymphopenia, elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels, elevated\naspartate amino-transferase levels and elevated creatinine kinase levels\nwere also reported. The World Health Organization is currently coordinating\nglobal efforts to better characterize the clinical manifestations of SARS.\nSeverity of Illness: Of all the probable cases reported to date, most\nremain hospitalised for isolation purposes and only 3 are currently in\nintensive care. Shown in Table 2 is the reported status of 26 probable\ncases currently hospitalised. Please note that these numbers are based on\npreliminary data, and will be updated accordingly as more information\nbecomes available.\nTable 2: Reported status of currently hospitalised probable cases of SARS\nin Canada: 2 Apr 2003\n(n=26, excluding 6 deaths and 30 individuals whose status is currently\nunknown)\nStatus: No.Cases/ Proportion\nImproving: 5/ 19.2 percent\nStable: 18/ 69.2 percent\nDeteriorating: 2/ 7.7 percent\nCritical: 1/ 3.8 percent\nTotal no. probable cases with known status currently hospitalised: 26/ 100\npercent\nAll 6 deaths reported to date have been associated with individuals with\nunderlying illness and all but one occurred in elderly patients.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 3 Apr 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States\n*Case definition -- see <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>\n\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on April 2, 2003.\nState: Suspected cases under investigation*\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 24\nColorado: 3\nConnecticut: 2\nGeorgia: 1\nHawaii: 4\nIllinois: 4\nKansas: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 4\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nMinnesota: 3\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 2\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 2\nNew York: 16\nOhio: 1\nPennsylvania: 4\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 4\nUtah: 4\nVermont: 2\nVirginia: 2\nWashington: 5\nWisconsin: 1\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 100\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[The newswires are filled with reports of suspected SARS cases in a number\nof countries that do not show up on the WHO update information. One\npossible explanation is that these are suspected cases and the WHO updates\nare presenting probable cases (with the exception of the data released by\nthe USA which does include both suspected and probable cases). This\nconfusion and discrepancy in reported cases will most likely continue until\nthere is a definitive etiology, with reliable laboratory testing to allow\nfor confirmation of actual infection with the etiologic agent responsible\nfor producing the clinical picture currently referred to as SARS.\nIn addition, in today's newswires were multiple iterations of theories that\nthe etiologic agent is a virus that has jumped species from animals (as the\nnewswires have mentioned pigs, fowl and in one case owls). The verdict on\nthe etiology and the origin of the etiologic agent is not out yet, and we\nhave decided to refrain from posting these newswires pending solid\nscientific information.\nThe WHO update for today highlights the additional reports in the past 24\nhours. worldwide (22): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=299", "date": "2003-03-31 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (22): CASES\n**********************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA - CDC\n[2] Canada - Health Canada\n******\n[1]\nDate: 31 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome report of suspected cases under\ninvestigation in the United States\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm> [website accessed 7:15 PM EST]\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on March 30, 2003.\n*Case definition <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>\nState: Suspected cases under investigation*\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 14\nConnecticut: 1\nGeorgia: 1\nHawaii: 3\nIllinois: 2\nKansas: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 2\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nMinnesota: 3\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 2\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 2\nNew York: 10\nOhio: 1\nPennsylvania: 3\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 3\nUtah: 4\nVirginia: 3\nWashington: 1\nWisconsin: 2\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 69\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 31 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada 31 Mar 2003\n\n[A] Summary of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) Cases: Canada and\nInternational accessed 31 Mar 2003 7 PM EST\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/sars20030330_e.html>\nCanada\nLatest Case Counts\n-------------------\nSince yesterday, 8 additional probable cases and one death have been\nreported in Canada. A total of 44 probable cases with SARS have been\nreported in Ontario and British Columbia, including 4 deaths (Table 1). The\nnumber of probable cases by symptom onset date and type of exposure is also\nshown (Figure 1). One individual previously classified as a probable case\nin Manitoba is no longer being considered for SARS since a specific etiology\nhas been identified.\nRecent Ontario Epidemiologic Findings\n--------------------------------\nThe Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care has reported a total of\n42 probable cases of SARS. Of these, most remain hospitalised for isolation\npurposes while six are in intensive care. Using the information currently\navailable, the average age of probable cases is 46.3 years (n=35, range 17\nto 82 years), with 24 known females and 17 known males. The majority of\nthose with severe illness or deaths have occurred in elderly patients with\nunderlying illness.\nWhile it is difficult to accurately determine the incubation period of the\netiologic agent, given the fact that many of the probable cases in Ontario\nmay have multiple exposures, the current estimated mean incubation period\nis 4 days (estimated range 2 to 10 days).\nIt is believed that 4 generations of transmission have occurred. The index\ncase in Ontario was an individual who travelled to Hong Kong and stayed at\nthe Metropole Hotel, where a cluster of SARS cases has since been reported.\nUpon return to Canada, disease transmission occurred in 4 members of the\nimmediate and extended family. A physician who had close contact with\nmembers of this family was also diagnosed with SARS. Following this, cases\nwere reported in individuals in a hospital setting where some of the first\ncases were treated. Most recently, SARS has been reported in a few of the\nhousehold contacts of these hospital-associated cases. An isolated case in\nOntario was reported in an individual who had travelled to Asia, but did\nnot stay in at the Metropole Hotel.\nBased on the most recent epidemiologic investigations, nearly all of the\nprobable cases of SARS that occurred in individuals outside of the initial\nfamily cluster have been linked to exposure to the first hospitalised case\nof SARS, on 7 Mar 2003. It is believed that disease transmission occurred\nmainly as a result of person-to-person contact. The initial\nhospital-associated cases are believed to have contracted the illness as a\nresult of unprotected contact with the initial cases prior to the\nrecognition of SARS. Subsequent transmission is thought to have occurred\nbetween households of these hospital-associated cases, and between other\nhealthcare workers. To date, there has been no evidence of transmission in\nthe general community.\nOther Reports\n--------------\nA Canadian with SARS [not counted in the official Canadian case count], who\nis currently hospitalised in Hong Kong, stayed at the Metropole Hotel. The\nfirst identified probable case of SARS in British Columbia also stayed at\nthis hotel. The second probable case reported by BC today did not stay at\nthe hotel but was exposed to a SARS case while in Hong Kong. Both\nindividuals are currently in isolation and no community transmission has\noccurred in this province.\nOntario has declared a provincial emergency and SARS is now a reportable\ndiseases under Ontario's Health Protection and Promotion Act. The province\nhas introduced a number of public measures in an effort to contain the\nspread of SARS. Key public health measures include extensive contact\ntracing of persons who may have come in contact with SARS cases, isolation\nof suspect and probable cases, and voluntary home quarantine for\nasymptomatic contacts. Isolation wards have been established at hospitals\nand health care staff are required to observe full airborne and contact\nprecautions. Health care staff across the province are now alerted to SARS\nand have implemented infection control practices to protect themselves and\ntheir patients in an effort to prevent any further infection.\nHealth Canada is supporting Ontario in its SARS response efforts by\nproviding epidemiologic and infection control expertise, as well as\nemergency supplies as needed. Health Canada in collaboration with the\nProvinces and Territories has implemented enhanced surveillance for the\ndetection of SARS cases, alerted laboratories and initiated special\nlaboratory investigations in an effort to identify the cause of SARS. In\naddition, Health Canada is working quickly to implement a screening\nprotocol for international travellers in response to the WHO\nrecommendations to prevent travel-related spread of SARS. Due to recent\nconcerns regarding the possibility of transmission of SARS aboard aircraft,\nHealth Canada has also recommended follow-up of all passengers on flights\nwhere a suspect or probable SARS case is identified. For regular updates on\npublic health actions taken by Health Canada, please see the most recent\nupdate at:\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/index.html>\nTable 1 Cumulative Number of SARS Cases Reported in Canada, March 30, 2003\nProvince/Territory: No. Cases\nBritish Columbia: 2\nOntario: 42\nTOTAL 44\n\nFigure 1: Number of probable cases of SARS in Canada by symptom onset date\nand exposure type from: February 23 to 30 Mar 2003 (n=37, excluding 7 for\nwhom onset dates are missing)\n[see epidemic curve at:\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/sars-sras/sars20030330_e.html>]\nInternational\n-----------\nSince 1 Nov 2002, 1557 cases of SARS (1513 outside of Canada) have been\nreported to the World Health Organization. The majority of cases are\nreported from Guangdong Province and Hong Kong SAR China, Singapore and\nHanoi, Vietnam with Hong Kong presently showing the greatest increase in\ncases. Cases of SARS in other parts of the world have occurred in persons\nor close contacts of persons who have travelled to these destinations. As\nof 30 Mar 2003, 51 deaths have been reported outside of Canada, the\nmajority (34) of which were reported in Guangdong Province of China. The\ntotal number of cases and deaths in Guangdong was only recently reported in\nthe WHO cumulative international total.\nAs of 25 Mar 2003, a cluster of 13 persons with suspected or probable SARS\nare known to have stayed at the Metropole Hotel in Hong Kong. These cases\nsubsequently became index cases in several countries, including Vietnam,\nSingapore, the United States, Ireland, and Canada (MMWR Vol 52, No. 12,\nMarch 28, 2003). The visitor from mainland China, a medical doctor from\nGuangdong Province who became ill a week before staying at the hotel, is\nconsidered to be the original source of the infection. No further cases\nhave been linked to the hotel.\nThe majority of cases have occurred in people who have had very close\ncontact with other cases including household contacts and health care\nworkers.\n[B] Update 16 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 31 Mar 2003 8:00 PM\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update16.htm\n>\nAs of 31 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of approximately129\nprobable or suspect cases of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in\nOntario, British Columbia, Saskatchewan, Alberta and New Brunswick. There\nhave been 4 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have occurred in persons\nwho have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household\nor in a health-care setting. The information contained in this update is\nbased on the best available information Health Canada has at this time.\nHealth Canada is changing the way it is reporting probable and suspect\ncases of SARS to ensure consistency in reporting across the country.\n'Probable' cases of SARS are similar to suspect cases, but often they have\na more severe illness, with progressive shortness of breath and difficulty\nbreathing, and in some cases, chest x-rays show signs of atypical pneumonia.\nA 'suspect' case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following two\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a 'probable'\ncase of SARS (i.e. within one metre).\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n-----------------------------------\nOntario is reporting 51 probable and 58 suspect cases. All cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting.\nBritish Columbia is reporting 2 probable and 11 suspect cases.\nNew Brunswick is reporting one suspect case.\nSaskatchewan is reporting one suspect case.\nAlberta is reporting 5 suspect cases.\nHere are the most recent developments:\n-------------------------\nDue to the mounting concern about transmission of the SARS agent in\nnon-hospital and community settings in the City of Hanoi, Vietnam; the\nPeople's Republic of China including the Hong Kong SAR; Singapore; and\nTaiwan, Health Canada recommends that persons planning to travel to these\nareas should defer all travel until further notice. Health Canada also\nrecommends alternate routing be considered, when possible, if a traveller\nis transiting through the People's Republic of China including the Hong\nKong Special Administrative; City of Hanoi, Vietnam; Singapore; or Taiwan.\nHealth Canada is aware that health authorities in these affected areas are\nmaking concerted efforts to contain the spread of SARS in their\npopulations. Given the uncertainties of the current situation, Health\nCanada believes it is prudent to await the outcome of national and\ninternational control measures before undertaking travel to these\ndestinations.\nFor further information on this travel advisory, please see:\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/tmp-pmv/2003/sars0329_e.html>\nEffective 1 Apr 2003, Health Canada will launch an initiative to inform all\ndeparting passengers from the Pearson International Airport about symptoms\nand contact with persons with SARS through the Health Alert Notice (cherry\ncards).\nFor more information on this initiative, please see: 'SARS Screening of\nTravellers To and From Canada'\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11factsheet1.h\ntm>\nOn 31 Mar 2003, Health Canada sent 2 mobile x-ray machines and processors\nto Toronto for 2 isolation units that are being set up in non-hospital\nfacilities.\nOn 29 Mar 2003, Health Canada deployed 2 additional staff to assist Toronto\nPublic Health and the Ontario Ministry of Health with the investigation of\nSARS cases. This now brings the total number of Health Canada staff\nassisting in Ontario to 7. The department has also provided guidelines for\ninfection control and recommendations on actions for public health settings.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[Presenting updated data is becoming a challenge as the time zone\ndifferences are impacting when data are submitted to WHO vs when data\nbecome available on the various websites. Interesting\nepidemiologic data, still supporting the observation that close contact has\nbeen necessary for transmission thus far in Ontario.\nIt would be interesting to see similar epidemiologic data on reported cases\nelsewhere. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "Connecticut: 1\nGeorgia: 1\nHawaii: 3\nIllinois: 2\nKansas: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 2\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nMinnesota: 3\nNew Hampshire: 1\nNew Jersey: 2\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 2\nNew York: 10\nOhio: 1\nPennsylvania: 3\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 3\nUtah: 4\nVirginia: 3\nWashington: 1\nWisconsin: 2\n A 'suspect' case of SARS is a person who fits into one of the following two\ncategories: a person who develops fever and one or more respiratory\nsymptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing,\nwithin 10 days of returning from travel to areas in Asia where SARS cases\nare being reported, or a person who develops fever and one or more\nrespiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath or difficulty\nbreathing, within 10 days of having had close contact with a 'probable'\ncase of SARS (i.e. within one metre). Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[Due to length constraints, we have decided to split the daily updates so\nas to have shorter postings for the sake of those servers that reject\nlarger postings. As there are time zone differences in reporting areas, we\nhave chosen to post today's first update on worldwide cases to include the\nglobal report from WHO in Geneva and the country reports from Hong Kong,\nSAR, and Singapore, as it is now past COB (close of business) in those\nlocations. We are also including a few newswire briefs of\ninterest/import. - Mod.MPP]\nIn this update:\n[1] Worldwide - WHO\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] Newsbriefs\n[A] Canada\n[B] Belgium\n******\n[1]\nDate: 31 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website 31 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Cases of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_31/en/>\nFrom: 1 Nov 2002(1) To: 31 Mar 2003, 17:00 GMT+2\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No. deaths Local chain(s) of\ntransmission(2)\nCanada: 44/ 4/ Yes\nChina(3): 806/ 34/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 530/ 13*/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 10/ 0/ Yes\nFrance: 1/ 0/ None\nGermany: 5/ 0/ None\nItaly: 2/ 0/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 2/ 0/ None\nRomania: 3/ 0/ None\nSingapore: 91/ 2/ Yes\nSwitzerland: 3/ 0/ None\nThailand: 5/ 1/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 3/ 0/ None\nUnited States: 59 \u00a7/ 0/ To be determined\nViet Nam: 58/ 4/ Yes\nTotal: 1622/ 58\nNotes:\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n1. The start of the period of surveillance has been changed to 1 Nov 2002\nto capture cases of atypical pneumonia in China that are now recognized as\nbeing cases of SARS.\n2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n3. The reporting period from Guangdong Province is from 16 Nov 2002 to 28\nFeb 2003.\n\u00a7 Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n* One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] Canada\nAffected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 31 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_03_31/en/>\nCountry: Area\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Beijing, Guangdong, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of\nChina, Shanxi, Taiwan Province\nViet Nam: Hanoi\nAn affected area: an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of SARS\nis/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.\n[C] Hong Kong\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) - multi-country outbreak -\nUpdate 15: 31 Mar 2003\nhttp://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_31/en/\n\nThe Hong Kong Department of Health has today issued an unprecedented\nisolation order to prevent the further spread of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (SADS). The isolation order requires residents of Block E of Amoy\nGarden to remain in their flats until midnight on 9 Apr 2003.\nThe decision to issue the isolation order was made following a continued\nsteep rise in the number of SARS cases detected in the building over the\npast few days. Concern about a possible outbreak in Amoy Garden mounted on\nSaturday [29 Mar 2003], when 22 of Hong Kong's 45 new SAR cases\nhospitalized that day were determined to be residents of the estate. On\nSunday [30 Mar 2003], 36 of the 60 new patients admitted to hospital with\nprobable SARS were Amoy Garden residents.\nHong Kong health authorities today informed the public that a cumulative\ntotal of 213 residents of Amoy Garden had been admitted to hospital with\nsuspected SARS since reporting on the disease began. Hong Kong's outbreak\nbegan on 12 Mar 2003 when health officials first recognized a cluster of\ncases of atypical pneumonia in the Prince of Wales Hospital.\nOf the 213 Amoy residents affected in the outbreak, 107 patients resided in\nBlock E. In addition, most of these 107 patients from Block E lived in flats\nthat were vertically arranged. This suggests that SARS may be spreading in\nHong Kong according to a different pattern, still involving close\nperson-to-person contact with bodily secretions from an infected person. WHO\nepidemiologists are considering the possibility that bodily secretions\ncontaining the causative virus might somehow enter common systems that link\nrooms or flats together. This pattern of spread would be in addition to the\nwell-documented\nface-to-face contact that has been seen in the majority of cases reported so\nfar.\nEarlier this month, Hong Kong epidemiologists detected an unusual pattern\nof transmission among guests and visitors at the Metropole Hotel during the\ncritical period of 15 to 23 Feb 2003. Guests and visitors at a single floor\nof the hotel are thought to have spread SARS to Toronto and Singapore and\nto have started the outbreak in Hong Kong's Prince of Wales Hospital. No\nstaff at the hotel developed symptoms.\nAmoy Garden is a large housing estate consisting of 10 blocks of 35-storey\nbuildings, where around 15 000 persons reside. It is located in Kowloon\nDistrict. WHO has been informed that environmental samples have been taken\nfrom the affected flats in Block E and that investigations are under way to\ndetermine a possible explanation for this apparent vertical spread of the\ndisease. Although the investigation is complex, results from testing of the\nenvironmental samples should be available within days and will help\ndetermine the source of infection in Block E and the mechanisms by which the\npathogen has spread.\nHong Kong epidemiologists have identified a possible 'index' case in the\nAmoy Garden outbreak. This is a patient, now hospitalized in Prince of\nWales Hospital, who visited his brother, a resident of Block E, several\ntimes before hospital admission.\nMainland China\n---------------\nThe WHO expert team spent the day in the Beijing Municipality Center for\nDisease Control and Prevention reviewing case records for all 10 cases\nreported in Beijing Municipality. Following the cases in Guangdong province\nin late January [2003] and early February 2003, Beijing Municipality CDC\nofficials said an enhanced local surveillance system was established by\nadding 11 sentinel hospitals (out of 50 total hospitals) to report cases of\natypical pneumonia.\nThe laboratory service was also geared up to receive specimens and carry\nout tests in secure conditions. Other preparation included stockpiling of\ndrugs, setting up a public hotline, and holding 2 news conferences. In\naddition, CDC and hospital staff were trained in prompt reporting of\natypical pneumonia and infection control. An isolation unit was\nestablished. CDC Beijing said that antibiotics and Ribovirin are being used\nroutinely as treatment and prophylaxis.\nThe team were told that contact tracing had begun as soon as the first\ncases of atypical pneumonia had been recognized in Beijing and had been\ncarried out for all subsequent cases. 8 of the cases were imported (from\nHong Kong and Taiyuan city, Shanxi province) and 2 were health care workers\nwho became infected trying to revive a 72-year-old man believed to have\nbecome ill after visiting a relative with SARS in a Hong Kong hospital.\nBesides the 2 health care workers, no other cases have been infected in\nBeijing.\nDiscussions concerning a visit by the expert team to Guangdong Province are\ncontinuing with the Ministry of Health.\nUpdate on cases and countries:\n--------------------------\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 1622 cases, with 58 deaths, have been\nreported from 13 countries. This represents an increase of 72 cases and 4\ndeaths since the last figures were compiled on Saturday [29 Mar 2003].\nThe greatest increase in cases occurred in Hong Kong SAR. The additional\ndeaths were reported in Canada (1) and Hong Kong (3). Germany reported its\nfifth case, and Switzerland its third.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 31 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health 31 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs at 1 PM 31 Mar 2003, a total of 79 patients with symptoms of atypical\npneumonia have recovered and been discharged from public hospitals.\nOf them, 19 patients, including 9 healthcare workers, were discharged today.\nMeanwhile, an additional 80 patients with symptoms of atypical pneumonia\nwere admitted to public hospitals. They include 2 healthcare workers and 64\npatients from Amoy Gardens. The remaining 14 were new patients and contacts\nof patients with atypical pneumonia.\nCurrently, 64 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit.\nA 79-year-old male patient with a history of heart disease died in Prince\nof Wales Hospital yesterday afternoon. Another 62-year-old male patient,\nwho was very ill when admitted to Queen Elizabeth Hospital, passed away. So\nfar, a total of 15 patients died with atypical pneumonia in public\nhospitals.\nThe cumulative figure for patients admitted to public hospitals with\natypical pneumonia is 610, starting from 12 Mar 2003.\nThe breakdown of figures is as follows:\n(The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 164 (164)\n45 of the patients were discharged\nPatients, family members & visitors 446 (446)\n34 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admission 610 (610)\n79 were discharged\nDirector of Health issues isolation order 31 Mar 2003\n-----------------------------------------\nDirector of Health, Dr Margaret Chan, has ordered Block E of Amoy Garden in\nNgau Tau Kok, Kowloon Bay, to be isolated for a period of 10 days starting\nfrom 6 AM 31 Mar 2003 to prevent the spread of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (commonly known as atypical pneumonia), a Government spokesman\nsaid.\nThe decision was taken because of the continued steep rise in the number of\ncases of infection in the building in the past few days.\nThe order, designed to protect the health of residents and the community as\na whole, was issued under the authority granted under Section 24 of the\nPrevention of the Spread of Infectious Diseases Regulations, Cap. 141.\nThe order requires residents of Block E of Amoy Garden to remain in their\nflats until midnight on 9 Apr 2003.\nDuring the isolation period, no one will be allowed to enter or leave the\npremises without express permission in writing of a health officer.\nMedical personnel from the Department of Health will visit residents' homes\nto conduct health inspections for them. Residents will be provided 3 meals\na day free of charge. They will also receive help and advice to conduct\nthorough cleansing and disinfection of their flats. Staff of the Home\nAffairs Department will be briefing residents on the detailed arrangements\nto take care of their daily needs.\n'We do understand that the measures that we have now taken will cause\nresidents great inconvenience. But because of the very special\ncircumstances that we now face, we have no choice but resort to this\nexceptional measure and we sincerely ask for residents' forbearance,\nunderstanding and support in joining the community's fight against this\ndisease.' the spokesman said.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 31 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health 31 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5800>\n\nSARS: Situation update 31 Mar 2003\nMore patients recovering and discharged\n--------------------------------\nOne death due to SARS has been reported today. The patient had travelled to\nSarawak with her family from 15 Mar 2003 to 18 Mar 2003 and had developed\nfever when she returned to Singapore on 18 Mar 2003.\nShe presented at NUH Emergency Department on 24 Mar 2003 with features of\npneumonia. At that time, the medical staff were unable to obtain from the\nrelatives a history of contact with a patient with SARS and she had also\nnot travelled to an affected areas. She was too unwell to be transferred to\nTTSH. Nevertheless, in line with MOH guidelines, she was treated as a\npotentially infectious patient and was warded in an isolation room. NUH\nstaff took all the necessary infection control precautions after her\nadmission, and the patient was isolated throughout her admission. She was\nalso not allowed any visitors. She was transferred to the ICU on 24 Mar\n2003, where she was received intensive treatment under isolation.\nOn 30 Mar 2003, one of her relatives gave the history that the NUH patient\nhad visited a non-SARS patient in a ward in TTSH on 12 Mar 2003. A patient\nin this ward was later found to have SARS. As the NUH patient herself was\nvery sick, it was not possible to ascertain who she had come into contact\nwith. Despite intensive treatment, her condition worsened and she passed\naway today. As a precautionary measure, this patient is being considered as\na case of SARS. As at 31\nMar 2003, a total of 92 people with SARS have been reported to the Ministry\nof Health. The total number of people who have recovered from SARS and have\nbeen discharged from hospital is 41. The remaining 47 patients are\nhospitalised.\nTo date, there have been no SARS cases that are linked to the fourth and\nfifth imported cases. The cases in Singapore are still traced to the first\n3 people who travelled to Hong Kong and contracted SARS. The number of\ninfected children still remains at 3. There is no change in the number of\npersons on the suspect list.\nThere are 13 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth\nimported case.\nCase of death on board the cargo ship, Kota Hasil from Hong Kong\n---------------------------------------------------\nMOH was notified of a case of an Indonesian crewman who developed high\nfever on 23 Mar 2003 while on board a cargo ship sailing between Taiwan and\nHong Kong, and who passed away on 28 Mar 203 while the ship was enroute to\nSingapore. The ship arrived in Singapore on 29 Mar 2003 and was anchored in\na quarantine area. 2 doctors from Singapore boarded the vessel and examined\nthe crew members. Although the history of the illness was not completely\ntypical of SARS, the doctors took all the necessary infection control\nprecautions. All crew members were assessed to be well but have not been\nallowed to come ashore. The body has been taken to the Centre for Forensic\nMedicine. The ship is scheduled to depart Singapore tonight after it has\ncompleted its cargo operations.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 31 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Newswire briefs [edited]\n[A] Canada - from Canada.com 31 Mar 2003\n<http://canada.com/national/story.asp?id=B33A6DDD-F9E1-45D9-AD56-873246C74FD\n5>\nThere are 2 probable and 3 suspected cases of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome at Toronto's Hospital for Sick Children. "292", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (16): etiology", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=292", "date": "2003-03-28 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (16): ETIOLOGY\n*******************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\n[1]\nDate: Thu, 27 Mar 2003 22:28:51 +0100\nFrom: 'Christian Drosten' <drosten@bni-hamburg.de>\n\nSubject: SARS, potential etiologic agent, Hamburg\n\nThis is a clarification note relating to a Reuter's report contained\nin ProMED message SARS - WORLDWIDE (13): ETIOLOGY\n\nIn the morning of Tuesday 25 Mar 2003, we had identified coronavirus\nsequences in supernatant of a culture of Vero cells showing a cytopathic\neffect after having been inoculated with respiratory fluid from the\nFrankfurt index patient [physician who had cared for SARS patients in\nSingapore - Mod.MPP] with SARS.\n\nThis tissue culture was grown at the Virology department of the University\nof Frankfurt (involved researchers: Wolfgang Preiser, Holger Rabenau, Marin\nSt\u00fcrmer, Annemarie Berger, Hans Wilhelm Doerr). On Monday, the colleagues\nin Frankfurt found seroconversion in an immunofluorescence test on these\nsame cells using serum of the index patient after defeverescence.\n\nThe virus was detected in the supernatant by a random amplification\napproach. 15 different pairs of primers directed to various parts of\nviruses other than coronaviruses were used in a low stringency RT-PCR. The\nrandom PCR products were sequenced, and 2 of the obtained sequences matched\nat the protein level to known coronavirus sequences deposited in GenBank.\nBoth sequences (90 and 300 nucleotides in length) are located in the\npolymerase gene but do not overlap with the sequence reported by CDC on 24\nMon 2003. Phylogenetic analysis of the larger fragment suggests that the\nnovel virus is not related closely to any of the known phylogenetic\nlineages of coronaviruses (groups 1, 2, and 3). The sequence diverges by\n50-60 percent from known coronavirus sequences and segregates\nphylogenetically between bovine coronavirus (group 2) and avian infectious\nbronchitis virus (group 3). Using primers specifically targeting the\nsequence reported by CDC, coronavirus sequences were also found in clinical\nspecimens of the Frankfurt index patient. The sequence of this PCR fragment\nmatched exactly the sequence reported by CDC, indicating an epidemiological\nlink between the patient in Frankfurt (who came from Singapore) and the\npatient(s) from whom the CDC sequence originates.\n\nWe are now setting up molecular diagnostic tests (RT-PCR, real-time\nRT-PCR). The primers are communicated through the WHO network. An\ninternational biotech company (Tib-Molbiol, Berlin) makes these oligos\nrapidly available to the laboratories involved in the network.\n\n--\nChristian Drosten/Stephan G\u00fcnther\nVirology/Molecular Diagnostics\nBernhard Nocht Institute of Tropical Medicine\nBernhard-Nocht Str. 74\n20359 Hamburg\nGermany\n<drosten@bni-hamburg.de>\n\n[These data provided by Drosten and Stephan G\u00fcnther of the Bernhard Nocht\nInstitute of Tropical Medicine, Hamburg, Germany, provide independent\nsupport for the conclusion that a novel coronavirus, distinct from known\nmembers of the genus _Coronavirus_ of the family _Coronaviridae_, is the\netiologic agent of SARS, and verifies the results reported from the CDC,\nAtlanta. The molecular and seroconversion data from Hamburg are well-nigh\nconclusive. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Fri 28 Mar 2003\nFrom: Jane Cardosa <jcardosa@dominomail.unimas.my>\n\nCorrection: Virologists at Hong Kong University Responsible for Coronavirus\nIdentification\n------------------------------------------------------------\nDr Jane Cardosa has pointed out an error in the Moderator's comment to the\nProMED-mail post 'SARS - worldwide (13): etiology 20030327.0758' in that\nthere are 2 universities in Hong Kong involved in the investigation of SARS\netiology.\n\nThese are (1) Hong Kong University and (2) the Chinese University of Hong\nKong. The start of the period of surveillance has been changed to 1 Nov 2002\nto capture cases of atypical pneumonia in China that are now recognized as\nbeing cases of SARS.\n\n2. National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas. [see [B] below]\n\n3. The reporting period from Guangdong Province is from 16 Nov 2002 to 28\nFeb 2003.\n\n\u00a7 Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the USA, which\nis reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n\n* One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR China occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n\n[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 29 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_03_29/en/>\n\nCountry: Area\n\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Beijing, Guangdong, Hong Kong SAR, Shanxi, Taiwan Province\nViet Nam: Hanoi\n\nAn affected area: an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of SARS\nis/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.\n\n[C] Update 14 - Update on cases and countries 29 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsarchive/2003_03_29/en/>\n\n\nAs of 29 Mar 2003, a cumulative total of 1550 cases and 54 deaths have been\nreported from 13 countries. This represents an increase of 65 cases and one\ndeath compared with the previous day.\n\nWHO infectious disease specialist, Dr Carlo Urbani, the first WHO officer\nto identify the outbreak of this new disease and treat the earliest cases\nin Hanoi, died of SARS today in Thailand, accounting for the additional death.\n\nThe number of cases in Viet Nam remained at 58 for the sixth day in a row,\nindicating that the outbreak in Hanoi is well-controlled.\n\nThe largest increases occurred in Hong Kong SAR China, with 45 new cases,\nand Canada, with 8 new cases. The United States of America reported 8\nadditional suspect or probable cases.\n\n[D] Dr. Carlo Urbani of the World Health Organisation dies of SARS 29 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/urbani/en/>\n\nDr. Carlo Urbani, an expert on communicable diseases, died today of SARS.\nDr. Urbani, worked in public health programs in Cambodia, Laos and Viet\nNam. He was based in Hanoi, Viet Nam. Dr. Urbani was 46.\n\nDr. Urbani was the first WHO officer to identify the outbreak of this new\ndisease, in an American businessman who had been admitted to a hospital in\nHanoi. Because of his early detection of the disease, global surveillance\nwas heightened and many new cases have been identified and isolated before\nthey infected hospital staff. In Hanoi, the SARS outbreak appears to be\ncoming under control.\n\n\u0093Carlo was a wonderful human being and we are all devastated,\u0094 said Pascale\nBrudon, the World Health Representative in Viet Nam. \u0093He was very much a\ndoctor, his first goal was to help people. Carlo was the one who very\nquickly saw that this was something very strange. When people became very\nconcerned in the hospital, he was there everyday, collecting samples,\ntalking to the staff and strengthening infection control procedures.\u0094\n\nDr. Urbani was married and the father of 3 children.\n\nDr. Urbani received his medical degree from the University of Ancona,\nItaly, and did post-graduate work in malaria and medical parasitology. He\nwas an expert in the parasitic diseases of schoolchildren. He was also a\npresident of M\u00e9decins Sans Fronti\u00e8res-Italy.\n\n\u0093Carlo Urbani\u0092s death saddens us all deeply at WHO,\u0094 said Dr. Gro Harlem\nBrundtland, WHO\u0092s Director-General. \u0093His life reminds us again of our true\nwork in public health. Today, we should all pause for a moment and remember\nthe life of this outstanding physician.\u0094\n\n[We are very sorry to learn of Dr. Urbani's death. A very sobering\noccurrence. - Mod.MPP]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\n\nDate: 29 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health 29 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\nFigures on atypical pneumonia\n------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nAs at 1 PM 29 Mar 2003, a total of 470 people with pneumonia symptoms have\nbeen admitted to public hospitals.
