The 3 additional patients, who are family members of\nSARS cases, are still traced back to the initial 3 index cases. This brings\nthe total number of family members, friends or close contacts infected by\nSARS to 44, and the total number of hospital staff infected by SARS to 41.\nThese 85 cases are all linked to the first 3 index cases. The number of\ninfected children still remains at 3.\n\nTo date, 28 patients have been discharged from hospital, 2 have died and\nthe remaining 59 patients are hospitalised. All the patients are stable\nexcept for 13 patients who are in serious condition, including the fourth\nindex case.\n\nThe fourth imported case reported yesterday is a 29 year old Chinese female\nwho travelled to Hong Kong on 14 Mar 2003 and then to Beijing on 15 Mar\n2003. While in Beijing, she became ill on 19 Mar 2003. She arrived back in\nSingapore on Southern China Airlines CZ 355 at Terminal 1, Changi Airport\non 26 Mar 2003 at 5.38 AM. Accompanied by her mother, she took a taxi from\nthe airport to the Accident & Emergency Department, Singapore General\nHospital. From there, she was transferred by ambulance and admitted to Tan\nTock Seng Hospital.\n\nOf the 49 passengers on board CZ 355, 31 (including the case) have been\ntraced. They are all well. Home Quarantine Orders are being issued. The 9\ncrew members of CZ355 returned to China on 26 Mar 2003. The Southern China\nAirlines has taken action to bar them from flights for 10 days. The names\nof the remaining 18 passengers who we have still been unable to locate [can\nbe found on the website at:\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5720> - Mod.MPP] The\nMinistry urges these persons or anyone who knows their whereabouts and the\nidentity of the taxi driver to call 91788389 with the information.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\n\nDate: 29 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website 29 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/>\n\n\n[A] CDC Extends SARS Travel Advisory; Offers Interim Infection Control Guidance\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/r030329.htm>\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) today extended its\ntravel advisory for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) to include all\nof mainland China as well as Hanoi, Vietnam and Singapore. The previous CDC\ntravel advisory was for only Hong Kong and Guangdong Province, People's\nRepublic of China and Hanoi, Vietnam.\n\nCDC advises that people planning elective or non-essential travel to\nmainland China and Hong Kong; Singapore; and Hanoi, Vietnam may wish to\npostpone their trips until further notice. CDC has been working closely\nwith the World Health Organization (WHO) to investigate cases of SARS. At\nthis time CDC is not advising against travel to or from Canada because\nthere is not evidence of widespread community transmission.\n\nCDC officials are meeting planes, cargo ships and cruise ships coming\neither directly or indirectly to the United States from China, Singapore\nand Vietnam and distributing health alert cards\n(<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/travel_alert.htm>) to disembarking\npassengers. In addition officials are assessing passengers returning from\nthose areas for symptoms of SARS.\n\nCDC is also issuing guidance for patients with suspected SARS designed to\nprevent transmission of the illness to their family members and other close\ncontacts. Health care officials are not certain how long a patient with\nSARS may be contagious to people with whom they have close contact.\n\nCDC recommends the following infection control measures for suspected\npatients with SARS in household or other residential settings:\n\nInfection control precautions should be continued for SARS patients for 10\ndays after respiratory symptoms and fever are gone. SARS patients should\nlimit interactions outside the home and should not go to work, school,\nout-of-home day care, or other public areas during the 10 day period;\n\nDuring this 10 day period, all members of the household with a SARS patient\nshould carefully follow recommendations for hand hygiene, such as frequent\nhand washing or the use of alcohol-based rubs;\n\nEach patient with SARS should cover his or her mouth and nose with a tissue\nbefore sneezing or coughing. If possible, a person recovering from SARS\nshould wear a surgical mask during close contact with uninfected persons.\nIf the patient is unable to wear a surgical mask, other persons in the home\nshould wear masks when in close contact with the patient;\n\nDisposable gloves should be considered for any contact with body fluids\nfrom a SARS patient. However, immediately after activities involving\ncontact with body fluids, gloves should be removed and discarded and hands\nshould be washed. Gloves should not be reused, and are not intended to\nreplace proper hand hygiene.\n\nSARS patients should avoid sharing eating utensils, towels and bedding with\nother members of the household, although these items can be used by others\nafter routine cleaning such as washing or laundering with soap and hot water;\n\nOther members of the household need not restrict their outside activities\nunless they develop symptoms of SARS such as a fever or respiratory illness.\n\n[B] Excerpts from Update Telebriefing Conference 29 Mar 2003\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/transcripts/t030329.htm>\n\nWe continue to regard the new coronavirus as the leading hypothesis for the\netiology of this condition. The evidence is mounting from a number of\ninternational laboratories, that this is indeed the case; but we are also\nexploring other potential viruses as are our collaborators. A number of\nthings are in progress, including sequencing of the whole virus genome.\n\nWe recognize that the disease is still primarily limited to travelers, to\nhealth care personnel who have taken care of SARS patients, and to close\ncontact with SARS patients. The affected travelers are those who have been\nin Hong Kong, in Hanoi, in Singapore, and in mainland China, for the most part.\n\nWe believe, based on the investigations so far, that the major mode of\ntransmission is through droplet spread when an infected person coughs or\nsneezes and droplets are spread to a nearby contact. But we are concerned\nabout the possibility of airborne transmission across broader areas and\nalso the possibility that objects that become contaminated in the\nenvironment could serve as modes of spread. Coronaviruses can survive in\nthe environment for up to 2 or 3 hours ,and so it's possible that a\ncontaminated object could serve as a vehicle for transfer to someone else.\n\nFor the people who are living in the household with the SARS patients, and\nwho are otherwise well, there is no reason to limit activities at this\npoint in time. The experience in the United States has not demonstrated\nspread of SARS from household contacts into the community and so we are not\nadvising any restrictions on the activity of contacts at this point in\ntime. However, it's very important that contacts with SARS patients be\nalert to the earliest symptom of a respiratory illness. If they have any\nsymptoms suggestive of an impending illness, they should contact a medical\nprovider, alert them that they are a SARS contact, so that the health care\nsystem can advise them where to come and get evaluation, and prepare the\ndelivery system to implement the appropriate infection control precautions\nso that others are not exposed in the health care setting.\n\nWe also are updating our guidance to travelers. The travelers at risk for\nSARS are those who have been in mainland China, in Hong Kong, in Hanoi and\nin Singapore. These travel alerts do not include passengers coming in from\nCanada. The epidemiology of the SARS in Canada is very different and there\nis not a risk from incoming travelers at this point in time. WHO is not\nissuing any travel restrictions. We are not issuing any travel restrictions\neither, but WHO has also implemented procedures for screening passengers\nbefore they leave the country of SARS origin.\n\nOf the 62 cases under investigation [in the USA], 2 of those cases are in\nhealth care workers and there have been no further signs of spread in that\nparticular cluster. 5 cases have been in household contact and the rest of\nthe cases have all been in travelers coming in from SARS areas. We are not\nexperiencing any sign of community transmission at this point in time.\n\nIn response to a question related to Hong Kong health officials reporting\nsuspect cases from an apartment complex: Information from Hong Kong does\nsuggest that in at least one apartment complex there has been spread. [It\nhasn't been identified as yet] to what extent the individuals in that\napartment have had face to face contact with each other, to what extent\nthey might have contacted contaminated environments in that facility or to\nwhat extent airborne transmission could play a role.\n\nIn response to a question on other modes of transmission and guidance for\nairlines: Preliminary guidance on appropriate means for disinfection of\ncommercial aircraft as well as very specific and more focused guidance for\ndisinfection of an aircraft that might be used in a medical evacuation of a\nhigh-risk or critically-ill patient [have been issued].\n\nIn response to a question re: treatment guidelines: [There is] no evidence\nright now, that any specific anti-viral therapy, or steroid treatment, or\nother agents that are targeting this virus, are of any benefit to patients.\n\nIn response to questions re: concern about community spread in the USA: We\nrecognize that there are at least some patients with SARS that are\nextremely efficient transmitters. For example, in Hanoi where there was one\npatient who was a source for health care worker transmission and\napproximately 56 percent of the health care [workers] who had direct\ncontact with the patient appeared to have acquired SARS.\n\nIn response to a question on evidence of coronavirus as the etiology:\nFirst, we have isolated the coronavirus from 2 patients, here, in the USA\nand elsewhere additional isolations are reported. We are using PCR or\npolymerase chain reaction technology to identify very specific pieces of\nthe coronavirus in the secretions and fluids from many of the case\npatients. We have developed an antibody assay which detects antibodies to\nthis new coronavirus with a high degree of specificity, some of the\npatients who have negative antibody tests at the beginning of their\nillness, subsequently, in paired serum have demonstrated development of\nantibody within days after their infection occurred. They are developing an\nimmunologic reaction to this new coronavirus, strong evidence of infection.\n\nWe now have 2 antibody tests that look quite promising and seem to be\nreproducible in different laboratories, and we're working to transfer\ndiagnostic testing capacity to public health laboratories around the\ncountry, so that before too long, tests will be available much more locally.\n\nLaboratories in at least 7 other countries now have evidence for coronavirus.\n\nIn response to a question on the period of infectivity of cases: One of the\nimportant studies going on is to look at passengers who traveled in\nairplanes with SARS patients, we have 3 separate cohorts of passengers who\ntraveled on the same plane with someone we knew was incubating SARS or had\nSARS during their travel experience. So far, those studies have not\nidentified evidence of transmission before people become sick but the\nnumbers are small and we can't draw any conclusions at this point in time.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\n\nDate: 29 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada - SARS website 29 Mar 2003 [edited]\n\n\nUpdate 14 - SARS 29 Mar 2003 5:00 PM\n\nAs of 29 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 37 cases of severe\nacute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Ontario, British Columbia and\nManitoba. There have been 3 deaths in Canada. All Canadian cases have\noccurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact with SARS\ncases in the household or in a health-care setting. The information\ncontained in this update is based on the best available information Health\nCanada has at this time.\n\nThe details of the cases to date are as follows:\n\nOntario: 35 total cases. All cases have occurred in persons who have\ntraveled to Asia or had contact with SARS cases in the household or in a\nhealth-care setting.\n\nBritish Columbia: one person has been hospitalized with SARS after\nreturning from travel in southeast Asia.\n\nManitoba: one person has been hospitalized with SARS after returning from\ntravel in southeast Asia.\n\nDue to the mounting concern about transmission of the SARS agent in\nnon-hospital and community settings in the City of Hanoi, Vietnam; the\nPeople's Republic of China including the Hong Kong SAR; and Singapore,\nHealth Canada recommends that persons planning to travel to these areas\nshould defer all travel until further notice. Health Canada also recommends\nalternate routing be considered, when possible, if a traveller is\ntransiting through the People's Republic of China including the Hong Kong\nSAR; City of Hanoi, Vietnam; or Singapore. Health Canada is aware that\nhealth authorities in these affected areas are making concerted efforts to\ncontain the spread of SARS in their populations. Given the uncertainties of\nthe current situation, Health Canada believes it is prudent to await the\noutcome of national and international control measures before undertaking\ntravel to these destinations.\n\nOn 29 Mar 2003, Health Canada deployed 2 additional staff to assist Toronto\nPublic Health and the Ontario Ministry of Health with the investigation of\nSARS cases. This now brings the total number of Health Canada staff\nassisting in Ontario to 7. The department has also provided guidelines for\ninfection control and recommendations on actions for public health settings.\n\nOn 27 Mar 2003, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommended new\nmeasures, related to international travel aimed at reducing the risk of\nfurther international spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).\nThe measures proposed by WHO on the screening of passengers presenting for\ninternational travel are under active consideration by Health\nCanada. Health Canada has discussed this issue with the local airport\nauthority in Toronto and we are putting together a plan. Health Canada is\nhoping to have something in place in Toronto over the course of the weekend.\n\nIt is important to note that airlines operating international flights in\nand out of Canada have been carrying out long-standing procedures to\nprevent sick passengers from getting on airplanes.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[6]\n\nDate: Sat 29 Mar 2003\nFrom: Eugene Yeung <eugene@technoworks.net>\n\n\nCorrection: The Department of Microbiology, Hong Kong University\n----------------------------------------------------------------\nI just wish to inform you of another correction: The virologist at Hong\nKong University (HKU)is Prof. Malik Peiris (not 'Professor Mark Peiris' as\nstated incorrectly by the Moderator in the ProMED-mail post entitled SARS -\nworldwide (16): etiology 20030328.0774). SARS - WORLDWIDE (12):CORRECTION SHANXI NOT SHANGHAI\n***************************************\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["sars"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Shanghai", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Shanxi", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "290", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (14): overview", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=290", "date": "2003-03-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (14): OVERVIEW\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 27 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: MMWR 28 Mar 2003 52(12);241-248 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5212a1.htm#tab>\n\nUpdate: Outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome --- Worldwide, 2003\n--------------------\nCDC continues to support the World Health Organization (WHO) in the\ninvestigation of a multicountry outbreak of unexplained atypical pneumonia\nreferred to as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) (1). This report\nincludes summaries of the epidemiologic investigations and public health\nresponses in several affected locations where CDC is collaborating with\ninternational and national health authorities. This report also describes\nan unusual cluster of cases associated with a hotel in Hong Kong and\nidentifies the potential etiologic agent of SARS. Epidemiologic and\nlaboratory investigations of SARS are ongoing.\nAs of 26 Mar 2003, a total of 1323 suspected and/or probable SARS cases\nhave been reported to WHO from 14 locations (2), using the WHO case\ndefinition or country-specific variations* (3). These reported SARS cases\ninclude 49 deaths (case-fatality proportion: 4 percent). The Chinese\nauthorities have reported 792 suspected/probable cases, including 31\ndeaths, which occurred in Guangdong province during 16 Nov 2002 - 28 Feb 2003.\nCDC is assisting in epidemiologic investigations of cases in Hong Kong,\nVietnam, Taiwan, and Thailand. CDC also is conducting surveillance and\nprevention activities in the United States.\nHong Kong: As of 25 Mar 2003, the Hong Kong Department of Health (DH)\nreported 290 suspected and probable SARS cases. Beginning on 11 Mar 2003,\nan increase in acute pneumonia cases among health-care workers (HCWs) at\nhospital 1 in Hong Kong was reported to DH. Epidemiologic investigation has\nlinked these cases to an index patient (Patient J) who visited a friend in\nhotel M in late February 2003, became ill a few days later, and was\nadmitted to hospital 1 on 4 Mar 2003 [see Figure 1 at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5212a1.htm#tab> an excellent\ndiagrammatic presentation of the outbreak associated with contact at hotel\nM - Mod.MPP]. Patient J visited hotel M while patient A, an ill visitor\nfrom Guangdong province, was staying there.\nAs of 25 Mar 2003, a cluster of 13 persons with suspected/probable SARS are\nknown to have stayed at hotel M (Figure 1). The index patient (patient A)\nhad onset of symptoms on 15 Feb 2003. He traveled from Guangdong province\nto Hong Kong to visit family and stayed on the ninth floor of the hotel on\n21 Feb 2003. He was admitted to hospital 2 on 22 Feb 2003 and died the next\nday. 4 HCWs and 2 of his family members subsequently became ill; one family\nmember died. Of the 12 other patients linked to hotel M, 10 were in the\nhotel the same day as the index patient; the other 2 patients (patients L\nand M) stayed in the hotel during the time that 3 other symptomatic\npatients were guests in the hotel. 9 of the 13 patients, including patient\nA, stayed on the ninth floor; one stayed on the 14th floor; one stayed on\nthe 11th floor; and 2 stayed on both the ninth and 14th floors.\nEpidemiologic investigations have identified patients from this cluster as\nindex patients in subsequent clusters in Hong Kong and other areas. Patient\nB is the index patient for the outbreak in Hanoi involving 59 HCWs and\nclose contacts and also is linked to one case in Thailand. Patients C, D,\nand E are associated with 70 cases in Singapore and 3 cases in Germany.\nPatient F is linked with a cluster of 16 other cases in Toronto (4).\nPatients H and J are linked with outbreaks among HCWs in other hospitals in\nHong Kong. Patient L appears to have become infected during his stay at\nhotel M, with subsequent transmission to his wife, patient M.\nAs of 25 Mar 2003, 6 hospitals and one clinic in Hong Kong have reported\nnosocomial transmission to HCWs following admission of persons with SARS.\nThe suspected index patients of 3 of the 7 nosocomial clusters reported in\nHong Kong have been associated with hotel M (Figure 1).\nHong Kong health authorities have implemented enhanced infection-control\nprocedures in all hospitals in Hong Kong, including more stringent barrier\nand respiratory protection for HCWs, at least daily environmental\ndisinfection of affected wards, and cohorting of SARS patients. New cases\namong HCWs have declined following implementation of these new guidelines.\nHowever, new cases continue to be reported, predominantly among close\ncontacts\u0086 of known patients.\nVietnam: As of 24 Mar 2003, the Vietnamese Ministry of Health in Hanoi has\nreported 59 probable SARS cases. The probable index patient (patient B) was\nan Asian-American businessman aged 47 years who had visited Hong Kong\nbefore traveling to Hanoi. During his visit to Hong Kong, he had stayed at\nhotel M on the same floor, and during the same time, as patient A. Patient\nB became ill after arrival in Hanoi on 23 Feb 2003 and was hospitalized\nwith lower respiratory symptoms on 26 Feb 2003. On 2 Mar 2003, he was\nplaced on mechanical ventilation. On 5 Mar 2003, he was medically evacuated\nto a hospital in Hong Kong and died on 12 Mar 2003. By 5 Mar 2003,\nsecondary probable SARS cases were identified among HCWs in Hanoi. All\nprobable SARS cases reported as of 24 Mar 2003 in Hanoi have been linked\nthrough primary or secondary exposure to the same hospital. 2 patients who\nwere exposed to hospitalized SARS patients traveled subsequently to\nThailand and France and are not included in these numbers.\nThe government of Vietnam has implemented control activities in Hanoi and\nthroughout the country, including daily follow-up of contacts of probable\nSARS cases and community surveillance for suspected SARS cases.\nInfection-control practices to prevent nosocomial transmission have been\nimplemented at Hanoi hospitals with probable SARS cases. Nosocomial cases\nhave decreased since the initial peak of cases linked to exposure to the\nindex patient.\nThailand: As of 23 Mar 2003, the Ministry of Public Health in Thailand has\nreported 4 suspected/probable cases. Dates of illness onset ranged from 11\nto 18 Mar 2003. Of these 4 ill persons, 3 reported travel to Hong Kong\nduring the week before illness onset; the other person is a physician who\ncared for SARS patients in Hanoi. Thailand has begun to implement hospital\ninfection control procedures on the presumption of airborne spread. Gowns,\ngloves, and N-95 masks are widely available in Thailand. As of 26 Mar 2003,\nsurveillance has not documented spread of infection to HCWs. However, one\nHCW from Thailand became infected while investigating the outbreak in Hanoi.\nTaiwan: As of 25 Mar 2003, the Taiwan Department of Health has reported 6\nprobable cases. Dates of illness onset ranged from 25 Feb 2003 to 17 Mar\n2003. Of these 6 ill persons, 4 reported travel to Guangdong province and\nHong Kong during the week before illness onset; none of them had stayed at\nhotel M. The other 2 cases occurred in family members of the first patient.\n2 patients required mechanical ventilation but have improved clinically.\nOn the basis of presumed airborne spread of SARS, Taiwan has aggressively\nimplemented and monitored strict infection-control procedures. Negative\npressure rooms and N-95 respirators are uniformly available for\nhospitalized patients. Active surveillance has not identified nosocomial\ntransmission. Epidemiologic studies are under way to determine specific\nrisk factors for transmission.\nUnited States: As of 26 Mar 2003, CDC has received 51 reports of suspected\nSARS cases from 21 states, identified using the CDC updated interim case\ndefinition. The first suspected case was identified on 15 Mar 2003, in a\nman aged 53 years who traveled to Singapore and became ill on 10 Mar 2003.\n4 clusters of suspected cases have been identified, 3 of which involved a\ntraveler who had visited Southeast Asia (including Guangdong province, Hong\nKong, or Vietnam) and a single family contact. One of these clusters\ninvolved suspected cases in patients L and M, who had stayed together at\nhotel M during 1-6 Mar 2003, when other hotel guests were symptomatic.\nPatient L became sick on 13 Mar 2003 after returning to the United States.\nHis wife, patient M, became ill several days after the onset of her\nhusband's symptoms, suggesting secondary transmission. 3 patients in the\nUnited States with suspected SARS (patients I, L, and M) reported staying\nat hotel M when other persons staying in the hotel were symptomatic. The\nfourth cluster began with a suspected case in a person who traveled in\nGuangdong province and Hong Kong. 2 HCWs subsequently became ill at the\nU.S. hospital where this patient was admitted.\nLaboratory investigations. On 24 Mar 2003, CDC announced that laboratory\nanalysis had identified a previously unrecognized coronavirus in patients\nwith suspected or probable SARS. The new coronavirus was isolated in Vero\nE6 cells from clinical specimens of 2 patients in Thailand and Hong Kong\nwith suspected SARS. The isolate was identified initially as a coronavirus\nby electron microscopy (EM). The identity was corroborated by results of\nimmunostaining, indirect immunofluorescence antibody (IFA) assays, and\nreverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) with sequencing of\na segment of the polymerase gene. IFA testing of sera and RT-PCR analysis\nof clinical specimens from 6 other SARS cases were positive for the new\ncoronavirus. Coronavirus particles also were identified by EM in cells\nobtained by bronchial lavage from a patient with SARS. Sequence analysis\nsuggests that this new agent is distinct from other known coronaviruses.\nOther laboratories collaborating in the WHO-led investigation have found\nsimilar results and also have isolated a different virus, human\nmetapneumovirus, from some patients with suspected SARS. Information is\ninsufficient to determine what roles these 2 viruses might play in the\netiology of SARS.\nEditorial Note:\nCases of SARS continue to be reported from around the world. These cases\nare linked primarily to areas with ongoing transmission, with some reports\nof secondary local transmission. Transmission has been reported in\nGuangdong Province, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Hanoi. In Canada,\ntransmission appears to be limited to a well-defined population of HCWs and\nclose contacts. In Taiwan, limited transmission has occurred to family\nmembers but not to HCWs. Chinese authorities have updated the number of\ncases in Guangdong province and confirmed ongoing disease activity. The\nnumbers of reported cases in Canada, Singapore, and the United States also\ncontinue to increase (2). Transmission in hospitals and households\ncontinues to occur. In addition, reports have been received of possible\ntransmission on ships and planes and in offices. On the basis of available\ninformation, country-specific efforts to limit and halt transmission have\nincluded enhancing surveillance, improving infection-control measures in\nhospitals and homes, selectively closing hospitals and schools, furloughing\nhospital staff, issuing travel advisories, restricting movement of patients\nwith suspected SARS, and establishing quarantines of exposed persons. In\nthe United States, CDC has issued travel advisories and developed\ninfection-control guidelines; efforts have been focused on rapid\nidentification and early isolation of symptomatic persons whose illnesses\nmeet the CDC case definition.\nThe summary of the demographic, clinical, and transmission patterns from\nthe reported areas documents some disparities in case-fatality proportion\nwith pneumonia, and ease of transmission. The data also highlight gaps in\nknowledge about the epidemiology of this new syndrome. Some differences\nprobably reflect concomitant differences in case definition and\nsurveillance methodologies. However, because of the nonspecific case\ndefinition, all reported cases might not represent a single clinical\nentity. Confirmation of the etiology and development of a diagnostic test\nshould help to resolve these discrepancies.\nAlthough the mechanism of SARS transmission remains unclear, on the basis\nof the reported exposures for the majority of cases (i.e., household\ncontacts and HCWs), droplet and contact transmission appear to be the\npredominant modes. The cases in the hotel M cluster and certain hospital\nclusters involving seriously ill patients suggest airborne or fomite\ntransmission. Therefore, infection-control recommendations should include\nprecautions to prevent airborne, droplet, and contact transmission. With\nthe introduction of these control measures, decreases in the reported\nincidence of SARS have been reported in Hong Kong.\nAlthough the etiologic agent has not been confirmed, laboratory data\nindicate that a metapneumovirus or a coronavirus are possible agents.\nInfection with a metapneumovirus, (i.e., enveloped, single-stranded RNA\nvirus) has been associated previously with respiratory disease with much\nless frequent occurrence of severe disease than SARS. Coronaviruses are\nenveloped, single-stranded RNA viruses that infect both humans and animals\n(5). The known human coronaviruses can cause serious infections of the\nlower respiratory tract in children and adults and necrotizing\nenterocolitis in newborns (5,6). Coronaviruses are able to survive on\nenvironmental surfaces for up to 3 hours (6). Coronaviruses might be\ntransmitted person-to-person by droplets, hand contamination, fomites, and\nsmall-particle aerosols (7).\nClinicians evaluating suspected cases should use standard precautions\n(e.g., hand hygiene) together with airborne (e.g., N-95 respirator) and\ncontact (e.g., gowns and gloves) precautions (8). Until the mode of\ntransmission has been defined more precisely, eye protection also should be\nworn for all patient contact. As more clinical and epidemiologic\ninformation becomes available, interim recommendations will be updated.\nThe international spread of disease underscores the need for strong global\npublic health systems, robust health service infrastructures, and expertise\nthat can be mobilized quickly across national boundaries to mirror disease\nmovements. The Institute of Medicine has recently issued recommendations\nfor invigorating the response to emerging infectious diseases that reflect\nthese needs, including the development of a comprehensive system of\nsurveillance for global infectious diseases, the enhancement of disease\nreporting, the development of diagnostic tests, and the formulation and\ndistribution of guidelines on diagnosis (9).\nReferences\n1. WHO defines a probable\ncase as a suspected case of illness that occurs in a person with either 1)\nchest radiograph findings of pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome\n(RDS) or 2) unexplained respiratory illness resulting in death, with\nautopsy examination demonstrating pathology of RDS but no identifiable cause.\n\u0086 Persons who have cared for, lived with, or had direct contact with\nrespiratory secretions and body fluids of a person with SARS.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 27 Mar 2003\nFrom: Marianne Hopp <mjhopp12@yahoo.com>\nSource: WHO SARS update [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_27b/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) - multi-country outbreak - Update\n12 27 Mar 2003\nSARS virus close to conclusive identification, new tests for rapid\ndiagnosis ready soon\n-------------------------\nOn 17 Mar 2003, WHO established a global network of leading laboratories to\ncollaborate in the identification of the causative agent of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS).\nEarly on, labs in the network narrowed the search to members of the\nparamyxovirus and coronavirus families. Findings shared by network labs\nearlier this week began pointing, with increasing consistency, to\ncoronaviruses.\n'Data from many network laboratories indicate that a coronavirus is the\nprimary cause of the disease,' said WHO virologist and epidemiologist Klaus\nStoehr. 'This virus is unlike any known human or animal member of this\nvirus family. It is consistently found in specimens from SARS patients from\nmany countries. It has been isolated in cell culture. We are very close to\nknowing for sure.'\nConclusive identification of a causative [agent] must meet all criteria in\nthe so-called 'Koch\u0092s postulate.' The additional experiments needed to\nfulfill these criteria are currently underway at a laboratory in the\nNetherlands.\nScientists at Hong Kong University had previously announced, on 21 Mar\n2003, the isolation of a new virus that was strongly suspected to be the\ncausative agent of SARS. The virus was detected in cell culture and by\nelectron microscopy. The identity of the virus was not known at the time.\nEarlier this week, researchers at the US Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC) produced strong evidence implicating a coronavirus as the\nagent that causes SARS. Many labs of the WHO network have since been using\nmolecular tests provided by CDC to confirm the presence of a coronavirus in\nspecimens from patients in various countries.\nRapid progress was also facilitated by the sharing of samples, taken from\nSARS patients in areas with large numbers of confirmed cases, among\nparticipants in the laboratory.\nHong Kong, with 367 patients, many of whom are in intensive care, and 10\ndeaths remains the most severely affected area.\nSequencing of the virus is ongoing in 4 laboratories. Results will help\nclassify the virus and refine molecular diagnostic tools. Results will also\nguide the development of specific interventions.\nAt present, no treatment beyond good intensive and supportive care has been\nconsistently shown to improve prognosis in persons with SARS.\nScientists in the network suspect that the virus will prove to be an\nentirely new, or until now undetected, member of the coronavirus family.\nProgress in the development of a diagnostic test:\nEfforts to develop a reliable and easy to use diagnostic test are also\nmoving forward quickly. Hong Kong University, Chinese University, and\nPublic Virus Labs, all located in Hong Kong and all members of the WHO\nnetwork, have devised a basic diagnostic test. In studies using confirmed\nSARS patients and healthy controls, results to date have been consistently\npositive in confirmed cases and consistently negative in the healthy\ncontrols. Further testing will begin tomorrow.\nThe Hong Kong diagnostic test is a molecular test based on the polymerase\nchain reaction (PCR) technology. Hong Kong scientists have also developed a\ndiagnostic tool using the immunofluorescence assay (IFA) technique.\nValidation of the test is being facilitated by gene sequences of the PCR\nprimers electronically by laboratories collaborating in the network. The\nWHO network is offering to make these test materials immediately available\nto labs in other countries throughout the world.\nOver the next few days, samples from hundreds of confirmed and suspected\nSARS cases will be tested using these new diagnostic tools. In so doing,\nthe tools will be further refined and streamlined to upgrade their capacity\nfor daily screening of large numbers of samples.\nThe PCR test is already showing good reliability in detecting SARS cases in\nthe early days of infection. The IFA test is being used to detect infection\nin convalescent sera at about 3 weeks after infection begins. Together, the\n2 tests should help to quickly and safely reassure the many patients the\nworld over who are concerned about suspicious symptoms and yet may be\nsuffering from common illnesses safely treated at home.\nProcedures of isolation and strict barrier nursing, recommended by WHO for\nthe management of suspected SARS cases, have placed a heavy burden on\nhealth care services in several affected areas.\nUpdate on cases and countries\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 1408 cases and 53 deaths have been\nreported from 13 countries. Romania is reporting its first 3 probable cases\ntoday. This represents an increase of 85 cases and 4 deaths compared with\nthe previous day.\nNew data from China\nThe Chinese Ministry of Health has today officially reported 792 cases and\n31 deaths, up to 28 Feb 2003, in Guangdong Province. Approximately 30\npercent of these cases occurred in health workers.\nThe Chinese Ministry of Health has further reported on SARS cases in other\nparts of China. In Beijing, 10 cases and 3 deaths have occurred as of 26\nMar 2003. 2 of these cases are in health workers. In the northern province\nof Shanxi, 4 cases, with no deaths, have occurred as of 26 Mar 2003. 2\ncases are in health workers.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail apologizes for apparent redundancies, but we do wish to share\nthese excellent updates with our readers. The disease has since spread to 13\ncountries on 3 continents.\nThe WHO investigation is being conducted in collaboration with the Chinese\nMinistry of Health, the Chinese Centers for Disease Control, and officials\nfrom Guangdong Province.\nIn the initial stage of the investigation, the WHO team compared case\ndefinitions used in China with those used by WHO to identify SARS and\nconcluded that most cases of atypical pneumonia reported in China from\nmid-November 2002 until 28 Feb 2003 were \u0093indeed cases of SARS.\u0094\nAs reported by the WHO team, Chinese authorities have now agreed to join\nthe WHO collaborative effort to contain the SARS outbreak and prevent its\nfurther international spread. Chinese institutes will be selected within\ndays to participate in 3 global electronic networks set up by WHO to\nfacilitate rapid international collaboration on SARS-related scientific and\nmedical problems. Networks of experts are working to further identify and\ncharacterize the SARS virus, develop better tools for diagnosis and\nmanagement, and understand how the disease is transmitted and what works\nbest to prevent its spread.\nWHO authorities have also been given access to meticulous records kept on\nChinese SARS cases. As China, according to statistics released earlier this\nweek, has experienced the largest number of SARS cases of any country in\nthe world, these data are expected to take understanding of the new\ndisease, and particularly its origins, a major step forward.\nOne of the greatest challenges in containing new diseases is the lack of\nunderstanding of their behaviour as they emerge. The Chinese data, which\nalso cover the longest time frame, are further expected to improve\nunderstanding of how the disease spreads from person to person and why some\noutbreaks appear to have much milder cases than others.\nProgress in identifying the causative agent, now being reported by members\nin a WHO global network of collaborating laboratories, indicates that the\ncausative agent is a new virus in humans that may have jumped the species\nbarrier from its animal host or mutated in ways that have given it more\nlethal properties. Chinese data may help solve the riddle of how the new\nvirus first began to cause disease in humans.\nChina released new figures on the Guangdong outbreak on Wednesday,\nsignificantly increasing the global cumulative total. On Thursday,\nofficials issued the first reports of cases and deaths in ongoing outbreaks\nin Beijing province and in the northern province of Shanxi.\nChina has further agreed today to begin providing up-to-date electronic\nreports of SARS cases throughout China. These reports will be submitted\nelectronically as official reports to WHO from the Ministry of Health.\nAccording to members of the WHO team in China, the government may need a\nfew days to get the new nationwide system of daily electronic reports in\noperation.\nUpdate on cases and countries:\nAs of today, a cumulative total of 1485 cases and 53 deaths have been\nreported from 13 countries. This represents an increase of 77 cases. No new\ndeaths have occurred.\nNo reports were received from China today due to the decision to introduce\na new system of nationwide daily electronic reporting to WHO.\nWith 58 new cases, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China remains\nthe most severely affected area. Other countries reporting new cases\ninclude Canada (1), China, Taiwan (4), Singapore (8), and the United States\nof America (6).\nViet Nam reported no new cases and no new deaths for the fifth day in a\nrow. WHO experts believe that rapid detection of the outbreak and immediate\nintroduction of stringent infection control procedures may have held\nfurther transmission at bay.\nSome patients recovering\nTo date, 19 SARS patients have been discharged from hospitals in Hong Kong,\n17 from Viet Nam, and 25 from Singapore.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 28 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong Department of Health SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/ap.htm>\n\n[A] Figures on atypical pneumonia 28 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs of 1 PM 28 Mar 2003, a total of 425 people with pneumonia symptoms have\nbeen admitted to public hospitals. The\nremaining 20 were new patients and contacts of patients with atypical\npneumonia.\nAs at today, 25 patients have been discharged from hospitals. Investigation also revealed that they went to Beijing on flight\nCA 112 on 15 Mar 2003. A number of passengers in flight CA 112 were\nconfirmed to have contracted with atypical pneumonia earlier this week. It\nis suspected that the 4 Taiwan passengers contracted the disease from a\n73-year-old passenger in flight CA 112 on their way to Beijing.\nDH has informed the Airport Authority and the 2 airlines concerned. Advice\nwas also given to the airline concerned to disinfect the airplanes. DH is\ntracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these 2 flights, for\nsurveillance purposes.\nThe spokesman reminded members of the public who have respiratory symptoms\nincluding fever, chills, malaise, and cough to avoid traveling by plane\nbefore recovery.\n[These advisories are consistent with the now global recommendation for\npre-boarding screening of airline passengers for symptoms compatible with\nSARS coming from areas with known local transmission. These cases do not\nas yet suggest a more widespread easier transmission, as sitting close to\nan individual who is actively coughing for several hours on an airline\nflight would still be classified as 'close contact'. - Mod.MPP]\n[C] Enhanced measures to control infectious disease 28 Mar 2003\nA spokesman for the Department of Health (DH) on 28 Mar 2003 called on\nmembers of the public who have paid visits to Metropole Hotel on 21-22 Feb\n2003 or the Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH) on or after 1 Mar 2003,\nexcluding staff working in PWH, to contact them for health surveillance.\nThe spokesman said in order to enhance measures to control atypical\npneumonia, DH has converted 4 clinics into designated medical centres (DMC)\nfor daily surveillance of contacts of confirmed atypical pneumonia cases.\nThe 4v DMC are Pamela Youde Child Assessment Centre (Shatin); South Kwai\nChung Jockey Club Polyclinic; Shek Kip Mei Health Centre, and Sai Ying Pun\nJockey Club Clinic. They will be operated from 9 am to 5 pm daily, starting\n31 Mar 2003.\nThe spokesman said that people who are identified to be close contacts of\npatients suffering from atypical pneumonia are required to report each day\nfor check-up at one of these DMCs for 10 consecutive days. 'Surveillance\nof the health condition of these individuals will be made accordingly. If\nthey have developed symptoms of the disease, they will be admitted to\nhospital for isolation and treatment. People who had close contact with\nthese patients should stay at home as far as possible and should not go out\nunless it is absolutely necessary,' the spokesman said. [This appears to\nbe a contradiction, as in order to report to one of the 4 designated DMCs,\nthese individuals will be leaving their homes and travelling to the DMCs,\nmany of whom might be travelling by public transportation. - Mod.MPP]\nDH will send letters to all close contacts to ask them to attend one of the\nDMCs for check-up. To ensure that every close contact would be put under\nhealth surveillance, DH will set up a special hotline 187 2222 to answer\nenquiries from this group of people. The hotline will be operated between 2\nPM and 6 PM 29 Mar 2003 and from 9 am to 5 pm from 30 Mar 2003 onwards. DH\nhas the power to enforce these mandatory measures whenever necessary.\nClose contact means persons having cared for, having lived with, or having\nhad direct contact with respiratory secretions and body fluids of a person\nwith severe acute respiratory syndrome. Close contacts are, therefore,\nmainly household contacts and those caring for the case. Social contact\nimplies persons who have had contact with an individual with severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome but do not fit the definition of close contact.\nAll co-workers and all visitors of cases in hospitals are social contacts.\nIf these social contacts had direct contact with respiratory secretions and\nbody fluids of a case, they are classified as close contact. Social\ncontacts with symptoms will be advised to attend one of the DMCs.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 28 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health SARS update [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5700>\n\nAs of 28 Mar 2003, a total of 86 people with SARS have been reported to the\nMinistry of Health. Of the additional patients, 7 were close contacts of\nSARS cases: 4 hospital staff and 3 family members. These 7 cases are traced\nback to the index cases. The remaining case is a new index case who\nreturned to Singapore from a trip to Hong Kong and Beijing, China.\nEpidemiological investigations are ongoing.\nTo date, 25 patients have been discharged from hospital, 2 have died, and\nthe remaining 59 patients are hospitalised. All the patients are stable\nexcept for 12 patients who are in serious condition.\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is a new disease for which the\ncause has not yet been determined. People may perceive the risks of being\ninfected by SARS differently. Some are complacent, while others overreact.\nSingapore has taken extra precautionary measures, beyond WHO's recommended\ncontrol measures, to ensure that the spread is contained. These include\nisolating all suspected and SARS patients in TTSH, enhanced infection\ncontrol measures for hospital staff, and instituting home quarantine\nmeasures for those who have come into contact with people diagnosed with\nSARS. The key strategy is to identify suspect cases once they show symptoms\nof the disease and isolate them to prevent transmission to more people. The\nclosure of schools is to allay the concerns of parents. We will step up\nefforts to help the public understand the nature of SARS and how they could\nhelp us in our efforts to minimise the risk of community spread.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 28 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome Report of Suspected Cases Under\nInvestigation in the United States\nCase definition:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization on 28 Mar 2003.\nState: Suspected cases under investigation*\nAlabama: 1\nCalifornia: 12\nConnecticut: 1\nHawaii: 3\nIllinois: 1\nKansas: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 1\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nMinnesota: 2\nNew Jersey: 3\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 2\nNew York: 8\nPennsylvania: 3\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 3\nUtah: 4\nVirginia: 4\nWisconsin: 1\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 59\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5]\nDate: 28 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada SARS 28 Mar 2003 6:30 PM [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update13.htm>\n\nUpdate #13 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n-------------------------\nAs of 28 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 37 individuals who\nhave become ill with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Ontario\nand British Columbia. "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (13): ETIOLOGY\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 27 Mar 2003 06:42\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: AFX News - Asia [edited]\n\nHK researchers announce diagnostic test for SARS; confirm virus source\n----------------------------------\nHONG KONG (AFX) - University of Hong Kong reseachers announced that they\nhave developed a diagnostic test to rapidly identify victims of an atypical\npneumonia which has killed some 50 people around the world.\nIn a statement, the Department of Microbiology of the Faculty of Medicine\nof the University of Hong Kong also said it has confirmed previous findings\nthat the global outbreak of atypical pneumonia was caused by the Coronavirus.\nThe US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said earlier this\nweek that the virus causing the global outbreak of atypical pneumonia, or\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), was from the Coronavirus group.\nIn their statement, the University of Hong Kong researchers said they have\n'confirmed that the recent outbreak of pneumonia is caused by the virus\nknown as Coronavirus.\n'The discovery of the agent is an important international research\nbreakthrough,' they said, adding that the disease should be referred to as\nCoronavirus Pneumonia, or CVP.\nThey said the diagnostic test they have developed 'will enable early and\nreliable diagnosies of CVP and hence early treatment of the disease.\n'The early phase diagnostic test helps infection control by identifying\nwhich contacts have or have not acquired CVP and ensure discharged patients\nwill not infect the community,' they added.\nThe diagnostic test will be available at hospitals here starting tomorrow,\nthe researchers told at a press conference.\nYuen Kwok-yung, head of microbiology at the faculty of medicine, said the\nvirus is mainly transmitted by contact.\n'Your hands are the greatest enemy,' Yuen said, adding that the virus can\nonly survive in the air for some three hours.\nThere have been more than 50 deaths and more than 1300 reported cases of\nSARS worldwide with the majority of the fatalities occurring in China. The\ndisease has claimed 10 lives Hong Kong, 4 in Vietnam and 3 in Canada.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 27 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: International Herald Tribune 27 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.iht.com/articles/91278.html>\n\nHONG KONG The government imposed quarantine measures Thursday to impede the\nspread of an epidemic of deadly pneumonia as scientists announced a\nbreakthrough in testing patients for the mysterious virus. Hong Kong, the\ntransportation hub from which the disease apparently spread worldwide,\nannounced the immediate quarantine of more than 1000 residents suspected of\ninfection and shut down schools for 1 million students. ''Hong Kong faces\nan epidemic that the world has never seen before,'' said Tung Chee-hwa, the\nterritory's chief executive. ''This is a very, very serious issue.''\nHong Kong has been battling a wildfire the rapid spread of the disease for\n2 weeks. The quarantine announced Friday applies to 1080 people who had\nclose contact with those infected by the disease. Nearly 1000 other people\nwho had social contact with infected patients will undergo\nsurveillance. Penalties for breaking domestic quarantine include a fine of\n5000 Hong Kong dollars (about USD 640) , obligatory confinement and 6\nmonths in prison. The Hong Kong measures came a day after Singapore\nundertook similar moves. Singapore, by contrast, cancelled all schools and\ninstituted draconian quarantine measures shortly after the first sign of\ninfection appeared.\n''We are favor of any measure within the law that will contain a disease\noutbreak,'' said Peter Cordingley, a spokesman for the World Health\nOrganization. ''We don't have any problem with Singapore's approach.''\nThe most secretive least forthcoming country, however, has been China,\nwhich on Wednesday acknowledged the presence of the atypical pneumonia for\nthe first time, announcing the highest number of infected patients and\nfatalities in the world. The Chinese authorities also said the situation\nwas ''basically under control,'' hoping to avert the panic that took place\nseveral months ago over outbreak of pneumonia now thought to be linked to\nthe current crisis.\nPopular worries were evident throughout Hong Kong on Thursday as a growing\nproportion of the public put on face masks while walking in public areas.\nResearchers at the University of Hong Kong announced successful DNA\nsequencing of a virus that they say causes the disease. The finding, if\nconfirmed by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, could\nallow creation of a rapid diagnostic test and reduce death rates by\nallowing doctors to identify affected patients sooner.\nThe illness, severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, has killed at\nleast 53 people, mostly in Asia, and infected 1300 in more than a dozen\ncountries. The group of microbiologists from the University of Hong Kong\nidentified the virus as a new strain from the family of coronaviruses,\nhighly contagious viruses that are the second leading cause of colds in humans.\n''The coronavirus is the primary cause of the disease,'' said Malik Peiris,\na professor of microbiology, adding that another virus, of the family that\ncauses mumps, may also be involved and increase the severity of the\ndisease. Peiris said the new strain had characteristics unlike any other he\nhad ever seen.\n''This is unlike any other human or animal virus ever described before,''\nhe said, adding that humans may not necessarily develop immunity to such a\nvirus after recovering from an infection.\n''If we find they behave like a cold, you can get the same cold again and\nagain,'' Peiris said, warning that transmission of such a virus occurs\nthrough droplets and can take place in many common public areas.\n''Railings, lift buttons and just about anything touched by a person with\nan infection can pass on the virus,'' he said.\nTo avoid infection, he warned people to wash their hands frequently, avoid\ntouching the eyes, mouth or nose and wipe down with rubbing alcohol. ''The\nvirus is easily killed with rubbing alcohol,'' Peiris said. ''Wear a mask\nif you want, but make sure not to touch your face with your hands when\nadjusting it.''\nPeiris said his findings supported the multiple drug treatment with\nribavirin and steroids currently administered to patients. The ribavirin\nsuppresses growth of the virus, while the steroids mitigate damage caused\nby the body's own immune reaction.\n[byline: Thomas Crampton]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 27 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Reuters 27 Mar 2003 10:50 EST [edited]\n<http://asia.reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type=healthNews&storyID=2459976>\n\nBERLIN (Reuters) - Microbiologist Bernhard Fleischer, head of Hamburg's\nBernhard Nocht Institute for Tropical Medicine (BNI), said his institute\nhad probably identified the virus causing severe acute respiratory syndrome\n(SARS).\n'I don't assume that there will be a worldwide epidemic which will spread\namong the population,' Fleischer told Reuters in an interview. 'We are\nlucky that this disease is not as contagious and does not spread as easily\nas first assumed.'\nScientists from the BNI, Germany's top tropical diseases institute, worked\non identifying the virus by analyzing tissue samples taken from a doctor\nfrom Singapore who was being treated in Frankfurt after showing symptoms of\nSARS. Fleischer said his institute had developed a test with which experts\ncould detect within one or two hours whether a patient had caught the virus.\nA group of microbiologists from the University of Hong Kong said on\nThursday they had also identified a virus and believe it is a new strain\nfrom the family of coronaviruses, the second-leading cause of colds in\nhumans. The finding is consistent with tests conducted by the U.S. Centers\nfor Disease Control and Prevention.\nCoronaviruses, so named because they have a crown-like appearance when seen\nunder a microscope, are often responsible for upper respiratory infections\nin premature infants.\nFleischer said he believed it is spread through droplets by sneezing and\ncoughing and therefore can only be caught through very close contact with\nan infected person. 'I expect it to abate in the next few weeks,' he\nadded. Fleischer also said he believed the disease was not very contagious\nbefore a patient started to show symptoms, such as high fever and shortness\nof breath. Other viruses are highly contagious from the moment of infection.\nDeveloping a serum against SARS could take years, Fleischer said, but he\nadded that a new vaccination may not be necessary as known medications\nagainst viruses could help to combat it. 'It first needs to be examined\nwhether known and existing medication can help,' he said. The Hong Kong\nresearch team said patients were responding well to a cocktail of\nanti-viral drugs and steroids.\nFleischer said his institute and U.S. scientists had independently found\nthat the cause of SARS was probably a coronavirus. It had probably been\ntransmitted from animals to human beings, he said. However, other labs that\nanalyzed samples from patients had said they found what looked like a new\nkind of paramyxovirus, which causes measles and respiratory disease in babies.\n[byline: Kerstin Gehmlich]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hong Kong is the third location with documented local transmission of SARS\nto implement quarantine measures for known contacts of SARS cases\n(Singapore and Ontario Canada have implemented similar quarantines). In\naddition, Hong Kong and Singapore have closed schools in an attempt to\nreduce situations of close contact that might enhance transmission.\nThe multiple press releases related to the identification of a coronavirus\ncontinue to be promising, (especially if there has been genetic sequencing\nof the virus), yet again caution needs to be exerted until further\nconfirmation that this agent is in fact the etiologic agent of\nSARS. (Remembering that last week 3 independent laboratories identified a\nparamyxovirus from specimens taken from SARS patients). It is also\npremature to conclude that infection with this agent does not lead to the\nproduction of protective antibodies as is suggested in one of the newswires\nabove. There are many questions that remain to be answered before\ndefinitive conclusions can be drawn and more detailed specific\nrecommendations can be made. - Mod.MPP]\n[Two of the laboratories that originally suggested that SARS was associated\nwith infection by an unspecified paramyxovirus have now come into line with\nthe CDC verdict that the etiologic agent has the characteristics of a\nmember of the genus _Coronavirus_ of the family _Coronaviridae_. A\nconsensus seems to be appearing. Until the full details of the scientific\nevidence become available, however, the final verdict will remain in doubt\nin view of the earlier contrary reports from Canada that the recently\ncharacterized human metapneumovirus may be the etiologic agent. WHO\n[2] Hong Kong - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] USA - CDC\n[5] Canada - Health Canada\n[6] Newswire briefs\n[A] Japan\n******\n[1]\nDate: 27 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Cases (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_27/en/>\nFrom: 1 Feb 2003 To: 27 Mar 2003, 17:30 GMT+1\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No.deaths/ Local transmission*\nCanada: 28/ 3/ Yes\nChina: + 806/ 34/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 367/ 10**/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 6/ 0/ Yes\nFrance: 1/ 0/ None\nGermany: 4/ 0/ None\nItaly: 2/ 0/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 2/ 0/ None\nRomania: 3/ 0/ None\nSingapore: 78/ 2/ Yes\nSwitzerland: 2/ 0/ To be determined\nThailand: 3/ 0/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 3/ 0/ None\nUnited States: 45 \u00a7/ 0/ To be determined\nViet Nam: 58/ 4/ Yes\nTotal: 1408/ 53\nNotes:\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n*National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n+ 792 cases, including 31 deaths, reported from Guangdong Province cover\nthe period 16 Nov 2002 to 28 Feb 2003. These cases were compiled from\ninvestigations as well as hospital reports and may include suspect as well\nas probable cases of SARS.\n\u00a7Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national level,\nprobable cases are reported by all countries except the United States of\nAmerica, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n**One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 27 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_03_27/en/>\nCountry: Area\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Beijing, Guangdong, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of\nChina, Shanxi, Taiwan Province\nViet Nam: Hanoi\nAn affected area: an area in which local chain(s) of transmission of SARS\nis/are occurring as reported by the national public health authorities.\n[Shanxi province and Beijing in China have been added to the affected areas\nlist in the past 24 hours with local transmission of SARS as officially\nreported by the government. - Mod.MPP]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[C] Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak -\nUpdate 11 27 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_27/en/>\n\nWHO recommends new measures to prevent travel-related spread of SARS\n-------------------------\nWHO is today recommending new measures related to international travel\naimed at reducing the risk of further international spread of severe acute\nrespiratory syndrome (SARS).\nThe recommended measures include screening of air passengers departing from\na small number of affected areas on flights to another country. The\naffected areas, where transmission of the SARS infectious agent is known to\nbe spreading in a human-to-human chain, are kept under constant review and\nposted each day on the WHO web site. At present, only 4 countries are\nconcerned. [see affected areas [B] above]\nNo additional precautions for the screening of departing passengers at\nairports in any other parts of the world are called for in today\u0092s\nrecommendations.\nThe screening measures, recommended for consideration by national health\nofficials and port authorities, involve an interview with passengers,\ndeparting from a limited number of areas, to detect illness with symptoms\nthat give reason to suspect that a passenger may be infected with SARS.\nNational authorities may wish to advise travellers with fever departing on\ninternational flights from the few areas where SARS transmission has been\ndocumented to postpone travel until they feel better. All international\ntravellers should be aware of the symptoms of SARS and seek immediate\nmedical attention should symptoms occur.\nSince global surveillance of SARS began at the end of February 2003, some\nevidence suggests that a small number of suspected and probable cases of\nSARS have departed from the small number of affected countries on flights\nto other countries.\nMost cases continue to occur in persons in close face-to-face contact with\nSARS patients. Close face-to-face contact could conceivably occur in an\naircraft among persons seated close to a person infected with SARS and\ncoughing or sneezing.\nWHO has also issued detailed recommendations to airlines on steps to take\nshould a suspected case of SARS be detected in flight. The WHO\nrecommendations include advice on step-by-step procedures for following up\nfellow passengers on the flight who may have had close contact with the\npossible case and the specific advice that should be given to these\ntravellers and their families.\nWHO recommends that contacts of a person be allowed to continue to travel\nso long as they do not have symptoms compatible with SARS.\nThe WHO case definition, which is being widely used for surveillance\npurposes, is posted at the WHO web site and is kept under constant review.\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/casedefinition/en/>\nMany national health authorities have also issued SARS-related advice to\ninternational travellers.\n******\n[2]\nDate: 27 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health [edited]\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n[A] Figures on atypical pneumonia 27 Mar 2003\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs at 1 PM 27 Mar 2003, a total of 367 people with pneumonia symptoms have\nbeen admitted to public hospitals. The 51 additional patients reported\ntoday include 6 healthcare workers and 22 patients from Amoy Garden. The\nremaining 23 were new patients and contacts of patients with atypical\npneumonia.\nAs of 27 Mar 2003, 19 patients have been discharged from hospitals. A total\nof 45 patients are receiving treatment in the intensive care unit. An\nadditional patient, a Filipino female with atypical pneumonia, died in\nQueen Elizabeth Hospital on 24 Mar 2003.\nDH confirmed 4 new cases of atypical pneumonia involving school children\ncomprising 3 boys and a girl aged from 5 to 13. These cases are among the\n367 cases reported today.\nMeanwhile, the Department of Health (DH) appealed to patients who had\nconsulted a private doctor, Dr Lau Tai Kwan, between 20-22 Mar 2003 to\ncontact the Department at 2760 7721 during office hours. Dr Lau suffered\nfrom atypical pneumonia and has been included in the reported cases.\nDr Lau's clinic address is Room 130, Tung Ying Building, 100 Nathan Road,\nTsim Sha Tsui. He developed symptoms on 20 Mar 2003 and was admitted to\nPrincess Margaret Hospital on 22 Mar 2003.\nDH and HA are pleased to see the development of rapid diagnostic test,\nwhich facilitates prompt confirmation of severe respiratory syndrome cases\nand evaluation of effectiveness of treatment.\n'We have great appreciation for the efforts of the health professionals in\nthe management of atypical pneumonia, and the important research progress\nof the University of Hong Kong and the Chinese University of Hong Kong\ntowards identification of the cause of the disease,' a DH spokesman added.\nThe breakdown of figures is as follows:\nTotal Admissions (The numbers in bracket are those with pneumonia symptoms)\nHealth care workers of Hospitals/Clinics and medical students 149 (148)\n10 of the patients were discharged\nPatients, family members & visitors 221 (219)\n9 of the patients were discharged\nTotal admissions 370 (367)\n19 were discharged\n\n[B] Ordinance amended to control infectious disease 27 Mar 2003\nIn order to enhance control over the spread of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome (commonly known as atypical pneumonia) in the community, the\nDirector of Health, Dr Margaret Chan, on 27 Mar 2003 added Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome to the list of infectious diseases specified in the\nFirst Schedule to the Quarantine and Prevention of Disease Ordinance (Hong\nKong Laws Chapter 141).\n'This enables the application of the provisions of the Ordinance and its\nsubsidiary legislation as and when appropriate. This would enhance the\ncoverage of our infectious diseases surveillance system so that Department\nof Health can better monitor the occurrence of Severe Acute Respiratory\nSyndrome.' Dr Chan said.\nRegulation 4 of the Prevention of the Spread of Infectious Diseases\nRegulations requires medical practitioners to notify the Director of Health\nif they have reason to suspect the existence of any of the infectious\ndiseases specified in the First Schedule to the Ordinance.\n'The reporting of infectious diseases is an important element of the\nsurveillance, control and prevention of outbreak of infectious diseases.'\nsaid Dr Chan.\nDr Chan reminded medical practitioners of the requirement to notify\nDepartment of Health any suspected cases of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome.\nDr Chan exercised her power in accordance with sections 72 and 8(4) of the\nOrdinance and amended the First Schedule to the Ordinance and Form 2 in the\nSchedule to the Prevention of the Spread of Infectious Diseases Regulations\nrespectively by making the Quarantine and Prevention of Disease Ordinance\n(Amendment of First Schedule) Order 2003 and the Prevention of the Spread\nof Infectious Diseases Regulations (Amendment of Form) Order 2003.\nWith the addition of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, a total of 28\ninfectious diseases are included in the First Schedule to the Ordinance.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 27 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 27 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5680>\n\n16 SARS patients discharged 27 Mar 2003\n------------------\nAs of 27 Mar 2003, a total of 16 SARS patients have been discharged from\nhospital. The number of SARS patients reported to MOH is 78. The 4\nadditional patients consist of one family member and 3 hospital staff.\nThis brings the total number of family members, friends, or close contacts\ninfected by SARS to 38, and the total number of hospital staff affected by\nSARS to 37. 2 patients have passed away. Among the 60 patients who are\nstill hospitalised, all are in stable condition, except for 11 patients who\nare in serious conditions.\nThe Ministry would like to reiterate that SARS is not infectious until the\nperson develops fever. Transmission of SARS is only through close contact\nwith infected persons, and all SARS cases in Singapore so far could be\ntraced back to the 3 index cases. There is no evidence to date that the\ndisease spreads through casual contact.\nSARS patients have been isolated for treatment at TTSH/ CDC, while those\nwho had close contact with them have been quarantined under the Infectious\nDisease Act. The risk of transmission to the general public is therefore\nvery low, so Singaporeans should stay calm and continue with their daily\nroutine.\nThe Ministry of Health advises the public to heed our travel advisory and\nto avoid travel to Hong Kong, Hanoi and Guangdong province in China for the\ntime being, unless absolutely necessary.
