(09): clinical features", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=282", "date": "2003-03-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (09): CLINICAL FEATURES\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: 26 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/cliniciansconference/en/>\n\nClinicians hold virtual conference on management of SARS patients 26 Mar 2003\n------------------------\nToday, 80 clinicians from 13 countries participated in an electronic 'grand\nrounds' on clinical features and treatment for patients with Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome, known as SARS. Their discussion, organized by the WHO\nnetwork of clinicians focused on the disease's features at presentation,\ntreatment, progression, prognostic indicators, and discharge criteria. No\ntherapy demonstrated any particular effectiveness. Clinicians agreed that a\nsubset of SARS patients, perhaps 10 percent, decline and need mechanical\nassistance to breathe. These people often have other illnesses that\ncomplicate their care. In this group, mortality is high.\nBased on their experiences with patients, SARS clinicians are drawing the\nfollowing conclusions:\nDisease presentation:\nAll of the clinicians described presentations of SARS patients and the\ngeneral consensus is that presentation is relatively consistent across all\nnations. Presentation is of a prodromal illness with a sudden onset of high\nfever. In a great number of cases this sudden, high fever is associated\nwith myalgia, chills, rigors, and non-productive cough. At presentation\n(which is often 3 to 4 days after onset of symptoms), a large proportion of\npatients have characteristic changes on chest x-rays.\nDisease progression:\nFollowing presentation, chest x-rays continue to worsen and most patients\ndemonstrate bilateral changes with interstitial infiltrations (fluid\nbuild-up between cells in the lungs). These infiltrations produce x-rays\nwith a characteristic cloudy appearance. Patients then fall into one of 2\ngroups. The majority, 80 to 90 percent of patients at day 6 or 7, show\nimprovement in signs and symptoms. A second smaller group, progress to a\nmore severe form of SARS, many of whom develop acute respiratory distress\nsyndrome and require mechanical ventilatory support. Though mortality\nassociated with the more severe group is high, a number of patients have\nremained on ventilator support for prolonged periods of time. Mortality in\nthe severe group appears to be linked to a patient's other illnesses\n(co-morbid factors).\nPrognostic indicators:\nGenerally, patients over 40 with other illnesses are more likely to\nprogress to the severe form of the disease.\nTherapy:\nNumerous antibiotic therapies have been tried to date with little clear\neffect. Ribavirin with or without use of steroids has been used in an\nincreasing number of patients. But in the absence of clinical indicators,\nits effectiveness has not been proven. Currently the most appropriate\nmanagement measures are general supportive therapy, insuring the person is\nhydrated and treated for subsequent infections.\nWhat next:\nPlanning these grand rounds regularly. The clinicians involved in\nestablishing management guidelines (treatment, management of patients and\ncontacts, discharge).\nThe participants agreed to 'meet' regularly using electronic communications\nand to rapidly develop international guidelines for the care of SARS patients.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 26 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC MMWR 21 Mar 2003 52 (Dispatch);1-2\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/m2d321.htm>\n\nPreliminary Clinical Description of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n-----------------------\nSevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a condition of unknown etiology\nthat has been described in patients in Asia, North America, and Europe.\nThis report summarizes the clinical description of patients with SARS based\non information collected since mid-February 2003 by the World Health\nOrganization (WHO), Health Canada, and CDC in collaboration with health\nauthorities and clinicians in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Bangkok, Singapore, the\nUnited Kingdom, Slovenia, Canada, and the United States. This information\nis preliminary and limited by the broad and necessarily nonspecific case\ndefinition.\nAs of 21 Mar 2003, the majority of patients identified as having SARS have\nbeen adults aged 25--70 years who were previously healthy. Few suspected\ncases of SARS have been reported among children aged <15 years.\nThe incubation period for SARS is typically 2--7 days; however, isolated\nreports have suggested an incubation period as long as 10 days. The illness\nbegins generally with a prodrome of fever (greater than 100.4 F [greater\nthan 38.0 C]). Fever often is high, sometimes is associated with chills and\nrigors, and might be accompanied by other symptoms, including headache,\nmalaise, and myalgia. At the onset of illness, some persons have mild\nrespiratory symptoms. Typically, rash and neurologic or gastrointestinal\nfindings are absent; however, some patients have reported diarrhea during\nthe febrile prodrome.\nAfter 3--7 days, a lower respiratory phase begins with the onset of a dry,\nnonproductive cough or dyspnea, which might be accompanied by or progress\nto hypoxemia. In 10--20 percent of cases, the respiratory illness is severe\nenough to require intubation and mechanical ventilation. The case-fatality\nrate among persons with illness meeting the current WHO case definition of\nSARS is approximately 3 percent [based on today's data with the additional\ninformation from China, 49 deaths reported and 1323 cases the observed case\nfatality rate is now 3.7 percent - Mod.MPP].\nChest radiographs might be normal during the febrile prodrome and\nthroughout the course of illness. However, in a substantial proportion of\npatients, the respiratory phase is characterized by early focal\ninterstitial infiltrates progressing to more generalized, patchy,\ninterstitial infiltrates. Some chest radiographs from patients in the late\nstages of SARS also have shown areas of consolidation.\nEarly in the course of disease, the absolute lymphocyte count is often\ndecreased. Overall white blood cell counts have generally been normal or\ndecreased. At the peak of the respiratory illness, approximately 50 percent\nof patients have leukopenia and thrombocytopenia or low-normal platelet\ncounts (50 000 - 150 000 / microL). Early in the respiratory phase,\nelevated creatine phosphokinase levels (as high as 3000 IU/L) and hepatic\ntransaminases (2 to 6 times the upper limits of normal) have been noted. In\nthe majority of patients, renal function has remained normal.\nThe severity of illness might be highly variable, ranging from mild illness\nto death. Although a few close contacts of patients with SARS have\ndeveloped a similar illness, the majority have remained well. Some close\ncontacts have reported a mild, febrile illness without respiratory signs or\nsymptoms, suggesting the illness might not always progress to the\nrespiratory phase.\nTreatment regimens have included several antibiotics to presumptively treat\nknown bacterial agents of atypical pneumonia. In several locations, therapy\nalso has included antiviral agents such as oseltamivir or ribavirin.\nSteroids have also been administered orally or intravenously to patients in\ncombination with ribavirin and other antimicrobials. At present, the most\nefficacious treatment regimen, if any, is unknown.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are posting this for the benefit of clinician subscribers who might not\nhave seen cases of SARS and would be interested in the current clinical\ndescription and discussions. As more information on the clinical\npresentation and treatment guidelines become available we shall post these\nas well. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n The case-fatality\nrate among persons with illness meeting the current WHO case definition of\nSARS is approximately 3 percent [based on today's data with the additional\ninformation from China, 49 deaths reported and 1323 cases the observed case\nfatality rate is now 3.7 percent - Mod. This report summarizes the clinical description of patients with SARS based\non information collected since mid-February 2003 by the World Health\nOrganization (WHO), Health Canada, and CDC in collaboration with health\nauthorities and clinicians in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Bangkok, Singapore, the\nUnited Kingdom, Slovenia, Canada, and the United States. Some close\ncontacts have reported a mild, febrile illness without respiratory signs or\nsymptoms, suggesting the illness might not always progress to the\nrespiratory phase. However, in a substantial proportion of\npatients, the respiratory phase is characterized by early focal\ninterstitial infiltrates progressing to more generalized, patchy,\ninterstitial infiltrates. Based on their experiences with patients, SARS clinicians are drawing the\nfollowing conclusions:\nDisease presentation:\n Today, 80 clinicians from 13 countries participated in an electronic 'grand\nrounds' on clinical features and treatment for patients with Severe Acute\nRespiratory Syndrome, known as SARS. At the peak of the respiratory illness, approximately 50 percent\nof patients have leukopenia and thrombocytopenia or low-normal platelet\ncounts At presentation\n(which is often 3 to 4 days after onset of symptoms), a large proportion of\npatients have characteristic changes on chest x-rays. Though mortality\nassociated with the more severe group is high, a number of patients have\nremained on ventilator support for prolonged periods of time. Following presentation, chest x-rays continue to worsen and most patients\ndemonstrate bilateral changes with interstitial infiltrations (fluid\nbuild-up between cells in the lungs). The clinicians involved in\nestablishing management guidelines (treatment, management of patients and\ncontacts, discharge). Source: WHO SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/cliniciansconference/en/>\n\nClinicians hold virtual conference on management of SARS patients 26 Mar 2003\n \nSevere acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) is a condition of unknown etiology\nthat has been described in patients in Asia, North America, and Europe. Clinicians agreed that a\nsubset of SARS patients, perhaps 10 percent, decline and need mechanical\nassistance to breathe. All of the clinicians described presentations of SARS patients and the\ngeneral consensus is that presentation is relatively consistent across all\nnations. Source: CDC MMWR 21 Mar 2003 52 (Dispatch);1-2\n<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/m2d321.htm>\n\nPreliminary Clinical Description of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n Early in the respiratory phase,\nelevated creatine phosphokinase levels (as high as 3000 IU/L) and hepatic\ntransaminases (2 to 6 times the upper limits of normal) have been noted. A second smaller group, progress to a\nmore severe form of SARS, many of whom develop acute respiratory distress\nsyndrome and require mechanical ventilatory support. After 3--7 days, a lower respiratory phase begins with the onset of a dry,\nnonproductive cough or dyspnea, which might be accompanied by or progress\nto hypoxemia. Typically, rash and neurologic or gastrointestinal\nfindings are absent; however, some patients have reported diarrhea during\nthe febrile prodrome. Their discussion, organized by the WHO\nnetwork of clinicians focused on the disease's features at presentation,\ntreatment, progression, prognostic indicators, and discharge criteria. Fever often is high, sometimes is associated with chills and\nrigors, and might be accompanied by other symptoms, including headache,\nmalaise, and myalgia. The illness\nbegins generally with a prodrome of fever (greater than 100.4 F [greater\nthan 38.0 C]). As more information on the clinical\npresentation and treatment guidelines become available we shall post these\nas well. - Mod. [We are posting this for the benefit of clinician subscribers who might not\nhave seen cases of SARS and would be interested in the current clinical\ndescription and discussions. Currently the most appropriate\nmanagement measures are general supportive therapy, insuring the person is\nhydrated and treated for subsequent infections. This information\nis preliminary and limited by the broad and necessarily nonspecific case\ndefinition. At present, the most\nefficacious treatment regimen, if any, is unknown.\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "sars"], "syndromes": ["acute respiratory syndrome"], "event_date": ["2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2049-03-25 00:00:00", "1323-03-25 00:00:00", "2003-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "United Kingdom", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Bangkok", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Slovenia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Singapore", "country": "Singapore"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "283", "headline": "PRO/EDR> SARS - worldwide (10): infectious disease perspectives", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=283", "date": "2003-03-26 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (10): INFECTIOUS DISEASE PERSPECTIVES\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 26 Mar 2003 11:12:02 -0500\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Infectious Disease Society of America letter to members [edited]\n\nEpidemiology:\nThis epidemic apparently started in Guongdong Province in Southern\nChina. Several cases have occurred in travelers to this area. An\n'impressive' cluster has been linked to one hotel in Hong Kong. A physician\nfrom Guongdong visited Hong Kong for a wedding on 21 Feb 2003, and stayed\none night at this hotel. 12 other cases have been linked to this hotel; 9\nof the 12 stayed on the same floor. These cases were then responsible for\nsecondary clusters in Toronto, Hanoi, Singapore, and further cases at 3\nHong Kong hospitals. It is my understanding that this floor is a 'smoking\nfloor' of the hotel, which may be of interest with regard to transmission.\nAt least 200 cases have occurred in Hong Kong, and transmission has been\ndocumented from patients to healthcare workers to healthcare worker's\nfamilies, and most recently into the schools in that area. WHO is\ncurrently investigating 456 cases, including 17 deaths in 16 countries.\nThis total does not include any from China. In the United States, CDC is\ncurrently investigating 40 cases that meet the case definition in 18\nstates. The age range is 7 years to 78 years. 16 of these cases were\nhospitalized, and one patient was placed on mechanical ventilation but has\nsince recovered. There have been no deaths attributed to SARS in the United\nStates to date. At least 10 of the cases had documented pneumonia by chest\nx-ray. 2 of the cases occurred in health care workers and 4 have been in\nfamily contacts.\nClinical Syndrome:\nIllness begins with a prodrome of fever, chills, headache, myalgias, and\nmalaise followed later by a respiratory phase characterized by a dry,\nnonproductive cough and dyspnea. Laboratory abnormalities include\nlymphopenia, leukopenia, mild thrombocytopenia, and elevations in serum CK\nand/or transaminase concentrations. Among the 7 cases investigated by CDC\nto date, all demonstrated lymphopenia (defined as less than 1500\nlymphocytes/mm3). For further details on the clinical findings, including\nchest x-ray, pathology, etc., please consult the MMWR dispatch\n[<http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/m2d321.htm>, covered in\nProMED-mail SARS - Worldwide (09): clinical features - Mod.MPP].\nEtiology\nOn Monday evening [24 Mar 2003], CDC has detected evidence for a\ncoronavirus-like agent in 5 patients. Samples from a patient from Thailand,\nalthough initially negative by PCR, produced a cytopathic effect in Vero\ncell culture. Supernatants from cell cultures were then tested by PCR,\nincluding a broadly reactive primer set against the polymerase region, and\ndetected the presence of a virus from the coronavirus family. A more\nspecific primer set is now being used to test other specimens. Initially,\nthis 400 base-pair amplicon suggests through a virus dendrogram analysis,\n[a virus] outside the 3 existing groups of coronaviruses known to infect\nhumans. cDNA cloning is in progress. CDC has developed an IFA in-house and\nhas used this to test supernatants from cell culture as well as paired\nsera from additional patients. Please note that these 'paired' sera were\nnot obtained more than 2 weeks apart and in fact, are often separated by\nonly several days. Nevertheless, IFA was initially negative in acute\nsamples and positive in a second sample from 3 patients from widely varied\ngeographic areas. Furthermore, CPE was detected in Vero cell culture from\nautopsy materials from the Hong Kong index patient. Again, PCR was\npositive. The sequence of this amplicon is pending, but it will\nbe interesting to note whether it is the same as from the Thai patient\nnoted above. In addition, BAL-cell pellets from the autopsy materials from\nthis Hong Kong index case also revealed coronavirus-like particles on\nthin-section electron microscopy. CDC has stressed that all specimens that\nthey have tested are negative for human metapneumovirus; nevertheless,\nthese agents have been detected in material in Canada and Hong Kong by\nPCR, and according to Donald Low, a human metapneumovirus was grown from\nlung tissue yesterday in Frank Plummer's laboratory in Toronto. A great\ndeal of discussion followed this information and the potential for a\ncoronavirus to 'jump' from animals to humans. This has been detected rarely\nin the past, but there is some precedent. At least in my view, it is\npremature to assume that a coronavirus is the etiologic agent. CDC is\nconsulting numerous experts and has shared PCR reagents with groups in\nToronto and Hong Kong.\nTreatment\nVery little information is available on treatment regimens and/or\noutcomes. Physicians in Hong Kong have reported 'success' with ribavirin,\nwith or without the addition of corticosteroids. As there are no controls,\nthese reports must be considered anecdotal at present. CDC has not yet\nmade recommendations on the potential use of ribavirin, the route of\nadministration (oral, intravenous, and/or aerosol), nor on the need for\nadjunctive corticosteroids. It is worth noting that ribavirin is active\nagainst mouse hepatitis, which is a coronavirus. Lacking other information\non pathogenesis, there is no known role for interferon, leukotriene\ninhibitors, etc.\nW. Michael Scheld, MD\nIDSA President\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This is an excellent overview of the situation as of the time of writing\nof this letter, covering the epidemiology, clinical features, treatment,\nand the status of the investigations on the etiologic agent of SARS. Of\nadditional note is the mention that ribavirin has been shown to be active\nagainst mouse hepatitis, a coronavirus, suggesting that if the etiologic\nagent is confirmed to be a member of the coronavirus family, this may be a\nviable treatment modality. Again, it is very premature to draw\nconclusions, and in turn to draw conclusions about clinical management\nother than supportive measures, which have been shown to assist in\npresumptive mortality reduction. - Mod.MPP]\n[This is the first coherent account of experimentation designed to\nestablish the identity of the etiologic agent of SARS. The experimental\ndata described appear to be consistent with the presence of a novel\ncoronavirus in clinical material from a small number of SARS patients. The\nmolecular data are preliminary but sufficiently broad-based to be\nconvincing, and as a consequence the coronavirus hypothesis is more\ncredible than any of the competing claims. Robust data on seroconversion\nare lacking, however, which are necessary to establish that the virus\npropagated in cultured cells is the pathogen and not a fortuitous passenger\nin the respiratory tract of SARS patients. If this agent isolated by the\nCDC group proves to be a novel coronavirus, the hypothesis that SARS\noccurs as a result of coinfection by two or more unrelated viruses becomes\nless probable.\nNonetheless the detection of human metapneumovirus (HMPV) by PCR in\nlaboratories in Hong Kong and Canada, and the isolation of HMPV in cultured\ncells in Canada cannot be discounted at this stage. The discovery of HMPV\nin the Netherlands in 2001, a ubiquitous human virus that had escaped\ndetection earlier, was partially dependent on the use of a particular cell\nsubstrate. It is possible that the Vero cell cultures employed by the CDC\ngroup might not have picked up HMPV. The pace of research is certainly\naccelerating and it is likely that very soon these matters will be resolved.\nCoronaviruses infect birds and many mammals; in humans coronaviruses are\nthe second most frequent cause of common colds. Infection of humans and\nanimals by coronaviruses is common and unrestricted by geography. No\nbiological vectors are known. The respiratory tract, gastrointestinal\norgans and neurological tissues are the most common targets of\ncoronaviruses. Coronavirus replication also occurs in macrophages.\nRespiratory, fecal-oral and mechanical routes of transmission are common.\nIn general coronaviruses have restricted host ranges, but instances of\ncross-species transmission have been described. The genus\n_Coronavirus_ comprises three groups of viruses. Goup 1 includes canine,\nfeline, porcine and human viruses, Group 2 includes bovine, human, murine,\nporcine and rodent viruses, and group 3 includes avian viruses. The\ncoronaviruses take their name from the prominent 'crown' of envelope spikes\nclearly visible by electron microscopy. - Mod.CP] .", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n W. WHO\n[2] Hong Kong SAR - DOH\n[3] Singapore - MOH\n[4] USA - CDC\n[5] Canada - Health Canada\n[6] Newswire brief\n[A] China\n[B] Canada\n\n******\n[1]\nDate: 26 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/en/>\n\n[A] Cumulative Number of Reported Cases (SARS) 26 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarscountry/2003_03_26/en/>\n\nFrom: 1 Feb 2003 To: 26 Mar 2003, 13:00 GMT+1\n\nCountry: Cumulative no. case(s)/ No. deaths/ Local transmission*\nCanada: 19/ 3/ Yes\nChina, Guangdong Province+: 792/ 31/ Yes\nChina, Hong Kong SAR: 316/ 10**/ Yes\nChina, Taiwan: 6/ 0/ Yes\nFrance: 1/ 0/ None\nGermany: 4/ 0/ None\nItaly: 3/ 0/ None\nRepublic of Ireland: 2/ 0/ None\nSingapore: 74/ 1/ Yes\nSwitzerland: 2/ 0/ To be determined\nThailand: 3/ 0/ None\nUnited Kingdom: 3/ 0/ None\nUnited States: 40 \u00a7/ 0/ To be determined\nViet Nam: 58/ 4/ Yes\n\nTotal: 1323/ 49\n\nNotes:\n\nCumulative number of cases includes number of deaths.\n\n*National public health authorities report to WHO on the areas in which\nlocal chain(s) of transmission is/are occurring. These areas are provided\non the list of Affected Areas.\n\n+This is an updated report of cases from 16 Nov 2002 to 28 Feb 2003 in\nGuangdong Province. The number of cases was compiled from investigations as\nwell as hospital reports and may include suspect as well as probable cases\nof SARS.\n\n\u00a7Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national level,\nprobable cases are reported by all countries except the United States of\nAmerica, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n\n**One death attributed to Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China\noccurred in a case medically transferred from Viet Nam.\n\n\n[B] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_03_26/en/>\n\nCountry: Area\n\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Guangdong Province, Hong Kong SAR China, Taiwan Province\nViet Nam: Hanoi\n\nAn 'Affected Area' is defined as a region at the first administrative level\nwhere the country is reporting local transmission of SARS.\n\n[C] Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak - Update 10\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_26/en/>\n\nData from China, countries introduce stringent control measures\n\nChina updates data on cases and deaths\nChinese authorities have today officially reported a total of 792 cases and\n31 deaths in an outbreak of atypical pneumonia that began in southern\nChina, in Guangdong Province on 16 Nov 2002. Cases were reported to have\noccurred in 7 cities of Guangdong Province.\n\nChinese authorities had previously reported to WHO, on 14 Feb 2003, a total\nof 305 cases and 5 deaths from 16 Nov 2002 to 9 Feb 2003. The new figures\ncover the period of 16 Nov 2002 to 28 Feb 2003.\n\nA WHO team of 5 international experts, which arrived in China on the\nweekend, has today reviewed the case definition used in reporting cases of\natypical pneumonia in Guangdong Province. The WHO team compared this\ndefinition with the WHO definition used to identify probable cases of\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), and concluded that the 2\ndefinitions are compatible.\n\nFollowing in-depth discussion with central-level authorities and health\nofficials in Guangdong Province on the details of several clusters of\ncases, the WHO expert team reached the conclusion that the atypical\npneumonia cases which began occurring in southern China in November 2002\nare likely cases of the same disease, now referred to as SARS, that began\nappearing in other Asian countries on 26 Feb 2003 and has since spread\nwidely to several cities throughout the world.\n\nChinese authorities further informed the WHO team of a new reporting system\nthat will rely on regular provincial updates. WHO is expecting further\ninformation on reported cases in China for March 2003 as these data become\navailable.\n\nCase management guidelines being used in China are in line with WHO\nrecommendations for minimizing further transmission.\n\nChina is also beginning a collaborative programme in which sera from\ninfected Chinese patients will be exchanged with the WHO network of\ncollaborating laboratories who are working to identify the SARS causative\nagent.\n\nUpdate on reported cases\nThe new data from China bring the total number of reported probable cases\nworldwide, dating back to 16 Nov 2003, to 1323 cases and 49 deaths. When\nthe data from China are excluded, today\u0092s figures represent an increase of\n41 cases, largely concentrated in Hong Kong SAR China, and one death, in\nSingapore, compared with yesterday. [see [A] above]\n\nNational measures to contain further spread\nSeveral countries are introducing maximum measures, including quarantine,\nto prevent the further spread of SARS.\n\nNew diseases such as SARS are poorly understood as they emerge. At the\nbeginning of an outbreak, it is sound public health policy to institute\nmaximum control measures needed to prevent further spread.\n\nMaximum measures are justified when, in the view of national health\nauthorities, they can be expected to protect populations against infection,\nkeep the disease from spreading into the general population, and help\nprevent international spread to other countries, particularly through air\ntravel.\n\nAs the epidemiology of SARS becomes more fully understood, such measures\ncan be adjusted and reduced in line with what is known about how the\ndisease is transmitted and what works best to stop its spread, both\nnationally and internationally.\n\nThe first global 'grand rounds' on SARS clinical features and treatment\nwere held today by WHO. The electronic meeting united 80 clinicians from 13\ncountries. A summary of their discussions and conclusions has been posted\ntoday at the WHO web site. [see ProMED-mail posting: SARS - Worldwide (09):\nclinical features]\n\nPrevious hypothesis for Chinese outbreak: atypical pneumonia caused by\nChlamydia:\nOn 18 Feb 2003, the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention, in\ncollaboration with the Guangdong Center for Disease Control and Prevention,\nannounced the finding of evidence of infection with the Chlamydia bacterium\nin 2 specimens taken from the lungs of patients who died from atypical\npneumonia in southern China. [see ProMED-mail posting Pneumonia - China\n(Guangdong) (04) 20030219.0427 - Mod.MPP]\n\nOn Monday, Chinese authorities asked the WHO team to assist in\ninvestigation of Chlamydia as a causative agent. This request was\ntransmitted to members of a WHO network of 11 labs set up to expedite\nidentification of the SARS pathogen.\n\nOn Tuesday, during the daily teleconference with the network, laboratory\nscientists reported that numerous tests had been run to determine the\npresence of Chlamydia bacteria in specimens from confirmed SARS cases\nelsewhere in the world. Most tests have come back negative for Chlamydia.\nAdditional negative test results were reported today.\n\nThese findings suggest that Chinese patients were likely co-infected with\nChlamydial organisms together with the true cause of the outbreak, which\nremains unidentified.\n\nProgress towards identification of the virus:\nResearch attention is increasingly focusing on the Coronavirus family,\nthough viruses from the Paramyxovirus and other families are also being\nconsidered as scientists cast the widest possible net in their search for\nthe cause of SARS. Many are of the opinion that a diagnostic test could\nrapidly follow conclusive identification of the pathogen. Experts in the\nnetwork are also considering the theory that SARS is caused by co-infection\nwith 2 new viruses that somehow need each other in order to cause severe\ndisease in humans. Evidence is strongly pointing to a new virus, or\npossibly 2 new viruses, that have not previously been known to infect\nhumans or cause severe disease.\n\nHypotheses include a virus known to cause disease in an animal host that\nhas jumped the species barrier to infect humans, or a known human virus\nthat has mutated to acquire properties that are causing much more severe\ndisease in humans. It is increasingly certain, however, that SARS is a\nserious new disease caused by a newly recognized pathogen.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 26 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong SAR - Department of Health\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\n\nPart 1 - Figures on atypical pneumonia 26 Mar 2003\n-----\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\n\nAs at 1 PM 26 Mar 2003 , the admission statistics of patients who have been\nin close contacts with atypical pneumonia patients are as follow: (The\nnumbers in bracket are those with Pneumonia Symptoms)\n\nA. Mod.MPP]\n\n\nPart 2 - Health condition of students under close surveillance 26 Mar 2003\n------\nThe Department of Health (DH) on 26 Mar 2003 confirmed 2 new cases of\natypical pneumonia involving 2 school children.\n\nThe Consultant in-charge of DH's Disease Prevention and Control Division,\nDr Tse Lai-yin, said the girls were among the 316 cases confirmed today to\nhave contracted atypical pneumonia.\n\nThe first case involved a 7-year-old girl who is a student of the PM\nsession of SKH Kei Tak Primary School in Wong Tai Sin. The 5 additional patients are hospital staff. All these\ncases are still traced back to the index cases. 13 patients have been\ndischarged from hospital, while the remaining 60 patients are hospitalised.\nAll the patients are stable except for 10 patients who are in serious\ncondition. One patient who was in intensive care passed away on 25 Mar 2003.\n\nSARS is not infectious until the person develops fever. Transmission of\nSARS is only through close contact with infected persons. All the SARS\ncases in Singapore so far are close contacts which are linked to the 3\nindex cases.\n\n\n[B] Joint Press Release by Ministry of Education and Ministry of Health -\nClosure of schools 26 Mar 2003\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5661>\n\nAs an additional precautionary measure in response to concerns expressed by\nparents on the recent SARS cases, the Ministry of Education (MOE) and\nMinistry of Health (MOH) have decided to close all primary schools,\nsecondary schools, junior colleges, and centralised institutes from Thu 27\nMar 2003 to Sun 6 April 2003.\n\nAll schools have been adhering closely to MOH's advisories since school\nre-opened after the March holidays. They have been screening their students\nevery day since school re-opened. On purely medical grounds, there are\ncurrently no strong reasons for closing all schools. However, principals\nand general practitioners have reported that parents continue to be\nconcerned about the risk to their children in schools. MOE and MOH hope\nthat this additional precautionary step to close schools will address\nparents' concerns and further reassure them.\n\n\nUpdate on SARS\n--------------\nThe control measures already instituted are minimising the risk of\ntransmission of SARS within the community. Home quarantine of contacts\nallows us to identify and isolate those who come down with SARS early and\nprevent spread to others. In the hospitals, no more healthcare workers have\nbeen infected with SARS by known or suspected cases, since the\nimplementation of the enhanced infection control precautions.\n\nAll the SARS cases in Singapore so far can be traced back to the 3 index\ncases. The index cases passed on the infection to 21 primary close\ncontacts, who in turn infected 26 other secondary close contacts. Further\ntransmission of the infection appears to be stabilising, with only 23 more\ntertiary close contacts being infected. The control measures appear to be\nworking, although it is still too early to be confident of this.\n\nDetails of school closure\n---------------\nAll school competitions and co-curricular activities scheduled between now\n[26 Mar 2003] and 6 Apr 2003 will be cancelled or postponed. The current\nschool term, Term 2, will be extended into the June school holidays, to\nmake up for losses in curriculum time.\n\nThe universities, polytechnics, and Institute of Technical Education will\ncontinue to operate as normal. These institutes of higher learning have a\ndifferent system of operation from our national schools. Furthermore, the\nstudents in our post-secondary institutions are older and are better able\nto understand the situation and take the necessary precautions.\n\nMOE will advise the pre-school centres to close for the same period.\nSimilarly, the Ministry of Community Development and Sports will be closing\nchildcare centres while the People's Association will be closing the\nplaygroups and tuition classes at community centres/clubs and residents'\ncommittees. Student Care Centres are advised to do likewise. Special\neducation schools, as advised by the National Council of Social Services,\nand madrasahs, as advised by Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura, will also close\nduring this period.\n\nMOE urges employers to exercise flexibility in allowing their employees\naffected by the closure of schools to take urgent leave to make alternative\nchild care arrangements.\n\nThe Ministry of Education and Ministry of Health will review the SARS\nsituation before the end of next week.\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4]\nDate: 26 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS website 26 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome Report of Suspected Cases Under\nInvestigation in the United States\n*Case definition <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>\n\nState: suspected cases under investigation*\n\nCalifornia: 10\nConnecticut: 1\nHawaii: 3\nIllinois: 1\nKansas: 1\nMaine: 2\nMassachusetts: 1\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nNew Jersey: 1\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 2\nNew York: 4\nPennsylvania: 2\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 3\nUtah: 3\nVirginia: 3\nWisconsin: 1\n\nTotal suspected cases under investigation 45\n[representing 20 states]\n\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[5]\nDate: 26 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada SARS website 26 Mar 2003 5:00 PM [edited]\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update11.htm>\n\n\nUpdate 11 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome\n--------------------\nAs of 26 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 28 individuals who\nhave become ill with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Ontario\nand British Columbia. "SARS - WORLDWIDE (06): WHO PRESS BRIEFING\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[We are posting this edited version of the most recent WHO update on the\nSARS outbreak and investigation as it provides additional background on the\ninvestigations to date along with preliminary interpretations of findings.\n- Mod.MPP]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS website 25 Mar 2003 [edited]\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/2003_03_25/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome - Press briefing Tues 25 Mar 2003, 10h00\nWorld Health Organization\nDr David Heymann, Executive Director, Communicable Diseases\nDr Klaus Stohr, Scientist, CSR\nDr Julie Hall, Medical Officer, CSR\nMr Dick Thompson, Communications Officer\nDr David Heymann: We are now 10 days into an outbreak of what we believe is\na previously unrecognized disease in humans. We have cases that have spread\nout of Hong Kong and Viet Nam, throughout the world, and we have a\nlaboratory group which has identified 2 different viruses in patient\nspecimens. a paramyxovirus and a coronavirus. At the same time, we\u0092ve done\nepidemiological studies which, to date, have shown us that most if not all\ncases can be identified in a chain of transmission from the patient back\nsomehow to a family member or to a contact directly with a hospital worker\nor with a hotel in Hong Kong.\nAs of now we still maintain that travel is not to be interrupted throughout\nthe world. But as you know there\u0092s much, much information coming out of\nHong Kong, and there\u0092s been a rapid increase in the number of cases this\nweek, and we are in regular contact with Hong Kong and with our Regional\nOffice in Manila and we will be reconsidering today our travel\nrecommendations as we do every day.\nToday we will be with a group of industrialized countries that have cases\nas well as the countries in which the majority of cases are occurring in\nAsia. So we\u0092re at the end of a 10-day period which has seen a remarkable\nworking together of scientists, epidemiologists and countries in the world\nto better understand and stop the spread of what we believe is a previously\nunrecognized infectious agent.\nDr Klaus Stohr: 8 days ago, WHO established a network of 11 laboratories in\n9 countries. Now 8 days later, these 11 laboratories in these 9 countries\nhave found already 2 very strong contenders, 2 viruses which are\nconsistently isolated from many patients from very many different countries.\nThe research is ongoing. It is not normal that one disease is caused by 2\nviruses. We will have to strengthen the activities, particularly as far as\nelectron microscopy is concerned, as well as genetic analysis.\nDr Julie Hall: WHO is working very closely with all its partners in the\nGlobal Outbreak Alert and Response Network. We\u0092ve been able to produce\nguidance based on clinical and epidemiological evidence posted on our web\nsite on the SARS page.We\u0092ve established a logistic basis throughout the\nworld and worked in close collaboration with bilateral arrangements from a\nvariety of different countries to ensure that supplies are in place. We\nalso have 3 field teams in place.\nIn Hanoi there are 9 people who have been there since 14 Mar 2003. Their\nkey focus has been on infection control and where infection control has\nbeen put in place and has been practised effectively, we have seen a\ndramatic reduction in inter-hospital and community transfer of this agent.\nThey have also been working hard in terms of clinical management, and we\nnow have a large data set of information about this syndrome which will\nhelp us to understand its clinical cause and possible effective treatments.\nIt\u0092s been shown that good supportive care has been effective, and we are\nnow in a position in Viet Nam where, now that we have developed a discharge\npolicy, a number of patients are likely to be discharged from hospital in\nthe very near future.\nIn Hong Kong we have a 5-person team that has been focusing on\nepidemiological research and has provided a lot of data in terms of how\nthis infectious agent has been transferred and transmitted between people\nand what infection control measures are required. A 5-person team arrived\non Sunday in China. They have a remit [permit?] to review the\nepidemiological data that\u0092s been collected by the Chinese authorities and\nalso to help support the microbiology and virology investigations into this\noutbreak. So there has been an unprecedented collaborative effort, and all\nthe institutions that are working in the various forms, whether it be in\nthe field teams, in the clinical network, or in the laboratory network; the\ndetails of all of those are on the sheets at the back if people want to\nlook at those.\nQ. When I look at the latest figures from the WHO, it is really worrying\nbecause it seems to me that only in Hong Kong, the figures kept increasing\nand we have now 10 deaths. What are the factors that make Hong Kong so\nspecial? It seems the situation is not under control.\nA. Dr David Heymann: Our teams are also concerned about the situation in\nHong Kong because of its spread in many different hospitals, and our team\nthere is working with the government in Hong Kong, not only to better\nunderstand what\u0092s going on in Hong Kong as far as the epidemiology or the\ntransmission of the disease, but also in trying to stop the spread of the\ndisease. There are people who are infection control experts working in the\ngovernment and with the government to try to make sure that we can stop\nthis outbreak. I just need to remind you though that at present there is no\nevidence that there is any transmission other than close contact with\npatients, either sitting next to patients or being in close contact with\npatients. But this adds to the urgency in Hong Kong to make sure that this\nremains true in the studies that are found because now, as you know, there\nare cases in schools, there are cases other places, and we need to make\nsure that if there are other cases in schools, they aren\u0092t cases that are\nrandomly occurring but are cases which sat next to students who were sick.\nAnd the same goes for airplanes, if there are airplanes that [transported]\nsomeone who\u0092s sick, we would want to be sure that it was people sitting\nnext to that person and not the ventilation system in the aeroplane which\nwas spreading the disease. We have no evidence of the latter right now, but\nthis is why studies are so important and why we reinforced our team to work\nwith the very excellent teams in Hong Kong to find out what\u0092s going on for\nsure.\nQ. A couple of questions. I assume you are supportive of the mass\nquarantine that Singapore authorities have announced that they are starting\ntoday. Singapore today began ordering hundreds of people to stay at home\nand it\u0092s being described as the world\u0092s largest quarantine. They are making\nuse of the Infectious Diseases Act, which is the first time they\u0092ve ever\nused it. So (a) are you in favour of measures like that? and (b) my second\nquestion is, when you were talking about the travel advisory, you seemed to\nstress there\u0092s no new advice for the present. But are you expecting this\nmight change after the meeting with industrialized countries today?\nA. Dr David Heymann: The first is that WHO puts out recommendations on\ntravel but it\u0092s countries who make the final decision based on their\nlegislation and their national laws. That\u0092s why we\u0092re meeting with\ncountries today, because other countries have the same concerns as\nSingapore. And we\u0092re trying to work with them to better understand the\nbasis for their concerns. The recommendations of WHO are always\nevidence-based. That means that when we get evidence that suggests that we\nshould be changing a policy, we move to change that policy. We\u0092ve been\nmeeting on a regular basis by telephone with many countries. Today we will\nbring all those countries together to discuss travel recommendations. And I\nwill say what I would say every day, that we leave it open that if there is\nnew evidence with which we can make a better policy or a different policy,\nwe will do that and we will not hesitate to do it. So, our recommendations\nwill be evidence-based and we do not make a recommendation if there\u0092s no\nevidence to support that. This many times occurs in national contexts\nbecause there are rules or laws which require them to judge on the side of\nsafety rather than on the side of non-safety, if you understand what I\u0092m\nsaying. So, yes there\u0092s always a chance that WHO will change its\nrecommendations and we will keep you posted if that should occur.\nQ. With Singapore, I presume that you are in favour of measures taken, such\nas those in Singapore \u00ad mass quarantine?\nA. Dr David Heymann: Governments take a decision based on the conditions\nlocally. If for some reason Singapore feels that they will not be able to\ntrace all cases because there\u0092s such great mobility in their populations\nthat they must make restrictions on them, then that\u0092s what they\u0092ve decided\nto do. Our recommendation is that there be no restrictions at present. But\nthat\u0092s a global recommendation. And again, that\u0092s being reconsidered on a\ndaily basis and will be re-considered today at 2.30 pm in our conference call.\nQ. The question about the 2 viruses having been, or 2 families of viruses\nhaving been associated with this disease or with this outbreak. You said it\nwas not normal, if I\u0092m not mistaken. Could you give us an idea of whether\nor not it\u0092s possible for a single disease to be caused by 2 viruses or is\nit more likely that at least one of the samples might not be related to SARS?\nA. Dr Klaus Stohr: Speaking as a scientist, we are looking at a very\ninteresting and a fascinating situation. Looking from the point of\ninfectious disease control, we are a bit puzzled because we are not only\ndealing apparently with one pathogen but with 2. The reason why we believe\nthat both pathogens should be given equal attention is that there is\nconsistent finding of both pathogens in individual patients or of either of\nthe pathogens in other patients. What we are seeing actually are 3\nhypotheses. The first hypothesis is that one of the viruses, for instance\nthe corona virus, causes the disease, and that might be a new corona virus.\nThe second hypothesis is that the paramyxoviruses cause the disease and if\nthat was the case, it\u0092s certainly also a new paramyxovirus. The third\nhypothesis, very obviously, is that these 2 pathogens have to come together\nto cause this very severe outbreak. One of the viruses, for instance the\ncoronavirus, is known to live in immune cells, cells which are important\nfor defense against infection. So what one could hypothesize is that this\ncoronavirus destroys or at least diminishes the immunity in the patient so\nthat the second virus has practically an open door to go in and to sicken\nthe patient beyond what this virus would be able to do normally.\nDr David Heymann: Let me just add to that: there could be a fourth\nhypothesis. It is possible that both are common viruses: one found in all\nthe patients, even though it's not causing disease, and the other will be\nthe disease-causing agent, so they could both be found but not be related\nin any way, just there by chance. So it's a very complicated issue that's\nbeing sorted out.\nQ. In China, is the team in Beijing getting new figures on how many cases\nwe have in China? Also, can they go to Guangdong or will they just remain\nin Beijing doing that kind of laboratory service?\nA. Dr David Heymann: Yesterday the team in China had a question from the\nGovernment, and that was 'why is WHO not putting on its web site the 305\ncases that we reported?' The answer was because we only started recording\ncases from 1 Feb 2003, and we don't know how many cases China had from 1\nFeb 2003 on. That made the Chinese believe that they needed to go back and\nlook at their data, and they've promised us they would do that and give us\nmore information. Today that information has not come out yet. Our team has\nmet with officials from Guangdong and from Beijing but the information is\nnot yet available, but we have reason to believe that it will be made\navailable and that there is very much interest in Beijing by the\ninternational press on these issues as well as by the press from outside\nBeijing.\nQ. Is the team going to Guangdong?\nA.Dr David Heymann: The team has not yet been invited to go to Guangdong\nand we don't know whether that invitation will be coming. Certainly our\nwish would be that the Government will permit us to work with them in all\naspects of this outbreak.\nQ. Do you think it's advisable for the team to go to Guangdong to help\ninvestigate what's going on? Did WHO request specifically that they should\ngo to Guangdong?\nA. Dr David Heymann: WHO has requested the Government to let the team work\nwith them as best it possibly can, and we would hope that that would\ninclude working in Guangdong as well as working in Beijing.\nQ. I have 2 questions. My first is that there is a lot of hypothesising\nabout the first case of the outbreak, a lot of media reported that it was\nthe Chinese businessman who came back from China who went to Hanoi who was\nthe one who was dead in Hong Kong. Do you have any information about the\nfirst case? Secondly, can you clarify the route of transmission. Is it\npossible to have transmission by air?\nA. Dr Julie Hall: We have quite a lot of information about the gentleman,\nwhat we are calling the 'Hanoi index case', the Chinese-American\nbusinessman who went to Hanoi, became unwell, and was then transferred to\nhospital in Hong Kong. He was transferred in isolation and treated in\nisolation as well once he got to Hong Kong. The team in Hanoi are currently\nfollowing up his travels prior to arriving in Hanoi. It seems that he\ntravelled quite extensively prior to becoming unwell and prior to arrival\nin Viet Nam. Further details on that are currently being sought by our team\nso that we can follow his travels in the 2-3 weeks prior to his becoming\nunwell in a little more detail. Obviously, when somebody becomes unwell in\none country, lives in another country, and is then transferred for care in\na third country, it does take a while for all this detailed information to\nbe put together.\nDr David Heymann: To date, in looking at every case that occurs, it has not\nbeen possible to say that there was not close contact with another patient,\nbe it a family member of a hospital worker, a hospital worker, or one of\nthe initial cases. Now that information comes in on a daily basis. If, and\nthe minute we find that there are cases which cannot be traced to close\ncontact with another patient or another person at risk, we will then be\nvery concerned that this might have become airborne. Airborne meaning that\nyou would be at risk sitting where you are. The way it is today that we\nbelieve from the evidence we have, the only person at risk in this room\nwould be Dr Stohr, who's sitting next to me. But if we find that you are at\nrisk, we will immediately have to consider a whole series of new measures\nto recommend and the studies will have to intensify to find out how it's\ncirculating more widely than just by person-to-person contact.\nQ. From what I understand from the end of last week, you were becoming more\nconfident that you had this under control. But the data this week seems to\nshow the opposite. How confident are you that you've got it under control?\nHow concerned are you that it could be getting worse instead of better?\nA. Dr David Heymann: When we made the global alert 10 days ago, our goal\nwas to stop outbreaks occurring in other countries than Hong Kong and Viet\nNam because of imported cases. We knew that Canada had had imported cases\nand had had local transmission within Canada. If you look at the global\nalert, it has brought in reports of disease from many different countries -\n13 I believe is the latest count - and there have been no additional\noutbreaks in those countries. So the global containment exercise has been\nsuccessful to date. The exercise of containing the disease in Viet Nam\nappears to have been successful, there has been a slowdown in new cases,\nhospital infection control has been strengthened in hospitals, and it\nappears that that outbreak has been contained in Viet Nam. In Singapore,\nwhere there were imported cases, there appears to now have been a closing\nin on contacts of patients, and we believe that the situation in Singapore\nis being controlled. In Hong Kong there is a very difficult situation and a\ndifferent situation in that 10 hospitals are now involved. It is a very\nimportant exercise to contain the disease in these 10 hospitals. We also\nknow that people have been in schools who have become sick, so there is\nwhere the efforts must be now intensified in addition to better\nunderstanding what is going on in China. So we have 2 countries in which we\nare very concerned now -- Hong Kong -- and in finding out more about what\nis going on in China, because those are the 2 countries where we have less\ninformation and we are less sure that containment activities are being\nsuccessful.\nQ. For the incubation period of the disease, WHO said that it was 2-5 days\nor 2-7 days. In Hong Kong, however, the doctor was in close contact with\nthe patient 11 or 12 days before. So people are now concerned whether we\nshould play safe and extend the incubation period so that the virus won't\nspread even further. Do you have any information and recommendation on this?\nA. Dr Klaus Stohr: Thank you. The incubation period is the period between\nthe infection, when the patient gets in contact possibly with the pathogen,\nand when the first clinical signs occur. Now that is a very important\nperiod of time because it tells us presumably that during this period of\ntime the person can start spreading the virus. The incubation period in\nHanoi, from the data which has been collected during the first two weeks of\nthe outbreak, the average incubation period is 4.5 days. The minimum\nincubation period is 2 days. The maximum incubation period is 7 days. Very\nsimilar data were forthcoming from Singapore, with a minimum 2 days,\nmaximum 7 days. We are talking about a biological phenomenon and we cannot\nrule out that there have been slightly shorter or slightly longer\nincubation periods. However, we have also to realize that not every contact\nof a doctor with a patient must necessarily lead to an infection, so even\nif there has already been contact between the doctor and the patient over a\nperiod of time, perhaps the infection took only place 4 or 5 days after the\ncontact began and the doctor started incubating. We are looking at a new\ndisease. We are looking at possibly 2 different viruses, so we really have\nto cautious in drawing generic and absolute conclusions. The data that we\nhave are relatively firm 2 days to 7 days and we have to take more data and\nanalyse them, and these data are going to be collected particularly from\nHong Kong and particularly in Hanoi, but there will be analytical\ninformation perhaps as you describe, but that has to be verified.\nQ. Now we have 10 days of the global alert, can we say what of the number\nof cases known, what the mortality percentage is?\nA. Dr Julie Hall: It has remained pretty static over the last 10 days, it's\naround about 4 percent mortality rate. So it's quite low and we haven't\nseen any change in that mortality rate over the 10 days.\nQ. In that case is it really such a horrible scourge that's menacing the\nworld, because normally influenza has that kind of mortality rate doesn't it?\nA. Dr David Heymann: I would differ I would say that this is not a low\nmortality rate, we want zero mortality rate. This is a 4 percent mortality\nin a disease for which we do not yet know the cause. So it's a very serious\nissue in having a 4 percent mortality in a disease for which we don't yet\nknow the cause and which is spreading throughout the world. 4 percent is a\nlevel of mortality that could be equivalent to other viral infections in\nmany parts of the world. It's equivalent of what might be occurring with\nWest Nile, it's probably more than what is happening with West Nile in\nNorth America.\nDr Klaus Stohr: The low mortality rate is perhaps also being contributed to\nby the enormous clinical efforts taken with those patients. In one hospital\nin Hong Kong there are more than 150 patients, almost 30 of whom are in\nintensive care. Quite a few of them are on ventilators; they would die\nwithout mechanical ventilation. The health system is burdened almost to the\nlimit in quite a few of the hospitals, and we of course have to look at the\ncase mortality rate and morbidity but also at the burden on the public\nhealth system, which is enormous.\nDr David Heymann: And just to put one more thing in perspective. Suppose\nthat there were 2 diseases occurring at the same time, SARS and a disease\nwhich causes the same symptoms but is less severe. It my be that this\nsecond less severe background disease, caused by another virus, would cause\na different case fatality rate. We can only begin to distinguish genuine\nSARS cases from other less severe diseases having similar initial symptoms\nwhen we have a diagnostic test. So we're still far from understanding\neverything.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Rather than be critical of changing interpretations and explanations,\nreaders should be reminded that this is a new disease process, a truly\n'emerging infectious disease' about which we have many questions and few\ndefinitive answers. We are very early in our identification of this\noutbreak, the etiology is still unknown, and the epidemiology is still\nbeing defined as more cases are identified and investigated. In our quest\nfor 'transparency' in investigations, the price we pay is early release of\nvery preliminary findings that with further investigation and study are\ndisproven or disqualified. They were\nadmitted to Tuen Mun Hospital on the evening of 22 Mar 2003 and are now in\nstable condition.\nOn receiving the notification on 23 Mar 2003, DH immediately contacted\nother members of the tour. Among them 3, one man and 2 women aged between\n27 and 50, were also confirmed to have developed atypical pneumonia\nsymptoms. They are in stable condition.\n6 other members of the tour who had been reported to have coughs, 3 men and\n3 women aged between 32 and 61, were admitted to hospitals for close\nsurveillance earlier. The man was\nfeeling unwell after visiting his brother in Ward 8A of Prince of Wales\nHospital earlier this month.\nDH has informed the Airport Authority, the Civil Aviation Department and\nthe airline concerned. Advice was also given to the airline concerned to\ndisinfect the airplanes.\nDH is tracing the crew members and passengers who had taken these two\nflights, for surveillance purposes.\nThe spokesman reminded members of the public who have respiratory symptoms\nincluding fever, chills, malaise and cough to avoid traveling by plane\nbefore recovery.\nIt is prudent for tourists to adopt the following precautionary measures to\nprevent atypical pneumonia:\nBuild up good body immunity by having a proper diet, regular exercise and\nadequate rest, reducing stress and avoiding smoking;\nMaintain good personal hygiene, and wash hands after sneezing, coughing or\ncleaning the nose;\nMaintain good ventilation; avoid visiting crowded places with poor ventilation;\nDo not share towels;\nConsult a doctor promptly if you develop respiratory symptoms and fever.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: WHO SARS update 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_25/en/>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak - Update 9\nUpdated travel advice\nOn 15 Mar 2003, WHO issued a travel advisory in response to the growing\ninternational threat posed by Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).\nSince then, WHO has conducted daily teleconferences with health authorities\nand WHO team members on the scene in all areas affected by SARS.\nWHO also receives detailed bulletins from ministries of health in the most\nheavily affected areas reporting on any SARS-related events that might\nalter understanding of the behaviour of this new disease.\nToday's communications included a report, from the Hong Kong department of\nhealth, providing detailed preliminary data on the detection of 9 atypical\npneumonia cases among members of a Beijing tour organized by a Hong Kong\ntravel agent. The general public has been\ninformed and a hot-line has been set up.\nWHO epidemiologists in Geneva, together with experts tracking outbreaks in\naffected countries, have decided today that, based on the information\navailable at present, there is no need to change previous WHO advice.\nWHO continues to recommend no travel restrictions to any destination. WHO\nadvises travellers to remain alert to the symptoms of SARS. These include\nhigh fever, respiratory symptoms, including cough, shortness of breath, and\ndifficulty breathing, and should report these symptoms promptly.\nAs of today, 487 SARS cases have been reported from 12 countries.\nA number of persons with SARS have taken long distance flights after\nbecoming ill. Thousands of passengers who travelled in the same flights\nhave been traced in Germany, Canada, Singapore and the United States. No\ncases have been discovered among these contacts. Today's report of a\npossible transmission of SARS on board a flight is undergoing\ninvestigation. As 'close' contact is possible during a flight, in\npassengers sitting close to an infected person, such transmission cannot be\nruled out. The evidence to date indicates that in-flight transmission is\nvery unusual.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nWHO advice to travellers is being kept under constant review. SARS is an\nemerging disease. Knowledge about is clinical behaviour, response to\ntreatment, and modes and risks of transmission are continually evolving.\nWHO is confident that, in the present climate of heightened awareness and\nrapid and detailed reporting, data useful in understanding SARS and issuing\nsound public health advice are being rapidly collected and rapidly made\navailable.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[ProMED-mail would like to thank subscriber John Herbert\n<j_a_herbert@yahoo.com> for sending information following a radio\nannouncement on this advisory.\nAccording to the very thorough investigation of the cases as presented\nabove, it appears as though the transmission would still qualify as 'close\ncontact' with the chain of transmission being sitting close to an infected\nindividual on a plane, and then being a member of a tour group that spends\nhours together on a daily basis for multiple days. Two\ncoronaviruses that are known to infect humans cause one third of common\ncolds and are also a common cause of health care-associated upper\nrespiratory infections in premature infants.\n'This is encouraging news from our laboratories at CDC,' said Tommy G.\nThompson, Secretary of Health and Humans Services. 'These and other\nexcellent scientists all over the world have been working around the clock\nfor days and their hard work is paying off. They continue to look at other\npossible causes of SARS, but this is a key finding in our efforts to\nidentify the cause of this global outbreak.'\nAdditional steps needed to confirm this hypothesis include further\nculturing of the virus from appropriate specimens, sequencing the viral\ngenome, and examining specimens from patients at different stages of their\nillness.\n'This collaboration among scientists led by the World Health Organization\n(WHO) is unprecedented,' said CDC Director Dr. Julie Gerberding. 'We\ncertainly have more work to do, but we think we are on the right track. And\nour systems to identify cases and investigate them are working too, thanks\nto all the frontline clinicians and state and local health departments\naround the country.'\nAs of Mon, 24 Mar 2003, CDC is reporting 39 suspected SARS cases in 18\nstates. WHO is reporting 456 cases and 17 deaths.\nSince the outbreak of SARS was first reported two weeks ago, CDC has\nresponded in these ways:\nActivated the agency's Emergency Operations Center.\nAlerted public health partners in cities and states by issuing electronic\nmessages.\nPrepared and distributed more than 60,000 health alert cards to travelers\nreturning from Southeast Asia.\nProvided guidance to public health departments, health care facilities, and\nclinicians in monitoring and identifying potential cases.\nProvided safe specimen-handling guidelines to laboratories.\nDeployed more than a dozen CDC staff members, including medical officers,\nepidemiologists, infection control specialists, and pathologists to support\nthe World Health Organization in the global investigation.\nProvided regular media briefings to report on progress of the investigation.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[This report does not provide much clarity but rather adds to the confusion\nregarding the nature of the infectious agent responsible for SARS. The\ncandidates so far include, an unspecified paramyxovirus, the recently\ndiscovered human metapneumovirus (representing the two subfamilies of the\nfamily _Paramyxoviridae_, and now an unspecified coronavirus (representing\nthe family _Coronaviridae_). A common feature of the families\n_Paramyxoviridae_ and Coronaviridae_ is that they contain viruses that are\nubiquitous respiratory tract pathogens. Consequently it would not be\nunexpected to detect such viruses in clinical samples entirely\nfortuitously, particularly where a diagnostic technique of limited\ndiscriminatory potential such as electron microscopy is employed. The\nparamyxoviruses and coronaviruses are quite distinct viruses with different\nbiological potential. The paramyxoviruses are negative-sense RNA viruses,\nwhich do not recombine, whereas the coronaviruses are positive-sense RNA\nviruses, which undergo recombination at high frequency.\nIn the UK at least coronaviruses are second only to rhinoviruses as causes\nof the common cold. In the case of the four types of human parainfluenza\nviruses (sub-family _Paramyxovirinae_), human respiratory syncytial virus\nand human metapneumovirus (sub-family _Pneumovirinae_) infection occurs in\ninfancy and early childhood, but does not confer prolonged immunity. In the\ncase of human respiratory syncytial virus it has been estimated that\nreinfection occurs on average every 36 months. The outcome of infection can\nbe serious in infancy (bronchiolitis) and in the elderly (pneumonia), At\nother ages infection is usually asymptomatic or mild URTI. While the\nnumber of 'fresh cases' may have decreased in Guangdong, there is no\nmention if there have been cases outside Guangdong Province, assuming that\ninternal travel within China does occur with significant frequency. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n [25 Mar 2003] that 792 cases of\natypical pneumonia were reported in the province by the end of February\n2003, with 680 in the capital Guangzhou. Chinese officials said previously that 305 people were sickened in the\natypical pneumonia outbreak.\n The\nepidemic had been brought under full control in the 6 cities and no fresh\ncases had been reported in those areas since 15 Feb 2003, said the spokesman. Medical\nexperts here said early diagnosis and treatment are essential to ensure a\nhigh recovery rate for patients of atypical pneumonia. Further\ninvestigation is underway to update figures.\n\u00a7 Due to differences in the case definitions being used at a national\nlevel, probable cases are reported by all countries except the United\nStates of America, which is reporting suspect cases under investigation.\n** One death attributed to Hong Kong SAR China occurred in a case medically\ntransferred from Viet Nam.\n[2] Affected Areas - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) 24 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sarsareas/2003_03_24/en/>\n\nCountry: Area\nCanada: Toronto\nSingapore: Singapore\nChina: Guangdong Province, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of\nChina, Taiwan Province\nViet Nam: Hanoi\nAn 'Affected Area' is defined as a region at the first administrative level\nwhere the country is reporting local transmission of SARS.\n[This is unchanged from the 22 Mar 2003 update. - Mod.MPP]\n\n[3] Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak -\nUpdate 8 24 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_24B/en/>\n\nAdvice to travelers, situation update\nTravel advice\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) was first recognized as a new\ndisease in Asia in mid-February 2003. Since then, more than 450 cases, with\n17 deaths, have been reported from 13 countries on 3 continents.\nOn 15 Mar 2003, WHO issued an emergency travel advisory, based on\ninformation available at that time, and a preliminary case definition of\nSARS. The travel advisory was intended to alert national authorities and\nclinicians to potential cases of SARS and to urge travelers, including\nairline crew, with symptoms suggestive of SARS to seek medical attention.\nWHO continues to recommend, on the basis of currently available data, no\ntravel restrictions to any destination. Guidance to governments, airlines,\nphysicians and travelers issued on 15 Mar 2003 remains valid.\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/pr23/en/>\nAdvice for health authorities and clinicians\nA more detailed clinical picture of SARS has been posted at the WHO Web\nsite: <http://www.who.int/csr/sars/clinical/en/>\nWHO has further recommended that suspect cases be placed in isolation and\nmanaged using strict barrier nursing practices:\n<http://www.who.int/csr/sars/management/en/>\nDrawing on partners in the Global Outbreak Alert and Response Network, WHO\nand its partner institutes and collaborating centres have placed field\nteams in Hanoi, Viet Nam, Hong Kong SAR, and Taiwan, China to assist health\nauthorities. Last week, WHO flew 300 kilos of protective equipment and\nmedical supplies to Hanoi.\nHealth authorities and hospital staff the world over are now alert to the\nsymptoms of SARS. Suspect cases are being quickly detected and promptly\nreported. Proper isolation and management of cases has greatly reduced the\nrisk of transmission of newly detected cases to others.\nAs of data available today, the vast majority of cases continue to occur in\nhealth care workers managing patients in hospital environments, and in the\nfamilies and other close contacts of patients. [see [1] above].\nUpdate on cases and countries affected\nReports from health authorities in 13 countries, compiled today, indicate a\ncumulative total of 456 cases of SARS and 17 deaths. This compares with\nreports a week ago (17 Mar 2003) of 150 cases in 7 countries. [see [1] above]\nFor most of the affected countries, cases reported today are for probable\ncases. Previous reports included both probable and suspected cases. As case\ndefinitions of SARS differ in some countries, the United States of America\nis today reporting 37 suspect cases under investigation.\nHong Kong SAR China remains the most severely affected area, reporting 260\ncases and 10 deaths. Other severely affected areas included Singapore, with\n65 cases and no deaths, and Vietnam, with 58 cases and 4 deaths. Canada has\nreported 11 cases and 3 deaths.\nChest X-rays showing distinctive features of SARS are presently the main\ntool for distinguishing suspected from probable cases. A \u0093hand-made\u0094\ndiagnostic test, developed by Hong Kong scientists, began producing\nreliable results on Saturday and will be made available to key laboratories\nin a matter of days. A more sophisticated test is expected to be available\nfor widespread use in diagnosing SARS cases within weeks.\nWork towards the definitive identification of the causative agent, now\nstrongly expected to be a virus of the Paramyxovirus or Coronavirus\nfamilies, is continuing at breakneck speed. Researchers in a network of 11\nleading laboratories, set up on Monday 17 Mar 2003, exchange data on a\nrestricted web site and compare virological and clinical information during\ndaily teleconferences.\nA second network of clinicians was set up on 20 Mar 2003 to expedite work\non diagnosis and treatment.\nWHO team of experts in China\nA WHO international team of experts in epidemiology, microbiology,\nvirology, and respiratory diseases arrived in Beijing, China on Sunday 23\nMar 2003. The multinational team was assembled in response to a request\nfrom the Chinese Ministry of Health to investigate possible links between\nthe current SARS outbreak, which began in Asia in mid-February 2003, and an\noutbreak of atypical pneumonia which began in Guangdong Province in China\nin mid-November 2002.\nThe WHO team, which includes experts from 5 countries, will review\navailable epidemiological and laboratory data on cases in the southern\nChina outbreak. It will also propose what additional investigations should\nbe carried out, and which additional reagents, antibodies, tests, equipment\nand expertise might be required to continue the laboratory and virological\nwork. This additional expertise and equipment is expected to bolster\nefforts to trace the source of atypical pneumonia in Guangdong Province.\nConcern over international spread\nThe first concern WHO has regarding travel is the possibility that the\ndisease will spread rapidly and become established in many countries around\nthe world. The extent to which this is happening is being monitored by\nheightened surveillance for SARS symptoms around the world and rapid\nreporting of suspected cases.\nThe worldwide awareness of the disease has been demonstrated by the number\nof countries reporting to WHO. Recommended isolation procedures appear to\nbe working. Since these measures were introduced, no onward transmission of\nthe disease, beyond those initially identified, has been reported.\nIn these circumstances, where the rapid identification and isolation of\ncases appears to be containing international spread, WHO does not consider\nthat any additional restrictions on travel or trade are required.\nConcerns over travel to affected areas\nAs countries around the world have increased surveillance activities they\nhave discovered a small number of cases in persons who have traveled to the\naffected areas. The small number of such cases, at present, is an\nindication that SARS poses little risk to travelers visiting the affected\nareas.\nBased on available information, WHO does not consider that the small health\nrisk attributable to SARS significantly increases the health risk\nassociated with travel to any destination. WHO therefore maintains its\nadvice that no SARS-related restrictions on travel to any destination are\nnecessary.\nWHO is aware that a number of countries have advised their nationals to\nconsider postponing unnecessary or elective travel to the areas where local\ntransmission of the disease has been demonstrated. Such advice does not\namount to a restriction of travel, and is the responsibility of the\nconcerned national authorities.\nConcern about air travel\nThe public is also concerned about the safety of air travel. Cases that\nhave been identified in countries outside the initially affected areas have\narrived by air transport.\nIt is important to note that there is no evidence to date to indicate that\nthe disease is transmitted during air travel, or that travelling in an\naeroplane with an infected person has resulted in illness to other\npassengers or crew. In case of concern that passengers have been exposed to\nan infected person during a flight, a protocol exists for the follow up of\npassengers and crew. When an airline wishes to disinfect an aeroplane after\ncarrying a suspected SARS case there is good reason to believe that the\nprocedures described in the WHO Guide to Hygiene and Sanitation in Aviation\nwill be fully effective.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Of interest is the mention that the etiologic agent could be a member of\neither the paramyxovirus family or the coronavirus family, 2 very distinct\nviral families. We await further clarification and testing of the\nhypotheses as to the etiology of SARS.\nAs mentioned in this update, transmission to date still seems to be\nrestricted to close contact of cases and not to general spread within the\ncommunity. It is noteworthy that with the implementation of appropriate\ninfection control procedures, transmission in the health care setting has\nbeen apparently interrupted. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n MPP]\n\n[3] Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) multi-country outbreak -\nUpdate 8 24 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_03_24B/en/>\n\nAdvice to travelers, situation update\nTravel advice\n The multinational team was assembled in response to a request\nfrom the Chinese Ministry of Health to investigate possible links between\nthe current SARS outbreak, which began in Asia in mid-February 2003, and an\noutbreak of atypical pneumonia which began in Guangdong Province in China\nin mid-November 2002.
