The 7 additional patients reported today comprise 3\nhospital staff and 4 close contacts of patients. 3 patients have been\ndischarged from hospital. The other 48 patients are still in hospital. All\nthe patients are stable except for 9 patients who are in a serious condition.\nTo date, apart from the 3 initial people who had travelled to Hong Kong, a\ntotal of 24 family, friends and those who had close contacts with the\ncases, and 24 hospital staff have been diagnosed with SARS. So far, all the\ncases of SARS have been linked to the initial 3 cases. No new index cases\nhave been reported. In addition, no further cases have occurred among\nhospital staff as a result of infection from known or suspected cases of\nSARS after the implementation of enhanced infection control precautions.\nAll suspected and probable cases, including pediatric cases, will be\nmanaged centrally at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and the Centre for\nCommunicable Diseases. This will facilitate the management of these\npatients and reduce the risk of secondary transmission of the disease.\nTo free up TTSH's resources to isolate and treat all SARS cases, TTSH will\nnot admit new patients for the next 2 weeks. As such, ambulance cases will\nbe diverted to other hospitals and the public is advised to seek accident\nand emergency care at other hospitals.\n\n******\n[3]\nDate: 23 Mar 2003 13:30 GMT\nFrom: ProMED-mail\nSource: Reuters UK [edited]\n<http://www.reuters.co.uk/newsPackageArticle.jhtml?type=topNews&storyID=242893>\n\nHONG KONG (Reuters): Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had\nisolated the virus, found it was new, and designed the first diagnostic\ntest, meaning patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) can be\nidentified, and therefore treated, much faster. On Sunday WHO praised the\nHong Kong's team's findings but sounded a note of caution. 'The race to\nidentify the SARS causative agent is by no means over. Although the virus\nhas now been isolated, its identity remains elusive,' the global body said.\nThe majority of cases are medical workers who have been in close contact\nwith patients or victims' family members. In Hong Kong health officials\nsaid 2 people who worked in the same office as a patient were infected at\nwork. [Other newswire reports have mentioned 3 cases among office workers.\nWe await official news from the Department of Health on these reports. -\nMod.MPP]\nAuthorities in the territory ordered all schools to be disinfected and\nvowed on Sunday to shut for a week any school with a child or staff member\nill with the disease. Education secretary Arthur Li told a news conference\nhe was ordering about 180 children with infected family members to stop\nattending classes for a week from Monday. Officials say 5 schools have\nalready been ordered shut.\nScientists in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Germany, and Canada identified viruses\ntaken from patients as paramyxoviruses, a large family of microbes that\nincludes germs that cause measles, mumps, and respiratory infections. WHO\nsaid other research groups in the network of collaborating labs were\nproducing hints the virus might belong to another family but also expressed\nhope of bringing the epidemic under control.\nThe University of Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had designed\nthe world's first SARS diagnostic test, which detects a patient's\nantibodies, which could confirm the diagnosis between 5 and 14 days after\ninfection. Hong Kong doctors have been treating patients with ribavirin --\nan anti-virus drug -- and corticosteroids. They say the regimen works for\nmost patients if treated early.\nHong Kong Hospital Authority director Ko Wing-man said on Sunday one more\npatient had died in Hong Kong, bringing the death toll in the city to 8.\nThe number of infections in Hong Kong rose to 247 on Sunday, including 242\nsuffering full-blown pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[An update on the overall worldwide number of cases officially reported was\nnot available at the time of preparation of this report. - Mod.MPP]", "summary": "As at 1pm today (23 Mar 2003), the admission statistics of patients who\nhave been in close contacts with atypical pneumonia patients are as\nfollows: (numbers in brackets are those with symptoms of pneumonia)\nA. The University of Hong Kong researchers said on Saturday they had designed\nthe world's first SARS diagnostic test, which detects a patient's\nantibodies, which could confirm the diagnosis between 5 and 14 days after\ninfection. WHO\nsaid other research groups in the network of collaborating labs were\nproducing hints the virus might belong to another family but also expressed\nhope of bringing the epidemic under control. Information on the identification of the\netiologic agent and development of specific diagnostic tests will be\ncovered separately as has been done by the issuing of separate 'stand\nalone' posts in the past week. \nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n To date, apart from the 3 initial people who had travelled to Hong Kong, a\ntotal of 24 family, friends and those who had close contacts with the\ncases, and 24 hospital staff have been diagnosed with SARS. In addition, no further cases have occurred among\nhospital staff as a result of infection from known or suspected cases of\nSARS after the implementation of enhanced infection control precautions. All suspected and probable cases, including pediatric cases, will be\nmanaged centrally at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and the Centre for\nCommunicable Diseases. Scientists in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Germany, and Canada identified viruses\ntaken from patients as paramyxoviruses, a large family of microbes that\nincludes germs that cause measles, mumps, and respiratory infections. Staff of Hospitals/Clinics\nStaff of Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH) admitted to:\nPrince of Wales Hospital 69 (69)\nPrince of Wales Hospital (Private doctors) 3 ( 3)\nKwong Wah Hospital 3 ( 3)\nPrincess Margaret Hospital (PMH) 4 ( 4)\nOne of the health workers was discharged\nTseung Kwan O Hospital (TKOH) 1 ( 1)\nQueen Mary Hospital (QMH) 1 ( 1)\nUnited Christian Hospital 1 ( 1)\nStaff of Kwong Wah Hospital (KWH) admitted to:\nKwong Wah Hospital 4 ( 4)\nOne of the health workers was discharged\nStaff of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital (PYNEH) admitted to:\nPamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital 7 ( 7)\nStaff of Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH) admitted to:\nQueen Elizabeth Hospital 6 ( 4)\nOne of the health care workers was discharged\nTseung Kwan O Hosptial 1 ( 1)\nStaff of a Private Clinic in Mong Kok admitted to:\nPrincess Margaret Hospital 4 ( 4)\n3 of the health care workers were discharged\nTuen Mun Hospital 1 ( 1)\nStaff of a private hospital on HK Island admitted to:\nPamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital 3 ( 3)\nStaff of a private hospital in Kowloon admitted to:\nPrincess Margaret Hospital 8 ( 8)\nPamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital 1 ( 1)\nTotal: 117 (115)\n6 of the health care workers were discharged\nB. Other Patients\nPatients, patient's family members & visitors PWH, PMH, PYNEH, QEH, TKOH,\nQMH, Tuen Mun Hospital, United Christian Hospital 156 (154)\n7 of the patients were discharged\nTotal Admission (A + B + C) 290 (286)\n14 were discharged\nIn addition, 10 patients with atypical pneumonia died recently in the\nfollowing public hospitals: Kwong Wah Hospital (2 patients); Princess\nMargaret Hospital (1 patient); Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital (1\npatient); Prince of Wales Hospital (6 patients).\n\nPart 2\n------\nDH keeps close watch on students' health 25 Mar 2003\nThe Department of Health (DH) on 25 Mar 2003 confirmed a new case of\natypical pneumonia involving a 6-year-old girl. The Consultant in-charge of\nDH's Disease Prevention and Control Unit, Dr Tse Lai-yin, said the girl is\na student of City One Anglo-Chinese Kindergarten in Sha Tin. She is among\nthe 286 persons confirmed today to have contracted atypical pneumonia. The\ngirl developed symptoms on 21 Mar 2003 and was admitted to Prince of Wales\nHospital today. Her condition is stable. Dr Tse said the girl had\nconsulted a private doctor on 14 Mar 2003. The doctor was confirmed to have\ncontracted atypical pneumonia earlier.\n'We are still looking for the source of infection. The health condition of\nthe girl's family members, classmates, and teachers are also under close\nsurveillance,' Dr Tse said. As a precaution against atypical pneumonia,\nthe kindergarten and City One Nursery, both of which shared the same\npremises, in consultation with DH and the Education and Manpower Bureau,\nhave decided to close from today to 31 Mar 2003 for disinfection and cleansing.\nDr Tse reminded teachers and parents to be cautious about the health\ncondition of their students and children and take every possible means to\nprevent infection.\nMeanwhile, the ninth floor of Metropole Hotel in Ho Man Tin has been\nre-opened. The ninth floor was closed for cleansing and disinfection on 19\nMar 2003 following reports that 8 people had contracted atypical pneumonia\nduring their stay or visit there. The environmental condition of the hotel\nis found to be satisfactory.\nTo enable members of the public to better understand the prevention of\natypical pneumonia, DH in conjunction with Home Affairs Department, will\nconduct a series of health talks at the community halls and community\ncentres in Sha Tin, Happy Valley, Yau Ma Tei, Tsuen Wan, and Tai Po from 26\nMar 2003 to 3 Apr 2003 in the morning and afternoon sessions. The talks\nwill be conducted in Cantonese. Members of the public who wish to attend\nare requested to call 2961 8673 during office hours for details and\nreservation.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore Ministry of Health [edited]\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5640>\n\nUpdate (12) on SARS cases in Singapore 25 Mar 2003\nAs at 25 Mar 2003, a total of 69 people with SARS have been reported to the\nMinistry of Health (MOH). The 4 additional patients reported today comprise\na hospital staff and 3 close contacts of patients. All these cases are\nstill traced back to the index cases. 13 patients have been discharged from\nhospital while the remaining 56 patients are hospitalised. All the patients\nare stable except for 11 patients who are in serious condition.\nWith the control measures instituted so far, including implementation of\nhome quarantine to isolate all contacts who have been diagnosed with SARS,\nthe Ministry of Health would like to assure the public that there is little\nrisk of a community spread. We would also like to emphasize that the\ndisease is not infectious until symptomatic. The home quarantine measures\nare additional safeguards to cut off any possible transmission to more\npeople. It enables contacts who may become symptomatic to be picked up\nearlier and limits the exposure of other people to symptomatic contacts. It\ndoes not mean that people under quarantine are infectious currently.\nTo date, there have been no additional children who have contracted SARS.\nThere had been reports circulating about a 2-year-old girl from the Little\nSkool House who had contracted pneumonia and high fever. This is not true.\nDoctors at KKH have confirmed that clinically, the girl does not have SARS.\nThe Ministry was notified of the death of a cancer patient at NUH who had\npreviously travelled to Hong Kong and who had developed pneumonia. The\ndeath has not been classified as a death from SARS because the patient did\nnot have the symptoms suggestive of SARS.\nHome Quarantine Measures\nThe Ministry would like to remind all persons served the quarantine order\nto stay at home for the period indicated in the letter to them. They should\nminimise contacts with other family friends or friends and to check their\ntemperature everyday. NEA officers will also be checking with these\ncontacts daily and conducting spot checks. If they develop symptoms\nsuggestive of the illness, they will be immediately referred to TTSH for\nfurther evaluation and treatment if necessary. If they do not develop any\nof the symptoms of SARS after 10 days, they are unlikely to contract SARS.\nThe public can call 1800-2254122 from 8.30am to 6.00 pm from Mon-Fri and\nSat from 8.30am to 1.30pm.\nThe Ministry is also asking all employers whose staff are affected by the\nhome quarantine measure to accept the letter from MOH to the contacts as\nvalid medical leave certificate from work. MOH would like to appeal to all\nemployers whose staff are quarantined to extend their understanding and\ncompassion to these people.\nTighter Screening Measures in school\nThe Ministry would also like to assure parents that the tighter screening\nmeasures in school are precautionary measures. Children who have come back\nfrom the affected countries and who have not shown any symptoms are not\ninfectious. This is based on the detailed analysis of all the SARS cases in\nSingapore so far.\nIt is not necessary to close all schools as the measures that have been put\nin place are adequate.\nTravel advisory\nThe public should continue to avoid travel to Hong Kong, Hanoi, and\nGuangdong province in China for the time being, unless absolutely\nnecessary. This would help us greatly in our efforts to contain the number\nof new cases.\nConcerned members of the public can call MOH hotline at tel: 1800-225-4122\nduring office hours.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS update [edited]\n<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome Report of Suspected Cases Under\nInvestigation in the United States\nThese data were reported to the World Health Organization 25 Mar 2003.\nState: Suspected cases under investigation*\n*Case definition <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>\nCalifornia: 10\nConnecticut: 1\nHawaii: 3\nIllinois: 1\nMaine: 1\nMassachusetts: 1\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nNew Jersey: 1\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 2\nNew York: 5\nPennsylvania: 1\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 3\nUtah: 1\nVirginia: 3\nTotal suspected cases under investigation: 40\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5]\nDate: 25 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Newswire briefs [edited]\n[A] Japan From: AFX News - Asia 24 Mar 2003 17:53\n2 more people in Japan have been identified as possible [cases of SARS],\nthe health ministry said yesterday. The latest findings bring the tally of\nsuspected cases of SARS in Japan to 4, health officials said.\n[B] Canada From: Canada.com / CP 25 Mar 2003\n<http://www.canada.com/health/story.html?id=C6B2F0C9-7FBB-40BC-AD97-EE8233A597BD>\nPublic health officials in Toronto moved for the first time to quarantine\npeople who have been in contact with a case of SARS and who are showing\nsome symptoms of the disease. Officials said about 25 people who appear\nsymptomatic, and their close family contacts have been ordered to stay home\nfor a period of 10 days. That is believed to be the outside limit of the\ninfectious period of the disease. Health Minister Tony Clement announced\nthat Ontario had moved to make SARS a reportable disease Tuesday, giving\npublic health officials the power to order people to remain in quarantine\nif necessary.\nThe number of probable cases of SARS in the province jumped to 18 from 10,\nwith 5 people remaining as suspect cases. Elsewhere in Canada, there is a\nprobable case in Vancouver and 2 suspected cases in Alberta. 3 people have\ndied.\nThe new cases are in health-care workers from Scarborough Grace Hospital,\nwhere a patient who later died of SARS was treated in mid-March 2003. A man\nwho shared an emergency department room with him also contracted the\ndisease and died last Friday. The health-care workers -- who include\nnurses, doctors, technicians, and paramedics -- treated the man before\nworldwide attention was drawn to the fact that a mysterious, contagious,\nand potentially fatal disease had spread from Southeast Asia. As such,\nthey were not taking the high level of care -- using special masks, gowns,\nand treating patients in isolation -- that is now being used for SARS\ncases. To date none of the staff in other Toronto hospitals caring for\nSARS patients have shown signs of the disease. 'We are taking steps to\ncontain the spread of SARS and to make sure people who have been exposed\nare safely isolated where they are cared for,' said Dr. Colin d'Cunha,\nchief medical officer for Ontario.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[In today's update there is an increase of 31 new cases reported to the WHO\nsince yesterday's report, of which the majority have occurred in Hong\nKong. worldwide (03): cases", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=275", "date": "2003-03-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "SARS - WORLDWIDE (03): CASES\n***************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn today's update:\n[1] Hong Kong - DOH\n[2] Singapore - MOH\n[3] USA - CDC\n[4] Canada - MOH\n[5] Newswire briefs\n[A] Viet Nam\n[B] Macau\n[C] Hong Kong SAR\n******\n[1]\nDate: 24 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Hong Kong - Department of Health 24 Mar 2003\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n\nPart I -- Latest admission figures <http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n---------------------\nThe following is jointly issued by the Department of Health and the\nHospital Authority:\nAs at 1 PM 24 Mar 2003, the admission statistics of patients who have been\nin close contacts with atypical pneumonia patients are as follow:\n(The numbers in bracket are those with Pneumonia Symptoms)\nA. Staff of Hospitals/Clinics\nStaff of Prince of Wales Hospital (PWH) admitted to:\nPrince of Wales Hospital 66 (62)\nPrince of Wales Hospital (Private doctors) 3 ( 3)\nKwong Wah Hospital 3 ( 3)\nPrincess Margaret Hospital (PMH) 4 ( 4)\nTseung Kwan O Hospital (TKOH) 1 ( 1)\nQueen Mary Hospital (QMH) 1 ( 1)\nStaff of Kwong Wah Hospital (KWH) admitted to:\nKwong Wah Hospital 4 ( 4)\nOne of the health care workers was discharged\nStaff of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital (PYNEH) admitted to:\nPamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital 7 ( 7)\nStaff of Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH) admitted to:\nQueen Elizabeth Hospital 5 ( 2)\nOne of the health care workers was discharged\nTseung Kwan O Hosptial 1 ( 1)\nStaff of a Private Clinic in Mong Kok admitted to:\nPrincess Margaret Hospital 4 ( 4)\n3 of the health care workers were discharged\nTuen Mun Hospital 1 ( 1)\nStaff of a private hospital on HK Island admitted to:\nPamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital 3 ( 3)\nStaff of a private hospital in Kowloon admitted to:\nPrincess Margaret Hospital 8 ( 8)\nPamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital 1 ( 1)\nTotal 112 (109)\n5 of the health care workers were discharged\nB. Medical Students\nMedical students Prince of Wales Hospital 17 (17)\nOne of the medical students was discharged\nC. Other Patients\nPatients, patient's family members & visitors PWH, PMH, PYNEH, QEH, TKOH,\nQMH, Tuen Mun Hospital, United Christian Hospital 136 (134)\n6 of the patients were discharged\nTotal Admission (A + B + C) 265 (260)\n12 were discharged\n10 patients with atypical pneumonia died recently in the following public\nhospitals: Kwong Wah Hospital (2 patients); Princess Margaret Hospital (1\npatient); Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital (1 patient); Prince of\nWales Hospital (6 patients).\nPart II - Students with atypical pneumonia under treatment\n<http://www.info.gov.hk/dh/new/index.htm>\n----------------------------------\nThe Department of Health (DH) on 24 Mar 2003 confirmed that 2 more\nstudents had contracted atypical pneumonia, this brings to 7 the total\nnumber of students infected with the disease.\nConsultant in-charge of the Disease Prevention and Control Division of DH,\nDr Tse Lai-yin said they are among the 260 persons confirmed today to have\ncontracted atypical pneumonia. The first case involved a 17-year-old girl\nwho is a student of Wa Ying College in Ho Man Tin. She has been feeling\nunwell since 10 Mar 2003 and took sick leave since 13 Mar 2003. She was\nadmitted to Princess Margaret Hospital (PMH) on 22 Mar 2003 for treatment.\nHer condition is stable. The second case involved a 13-year-old girl who is\na student of SKH Kei Tak Primary School (AM) in Wong Tai Sin. She has not\nattended school since 13 Mar 2003 and developed symptoms on 12 Mar 2003.\nShe was admitted to PMH on 22 Mar 2003. Her condition is stable.\nMeanwhile, DH is also investigating a suspected case in which a 7 year old\ngirl student, of SKH Kei Tak Primary School (PM) was found to have\ndeveloped atypical pneumonia symptoms 23 Mar 2003. She was admitted to\nKwong Wah Hospital today for observation.\nAs a precaution against atypical pneumonia, Wa Ying College and both the AM\nand PM sessions of SKH Kei Tak Primary School, in consultation with DH and\nthe Education and Manpower Bureau, have decided to close for 7 days until\n31 Mar 2003. Investigation is being conducted to ascertain if any of the\ngirls' close contacts have contracted atypical pneumonia.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[2]\nDate: 24 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Singapore - Ministry of Health 24 Mar 2003\n<http://app.moh.gov.sg/new/new02.asp?id=1&mid=5620>\n\nUpdate (11) on SARS cases in Singapore\n-------------------\nAs at 24 Mar 2003, a total of 65 people with SARS have been reported to the\nMinistry of Health (MOH). The 14 additional patients reported today\ncomprise 4 hospital staff and 10 close contacts of patients. Among the\nclose contacts are 3 siblings (two boys and one girl) aged 17, 13 and 5.\nFive patients have been discharged from hospital while the remaining 60\npatients are hospitalised. All the patients are stable except for 12\npatients who are in serious condition and being treated in the ICU.\nBased on the detailed analysis of the 65 cases so far, the evidence is that\nSARS is transmitted only when a patient develops the symptoms of the\nillness. The incubation period is usually 3-7 days but could be up to 10\ndays. Epidemiological tracking of the outbreak shows that the initial 3\nindex cases resulted in 21 primary contacts developing probable SARS. This\nlatter group of patients in turn have infected a further 41 cases of\nprobable SARS. While stringent infection control measures have been\ninstituted, their effect will only be apparent several days later, during\nwhich time we expect further increases in the numbers of SARS cases from\nsecondary and tertiary transmission.\nSince the implementation of the stringent control measures in hospitals,\nparticularly TTSH/CDC, no new health care workers have been infected. The\nnew cases of probable SARS involving healthcare workers are still traced\nback to the primary contacts.\nAt present, MOH/NEA officers trace contacts of cases and advise them to see\na doctor in TTSH/CDC immediately if they develop fever or symptoms\nsuggestive of SARS. In addition, the officers call the contacts every day\nto check on their condition. As a further step to reduce the possibility of\ntransmission from symptomatic contacts to others in the community, MOH will\nbe instituting home quarantine measures.\nHome Quarantine Measures\nMOH will be invoking the Infectious Diseases Act to isolate all contacts\nwho have been exposed to infected SARS patients. They will be required to\nstay at home for 10 days and to minimise contact with other people. Those\nwho do not heed the quarantine requirement are liable for prosecution under\nthe Act.\nDuring the home quarantine period, NEA officers will be checking with these\ncontacts daily. If they develop symptoms suggestive of the illness, they\nwill be immediately referred to CDC and TTSH for further evaluation and\ntreatment if necessary. If they do not develop any of the symptoms of SARs\nafter 10 days, they are unlikely to contract SARS.\nThere are presently more than 300 people on our contact tracing list who\nwill be quarantined at home. These are mainly family and friends who have\ncome into close contact with the SARS patients.\nMOH will make provisions for those who experience financial difficulties\narising from home quarantine.\nTighter Screening Measures in Schools\nThe 5-year-old boy is from the Pats School House in Lim Ah Pin Road. As a\nprecautionary measure, the Ministry of Health has asked Pats School House\nto close for 10 days.\nThe 13 year old girl, a student at Pei Cai Secondary School had limited\ncontact with her classmates during the school holidays. Although she was\nwell at that time when she was with her classmates, as a precautionary\nmeasure Pei Cai Secondary School has asked about 200 students who may have\ncome in contact with her to stay away from school for a week. The 17 year\nold boy did not attend school during the school holidays.\nWHO has not recommended closure of all schools as cases of transmission are\nstill confined to those who have been in close contact with infected persons.\nTo prevent any possible SARS outbreak in childcare centres, pre-schools and\nschools, the MOH, Ministry of Education, and Ministry of Community\nDevelopment and Sports have tightened screening measures in these places.\nAny child with fever will be asked not to attend school, even though they\nmay not have been in contact with infected persons or had not travelled to\nthe affected areas. Nurses from the Health Promotion Board will also help\nto detect unwell children in childcare centres and kindergartens for early\nmedical attention.\nThe Health Advisory to child care centres, kindergartens and schools is\nattached at Annex A.\nThe MOH would like to appeal to all parents whose children have been to\nHong Kong, Guangdong province in China or Hanoi to closely monitor their\nchildren. They should not be sent to school if they have fever and should\nbe seen by a doctor immediately.\nMore stringent infection control measures at hospitals\nTo fully protect visitors, MOH is heeding WHO advice to stop visitations\nfrom family and friends for all SARS patients. At all other hospitals,\npatients with fever which may or may not be SARS will be isolated until a\ndiagnosis is made. All discharges from TTSH from 10 Mar 2003 will also be\nadded to the contact tracing list for daily surveillance.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[3]\nDate: 24 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: CDC SARS update 24 Mar 2003\n<<http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/sars.htm >>\n\nSevere Acute Respiratory Syndrome Report of Suspected Cases Under\nInvestigation in the United States\n(These data were reported to the World Health Organization on March 24, 2003.)\nState: No. suspected cases under investigation*\nCalifornia: 10\nConnecticut: 1\nHawaii: 3\nIllinois: 1\nMaine: 1\nMassachusetts: 1\nMichigan: 2\nMissouri: 2\nMississippi: 1\nNew Jersey: 1\nNew Mexico: 1\nNorth Carolina: 2\nNew York: 5\nPennsylvania: 1\nRhode Island: 1\nTexas: 3\nUtah: 1\nVirginia: 2\nTotal Suspected Cases Under Investigation: 39\n*Case definition <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/casedefinition.htm>\n[As mentioned in the WHO update [1] above, the USA is reporting suspected\ncases under investigation, while other reports to WHO have been on probable\ncases. The CDC case definition description page states 'Suspect cases with\neither radiographic evidence of pneumonia or respiratory distress syndrome;\nor evidence of unexplained respiratory distress syndrome by autopsy are\ndesignated 'probable' cases by the WHO case definition.' - Mod.MPP]\n[Additional advisories related to travel can be found at the CDC SARS website:\nInterim Travel Advisory: Hong Kong, Guangdong Province, People's Republic\nof China, and Hanoi, Vietnam (Updated 23 Mar 2003, 10:00 PM EST; Released\n13 Mar 2003)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/travel/other/acute_resp_syn_multi.htm>\nWarden Notice: Guidance About Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome for\nAmericans Living Abroad 23 Mar 2003 10:00 PM\nEST <http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/warden_notice.htm>\nInterim Guidelines about Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) For\nAirline Flight Crew Members 23 Mar 2003\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/sars/flight_crew_guidelines.htm> 'As with all\ninfectious illnesses, the first line of defense is careful hand hygiene. As\na general rule, it is good practice to wash hands frequently with soap and\nwater; if no visible soil is present, alcohol-based hand rubs may be used\nas an alternative.\nIf you are concerned that a passenger traveling from Hong Kong and\nGuangdong Province, China; or Hanoi, Vietnam, may be seriously ill with a\nrespiratory illness, you should try to keep him or her separated from the\nother passengers as much as possible. You may provide a surgical mask, if\navailable, for the ill passenger to wear. A surgical mask can reduce the\nnumber of droplets coughed into the air. If a surgical mask is not\navailable, provide the passenger with tissues and ask him or her to cover\ntheir mouth and nose when coughing. CDC does not recommend the routine use\nof masks or other personal protective equipment, such as N95 respirators,\nfor the flight crew or healthy passengers. However, paying careful\nattention to handwashing after contact with the ill passenger is important.\nThe captain is required by law to report the illness to the nearest U.S.\nQuarantine Station. Quarantine officials will arrange for appropriate\nmedical assistance to be available when the airplane lands.'\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[4]\nDate: 24 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Health Canada SARS update 24 Mar 2003\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/english/protection/warnings/2003/2003_11update9.htm>\n\nUpdate #9 - Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 24 Mar 2003 7:00 PM\nAs of 24 Mar 2003, Health Canada has received reports of 11 individuals who\nhave become ill with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in Ontario\nand British Columbia. There have been 3 deaths in Canada. All Canadian\ncases have occurred in persons who have traveled to Asia or had contact\nwith SARS cases in the household or in a health-care setting. The details\nof the cases to date are as follows:\nOntario: 10 total cases. To date, all cases have occurred in close family\ncontacts of travelers returning from Hong Kong or in heath care workers who\nhave cared for these cases.\nBritish Columbia: one person has been hospitalized with SARS after\nreturning from travel in southeast Asia.\nAt this time, the cause of SARS remains unknown, however national and\ninternational laboratory testing and collaboration is ongoing. Here are the\nmost recent developments:\nHealth Canada has deployed 3 epidemiologists to assist Toronto Public\nHealth and the Ontario Ministry of Health with the investigation of SARS\ncases currently under investigation.The department has also provided draft\nguidelines for infection control and draft recommendations on actions for\npublic health settings.\nHealth Canada is ready to respond to any requests for support from\nprovinces and territories on the SARS issue.\nHealth Canada issued a revised Travel Advisory on 23 Mar 2003. The overall\nrisk for travellers appears to be low at this time. However, because of\nrecent increases in cases of SARS in the City of Hanoi, Vietnam; Hong Kong\nSAR; and Singapore and that transmission may not be limited to the hospital\nsetting, Health Canada advises that persons planning elective or\nnonessential travel to the City of Hanoi, Vietnam; Hong Kong SAR; and\nSingapore may wish to postpone their trips until further notice. For\nfurther information on this travel advisory, please see:\n\nScientists at Health Canada's National Microbiology Laboratory (NML) in\nWinnipeg are now able to report that they have found evidence of human\nmetapneumovirus (hMPV) in specimens from 6 of the 8 cases they are\nstudying. The metapneumovirus is part of paramyxoviridae family. These\nfindings are consistent with the results previously released by scientists\nin Germany and Hong Kong.\nThe findings of the NML are significant in that a common thread has been\nfound in a majority of cases in Canada. This is a promising step in the\nongoing investigation. Scientists will continue their work to try to verify\nthe findings and to determine if there are other factors involved that are\ninfluencing the severity of this outbreak. These findings will not likely\nalter the current treatment for SARS patients. For more information on\nhMPV, please see Health Canada's Qs & As:\n\nHealth Canada has initiated the following activities:\nHealth Canada is providing epidemiological expertise and laboratory support\nto provinces/territories and hospitals involved in managing the SARS cases.\nHealth Canada is chairing five Working Groups made up of\nfederal/provincial/territorial and public health officials, as well as\nother community-based experts dealing with such issues as infection\ncontrol, treatment guidelines and public health measures.\nHealth Canada is in daily contact with the provinces and territories, the\nWorld Health Organization (WHO) and the Centre for Disease Control (CDC).\nWe have expanded health alert card distribution at major airports in\nCanada. In addition to Pearson and Vancouver, these cards are available at\nall airports that receive international flights from all destinations other\nthan the United States.\nIn collaboration with the provinces, territories, and local health units,\nHealth Canada is leading enhanced surveillance activities for the\nrecognition of SARS cases.\nHealth Canada has also asked officials at the Pearson and Vancouver\nInternational Airports to carefully monitor passengers arriving from Hong\nKong and Singapore to see if anyone has flu-like symptoms.\nHealth Canada has sent staff to Pearson and Vancouver International\nAirports to support airport staff. Health professionals have been sent to\neach airport to help monitor passengers arriving on direct flights from\nHong Kong and Singapore for flu-like symptoms and to assist those who\nappear to be ill.\nThey have started distributing Health Alert Notices to all passengers\narriving in or returning from Hong Kong and Singapore which will ask\npassengers to see a physician if they begin to have any symptoms related to\nSARS. These symptoms include a fever over 38.0 degrees Celsius AND one or\nmore of the following respiratory symptoms: cough, shortness of breath or\ndifficulty breathing.\nHealth Canada's Workplace Health and Public Safety Programme is providing\nadvice to federal employers on occupational health and safety matters.\nHealth professionals from Health Canada's Workplace Health and Public\nSafety Programme were on site at the Pearson and Vancouver airports to\nprovide information sessions for federal employees. They are available, at\nthe employer's request, to provide sessions for federal employees at all\nairports that receive international flights from all destinations other\nthan the United States. The Workplace Health and Safety Programme has\nissued an advisory and has spoken to or met with representatives of a\nnumber of federal departments to provide them with information and advice\nthey can use in determining what health and safety measures they deem\nappropriate for their employees. It is Health Canada's position that\nGovernment of Canada workers are not considered to be at high risk of\ninfection because of the limited contact with and proximity to the\nindividuals. Therefore, Health Canada advises that the use of masks is not\nnecessary. Health Canada continues to provide employer departments with the\nmost current information and advice available on SARS.\nThe information contained in this update is based on the best available\ninformation Health Canada has at this time.\nFor additional information on SARS, please contact Health Canada's\ninformation line at: 1-800-454-8302.\nFor information on previous travel advisories to South East Asia issued by\nHealth Canada and the World Health Organization, please see the following\nlinks:\nWorld Health Organization issues emergency travel advisory (15 Mar 2003\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/releases/2003/pr23/en/>)\nHealth Canada Travel Advisory (23 Mar 2003\n<http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/pphb-dgspsp/tmp-pmv/2003/sars0323_e.html>)\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n******\n[5]\nDate: 24 Mar 2003\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Newswire briefs\n[A] Vietnam from Reuters 24 Mar 2003\n11:29 <http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/HAN42827>\nDoctors at the Vietnam-France Hospital, where the outbreak in Vietnam's\ncapital began, said a 43-year-old Vietnamese nurse who worked at the\nfacility and who was one of three patients there in critical condition,\ndied on Monday afternoon.\n[She is the third death reported from VietNam, the other 2 were a nurse and\na physician].
